In addition, when you received the legislators some time ago, you talked about adding another vice president to the Legislative Yuan and another vice premier to the Executive Yuan by revising the constitution. Will you ask for the support from all sectors in order to achieve this goal?

A: According to my understanding, it shouldn't be long before the composition of the inter-party committee will be decided. Naturally, there have been some difficulties, for which there are active remedial measures. In fact, the goal of the inter-party committee is quite clear. That is, we hope its members will reach a minimum consensus or common denominator on the cross-strait policy between the ruling and the opposition parties and among different parties. Thus, we can consolidate the strength of the people on Taiwan to negotiate with the Chinese mainland for the best interests of the people and the country.

Despite resistance, reservation, or even disdain for the committee, I believe its operations in the future will not be affected. In fact, the original plan did not require political parties to formally designate representatives. However, later some people suggested that political parties dispatch members to participate in the inter-party committee. In such a difficult position, Dr. Lee Yuan-tseh, as the convener of the committee, took great pains, with the determination to do things for the country, the people on Taiwan, and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and his efforts should not be questioned. People should not resisted or refuse to cooperate with Dr. Lee, because of their personal prejudices.

I just mentioned that it is not time for constitutional reform. Perhaps conditions are not mature enough. However, I have no special opinions on the content and subject of the reform. I just want to point out that two years ago, I also suggested adding another vice premier to the Executive Yuan and one more vice president to the Legislative Yuan. Our considerations were very clear. We all know that the Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, and many large counties have two deputy mayors or two deputy county chiefs. As the highest administrative organ of the country, the Executive Yuan has only one vice premier. Perhaps the workload of former Vice Premier Yu was too heavy. He told me recently that he has to work very hard, because there was only one vice premier.

Since the Vice Premier is not able to handle so many economic and trade matters, the Premier usually asks the Secretary-General to handle them. Yet, the related executive departments seem to have some opinions about this arrangement, therefore discouraging heads of the executive departments from attending meetings personally. (more) ZCZC CEP032 08-01-00 PRESS CONFERENCE (XIII)
Q8: Does the new administration have any new plans regarding reentry into the UN or will it instead seek to apply for initial admission as a sovereign state?

A: The ROC on Taiwan sincerely desires the opportunity to fulfill its duties as a member of the international community. As such, it is only natural that we hope to play a more active role in international organizations, including the UN. Whether they are governmental or non-governmental organizations, we hope to work through such groups to contribute even more to the international community. In my May 20 inaugural speech, I particularly mentioned that we hope to use humanitarian assistance programs, economic cooperation, and cultural exchanges to increase our participation in international organizations. The UN is just one of these organizations, however, and it is definitely not the only one.

As the new administration has only been in office since May 20, we have had a very limited amount of time to prepare for the UN General Assembly meeting in September. Thus, although a team has been continuously examining the situation and seeking methods, based on the existing foundations, to regain the ROC's entry into this world body, we do not expect to make any significant breakthroughs in such a short span of time. I truly realize the people's concern regarding this issue. Many public opinion polls have shown that most people on Taiwan support our reentry or admission into the UN. It is what the people want. However, we must understand that there are many obstacles before us, and it will not be an easy task to accomplish.

I am certainly not saying that we should quit because of these obstacles or because the path will be difficult. On the contrary, the most important thing is not to give up. I reiterate that Taiwan must "stand up" and "reach out" to attain its goal. Not only do we want to see the rest of the world, but we also want the world to see the ROC and Taiwan. Thus, we will not forsake our goal of reentering the UN; instead, we will work harder and more vigorously. Hopefully, our compatriots will grant us their consent on this issue by giving the new administration the complete support that it needs. Thank you!

Q9: You just mentioned the special group to investigate the murder of navy Captain Yin Ching-feng. Is the special group placed under the Office of the President? Is Prosecutor General Lu Jen-fa directly responsible to you? Will this become an established practice in dealing with serious criminal cases in the future? Will the case of Chen Wen-cheng's death and the murder of the Lin families have similar action?

A: I did not say that the special group belonged to the Office of the President, neither could it be. The whole investigation should belong and return to the judicial system. We just ask Prosecutor General Lu Jen-fa of the Supreme Court to be the convener of the special group. Because the case involves many agencies, including the military and police, we think the special group will experience some difficulties in investigation if it is not upgraded to a higher level. Therefore, as a result of prior communication and coordination, we deem it appropriate to establish a special investigation group led by Prosecutor General Lu Jen-fa. I do not want any misunderstanding. We respect the judicial system. We will do our best to investigate the case as long as it is necessary. In other words, if we make any breakthrough in investigating previous criminal cases, we will let you know. Thank you. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESS CONFERENCE (XIV)

TEXT.P: Q10: Mr. President, the Tang cabinet might become incapable of implementing major policies, if the opposition parties reject the government budget for next fiscal year. If the Democratic Progressive Party fails to obtain a majority of the seats in the legislative election next year, would it be possible to form a coalition cabinet under such circumstances?

A: We have reiterated that the coalition cabinet is not an option so far. Premier Tang has also made this point very clear in the Legislative Yuan several times. It is obvious that our government for all people is not contrary to multi-party politics. We formed the government for all people on the basis of multi-party politics. The government for all people does not equal the cabinet for all people. Instead, it means that the general public are shareholders of the nation company. The president of the nation company was elected by the people, and then the premier CEO was appointed by the president. Forming a government for all people means recruiting capable individuals to serve in the government regardless of party affiliation, geographic identity and gender.

Therefore, the government for all people is supervised by the general public and the legislature. The Democratic Progressive Party is the ruling party now, but it is a minority party in the Legislative Yuan, with less than one-third of the seats. However, it does not mean that we must form a coalition cabinet. Obviously, the congress supervises the government and the policy of executive departments. It is no wonder that boycotts and resistance from the opposition parties, which are often seen in democratic countries, sometimes occur.

Some people believe that they should bring down the cabinet if they disagree with the new administration and the new cabinet, while others think that refusing to participate in the cabinet will be sufficient. We hope to strengthen the interaction and communication between the ruling party and opposition parties in the future, especially on the issue of cross-strait relations.

I personally believe that our legislators will consider the interests of the nation and the general public when reviewing the government budget. I will put the interest of the nation and the general public above party and personal interests. I believe that we will act positively towards criticism and budget cutting. We will never let the review of the government budget interfere with the development of the nation, especially the prosperity of economy, the welfare of the people, and the security of the nation.

This is not to say that by returning the government budget the legislators can overturn the cabinet. The current constitutional structure and laws have certain mechanisms to overcome such difficulties. Therefore, even if the government budget is returned, a coalition cabinet is still impossible. Our citizens are not fools, and the indirect checks and balances from the general public still exist. Our fellow countrymen supervise and check both the new administration and the legislature. We hope the cabinet and the Legislative Yuan can work together in the future. Thank you.

Q11: Taiwan Power Company recently announced that it would continue to cooperate with North Korea to establish facilities for handling low-level nuclear waste. The previous government regarded such a plan as a usual commercial transaction. I am not sure whether the new government sees it in a new way or perhaps has a new approach. If you do not call off plans for the fourth nuclear power plant, will you take a more vigorous approach?

A: This question is closely related to whether we will continue with the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant and also to the final disposal of nuclear waste from the power plants. I am sure that everyone knows we do not have the best solution for disposing nuclear waste. In other words, no country in this world has a truly perfect and safe way for the final disposal of nuclear waste. This is the crucial reason why so many people are opposed to the fourth nuclear power plant and its continued construction. Ironically, while the fourth nuclear power plant is under construction, however, we still do not have a truly effective and safe way to dispose of nuclear waste from our existing power plants. We find this incredible. Whether the fourth nuclear power plant will continue to be built is under evaluation. The Ministry of Economic Affairs hopes to reach a decision in four months' time. And we would not want too much interference by my remarks. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESS CONFERENCE (XVI)

TEXT.P: Even former Vice Premier Yu felt a need to add another vice premier post to the Executive Yuan. It would be helpful to the Premier. The Legislative Yuan is in the same situation. Korea has two parliamentary speakers. One of them is from the largest opposition party. In fact, the consideration of slowly cultivating parliament leaders has its merit. Just like the present executive departments, which have experienced unprecedented party change.

Who can guarantee which party will one day become the majority in our parliament or our Legislative Yuan. It is difficult to predict. Therefore, we should consider it as it stands. Perhaps we should consider adding another vice president post to the Legislative Yuan. Many people think about this. I just raise it and ask for your advice. I have no specific prejudice. I mean we all should put considerations to constitutional reform. I have no prejudice against subjects for discussion on constitutional reform. I am willing to listen to you all.

Q13: Mr. President, questions about domestic and foreign affairs and the cross-strait relationship have already been raised, so I want to ask about problems occurring within the Office of the President, that is, your communication with the Vice President. The Vice President has criticized your attitude in handling the Pachang River incident, and you made a response accordingly when receiving foreign guests the next day. Don't you think that the broadcast dialog between the president and the vice president of the country represents a problem in communication? Or, do you think a more serious style of communication should be taken to ensure clarification?

A: Not long ago I noticed that a member from the media interviewed the president of Latvia, who is a woman. At the end of the article, a similar question was asked: "As a woman president, what do you think is the greatest obstacle in politics?" The Latvian president answered that the question was in fact a matter of personality and not a matter of gender. Unless everyone has forgotten, at my June 20 presidential press conference, I also addressed this same question. I made it clear that even though I am quite clear on the issues between us, it is a matter of personality rather than gender. Personality needs some time for adjustment. I am a patient person, and I am willing to coordinate and make some adjustments.

Everybody has extremely high expectations and demands of the Vice President, and she also has very high expectations of herself. We are willing to provide her with opportunities and occasions to show her ability. But the functions we have are determined according to the constitutional system. As a matter of fact, in many cases we have already overcome past areas of ambiguity, and even some taboos. For example, in the second military affairs meeting that will be held this afternoon, I have, just as in the first meeting, broken precedent by taking the initiative in personally inviting the Vice President to join me at the meeting. Therefore, in the present and in the future, there are many occasions where I will need to ask for the Vice President's support. Gradually, people will understand that the Vice President can play an even more active role in handling many government affairs, and she can do it very well. I would like to ask everyone to do as I have, by patiently encouraging, and supporting Vice President Lu. Thank you.

Q14: Mr. President, based on your previous statement, I believe that everyone can clearly perceive your goodwill and sincerity -- whether it is with respect to improving finance and economics or cross-strait relations. However, although we can sense your goodwill and sincerity, you have yet to give us a clear idea about what your specific policies are since taking office. Specifically, what is your actual position for Taiwan in cross-strait relations? During the presidential campaign when former President Lee Teng-hui stated his policy on the two sides was based on "special state-to-state relations," you firmly insisted on Taiwan's independent sovereignty. Has your stance on this changed any since then? Thank you. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESS CONFERENCE (XVII)

TEXT.P: A: I already outlined my cross-strait policy in my May 20 inaugural address, and I expounded upon it during my June 20 press conference. To this day, there still have not been any changes or advancements made with respect to cross-strait policy. To refresh everyone's memories, I clearly stated that: First, we will definitely maintain our nation's sovereignty, dignity, and security while seeking the greatest welfare for the people; and second, we feel that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should respect the people's freedom of choice. I never used the term plebiscite, nor did I use the term of right of resident self-determination. Again, what I stressed was respecting the people's freedom of choice. In other words, regarding Taiwan's future, only the 23 million people on Taiwan have the right to make that final choice and decision. This point is completely consistent with the remarks made by US President Clinton that any resolution of cross-strait relations must have the consent of the people on Taiwan.

I have continuously stated that we hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can improve their relations and deal with the future question of "one China" according to the principles of peace, democracy, and parity. The resolution of cross-strait relations is the unavoidable responsibility of the leaders on both sides, and my words on this matter have already been made extremely clear. However, it is impossible for me to tell you choices in a multiple-choice question or which is right in a true-or-false problem each time immediately after I am given the test paper.

I only hope that everyone can understand my sincerity, goodwill, and sense of responsibility. Indeed, our current cross-strait policy has not only met with the approval of the majority of the people on Taiwan, but is also acceptable to both the ruling and opposition parties. Thank you.

Q15: Everyone is concerned about the president's trip abroad next month. In a company, whenever the president leaves on business, the question on everyone's mind is always: who will be left in charge, the vice president or the general manager? With respect to future and past policies, can you clearly expound upon the responsibilities that will be given to the vice president while you are away? Will she be given more power to deal with domestic affairs during your absence?

A: The president will still exist; he won't simply disappear just because he is abroad. As the president and commander-in-chief of the armed forces of the Republic of China, the powers that I hold will not be affected in the slightest by an overseas trip. Indeed, considering how developed connections and communications are in today's world, there are absolutely no obstacles that could hinder me from carrying out my duties in governing domestic affairs while outside of Taiwan. Similarly, whenever US President Clinton is outside of the United States, he is still the president of the United States no matter where he goes. There is no problem of finding an "acting president." The same is true for former President Lee Teng-hui -- wherever he went or whatever countries he visited, he was always the president of the Republic of China, and his powers as president and as commander-in-chief of the armed forces remained perfectly intact.

My visit abroad next month has already been carefully planned and coordinated by the national security and foreign affairs department to the best of their ability, and the "command post exercises" ensuring our country's security have already been carried out by the Ministry of National Defense. Thus, everyone feels that the timing is right, and I am confident of embarking on my first "friendly journey for democratic diplomacy" next month. I hope the trip can gain the support of the people and the affirmation of both the ruling and opposition parties. While on my trip, if you should have any further questions, please feel free to offer them to me at anytime. I promise to do my best to take your suggestions into consideration. Thank you again, and I invite all of you to take the trip with me next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ASKED TO GRANT ZHONG GONG FOUNDER POLITICAL ASYLUM

TEXT.P: Zhong Gong, a spiritual sect similar to Falun Gong in China, has asked the US government to grant its founder Zhang Hongbao political asylum.

Zhang was preliminarily granted political asylum status by US immigration authorities in Guam on June 13, but the confirmation of the status for him has been delayed because China has asked the US to deny him the status.
US authorities in Guam said in a recent immigration hearing that the Chinese embassy has alleged in a letter that Zhang fled China illegally and that he is a suspect in a criminal case.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Tuesday that the Zhong Gong organization, which is said having an estimated membership of 38 million in China, has sent an open letter to President Bill Clinton, requesting the US government to grant him political asylum.
The organization said that Zhang did not commit any crime in China and that the Chinese embassy made the allegation in order to undermine his application for political asylum in the US.
The Chinese government has arrested at least 600 leaders and closed 3,000 training bases of Zhong Gong since it began to crack down on the organization in 1996, according to the letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSPECTS FLOODED AREAS IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei inspected on Tuesday areas of Kaoshiung County that have been hit by recent flooding. He urged the local governments and residents to cooperate with central government agencies in their efforts to carry out creek dredging and other reconstruction operations.
The premier also ordered reconstruction agencies to finish rebuilding structural supports under Kaomei Bridge by September, as scheduled. The damaged bridge connects Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties.

Tang arrived on Tuesday morning at the Moon World, a tourist attraction site, where he was briefed by Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien on the situation caused by the flooding in recent days.

In order to improve the drainage system in the Moon World area, bidding for the construction of dikes, dredging of Erjen Creek, and work to enlarge Teho Bridge have all been completed, Yu said. But he added that the local government has so far failed to assess and obtain the property that must be acquired for the work and related operations to go further.
Economics Minister Lin Yi-hsin, Vice Communications Minister He Chen-dan and Vice Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang accompanied Tang on his trip.
Later in the day, Tang also exchanged views with residents of Meilung Township about the construction of the controversial Meilung Reservoir.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF HOUSEHOLDS WITH CELL PHONE SUBSCRIPTIONS HITS 15 MILLION

TEXT.P: The number of households with cellular phone subscriptions reached 15,097,000 in Taiwan as of the end of June this year, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) on Tuesday.
This indicates that an average of 68 out of every 100 people in Taiwan is now carrying a cellular phone, the same figures show.

Cellular phone market penetration had surpassed that of fixed-line services in Taiwan in February this year, with 12,300,000 subscribers, or 55.7 percent of the island's total population, at the time, the DGBAS said.
The rise of wireless phones has seen the demise of pagers, as the number of households using pagers dropped to just 3,517,000 at the end of June, according to the statistics.

Meanwhile, Internet fever continues to spread across Taiwan, with the total number of Internet accounts reaching 3,923,000 as of the end of June, an increase of 82 percent compared with the previous year, according to the same figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP HEADS TO MEET

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will call on Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh as scheduled on Wednesday, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said on Tuesday.

Lin stressed that there will be no change in the planned Lien-Hsieh meeting, and expressed the hope that the meeting will help forge a mechanism of communication between different political parties as a way to help boost national security and social progress.
Lin made the remarks amid the news about the latest development that Hsieh will visit New Party chief Hau Lung-bin first, on Tuesday afternoon.

The Lien-Hsieh meeting will serve as a prelude to a much-anticipated roundtable meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and leaders of the major opposition parties amid the political, economic and social uncertainties that have plagued government operations since the DPP took over the administration on May 20.

Meanwhile, People First Party (PFP) Secretary-General John Chung lamented that there was no time to arrange a meeting between Hsieh and PFP Chairman James Soong earlier the same day, because he had been informed by the DPP side of the idea only on Monday night.

Regarding the many public calls that Soong should meet with Lien to exchange opinions on the current political situation and major issues of national concern, Chung said that there is no concrete plan for a Soong-Lien meeting at present.

Chung emphasized that as a responsible opposition party, the people's interests will take precedence over any issue for the PFP. The party will throw its backing behind any government policies as long as they are good for the people, he reiterated.

Meanwhile, Chung also announced that Soong, accompanied by ranking party officials, will leave for a European tour on Aug. 9. While there, the PFP chairman will take part in activities sponsored by local Chinese communities and give speeches to help garner international support for Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFSHORE KUEISHAN ISLAND FORMALLY OPENS TO TOURISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, northern Taiwan, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Kueishan Island off Taiwan's northeastern coast was partially opened to tourists on Tuesday after 24 years of military control.

More than 400 people, including 100-plus Kueishan Island residents, 160 tourists from various parts of Taiwan, 68 journalists and 70-plus government officials embarked on the maiden voyage from Ilan County's Wushih fishing port to the newly opened offshore island.

Mao Chi-kuo, vice minister of transportation and communications, and Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng jointly presided over a prayer service at Wushih in celebration of the opening of Kueishan Island for pleasure trips.

Speaking on the occasion, Mao said the lifting of the tourist ban is the result of many years of concerted efforts of the Ilan County Government and elected representatives at various levels, as well as the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of the Interior and several other government agencies.
"We appreciate their contributions and will make continued efforts to conserve Kueishan Island's beautiful natural scenery and wildlife," Mao pledged.
Led by Mao, a total of 10 boats left Wushih at 10:20 a.m. on the maiden voyage, with their sirens blaring and colorful balloons bobbing in the breeze.
When the visitors arrived at a newly completed mooring on the island, indigenous residents performed drum and gong dances to welcome their arrival.
Mao then officiated at an inaugural ceremony for a newly completed travel service center. Mao said the inauguration of the center ushered in a new era in the Ilan area's tourist industry.

Kueishan Island, a volcanic island formed 200,000 years ago, has an area of 2.9 square kilometers. It is rich in tourist resources, including strangely shaped steep cliffs, spas and wildlife. Pleasure trips to the island were banned after the military took control of the island in 1977.
As the island, which is said to resemble a turtle in shape, remains a special military-controlled area, only part of it will be opened to sightseeing tours, mainly the "tail" section.

Sightseeing visits will also be restricted to the period between March 1 and Oct. 31, and the number of daily arrivals should not exceed 250 for ecological conservation purposes. No overnight stays will be allowed and no food or water will be sold.

According to regulations set by the Northeast Coast National Scenic Area Administration (NCNSAA) under the Tourism Bureau, prospective visitors must apply for landing permits 15 days before their desired travel dates (each applicant can propose three dates). Application forms should be mailed to the NCNSAA's Tali office at No. 125, Shihcheng Road, Toucheng, Ilan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE ENVIRONMENTAL PUBLIC HAZARD REGISTERED EVERY 6 MINUTES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: One environmental public hazard was registered every 5.6 minutes in Taiwan last year, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
The EPA statistics show that there were a total of 93,555 complaints of environmental public hazards in Taiwan last year, with illegal trash dumping and excessive noise making up most of the cases.
Complaints of illegal dumping reached 32,135, the majority of which were cases of dumping trash and vehicles, as well as abandoning dogs, according to the statistics.
Complaints of excessive noise totaled 22,306 last year, with factory-generated noise pollution accounting for more than 30 percent of the total, the figures show.
EPA officials said that the public has become more concerned about environmental problems such as improper trash disposal and excessive noise.
Meanwhile, complaints of repulsive odors in the air have increased as high as 250 percent over the last 7 years.
The statistics also found that industrial pollution accounted for 25.6 percent of last year's complaints, followed by residential pollution, and commercial-sector pollution, in this order.
Taipei City was the location of most complaints of public hazards last year, accounting for more than 20 percent of all cases among cities in Taiwan, according to the same figures.

EPA officials urged the public to be on guard and actively inform the agency of any illegal pollution, adding that more evidence is helpful for prosecuting cases. Citizens can now use e-mail to inform the EPA of any environmental crimes, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAINAN MAYOR SENTENCED TO SIX-YEAR JAIL TERM
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Tainan Mayor Shih Chih-ming was sentenced on Monday to six years in jail by the High Court on a charge of corruption in a construction project.
Lin Chung-hsiung, former director of Tainan City Hall's Bureau of Public Works, was handed a five-year jail term in the same case.
Shih was convicted of illegally issuing a license for a sub-standard building to a well-known local constructor to permit him to apply for bank loans.
The sentence was reduced from an eight-year term imposed earlier by the Tainan District Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENT DROWNED IN OAKLAND, CALIF.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, July 31 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: An 18 year-old Taiwanese student drowned on Saturday at Holy Names College in Oakland, California.

Huang Rou-fei had joined an ELSI Language School-sponsored study-abroad trip to Oakland. She reportedly went swimming in the college swimming pool with her classmates at 6:30 p.m. Because the pool had already closed, no lifeguard was present to prevent the tragedy. This is the second incident in the past month in which a Taiwan student has died while studying abroad.

Huang's remains were sent to a hospital in Oakland. Hou Guang-chie, ELSI's director, left for Oakland on Tuesday. Although Holy Names College, Huang herself, and ELSI all are responsible for this accident, ELSI should take the most responsibility, said an Oakland Police Department representative.

Officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco began making arrangements as soon as they got the bad news, and asked the hospital to refrain from making an autopsy on Huang's remains until her parents arrive.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY'S COMBINED AMPHIBIOUS EXERCISE CANCELED DUE TO ADVERSE WEATHER
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, Eastern Taiwan, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: A combined amphibious exercise to put marines-in-training to the test has been canceled due to adverse sea conditions, according to the Republic of China Navy.

The exercise had originally been scheduled for Monday, and was then postponed to Tuesday. However, continuing rough seas on Tuesday forced the navy to cancel its Lienhsing No. 82 amphibious operations exercise.

A typhoon in the Northwest Pacific has brought heavy rainfall to nearby Taiwan since Friday. The Central Weather Bureau announced that the typhoon's southwestern airstream will continue to affect Taiwan until at least Thursday.
Lienhsing No. 82 was planned as a routine drill, the main objective of which was to test the combat readiness of the navy's marines before they complete their training at amphibious bases.
The army, navy, and air force would have also taken part in the exercise to test their combined operational ability.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE NABBED FOR ELECTROCUTING FISH IN KINMEN WATERS

TEXT.P: Four mainland Chinese were handed over to the Kinmen District Prosecutors' Office on Tuesday on charges of electrocuting fish near Kinmen and illegally entering Republic of China waters, sources from Kinmen Coastal Patrol Squad reported.

Kinmen coastal patrol forces discovered more than 30 mainland Chinese fishing boats converging on an inner channel between Kinmen Island and neighboring Liehyu Islet the previous day. After the mainland vessels dispersed later in the day, patrol officers found that four mainland men had landed near the inner channel and were poaching fish with electrification gear.
The four were then brought to a nearby police station for interrogation and their gear was confiscated.

According to Peng Ju, described as the leader of the four, mainland fishermen pay about 20 renminbi each to skippers who take them to Kinmen, located just 2.4 km off the mainland Chinese coast, where they go electro-fishing and then sell their catches on the spot to Kinmen residents.
The four mainlanders' daring deeds were considered only the tip of an iceberg of illegal transactions across the Taiwan Strait.

According to private business sector sources in Kinmen, mainland people have become increasingly active in recent months, sailing frequently to Kinmen where they conduct "small scale" trade with the locals.

This "small scale" trade activity is so easy and prevalent that some Kinmen-based travel agencies have even incorporated it into their tourist itineraries for visitors from Taiwan -- if the tourists are interested in taking a look at the illegal trade, the travel agency simply makes a phone call, and within half an hour, mainland fishing boats arrive at a predetermined spot where the tourists are not only entertained by watching the transactions, but can also make purchases of their own.
Over the past month, the Kinmen coastal patrol forces have confiscated over 8,000 kg of mainland-originating agricultural products, including wheat, rice and peanuts.
The Kinmen County government has decided to make the confiscated products into fertilizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR VISITS SWEDISH CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou paid a visit to the Stockholm city government on Monday, where he agreed with the municipal officials to promote bilateral exchanges in the future.

Stockholm Trade Development Bureau head Ulf Bergendal briefed Ma on life in the Scandinavian country, saying that 75 percent of all Swedish households own computers, which he said proves Sweden's international competitiveness in the information industry.

Hailing Stockholm's efforts to promote hi-tech know-how among its citizens, Ma said that Taipei should do the same and proposed dispatching students from Taipei to take part in research seminars here beginning next summer.
Ma also contended that improving the English ability of Taiwan residents holds the key to the city's efforts to develop itself into an international metropolis.

In addition to visiting a local water purification establishment, the Taipei mayor later also met with Carl Bildt, former Swedish prime minister and now a parliamentary member and the country's special envoy to the United Nations, who expressed "grave concern" for Taiwan.
Ma is currently on a European tour that has already taken him to London and Prague. He will proceed to the Finnish capital of Helsinki before flying back to Taipei later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONAL BECOMES 10 MILLIONTH TRAVELER TO MACAU

TEXT.P: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu on Tuesday became the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.

Huang and the nine travelers who came after him were welcomed with gifts and flowers upon arrival by officials of the Macau Tourism Department, representatives of Air Macau and Macau airport officials.

Macau International Airport opened in November, 1995, and airport statistics show that 84.8 percent of the 10 million passengers to pass through the facility have been from Taiwan. Because of this, Macau has been dubbed "Taiwan's domestic airport."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS CAN ENJOY 30-DAY VISA-FREE STAY IN MACAU

TEXT.P: Taiwan tourists can now enjoy 30-day visa-free stays in Macau, sources with the Macau tourist industry said on Tuesday.

The Macau Special Administrative Region (MSAR) government had already announced the loosening of limitations on travelers' entry into the former Portuguese enclave, but the measure did not originally extend to Taiwan.
Macau tourism officials said that the MSAR government changed its mind in view of the fact that Taiwan is an important source of tourism income for Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPEACHED MINISTER SAYS HE HAS `NO INTENTION' OF RESIGNING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Education Minister Ovid Tzeng, who was impeached by the Control Yuan on Monday, said on Tuesday that he has no intention of relinquishing his current post.
He told reporters that he respects the decision of the Control Yuan, but added that he would not resign because the country's educational reform should not be delayed or come to a standstill.
Tzeng was in Hsinchu to preside over a meeting of the national educational administration that was attended by chiefs of education bureaus from all the island's counties and cities.
He said that he will make a full explanation to the Judicial Yuan's Committee on Discipline of Public Functionaries if he is required to do so.

The Control Yuan decided 9-1 on Monday to impeach Tzeng for his failure to forsake his American citizenship, as required by law, when he took posts as dean of the College of Social Sciences under National Chung Cheng University and as vice president and president of National Yang Ming University from 1992 to May 2000.

The case came to light after Tzeng was appointed education minister last May. He then applied to renounce his American citizenship at the American Institute in Taiwan in June, and completed the procedure in mid-July.

Although the Nationality Law was revised in February of this year to allow holders of dual citizenship to serve as president of a national university, but Tzeng had broken the law before the revision was made.
Prior to the revision, high-level university officials were considered to be government-level officials and therefore prohibited from holding more than one passport.

People First Party Legislator Chin Hui-chu (Taipei City) said on Tuesday that Tzeng should step down because as a lawbreaker, he is not qualified to serve as a model for the country's educators and public servants.

Chin expressed her support for the Control Yuan's impeachment, and added that the Control Yuan should also investigate the dual citizenship issue among the senior presidential advisors and national policy advisors appointed by President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7 INDICTED FOR PACHANG CREEK TRAGEDY

TEXT.P: Seven people were indicted on Tuesday on charges of involuntary manslaughter or other offenses for the recent Pachang Creek tragedy which claimed four lives and ended the honeymoon for the country's two-month-old government.

The Chiayi District Prosecutor's Office said the seven people -- a private contractor, a foreman and five public functionaries -- should receive criminal penalties for the deaths of the four riverbed clean-up workers.

The indictment accused Chang Yung-hui, the contractor for the Pachang Creek clean-up project, of violating labor security and health management laws for forcing the workers to work in the creek on July 22 after the Central Weather Bureau had issued a warning of thunderstorms for that afternoon. Chang was also charged with involuntary manslaughter.

Kuo Ching-shen, the foreman overseeing the conduct of the riverbed project, was accused of involuntary manslaughter for allegedly failing to take any precautionary measures to protect the safety of the deceased workers.

Meanwhile, five duty officers with the Chiayi County Government fire department, the National Fire Administration's (NFA's) command center in Taipei and the Police Airborne Squadron's Taichung branch were charged with either involuntary manslaughter or criminal negligence of official duties and document forgery.
If convicted, all seven will face three-to-10-year prison sentences in line with Taiwan's current Criminal Code.

According to the indictment, Yo Ching-hung, a squadron leader with the Chiayi County Government fire department, and Chen Feng-jen, a member of Yo's team, were charged with involuntary manslaughter for failing to provide rescue ropes to the ill-fated workers.
NFA duty officers Hsu Ching-hui and Lu Wen-tsun were charged with criminal negligence of duty which resulted in a serious disaster.

Yang Tao-hung, the helicopter captain with the Police Airborne Squadron's Taichung branch, was charged with criminal negligence and document forgery for making a false report regarding the time the distress call was received.

Meanwhile, the Chiayi prosecutor's office asked military authorities to punish Chen Meng-hung, a duty officer with the Air Force's Seagull Rescue Center, in line with relevant military laws for alleged criminal negligence of duty due to a delay in reporting the distress call.

On July 22, people in Taiwan watched in horror and anxiety as live TV beamed the image of four hapless workers huddled together in the raging Pachang Creek in the southern county of Chiayi waiting for rescue helicopters until they finally lost their footing and were swallowed by the surging current.

For more than two hours, the three men and a woman waited for a helicopter rescue which was only a five-minute flight away, as the Air Force's Seagull Rescue Team is stationed nearby. However, the various authorities -- firefighters, police and military -- were unable to agree as to who was responsible for rescue, and the petty bureaucratic wrangling of low-level pen-pushers led directly to the death of all four people. Their deaths triggered a public uproar and shaved about 20 percentage points off President Chen Shui-bian's popularity ratings.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE INVESTMENT HELPS TAIWAN SECURITY: CBC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Chen Shih-mung, the new deputy governor of Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC), said on Tuesday that opening up to an "appropriate" amount of investment from mainland China would be helpful to Taiwan's security.

Chen, who took over his post just that day, said at an evening press conference that mainland investors would be more concerned with Taiwan's social stability and economic prosperity if it was tied in with their interests.

He added that while it would not be suitable to allow mainland communist central and state enterprises to invest in Taiwan, consideration could be given to allowing mainland local governments and individuals to investment here because they would be less likely to become tools of warfare or to disrupt Taiwan's financial system.

Regarding criticism of the government's financial and economic policies, Chen said that most officials know where the problems are, and added that he hopes Premier Tang Fei will exchange opinions and hold private discussions with senior government officials in charge of financial and economic affairs.

According to Yiou Ming-nan, deputy director-general of the CBC's foreign exchange department, Taiwan's policy-setting Mainland Affairs Council is looking into the feasibility of allowing mainland Chinese investments into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VICE PREMIER VOWS TO STRENGTHEN YUANS' INTERACTION

TEXT.P: Newly inaugurated Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung vowed on Tuesday to strengthen interaction between the Republic of China's legislature and its administration.
Chang succeeded Yu Shyi-kun, who resigned as a token of the government's responsibility for the Pachang Creek tragedy of July 22 in which four workers were washed away in a flash flood.

On his first day in office as vice premier, Chang, who was President Chen Shui-bian's secretary-general before being appointed to succeed Yu, said his top goal is to smooth relations between the Executive Yuan led by Premier Tang Fei and the Legislative Yuan, where the opposition Kuomintang remains in the majority.

Chang, who served as a legislator for six terms before becoming the president's top secretary, said the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan could use more dialogue and communications to dissolve discrepancies, most of which he described as unnecessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN VISITS NEW PARTY LEADER

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh paid a visit on Tuesday to New Party (NP) leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said was aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
However, political observers said the visit was an attempt to offset the fact that the New Party was not invited by President Chen Shui-bian to take part in a roundtable interparty meeting.

Chen recently called for party leaders from the ruling DPP and the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party to take part in a roundtable meeting for discussions conducive to the benefit and welfare of the people.

After the Hsieh-Hau meeting, the two party leaders convened a press conference where they said they had reached consensus on constitutional reform and measures on how to wipe out corruption and organized crime in the nation's politics.

Hau noted that the roundtable meeting is supposed to lead to a reconciliation among the three parties, which had serious conflicts in the presidential elections in March, and added that his tiny party could accept this.
However, he went on to say that it is a pity the party was not invited to participate in the roundtable meeting and pointed out that any constitutional amendments would require national consensus.
He also said the New Party should examine itself to find out why Chen did not invite it, and that it should make itself stronger.
Hsieh echoed Hau's opinion that Chen should let the New Party have a chance to express its opinion if he discusses constitutional amendments with the other political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CRIME RATE CLIMBS WHILE CRACKDOWN RATIO DROPS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's crime rate climbed in the first six months of this year, while the rate of police crackdowns on crime dropped, sources from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Tuesday.

DGBAS officials said the number of reported crime cases totaled roughly 196,000 in the first six months of 2000, equivalent to 844 reported cases for every 100,000 people, up 31 in number, or 4.4 percent, over the figure posted in the same period of last year.
Theft topped all the crimes in the six-month period, followed by drug abuse and trafficking, drunken driving, and violence, in that order, DGBAS officials noted.

The number of cases involving drunken driving and reckless driving under the influence of drugs increased the most, up 3.3-fold over the year-earlier period. DGBAS officials attributed the sharp increase to the formal inclusion into criminal records of such irregularities this year for the first time.
Meanwhile, DGBAS tallies show that the island's police posted a crime crackdown rate of only 62.6 percent in the six-month period, down 2.9 percent from the same period of the preceding year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN HOLDS DISASTER RELIEF EXERCISE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Eight central Taiwan counties and cities held the annual Wanan No. 23 disaster relief exercises on Tuesday to practice coordination of civil defense, transportation, telecommunications, and medical rescue.

This year's drills began in central Taiwan's Taichung, Miaoli, Nantou, Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi counties, as well as in the cities of Taichung and Chiayi. They will continue in northern, southern, and eastern Taiwan, and in the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen, and Matsu.

Chin Eng-ching, commanding general of the Armed Forces Reserves Command, said that Wanan No. 23 follows the rescue model imposed after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake and focuses on the operations of each county and city's coordination centers for civil defense mobilization in order to improve the public's ability to react.

Chin, who was in charge of overseeing the exercises, inspected evacuation drills at a local train station, the regrouping of commandeered disaster rescue vehicles, emergency repairs to transportation and telecommunications facilities, detoxification of contaminated water sources, and emergency medical rescues.

Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai noted that Taichung County experienced disaster rescue first-hand during last year's devastating earthquake and said that the establishment of a regular disaster-prevention system and the practice of disaster relief have already become essential missions at all levels of local government.
Liao urged the public to make comprehensive preparations and "treat peacetime exercises as if they were wartime."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE TO HAVE CHANCE OF EMIGRATING TO US BY LOTTERY

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan will soon have the opportunity for the first time to emigrate to the United States by lottery, according to a statement released on Tuesday by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

The statement said the US State Department announced the news a day earlier, and that Taiwan people interested in participating in the lottery for an immigration visa for 2002 should mail their application between Oct. 2 and Nov. 1 this year to the Kentucky Consular Center, Lexington, KY 41902 USA.
However, the statement warned that eligibility is limited to Taiwan residents actually born on the island, while Taiwan residents born in mainland China are excluded from taking part.
Additional information is available at the AIT website (www.ait.org.tw), according to the press release.
The lucky winners will still have to satisfy all American visa and immigration laws before they will be issued a visa, the AIT added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANEL CHARGED WITH PROBING NAVY SCANDAL GATHERS FOR FIRST TIME

TEXT.P: A panel established on the orders of President Chen Shui-bian to probe the death of a navy captain six years ago gathered for the first time on Tuesday.

The panel, led by State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa, consists of prosecutors from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), detectives from the Investigative Bureau under the Ministry of Justice and the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB), and the director of the Military Justice Bureau Maj. Gen. Liu Chin-an.

Lu said after the one-and-a-half-hour meeting that the probe into the death of Capt. Yin Ching-feng will be led by the CIB, which has been in charge of the case even since the crime's perpetration in 1993 -- despite the fact that it has made absolutely no headway in the investigation in all that time.

Meanwhile the Investigative Bureau will look into alleged irregularities in the navy's purchase of four minesweepers from Germany and six Lafayette-class frigates from France in the 1990s, which could led to Yin's murderer, as Yin was the executive director of the navy's weapons purchase program before his death.
The detectives from both the Investigative Bureau and the CIB will be subject to the supervision of MOJ prosecutors, said Lu.

Lu said the panel has received a promise from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to hand over all information related to Yin to the panel within one week. The MND also promised to produce any other documents in its possession needed by the panel.
In order to get to the bottom of the case, the panel is also empowered to interview military officers regardless of rank, said the national head of prosecutors.
The case opened in 1993 when Yin's body was found floating in northern Taiwan's Suao Harbor after he began collecting evidence of irregularities in the navy's weaponry purchase program.

Yin's death was first determined by the navy to be a suicide, but evidence came to light afterward suggesting that he had been murdered because of his knowledge of the irregularities in the navy's purchase of warships. No one has ever been arrested for Yin's murder.
Recent reports from Paris that US$500 million in kickbacks were paid to Taiwan in the deal for the six French frigates fueled speculation that the navy was conducting a large-scale cover-up.
In a related development, Yin's widow Lee Mei-kuei and Legislator Lee Ching-hua questioned the appropriateness of having Maj. Gen. Liu Chin-an on the panel.

Claiming that Liu himself had tried to cover up the case while investigating Yin's death as the head of navy legal department in 1994, they argued his inclusion in the panel will only undermine its credibility, given his previous fruitless probe.

Liu said he understood Lee's grief over the loss of her husband and her anguish over the military's failure to hunt down the murder or murders, but he claimed his participation in the panel will "definitely benefit the investigation."
The MND said on Tuesday that Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen had named Deputy Defense Minister Chen Pi-chao as the panel's MND contact and that he will cooperate fully in the investigation.

Vice Chief of the General Staff Gen. Wang Han-ning was appointed the panel's contact at the General Staff Headquarters, and Lt. Adm. Chang Chih-hua as the contact at Navy General Headquarters, said a spokesman for the MND.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MULLS IMPORTS OF SKILLED MAINLAND CHINESE TECHNOLOGISTS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is mulling the feasibility of importing skilled mainland Chinese hi-technology workers to develop the knowledge-based industry on Taiwan, a CEPD official said on Tuesday.

Under the draft proposal on the development of knowledge-based economy approved by the CEPD on Tuesday, the government should tap overseas skilled technologists, especial those from mainland China, to develop the island's economy.

The proposal also suggests that the government streamline its education system to facilitate the development of the knowledge-oriented industry by revamping the courses available at local schools to produce broadly educated people rather than people specialized in a single field.
After it has been approved by the Cabinet, the draft proposal will be passed on to related government agencies for implementation, according to the CEPD official.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Prosecutors indicted 7 businessmen and officials for river deaths.
The China Times:
The government will unveil a package of measures to stimulate the real estate market.
The United Daily News:
Premier Tang Fei will approve resignation of police and fire administration chiefs over the river tragedy.
The Liberty Times:
Seven indicted over river tragedy; police and fire administration chiefs to step down to take the blame.
The China Post:
Seven indicted over Pachang rescue fiasco.
The Taiwan News:
Prosecutor puts big blame on contractor over Pachang tragedy; rescue officials are among those charged.
The Taipei Times:
The US Republican Party platform supports Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 67.8 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 67.8 points to close at 7,916.85.
Market turnover amounted to NT$49.28 billion (US$1.59 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 2, or the third day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a 17-strong French fleet in the Mediterranean.
1849: Mohammed Ali Pasha, the Egyptian ruler, dies in Alexandria at the age of 80, a year after retiring from office.
1918: British, French, and US troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1932: Peter O'Toole, Irish actor, most famous for his role in "Lawrence of Arabia," for which he won an Oscar nomination, is born.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., US Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final allied summit of World War II, ends.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger, and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington D.C. opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the US Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1974: The Babe Ruth junior boy's all-star baseball team of Washington State arrives in Taipei for a goodwill visit.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France, and West Germany.
1980: A right-wing Italian terror group bombs the Bologna rail station in northern Italy, killing 84 people and injuring some 200 others.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of an illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-US trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of its capital, Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and architect of the Fifth Republic.
1997: Typhoon Victor injures 32 people in Hong Kong.
1999: Two trains collide head-on in eastern India, killing 226 people and injuring some 300 others.
1999: Republic of China Representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 67.8 points to close at 7,916.85.

After scoring a new low turnover record on Tuesday, the bourse opened at a high of 7,985.83 on Wednesday, but due to lack of confidence on the part of investors, share prices began to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 8,044.87 and 7,910.28 during trading.

A total of 1.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$49.28 billion (US$1.59 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.18 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$45.88 billion.

Half of the eight major categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 4.6 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.6 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.5 percent, electrical stocks at 1.4 percent, and cement shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 287 to 212, with 83 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM ACCEPTS RESIGNATIONS OF TWO ADMINISTRATORS

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei on Wednesday accepted the resignations of the chiefs of the police and the fire administrations over the Pachang Creek tragedy on July 22 in which four riverbed clean-up workers were washed away in a flash flood because of a bungled rescue effort.

Ting Yuan-chin, director-general of the National Police Administration (NPA), and Chen Hung-yi, director-general of the National Fire Administration (NFA), submitted their resignations soon after the river rescue fiasco. After about a week of consideration, Premier Tang accepted their resignation proposals.
Meanwhile, Tang also approved Ting and Chen's successors proposed by Interior Minister Chang Po-ya on Tuesday.

Wang Chin-wang, 53, currently director of the Taipei City Police Headquarters, will succeed Ting as NPA director-general. Wang, who has received more than 500 citations during his 27-year police career, was highly recommended for his integrity and ability.

Wang's being nominated as the new police administrator was considered natural as he had a good working relationship with Chen Shui-bian during Chen's tenure as the mayor of Taipei between 1994 and 1998.

Chao Kang, 55, holder of a master's degree in public administration from New York University, is currently a lecturer at Central Police University and Chaoyang University. Chao was formerly director-general of the Fire Department of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

Chao's nomination as Taiwan's top fire official was welcomed by former Taiwan provincial governor and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong as a wise decision, jointly made by the Presidential Office, Premier Tang Fei, and Interior Minister Chang Po-ya.
Chao had been a key campaigner for Soong during the 2000 presidential race, in which Soong lost to Chen Shui-bian by a narrow margin.

On July 22, people in Taiwan watched in horror and anxiety as live television cameras beamed images of the four hapless workers huddled together in the raging Pachang Creek in the southern county of Chiayi waiting for over two hours for rescue helicopters that never came until finally losing their footing and being swallowed up by the surging current.
Their deaths triggered a public uproar and shaved about 20 percentage points off President Chen Shui-bian's approval ratings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Wednesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved down 9 points to close at 7,983, with 3,654 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September decreased 53 points to finish at 7,985, with 48 contract transactions, while December futures fell 32 points to close at 8,050, with four contract transactions.
Next March futures plunged 190 points to finish at 8,055, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for next June futures.
