DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC RULING PARTY TO BOOST EXCHANGES WITH BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's new ruling party will not change its basic stance on Taiwan's independent sovereign status, but is willing to promote exchanges with mainland China in a flexible manner, a Japanese daily reported on Wednesday.
The Mainichi Shimbun said Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh has repeatedly emphasized the ROC's status as an independent sovereign state in a recent interview with the paper.
Nevertheless, the paper said, Hsieh has also expressed the DPP's willingness to forge ties with mainland China in a flexible attitude.

Hsieh was quoted as having told the Japanese paper that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can maintain good relations, the DPP will take active steps to boost exchanges with the mainland. "But if Beijing remains hostile toward Taiwan, the DPP may change its strategy and suspends its reconciliation efforts," he added.

Hsieh, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician, further said the DPP is likely to revise its pro-independence party platform if mainland China renounces its attempt to use force against Taiwan and the cross-strait atmosphere becomes increasingly peaceful.
Mainland China has ruled out any party-to-party contacts with the DPP unless the ROC's new ruling party scraps the pro-independence plank in its party charter.

Hsieh, who concurrently serves as mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city, said he personally favors increased cross-strait exchanges to enhance mutual understanding and foster rapprochement.
Hsieh criticized the new ROC government's disapproval of his plan to visit Xiamen, a southeastern mainland Chinese port city located opposite Taiwan.

"The disapproval reflects the government's conservative attitude toward breaking the current cross-strait impasse," Hsieh noted, adding that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should encourage city-to-city interchanges to help revive the long-stalled quasi-official cross-strait dialogue.

Hsieh said both Kaohsiung, also Taiwan's largest sea port, and Xiamen play a pivotal role in the existing direct cross-strait transshipping service. "Against this backdrop, the two cities should be allowed to engage in exchanges in various fields," he noted.

Touching on President Chen Shui-bian's recent criticism of opposition lawmakers' craze for visiting mainland China, Hsieh said he personally does not oppose such visits so long as Taiwan's legislators can maintain dignity in their engagement with mainland officials.

"It's not bad that Taiwan's elected representatives travel to the mainland and inform Beijing officials of Taiwan people's mainstream opinions and aspirations concerning cross-strait relations," Hsieh explained.
President Chen, also a DPP stalwart, has branded his administration as a "government for all people" and has pledged to put overall national interests above personal and partisan interests.

As the DPP's new chairman, Hsieh said he will hold regular consultations with Chen's administration. "But if the government's policy seriously contradicts the DPP platform, we'll firmly uphold our party platform," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO HOLD ECONOMIC CONFERENCE WITH FIVE LATIN ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is scheduled to hold an economic conference with five of its diplomatic allies in Central and South America on Aug. 27 in an effort to further bolster economic and trade ties with that part of the world, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said on Wednesday.

Vice ministerial-level economic and trade officials from Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Nicaragua, and the ROC are expected to get together in Guatemala City beginning Aug. 27 to explore the feasibility of further cementing trade, business, and investment exchanges between the ROC and its five diplomatic allies, Chen noted.

The six-nation economic conference, the first of its kind, will come on the heels of President Chen Shui-bian's state visits to Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, and Nicaragua between Aug. 13-25, Chen added.
The president's first overseas tour since his inauguration on May 20 will also take him to the African nations of Gambia, Burkina Faso, and Chad.

Major topics expected to be discussed during the conference include the signing of agreements on double-tax exemption, temporary admission of goods, simplification of entry visa processing procedures, and also how to strengthen bilateral economic and trade relations, as well as how Taiwan should further expand sales to Central and South America, said Chen.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs on Wednesday convened the first preparatory meeting for the cross-border conference with officials from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Council of Labor Affairs, and the Ministries of Finance, Foreign Affairs, and Transportation and Telecommunications.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CALLS FOR `SUBSTANTIVE CONTACTS' WITH ARATS

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of Taiwan's intermediary body with mainland China, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), called on Wednesday for "substantive contacts" between the SEF and its Beijing counterpart to help resume cross-strait dialogue.

SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said that only when negotiators from the SEF and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) return to the negotiating table will the cross-strait dialogue get back on track.

Shi suggested that the two quasi-official bodies begin with actual contacts and gradually proceed toward a resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, which was unilaterally suspended by Beijing last July when then-President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."
Shi made the remarks on the eve of the first board directors meeting of the SEF since the new ROC government was inaugurated on May 20.

During Thursday's meeting, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top appointed negotiator with mainland China, is expected to repeat Taipei's sincerity in its invitation to ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan for the second round of Koo-Wang talks since 1993 and to reiterate the consensus reached in 1992 by both sides on separate verbal interpretations of the "one China" principle, according to Shi.
Shi noted that without written confirmation of the 1992 consensus, both Beijing and Taipei have different interpretations as to exactly what consensus was reached.

He added that Beijing made "one China" its supreme direction principle so that militarily, it can impede Taiwan's purchase of defensive weapons and diplomatically, it can hamper Taiwan from participating in international activities and hinder overseas trips by Taiwan's head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAPPY TO SEE INTER-PARTY ENGAGEMENT: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is happy to see increased engagement among Taiwan's major political parties, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said on Wednesday.
Hsieh made the remarks after a weekly lunch meeting with Chen, who is also a DPP stalwart.
Hsieh had just ended a high-profile meeting with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan before his lunch meeting with the president.
"I briefed President Chen on my meeting with Lien," Hsieh said, adding that Chen was pleased to learn that the unprecedented DPP-KMT summit meeting "turned out to be a success."
Chen was quoted as having told Hsieh that he is convinced that constructive inter-party engagement can help promote inter-party harmony and is also conducive to domestic political development.

"President Chen also said he hopes that the Hsieh-Lien meeting will mark a start toward the establishment of a sound inter-party consultative mechanism to facilitate the formation of a national consensus on major national policy issues," Hsieh told reporters.
The new DPP chairman further said Chen does not think that traditional party politics contradicts his ideal of making his administration "a government for all people."

Hsieh said Chen has encouraged him not to confine his inter-party engagement to any specific party. "The president has encouraged me to arrange meetings with the leaders of other major opposition parties," he noted.

Meanwhile, Hsieh told Chen that he had come to terms with Lien on several technical details concerning the holding of a preparatory meeting for a Chen-proposed roundtable discussion with the top leaders of the ruling and opposition parties.

"Chen said he will appoint a deputy secretary-general to the president to contact the KMT and other major opposition parties and arrange a preparatory meeting to set the agenda and timing for the much-anticipated inter-party roundtable," said Hsieh.

Chen swept to power in the March 18 presidential election and his election victory marked an end to the KMT's 55-year political monopoly in Taiwan. The KMT, however, still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan's parliament. A lack of communications between the DPP and the KMT has hindered the operation of Chen's administration since it was inaugurated on May 20.

In addition to the inter-party interaction issue, Hsieh said he also exchanged views with the president on other major domestic problems, including the government's anti-black gold politics campaign to eradicate official corruption and gangster involvement in politics.

"Chen also reiterated his determination to probe the high-profile Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng murder case," Hsieh added, referring to the controversial case in which Yin's body was found in eastern Taiwan's Suao Harbor in 1993.

Yin had been in charge of the navy's weapons procurement program and had reportedly been on the point of blowing the whistle on a massive corruption and kickback scam involving the purchase program. No one has ever been indicted in the case, but a new panel set up on the order of Chen on Monday is hoping to shed more light on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC SET TO APPROVE TEST FOR BANNED SUBSTANCE EPO

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is set to approve the testing for the presence of the hormone erythropoietin (EPO) in atheletes competing at the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, according to organizers.

They told reporters that a team of IOC doctors and scientists is poised to approve testing for the presence of EPO following two days of intense scrutiny of the science underpinning two EPO test methods -- a urine test established by French scientists and a blood test created by Australian scientists.
It appears that the IOC is set to implement a test using both procedures in time for the Sydney Olympic Games in mid-September.

Sports experts said the two tests combined provide a solid and reliable test for EPO, but if applied singularly, may only give lawyers a very small chance to contest the validity of the tests in court.

"If the science can be shown to be flawed, then any athlete would be entitled to contest it just as they did in the early days with urine testing," said Brian Doyle, who represents the Australian and New Zealand Sports Law Association.
The IOC, which is facing pressure to present a clean Olympic Games and whose reputation hangs in the balance, has demanded an infallible test.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WOULD UNLIKELY STAND BY IF CHINA ATTACKED TAIWAN: US COMMANDER

TEXT.P: Beijing would have a difficult time if it attempted an invasion of Taiwan, and it is unlikely US forces would stand idly by if an unprovoked attack occurred, said Adm. Thomas B. Fargo, commander of the US Pacific Fleet.

Fargo told the Naval Submarine League annual conference held recently in Alexandria, Virginia that he envisions two possible courses in US relationships with Communist China. "We could develop closer economic ties, which is what we would like to see happen. The alternative would be a zero-sum game where what is to our advantage equates to their disadvantage and vice versa," he said.
Fargo is scheduled to visit mainland China this month, reported the magazine National Defense in its latest issue.

His plan is to treat Communist China the same way a shepherd treats his camel, he said. As the story goes, the shepherd goes to Mohammed asking whether tying up his camel means he has lost his faith in God. Mohammed's answer is, "trust in God, but you'd better tie up your camel too. I think that is how we need to treat China," said Fargo.

Fargo also believes there is a "growing recognition that our military interests are shifting to the Pacific." And top US priorities in the Pacific today include maintaining a balance of power that will preclude the rise of government-sponsored military buildups, and providing US military presence for regional security.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH SCIENTISTS FIND MEN ALSO HAVE BIOLOGICAL CLOCKS

TEXT.P: Men have biological clocks, and they start ticking once a man hits his 30s, according to a major British research study of 8,515 couples, reported The Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday.

The study confirmed for the first time that a man's age affects his ability to procreate. It also found the likelihood of a couple conceiving in the first 12 months of trying for a baby drop 3 percent for every year the male partner is over 24, reported the daily.

A report published by the journal Human Reproduction said the probability of it taking more than 12 months for a couple to conceive a baby is 8 percent for men aged under 25, but by the time men have reached the age of 35, that probability rises to 15 percent.

The daily quoted Dr. Chris Ford, the research leader, as saying that "the study tells us that to some degree that men as well as women have a biological clock that starts ticking as they get into their 30s."
"It also indicates that paternal age is another factor to be taken into account when doctors are looking at the prognosis for infertile couples," he said.
The British researchers from the University of Bristol and Brunel University analyzed data from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Pregnancy and Childhood to reach their findings, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE HOSTS GUESTS IN PHILADELPHIA
DOC.DATELINE: Philadelphia, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen on Tuesday hosted a party in honor of scores of US and foreign dignitaries attending the Republican nomination convention here, including a group of ROC lawmakers.

Addressing the occasion, Chen welcomed the presence of the 10-member ROC legislative delegation headed by Kuomintang Legislator Hung Yuh-chin and his counterparts from three other major political parties in Taiwan.

According to Chen, the ROC lawmakers were in Philadelphia to gain a better understanding of US democratic practices by taking part in activities sponsored by the Republican Party and also "to celebrate democracy, freedom and human rights with their American friends."

Senator Craig Thomas (R. Wyo.), head of the Senate Asian affairs committee, said he does not think that there will be any changes in Washington-Taipei-Beijing relations if Texas Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican Party's presidential nominee, is elected as the next US president in November.

Thomas said the United States will continue to maintain its existing policy toward Taiwan and to carry out bilateral cooperative ventures. While seeking to engage with Beijing, Washington insists that Taipei and Beijing should try to resolve their problems on their own, he added.

Representative Dana Rohrabacher (R. Cal.) told reporters from Taiwan that the first thing the new US government will handle when it is set up in January 2001, will be to decide whether Washington will provide adequate anti-missile equipment to Taiwan.

Stressing his strong belief that Bush will win the election, he said the Texas governor and son of former US President George Bush is more in favor of providing Taiwan with sufficient defensive weapons systems than the current Clinton administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAS LEAK CAUSES THOUSANDS TO BECOME ILL IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A chemical gas leak causing more than 1,000 people to become ill occurred on Tuesday night in Kaohsiung Harbor when chemical products were being unloaded by Lee Chang Yung Chemical Industry Corp.

Before noon on Wednesday, more than 1,000 residents in the Chichin District of Kaohsiung were admitted to hospitals with symptons such as nausea, dizziness, headache, and vomiting. Two of them in serious condition are still in hospital for further observations. The rest have already been released.

Lee Chang Yung Chemical Industry Corp. has admitted that the source of the leak was their chemical products. Although the company denied the leak has any connection to the illnesses of the residents, Kaohsiung City's Department of Environmental Protection has decided to fine Lee Chang Yung Chemical Industry Corp. NT$1 million.

The director of Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office, Shih Mao-lin, has assigned public prosecutor Liu Yun to take charge of the case. Due to the constant environmental pollution in Kaohsiung City, Shih on Wednsday indicated that public prosecutors will also be sent to district police offices to investigate environmental pollution cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.011 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 31.086.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 31.095 and was traded between 31.058 and 31.1.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$449 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN `LITTLE REPORTERS' TO VISIT MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: A group of 12 Taiwan children is scheduled to visit Mongolia from Aug. 5-12 to see for themselves winter storm disaster relief and rehabilitation work being implemented, sources from World Vision of Taiwan (WVT) reported on Wednesday.

Mongolia suffered its worst winter storms in four decades this year and the WVT has dispatched relief aid and maintained a center for homeless children in the capital, Ulan Bator, said WVT President Shao Ching-ming.

By organizing the "little reporters" visit to Mongolia, the WVT aims to allow Taiwan youths to appreciate the beauty of an entirely different culture and to experience in person the difficulties of Mongolian people who lead materially deprived lives, Shao said.
Also traveling to Mongolia with the youths will be young TV variety show hostess Liu Han-ya, who is WVT's ambassador for its "Bread of Love" fund-raising drive, according to Shao.

WVT began to organize "little reporters" visits 13 years ago to allow Taiwan children and youths to visit rural and backwater areas and bring love and care. At home, the children have visited Ilan, Pingtung and Hualien, while abroad they have visited Thailand.
The costs for the group's air tickets and hotel accommodation will all be footed by the children's parents, Shao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATCHERS OF PROTECTED INSECTS MAY FACE FIVE-YEAR JAIL TERMS

TEXT.P: People convicted of catching protected local insect species might face jail terms of up to five years and fines of up to NT$1 million, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Wednesday.

Officials from the COA's Wildlife Protection Task Force said 18 species of insects and arachnids, most of them indigenous to Taiwan, have been listed as protected species that must not be taken except for academic research and education purposes.
People caught capturing the protected insects will face jail terms from six months to five years and fines of between NT$200,000 and NT$1 million, the officials noted.

Illegal capture of other insects and arachnids which are not listed as protected will also be dealt with the country's wildlife protection codes, they added, with poachers facing fines ranging from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000.
Ignorant of government regulations, many Taiwan residents still use lights and nets to catch insects randomly, the officials said.

On July 14, a Japanese man surnamed Tanikado was detained by Chiang Kai-shek airport police for trying to smuggle out Taiwanese indigenous insects that were either protected or biologically invaluable, including an 8-cm Formosan giant stag beetle which reportedly has a street value of about 10 million yen in Japan, where they are prized as pets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR IN FINLAND TO LEARN FROM `VIRTUAL HELSINKI' PROJECT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou arrived in Finland on Tuesday to learn about the ongoing "Helsinki Arena 2000" virtual city project in the hope of building Taipei into a competitive "networked city."

Ma said on the last stop of a European tour that although Taiwan may have limited natural resources, it abounds in talented people. He added that information technology represents the best competitive edge for Taiwan in the future, and that Taipei has already been ranked as the most influential high technology center in the Asia Pacific region by a recent report in the US magazine Wired.

Ma listened to a briefing on how to integrate existing network communication tools to make "ubiquitous network communication" possible. He then proposed plans for exchange visits by high school students from Taipei and Helsinki so that each side could learn about the other's virtual city.

Risto Linturi, founder of Helsinki's virtual city project, described for Ma an interactive virtual replica of the city of Helsinki and envisioned permanent links between home and office that would allow users to control all kinds of appliances and equipment at any time.

Linturi, who last visited Taipei in June to speak at the 12th World Congress on Information Technology, added that his project would let a user "walk" to his next-door neighbor's house on the net and ring a virtual doorbell.

Mobile phones become remote controls for use around the house, and everything from opening the door, turning off the light, going shopping, and doing business at the bank can be done through the network, he said.

Some of Linturi's other virtual city ideas are electronic "heads up display" windshields that allow drivers to see a virtual road and virtual traffic signs and -- when everyone in Finland carries a mobile phone as will soon be the case -- streetlights that turn off automatically when there are no mobile phones nearby.
Finland has a 70 percent mobile phone penetration rate and is widely expected to be one of the first countries to reach 100 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPUTER APPLICATION SHOW KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The Taipei Computer Application Show began on Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC).
The show, the biggest in Taiwan's history, includes almost 500 firms and more than 1,700 stands in TWTC Exhibition halls one and two.
Despite rainy weather, many students arrived at the exhibition before the 10 a.m. opening, and the exhibiting companies used all their sales wiles and gimmicks to attract these young customers.

In recent years, with the rise of the Internet, domestic software and hardware firms have been trying to extend Taiwan's market. This year is no exception, and the exhibition has employed a legion of salesmen and part-time workers to explain and demonstrate the products on display.

The Taipei Computer Application Show is scheduled for five days and will wind up on Sunday. The opening hours in Hall 1 are from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., extended to 7 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday. Hall 2 is open from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Entry costs NT$200.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL FAMILIES CRITICIZE NEW FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: In the face of a new foreign labor policy planned by the government, local hirers complained on Wednesday that the planned measures will create problems for Taiwan families that need someone to take care of seriously ill family members.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the Employment and Vocational Training Administration (EVTA) under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), Lan Liang Hsiao-chuan, head of an association of local employers of foreign laborers, said that 80 percent of those families will no longer be able to hire foreign care givers if the "harsh" new restrictions are implemented.

Under the new measures, only those families with comatose family members, or about 20 percent of the total, will be qualified to hire foreign care givers, a situation which Lan warned will force many career women to quit their jobs.

Accusing the government of having caused pain to many Taiwan families with its new plan, she criticized the government for targeting local families rather than the high-tech sector in its bid to cut the number of foreign workers in Taiwan, despite the fact that it is the local hi-tech industry that actually employs the bulk of foreign laborers on the island.
According to CLA statistics, only 76,000 of the nearly 300,000 foreign workers in Taiwan are care givers, while the number of foreign housemaids totals only around 7,000.

EVTA Director-General Lin Tsong-ming said the government decided to reduce the number of alien workers in an effort to lower Taiwan's unemployment and he added that the government had fully communicated with local employers organizations before deciding to adjust the foreign labor policy.
A special government ad hoc group made a final decision on July 31 to slash the number of alien workers by 15,000 each year to fulfill a campaign promise made by President Chen Shui-bian.

In the future, quotas for alien laborers in major public construction projects will be reduced from the current level of 50 percent to 30 percent, while the number of foreign care givers will be slashed by 6,400 each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S RECORD-SETTING FATHERS HONORED
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records unveiled two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers on Wednesday as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8.

One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.

Lo, 78, lives in the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu. He is himself a retired policeman and has six sons, five of whom have followed in their father's footsteps to join the country's police force. His eldest son is a career military officer. It is rare in Taiwan that so many family members would be willing to work in the police community.
Lo said he took pride in his police job and is very pleased that his children have chosen the same career path to help maintain law and order and protect the safety of their fellow countrymen.

He said that although his children now work and live in different places, they maintain a close, intimate relationship. "The family meets regularly to share its joys and experiences. And issues related to public order, crime and the police community are common topics of our chats," he said with a smile.

Also honored was Chang A-piao, a 103-year-old resident of Fengyuan, Taichung County. The centenarian had also received a citation in June for his 55 years of service as a grassroots neighborhood chief in his hometown.

Chang is the oldest neighborhood chief in Fengyuan, but as he has practiced Chinese martial arts since childhood, he is still in good health despite his age. He has maintained good living habits and consistently rises at 5 a.m.
Chang has one son, three daughters and "countless" grandchildren, great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren, all of whom live under the same roof.
Chang said his current greatest wish is that Taiwan can enjoy sustained development and stability.
The Asian center of the Guinness Book of World Records said it is seeking other record-setting fathers in Taiwan as part of celebrations for Father's Day.

"We are still seeking the island's most productive father, the oldest child-breaing father and the oldest father," said Tai Sheng-tung, chairman of the Taiwan Museum of the Guinness Book of World Records.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MISSION TO VISIT JAPAN, SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: A 13-member mission composed of lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is slated to embark on a weeklong trip to Japan and South Korea on Sunday.

The delegation, led by DPP Legislator Tsai Trong-rong and his counterparts from the Mainstream Alliance -- a DPP subgroup in the Legislative Yuan -- will be visiting the neighboring countries over the next week in conjunction with the government's efforts to undertake "parliamentary diplomacy."
The DPP lawmakers will exchange opinions with pro-Republic of China (ROC) lawmakers in Japan and South Korea on issues of common concern in Northeast Asia.
The group's itinerary in the two countries will be fully arranged by the ROC representative offices there.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT UNITED STATES, CANADA

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to visit KMT chapters and overseas Chinese organizations in the United States and Canada during a 14-day trip that begins on Thursday.

Lien will initially spend three days in San Francisco, where he will be the first KMT chairman to visit the KMT's US headquarters. The office was established before the founding of the Republic of China in 1912.
Lien will be accompanied by a delegation, including his wife and KMT spokesman Jason Hu, who said that the visit will not involve any "political activities."

The trip will be Lien's first visit to the United States since stepping down from his previous post as Republic of China vice president. He was defeated in the March 18 presidential election as the KMT's presidential candidate.

Some analysts see the trip as a mission to consolidate KMT support in the Bay Area. People First Party (PFP) supporters appear to be increasing rapidly there after PFP Chairman James Soong spent over a month in San Francisco, following his defeat in the same election.

Lien will also visit his son, who is currently studying at Stanford University, and then head toward Los Angeles and later Vancouver, Canada, where Hu said Lien wished to keep a low profile out of respect for the host country. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DEPUTY HOPES FOR QUICK RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China official in charge of mainland China affairs expressed his hope on Wednesday that two sides of Taiwan Strait should soon resume their dialogue and conduct negotiations on the basis reached between the two sides in 1992.

Chen Ming-tung, deputy chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that the summit between the two Koreas last month is an indication that reconciliation and negotiations have become the watchwords of the modern world.

In response to this worldwide trend, both Taipei and Beijing must temporarily shelve their so-called "one China" ideological dispute and resume talks based on the spirit of the agreement reached between the two sides in 1992, Chen said.
Chen made the remarks at a seminar for legislative aides on mainland China policy and cross-strait relations.

Chen noted that two sides of the strait have spent a lot of time in the past discussing the controversial issue of reunification or Taiwan independence. Last month's historical summit between the two Koreas has shown the entire globe that negotiations to overcome disputes between conflicting sides is the trend for the future, he added.
He pointed out that the Chen administration hopes that it will be able to put aside the dispute over reunification or independence, and work towards the future.

He said that both Taipei and Beijing reached an understanding about "one China," in which both sides are able to form their own interpretation of what that means, in a meeting held in 1992. The "one China with separate interpretations" basis is sufficiently vague to provide ample space for negotiations in the future, Chen added.

Several ROC allies, including the United States, have been pushing the two sides of Taiwan Strait to begin talks as soon as possible, he said, adding that the ball is in Beijing's court, as Taiwan's new government is already prepared to resume talks with Beijing.
President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Tang Fei have repeatedly tied cross-strait relations to the frame of a "future China" in which both sides of the Taiwan Strait has a share.
President Chen has expressed his hope that he will play a historic role in normalizing cross-strait relations during his four-year tenure in office, as Richard Nixon had done for US-China relations.
Both Taipei and Beijing should do their best to carry out a reconciliation with good will and mutual cooperation, so as to create a permanent peace for a future China, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP LEADERS HOLD LANDMARK MEETING

TEXT.P: The top leaders of Taiwan's new ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the leading opposition Kuomintang held a landmark meeting on Wednesday as part of their efforts to improve inter-party relations.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who ended his stint as vice president on May 20, led a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on his DPP counterpart Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
The Lien-Hsieh meeting drew much attention in local society as it came amid growing rows between the DPP-led government and the KMT-controlled Legislative Yuan (parliament).
Lien, who lost to DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian in the March 18 presidential election, seemed to be happy at the meeting.
"This is a milestone in the history of domestic party politics, and I hope it will help lay a foundation for mutual respect and mature interaction among major domestic political parties," Lien said.

Under the mechanism of democracy, Lien said, competition among political parties may be unavoidable, "but it should be a must that all political parties work together to bring about benefits for the general public."

DPP Chairman Hsieh echoed Lien's view, saying local political parties should shelve unnecessary ideological and emotional confrontation and forge a consensus on major policy issues in order to upgrade the quality of domestic politics.

Hsieh said major political parties have their own social responsibilities. "If they have different opinions, they should hold a rational debate and present policy proposals for public choice through rational debate instead of indulging themselves in political wrangling. By so doing, we can establish a healthy party politics system and improve government efficiency and national competitiveness," he noted.
Hsieh went on to say he hopes that his meeting with Lien can contribute to constructive interaction between the KMT and the DPP.

During their 30-minute talks in a friendly atmosphere, Lien and Hsieh agreed to name the top managers of day-to-day affairs of their respective parties to work out details for a "roundtable meeting" proposed by President Chen.

Lien previously turned down Chen's proposal that a summit be held by heads of the domestic political parties on national issues, ranging from long-stalled cross-Taiwan Strait ties to possible constitutional amendments, and financial and economic topics.
But Lien told Hsieh that if President Chen makes clear his basic attitude or bottom line for the proposed roundtable, the KMT might not oppose such an inter-party summit meting.

Hsieh suggested that a preparatory meeting be held to set the agenda for the roundtable meeting. Lien agreed to Hsieh's proposal and named KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng to work out details with his DPP counterpart Wu Nai-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: "COMFORT WOMEN" ACTIVISTS TO MEET IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of South Korean social activists will meet with their Taiwan counterparts in Taipei in September to draw up a written accusation against Japan for the Imperial Japanese Army's practice in World War II of forcing many Asian women to serve as sex workers for its soldiers.

Chi En-hee, a South Korean advocate for the former so-called "comfort women", said on Wednesday that a group of South and North Korean activists will met with their Taiwan counterparts in Taipei between Sept. 15-17 to work out a symbolic indictment against Japan's government.

The indictment will be presented to a moot international tribunal organized by a civilian group in Tokyo to underline Imperial Japan's brutality and press demands for the Japanese government to pay compensation to the former comfort women.

Thousands of Asian women were forced or lured into prostitution by the Imperial Japanese Army during World War II. Instead of officially apologizing and paying them appropriate compensation, the Japanese government has only offered symbolic compensation through private funds.

Tokyo's stubborn refusal to admit its liability for the former comfort women -- most of whom are in their seventies or older and living in poverty -- has angered international human right activists. A group of them are planning to stage a mock trial of the Japanese government in Tokyo later this year, after fruitless attempts to the win the women's claims for damages through the Japanese judicial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS HEAVYWEIGHTS TO ACCOMPANY PRESIDENT ON O'SEAS TRIP

TEXT.P: In addition to Cabinet members, many of Taiwan's industrial heavyweights will accompany President Chen Shui-bian on his first official overseas trip as president, which will take him to six countries and is scheduled to start on Aug. 13, a senior official of the Presidential Office said on Wednesday.

Eugene Chien, deputy secretary general to the President, said that Wang Yu-tseng, chairman of General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China; Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industries and Commerce; Lin Kun-chung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries; Chien Ping-tsai, chairman of Taiwan Sugar Corp.; and Hsih Shih-chen, chairman of Taiwan Power Co., will accompany President Chen on the trip.

Other leading entrepreneurs expected to accompany the president on the coming trip include Wu Tung-chen, chairman of Shin Kong Group; Chen Jung-chiu, chairman of Lien Hsing Textile Corp., Kao Chih-shang, deputy chairman of I-Mei Foods Co., Ltd.; Lin Wei-shan, general manager of Tatung Co.; and Shen Ching-peng, chairman of the Ret-Ser Engineering Agency, Chien said.
Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the President Enterprises Group, reportedly canceled his original plan to accompany Chen on the trip, based on the advice of his medical doctor.

A group of legislators, including Hung Chi-chang (DPP-Taipei City), convener of Foreign Relations and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee; Chu Feng-chih (KMT-Taoyuan County), chairman of the ROC-African Parliamentary Association; Lee Ying-yuan, vice chairman of the same association; and Chen Chin-ting (Independent), chairman of the ROC-Central American Countries Parliamentary Association, will also accompany the President on the trip.

Members of the Cabinet accompanying the president on the trip include Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Secretary General of the National Security Council Chung Ming-yao, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih, and Chairman of the Council of Agriculture Chen Hsih-huang.
The first lady will not accompany the president on the trip.

President Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei on Aug. 13. He will arrive in Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic on Aug. 14 after spending an overnight stop in Los Angeles. The ROC head of state is scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 26 after ending an official visit to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GO SLOW' POLICY REVIEW NO LINKS TO INFLOW OF MAINLAND CAPITAL

TEXT.P: A senior official said on Wednesday that the government's ongoing review of the existing "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment has nothing to do with a proposal for opening the door to mainland capital.

Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu made the remarks after new Central Bank of China (CBC) Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng suggested on Tuesday that the government allow a "proper amount" of mainland Chinese capital to flow into Taiwan for selected investment projects.

Lin said he couldn't make any comment on Chen's proposal before gaining a better understanding of the full content of Chen's speech. Nevertheless, Lin stressed that one thing is certain that the government's current review of the "go slow, be patient" policy has nothing to do with the proposed inbound flow of mainland capital.

The "go slow, be patient" policy is designed to regulate Taiwan investment in mainland China, Lin explained, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and other relevant government agencies are still discussing whether to ease the policy to offer local entrepreneurs a freer hand in launching investment projects on the mainland with a view to enhancing competitiveness in the world market.
Lin said the MOEA is mulling some major issues regarding the adjustment of the "go slow" policy, such as the new fields to be open for local companies to invest on the mainland.

"Before we come up with a new liberalization package, we must conduct extensive discussion with local industries," Lin said, adding that a new version of regulations governing mainland China-bound investment is expected to be finalized by mid-September.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIJAY SINGH TO COACH TAIWAN YOUNGER GOLFERS IN SEPTEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 2 (CNA): World's famous golf player Vijay Singh will take part in annual Johnnie Walker Golf Tournament--the Republic of China Open Golf Championship scheduled to be held at the Sunrises Golf & Country Club in Yangmei in September.
During his stay in Taiwan, the neckname "black pearl" will preside over a golf clinic for a group of prominent teenaging golfers on Sept. 9.
A spokesman for the ROC Golf Association said six young golf under the age of 17 will be chosen to take part in the golf clinic to be presided over Vijay Singh.
The golf tourney also known as the ROC Open Golf Championship Tournament will be teed off on Sept. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD PUTS OFF DECISION ON ATTENDING CROSS-PARTY CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Wednesday put off deciding whether or not to accept President Chen Shui-bian's invitation to a conference of the major political parties, although the KMT said it will positively respond to the initiative.

The KMT head, who was defeated by Chen in the March 18 presidential election, sent a letter to Chen in which he politely suggested that the two reschedule the so-called "roundtable conference", because both Chen and he are slated to travel overseas in the near future.
The letter was handed over to Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, by a member of Lien's staff.
Chien said he will contact KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng on the possible meeting immediately.

Lien is slated to visit the United States and Canada from Aug. 3-16, according to his staff. President Chen announced in July that he will visit six of Taiwan's allies in Central America, the Caribbean and West Africa between Aug. 13-26.
In order to reconcile with the opposition parties and consult with them on national issues, Chen proposed that he host a meeting with Lien and James Soong, the head of the People First Party.

Soong has expressed his willingness to attend such a conference. Chen's staff said that the president would reschedule the conference at Lien's convenience after Lien turned down the invitation last month, on the grounds that it would conflict with his overseas visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER COUNTY SPEAKER EXECUTED FOR MURDER IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Former speaker of Pingtung County Cheng Tai-chi, who was sentenced by the Supreme Court to death for murder on July 14, was executed by firing squad in Kaohsiung Prison on Wednesday.
Cheng was led to a courtyard at the jail complex on Wednesday evening and was shot three times, said the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).
The gangster-turned politician was convicted of killing business partner Chung Yuan-feng in 1994, while serving as speaker of Pingtung County Council.
Cheng and Chung had a falling out because of quarrels over the division of profits from their gambling hall. Cheng eventually shot Chung over the dispute, murdering him in front of Chung's mother.
The MOJ said that Cheng apologized to family members of his victim, as well as his own family, before the execution.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING TO MAINLAND CHINESE INVESTMENT SHOULD BE PHASED: CENTRAL BANK

TEXT.P: Chen Shih-meng, the new deputy governor of Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC), said on Wednesday that Taiwan should open up to investment from mainland China in phases and in "appropriate" degrees.

Chen's comments came after he said on Tuesday that opening up to mainland Chinese investment would be helpful to Taiwan's security because mainland investors would be more concerned with Taiwan's social stability and economic prosperity if their financial interests were tied to Taiwan.

On the second day on his post, Chen said that higher tariffs should be charged for short-term capital investment than those for long-term investment, and that personal investors and mainland non-state institutional investors with good records in the past should be the first to be legalized because they would be less likely to be used by Beijing for "united front operations."
He went on to say that individual investors can be given higher ceilings for shareholding ratios because they are mainly "profit-oriented" and less likely to cause problems.
Chen added that more discussions should be held regarding the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC HEAD MEETS WITH OVERSEAS CHINESE IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Minister of Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chang Fu-mei on Wednesday urged overseas Chinese in Japan to close ranks to guard against a plot by Beijing to sow discord among them.

Chang made the call at a seminar attended by some 60 overseas Chinese representatives on ways to cope with the coming of the new century, to propagate the ROC's democratic achievements, as well as to implement earnestly the ROC's overseas Chinese affairs policy.
She referred to mainland China as launching a strong "anti-(Taiwan) independence, pro-unification" campaign overseas.

The OCAC head said that ROC's worldwide network of overseas Chinese units will work to strengthen communications with overseas Chinese. She also urged overseas Chinese to heighten their vigilance against Beijing's plot to sow discord among them.
She stressed that overseas Chinese who support the ROC government and love Taiwan fervently are all entitled to enjoy the services provided by the OCAC.
Chang, who assumed the OCAC post after Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party government was inaugurated on May 20, urged overseas Chinese to unite.

Chang arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday after winding up a visit to Los Angeles to attend the 21st annual meeting of overseas Chinese in the Americas and the 25th annual meeting of overseas Chinese in the United States.
Also present at the five-and-a-half-hour seminar was ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan.
Chang returned to Taipei on Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 71.92 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 71.92 points to close at 7,844.93.
Market turnover amounted to NT$57.67 billion (US$1.86 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 3, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed against British loses of 1,100 men.
1916: Sir Roger Casement, one of Britain's most distinguished civil servants, is hung in London for his involvement in the Easter Uprising in Dublin.
1926: The first traffic light in England is set up in London's Piccadily Circus.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the US atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K. T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the US Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight service between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the US 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park; it is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 US senators calling for prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 71.92 points to close at 7,844.93.

The bourse opened at 7,888.32, and due to lack of confidence on the part of investors, it continued to go down to 7,736.19, but purchases made by government funds boosted share prices. The bourse fluctuated between 7,912.4 and 7,736.19 during trading.

A total of 1.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.67 billion (US$1.86 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.38 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$49.28 billion.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 3.5 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.4 percent, electrical stocks at 1 percent, bank and insurance shares and cement stocks, both at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 354 to 142, with 89 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Thursday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved down 68 points to close at 7,915, with 4,271 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September decreased 50 points to finish at 7,935, with 107 contract transactions, while December futures lost 64 points to close at 8,009, with nine contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 7,983 for August; 7,985 for September; 8,073 for December; 8,103 for next March; and 8,304 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
August TE futures moved down 3.8 points to close at 412.1, with 1,577 contract transactions, while September TE futures fell 3.8 points to finish at 412.2, with 29 contract transactions.
December TE futures decreased 2 points to close at 414.3 with three contract transactions, while next March TE futures moved up 2 points to finish at 420, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next June TE futures.
August TF futures lost 3.2 points to close at 926, with 747 contract transactions, while September TF futures fell 5 points to finish at 925, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO DINE PARLIAMENTARY LEADERS FOR BETTER TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will dine parliamentary leaders of all political stripes on Monday in an effort to improve interaction between the executive and legislative branches, the Presidential Office said on Thursday.
This will be the first time that President Chen holds direct face-to-face talks with influential Legislative Yuan figures since he took office on May 20.
Chen's 20-plus guests will include Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Deputy Speaker Yao Eng-chi, and leading members of the legislative caucuses of various political parties or groups.
Premier Tang Fei and Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will also attend the dinner at the Taipei Guest House, a government estate near the Presidential Office.
Chen Tze-nan, deputy secretary-general to the President, visited the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan's parliament, to distribute invitations on behalf of the president.

Chen said the dinner is scheduled for Monday as the parliament is now in recess. "President Chen will take advantage of the dinner to exchange views with parliamentary heavyweights on major policy issues," Chen said while extending an invitation to Speaker Wang.
Chen stressed that the president will not set any limit to topics to be discussed at the dinner. "There will be neither ceiling nor bottom line for the agenda," he added.

All party whips from across the political spectrum said they accept the president's invitation with great pleasure. Hsu Tien-tsai, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus, said he hopes the dinner will mark a good start for better interaction between the DPP-led government and the opposition-dominated parliament.
Opposition New Party whip Lai Shih-pao said he hopes the dinner can bring about substantive results and will not be just a social function.

President Chen, a DPP stalwart, won only 39.3 percent of the vote in the March 18 presidential election, and his party controls barely one-third of seats in the legislature. In contrast, the island's long-ruling Kuomintang still controls a majority in the parliament after losing the presidency.

President Chen has rejected opposition calls for a coalition government and formed what he calls "a government of all people," naming Tang Fei, a stalwart of the rival KMT, as premier. But KMT legislators have refused to go along and have blocked the Cabinet's policies at every turn.

Against this backdrop, DPP sources said, President Chen has arranged the dinner as part of his efforts to improve communication and coordination among the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the Legislative Yuan in order to ensure smooth operation of his administration.
