DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR OF SAN MIGUELITO EXPRESSES THANKS TO ROC GOV'T

TEXT.P: San Miguelito Mayor Luben Dario Campos on Tuesday expressed gratitude to the ROC government on behalf of the city's citizens for helping the Panamanian city upgrade its image by getting a new look.
Early this year, the ROC government donated more than US$200,000 to the city to assist it in the purchase of garbage trucks and in dredging rivers to beautify the city's appearance.

At an appreciation ceremony held on Roosevelt Bridge in San Miguelito, Councilor Shing Ying-huei of the ROC embassy in Panama City accepted a thank-you plaque from mayor Campos on behalf of ROC Ambassador Lan Chih-min. Panama City mayor Juan Carlos Navarro also attended the ceremony.

Prior to the cleanup campaign, the side walls of the bridge used to be covered in campaign posters and graffiti. Now the bridge is decorated with paintings and art work characteristic of Panama's culture, giving it a fresh new look.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR PLANNING NEW-GENERATION OF WARPLANES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday directed the Republic of China's Air Force to draw up a forward-looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the sky over the Taiwan Strait.
President Chen gave the directive during an inspection tour of the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) in Taipei in his capacity as the ROC military's supreme leader.

Noting that air defense plays a crucial role in the ROC's overall defense system, Chen said he is pleased to see the commissioning of the country's second-generation warplanes to help safeguard national security.

Nevertheless, Chen said, mainland Chinese air force's combat capability is expected to be greatly beefed up after 2005 with the maturity of its airborne early-warning system, airborne fueling and electronic warfare technology and automatic command system as well as mass production of its new warplanes. "The advancement in mainland China's air combat capability will certainly affect military balance across the Taiwan Strait," the president noted.
In the face of this challenge, Chen said the ROC air force should draft a plan for development or acquisition of a new generation of warplanes for use in the 2010s and even in the 2020s.

Chen said the air force should also continue upgrading the new-generation warplanes' air-to-surface and air-to-sea assault and reconnaissance capabilities to maintain its air supremacy and ensure air defense security.

The ROC began to prepare for replacing its aging air fleet with second-generation warplanes in the 1980s. In addition to developing IDFs (indigenous defense fighters) on its own, the air force has also managed to purchase 150 F-16 advanced jet fighters from the United States and 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters. The three types of high-performance fighter planes and several other sophisticated reconnaissance and early-warning aircraft now form the backbone of the air force arsenal.
In his speech to AFGH staff, Chen further said mainland China's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan is the greatest threat to the ROC's security.

Noting that the development of cross-strait relations will not only affect the well-being of the people on both sides but will also have a significant impact on peace and stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region, Chen said he has repeatedly held out olive branches to Beijing and called for resumption of dialogue and consultations to ease animosity and resolve disputes.

In view of the prevailing world trends, Chen said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can no longer afford to waste energy, wisdom and limited resources on mutual suspicion, squabbling and confrontation.

In preparation for negotiation with mainland China, Chen said, the ROC must simultaneously strengthen its military muscle to guarantee its national security. "Only when our national security faces no threat can we develop constructive interaction with the mainland," he explained.
Therefore, Chen encouraged all air force staff to develop a healthy internal operation, management, control and supervisory system to ensure efficiency and high-performance of all weaponry systems.

The air force must also cooperate with other military branches to perfect its combined service combat capability because amphibious and three-dimensional warfare have become the mainstay of modern war, Chen said.

He also encouraged the air force to devote more energy to research and development and overcome all obstacles and difficulties in training exercises in order to maintain air supremacy and upgrade overall defense capabilities.
Chen further said he felt very regret that the recent Pachang Creek rescue fiasco has tarnished the Air Force's Seagull Rescue Team's reputation and even the military's overall image.

Chen attributed the tragedy, which claimed four lives and led to the resignation of vice premier and several other senior officials, mainly to the outdated rigid emergency rescue system and "bureaucratic thinking and mentality" on the part of relevant personnel.
"The government has taken mend-fencing steps to improve our emergency rescue system and I hope similar tragedy will never recur," Chen said.
The president also stressed the importance of flight safety in his speech, urging all air force staff, including maintenance personnel, to make every effort to prevent any flight mishaps.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION APPLAUDES REPUBLICAN PLATFORM ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The American Conservative Union (ACU) on Wednesday applauded the strong language in the Republican party's platform passed by the Republican National Convention on Monday regarding the United States' ongoing relationship with the government and people of the Republic of China on Taiwan.
"The American Conservative Union worked very hard to make certain that the position of the Republican Party towards our friends in Taiwan is very clear," said Patricia Fava, ACU Legislative director.

She emphasized that "to state in no uncertain terms that `America will help Taiwan defend itself' is a clear message that the Republican Party and Governor George W. Bush understand the importance of maintaining a strong relationship with Taiwan and ensuring that the freedom loving people of Taiwan continue to prosper in a democratic society."

Additionally, Fava noted, the Republican Party Platform states that the United States recognizes the growing importance of the Republic of China on Taiwan in the global economy and that "we support their accession to the World Trade Organization and other multilateral institutions."

"The people of Taiwan deserve the support and assistance of the United States whenever and wherever possible. The democratically elected government and the people are a beacon of freedom in an area of the world where threats to their national security are part of daily life," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TEST FOR BANNED EPO SEEN MAKING SYDNEY OLYMPICS CLEANER

TEXT.P: The Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) stated that it believes the new test for the presence of erythropoietin (EPO) in athletes, approved by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) on Tuesday, will help weed out users of performance-enhancing drugs and make the 2000 Olympic Games a cleaner sports event.
"To have a valid test now will cause a number of drug cheats to have second thoughts," AOC Secretary-General Graig McLatchey told reporters on Wednesday.

Brian Doyle, president of the Australian and New Zealand Sports Law Association, said that "who knows, we might even see a spate of injuries," implying that some athletes may withdraw from competition feigning injury rather than risk facing an EPO test.
Organizers said at least 3,000 out of the more than 10,000 athletes participating in the Olympic Games will face EPO testing before and during the event, which gets under way in mid-September.

Nicki Vance, doping control manager for the Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games, said that testing equipment has already been purchased and that a clinic in Homebush, one of the Olympic venues, has been modified for blood collection.
Sporting authorities said they believe EPO, which can increase an athletes performance by up to 15 percent, is being widely used by athletes, particularly in speed sports.
Athletes most likely to benefit from the use of EPO are those who experience a high oxygen uptake during competition, such as middle and long distance runners, swimmers, cyclists, and rowers.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP, KINGSTONE OFFERING VALENTINE'S DAY ONLINE `PRINT SHOP'

TEXT.P: The Taiwan subsidiary of Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP) is teaming up with Kingstone Book Store Co. to provide an online "print shop" service for lovers in the week leading up to Chinese Valentine's Day.
Chinese Valentine's Day falls on the seventh day of the seventh month of the Lunar calendar.

Since Tuesday, visitors to a special HP website (image.hp.com.tw) have been able to create their own Valentine's cards, color calendars, and visiting cards adorned with images that the users prepare from ready-made templates.

Surfers can upload pictures taken from off-the-shelf graphics archives, digital camera photographs, or scanned images to design personalized cards for Chinese Valentine's Day through the site's "real-time interactive editing."

Meanwhile, consumers can vote on the best Chinese Valentine's Day cards by visiting Kingstone bookstores or the HP website. Designers of the top five Valentine's Day cards will receive prizes, including an HP printer.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR DEFENSE EXERCISES TO BE HELD IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's annual air defense exercises will begin in southern Taiwan on Aug. 4, military sources said on Thursday.
The drill, code-named Wanan No. 23, will be held throughout the same month all across the island of Taiwan, as well as Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, the sources said.

The sources said the exercises, which will include demonstrations of emergency rescue operations, will follow the regulations formulated after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake. The drill is aimed at reinforcing the nation's defense and combat readiness, as well as its rescue capability, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES CSF STAFF TO RESIST TEMPTATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday urged all Combined Service Force (CSF) staff to resist temptation, maintain integrity and serve as a model for the new government's campaign for establishing clean politics.
Chen made the appeal during an inspection tour of the CSF General Headquarters in his capacity as the supreme leader of the Republic of China's armed forces.
Chen said CSF staff have many opportunities to deal with the business and industry community for various military procurement and construction projects.

In the highly competitive business world, Chen said, it is understandable that businessmen and construction contractors will offer various forms of benefits to temp CSF officers for securing procurement or construction contracts.

"I hope all relevant CSF staff members can strictly abide by the existing laws and regulations in handling those projects," Chen said, adding that all CSF personnel should resist temptation to avoid offending laws and official ethics and help eradicate corruption and establish clean politics.

Chen's advice was seen very significant as some CSF officers were convicted of corruption and kickback scandals in handling military construction and procurement projects in the past. His "resist temptation" call also coincided with Chen's order for the ormation of a special task force to probe the 1993 murder of Navy arms acquisition officer Yin Ching-feng. The high-profile murder case was suspected of links to several naval arsenal procurement scandals.

In his speech, Chen further said the CSF headquarters will form the mainstay of the future military supply system to be formed under the newly passed National Defense Law and the Organizational Law of the MInistry of National Defense.

"And the new military supply system will also become one of the most important parts of our overall national resources application and military production systems," Chen explained, adding that he hopes all CSF staff members can work hard to establish an efficient, high-quality and self-sufficient logistic mechanism.
Chen also encourged the CSF headquarters to pool all military and civilian resources to help upgrade Taiwan's defense technology and industry and cultivate more technological manpower.

Meanwhile, the president stressed importance of adopting an active approach to improve logistic support and services to officers and men in other military branches. He further said the CSF headquarters should take precautionary measures to avoid environmental pollution and ensure public and workplace security.
Later in the day, Chen also made a similar inspection tour of the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) and lunched together with all AFGH staff.

Since taking office on May 20, Chen had presided over several major military commissioning ceremonies and a joint cadets exercise as well as visited some military units. He will also supervise a massive annual combined services training drill, code-named Han Kuang No. 16 Exercise, after ending his Aug. 13-25 overseas visit, which will take him to six of the ROC's diplomatic allies in Central America, the Caribbean and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT 3RD MOST INFLUENTIAL MAN IN GREATER CHINA: POLL

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian is the third most influential figure in the Greater China area comprising Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, according to the results of a recent survey released on Thursday.
Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin tops the list of the 50 most influential people in the three Chinese societies rated in the survey.

Jiang is immediately followed by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, according to the "Power 50" survey, conducted jointly by Taiwan's "The Journalist" weekly paper, the Hong Kong-based Ming Pao daily and the New City radio station.

A panel of 90 judges from mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong were invited to select the 50 most influential or powerful people from a list of 150 candidates chosen from political, business, religious, media and pop culture circles in the three societies.

A total of 18 Taiwan celebrities make the "Power 50" list along with Chen, two of whom rank among the top 10 most influential -- former President Lee Teng-hui, in seventh place and Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, also a Nobel laureate, in 10th.
The survey found that entrepreneurs play a very important role in capitalist Hong Kong and Taiwan, with business magnates accounting for more than a quarter of the listed figures.

Noted Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing trails the ROC president as the fourth most influential figure in the three Chinese communities, ahead of even Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hua, who only made ninth.

Taiwan business barons on the "Power 50" list include Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching (12th); Koo's Group Chairman Koo Chen-fu (17th), who is also Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China; Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa (33rd); Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih (35th); and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. Chairman Morris Chang (42nd).

The heads of Taiwan's three major political parties all make the list -- opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong (11th); ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh, also mayor of Kaohsiung (20th); and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, a former vice president (21st).
Premier Tang Fei, a four-star general-turned-politician, ranks 27th, while Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is rated the 13th most influential.

The key figures in charge of cross-Taiwan Strait relations all rank among the top 50 influential people, indicating that cross-strait relations are an issue of "great concern" in the three areas. Wang Daohan, mainland China's No. 1 negotiator with Taiwan ranks 8th, even though his ranking in Beijing's official hierarchy is not high.

Meanwhile, Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, ranks 44th. Apart from Premier Tang Fei, she is the only Taiwan Cabinet member to make the list.
Although women account for 50 percent of the total population of Greater China, they make up only 10 percent of the most influential people.

The respected Buddhist Master Cheng Yen is the highest-ranking influential woman, placing at 18th, while Annette Lu, the ROC's first female vice president, ranks 24th. This indicates that female influence in Chinese society remains weak.

Another interesting finding is that "gun barrels" have greater influence than "men of letters," with senior mainland Chinese military officials ranking far ahead of media executives in Hong Kong and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FIFTH IN INSTITUTIONAL PERFORMANCE IN ASIA
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks fifth in overall institutional performance among Asian states and areas, according to the results of a recent survey conducted by the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy (PERC) Co.
Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, and India take the top four spots in the PERC evaluation report, while Taiwan is followed by Malaysia, South Korea, mainland China and Indonesia, in that order.

The PERC survey was conducted in the performance fields of banking systems, central bank and financial management, stock transaction regulations, and parliamentary and judiciary institutions. Zero was the best possible score on the 10-grade scaling system, while ten was the lowest rating.

Taiwan garnered 5.05 points for its banking system, 5.01 points for the performance of its central bank and financial management; 5.09 points for stock transaction regulations, six points for the performance of its legislative sector; and five points in the category of social order and the judiciary.

According to the report, Taiwan and South Korea have transformed from authoritarian regimes into democratic institutions. At the same time, mainland China has also achieved noticeable progress over the past ten years in group management initiated by former mainland Chinese paramount leader Deng Xiaoping.

Although Singapore has been criticized for being too centralized, the report also points out that the country's stable institutional system, led by a group of elite rather than just one strong-man, has ensured its continued development, and enjoys high marks among foreigners working here.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTRY MONITORING MAINLAND CHINA'S 'ROUTINE' EXERCISE

TEXT.P: A military spokesman said on Thursday that Taiwan is closely watching the "routine" maritime exercises currently being conducted by mainland China's coastal troops.
Maj. Gen. Kung Fan-ding said that the Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense (MND) is "closely monitoring" the troops' every movement, and he urged the public to rest at ease.

Mainland China's official Xinhua News Agency reported on Wednesday that the Nanjing Military Region is currently conducting its largest maritime exercises in recent years on the Yellow and East China Seas.
Xinhua reported that as many as 110,000 soldiers are involved in the exercises.

Kung said that the mainland's littoral forces conduct training exercises at sea every year from June to August, and that the drills include maritime first-aid, barehanded swimming, long distance swimming, and full-gear swimming.

A spokesman for the MND's Office of the Deputy Chief of the General Staff for Operations said that no "unusual circumstances" are behind the exercises, which he said are simply "swimming drills" planned to coincide with the seasons.

He added that the exercises are already being closely monitored, and that Beijing clearly meant to play up its "verbal attacks and saber rattling" again by announcing the news through Xinhua. He urged the public not to be influenced by the intimidation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES ROC SPEED SKATERS FOR WINNING SECOND GOLD

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian cabled on Thursday his congratulations to the members of the Chinese Taipei speed skating team for winning their second gold medal in the World Cup Speed Skating Championship Tournament now being held in Bogota, Colombia.
Chinese Taipei just managed to edge host Colombia by 10 cm in the women's 5,000-meter relay, thus securing the second gold medal for the ROC team.
Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang Fei and Chairman of the Council of Physical Fitness and Sports Hsu Yi-hsiung also cabled their congratulations to the team for their excellent performance.
The Chinese Taipei women's speed skating Team is made up of Hou Hsin-su, Chen Ya-wen and Lin Ling-oh.
Lin Ling-oh won another gold medal for the team in the women's 5,000-meter point-accumulated skating competition.
The three-member Chinese Taipei Men's Speed Skating team came in fifth at the men's 5,000-meter relay competition.
The Year 2000 World Cup Speed Skating Championship Tournament opened in Colombia on July 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR BACK FROM EUROPEAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou returned home on Thursday, having finished a 10-day tour of cities in the United Kingdom, Sweden, Finland, and Czechoslovakia.

Ma said that he learned a lot about city management on his fact-finding tour, adding that it will be helpful to Taipei's ongoing construction of the Metropolitan Area Rapid Transit System, garbage disposal, and creating a citywide computer network. Meanwhile, he also invited UK Premier Tony Blair to visit Taiwan in the future.

Ma was informed on Wednesday that Wang Chin-wang, director of the Taipei City Police Bureau, will take the post of director-general of the National Police Administration. Noting that his relationship with the Police Office director has always been one of cooperation, Ma said that he will make a final personnel decision on the matter after meeting with Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI AND TAIWAN STOCK EXCHANGES SIGN COOPERATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Vicharat Vichit-Vodakan, president of the SET, said that the memorandum was co-signed in Taipei on Thursday by Lee Chung-ying, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation, and Amaret Sila-On, chairman of the Stock Exchange of Thailand.

Vicharat said the formal agreement will facilitate information sharing between the SET and TSEC with regards to financial products traded on each exchange, as well as transaction details for the purposes of trading regulation and enforcement.

He added that the TSEC is the fourth stock exchange in the Asia Pacific region with which the SET has entered formal agreements to facilitate the flow of information and exchange of cooperation with regard to securities trading. The Thai bourse already has similar agreements with exchanges in Australia, Japan and Vietnam, according to the announcement.
The SET official said that strategic partnerships with foreign stock exchanges are vital for the operations of the Thai stock exchange amid rapid changes in today's capital markets.

The memorandum of understanding with the TSEC will enable the SET to establish a formal and open line of communications with Taiwan, strengthening the Thai bourse by allowing its regulators to cooperate more closely with their counterparts in Taiwan for the mutual benefit of both exchanges, he added. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING SHOULD BUILD UP 'MEANINGFUL POLITICAL TIES': MAC

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should sit down to talk and forge a "meaningful political relationship," the Republic of China's top mainland policy planner said on Thursday.
Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks at a parliamentary aides training camp.
Tsai said the new ROC government is endeavoring to seek "common grounds" with mainland China in order to achieve a breakthrough to the long-stalled cross-strait ties.

Tsai said if Beijing thinks the 1992 cross-strait consultations were meaningful to both sides, the ROC government is willing to carefully review the meeting results in a positive direction and manner,
Basically, Tsai said, the ROC thinks that the true spirit reflected in the 1992 consultations was "exchange, dialogue and shelving disputes."
Tsai said so long as the two sides can shelve disputes over the definition of "one China" and successfully conduct dialogue and exchanges, then the "objective environment" can gradually change.
"Should that be the case, it will become relatively easier to resolve the thorny 'one China' issue," Tsai noted.
The international trade law expert-turned-official pointed out that such terms as Taiwan independence, unification, or maintaining the status quo are too vague to define.

To her, Tsai said, the people of Taiwan have only one choice in the future. "That is to develop a meaningful political relationship with mainland China," she explained, adding that from the viewpoints of culture, history, geography and race, no human force can cut cross-strait exchanges.
The sophisticated policy planner further said people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should avoid simplifying or narrowing the "one China" concept.
Tsai said "one China" can be a system under which the two sides of the Taiwan Strait co-exist peacefully and prosperously over the next five or 10 years.
"So long as both sides have confidence and mutual trust, there can be infinite room and flexibility for the development cross-strait relations," Tsai noted.
She rejected opposition criticism that the new government's mainland policy is in disarray or like "a car parked in neutral."

Noting that cross-strait relations are currently in a "relatively stable" condition, Tsai said if cross-strait ties move at a "first-gear" speed during the Kuomintang era, the new government will move at a faster "second-gear" speed in promoting cross-strait relations.

Tsai said the new government is accelerating review of various existing regulations or measures concerning cross-strait relations and is also studying various possibilities for future development. "Some new measures or policies are taking shape," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS HOPING FOR STRENGTHENED TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and the Republic of Marshall Islands will be further strengthened following a visit on Thursday by Marshall Islands' officials to Kinmen, an ROC-controlled island off mainland China's Fujian Province.

Accompanied by Joseph Shih, director of the Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Marshall Islands' Foreign and Trade Minister Alvin T. Jacklick, Finance Minister Mike Konelios, and Government Legal Advisor Moses Gago traveled to Kinmen to gain an understanding of Kinmen's economic development in a bid to learn from the frontline island's experience as a reference for the Marshall Islands' economic development.
Located in the North Pacific near the equator, the Marshall Island group is composed of 1,225 islands with an area of about 181 square kilometers and a population of 58,000.
The Marshall Islands established diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Nov. 20, 1998.

Because of the abundant fishery resources in the area, the ROC signed an agreement with the Marshall Islands to establish a deep-sea fishery base there. At present, there are 42 ROC pelagic fishing boats operating in the waters around the Marshall Islands, catching NT$90 billion-worth of fish each year.
Kinmen Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai hosted a luncheon to entertain the three visiting dignitaries, who also toured several of Kinmen's scenic spots before flying back to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC CHIEF TO VISIT BERLIN, PARIS

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei will leave for Berlin on Friday to attend the annual meeting of the Federation of Taiwanese Associations.
It will be Chang's first visit to Europe since assuming her Cabinet post on May 20.

An OCAC official said that on Saturday, Chang will host a dinner in honor of the delegates to the meeting and the following day will deliver a speech at the meeting and attend a symposium to exchange views with the delegates.

She will then depart for Paris to inspect the Cultural and Educational Service Center in Paris and visit overseas Chinese organizations there before returning to Berlin on Aug. 9 to attend the opening of the annual meeting of Chinese Associations in Europe on Aug. 11.

Later that day, she will leave Berlin for San Francisco to attend the opening of an athletic meet for local Chinese residents scheduled for Aug. 12, and will visit Los Angeles from Aug. 13 to 16 before leaving for home on Aug. 17.
Since assuming her current post, Chang has visited South Africa, Singapore, Los Angeles and Tokyo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AMONG TOP LIST OF HIGHEST ENTERPRISE PROFIT GROWTH NATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is among the highest enterprise profit growth nations in the world, according to an international study reported by a Belgian financial newspaper on Thursday.

The Echo D'Oran quoted the IBES International as reporting that the global enterprise profit in the coming 12 months will average a 29 percent growth rate. However, the average would have been reduced to 25 percent if Japan had been excluded from the list.
The same study shows that Taiwan is included in a list of nations whose growth rate will be higher than that of the global rate.

The study showed that the Taiwan rate is expected to grow 56 percent in the coming 12 months, behind only Indonesia and Japan. The Philippines, Brazil, Argentina and Norway will also surpass the global growth rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TEAM TO COMPETE IN 2000 PONY LEAGUE WORLD SERIES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Peng Szu-chou and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei defeated South Korea 2-1 in the championship round of the 2000 Pony Asia-Pacific Zone Baseball Tournament on Thursday, earning it a berth in the 2000 Pony League World Series slated to begin on Aug. 12 in the United States.
Chinese Taipei head coach Chang Hsih-chieh attributed his team's victory in Beijing to the "thoroughness" of the pitchers and the "seamless" defense that consistently shut out South Korea.

Pitcher Luo Ching-lung, the team's so-called "secret weapon," struck out a total of 14 hitters throughout the seven innings and helped Chinese Taipei maintain its 2-1 lead over South Korea since the fourth.

Chinese Taipei will face the winners of other regional tournaments at the world series and dish it out for the championship in an eight-team, two-division double elimination tournament to be held in Pittsburgh from Aug. 12-19.

The PONY (Protect Our Nation's Youth) Baseball and Softball League is a private organization founded in 1950 with the purpose of promoting baseball and softball around the world. It has developed a system of competition based on seven age groups. The Pony division -- originally the only league division -- is for children between the ages of 13 and 14.
Taiwan joined the PONY competition system in 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO MEET PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said on Thursday that once he returns from a 14-day trip to North America, he will meet with President Chen Shu-bian.

He also said the KMT will cooperate with the Republic of China's other political parties on the basis of promoting the best interests of the public. He added that his Wednesday meeting with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh was an example of political party interaction.

Lien made the remarks just prior to his departure for the United States and Canada to visit local KMT chapters and overseas Chinese organizations where he will explain the present domestic political situation to overseas Chinese. According to Lien, because the KMT originated from an overseas political party, it has a deep relationship with overseas Chinese.

Depending on his schedule, Lien will initially spend three days in San Francisco, where he will be the first KMT chairman to visit the party's US headquarters. The office was established before the founding of the Republic of China in 1912.

Lien will then head for Los Angeles, after which he will visit his son, who is currently studying at Stanford University. On Aug. 9, he will leave for Vancouver, Canada before returning to Taiwan on Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHIEF HOPING TO MEET MAINLAND CHINESE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu said on Thursday that he hopes to meet his mainland Chinese counterpart soon and seize the opportunity to forge normal relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

As a meeting with Chairman Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is of key importance in promoting bilateral exchanges, Koo said he wishes to meet Wang as quickly as possible.

Saying that "the factor preventing Wang from visiting Taiwan no longer exits," Koo called on the ARATS chairman to make the trip as soon as possible. "I sincerely wish to meet Mr. Wang in Taiwan, the sooner the better. Taiwan has never halted its preparations for his visit here," he added.

Koo further pointed out that Taiwan and mainland China should first hold a preparatory meeting prior to the much-anticipated second Koo-Wang meeting, and that the SEF has decided to first invite vice-secretary-level ARATS officials to visit Taiwan for that purpose.
The SEF chairman, Taiwan's No. 1 negotiator with mainland China, contended that "there is still a chance that Wang will visit Taiwan," since "we will not mention again the `two-states' theory."

He was referring to the "special state-to-state relationship" theory aired by former President Lee Teng-hui in July 1999 to describe Taiwan-mainland ties that angered Beijing and stalled Wang's planned trip to Taiwan, originally scheduled for September of the same year.

Stressing that it requires efforts from both sides to create a favorable climate for the resumption of bilateral talks, Koo said the current administration of President Chen Shui-bian has displayed a high degree of goodwill and that it is willing to discuss cooperation with the mainland.
Koo made the remarks while answering questions from reporters following a meeting on a reshuffle of the SEF board and supervisory members.

Addressing the meeting, the SEF head detailed how Taiwan and mainland China reached the so-called "1992 consensus," and emphasized that the spirit of the consensus is to "communicate, talk, and put aside disputes."

Based on that spirit, the two sides were able to hold the landmark 1993 Koo-Wang meeting in Singapore -- the first of its kind in cross-strait contacts in 50 years -- which clinched four agreements, he noted.

Meanwhile, a mainland Chinese source close to ARATS told CNA that Wang has not given up on his plan to visit Taiwan, but added that a positive climate and sound foundation are necessary before such a trip can take place.
According to the source, the precondition for Wang's Taiwan trip is that "Taiwan must recognize the `one China' principle," which is Beijing's foundation for the resumption of bilateral dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITABLE MEDICAL GROUP TO VISIT BOLIVIA

TEXT.P: The Luchu Medical Service Group, a Taiwan-based charitable medical organization, will visit Bolivia from Aug. 5-21 to provide medical services to residents of the Province of Santa Cruz, a spokesman said on Thursday.

The spokesman said that the medical team will include two dentists, a surgeon, a physician, a dermatologist, a nutritionist, a medical examiner, five nurses, two professors, a student and an official from the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

Liu Chi-chun, president of the medical service group, told reporters that he flew to Santa Cruz in June to inspect the prospective site for the charitable medical service with the assistance of local Chinese and Taiwanese organizations.
During their stay in Bolivia, the members of the medical team will call on the minister of the Bolivian Health Ministry and attend a medical seminar.
The Luchu Medical Service Group was established about six years ago, mainly to provide regular medical services for Taiwan aborigines.
Since last year, the group has expanded its services to foreign countries, including Macedonia, Liberia, the exiled Tibetan government in India and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT UNDECIDED ON MAINLAND CHINA INVESTMENT POLICY ADJUSTMENT

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Shin-yee said on Thursday that the government has not yet made a final decision on whether it should adjust the current "no haste, be patient" policy regarding local investment in mainland China.

Brushing aside recent media reports that the government has agreed to loosen the mainland investment policy introduced by former President Lee Teng-hui, Lin said his ministry and the Mainland Affairs Council, the highest government agency in charge of drawing up Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, are still discussing the issue.

As an adjustment in the mainland investment policy might significantly affect Taiwan's national security and economic stability, Lin said, officials from the two government departments are still assessing the possible ramifications of a modification of the present measures.

Echoing Lin's remarks, Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chen Ruey-long reiterated that no policy has been forged to revise the "no haste, be patient" policy, and he criticized the media for publishing speculation which might misguide the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR THREATENS TO SEARCH MILITARY HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: A prosecutor assigned to probe the death of a navy captain and alleged irregularities in the navy's arms purchases threatened on Thursday to search military agencies if they kept resisting producing documents needed for his investigation.

Hung Wei-hua, a prosecutor of the Prosecutor's Office under the Taiwan High Court, warned the military authorities: "Don't try to trifle with, resist, or block the investigation, let along conceal any leads."
He issued the ultimatum after six agents dispatched by his office to the military authorities to collect documents in connection with the case were given only two small cases of paperwork.

The prosecutor said he reissued an urgent memorandum on Thursday to the Navy General Headquarters, The Military Legal Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the General Political Warfare Department under the MND, The Corps of Anti-intelligence under the MND, and the Headquarters of Taipei Military Police, asking them to hand over all related documents to his office within a week.

If the documents passed over to him are insufficient to piece together the whole case, Hung said he will consider exercising his legal investigation power "in due course of law," which would mean a search of related military agencies.

Later on Thursday, Vice Chief-of-General-Staff Gen. Wang Han-ning, who was named as the investigation team's contact at the General Staff headquarters, called on State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ran-fa, who is Hung's supervisor and the head of the special panel charged to look into the case.
Wang would not comment on Hung's warning after the meeting, saying only that he would "try to understand" Hung's complains.
Hung was assigned by Lu to investigate the death in 1993 of navy Capt. Yin Ching-feng, who at the time was the executive director of the navy's weaponry acquirement program.

Yin's body was found floating in Suao Harbor in northern Taiwan on Dec. 9, 1993 several days after he had been collecting evidence about alleged irregularities concerning the navy's procurement of four German-made minesweepers and six French-made frigates.

The investigation into his death has bogged down over the past six years since several arms brokers competing for contracts to provide the navy with the warships fled the island shortly after Yin's death.

Recent reports from Paris that huge kickbacks were paid to Taiwan officials for the deal of six frigates fueled speculation that Yin's death was just the tip of an iceberg, and that there was a ploy to cover up massive corruption involving senior military officers and government officials.
The investigation of Yin's death got a shot in the arm after President Chen Shui-bian on July 30 ordered the establishment of an ad hoc panel, with Lu Ren-fa as its head, to look into the case.

Meanwhile, Rear Adm. Liu Chin-an, director of the Military Legal Bureau under the MND, quit the panel on Thursday after he was accused by Yin's widow and Legislator Lee Ching-hua of trying to cover up the alleged plot behind Yin's death while probing the case as head of the navy's legal department in 1993.
Given Liu's involvement in the previous botched investigation, Lee said his participation in the new panel would only undermine its credibility.

After consulting with Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen, Liu said he decided to withdraw from the panel and have an acting deputy director of the MND Military Legal Bureau, Maj. Gen. Hsu Ho-ping, take his place.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NOT MULLING LIFTING OF BAN ON INFLOW OF BEIJING FUNDS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said on Thursday that far from considering the lifting of a ban on capital from mainland China, the government has not even assessed the impact of such capital inflow.

In a meeting with a group of lawmakers' aides, Tsai said that once Taiwan is admitted to the World Trade Organizaiton, it will be obliged to open its service market to foreign service providers, which will inevitably bring in outside capital.

However, she went on, capital inflow from Beijing would not be ordinary capital movement on markets seeking profits, but capital used for non-commercial purposes and therefore requiring special control, which the government has not considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES CARIBBEAN FOREIGN MINISTERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian told visiting foreign ministers of the ROC's four Caribbean allies on Thursday that there will be "continuity and stability" in Taiwan's foreign policy under his government.

Chen added that Taiwan will further strengthen its substantive relations with the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, Saint Christopher and Nevis, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, by continuing bilateral cooperative exchanges in agriculture, trade, news, and culture.

He also thanked the ministers for their countries' long-term support of the ROC in the international arena and for coming to Taiwan to attend the fourth meeting between the ROC foreign minister and his Caribbean counterparts, to be held in Taipei on Friday.

Chen asked for their understanding for his being unable to visit their countries during his upcoming trip to Central America, South America, and Africa due to his tight schedule, but he expressed hope that he will meet the leaders of the Caribbean nations at the inauguration ceremonies for the Dominican Republic president during his trip.

Earlier in the day, ROC foreign minister Tien Hung-mao said after meeting with the Caribbean visitors that while Taiwan provides assistance to its allies, he hopes the allies will be able to assist the ROC in carving out more space in the international community and give Taiwan a hand when it seeks to join in various international organizations.

He added that mainland China's continued attempts to woo away ROC allies is old news, and that the meeting of the foreign ministers will strengthen mutual cultural exchanges and private visits among government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ROUND OF 2000 WORLD WOMEN'S VOLLEYBALL TOURNAMENT TO BE HELD
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's preliminary competition of the 2000 World Women's Volleyball Tournament is scheduled to be held at the Kaohsiung County Gymnasium on Aug. 11-13.
Four teams representing Brazil, Russia, Japan and Italy will also take part in the competition.

The World Women's Volleyball Tournament was first held in 1993 and the top eight teams in the world compete in two sets of preliminary contests held in six countries each year, said Chang Chin-jung, secretary-general of the ROC Volleyball Association.

Although the ROC's volleyball strength is not up to the standard of the world's top eight teams, the prevailing and general mood of the sport here has been affirmed by the International Volleyball Federation, and the ROC has been chosen for three consecutive years to be the venue for the preliminary competition.

Eight teams representing Brazil, mainland China, Cuba, Russia, Italy, Japan, South Korea and the United States are taking part in this year's tournament, with preliminary contests taking place from Aug. 4-20 in Taiwan, mainland China, Macau, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines. The top prize for each leg of the competition is US$100,000.
The final round is slated to be held in Manila from Aug. 25-27 with teams battling for a US$400,000 prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan embarks on US-Canada visit, willing to meet President Chen Shui-bian after his return.
The China Times:
The government will offer NT$300 billion in soft loans to attract home buyers and stimulate the sluggish housing market.
The United Daily News:
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should develop a meaningful political relationship under the concept of a "future one China."
The Liberty Times:
The chief special task force prosecutor blasts the military for failing to cooperate in probing the high-profile 1993 naval captain murder case.
The China Post: President Chen urges upgrade of jet fighters. @The Taiwan News:
Prosecutor blasts military over inadequate evidence to the naval captain murder case.
The Taipei Times:
Investigators storm Chenlan Temple, famous for its support of pilgrimages to mainland China, in search of accounting books allegedly revealing illegal land ownership.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 4, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between fascists and socialists.
1938: The National government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the long-time War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding places in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports to Britain within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake in northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei, who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1981: A US court orders striking air traffic controllers back to work.
1986: ROC-US trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country, and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1997: North Korea hands over the remains of four American soldiers killed during the 1950-1953 Korean War.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary-general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro, sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM AGREE TO INCREASE TWO-WAY PASSENGER TRAFFIC

TEXT.P: Airline representatives from Taiwan and Vietnam have agreed to increase the number of seats available for flights between the two countries in order to meet soaring demand, sources from the Taipei Association of Air Transportation Business said on Friday.

After a day of discussions on Thursday, airline carrier representatives from Taiwan and Vietnam agreed to increase their passenger load factor, or percentage of seats filled, by 50 percent in the years to come beginning from this year.

It was agreed that beginning this winter, 800 seats will be added to the weekly Taiwan-Vietnam flights and return flights, with another 1,200 seats to be added by the winter of 2001. This is expected to largely accommodate consumer demand, said the sources.

At the beginning of discussions on Thursday, Taiwan negotiators asked for an increase of 1,200 seats per week for this winter, while their Vietnamese counterparts agreed to only a 600-seat increase. Later in the day, they compromised and settled on an increase of 800 seats for this year. The two sides are expected to sign a formal agreement on Friday.

Currently, under the 1993 air pact signed between the two sides' airline associations, Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airway together operate 3,759 seats per week, while Vietnam Airlines and Vietnamese Pacific Airlines offer 3,856 seats.
These numbers could hardly meet the soaring demand, particularly after Taiwan suspended direct air links with Manila and stopped accepting more Philippine laborers in recent months, said the sources.

The number of Vietnamese laborers being introduced to Taiwan has increased by leaps and bounds in recent months, making it one of the reasons for the shortage of airplane seats for flights between Vietnam and Taiwan, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 80.27 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 80.27 points to close at 7,925.2 .
Market turnover amounted to NT$68.57 billion (US$2.21 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: US SEES NO INDICATORS IN TAIWAN STRAIT THAT RAISE LEVEL OF CONCERN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Department of State said on Thursday it is closely monitoring mainland China's current military exercises along the southeastern mainland coast opposite Taiwan.
Nevertheless, the State Department said it has so far not seen any indicators that raise its level of concern.
According to mainland China's state media, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is conducting war games involving 110,000 troops along a wide arc of the eastern mainland coast opposite Taiwan.

The Beijing-based People's Daily said combined land, air and sea forces of the Nanjing military district were holding drills along a 6,000 km (3,700 mile) length of the east coast provinces of Jiangsu, Zhejiang and Fujian.
The Chinese Communist Party paper quoted a military spokesman as saying such exercises were "rarely seen in recent years in terms of scope, number of participating troops and thoroughness."

Maritime, amphibious and land drills involving submarines, frogmen, gunboats, paratroopers and attack helicopters were "necessary to prevail in future local wars under high-technology conditions," the PLA spokesman was quoted as saying.

Commenting on the report, a State Department official who asked not to be identified said, "as with all such exercises we are alert for any indicators that warrant concern. So far we have seen no indicators that raise our level of concern."
"We have and will continue to urge both sides to avoid any actions which might increase tensions in the (Taiwan) strait," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 80.27 points to close at 7,925.2.

Encouraged by a surge in the NASDAQ index, favorable government measures, and a rebound after a downward streak, the bourse opened at 7,881.72 and fluctuated between 8,029.14 and 7,856.6 during trading.

A total of 1.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.57 billion (US$2.21 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.51 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$57.67 billion.

Two of the eight major categories posted losses, with cement stocks moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent. Plastics and chemical shares and foodstuff stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 0.4 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 299 to 178, with 109 stocks remaining unchanged.

TAIEX Index Futures for September increased 54 points to finish at 7,989, with 90 contract transaction, while December futures gained 60 points to close at 8,060, with four contract transactions.
Next March futures surged 115 points to close at 8,150, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for next June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 7,915 for August; 7,935 for September; 8,000 for December; 8,035 for next March; and 8,236 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH AIDE STRESSES OPPOSITION TO USE OF FORCE IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: A senior advisor to George W. Bush, the Republican Party's presidential candidate, indicated on Thursday that a new Bush administration would firmly oppose any use of military force in the Taiwan Strait while adhering to the one-China policy.

"The United States has and continues to have a one-China policy," said Robert Zoellick, a former White House deputy chief of staff during the Bush administration and now a senior advisor on foreign policy to the Texas governor.

"What that platform emphasizes is the view that it's important to make it clear to Beijing that any use of force would be counter-productive in its relations with Taiwan and also its relations with the United States," he said.
He was referring to the language pertaining to cross-strait issues in the Republican Party's platform adopted this week at the party's national convention in Philadelphia.
As Bush has frequently stated, Zoellick told reporters, he is "resolutely committed to the Taiwan Relations Act, including helping Taiwan defend itself."
Zoellick said that while holding to the one-China policy, there needs to be a recognition by both Beijing and Taipei that it is in their interest to achieve a peaceful accommodation.
However, he would not say whether an administration under Bush would change its one-China position if mainland China attacks Taiwan.

The Republican Party platform says that the United States "has acknowledged the view that there is one China". But it also says that "our policy is based on the principle that there must be no use of force by China against Taiwan".

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE NAVAL SHIPS TO VISIT US PORTS

TEXT.P: Some Communist Chinese naval ships will visit US ports in Honolulu and San Diego some time later this year or early next year following the USS Chancellorville's current visit to mainland Chinese ports between August 2-5, said Pentagon spokesman Kenneth Bacon on Thursday.

Bacon told a routine Pentagon press briefing that it is the first visit by a US naval ship to a Chinese mainland port, excluding Hong Kong, since 1998. It also represents the first such visit since the tragic bombing of the PRC embassy in Belgrade during Operation Allied Force a little more than a year ago.
"It is part of a military re-engagement program with China that involves mutual ship visits," explained the spokesman.

"We are also obviously increasing high-level contacts. Secretary of Defense William Cohen recently came back from China. Admiral Thomas B. Fargo is now in China, both in Beijing and then accompanying his ship in Qingdao," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUN'S RADIATION PEAKING THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The sun's brightness has been increasing steadily for the past 3 years, but that's no reason for alarm because the change has been expected and astronomers predict that the sun's radiation levels will start reducing again after peaking this year.

On Aug. 7, at the invitation of the International Astronomical Union, Dr. Judith Lean of the Naval Research Laboratory in Washington DC will explain how high precision instruments on board spacecraft have been monitoring the sun for the slightest changes since 1984.

Astronomers at ground-based observatories have studied the sun's activity for the past 400 years by counting the number of dark sunspots on its disk. Their records reveal a repeating cycle in which the number of sunspots hits a maximum approximately every 11 years.

Sunspots are dark and so reduce the sun's total radiation. But another manifestation of solar activity, called faculae, is bright and enhances the sun's output. Typically, the increase due to faculae more than outweighs the decrease due to sunspots. Astronomers can calculate the net effect of these two competing influences.
Since 1997, the sun's activity and brightness has increased steadily. Now, near the predicted time of maximum radiation, levels are 0.06% higher than in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DETERMINED TO JOIN ASEAN PLUS 3 GROUPING

TEXT.P: Australia is determined to join the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus 3 grouping despite the current restrictions imposed by certain member countries, particularly Malaysia, according to the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Department Secretary Ashton Calvert on Thursday told reporters that Australia would exploit every opportunity to "play ourselves into the new dynamic of dialogue and cooperation in East Asia" through the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which is the brainchild of Canberra.

In a speech to the National Press Club in Canberra, Calvert voiced Australia's disappointment and frustration for its exclusion from the ASEAN plus 3 grouping because of what he called "the preference of some participants to restrict membership" -- a criticism mainly of Malaysia's persistent rejection of Australian efforts to join the regional body.

ASEAN plus 3 was formed in Kuala Lumpur in 1997, and Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was the key factor behind the exclusion of Australia. He also blocked Australia from taking part in ASEM -- the Asia-Europe meeting.

Calvert stressed that Australia has the right to take part in ASEAN plus 3 because of its credentials, including its contributions and intellectual input into regional bodies such as APEC, the ASEAN Post Ministerial Council, and other regional bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIALISTS CRITCIZE NUCLEAR POWER, RECOMMEND LNG AND WIND

TEXT.P: A US-based energy systems research specialist on Friday discounted Taiwan Power Company's statements that the replacement of nuclear power would be too costly, saying that Taiwan should end its reliance on this form of energy once and for all.

Dr. Chen Mo-shing, director of the Energy Systems Research Center at the University of Texas at Arlington, said the development of nuclear power worldwide seems to approach a dead end, adding that if nuclear power is indeed irreplaceable as some claim, then "the world is doomed."

Chen, a member of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant Reassessment Committee sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the remarks during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan into possible alternatives to completion of the fourth nuclear power plant by Taipower.

Chen refuted Taipower's statement that the cost of generating electricity at its nuclear power plants averages NT$0.85 per kilowatt-hour, compared with NT$0.89 per kwh at coal-powered thermal plants, saying this claim is "definitely impossible."
He added that Taipower officials had "righteously lied" by compiling and publicizing calculations that seem to justify the use of nuclear power.

Chen, who also teaches at National Taiwan University, strongly recommended that Taipower retain most of its existing facilities at its three nuclear power plants and remodel them into thermal power plants using liquefied natural gas (LNG) as fuel to generate electricity.

Chen said in the present situation, based on Taipower's calculations, where 45.1 percent of Taipower's installed capacity is provided by coal-powered thermal plants, 23.3 percent by nuclear power plants, and 18.8 percent by thermal plants using LNG, it is impossible for Taipower to maintain a clean environment in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lai Ching-lin recommended that Taipower use wind as an alternative method of generating electricity. As an island nation where wind is readily available and costs nothing, Taiwan should abandon nuclear power and use alternative energy sources that don't destroy the island's environment and threaten the lives of the people.

Lai added that Taipower actually already operates four wind-powered generators on Penghu Island, and Taiwan's plastics giant Formosa Plastic Group also has four similar generators to supply electricity for the company's own use.

Wang Ching-chuan, vice president of Chunghsing Electrical Engineering and Machinery Corp., who was also present at the hearing, said solar power should also be used for generating electricity, pointing out that Taipower has already begun to cooperate with privately-run companies to develop related facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the Republic of China's opposition party Kuomingtang, arrived in San Francisco on Thursday for the start of a 14-day North American visit.
Lien and his wife, accompanied by Jason Hu, director of the KMT Department of Cultural Affairs, were greeted warmly by about 200 overseas Chinese and KMT members upon their arrival.

Also on hand to greet the Liens were Ting Shou-chung, a KMT Central Standing Committee member and currently a visiting scholar at Stanford University; Wang Neng-chang, director of the KMT Department of Overseas Affairs; Chiao Jen-ho, former Minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee; and Victor Tseng, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco.

Lien did not answer any questions by reporters, but he did tell supporters briefly that he was heartened by the warm welcome on his first trip to the United States since stepping down from public office in May.

The former vice president said that although the KMT, which gave up power to the Democratic Progressive Party after the March 18 presidential election, has encountered great difficulties, it has not lost its ideals and will not shy away from its responsibilities.
US customs accorded the Liens preferential treatment despite the fact that Lien no longer holds public office.
Lien made several transit stops in the US when he was the ROC vice president, and the US always issued him a visa on an individual basis and accorded him preferential treatment.

The US State Department said that Lien's visa this time was issued on an individual basis, but his movements while in the country will not be subject to restrictions because he is no longer a public official.
It is understood that Lien, who wants to establish a good pattern for future visits, is keeping a low-profile and not engaging in any political activities during his trip.

After a four-day stay in San Francisco, Lien will head for Los Angeles where he will visit his son, who is currently studying at Stanford University. On Aug. 9, he will leave for Vancouver, Canada before returning to Taiwan on Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY AGREES TO PARTIAL DEMINING OF KINMEN COAST

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army General Headquarters on Friday gave a green light to allow the removal of some of the landmines scattered around a power plant that became operational on the frontline island of Kinmen late last year.

Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chen-hsiang, who was making an inspection tour of Kinmen, instructed the Kinmen Defense Command to approve the demining application submitted by the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).

Chen said the army's approval for Taipower to cooperate with private demining companies to remove the landmines from the coast of Tahshan does not necessarily mean that landmines in other coastal areas will be also be removed, as coastal landmines still have a certain value to deter invasion, particularly at a time when cross-Taiwan Strait tension remains high.

Between late last year and June 2, more than 80 anti-personnel and anti-tank landmines have been found exposed on the coastal area outside Taipower's Tahshan plant, where water discharged from the plant has continuously washed away beach sand and exposed the mines.

According to the Kinmen Defense Command, the military authorities have since 1997 contracted noted British demining firm -- Specialist Gurkha Services UK Ltd. -- to clear eight abandoned minefilds in Kinmen villages that now have large civilian populations.

Gurkha Services is staffed mainly by retired Nepalese veterans from Britain's famous Gurkha Regiment. The company has undertaken demining jobs in more than 10 nations around the world, including Afghanistan, Cambodia, Kuwait and Mozambique.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES III TO MAKE MORE EFFORTS ON INTERNET SECURITY R&D

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said during a visit to the Institute for Information Industry (III) on Friday that it will be necessary to integrate the strength of the whole nation to develop Taiwan's information industry.

III President Huang Ho-ming cited the Information Technology Charter newly passed at the just-concluded G-8 summit in explaining to Tang that information technology will have the greatest single influence in the 21st century. He also pointed out that US investment in information technology accounts for up to one-third of the United States' Gross Domestic Product growth rate.

Tang said that efforts must be made to strengthen the nation's information and Internet security research and development in order to consolidate the nation's security and solve such problems as Internet crime and on-line pornography.

In addition, he suggested that Taiwan's financial policies should rely on information technology to help transform and upgrade traditional industries so that Taiwan can perform better in the face of keen global competition.
