DOC.HEADLINE: MSA-ROC TO DEFEND FOR MEMBERSHIP IN IFMSA

TEXT.P: The Medical Students' Association of the Republic of China (MSA-ROC) is to defend its membership of the International Federation of Medical Students' Associations (IFMSA), MSA-ROC Chairman Wang Shi-hsiou said on Friday.

The IFMSA has proposed a revision of its membership regulations that would require member countries to be United Nations members, which means that while mainland China could be admitted, the MSA-ROC would perhaps have to change its name or the status of its membership.

Wang said he will leave for Portugal with 11 Taiwan medical students to take part in an upcoming IFMSA conference, where they will try to convince other member countries of the "unreasonableness" of the proposed new membership requirement.

He pointed out that ROC is not a member of the United Nations, and added that mainland China could use its political clout to edge out the MAS-ROC membership of IFMSA. The delegates are scheduled to meet officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs before they make the trip to Portugal, to discuss an acceptable name should the MAS-ROC be forced to change its name.

The IFMSA was founded in 1951 and is officially recognized by the United Nations as a non-political, non-government organization. Its membership includes students from more than 50 countries all over the world.

Its purpose is to promote international cooperation in professional training and the achievement of humanitarian ideals. It provides medical students with a forum to address related concerns and an opportunity to influence the practice and development of medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC APPROVES SEF PLAN TO INVITE MAINLAND NEGOTIATOR TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday it has approved a Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) proposal to invite a senior mainland Chinese negotiator to Taiwan to resume the long-stalled dialogue.

MAC Vice Chairman Teng Chen-chung was responding to SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's statement on Thursday that SEF will send a letter to mainland China in a few days inviting a deputy secretary-general of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to Taiwan to set the stage for mainland China's top negotiator Wang Daohan to visit this island.

Teng said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland and oversees SEF operations, fully supports Koo's proposal. "We hope mainland China can make a positive response to Koo's invitation," he said, adding that the Republic of China is willing to exercise the greatest possible flexibility on the agenda so long as Beijing agrees to resume talks.

Koo made a landmark visit to Shanghai and Beijing in October 1998 and his mainland counterpart Wang promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan in 1999. However, Beijing announced an indefinite postponement of Wang's visit last September in retaliation for then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui's remarks that cross-strait exchanges should be conducted on a "special state-to-state" basis.

On Thursday, Koo urged Wang to honor his promise to visit Taiwan. "The spring has come and gone, and now there is a new autumn at our doorstep," he noted, adding that SEF will invite an ARATS deputy secretary-general to come over for some consultations about resuming dialogue and paving the way for Wang's Taiwan tour.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Commenting on Koo's remarks, Teng said the new ROC government has never ceased expression of goodwill toward the mainland since its inauguration on May 20.

Teng said both Koo's invitation and President Chen Shui-bian's recent mention of "the spirit of the 1992 meeting" were part of the new ROC government's efforts to foster an atmosphere favorable for resumption of institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue.

In 1992, SEF and ARATS officials held talks on the "one China" issue. Although the two sides failed to reach a unanimous conclusion, they agreed that each side could have its own definition of the "one China."
"And this is what President Chen calls the 'spirit of 1992' which means dialogue, exchange and shelving disputes," Teng explained.

According to Teng, SEF sent a message to ARATS late last month calling for talks on repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants and issues related to a detained mainland boat suspected of involvement in espionage. However, Teng said, ARATS has so far not made any response.

Teng said if ARATS sends a deputy secretary-general to Taiwan, the two sides can discuss a host of practical issues closely related to interests and well-being of the people on both sides, including fishing disputes, emergency rescue and repatriation of illegal immigrants.

The two sides can even discuss technical details regarding proposed opening of direct "mini three links" (trade, mail and transportation) between Taiwan's outlying islands and several mainland Chinese southeastern port cities, such as Xiamen or Fuzhou, Teng said.

As for Wang's Taiwan travel promise, Teng said, the ROC has consistently welcomed the top mainland envoy's visit. "We hope Wang can visit Taiwan as early as possible," Teng said, adding that resumption of cross-strait dialogue needs joint efforts of the two sides and that the timing of Wang's visit will largely be determined by Beijing.

Touching on a newspaper report that mainland China plans to promote cross-strait exchanges of resident journalists, Teng said the ROC will not oppose including the issue into the agenda if SEF and ARATS resume dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALED GOSHAWK RELEASED BACK INTO WILD
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An adult crested goshawk, which was found on the brink of death more than two months ago in the central Taiwan town of Puli, was released to back into the wild on Friday in perfect health.
The crested goshawk, a medium-sized diurnal bird of prey, is a sub-endemic species that enjoys special protection in Taiwan.
The bird, a female, was found in a forest camp site in mountainous Puli and rushed to an endangered species research center run by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture in the town of Chichi.
Believing that the bird had been poisoned, veterinarians at the center treated and cared for it for more than two months until it had fully regained its health.
According to the vets, despite weakness and hunger, the bird refused to eat anything for the first few days, but gradually began to accept baby food and canned dog and cat food.

The 45-cm long raptor bearing dark brown plumage with striking horizontal barring on its breast, was recently let out of its cage and was found to have retained its ability to hunt its normal prey of small birds and animals, said the vets.

Crested goshawks are considered an indicator bird of Taiwan's environment, as it is a species at the top of the island's food chain, which makes it very vulnerable to environmental pollution and harm, according to bird specialists.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO PRESENT PREFERENTIAL HOME LOANS FOR YOUNG PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will present a preferential home loan package on Monday especially for young people, Vice Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang confirmed on Friday.

The package includes low interest loans totaling NT$100 billion (US$3.2 billion) and a reduction in down payments for each house buyer. The package will have age and loan volume restrictions and will be limited to first-time buyers.
The program was one of the major campaign promises made by President Chen Shui-bian during the Republic of China's presidential elections in March.

Yen noted that there is a housing surplus in Taiwan and he warned local builders not to "blindly expand" their construction projects to take advantage of the rich pickings offered by the loan package.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS TO VISIT JAPAN, KOREA

TEXT.P: A group of 13 legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), led by Legislator Trong Chai, is scheduled to leave on Sunday for a weeklong visit to Japan and Korea.
A source close to the group said that the legislators of the DPP's Mainstream Alliance had originally planned to visit mainland China but later altered its schedule.

While in Japan, they will call on Toshio Goto, chairman of Japan's Interchange Association, which handles Japanese interests in the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, as well as paying a visit to the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council and the Diet.
They will also call on the Japan-Taiwan Dietmen Amity Association of Japan's opposition Democratic Party and meet with correspondents from Taiwan stationed in Japan.

They will conclude their Japanese trip on Wednesday and proceed to Seoul for a three-day visit where they will be briefed by the Taipei Mission in Korea on the current situation on the Korean peninsula.
They will visit the Korean parliament, lunch with members of the Korea-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendly Association, and call on the ruling Millennium Democratic Party and the National Party.
They will then call on the Federation of Korean Industries and visit the Democratic Liberal Party and the Korean Foreign Trade Association before returning to Taipei on Aug. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADER CALLS FOR MORE HIGH-TECH TALENT FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A local business leader on Friday urged the government to speed up the introduction of high-tech talent from mainland China and other parts of the world.

Richard Wu, chairman of the Taiwan Electric & Electronic Manufacturer's Association, made the appeal during a call on Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), prior to his departure for the mainland.

Wu spoke of the deficiency of local high-tech talent and expressed the hope that high-tech talent from the mainland can be recruited on year-long contracts to work in Taiwan. He also said the government should lift its ban on "three direct links" -- direct trade, postal and transport cross-strait links -- to cut shipment costs.

Wu also suggested that the government permit Taiwan banks to set up branches in the mainland, saying that "Chinese should help Chinese" and that the move would help take care of the problems of deposits and loans of Taiwan businessmen in the mainland.
Wu said that Tsai listened carefully to his suggestions, but did not respond to them.
Also attending the meeting was Fu Tung-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELIVERY TRUCK CARRYING US$3 MILLION IN COMPUTER PARTS HIJACKED
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: An express delivery truck carrying computer parts worth about NT$100 million (US$3.2 million) was hijacked on Friday in what the delivery company said was the latest in a series of hijackings over the past three months.

The Taipei-based Jih Tung Express truck and less than 20 percent of its high-tech cargo was later discovered abandoned off a remote road kilometers from the expressway where it had been waved down and hijacked in the early morning hours.
Police said that they dusted the truck and boxes strewn in a clearing approximately 200 meters from the truck for fingerprints and returned what was left to the delivery company.
They added that they were investigating the truck driver's personal acquaintances and how the suspects were able to find out about the truck's delivery route and schedule.
A spokesman for Jih Tung said that the losses totaled around NT$100 million, and that the recovered goods represented the less valuable part of the shipment.

The truck driver, Chin Jung-hua, said he had been heading south on the expressway when he stopped at 3 a.m. on the Chungching interchange in the central Taiwan county of Taichung to offer assistance to a passenger car that was blocking the road.

Chin said the car contained four men in their 20's who claimed the car had broken down. They allegedly covered Chin's mouth and nose with what he suspected was a towel drenched in sedatives, beat him, and dumped him in the hills outside Fengyuan, a small town near Taichung.
Chin suffered minor injuries to his chin and abdomen, but was reported to be in good condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO SUBSIDIZE AIDS SCREENING

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will use some of its reserve funds to subsidize a screening program for the AIDS virus, starting from September, officials of the Department of Health (DOH) said on Friday.

NT$30 million (US$0.97 million) is to be made available for a pilot scheme to screen pregnant women for the virus, and the program will be expanded to become regular next year if it is found to be effective, the officials said, adding that the cost of the full program is expected to exceed NT$60 million per year.
To date, local AIDS-infected mothers have given birth to six infants born with the disease, according to DOH statistics.
If pregnant women screen positive for AIDS within 24 weeks of becoming pregnant, they can choose to terminate the pregnancy under the Genetic Health Law or accept the drug cocktail treatment.

The DOH also pointed out the risk to medical personnel who assist with deliveries without being aware that the mother is infected. It said AIDS-infected pregnant women can seek help from the DOH, which will provide qualified doctors to deliver their babies. This will allow patients to keep their privacy while ensuring the safety of the attending medical personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE ROC GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS SUED FOR HOLDING DUAL NATIONALITY

TEXT.P: A Taipei citizen lodged a lawsuit with the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office on Friday against three ranking government officials for illegally holding dual nationality.

Hsu Mu-min sued Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, Education Minister J.L. Tzeng and Yang Huang Mei-hsin, vice chief of the Research and Planning Board under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, for fraud and for breaking the Republic of China Nationality Law by holding passports of both the ROC and the United States.

Hsu said he decided to file the lawsuit against the three officials, because he believes that the three still possess US nationality, although according to local media reports, the three had applied at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) to renounce their US nationality in mid-May and June.

Hsu pointed out that under US federal law, naturalized US nationals wishing to abandon their US nationality are required to complete the process by taking an oath under the witness of a US ambassador or consul.

He went on to point out that the AIT, the US representative office in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries, is not a US embassy, nor are AIT officials formal US diplomats.

Claiming that AIT officials had responded to his inquiry by confirming that their office does not have the authority to legalize such an act, Hsu said he suspects the three lied about their status in order to acquire the government posts. Should they have failed to renounce their US nationality, they would have already violated the ROC Nationality Law and committed fraud, he noted.

Citing Article 20 of the ROC Nationality Law, Hsu said: "Those ROC nationals who possess foreign nationality are not entitled to take ROC public office ... and those who have already served in the government should be stripped of their public office."

DOC.HEADLINE: WEEKLONG TORRENTIAL RAIN TAKES TOLL ON TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Weeklong heavy rain has taken a heavy toll on Taiwan's agriculture, causing damage worth NT$180 million (US$5.8 million), the Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Friday.

A southeasterly airstream passing that has affected the island since July 27 has packed extremely high humidity and has triggered heavy precipitation in various regions of eight counties in central and southern Taiwan.
The heavy rains have sparked mudslides in mountainous areas and flooded many hectares of farmland on the western plains.
The COA estimated that vegetables and fruit in Kaohsiung, Tainan, Pintung, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi and Taitung counties have suffered combined damage of about NT$178 million.

The extent of the damage has make farmers in the eight counties eligible for soft loans from the government, allowing them to borrow NT$250,000 (US$8,064) for every hectare of their farmland at an interest rate of 4.5 percent over five years, said the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT OUTLINES POLICY GOALS IN INTERVIEW WITH WEEKLY (I)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said in a recent interview with a US business weekly that the people of Taiwan expect his administration to take them back into the United Nations.

"Naturally, we face some difficulties, but we must not give up (our UN bid). At the same time, we must try to participate in other international organizations," Chen said in an interview with Business Week Asia Regional Editor Mark L. Clifford.

Chen gave the interview at his Taipei office on July 27 and edited extracts were carried in the Aug. 14 issue of the weekly. In the interview, Chen indicated his eagerness to talk with Beijing and promote peace in the Taiwan Strait. He also presented his views on Taiwan's diplomatic and security issues.

The longtime opposition politician-turned-president made it clear that despite Beijing's opposition and boycott, he will continue the former ROC government's policies of visiting friendly foreign countries, seeking Taiwan's representation in the UN and other international bodies and supporting continued research into the US-developed theater missile defense (TMD) system.
Asked what he hopes to accomplish during his term in office, Chen said promoting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is not only his top priority but also "a moral obligation."
"Next, we need to clean up Taiwan politics," Chen said, adding that he will work hard to terminate "black gold," or corruption and gangster involvement in politics.
In addition, Chen said his administration must ensure economic prosperity and progress. "We will work to create an improved climate for investment and business," he added.
Touching on his campaign promise to "expand Taiwan's room for survival in the international arena," Chen recalled that in his inaugural speech, he said Taiwan stands up.

"That means I must also go out into the world as the leader of a sovereign and independent country...We hope to enhance the substantial relationship between Taiwan and our diplomatic friends," Chen explained.

Asked whether he is concerned that Beijing will be enraged by his upcoming state visits abroad, Chen said: "I believe that as President of a sovereign state, going abroad and exchanging meetings with our diplomatic friends is my duty."

Turning to the US role in the Taiwan Strait region, Chen said he is convinced that permanent peace, security and stability in the area are not only in the interests of Taiwan but also in the interests of the United States.
"I believe we can cooperate on this. I think the US can play a more active role -- a balancer and stabilizer," Chen noted.
He went on to point out that the issue of TMD exists because of mainland China's deployment of missiles along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan.
"This has been a threat to the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific region. This is why the US is considering the development of TMD," Chen said.
Noting that TMD is not yet fully developed, Chen said it is too early whether Taiwan would invest in this project. But he added that the ROC government is seriously studying this policy.

Chen further said the ROC government is fully aware that "TMD is not absolute" in terms of resolving cross-Taiwan Strait problems. "We must use creativity and wisdom to improve cross-Strait relations."
As for the current state of cross-strait ties, Chen said although there are no significant breakthroughs, the situation has not worsened.

"In terms of cross-Strait relations, it is not seen as tense right now. There is not a sense of urgency or of crisis... We hope to sit down and resume negotiations. We can only do that by offering goodwill and through the wisdom of leaders on both sides. I have confidence that relations can improve. We feel it is most important to sit down and talk without prejudice. We should put aside our differences and seek a foundation that is acceptable to both sides," Chen said. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT (II)
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Asked whether Taiwan and mainland China can negotiate on the basis of the 1992 consensus about "one China," Chen said that according to Taipei's understanding, in 1992, there was discussion of a so-called "one China."

"However, there was a disagreement and no consensus. Most Taiwanese people cannot accept Taiwan becoming a second Hong Kong or a second Macau," Chen said, adding that the people of Taiwan cannot accept the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" formula applied to Hong Kong and Macau.
Nor can the majority of Taiwan people accept the "one China" principle if it is interpreted as Taiwan become part of the PRC (People's Republic of China), Chen reiterated.

Asked what mainland China can learn from his election victory, Chen said the results of the ROC's March 18 presidential election demonstrate that the PRC leadership does not understand the Taiwanese people.
"Over the past two presidential elections, they have applied the same methods of threats and intimidation. However, the choices of the people of Taiwan have proven them wrong," Chen said.

He further said the PRC doesn't understand his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). "Nor do they understand me. They believe that a DPP victory would bring a declaration of independence. Thus far, my cross-Strait policy has been supported by 70 percent of the people in this country. It represents a consensus of the Taiwan people... The PRC leadership listens to people who visit China and often misleads them. The information they get is far from the truth. This lead to miscalculations and misjudgments on their part. They must learn from the election result. They need to get to know me, and they need to get to know the DPP."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMPORTS MORE CALIFORNIA PEACHES THAN ANY OTHER COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the largest importer of California peaches in the world, according to the latest statistics compiled by the California Tree Fruit Agreement (CTFA).

Steven Chu, the CTFA's local representative, said on Friday that although the United States is currently the major supplier of agricultural products for Taiwan, US producers will face greater challenges and competitive pressure from the rest of the world after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.

CTFA records showed that Taiwan is not only a major importer of California peaches, at 40,000 metric tons per year, but that it also gobbles up the world's second largest amount of imported California grapes, at about 16,000 metric tons per year.
Taiwan is also the second largest importer of California cherries and the fifth largest importer of Florida grapefruits.
The CTFA is an association that promotes US agricultural products around the world, including California peaches, nectarines, plums, prunes, grapes, and cherries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF A CHINESE RADIO STATION IN SERIOUS TROUBLE

TEXT.P: The top official of a Chinese radio station in southeastern Guangdong province has found himself in serious trouble, because a brief comment criticizing the Communist party by the audience was broadcast inadvertently on July 27.

On that day a caller said, among other things, in the "Today's Hotline" talk show program of the Guangdong People's Radio Station, that "There is no cure for such a corrupt government, unless the Communist regime steps down," the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy reported Friday.
The information center said that the radio station, which is not supposed to broadcast such kind of opinion, is now in trouble, and that its president Zeng Guangxing might be fired as a result.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT JOURNALIST EXCHANGE A PRACTICAL ISSUE: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China's desire to exchange resident journalists with Taiwan is one example of a situation in which both sides need to put aside their political disputes and seek to resolve practical issues of mutual concern through systematic channels, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman John Deng said on Friday.

Deng made the remarks at a regular news conference while answering questions from the local press about a report by mainland Chinese media that Beijing is planning to discuss with relevant Taiwan authorities the exchange of journalists, and that the mainland's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under the State Council has already approved such an application by Xinhua News Agency.
Xinhua, Beijing's official mouthpiece, reportedly will submit an application for that purpose with the Taipei-based Government Information Office (GIO) in the near future.
According to Deng, the Republic of China government will process mainland China's application in abidance by the nation's laws as long as the mainland duly files the application as required.
As the issue is related to the enforcement of regulations, Deng called on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume their talks as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA CHAIRMAN TO JOIN ROC PRESIDENT ON FOREIGN TRIP

TEXT.P: Chairman Isqaqavut Yohani of the newly-established Council of Aboriginal Affairs (CAA) said on Friday that he will join Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on his official visit to several countries in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa later this month.
Yohani's presence will not only demonstrate the achievements of the island's aborigines, but also help improve the status of aboriginal peoples in the ROC's diplomatic allies, he told CNA.

Government officials say that in addition to Yohani, an aboriginal performance troupe under the CAA's Cultural Garden Area Administration in Southern Taiwan's Pingtung County will accompany Chen on his first overseas trip as president.
The officials noted that the main purpose of their arrangements were to promote cultural exchanges between the ROC and its allies, and to help improve the welfare of the aborigines there.

In order to promote mutual understanding between the aborigines of Taiwan and the Commonwealth of Dominica, a 13-member delegation from that country will visit the Cultural Garden Area Administration on Aug. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FOLK PERFORMANCE TROUPE TO MAKE 20-DAY TOUR OF CANADA

TEXT.P: A folk arts performance troupe comprised of youngsters from Taipei will soon head for Canada, where they are scheduled for a 20-day tour.

The troupe's 26 members are students from Hsi-yuan Elementary School and Hung-dao Junior High School. The group's dress rehearsal on Friday was a brilliant demonstration of rope skipping and traditional dance, as well as other forms of folk entertainment, officials of the Ministry of Education (MOE) said.

The officials added that the troupe will stage a public performance at Taipei City Hall on Aug. 11. Lee Hsi-Jin, director of the Bureau of Education, will then accompany the young performers on their tour of Canada. The troupe is scheduled to depart Taiwan on Aug. 13 and will perform in Vancouver, Edmonton, Ottawa, Toronto, and Montreal.
Meanwhile, they will also visit local governments, schools, and overseas Chinese communities.

Taipei City Government each year selects talented elementary school and high school students to travel and perform throughout the world. These young ambassadors are responsible for visiting international friends and overseas Chinese.

Taipei students also often perform in international folk festivals, as well as athletic and academic meetings. They have not only played an important role on their goodwill missions, but introduced Taiwan's multicultural folk arts to the entire world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAUNCHES UN BID FOR 8TH TIME

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has launched a new push to join the United Nations as 12 of its diplomatic allies have jointly submitted a proposal asking the world body to consider its representation, a senior official said on Friday.

Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan told a news conference that 12 ROC allies presented the proposal to the UN Secretary General on Aug. 3, requesting the UN to set up a working group to examine the exceptional international situation pertaining to the ROC, and to ensure the right of its 23 million people to participate in the UN and its related agencies.

According to Wu, the 12 allies were Senegal, Grenada, the Gambia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, the Marshall Islands, Nicaragua, Swaziland, the Solomon Islands, Nauru, Burkina Faso, Malawi and Honduras.

Wu said the UN representatives of the 12 countries submitted a joint letter to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan on Thursday requesting the inclusion of the proposal as a supplementary item in the agenda of the 55th plenary session of the General Assembly scheduled to open in September.

The proposal bears the title "Need to examine the exceptional international situation pertaining to the Republic of China on Taiwan, to ensure that the fundamental right of its 23 million people to participate in the work and activities of the United Nations is fully respected."

The ROC has launched an annual bid to seek UN representation since 1993, but this year's drive was the first by the new government under President Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party. Chen swept to power in March 18 presidential election, ending Kuomintang's 55-year political monopoly in Taiwan.
Wu said an explanatory memorandum with the proper justification for the proposal is attached to the joint letter to the UN Secretary General.
According to Wu, the memorandum first pointed out that Tuvalu's admission to the UN later this year will leave the ROC "the only country in the world that remains excluded from the United Nations."
It then indicated that the ROC and the PRC have coexisted for more than 50 years on their respective sides of the Taiwan Strait, with neither subject to the other's rule.

"However, the UN General Assembly Resolution 2758 failed to address this reality. The ROC has been excluded from all UN activities, and even been blocked from participating in non-governmental international activities," the memorandum regretted.

It further said the ROC completed its first-ever democratic peaceful transfer of power between different political parties in May. Moreover, the memorandum said, "the ROC has been playing an active role in international cooperation programs and humanitarian relief operations, and is willing to integrate itself into the international human rights system spearheaded by the UN."
The memorandum went on to stress that the ROC has continuously expressed its good faith to the PRC with an aim to improve cross-strait relations.

"The ROC government believes that its participation in the UN would enable both sides to work and cooperate in the UN and its related agencies, and thus gradually build mutual trust and accelerate the peace process in the Taiwan Strait," the memorandum, adding that at the same time, the UN could live up to its principle of universality and achieve its goal of preventive diplomacy by accepting the ROC's participation.
The memorandum also said the ROC has repeatedly stressed that its bid for UN representation is not intended to challenge the PRC's membership in the UN.

"However, the PRC must acknowledge that Taiwan is a full-fledged democratic society today. Threats and intimidation can only do harm to the feelings of the people on both sides. Only when the PRC acknowledges the existence of the ROC can cross-strait relations develop in a positive direction and in a mutually beneficial way," it noted.

Mainland China strongly opposes a UN representation for Taiwan and has successfully blocked the island's membership bid each time. President Chen said on Monday he did not expect the island to have a significant breakthrough in its UN membership drive this year, but said this was something the government had to do.

DOC.HEADLINE: COASTAL PATROL ARRESTS 14 MAINLAND CHINESE STOWAWAYS
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Coastal patrol officers on Friday arrested 14 stowaways from mainland China who had made their way ashore near a fishing port in northwestern Taiwan.
The officials also arrested Chuang Hung-yang, a Taiwan native who allegedly ran a barricade with his van, which was carrying 18 stowaways. Chuang denied any involvement in the case.
Patrol officers are searching for the four other stowaways, who are still on the run.

The captured stowaways said that they each paid 10,000 to 30,000 renminbi to come to Taiwan, adding that they left mainland China's Fujian province the night before on a speedboat and rendezvoused with Chuang at around 1:30 a.m. on Friday.
The authorities are investigating how the 18 stowaways were able to avoid radar surveillance when they landed at Hsinchu.
Coastal patrol officers said that they had earlier received an informer's report claiming that the stowaways were preparing to land in Hsinchu.
They set up barricades along all major intersections in the vicinity, and were about to wave down an approaching van for inspection when it accelerated and broke through a barricade.

Chuang and the mainlanders abandoned their vehicle and fled on foot after coastal patrol officers continued to give chase, and a blanket search involving over 200 coastal patrol officers yielded the arrests.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM TO START PRIVATIZATION IN LATE AUGUST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Friday approved a plan to auction off three percent of the government's stake in Chunghwa Telecom within two weeks, in the company's first step toward privatization.

The offered price for each of the over 289 million shares up for grabs was set at NT$104 (US$3.35) on Friday by a share price appraisal committee comprised of officials of government departments concerned.
Buyers must purchase a minimum of 5,000 shares, while the maximum number a single investor will be allowed to buy is 5,000,000 shares, said Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan.
The auction is part of the first phase of a privatization plan in which a total of 33 percent of Chunghwa Telecom will be sold off.
It is expected that the auction will augment government coffers by at least NT$30 billion.

The government will also release 13 percent of shares for public subscription in Taiwan, five percent for company employees subscription, and 12 percent for listing on the New York Stock Exchange. The first phase of privatization is expected to be completed by the end of this year.
The government plans to release another 33 percent of its shares in Chunghwa Telecom starting in February next year, with a goal of complete privatization by the end of June.
The two phases of privatization are expected to raise at least NT$660 billion for the government.
At present, Chunghwa Telecom is totally owned by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and has a total capital of NT$96.48 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROUNDTABLE MEETING SHOULD NOT AFFECT DEMOCRATIC MECHANISM: KMT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will not refuse to meet with the heads of rival political parties in a roundtable meeting called by President Chen Shui-bian, but the public should not view the meeting as overly dramatic, a KMT official said on Thursday.

Jason Hu, head of the KMT's Cultural Affairs Department, said a gathering between heads of different political parties is a natural thing, and that the public should not exaggerate or dramatize such a matter.

Claiming that the KMT is not opposed to a plan for a roundtable meeting by President Chen Shui-bian, in which he would meet with rival party leaders to discuss major national issues, Hu pointed out that such a meeting should not turn out to be a formality, and would not represent a sign of "political reconciliation."

Calling on the public to give the KMT space, Hu said the KMT is determined to play its role as an effective opposition party and added that any "roundtable meeting" should not hinder the normal systematic mechanism in a democratic country.
Hu, who is accompanying Lien on a North American tour, made the remarks upon arrival at the airport here.

Meanwhile, some local experts attending a seminar in Taipei criticized Chen's idea of holding a roundtable meeting as a trick which is only aimed at satisfying the goals of his "political propaganda."

Lin Cho-shui, a lawmaker of the ruling pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, said Chen should do his best in the planned meeting to forge a consensus with Lien and leaders of other parties on issues such as national security, foreign policy and cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

In addition to that, the president should also try to find ways with the heads of the opposition parties to dissolve the current confrontation between the legislative and administrative branches of the government, he added, warning that greater disorder for the nation is in store if the situation continues.
Y. C. Liu, an Academia Sinica researcher, said he highly doubts that any conclusions made in the roundtable meeting would have any legal basis.

Liu predicted that the meeting would be only a political game, if Chen and the heads of the three other major parties cannot even reach consensus on Taiwan's political fundamentals and major problems.
He suggested that Chen and Lien as well as People First Party Chairman James Soong and New Party leader Hau Lung-bin hold a closed-door meeting first to clear the way for a formal roundtable meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT JOURNALIST EXCHANGE SUBJECT TO GOV'T M'LAND POLICY: GIO HEAD

TEXT.P: Government Informataion Office (GIO) Director General Chung Chin said on Friday that GIO is mapping out procedures for making an exchange of permanently-stationed journalists across the strait.
Chung however said that the final decision will be based on the government's mainland affairs policy.

Chung made the remarks in a reaction to a local news report that Beijing has authorized its agency in charge of Taiwan affairs to work out a plan under which Beijing will send journalists to be stationed in Taiwan in two separate stages.

She said the GIO believes that the cross-strait journalist exchange will be eventually implemented, pointing out that both the GIO and the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) have already made preparations. The GIO plan should be in step with Taiwan's broader mainland policy, which is worked out by the MAC, Chung stressed.

Actually, a cross-strait exchange of permanently-stationed reporters had been discussed during the previous administration, Chung said, adding that David Lee and Su Chi, former directors-general of the GIO, had already taken up the issue. However, it had not been deemed proper for mainland Chinese reporters to be stationed permanently in Taiwan after careful consideration of the cross-strait situation at that time, she said.

She said that an exchange of journalists between Taiwan and mainland China would have a positive meaning. No matter what form the exchange takes, the GIO hopes that the swap will promote further interchange between Taiwan and mainland China, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMBERS OF SUPRA-PARTY COMMITTEE TO BE ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will announce the members of the projected supra-party committee on Saturday, as attention focuses on whether or not the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) will boycott it.

Lee has been entrusted by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to head the committee to offer advice to the president, mainly on matters related to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The committee was originally scheduled to be established by the end of July, but the schedule has been delayed by the boycott of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party.

The three opposition parties have been reluctant to support the forming of the committee because they say that the National Unification Council is functioning well enough to handle cross-strait affairs.

According to the organizing group of the advisory committee, it will have 21-29 members -- four from the KMT, three from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), two from the PFP, one from the New Party, one non-partisan, four to six from academia, two to four from economic circles, and three to five from society at large.
So far, the three members from the DPP have been decided -- Legislator Lin Cho-shui (Taipei City), Legislator Tsai Tung-jung (Chiayi City) and DPP China Affairs Department Director Yen Chien-fa.
Other designated members include former Tsinghua University President Shen Chun-shan, Academic Sinica researcher Hsiao Hsin-huang, painter Liang Tan-feng, and Legislator Chu Hui-liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS WITH COUNTERPARTS OF FOUR CARIBBEAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: An annual meeting of foreign ministers of the Republic of China and its four tiny allies in the Eastern Caribbean occurred in Taipei on Friday.

The ROC offered aid to the allies and they in return reaffirmed for their support for Taiwan's bid for access to international organizations, according to a joint communique signed by attending officials at the end of the annual conference.

The meeting brought together ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, Dominican Republic's Premier and Foreign Minister Roosevelt Douglas, Saint Christopher and Nevis Vice President and Foreign Minister Sam Condor, Grenada Foreign Minister Mark Issac, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Foreign Minister Allan Cruickshank.
Tien told a press conference after the meeting that Taiwan has agreed to extend US$2.5 million in loans to Dominican Republic to boost its sagging banana exports, the lifeline of that state.

Taiwan also offered to each of the four states grants of US$100,000 for the development of manpower resources, US$60,000 for the purchase of computer equipment, and US$100,000 for the improvement of medical equipment.

Tien deliberately expressed thanks to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Christopher and Nevis, and Grenada for sponsoring a United Nation proposal to put Taiwan's UN bid on the agenda of the body's assembly this year.

Noting that Taiwan is fully-qualified to be a UN member, Tien disputed claims that Taiwan is engaging in "checkbook diplomacy", a term which refers to paying tiny UN member-states to support Taiwan's bids for UN access.
Douglas echoed Tien's view by saying that his country supports Taipei's UN bid because it believes the ROC and its 23 million people deserve a seat at the UN.
Asked by reporters about Beijing's ploy to lure the four ROC allies away, Tien said he was confident that Taiwan's ties with the four nations are secure and firm.
Cruickshank supported Tien's view, saying at the press conference that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines supports the ROC because they share the same values of peace and democracy.

Premier Tang Fei met with the foreign ministers of the four states on Friday evening, and reiterated Taipei's willingness to share with them the island's experience in development. Tang also thanked them for their steadfast support of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S LATEST UN BID WORDED DIFFERENTLY, BUT MEANING IS SAME

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's latest bid to seek re-admittance into the United Nations is worded differently because a new ruling party is at the helm, but Taiwan's stance remains essentially the same, the ROC foreign minister said on Friday.

Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao noted that changes in some of the bid's wording and content happen every year, and added his hope that people will not dwell too much on the words, because they are merely "portrayals of the facts."

Tien said that the bid stresses the hope of the 23 million people living here to be seen as living in a sovereign state, and to join the UN and other international organizations under this designation.

Twelve of the ROC's allies filed the bid on Taiwan's behalf earlier in the day. Last September, a similar proposal demanding that the UN reconsider Taiwan's representation issue again failed to make the agenda for the 1999 UN General Assembly plenary session due to pressure from mainland China.

This year's bid includes an explanatory memorandum, a draft resolution, and a joint letter to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan requesting the inclusion of the proposal as a supplementary item in the agenda of the 55th plenary session of the General Assembly scheduled to open in September.
Tien said that Taiwan settled on the final version of its proposal with "careful consideration" and included opinions from all quarters within the Executive Yuan.

He went on to say that this year's version does away with words such as "the Republic of China on Taiwan," "the Republic of China in mainland China," and "democratic reunification" so as to avoid unnecessary speculation that the new ROC government may be trying to tell mainland China about its position on cross-strait relations through the documents.

He added that the wording was also carefully chosen to avoid contradicting newly-elected ROC President Chen Shui-bian's statements on "a future one China," the "one China" issue, "one China, respective interpretations," and the "1992 spirit" -- referring to that year's consensus with mainland China.
The Republic of China was a founding member of the United Nations and has continually sought re-admittance to it since mainland China took over the ROC seat in 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING VOICES OPPOSITION TO CHEN'S TRANSIT STOP IN L.A.: PAPER

TEXT.P: Washington, Aug. 4 (CNA): The Washington Times reported Friday that Communist China has expressed to the United States its opposition to ROC President Chen Shui-bian's scheduled "transit stop" in Los Angeles on his way to visit Latin American countries later this month.

But the conservative newspaper quoted Clinton administration officials as saying that the visit is not expected to touch off another Taiwan crisis, as occurred following the 1995 visit to the United States by Mr. Chen's predecessor, Lee Teng-hui.

Upon arrival on Aug. 13, one day before the start of the Democratic national Convention, Mr. Chen will be greeted by Richard Bush, Board Chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan. The States Department calls the visit a "transit stop" and does not expect the new president to do public appearances or media interviews, said Clinton administration officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

The Beijing regime, however, opposes the one-day visit and has expressed its views to US officials in Washington and in Beijing, Zhang Yuanyuan, press spokesman for the PRC embassy in Washington told the newspaper.

"Of course we're opposed to this kind of action on the part of the US government," Zhang said in an interview. "Especially when the new Taiwanese leader, since his coming to power last March, has not embraced the one-China principle. This kind of action might send some wrong singles to the forces in Taiwan that promote separatism and independence."

"They always make this kind of comment," retorted Eric Chiang, information division director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington, when asked about Beijing's opposition. "We don't think that helps to promote the atmosphere between the two sides," he said.

The Washington Times noted that although the State Department and the White House said the stop was routine, but officials acknowledged there could be political fallout from Beijing any time the leader of Taiwan comes to the United States.

Asked whether Mr. Chen is restricted from holding meetings or giving press interviews, the State Department official said, "We understand Mr. Chen's activities will be private and consistent with the purpose of a transit stop." Such stops are granted for senior Taiwan leaders' safety, comfort and convenience" on a case-by-case basis. "We understand there will be no public and media events," added the official. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 5 or the sixth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother, William Rufus, was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Friderick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The ROC and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction (JCRR) with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen, and Shen Chung-han from the ROC and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the US as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The US 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road, following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes an historic 2,000 mile (3,200 km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of president of the Executive Yuan, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: US Representatives Robert Leggett, Robert McClory and Floyd Spence arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High Scholl baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series at Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension of the Sino-Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation for two years.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The Executive Yuan approves an agreement to void double taxation and prevent tax evasion between the Republic of China and Thailand.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 83.77 points to close at 7,841.43.
The bourse opened at 7,926.79, but due to a plunge in some mother board stocks, share prices began to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 7,982.71 and 7,834.13 during trading.

A total of 1.28 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.66 billion (US$1.67 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.52 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$68.57 billion.

Half of the eight major categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement shares at 0.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.4 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.9 percent, and textile issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 302 to 198, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MINIMIZES SIGNIFICANCE OF GRANTING ROC PRESIDENT VISA

TEXT.P: Clinton administration officials Friday minimized the political importance of the decision to allow ROC President Chen Shui-bian to stay in Los Angeles overnight later this month after Communist China lodged a protest against the move.

The officials said there will be no official welcome for, or meetings with, Taiwan's leader, adding that the granting of the transit visa to Mr. Chen has ample precedent and signals no change in the United State's China policy.

Both the PRC foreign ministry and its embassy in Washington lodged protests over the decision to allow Mr. Chen to make a stopover in Los Angeles on Aug. 13 while on his way to visit six Caribbean and African states that have diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
Communist Chinese spokesmen pointed out that the visa decision "may send some wrong signals to forces in Taiwan that promote separatism and independence."

However, the US State Department noted that Mr. Chen will have no meetings with Clinton administration officials and that giving permission for transit stops by senior Taiwan leaders is nothing new and consistent with long-standing US policy and practice.

Mr. Chen will be met in Los Angeles by Richard Bush, head of the non-governmental American Institute in Taiwan, which handles unofficial US relations with Taipei. American officials also said it is "understood" that Mr. Chen will not hold any interviews with the media or make any public appearances during his brief stay in the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATOR HOPES US WOULD REVIEW TAIWAN POLICY

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China legislator on Friday expressed the hope that a new US administration will thoroughly review US policy toward Taiwan so as to remedy the damage inflicted by President Bill Clinton's "Three Noes" policy statement in Shanghai last year.

When addressing the Washington-based Heritage Foundation on "Cross-Strait Relations: A Taiwanese View," Parris Chang said it would be even better if the new administration could discard the "one China" notion as presented by Beijing.

The former University of Pennsylvania professor pointed out that by stating the United States does not support "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," does not support the independence of Taiwan, and does not believe Taiwan should be a member of international organizations that require statehood for membership, Clinton "somehow tried to determine Taiwan's destiny by himself."

While the balance of power across the Taiwan Straits is tilting in favor of Beijing, Chang accused the Clinton administration of not only rejecting Taiwan's request to buy Aegis destroyers and other advanced weapons systems to counter the growing Communist Chinese missile threat, but also of not faithfully implementing the Taiwan Relations Act with regard to Taiwan's defense needs.
As to Taiwan's continuing efforts to join the United Nations, Chang said denying Taiwan UN membership is a "violation of the human rights of the 23 million people on Taiwan."

"If Beijing really cares about the people of Taiwan as it claims, then it should not block Taiwan's bid to enter such non-political international bodies as the World Health Organization, World Bank, and International Monetary Fund," he added.

He emphasized that Taiwan is not a trouble-maker because the government of President Chen Shui-bian has offered to resume cross-strait dialogue, to improve bilateral relations with the mainland, to establish direct communication links, and even to discuss "the future one China" and peaceful reunification.

Chang noted that Beijing has refused to respond positively to these overtures and insist that Mr. Chen has not embraced the "one China" principle. "It is Beijing's problem for not trusting Mr. Chen," he said, adding that Mr. Chen deserves some encouragement for his offers of constructive engagement with mainland China.

However, Chang also noted that it is very difficult for the two sides to discuss peaceful reunification right now, given the stark contrast in political, economic, and social conditions across the Straits.
If the mainland democratizes and becomes a real free market economy as Taiwan has already done, then the timing for peaceful reunification would come naturally, he continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO IMPROVE KAOHSIUNG WATER QUALITY, NO NEW RESERVOIR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged on Saturday that his administration will spend NT$15 billion (US$483.87 million) over the next three years improving the quality of tap water in the Greater Kaohsiung area in southern Taiwan.
Chen offered the promise during an inspection tour of a water purification plant near the Chengching Lake on the outskirts of the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Chen also declared that he will honor his campaign check not to construct a controversial reservoir in the beautiful Kaohsiung County township of Meinung during his tenure.
"So long as I'm in office, construction of the controversial Meinung Reservoir will be nowhere in sight," Chen stressed.

The president pointed out that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has drafted short-, medium- and long-term packages of measures to ensure adequate tap water supplies for residents in the Greater Kaohsiung area comprising Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.

"Instead of constructing a new reservoir in Meinung, broached by the previous Kuomintang government, we will adopt other strategies and substitute measures to resolve the Kaohsiung area's water shortage problems," Chen explained.

Noting that short supply and poor quality of drinking water have troubled many residents in the Greater Kaohsiung area, Chen said his administration is determined to carry out a number of programs to ensure fully supply and improve water quality over the next three fiscal years.

The projects will include construction of a highly advanced water purification facility, installation of new water quality improvement and monitoring systems, renovation of the existing Nanhua Reservoir and a Kao-Ping Stream dam, Chen said.

Meanwhile, Chen said the government will streamline the country's overall water management system to upgrade operational efficiency. "We'll integrate all existing water administrative agencies at various levels into a single unit in two phases. As the first step, we will integrate the five water management divisions under the MOEA into a single agency by the end of this year," he pledged.
Chen also urged all fellow countrymen to jointly launch a "Clean Water, Clean River" campaign to protect and conserve water resources.

"The government alone cannot ensure clean water supply. The public and private sectors should join forces to prevent river pollution, particularly the upperstream of major rivers which are primary source of drinking water supplies," Chen said, adding that local companies should also abide by current regulations governing treatment of waste water and chemical solvents. (BY Sofia Wu)
