DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO AUSTRALIA SEES ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT IN TIES

TEXT.P: There is room for an expansion in bilateral relations between the Republic of China and Australia, said Dr. Liu Polun, retiring representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canberra.

Liu, who is stepping down after serving in the post for two years and seven months, is making last-ditch efforts to encourage Australian officials and politicians to exploit opportunities to improve ties with Taiwan so that both countries can benefit.

Liu told the CNA on Friday that he was interviewed by the state-funded Special Broadcasting System (SBS) in Sydney this week in which he earnestly urged the Australian government to take bolder and more practical steps to better ties with Taiwan without being too concerned about mainland China's reaction so long as the moves are in the national interests of the two countries.

He said the stumbling block behind closer ties between Australia and Taiwan is mainland China because Canberra takes an extremely cautious approach in order to not antagonize Beijing, adding that this is resulting in its losses in business opportunities with Taipei.
"This is indeed unfortunate for Australia because it does not understand much about the Taiwan market and about snatching at business opportunities at the right time," he said.

He noted that Taiwan is a big and established market for Australian liquified natural gas (LNG), but Australia only secured a contract for the export of four-million tons of LNG through the signing of an understanding of memorandum with the Tuntex Group. This figure represents only half the amount that the Taiwanese conglomerate had planned on importing per year.
Liu continued by saying that Australia is not only complementary to Taiwan in terms of economic considerations, but also in the fields of science and education.

Australia is rich in natural resources and Taiwan needs them to fire its economic engines so that it can export more products to the world. But Australia and Taiwan are also complementary in scientific and educational fields because both sides can cooperate in research and development, biotechnology, information technology, telecommunications, aerospace, and other areas, Liu said.
Through cooperation in these fields, businessmen from the two countries can increase investment in each other's country, thus broadening the scope of mutual interests and benefits, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE 4.9 QUAKE HITS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.9 on the Richter scale struck eastern Taiwan at 10:32 a.m. on Saturday, said the Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau.
There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, seismologists said.
The quake's epicenter was 88.8 kilometers east of Hualien and 15.8 km below the earth's surface. It registerd 2.0 in Ilan county and 1.0 in Hualien city and Ilan city.
On June 11, a quake measuring 6.7 hit central Taiwan, killing two people and injuring 36 others.
Minor tremors and aftershocks have been a daily occurrence on the island since a deadly quake registering 7.6 on the Richter scale struck on Sept. 21 last year, killing some 2,400 people.
The September quake was the biggest to rock the island in 100 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR UP NT$0.001 AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 to close at NT$31.07 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Saturday.
The local currency opened at NT$31.069 against the US dollar and fluctuated between NT$31.063 and NT$31.072 during Saturday's trading. Interbank US dollar trading totalled US$93.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKSHOP FOR FOREIGN YOUTHS OPENS

TEXT.P: A vocational training workshop sponsored by the Republic of China government for 59 foreign youths kicked off on Saturday in Taipei.
Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao delivered a speech in the opening ceremony, which was presided over by Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Vice Chairman S. C. Wang.

In addition to learning all professional skills provided by the workshop, Tien encouraged the 59 young men from 29 ROC diplomatic allies in Asia, Europe, Latin America and Africa to seize the opportunity to learn more about Taiwan's culture and its affairs during their two-month stay here.

According to an official with the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, the ROC government started sponsoring the workshop in 1992, with an aim of helping train young technicians for the nation's diplomatic partners.
Japan also began financing part of the workshop's programs in 1997 in efforts to strength bilateral cooperation with Taiwan in exchanges of vocational training, the official noted.

The vice chief from the Taipei office of the Interchange Association, which represents Japan's interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal relations between the two countries, also addressed the occasion. He promised to do his best to continue promoting such cooperation between Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER RATE MAY BE RAISED: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) may consider raising the water rate to reflect cost, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said on Saturday.
Lin made the statement after accompanying President Chen on an inspection tour of the seventh management center of Taiwan Water Co. in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
During the inspection tour, Lin exchanged views on water fees with Lin Hsueh-cheng, chairman of state-run Taiwan Water Co. which is under MOEA jurisdiction.

Minister Lin said Taiwan Water Co. has incurred a debt of nearly NT$50 billion (US$1.61 billion). "As the company will have to assume part of the cost for improving tap water quality in the Kaohsiung area, its financial status will worsen further," the minister noted.

Lin attributed the water firm's huge debt mainly to the island's unreasonably low water rate. According to Lin, Taiwan's current tap water fee, NT$9.53 per liter, is one of the world's lowest and far cheaper than that for a 1-liter bottle of mineral water.

Another reason behind the company's deficit was high water treatment cost, Lin said. "Due to pollution in the upperstream of major local rivers, our water company has to spend much money on water treatment to ensure that the quality of our tap water meets the standards of hygiene," he explained.

Against this background, Lin said he thinks that there should be room for upward adjustment of water rate. "We will consider adjusting our water fee in accordance with our gross national product (GNP) to better reflect our treatment cost," the minister added.

During the inspection tour, President Chen reaffirmed his determination to honor his campaign promise not to construct a new reservoir in Meinung, a Kaohsiung County mountain town rich in Hakka cultural relic, natural scenery and wildlife.

Following Chen's declaration of "no Meinung Reservoir construction during his tenure," Minister Lin said the Cabinet has approved an MOEA-drafted plan for improving tap water supply and quality for residents in the Greater Kaohsiung area.
Over the next three years, Lin said, the MOEA will launch a number of improvement projects to ensure stable, adequate supply of high-quality tap water for Kaohsiung residents.
Lin said the Cabinet has agreed to set aside a budget of NT$15 billion (US$483.87 million) for various Kaohsiung water supply improvement projects which are scheduled to be completed by 2003.

"The projects were originally scheduled to be finalized by 2007, but now we have decided to advance the completion to 2003 for an early solution to the short supply and poor quality problem," Lin said.
The improvement plan includes a Nanhua Reservoir-Kaoping Stream Dam link-up project and construction of several highly advanced water purification and softening facilities, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPPING SECTOR SATISFIED WITH KAOHSIUNG HARBOR SERVICE: POLL

TEXT.P: Most shipping-related organizations with operations in Kaohsiung Harbor are satisfied with the performance of the southern Taiwan port, a recent survey has found.

According to the results of the poll conducted by the Kaohsiung Harbor Administration in the first half of this year, 74 percent of shipping companies and shipping agents are satisfied with the harbor's services, up from the previous level of 69 percent posted in the second half of last year.

In a bid to upgrade the harbor's services and correct its shortcomings, administration officials said they usually conduct a poll on customer satisfaction each six months. According to the officials, the administration also informs the customers of the harbor's improvement results periodically as part of its efforts to achieve the goal of "a total satisfaction" from the clients.

The survey also pointed out that the prime complaints of the shipping sector about Kaohsiung Harbor are its inadequate environmental protection measures and scarce space for increased volumes of operations.

Kaohsiung Harbor is Taiwan's largest port and the world's third-largest in terms of the handling of standardized 20-foot cargo containers. It handled nearly 6.27 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MAINTAIN STATUS QUO WITH MAINLAND CHINA: ROC VP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu told Radio Free Asia on Friday that Taiwan's new government is willing to strive for "a new page in history" together with mainland China and maintain the status quo in cross-strait relations.
Lu added that the people of Taiwan and mainland China are both of the Chinese race, but the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are separate political entities.
"For the sake of cross-strait relations, let us put aside nationalism. The two sides of the Taiwan Strait definitely have the ability to establish peaceful and friendly relations," she said.
Lu went on to say that although Taiwan has never been a part of the People's Republic of China, Taiwan and mainland China should respect each other.
She said that she hopes to exchange views with mainland China in a rational and friendly manner, adding that it is important for humankind to display rationality and strive for peace.

Recalling her last visit to mainland China in 1990 in search of her roots, she said that the trip made her feel even more certain that no matter how similar their language and racial heritage, the two sides are vastly different in political thinking.
She added that Taiwan values the "special racial and cultural relationship" with mainland China and that Taiwan cannot deny the fact that the two peoples are related to each other by blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CHIEF URGES PREVENTION OF CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's highest-ranking military chief on Saturday told senior political warfare officers that they must weed out corruption in arms purchases and other military projects to avoid recurring problems.

Gen. Tang Yao-ming, the ROC's Chief of the General Staff, said that the damage done by a scandal involving alleged kickbacks received in the French-made Lafayette frigate purchase case occurred precisely because the anti-corruption measures were not properly implemented.

He added that the entire armed forces should cooperate with the special task force that was recently appointed to investigate the circumstances surrounding the Lafayette purchase scandal, which allegedly led to the death of a navy captain who is widely believed to have been trying to blow the whistle on corrupt officers.

Tang made his remarks on the second day of the military's annual review of political warfare affairs, which include counseling and services for the nation's servicemen and their families, discipline, safety, supervision and monitoring, and internal security.

He said that the scandal actually represents an opportunity because the sooner truth is revealed and the military fully redresses past wrongs, the sooner the military's honorable image can be rebuilt.

The body of ROC Navy Capt. Yin Ching-feng, who was the executive director of the navy's weaponry procurement program at the time of his death in 1993, was found floating in a harbor in northern Taiwan several days after he had been collecting evidence about alleged irregularities concerning the navy's procurement of six Lafayettes and four German minesweepers.

The investigation into his death had been bogged down over the past six years but received a shot in the arm after President Chen Shui-bian on July 30 ordered the establishment of an ad hoc panel to look into the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TALKS ABOUT ROC DIPLOMACY GUIDELINES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said in Kaohsiung on Saturday that Taipei will take a positive attitude toward participating in international activities.
He made the remarks while delivering a report at the invitation of a Kaohsiung construction group on the new steps being taken by Taiwan to expand its foreign relations.

Tien noted that the basic guidelines for Taiwan's diplomacy are: cementing relations with its diplomatic allies, improving substantive ties with countries which maintain no formal relations with Taiwan, and taking a positive attitude toward joining international organizations.
The scholar-turned foreign minister pointed out that ROC President Chen Shui-bian has stressed the importance of maintaining the continuity and stability of the country's diplomacy.

As a result, he said that the new government, which was formed on May 20, will continue honoring all treaties, agreements, and cooperative plans signed by the previous government with foreign countries.
The ROC now maintains diplomatic relations with 29 countries around the world, with about half being located in the Caribbean area, and Central and South America.

Tien said that Chen is set to leave on his first overseas trip as president to some countries in the Caribbean and Central American on Aug. 13, indicating that Taiwan attaches much importance to its relations with its diplomatic allies.
He went on to say that more than 150 countries around the world have no formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, but the ROC maintains close economic and trade relations with them.
Among these countries, Tien said, Taiwan has established 97 quasi-official organizations in 63 countries.

According to Tien, after the inauguration of the new administration, the US government lauded the democratic achievement of Taiwan, with the Seoul and Tokyo governments voicing their willingness to improve substantive ties with Taipei.
He said that the European Union has also expressed its intention of setting up an office in Taiwan.
Tien added that Taipei will continue its efforts to join the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, and the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-PARTY TASK FORCE NOT RUBBER-STAMP BODY: NOBEL LAUREATE

TEXT.P: The newly formed cross-party task force for the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait is absolutely not a rubber-stamp body, the convener of the group said on Saturday.
Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh made the assurance at a news conference where he unveiled a list of 25 members for the high-profile cross-party task force.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, said he personally looks forward to seeing the top leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait sit down to talk.
"Nevertheless, before an effective cross-strait dialogue channel is forged, we can't predict when such a scenario can be realized," said the respected scholar.

Lee said although the island's two largest opposition parties -- the Kuomintang and the People First Party (PFP) -- declined to name representatives to take part in the panel, the cross-party task force is scheduled to hold its first meeting at the end of this month.
Asked how the task force will operate, Lee said he will fully respect the opinions of all panel members. "At any rate, we will not use voting to reach a conclusion," he added.
As for the agenda, Taiwan's foremost scholar said, it's up to all panel members to work out a priority list.

Asked whether the opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links and a review of the existing "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment will be priority topics of discussion, Lee said President Chen Shui-bian has never mentioned that any issue should be given priority.
Lee said he once asked President Chen why the president wanted him to organize a new cross-party panel instead of restructuring the existing National Unification Council (NUC).
"President Chen said the NUC had been dominated by the KMT, Taiwan's ruling party until May 20, and 70 percent of its members were government officials," Lee said.

Quoting Chen, Lee said the government-dominated NUC was unsuitable to serve as an advisory body to the president. "Therefore, the president intends to form a new panel comprising members from across the political and social spectrum to facilitate formation of a national consensus on future cross-strait ties," he added.
Lee stressed that the new panel does not include any government official as its member, nor will it rubber-stamp any government decision on cross-strait issues.

Lee said the task force will offer counseling or advice on the development of cross-strait relations for President Chen's reference. "I believe that Chen will respect the views and opinions presented by the panel."

Lee further said the task force is not aimed at inviting politicians for political consultations. "In face, the panel comprises members from different political groups and professional fields to work for peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and for ethnic harmony in local society," he added.

Lee said the non-political members in the panel were selected from more than 200 celebrities in various non-political fields. "I believe that all panel members are competent and experienced enough to assume their new job in the panel," he said confidently.

In addition to legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the pro-unification opposition New Party, the task force also include an independent lawmaker and sever KMT members who join the panel on their own right, not as party representatives.
Non-political members include a painter, a chicken tycoon, an aboriginal clergyman, a medical expert, and several legal and economics experts and presidential advisers.

DOC.HEADLINE: URBAN WOMEN VALUE MATE'S PERSONALITY OVER EARNING POWER: POLL

TEXT.P: A new poll shows that Taiwan's urban women now value personality and temperament over earning ability in choosing a potential mate, indicating a shift away from traditional values that rate bread-and-butter over other factors.

The poll, which was conducted by National Sun Yat-sen University on behalf of a pharmaceutical company that manufactures hair growth drug, also revealed that looks do matter, with this consideration coming in third behind personality and financial standing.

Out of the 500 single women surveyed in Taipei, Taichung, and Kaohsiung, 91. 8 percent said that they attach importance to a potential mate's personality and temperament, 75.8 percent said they look at earning ability, and 66 percent take appearance into consideration.

Meanwhile, 75 percent of those interviewed said they are concerned about their mates' hair. Among the reasons stated were that bald-headed men or men with little hair may give the impression of lacking confidence or being advanced in age. Another reason mentioned was that bald-headed men are not as attractive.

Of the women surveyed, 61 percent said they will choose mates with a full head of hair. Also, almost 60 percent said they would ask their mates to undergo hair treatment if they started losing their hair.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGER CAPACITY ON FLIGHTS BETWEEN VIETNAM AND TAIWAN TO INCREASE

TEXT.P: Airline representatives from Taiwan and Vietnam have agreed to increase the number of seats available for flights between the two countries starting in October 2000, said officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Saturday.
After two days of discussions on Thursday and Friday, airline representatives from the two countries agreed to increase passenger capacity by 50 percent.

It was agreed that beginning in late October, 800 seats will be added to the weekly Taiwan-Vietnam flights and return flights, with another 1,200 seats to be added by next October. This is expected to largely accommodate consumer demand, said the officials.
Currently, Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways offer a combined 4,010 seats per week. According the new agreement, the two sides will increase the number of seats to 6,010 by late October, 2001.

Taiwan's negotiators also actively strived to introduce an additional Taiwanese airline to the flight route. However, Vietnamese officials declined the proposal, saying that Taiwan is already receiving special treatment as other countries each only have one appointed airline carrier company for flights to and from Vietnam.
The officials also noted that demand for seats on the Taiwan-Vietnam flight route has only recently increased, so it is still to early to consider adding a third airline to the route.

Because of the seat limits, China Airlines and EVA Airways can only provide seven flights per week from Taiwan to Ho Chi Minh City. Taiwan-Hanoi flights are expected to begin after the increase in the number of seats under the agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATION OF KAOHSIUNG CITY, HARBOR TO BE MERGED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Saturday that the Kaohsiung Harbor will be put under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung City Government in the future.
Chen made the announcement during an inspection tour of the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.
Chen said he is aware that the merger of the Kaohsiung city and harbor administration is a "dream come true" for Kaohsiung residents.
Chen said he has consistently advocated that the central government delegates more power and resources to local governments to ensure balanced development in various parts of the island.
"Sharing power and resources is the basis for the central and local governments to forge a partnership and jointly push for balanced national development," Chen explained.

Chen said he hopes that the Kaohsiung City Government and the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau, which is now under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), can cooperate closely to promote the development of the city and the harbor after the merger.
MOTC Minister Yeh Chu-lan, who accompanied Chen on his Kaohsiung inspection tour, said the MOTC has formed a task force to promote the long-talked-about Kaohsiung city-harbor merger plan.

"According to our work scheduled, the ministry will refer a draft bill on the city-harbor administration merger to the Legislative Yuan for screening in September. As many legislators have voiced support for the proposal, I believe that the bill will pass the legislature smoothly to pave the way for the city-harbor merger," Yeh said.

Under the MOTC-drafted bill, navigation administration will still be handled by the MOTC, while harbor administration will be delegated to the local government. Moreover, Yeh said, the Kaohsiung City Government will be authorized to handle harbor land use and development affairs.

Yeh said the MOTC will strengthen coordination and communication with the Kaohsiung City Government in order to protect legitimate rights and interests of harbor bureau staff and shipping companies in the process of merger.

During his Kaohsiung inspection tour, President Chen also inspected a tap water softening facility to express his concern about water supply problems in the Greater Kaohsiung area. Chen also officiated at the opening of a southern Taiwan branch of the Fishery Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA). The opening of the new fishery administration office was part of the new government's efforts to improve services for fishermen in southern Taiwan, also Taiwan's deep-sea industry stronghold. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMBERS OF INTERPARTY TASK FORCE ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announced on Saturday the list of members for his interparty task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the President, not a policy-making unit.

Drawing from across the political and social spectrum, the task force comprises of legislators from different parties, legal and economics experts, presidential advisers, academics, a media expert, a painter, an aboriginal clergyman, and a chicken tycoon.
Notably absent from the list of 25 members are appointed representatives from opposition parties Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).

The KMT and the PFP have consistently refused to take part in the committee since Lee -- the convener and a member himself -- was first approached by newly elected Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian in May to form an advisory task force on cross-strait issues.
However, the KMT is unofficially represented by a legislator and a former legislator who joined the team in their personal capacities.

Lee said that he will keep four seats open in case the two parties wish to participate in the task force one day, and he urged those party representatives who have already joined the team to put the nation's interests ahead of those of their respective parties.
Lee went on to say that Chen had already reviewed the list two days ago, and that Chen did not have any disagreeing opinions.

He added that the task force is scheduled to convene for the first time before Chen departs on his first official trip to the ROC's Caribbean, Central American, and African allies at the end of August.

Lee said that Chen will be invited to attend the meeting, which may involve discussions on the impending admission of both Taiwan and mainland China into the rule-setting World Trade Organization and on the "one China" issue.

He added that the people of Taiwan and mainland China have no deep-seated hatred for each other and that they share a common history and culture, so they should cooperate with each other and strive ahead "hand-in-hand."

Billed as a presidential advisory body, the task force will not be a policy-making unit nor an executive unit, Lee said, adding that the group will consolidate public consensus and promote the development of ethnic harmony and peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Given that the committee was formed at Chen's request, DPP legislative whip Hsu Tien-tsai said that the task force should try its best to help Chen collect information and provide valuable advice.

Hsu urged Lee's newly formed task force to refrain from publicly announcing its views too often but instead stick to its role of presidential advisor so that it will not unstabilize the political scene.

PFP spokesman Sun Ta-chien said that his party prefers to bring up its views and opinions on cross-strait policies through official channels within the system and through other opportunities such as the interparty leadership roundtable that may be hosted by Chen in the future.
Sun added that just because the PFP did not appoint a representative to join the task force does not mean that it does not support trying to forge a domestic consensus on cross-strait policies.

KMT deputy secretary general Shao Yu-ming said that his party did not want to be officially represented in the task force because of a "basic distrust" of the DPP's position on cross-strait relations. Therefore, he added that the KMT does not wish to be a part of the committee simply to endorse the DPP's stance.

As to whether or not the KMT will take disciplinary action against the KMT members who joined the committee in their personal capacities, Shao said that the KMT has yet to discuss the issue. However, he added that the KMT "does not endorse" and "does not support" their membership in the task force.

The 25 members of the interparty task force on cross-strait relations are: Academia Sinica president Lee Yuan-tseh, aboriginal clergyman Pai Kuang-sheng, non-affiliated legislator Chu Hui-liang, former National Tsinghua University president Shen Chun-shan, Public Television Service chairman Wu Feng-shan, enterprise sector representative Wu Tung-shen, National Taiwan University (NTU) political science professor Ming Chu-cheng, Hua Nan Commercial Bank vice chairman Lin Ming-cheng, DPP legislator Lin Cho-shui, NTU law professor Lin Tzu-yi, lawyer Fan Kuang-chun, former KMT legislator Hung Tung-kuei, New Party (NP) legislative whip Hau Lung-bin, painter Liang Tan-feng, NTU economics professor Chen Tien-chi, United Microelectronics Group chairman Tsao Hsing-che.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ENCOURAGES MEMBERS TO REGAIN POLITICAL POWER

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the Republic of China's opposition party Kuomintang, on Friday urged KMT members at the KMT's US headquarters in San Francisco to maintain party unity and reclaim political power in the next presidential election.

Lien said on the third day of his US visit that the KMT, which lost to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the March 18 ROC presidential election, has not lost its ideals and will not shy away from its goals. He added that the KMT will regain power in the next election three years from now.

Lien is the first KMT Chairman to visit the United States and the KMT's US headquarters. He also visited a memorial hall dedicated to founder of the KMT and father of the ROC, Sun Yet-sen. He said that he will follow Sun's against-all-odds spirit to reform the KMT and prepare for its comeback.
Lien added that the KMT has been actively promoting party reform, saying that in the future, it will be a party filled with freedom, democracy, and creativity.

He went on to question the DPP government's ruling abilities, pointing out that the DPP's public approval rating has dropped by more than 20 percent over the past two months. He criticized the DPP government as being "unpredictable and incompetent."

Lien donated a wooden board with morale-boosting inscriptions to the KMT's headquarters in San Francisco. He emphasized that overseas Chinese people and the KMT are "as close as flesh and blood," adding that they have to cooperate in order to win the next presidential election.
Many of the overseas Chinese and KMT members said that Lien's speech and actions had strengthened their morale, adding that they will work hard to help the KMT regain power.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST GROUP OF CONSCRIPTS FOR ALTERNATIVE SERVICE RECEIVE TRAINING

TEXT.P: The country's first group of conscripts for alternative service began to receive basic military training at Chengkungling, a military training base in central Taiwan, on Saturday.

The 1,800 young conscripts will receive 39 days of basic training in shooting, patriotic education, combat expertise and physical training at Chengkungling before they are distributed to various social service positions according to their specialties.

Interior Minister Chang Po-ya presided over the opening ceremony of the special training program. Chang encouraged all young conscripts to cultivate a service-oriented attitude and law-abiding spirit in preparation for taking up new social service positions.

After two years of joint planning by the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of the Interior, the Republic of China began to implement an "alternative service" conscription system this year. Although many Western countries have long adopted such a system, the ROC is the first Asian country to implement it for better use of its manpower resources.

A total of 5,000 young men have been selected for mandatory service in social work rather than in the military this year. Similar training programs for the second and third groups of those conscripts will begin in September and November, respectively.

Positions available for the young conscripts include those in the police and firefighting forces, as well as that of environmental protection worker, or nurse for the elderly and handicapped. Some conscripts will work for reconstruction projects in the 921 earthquake-stricken areas in central Taiwan.
After the Chengkungling training program, the conscripts will receive further training in professional skills related to their future work, in addition to first aid skills and legal regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOWER OIL PRICES EXPECTED TO STABILIZE DOMESTIC COMMODITY COSTS

TEXT.P: The July consumer price index (CPI) increased by 1.45 percent, indicating that domestic commodity prices continue to be on the rise moderately, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

From January to July, the CPI was up 1.17 percent while the agency expected inflation to rise 1.77 for the whole year. The wholesale price index (WPI) in July registered a year-on-year increase of 2.67 percent.

Officials of the Central Bank of China (CBC) said that domestic consumer prices are facing moderate inflationary pressure because of recent increases in international commodity prices and decreases in the price of local fruits and vegetables. However, the officials added that international oil prices have declined in recent weeks, a trend that is expected to help stabilize domestic commodity rate.
Due to the lower international oil prices, import commodity prices went down by 11.21 percent in July in the first registered drop since April.
The officials said that Taiwan-based industries have experienced a continued drop in labor costs since 1995, another factor that has also helped stabilize domestic commodity rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS TO VISIT JAPAN, SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Thirteen legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will leave for Tokyo on Sunday for a five-day visit and then proceed to Seoul.
Tsai Tung-jung, leader of the delegation, told reporters on Saturday that the main purpose of the visit is promote friendly relations between Taiwan, Japan and South Korea.
He added that members of the delegation will exchange views with their Japanese and South Korean counterparts on the East Asian situation and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
During their stay in Tokyo, the lawmakers will hold talks with friendly Japanese parliamentarians, call on Japan Interchange Association leaders and meet with Taiwan reporters stationed in Tokyo.
The delegation will leave Taipei on Sunday noon and will leave for Seoul from Tokyo on Aug. 9. It will return to Taipei on Aug. 12.
This will be the first time for the ruling party to send a parliamentarian mission to Japan and South Korea since the inauguration of the DPP-controlled new government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 6, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: The Holy Roman Empire ends when Francis II abdicates. He later becomes Francis I, emperor of Austria.
1825: Bolivia becomes an independent republic after being ruled by the Spanish for nearly 300 years.
1881: Alexander Flemming, Scottish scientist who discovered penicillin at St. Mary's Hospital in London in 1928, is born. He won the 1945 Nobel Prize for medicine with Howard Florey and Ernest Chain.
1890: The electric chair is used for the first time to execute convicted murderer William Kemmler at Auburn Prison in New York.
1911: Lucille Ball, American actress and comedienne who starred in the series "I Love Lucy," is born.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced China's congress to elect him president on Oct. 10, 1913, declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1917: Robert Mitchum, American actor who starred in "The Enemy Below," "Cape Fear," "The Longest Day," and many other films, is born.
1926: Gertrude Ederle, American sports star and 1924 Olympic gold medalist, completes the 35 miles (56 kilometers) that separate Cap Gris-Nez and Dover in 14 hours 31 minutes, becoming the first woman to swim the English Channel.
1932: The first international film festival is opened in Venice, with 29 films from the United States, Britain, France, Germany, the Soviet Union, and Italy.
1933: Feng Yu-hsiang, an army general who revolted at Kalgan Pass (Changkiakow) in Chahar province on May 28, announces his revolt has failed.
1945: An atomic bomb, dubbed "Little Boy," is released by a US Air Force B-29, known as the "Enola Gay," above the central Japanese city of Hiroshima, killing more than 90,000 people, and injuring at least 9,000 others.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai-shek flies to Chinhae, Korea, to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1952: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the designation of Sept. 28, instead of Aug. 27, as the birthday of Confucius, the great sage and teacher who has had a far-reaching influence on Chinese philosophy and culture.
1962: Jamaica becomes independent after 307 years of British rule.
1962: Film star Marilyn Monroe is found dead in the bedroom of her Hollywood home. She was 36.
1962: Ugandan dictator Idi Amin throws 50,000 Asians out of Uganda.
1971: British sailor Chay Blyth completes his solo non-stop 48,000-kilometer round-the-world voyage in 292 days on his 18-meter, all-steel ketch "British Steel."
1973: The second National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei, with some 180 Chinese scholars attending.
1973: A fully automatic information handling system, the most modern in Southeast Asia, is inaugurated at Taipei's International Airport.
1978: Pope Paul VI, who succeeded John XXIII in 1963, dies at the age of 80.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo points out at an annual military conference that "we shall rely on ourselves in our fight against Communism."
1990: The United Nations Security Council votes 13-0 to ban all trade with Iraq, except for medicine and some food for humanitarian relief, after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
1991: A Republic of China-Fiji technological cooperation agreement is signed during Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara's visit to Taipei.
1997: A Korean Airlines Boeing 747-300 passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area of Guam, killing 254 people on board. There were only 20 survivors.
1999: The Philippine government proposes that Taipei and Manila either renegotiate their aviation accord or air carriers from both countries enter into a commercial agreement so as to avoid the cessation of the Taipei-Manila air link.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By welcoming them when they come and giving them protection when they go, commending what is good in them and making allowance for their ignorance: that is how the ruler shows tenderness to strangers from far countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHLIGHTS OF INTERVIEW WITH ROC VICE PRESIDENT (I)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu spoke of constitutional amendment and Taiwan's foreign and domestic affairs, as well as the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, in a recent interview with CNA. Following are highlights of the interview:
Q: Your recent remarks on the Pachang River incident might have caused some misunderstanding. Do you have any further clarification?

A: My comments were made in reply to questions raised by the media. But some people exaggerated them as indicating a "division" between President Chen Shui-bian and myself. In fact, I usually have dinner with Chen on Fridays. It is actually the speculation about my relations with him that represents a misunderstanding.

In my talks with reporters, I said that a state affairs conference should be convened to discuss all subjects relating to domestic and foreign affairs, as well as constitutional revision to resolve the existing embarrassing situation under which the premier, who is not elected by public vote, has strong power, while the president is not allowed to intervene, even though he may want to air his views and take charge of the business.
Q: The present constitutional system has created some political bottlenecks and many different opinions have been voiced. What is your opinion?

A: Now that the Legislative Yuan has closed the general interpellation session, I hope that different views can be voiced, or that a public poll can be held to analyze the results. The scholars should also study this issue thoroughly. A television station said the other day that I hope to assume the premiership. In fact, I have no interest in that at all, because it does not comply with the constitutional system.
Q: What do you want to do most as vice president?

A: I am doing my job as a "promoter of conscientious business." I do whatever I think I have to do. For instance, I went to see the bereaved families of the victims of the Pachang River incident. Wherever there is a problem, the people with power must be there. They must be on the frontline because "wherever there is fire, they have to fight the fire."
Q: Is President Chen's plan to convene a roundtable meeting with party leaders designed to find ways to resolve the constitutional problem facing the new government?

A: Listening to different opinions is a normal political practice, but a single meeting is unlikely to resolve all problems. The roundtable meeting, like the projected supra-party committee, is a prelude to a state affairs conference. The ultimate goal is to formulate a good Constitution.
Q: But the Kuomintang seems to be less enthusiastic about the roundtable meeting. What is your view?

A: The Kuomintang's attitude is understandable, as it has just become the opposition after holding power for a long time. President Chen should display more sincerity to indicate his respect toward the party.
Q: Do your previous remarks indicate that the constitutional dispute should be resolved through revisions to the Constitution?

A: Regarding constitutional revision or formulating the Constitution, I have no ideas. The best way is to hear views from relevant quarters. The unresolved problems must be resolved before next year's election of Legislative Yuan members.
Q: As the Democratic Progressive Party holds only 30 percent of the seats in the Legislative Yuan, is it better to amend the Constitution now or after the elections?

A: That is hard to say. There are two sorts of suggestions. The first suggestion is to do it after the election, while the second suggestion is to amend the Constitution now and let the voters examine the results. Anyway, the next round of constitutional amendments and the state affairs conference must be conducted with sound planning. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHLIGHTS OF INTERVIEW WITH ROC VICE PRESIDENT (II)

TEXT.P: Q: What kinds of government problems came to light in the Pachang River incident?

A: The incident was just a "trigger." If it had not happened, something else would have occurred, sooner or later. The Kuomintang handed over its 55-year-old ruling power, but the departments of the government are still occupied by old faces. The old bureaucratic system should be held responsible for the Pachang River incident.
Q: Do you plan to arrange more speeches to spell out your ideals?

A: I give speeches often. But at present I plan to focus my attention on reconstruction of the earthquake-stricken areas. In fact, I visited the hardest-hit areas recently, at the instruction of the president. Basically, post-quake rehabilitation work has been affected by two factors.

In the first ten months after last September's temblor, the government spent the first three months in rescue operations, and the reconstruction work was then delayed by the campaigns for the March 18 presidential election, the hospitalization of Premier Tang Fei and the general interpellation session. Concrete construction projects will not be completed until the end of August.

The second factor is that during the presidential election, local political forces threw their support behind five different candidates. Friction in the aftermath of the election also affected reconstruction work. I am now pushing a plan to build fairly-priced houses in disaster areas.
Q: What is your opinion on the development of cross-strait relations?

A: Since winning the presidential election, Chen has been extremely mild in his posture toward mainland China, and Beijing leaders have found no excuse for using force against Taiwan. But Jiang Zemin may be anxious to realize political negotiations with Taiwan, as he is apparently to relinquish his presidency in 2001.

Therefore, I want to remind the public that "our challenge has just started, and the crisis is not over yet." Mainland China's military intimidation was nothing but a boast, because the world will not tolerate a mainland Chinese military attack on Taiwan.

Beijing will induce Taiwan to engage in negotiations, and Taiwan has no ability or excuse to resist it. Why do I think a state affairs conference must be convened? Because we have to discuss who is qualified for the talks, to what extent he will be authorized, and how much bargaining power we have.
Q: What kind of posture should the government take in its bid to join the United Nations?

A: I feel that Taiwan joining the United Nations is not a dream, but rather a kind of truth and justice. According to the various charters of the UN and their spirit, Taiwan's failure to enter the world body is the fault of the UN. The world refuses to allow Taiwan to join the UN, only because of Beijing's opposition. This is a violation of international justice.
Q: Are you willing to visit mainland China?
A: I am very willing, as I said before the presidential election. I visited there in 1990.

Q: Some people suggest that Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh is a good choice to serve as cross-strait emissary. Some speculate that he might have already made contact with Beijing officials during his recent foreign trip. What is your view?
A: I have no comment on this matter. I am not well acquainted with Lee.
Q: You said before that female voices should be added to cross-strait affairs. Do you have any concrete plan?
A: The president has already realized it. Both the Mainland Affairs Council chair and the Government Information Office chief are female, and I also occasionally voice my opinions. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHLIGHTS OF INTERVIEW WITH ROC VICE PRESIDENT (III)

TEXT.P: Q: In addition to the UN, we are also trying hard to join the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization. What name should we use when we seek to join international organizations? Do you agree with the name "Taiwan Republic of China" as mentioned by former President Lee Teng-hui?

A: This is also a subject which should be discussed in a state affairs conference. I think the new government should work out a new foreign policy, a more strategic policy. It is important to cement our relations with diplomatic allies. Therefore, I strongly support President Chen's foreign trip.

In the past, we considered our relations with the United States to be more important than those with Asian and European countries. We should now turn more attention to relations with our neighbors, starting with Japan and South Korea. I think that Taiwan, Japan and South Korea should work to enhance relations to establish to the point where we can establish a free trade zone.

I have learned something from the European Union. We should work to form an Asian Union. Such a union will not be designed to counter the power of mainland China, as mainland China will also be allowed to become a member. This may also help us deter military conflicts, because war must be avoided for the sake of economic interest.
Q: What is the emphasis of your work for the immediate future?
A: I hope that reconstruction work in the quake-stricken areas will have had a good start before the first anniversary of the Sept. 21 quake. After that, I may pay more attention to women's welfare.

I recently received women's representatives from all the island's counties and cities to pave the way for convening a national women's conference, with focus to be given to the protection of women's safety, women's employment, and assistance for needy parents.
Q: What score you will give over your performance as vice president in the past two months?

A: I have never given scores for myself, as it is too subjective. I also do not care about results of public opinion polls. But I care about votes, because at the moment of voting, a vote represents a heart.

I desire nothing. I am not thinking about getting reelected four years from now. Therefore, I just do the things that I think are meaningful. I work conscientiously with a dedicated spirit. Regarding scores, let God write them.
Q: What is your impression since assuming the vice presidency?
A: I have encountered lots of challenges in my life, but the current one is unprecedented in my experience, in terms of its severity and cruelty.

I think the public has gradually come to know Annette Lu. In the past, many people did not know me, and they created an unreal Annette Lu. In fact, Annette remains Annette. My style is always the same.

The most wonderful thing about Taiwan society today is that it has developed into a "very healthy organic entity." This can be seen by the public's furious reaction to the loss of four lives in the Pachang River incident. In comparison, people in mainland China do not get angry over huge losses of lives in floods, because they have become numbed.

Our society has developed into a healthy organic entity. We can call it a healthy organic entity because it is able to adapt to a changing environment and develop in the best possible direction. Authorities in Beijing should not underestimate this aspect of Taiwan, as it is the most wonderful characteristic of our society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
TYPHOON TO BRING RAINS TO CENTRAL, NORTHERN TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: One day after torrential rain warnings were lifted, Taiwan is expected to be influenced by the outward spiraling cirrus of a typhoon, said the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) on Sunday.

The island is basking in sunshine on Sunday, as a southeasterly airstream which packed with heavy humidity and triggered torrential rain in central and southern Taiwan has passed Taiwan, with the temperature hovering between 33 and 34 degrees Celsius, said the CWB.
However, the outward spiraling cirrus clouds of a typhoon are expected to reach Taiwan on Monday evening, bringing more rain to northern, northeastern and central Taiwan.

A storm warning for mariners is expected to be issued as early as Sunday night due to Typhoon Jelawat, the eighth typhoon in the Western Pacific this year. Jelawat was centered 1,000 kilometers to the east of Taiwan on Sunday at noon, and was moving westward at a pace of 15 kilometers per hour, said the CWB, adding that the storm is not likely to reach Taiwan, said the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS CHINESE AND DIPLOMACY TWO SIDES OF SAME COIN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-hueng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Noting that services for overseas Chinese and diplomacy are two sides of the same coin, Chang Fu-mei, Minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), said on Sunday that the OCAC will not be dismantled.

Presiding over the opening of the joint conference of the Federation of Taiwanese Associations in Europe, Chang said that President Chen Shui-bian had assured her when he offered her the post as head of the OCAC that the agency charged with serving overseas Chinese individuals and communities would not be abolished.

Noting that overseas Chinese can help facilitate the ROC's diplomacy, Chang said her commission, with its limited budget of NT$1.9 billion (US$61 million) per year, will do its best to serve overseas Chinese, help their descendants learn the Chinese language, and provide assistance to overseas Taiwanese businessmen.
The conference of the Federation of Taiwanese Associations in Europe has brought together some 200 representatives from overseas Taiwanese communities across Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO MEET WITH PARTY WHIPS ON MONDAY

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party legislative whip said on Sunday that he expects President Chen Shui-bian will exchange views on the general budget with the party whips of the various political parties in the Legislative Yuan when he meets with them on Monday.

Lai Shih-pao, New Party (NP) whip, said that President Chen and the opposition officials will probably discuss the overall budget, and whether to increase government expenditures or borrowing, although he added that the NP believes that both ideas will not work.

Lai also said that his party will do everything possible to screen the special funds in the overall budget, adding that the NP's attitude will not be to oppose such expenditures simply to cause gridlock.

Monday's meeting will be held at the Taipei Guest House, with Hsu Tien-tsai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, He Chih-hui of the Kuomintang, Lai Shih-pao of the NP, as well as Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Vice President Jao Eng-chi, Premier Tang Fei, and Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung expected to attend.

Lai said that he would also suggest that President Chen review the "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment in the mainland, and undertake careful planning on the "three direct links" -- direct trade, post and transport with the mainland.

On the issue of a proposed roundtable meeting of various political parties, he said that the NP will not attend the meeting if it is simply an attempt to bury the political hatchet drawn during the presidential election.

The DPP won the March presidential election, ending the Kuomintang's more than five-decade grip on political power. But the KMT remains dominant in the 225-seat legislature, prompting the DPP administration to plan a roundtable meeting to facilitate relations between the executive and legislative branches.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEFEATED ITSELF IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) was defeated by itself, rather than by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the March 18 presidential election, said KMT Chairman Lien Chan on Friday.

Speaking at a dinner party attended by 1,500 KMT officials and members residing in the San Francisco Bay area, the visiting KMT head said that his party lost out in the March 18 election mainly because of division among its rank-and-file membership.

Lien, who stood for the KMT in the presidential race, got 23.1 percent of the votes, while his former comrade James Soong, who split from the party and ran against Lien as an independent, won 36.8 percent of votes. Chen Shui-bian of the DPP won the race with 39.3 percent of votes.

Lien also cast blame for his election setback on the KMT's deviation from public opinion in making policy, its loss of vision after ruling Taiwan for more than five decades, and its neglect of young voters.

Meanwhile, KMT spokesman Jason Hu, who accompanied Lien on the visit, said it was too early to weigh the possibility of joining hands with People First Party, formed by Soong after the March 18 election. He said that the top agenda for the party now is to win next year's legislative and local government elections.
Lien and his entourage arrived in San Francisco on Aug. 3. Their trip is seen as part of efforts to rally the KMT's supporters.
Judging by the huge attendance at Friday's dinner party, Lien was successful in reclaiming the allegiance of the party's members living in the Bay area.
Lien and his entourage will leave San Francisco for Los Angeles on Sunday afternoon, continuing his tour of the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF URGES ARATS TO HELP RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT TRAVEL DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) urged on Sunday its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Accross the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to help resolve a travel dispute that has arisen between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.

A group of 23 tourists organized by Chiaan Travel Agency in Taiwan were detained by a mainland travel agency -- Beijiang International Travel Agency -- for three days in Beijing. A spokesman for the Taiwan travel agency said that his firm has made all the necessary payments to its contracted mainland agency -- Strait International Travel Agency.

Due to a financial dispute between Strait International and Beijiang International, the group's travel itinerary was interrupted, and the travellers' documents were held for three days in Beijing, the Chiaan spokesman said.

They regained possession of their documents after reporting the case to police authorities in Beijing, after which they returned to Taiwan, he said, adding that they had suffered both property losses and mental stress.
Chiaan Travel Agency then asked the SEF for assistance in settling the grievance so as to ensure fair treatment, the SEF added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO SERVE AS CONVENOR OF HUMAN RIGHTS CONSULTATION TEAM

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will serve as the convener of a national human rights consultation team, officials of the Presidential Office said on Sunday.

Aides of the Vice President said that after President Chen Shui-bian announced at a press conference on July 31 the establishment of a national human rights committee, he soon instructed Lu, a long-time advocate of human rights, to serve as the convener of a human rights consultation team.
Chen Che-nan, acting secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that the team will set the establishment of a national human rights committee as its long-term goal.

The team will also research declarations, documents, and agreements that have been important in the worldwide international fight for human rights in the past, and will assimilate them into a human rights reference book for Taiwan, Chen said.
Chen is expected to announce the establishment of the team, which the government is hoping will present substantial results by December 10, which is International Human Rights Day.

The officials of the Presidential Office also said that the consultation team will include many domestic human rights activists, including writer Po Yang and Huang Wen-hsiung, former president of the Taiwan Association for Human Rights; as well as representatives of international human rights groups, such as Amnesty International.
Vice President Lu will hold a meeting this week to discuss the members of the team and its future direction, Lu's office said.

President Chen had been very impressed by a recent documentary film on the establishment of a human rights monument on Green Island off Taiwan's southeast coast, and had then decided to establish a national human rights committee, officials said.
The president is expected to preside over the official inauguration of the monument on Green Island on December 10.
President Chen had made the protection of human rights one of his administrative goals in his inaugural speech on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S YOUTH DEPARTMENT PLANS TO HOLD SUMMIT ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Youth Department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning to hold a cross-strait youth summit to cultivate political awareness in the younger generation, a DPP official said on Sunday.
Wang Ming-yuan, director of the DPP Youth Department, said that if everything goes smoothly, summit meetings will be held in both Taipei and Beijing by the end of this year.

He also said that his department also plans to set up a "shadow Cabinet" comprised of youth leaders chosen from the Association of Friends of President Chen Shui-bian and student organizations established before the March 18 Presidential election.
Internet discussions will give young people a chance to learn how political affairs are handled and cultivate their sense of political awareness, Wang said.

His department will cooperate with Tamkang University's Institute of Mainland Affairs Research in holding the cross-strait youth summit. Students of cross-strait affairs will be invited to the proposed meeting, he said.
Details on the proposed meeting will be available next week, he said.

Cultivating the political talent of Taiwan's youth is one of the DPP's top priorities, he said, admitting that the DPP was forced to face up to its own internal lack of high-level political talent after assuming control of Taiwan's administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC IN FAVOR OF ROUNDTABLE MEETING FOR RECONCILIATION: POLL

TEXT.P: Some 81.44 percent of people in Taiwan are in favor of a roundtable meeting of the major political parties to help smooth out relations between the government's executive and legislative branches, a poll showed on Sunday.

The poll, conducted by Eastern Multimedia Co., surveyed people over 18 years of age around the island between Aug. 3 and Aug.4. Effective samples totaled 1,088, and the poll carries a margin of error of 3 percent.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) defeated the Kuomingtang (KMT) in the March presidential election, ending the latter's five-decade-old grip on political power. But the KMT remains dominant in the legislature, prompting the government to plan a roundtable meeting to smooth out relations between the executive and legislative branches.

On the clashes between the executive and legislative branches, 30.33 percent of the people said that they have been caused by the legislature, some 12.32 percent said that the executive branch is to blame, while 27.76 percent believe that both branches should take the blame.

Some 54.96 percent of the poll's respondents said that they have confidence in the new government's ability to solve the political and economic problems of the nation, while 30.89 percent said they had no confidence. Additionally, some 76.38 percent are in favor of party reconciliation, the survey said.
The poll also showed that 71.32 percent of the public are in favor of convening an interparty task force to map out a new cross-strait policy.

Cross-strait relations have been in limbo since former President Lee Teng-hui defined ties between the two sides as "special state-to-state" in July 1999. Relations between the two sides were further strained after the election of Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, although Chen has extended conciliatory gestures since his election.

Hung Chao-nan, a KMT official, said that political parties are all rivals to each other, and the opposition parties must monitor the administration. He expressed the hope that the nation will return to party politics, and that the Legislative Yuan will become the center of national policy formation.

Peng Shao-chin of the DPP said that the poll shows that the public wants political stability, party reconciliation, and cross-strait peace. Peng added that people still have confidence in the new administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIV. OF HAWAII HAS LARGEST ASIAN-AMERICAN STUDENT BODY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The University of Hawaii enrolls the largest number of Asian-American students of all US colleges, according to a result of a survey conducted by the August-September issue of the English-language "aMagazine."
Polytechnic University at Brooklyn, New York City, boasts the largest line-up of Asian-American faculty and administrative staff among all US colleges, the same survey indicates.

The survey shows that 71 percent of students at the University of Hawaii are Asian-Americans, the highest percentage of all US colleges. Nineteen percent of the faculty and administrative staff of Polytechnic University are Asian-Americans, the survey reveals.
Meanwhile, Pomona College in California grants more scholarships to Asian-American students than any other US college, according to the survey.
Claremont McKenna College in California offers more elective and required courses on Asian, Asian-American and ethnic group issues that any other US college, the survey shows.

The results of the survey also list the eight colleges with the largest number of Asian-American students. They are the University of Hawaii; the University of California, Riverside; the University of California, Los Angeles; the University of California, Davis; Polytechnic University; the University of Pennsylvania; the University of California, San Diego; and the University of Maryland, College Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100 COUPLES MARK DIAMOND WEDDING ANNIV. ON CHINESE VALENTINE'S DAY

TEXT.P: One hundred couples across the island who have been married for more than 60 years are celebrating their diamond wedding anniversary on Chinese Valentine's Day, a spokesman for the committee organizing the celebration said on Sunday.

The spokesman for the Republic of China Senior Citizens' Club said that the long-lasting marriages serve as an example for modern society, in which mounting divorce rates prevail among the younger generation.

He said that the organizing committee had originally planned to select 100 Taiwan couples with marriages greater than 50 years of age to take part in the celebrations. However, the committee found 100 couples that have already been married for over 60 years, he said.
Therefore, the club has decided to hold a diamond wedding anniversary celebration for them, he said.

Among the top 100 couples selected, Lin Hao and Lin Cheng-chien have been married for 79 years and seven months, the longest-lasting marriage on the island. The couple now lives together with their descendants of five generations.
Asked about their secret for maintaining a long marriage, Mr. Lin said that there is no secret method, but that he always showed his concern for his wife.
Although the marriage has not exactly been a continuous romantic love story, the fact that they stood by each other throughout eight decades is an example for younger generations to follow, he said.
