DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON JELAWAT GROUNDS FLIGHTS FROM TAIWAN TO OKINAWA

TEXT.P: Due to unstable weather conditions influenced by the outward spiraling cirrus of Typhoon Jelawat, flights from Taiwan bound for Okinawa were canceled on Monday, air traffic sources reported.

China Airlines and Japan Asia Airways canceled all three of Monday's Taipei-Okinawa flights as Jelawat, the eighth typhoon in the Western Pacific this year, was looming somewhere east of Okinawa and moving slowly in a westerly direction toward Taiwan, said the sources.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), Jelawat was centered 1,000 kilometers to the east of Taiwan on Sunday at noon and was moving westward at a pace of 15 kilometers per hour, but it began slowing on Monday. Consequently, the issuance of a storm warning for mariners, previously expected to be made Monday morning, was delayed further.
Jelawat's speed reduced from 15 km per hour to 11 km per hour at around noon on Monday, thereby postponing its influence on the Taiwan area, noted CWB weathermen.

The chances for torrential rains on the island also decreased, with only southern Taiwan forecast to be hit by occasional showers on Monday and Tuesday, said the weathermen, adding that temperatures should remain high islandwide, hovering between 32 and 34 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 125.44 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 125.44 points to close at 7,715.99.
Market turnover amounted to NT$48.15 billion (US$1.55 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 125.44 points to close at 7,715.99, the lowest level this year.
Due to a lack of confidence on the part of investors, the bourse opened at 7,804 and fluctuated between 7,809.44 and 7,680.53, also a record low for this year, during trading.

A total of 1.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.15 billion (US$1.55 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.28 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$51.66 billion.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.4 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.2 percent, cement shares at 1.9 percent, electrical stocks at 1.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.5 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 430 to 81, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Monday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved down 74 points to close at 7,805, with 3,235 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September decreased 85 points to finish at 7,830, with 173 contract transactions, while December futures plunged 101 points to close at 7,858, with four contract transactions.
Next March futures lost 42 points to finish at 8,017, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 7,879 for August; 7,915 for September; 7,959 for December; 8,059 for next March; and 8,200 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
August TE futures moved down 4.5 points to close at 407, with 1,091 contract transactions, while September TE futures decreased 3.5 points to finish at 408, with 49 contract transactions.
December TE futures lost 9.2 points to close at 409.3, with five contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.
August TF futures plunged 26.2 points to close at 881, with 537 contract transactions, while September futures decreased 21.8 points to close at 887.4, with 26 contract transactions.
December TF futures moved down 24 points to finish at 892, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAO OFFERS 30-DAY VISA-FREE STAYS FOR TAIWANESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: To further attract more Taiwanese tourists, Macao on Monday extended the length of visa-free stays for visitors from Taiwan from 20 days to 30 days, reported the Macao Tourism Bureau.

The new 30-day visa-free treatment, taking effect on Monday, will allow more Taiwanese tourists to visit Macao for a longer period of time, particularly during this August when a gourmet food festival is being held in the former Portuguese enclave.

The number of Taiwanese tourists visiting Macao has substantially increased since the visa-free policy was implemented and is expected to further surge as Taiwan and Macao's airlines have agreed to add 300 flights between the two sides this summer, said officials from the Macao Tourism Bureau.

In addition to the food festival, the Ghost Festival, a traditional Chinese festival devoted to bribing wandering souls of the afterworld, is scheduled to kick off in Macao on Aug. 13. Also, an international fireworks competition is slated for early September, with contestants from more than 10 countries participating, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTISTS DEVELOPING NEW LIGHT BULB

TEXT.P: Australian scientists at Australian National University in Canberra are developing a revolutionary light bulb capable of shining for 50 years.

Professor Chennupati Jagadish, the head of the research team, told reporters on Sunday that the new bulb uses light-emitting diodes, or LEDs, that produce white light. He said a diode producing ultra-violet light is coated with phosphor, and the phosphor glows white.

But the light producing part of a modern LED is only about one square millimeter and is not strong enough for home or office lighting. The light must be 100 times stronger in order to be of practical use, he noted.
He said a possible solution could be to bundle from 50 to 100 white LEDs -- now worth about A$10 (US$6.30) each, adding that mass production would cut the price of the light bulbs.
Bulbs made from white LEDs would be more environmentally friendly and far cheaper to run than conventional ones as they would reduce power consumption by a factor of 10, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG CHO-CHUN TO HEAD TAIPEI CITY POLICE HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: Wang Cho-chun, currently the director of Taichung City Police Headquarters, will become the director of Taipei City Police Headquarters, it was announced on Monday.

Wang will fill the vacancy left by Wang Chin-wang, who will be promoted to director-general of the National Police Administration. Ting Yuan-chin, who was the original NPA head, resigned over the river rescue fiasco earlier this month.

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, in announcing Wang's new position, said he hopes Wang will continue to work toward meeting the high expectations of Taipei residents for a better and safer living environment.
Wang said he has been living away from Taipei for a long time and will therefore need some time to fully grasp the situation and decide the future direction of Taipei city's police force.
Wang said that after he assumes his new post, he will first visit with rank-and-file police officers to learn what their needs and concerns are.
He also stated that he will make social order and security his top priority, saying that Taipei Mayor Ma attaches special importance to the issue.
Furthermore, he said he will be strict about internal discipline and the auditing of the police officers.

Wang, whose specialty is criminal cases, said that he feels some regret about leaving Taichung, where some major crimes remain unsolved, including the high-profile case of a pregnant woman being shot in a downtown department store and the murder of the wife of an American businessman.
In addition, Wang pointed out that the problem of an insufficient police force in Taichung has yet to be resolved and that police relations with the people at the grassroots level are not ideal.

Wang, 49, will become the youngest director to head Taipei City Police Headquarters. After graduating from Central Police University in 1975, he served in various rank-and-file jobs on the police force before working his way up to deputy director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau in 1994, and then director of Taichung City Police Headquarters in 1996.
Wang has followed in his father Wang Lu-chiao's footsteps. The elder Wang served as the top police officer on the Taipei police force between 1972 and 1974.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SPECIAL ENVOY FOR ROC-US DIALOGUE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Monday denied a press report that President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Chiou I-jen, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), as his special envoy for consultations with the United States.

The Liberty Times, a Taipei-based Chinese daily, said in a front-page report that former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's special envoy with the United States Ding Mou-shih has offered to resign from his current post as a "senior adviser to the President" because his "special envoy" role has been replaced by Chiou.

"The report was wrong," Deputy Secretary-General to the President Chen Tze-nan said, adding that President Chen respects the Republic of China's existing administrative system and would not name any special envoy or "emissary" for dialogue with any other country.
Under the present system, Chen said, the ROC's representative office in Washington, D.C. is fully authorized to take charge of Taiwan's relations with the United States.
Nevertheless, Chen confirmed that Ding, a veteran career diplomat, really has sent a letter to President Chen expressing his intention to resign from the "senior adviser" post.
"I think President Chen will respect Ding's personal desire," Chen said.

Ding once served as the ROC's foreign affairs minister and its representative or de facto ambassador to the United States. During his stint as the NSC secretary-general, Ding traveled to the United States annually to hold closed-door meetings with President Bill Clinton's senior national security advisers on cross-Taiwan Strait issues and the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.

Ding's role as a special security envoy with the United States began in 1996 when mainland China test-fired missiles and conducted live-fire war games in waters near Taiwan in an attempt to influence the result of the ROC's first-ever presidential election. Amid escalating tension in the Taiwan Strait, the Clinton administration took the initiative to forge a high-level communication mechanism with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties

Then-ROC President Lee assigned Ding to travel to New York for behind-the-scenes meetings with senior US officials on Taiwan Strait security affairs. Those meetings were believed to have help stabilize the cross-strait situation, and such high-level ROC-US dialogue mechanism has since been maintained. Ding traveled to the United States once a year to meet senior US security officials until Lee ended his presidential tenure on May 20.
According to the Liberty Times, President Chen has retained Ding as a "senior adviser to the President" at the recommendation of his predecessor in view of Ding's role in high-level ROC-US dialogue.
However, the Liberty Times said, incumbent NSC Deputy Secretary-General Chiou has gradually taken over Ding's "special envoy" job since the inauguration of President Chen's administration.

For instance, the paper said, Chiou traveled to the United States in mid-July to meet with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky to discuss issues related to Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization.

During that trip, the paper speculated that Chiou might also hold secret talks with US national security advisers and State Department officials on the Taiwan Strait situation. The paper said Chiou's US visit marked a quiet completion of personnel replacement for the high-level Taipei-Washington dialogue mechanism.

However, Chiou himself denied the report. "I'm neither President Chen's special envoy for dialogue with the United States nor the parallel unit for the ROC government's dialogue mechanism with the US White House National Security Council," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT NEEDED BEFORE OPENING DOOR TO M'LAND CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan might open its capital market to mainland Chinese funds in a prudent and gradual manner only after carefully considering national security, management control, and other essential issues, said a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official on Monday.

Noting that the Republic of China's opening of its doors to mainland Chinese capital would have a greater impact on Taiwan society than the establishment of direct trade, transportation, and communications links with the mainland, Fu Dong-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, said in-depth and comprehensive assessments by all agencies concerned will have to be conducted before the government decides on the issue.
Fu pointed out that Taiwan currently bans the entry of mainland capital in principle, but grants permission to a few applicants on a case-by-case basis.
The stakes are high, particularly when mainland capital goes into Taiwan's high technology industries and financial markets, Fu added.

He also pointed out that once mainland capital is permitted to enter Taiwan, mainland Chinese handlers of those funds, as well as their spouses and children, will also be allowed to come, saying this will immediately result in the appearance of related education, marriage, insurance, and health care issues.
Fu made the remarks at a hearing hosted by New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao at the Legislative Yuan on the topic of whether it is safe or not to allow mainland Chinese capital into Taiwan.

Lai said that Taiwan's opening of its capital markets to mainland Chinese funds should not be a forbidden issue, but added that the ROC government should come up with a control task force to monitor the flow of this capital in and out of the country.

Lai said Taiwan should at least establish an "economic security task force," manned by officials from all related agencies, to monitor the applications, screening, control, and verification of the activities of the mainland funds.

Due to the different "political significance" behind mainland Chinese capital and capital from other countries and areas, Taiwan must come up with proper legislation governing mainland Chinese capital so as to make the management of such transactions transparent and legitimate, Lai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFORMITY OF GAS PRICES ISLANDWIDE TO BE BROKEN IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Formosa Gasoline, an affiliate of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), is going to break the uniformity of gasoline and diesel prices islandwide when it comes onto the market this September.

Wang Yun-ming, vice secretary-general of the Ministry of Economic Affair's Energy Commission, said on Monday that the FPG will obtain a license from the Energy Commission this week to operate its naphtha cracking plant in the offshore Mailiao Industrial Complex in Yunlin County, paving the way for an end to the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corporation's decades-old monopoly on oil sales in Taiwan.
This means that each gas station will now be able to decide for itself the price of its gasoline and diesel.
Consumers will likely be able to purchase fuel more cheaply in northern Taiwan than in other areas because of the keener level of competition there. (Yolanda K. C. Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES SOUTH AFRICAN OMBUDSMAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed the hope to a visiting South African ombudsman on Monday that ombudsmen agencies between the two nations could increase cooperation and exchanges.
Lu made the remarks when he received Selby Baqwa, South African National Public Protector, at the Presidential Office.

Lu also wished success for the 7th conference of International Ombudsman Institute (IOI), which is scheduled to be held in Durban, South Africa in late October this year. The meeting is held every four years.

Baqwa said Taiwan's democratic development and economic liberalization is well-known in South Africa. He added that he was glad to have experienced it and exchanged views with the Control Yuan, the ROC's highest watchdog body.

Lu told the South African visitor that she has long been concerned with political democratization, human rights protection and the rights of women. She added that the political and economic development of the island has been the result of the long-term efforts of its people, with women playing a vital role, especially in the economic sphere.
She noted that women now comprise one-fourth of the members of the Cabinet. More women will go to the politics in the future, she said, adding that this will be a good development.

Baqwa and his wife arrived here on Sunday at the invitation of the Control Yuan. They will visit the Legislative Yuan and the Government Information Office during their stay in Taiwan, which winds up on Friday.
Headquartered in Canada, the IOI had 108 members as of the end of last year. Taiwan joined the organization in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: JULY TWO-WAY TRADE HITS NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two-way foreign trade continued to gain momentum in July with both exports and imports hitting new single-month records, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Monday.

The country's export trade totaled US$13.60 billion in July, up a whopping 36.5 percent over that posted in the same month of the previous year, while import trade amounted to US$13.47 billion, a sparkling increase of 41.9 percent, MOF officials noted.
July's brilliant performance marked another two-digit monthly growth in foreign trade -- the 10th month in a row -- cementing the fact that Taiwan's foreign trade has been on a tear in recent months.

With brisk performance in July, usually a slow month for foreign trade, MOF officials predicted that Taiwan's annual growth of exports for the year 2000 is expected to top 20 percent, while that of imports will advance by an even larger margin of 25 to 26 percent.

The MOF officials attributed the remarkable growth in export trade in the first seven months of this year mainly to the ongoing economic recovery in the Asia-Pacific region and the steadily expanding economies in Europe and America.

Between Jan. 1 and July 31, exports of electronics, communications, machinery, steel and optical products as a whole grew an annual 32.9 percent, while those of traditional manufacturing industries and agricultural products edged up 9.8 and 18.5 percent, respectively, compared to the previous year.

During the same period, imports of capital goods surged 44.6 percent compared to the same period in 1999, while those of agricultural and industrial raw materials increased an annual 35.1 percent, MOF officials added.
The officials predicted that continuously expanding exports will fuel further growth in imports and domestic investment in the latter months of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INFLUENCE MAINLAND CHINA: EX-ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Tseng Chih-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui has said in a recent interview with Newsweek that Taiwan is creating a new culture which he believes will eventually influence mainland China.
Lee said although Taiwan is a small place vis-s-vis mainland China, it is developing a new culture intending to influence the Chinese mainland.

"It may take a period of 'two to three generations' for the new Taiwan culture to influence the mainland. I believe this scenario will certainly take place," the outspoken former leader of the Republic of China said.

Touching on mainland China's reform programs, Lee said "globalization" was taboo in mainland China three years ago. But, today, the mainland leaders have begun to promote globalization. Lee said he thinks mainland China will continue its reform path. But it will take time for the mainland to complete its ambitious reform programs.
Lee further said it is important for the United States to continue leading mainland China into the international community by adopting an "engagement" policy.

Turning to relations across the Taiwan Strait, Lee said Taiwan is bound to adjust its trade policy toward the mainland after both sides of the strait are admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the near future.

Lee said Taiwan's agricultural industry will certainly face a serious challenge after its WTO accession as prices for many mainland Chinese agricultural products are only half or one-third of those for Taiwan-grown ones.

Taiwan must also adjust its current "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China following its WTO entry, Lee said, adding that Taiwan should make a prudent review before making necessary adjustments.

Asked about his views on Beijing's restrictions on Taiwanese investors on the mainland, Lee said when Taiwanese businesspeople make forays into the mainland market, most of them are aware that they will face unfavorable treatment there. It's not uncommon that Beijing leaders use business for political purposes, he noted.

Lee, an outspoken critic of mainland China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, said Taiwan must impose some barriers or adopt some measures in opening cross-strait shipping links. Otherwise, Lee said he is afraid that Taiwan would become part of the PRC.
Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait shipping links. But merchant ships from Taiwan make an estimated 1,300 visits to the mainland by making a stopover at Okinawa annually.

Lee made strenuous efforts to upgrade the ROC's international profile and break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation during his 12-year presidential stint. He has retired from public service since stepping down from the presidency on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.022 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 31.092.
The local currency opened Monday at 31.067 and was traded between 31.065 and 31.099.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$297 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO HEAD HUMAN RIGHTS PANEL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has assigned Vice President Annette Lu to serve as the convenor of a national human rights consultation panel, the Presidential Office said on Monday.

Chen Che-nan, acting secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said in a routine press conference that the President will respect Lu's ideas about the future direction and the members of the panel.

The panel is expected to seek to establish a national human rights committee and its members will include such human rights activists as writer Po Yang and Huang Wen-hsiung, former president of the Taiwan Association for Human Rights, as well as human rights organizations, such as Amnesty International.

Noting that President Chen will embark on Sunday on a visit to six allies in the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa, Chen Che-nan said that the Presidential Office will set up a hot line to keep in touch with the president during his absence.

Meanwhile, Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, stressed that the main purpose of the visit will be to cement relations with the allies, and will not touch on new aid projects to the allies.
Chien added that all foreign aid programs are being carried out by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, according to its plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MODIFIES RULES FOR MAINLAND VISITS BY RANKING OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) decided on Monday to modify current rules so as to impose more restrictive conditions on visits to mainland China by ranking ROC government officials.

The MAC, while screening a draft worked out by the Interior Ministry, decided to add the new act to current government regulations regarding mainland visits by people from Taiwan. The new rules demand that ranking government appointees and officials in charge of national security and intelligence affairs inform the Bureau of Entry and Exit of their scheduled retirements two weeks in advance.

In cases of early or unscheduled departure from public office, government departments concerned will be required to report any resignations to the bureau immediately, and send related documents to the bureau before the official date that such officials leave their posts.
High-level retired government officials planning to visit the mainland will be asked to submit their applications to the bureau at least three weeks prior to their slated departure.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung admitted that the council's decision to adopt the act was prompted by the arrest in July by mainland Chinese authorities of a former ranking National Security Bureau (NSB) official whose whereabouts remain unknown, despite efforts by relevant government authorities and lawmakers to rescue him.

Pan Hsi-hsien, a former ranking NSB official and a personnel manager for a Taiwan-invested company in Dongguan, in mainland China's Guangdong province, was detained by mainland Chinese police for unknown reasons in late June.
The news shocked Taiwan, because Pan had headed for mainland China on June 1, only three days after retiring from the NSB.

Pan's wife, claiming that his husband had traveled to the mainland for business purposes only, has asked the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to help rescue Pan through its connection with the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary bodies authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACEFUL UNIFICATION CHARACTERIZES BEIJING POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: The strategy of promoting "peaceful unification" has again become the axis of mainland China's policy toward Taiwan since mid-July, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, pointed out in an analysis of the latest mainland situation that mainland China adopted a "wait-and-see" attitude toward Taiwan after the Republic of China's March 18 presidential election.

Much to Beijing's surprise, Chen Shui-bian, the standard bearer of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), won the presidency in the hotly contested race. The Beijing leadership then said it would listen to Chen's words and watch his deeds in gauging changes in Taiwan's internal politics and the DPP-led government's policy toward the mainland.

The MAC report said as the new ROC government has repeatedly held out olive branches to Beijing since its May 20 inauguration, mainland Chinese authorities have felt the pressure to respond to Taiwan's goodwill appeal.

Against this backdrop, the MAC report said mainland China has adjusted its double-handed strategy toward Taiwan since mid-July. On the one hand, the report said, mainland China has softened its rhetoric on Taiwan-related affairs and stepped up efforts to court various Taiwanese groups, particularly subgroups in the ROC's Legislative Yuan, or parliament.

On the other, the report said, Beijing has continued its diplomatic and military pressure on Taiwan and has also not stopped its criticism of selected ROC officials for their stances on cross-strait ties, such as Vice President Annette Lu and MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.

Generally speaking, the MAC report said, mainland China has returned to its old path of promoting "peaceful unification" of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as the gist of its policy toward Taiwan. Nevertheless, the report said, Beijing is not expected to cease its diplomatic embargo and military pressure against Taiwan in order to force the island into negotiation for unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 7, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1556: A UFO appears above Basle in Switzerland.
1830: Louis Philippe, known as the "Citizen King," is proclaimed King of France on the abdication of Charles X.
1840: Law brings protection for children when British Parliament passes a law forbidding the indenturing of child chimney sweeps.
1858 Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations, and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab-Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: US marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four communist warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the fat one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people and injuring 852 others with property damage surpassing NT$3.4 billion.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H. K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office arrives to assume his post.
1983: Chinese communist air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jet fighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders US troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to US markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting between Siew and his Macedonian counterpart, Ljubco Georgievski.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TAKE INITIATIVE TO PROMOTE CULTURAL EXCHANGE WITH PRC

TEXT.P: Chen Yu-hsiu, chair of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), said on Monday that Taiwan will take the initiative to promote cultural exchanges with mainland China.
Chen aired her views on cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges of cultural and artistic relations while meeting with the media.
She stressed that the CCA's new policy is to take the initiative, rather than waiting for invitations from mainland China.
The scholar-turned-official also stated that she herself would be pleased to visit mainland China in her official capacity if invited by Beijing to promote cultural and artistic exchanges.
Chen also reiterated the importance of respecting regional culture and arts.
She said that under a cultural promotion project jointly sponsored by the CCA and the Cultural Development Foundation, a Beijing opera troupe will arrive in Taipei on Aug. 16.
If the weather permits, the troupe will give a free public performance on the square of the National Theater in Taipei on the night of Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECORDS US$ 113.52 BILLION FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$113.52 billion as of the end of July, down US$303 million from the previous month, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Monday.
Taiwan retains its third-highest ranking in foreign exchange reserves in the world, behind Japan and mainland China.
Sources said that as the New Taiwan dollar faced depreciatory pressure during July, the CBC intervened to bolster the local unit, resulting in the decreased national foreign exchange reserves.
Nevertheless, July's figure is still an increase of US$14.93 billion from the same month last year, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA DELEGATION TO OBSERVE DISTRIBUTION METHODS IN US

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will send a trade mission on Aug. 23 to observe product distribution methods in the United States, a CETRA spokesman said on Monday.

He said that the planned mission will visit product distribution centers and bonded warehouses in New York, Los Angeles and Miami so as to help local traders upgrade their competitiveness in markets in the United States and Latin America.

The mission, headed by Kao I-hsin, secretary general of CETRA, will also visit local government agencies and banking institutions. It has also scheduled a series of symposia with accountants and lawyers during its stay in the United States, he said.
The mission will also meet with Taiwan businessmen who have already set up bonded warehouses in the United States to share their experiences and opinions on the distribution business, he said.
The mission is scheduled to return to Taipei on Sept. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENDANGERED SEA BIRD SPECIES SPOTTED IN MATSU

TEXT.P: At least eight Chinese crested terns, an endangered sea bird species, have been spotted for the first time on Taiwan's frontline islands of Matsu, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Monday.
COA officials said as the total world population of Chinese crested terns falls below 100, the latest discovery has caught the attention of the international wildlife conservation community.
The first-ever discovery of the rare bird in the Republic of China territory came as a surprise, COA officials said.

According to COA officials, Liang Chieh-teh, a noted Taiwan nature photographer, first spotted a special sea bird with long pointed wings and a forked tail in a wildlife reserve on the ROC-held Matsu Islands in June this year.
Liang informed the Institute of Zoology of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic body, of the discovery, and a sea bird researcher with the institute then traveled to Matsu for a field study.

The Academia Sinica researcher confirmed that the rare bird was a highly treasured Chinese crested tern. The ROC Wild Bird Society then informed the International Wild Bird Federation of the new discovery.

COA officials said major international wild bird organizations and heavyweight wild bird researchers from several foreign countries have expressed interest in the new discovery. Some international news media have contacted the Lienchiang County Government, which administers civilian affairs in the Matsu Islands area, for producing a special film introducing the rare bird.
COA officials said at least eight Chinese crested terns have so far been detected in the Matsu Islands wildlife reserve and that four relevant nests have been discovered in the area.

The Chinese crested tern was discovered for the first time in the world in 1863. Over the past 100-plus year, only five groups of the bird have been recorded. The latest two records documented 10 Chinese crested terns discovered in Thailand in July 1980 and three discovered in northern mainland China in September 1991.

COA officials said there are still no detailed records concerning the bird's natural habitats, outer features and habits. The bird is listed as an "endangered species" in the World Wild Bird Red Book.

According to the officials, the Chinese crested tern looks like the greater crested tern, a rare migrant bird species found in Taiwan's coastal region. But the Chinese crested tern is smaller than the greater crested tern.

COA Vice Chairman Lin Kuo-ching said the discovery of the Chinese crested tern marks an achievement of Taiwan's wildlife conservation campaign. "We should continue our efforts in this regard to ensure our sustainable development," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNCILORS VISIT MAINLAND FOR DIRECT 'MINI 3 LINKS'

TEXT.P: A Kinmen County Council delegation left for mainland China on Monday for a fact-finding visit aimed at promoting an early opening of direct "mini three links" between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China's southeastern port cities.

As the Republic of China government still bans direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, the delegation had to traveled to Taipei first and then flew to mainland China's Fujian province via Hong Kong.
Kinmen, an ROC-held defense outpost, is 150 nautical miles from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, but the shortest distance from Kinmen to Fujian is only 2.3 kilometers.

Kinmen County Council Speaker Chen Shui-tsai, leader of the delegation composed of six councilors and their aides, said the group will collect first-hand information about mainland China's preparations for the proposed opening of direct trade, postal and shipping links (commonly known as mini three links) between Taiwan's outlying islands and southeastern mainland port cities, such as Fujian's Xiamen and Fuzhou.

According to a bill passed by the Legislative Yuan early this year, three outlying islands -- Kinmen, Penghu and Matsu -- will be allowed to open direct "mini three links" with southeastern mainland port cities to help boost the offshore islands' economic development.

In line with the bill, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is evaluating the feasibility of the proposed opening of the "mini three links" with a view to maintaining a balance between national security and practical needs of the offshore islands.

Noting that the opening of "mini three links" holds the key to Kinmen's future economic development, Chen said he hopes the MAC can give a green light to the liberalization proposal and complete all necessary preparations as soon as possible.

During its 10-day visit, the group will visit Fuzhou, Quanzhou and Xiamen of Fujian province, which lies opposite Taiwan. In addition to meeting with officials of the three cities, the delegation will also tour major port facilities and local community development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN TO PROBE 'EMISSARY' CASE

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan said on Monday it has decided to probe a high-profile "emissary" case involving two officials of the former Kuomintang government in holding secret talks with their mainland Chinese counterparts in the early 1990s.

The Republic of China's highest watchdog body said it has appointed three Control Yuan members to investigate the "emissary" case involving Su Chih-cheng, former President Lee Teng-hui's closest aide, and Cheng Shu-min, a former chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs.

The three Control Yuan members -- Kang Ning-hsiang, Lin Shih-chi and Lee Shen-yi -- will investigate whether Su and Cheng had violated the country's Civil Service Law, National Security Law, Criminal Code and other related regulations, the Control Yuan said.

"We want to know whether the Presidential Office, the National Security Council, the National Security Bureau and other relevant government agencies were aware of the "emissary" decision-making and enforcement processes," Kang said, adding that the Control Yuan also hope to know whether government funds had been legally used in carrying out secret contacts with mainland China during Lee's presidential stint.

Kang said the probe is necessary to determine whether any civil servants and government agencies should be held responsible for any irregularities or negligence in the case in order to ensure national security and the well-being of all fellow countrymen.

News about Su and Cheng holding secret talks with mainland Chinese representatives in Hong Kong and even several mainland cities in the early 1990s to forge cross-strait rapprochement was broken in July, roughly two months after the transfer of the helm of the country from the KMT to the Democratic Progressive Party.

Su, now a deputy head of the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank, and Cheng, chairwoman of the KMT-controlled China Television Co., had confirmed press reports about their roles in secret cross-strait contacts in the 1990s, but they declined to go into detail.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGES GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO REDUCE SPENDING

TEXT.P: People First Party Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung on Monday urged government agencies to reduce what he described as their "lavish spending."

Chang singled out Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic institution, saying that if this so-called "clear stream" of local society continues spending lavishly, the PFP will attempt to slash its budget for next year during legislative screening.

Chang, who returned from the United States on Sunday after attending the Republican Party convention, said that he saw "benign competition among US political parties," which he said has resulted in the progress of "various systems." However, he added that he still saw "old thinking" in Taiwan's new government.

He claimed that "excessive spending by government agencies and schools" is carried out in order to use up their budget allocation for fear that if they do not, their budgets will be cut the following year. Chang urged the government to examine its method of budget allocation in order to put an end to such spending.

The former medical doctor also said it is worth promoting the environmental protection industry at a time when the nation hopes to increase its national competitiveness. He also claimed that most of this industry is controlled by gangster-related groups.
Chang said the people will see if the new government has the courage to wipe out "the gangsters in this industry."

He also revealed that the PFP will suggest at an upcoming interparty round table meeting that the new government review the broker system for foreign laborers, because it has "caused many problems in society."

He said that under the current broker system, foreign laborers and their employers have to repeatedly pay agent fees. In addition, he further claimed that government regulations stipulate that foreign laborers must return to their home countries every two years, which he said means employers are always short of qualified laborers and that some foreign laborers abscond when their contracts are due to expire.

DOC.HEADLINE: REASSESSMENT OF NEW NUKE PLANT TO BE COMPLETED SOON: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei on Monday told anti-nuclear legislators, experts, and scholars that a reassessment committee's report on the continued construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant will be completed "in the near future."

Tang received an 11-person delegation that included Chen Mo-shing, director of the Energy Systems Research Center at the University of Texas at Arlington, legislators Liao Hsueh-kuang and Ke Chien-ming, anti-nuclear groups, and others to exchange opinions on the cost-effectiveness of various power generation methods, alternatives for Taiwan, pollution issues, and comparative studies with other countries.

Tang said that there would have been no room for discussion if the government had simply followed the laws set by the Legislative Yuan. However, he added that the new government decided to reassess the construction project because it is considered "a major issue" that should be discussed fairly and openly.

He went on to say that anyone -- whether for or against nuclear power -- is welcome to speak out freely during the re-evaluation process, and that detailed minutes of the discussions will be made public so that the entire process is transparent.

Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant was halfway through its construction when controversy over whether the plant should continue to be built prompted the Ministry of Economics Affairs to organize an ad hoc committee of scholars and experts to re-evaluate the project.
Chen, a member of the committee, espouses the use of alternative fuels such as liquefied natural gas to generate electricity for Taiwan.

Noting that the fourth nuclear plant project was approved by the Legislative Yuan in 1993, Tang had said earlier that the government has to re-evaluate the project in light of the issues of environmental protection, security problems, and the island's strong anti-nuclear movement.
Construction work that has not been started has been put on hold pending the reassessment committee's report, which is expected to be delivered in September.
Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged the anti-nuclear groups to make use of more persuasion and less emotion when making their arguments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERCUSSION GROUP TO PERFORM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United Kingdom-based percussion music group STOMP will give eight performances at the Taipei International Convention Center from Oct. 20, the promoter of the event said on Monday.

International New Aspect Cultural and Educational Foundation head Hsu Po-yun said the group was formed in Britain 10 years ago and uses everyday items such as brooms, trash can lids and lighters to create their distinctive brand of percussion.
The group, which will also perform in Shanghai and Beijing, is influenced by Oriental and African dance and percussion, with a dash of humor added, said Hsu.
Further information can be obtained by calling 02-2709-3788.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CHINESE WOMEN GO TO HONG KONG FOR ILLICIT PROSTITUTION

TEXT.P: More and more mainland Chinese women are coming to Hong Kong for illicit prostitution, according to official statistics compiled by the immigration office.

The statistics showed that the number of female travelers who were caught by Hong Kong authorities for prostitution increased from 900 in 1997, to 1,700 in 1998, 1,900 in 1999, and 1,200 in the first half of 2000. Hong Kong became part of China on July 1, 1997.
Hong Kong news media quoted immigration officials as saying Monday that most of them were mainland Chinese women, who came to Hong Kong and usually stayed for three months on valid travel documents.

The reports said many of the disguised Chinese tourists also went to Thailand on Chinese passport for a one-month stay, and then made a seven-day stopover in Hong Kong for prostitution on their way home. They seldom overstayed their travel permit in Hong Kong.
The Chinese mainland has replaced some countries in Southeast Asia as the major source of prostitutes to Hong Kong, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WELCOMES ROUNDTABLE MEETING CALLED BY PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said on Monday that the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.

Lin said the KMT, the former ruling party which shifted central government power to the Democratic Progressive Party on May 20, would be willing to take part in such a meeting, as long as it is beneficial to national security and interests.

Lin's remarks came just hours before a meeting scheduled between Chen and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and representatives from other major opposition parties -- mainly the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party -- aimed at paving the way for a much-anticipated formal roundtable meeting between the different political camps.
Wang claimed that the gathering slated for Monday evening would be just a "union," and that no specific topics had been settled for discussion.

At the same time, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung said in a news conference that the people of Taiwan have placed high expectations on the roundtable meeting because the pubic is disappointed with the performance of Chen's administration.
Chang said he hopes the cross-party roundtable meeting will proceed smoothly and achieve consensus on important issues of national concern to display its determination to achieve government reforms.

Although PFP Chairman James Soong lost the March 18 presidential race, Chang said Soong is clearly aware that Taiwan "cannot afford to lose" and that the PFP head is willing to make a contribution to the nation through his participation in the meeting.

As to a scheduled Tuesday meeting between Soong and DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh, the PFP vice chief described it as a positive thing, since the transfer of government power, which is a common practice in a democratic country, does not mean "live or die."

Meanwhile, other sources close to the PFP revealed that Soong and Hsieh will exchange opinions on major national issues during their meeting and that Soong may air his policy regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations as part of his efforts to demand that the ruling DPP face the existing problems.

In the face of the upcoming Beidaihe meeting in mainland China in which the Beijing leadership is expected to outline mainland China's future policy toward Taiwan, a PFP department chief said it may be a crisis or a turning point for Taiwan's future.

If the government still refuses to clarify its stance on mainland China, the PFP policy planner asserted that it will undermine Taiwan's interests and added that the PFP, as an effective opposition party, will express its viewpoints and grave concern over this critical facet of Taiwan's future.
Out of consideration for the overall national interest, a PFP spokesman said the party is willing to shrug off political differences and participate in the roundtable meeting.

In a related development, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who had just returned from a trip to San Francisco, was reluctant to comment on the establishment on Saturday of a cross-strait task force led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.
Lien told reporters that he had no idea about the special ad hoc group, and described it as an "outlaw" organization.

Responding to a question as to whether he was planning to visit mainland China in the near future, Lien said he will consider doing so at the "proper time" if it can help boost the well-being and security of the Taiwan people.

Accompanied by ranking party officials, Lien paid a four-day visit to San Francisco to meet KMT supporters. It was his first trip to the United States since being defeated by Chen in the March 18 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PROMOTING TOURISM IN QUAKE-HIT AREAS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Tourism Bureau is helping central Taiwan's hard-hit Nantou County to rebuild its tourism industry after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake made domestic travelers shy away from the area.

According to the Nantou County Government, the Tourism Bureau has begun an advertising campaign to encourage the public to travel to Nantou and providing transportation and lodging information about the area. It is also urging travel agencies and government agencies to organize group tours to the disaster area and provide low-interest financing to the local tourism industry.

The county government said that Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan is scheduled to accompany the first in a series of groups of ministry employees to visit Nantou on Aug. 17 to host the opening ceremony of a county agricultural and specialty product fair.

A total of 125,000 ministry employees and workers of state enterprises under the jurisdiction of the ministry are scheduled to visit Nantou in five groups to "provide tangible help" to the area's tourism industry, the county government added.

The Tourism Bureau, which is a subordinate agency of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, also accepted the Nantou County Government's suggestion to ask the Weather Bureau to refrain from being overly vague in its reporting, pointing out that phrases such as "mountainous areas will experience thunderstorms, please beware of mudslides" can risk ruining the entire area's tourism prospects with one broad stroke.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S VISA CARD SPENDING HITS NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: More and more Taiwan consumers are whipping out their Visa cards when making purchases, as Visa's total turnover in Taiwan hit a new high in the first half of this year, according to statistics reported on Monday by Visa International Service Association.

Taiwan shoppers charged NT$243.3 billion (US$7.85 billion) on their Visa cards during the first half of this year, an annual increase of 17.48 percent, Visa officials said. They forecasted that total Visa card spending will reach more than NT$500 billion this year, a new record high for Taiwan and an indication of Visa's dominance in the island's credit card market.

Visa International Service Association said that Taiwan's credit card market has plenty of room to grow, because Taiwan consumers are used to paying cash for their purchases, with only 10 percent of consumers using credit cards. In comparison, that figure has reached 23 percent in the United States, 18 percent in Singapore, and 16 percent in Hong Kong, the firm said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POTENTIAL PAPER BUYER GETS COLD FEET

TEXT.P: A potential purchaser of the Taipei-based Independence Evening Post got cold feet at the last minute and asked on Monday for a postponement on the inking of a buyout contract.

Wang Shih-chin, a Taipei City councilman from the Democratic Progressive Party, said on Monday that he needed more time to reassess the financial health of the paper, and asked that the singing of a deal, slated originally for Aug. 10, be put on hold for another 10 to 15 days.

Wang said his friends had persuaded him to back away from the deal after he confirmed last week that he had offered to buy the paper out of respect for the paper's "objectivity" when the island was ruled by the Kuomintang under martial law.

However, he went on, given the financial hardships faced by the press amid the fierce competition posed by the electronic mass media and the huge capital needed to revitalize the paper, not to mention the impact of a possible exodus and layoff of workers, Wang said he needed more time to learn the ramifications of taking over a high-quality paper.
Wang, who tried unsuccessfully to set up "The Voice of Taipei" radio station, is said to be bending over backwards to acquire a paper to boost his bid for a seat in the Legislative Yuan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN SPEAKS TO OVERSEAS CHINESE RESIDENTS IN LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Shu Lu-sheng & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan told some 2,400 overseas Chinese residents at a gathering in Los Angeles on Sunday that the KMT's overseas work will be increased in the future.

The KMT lost its 55-year grip on power in Taiwan to the Democratic Progressive Party in last March's presidential election, but Lien said that despite this, the party will step up its work abroad, rather than reduce it.
On cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Lien said that the people on both sides of the strait should join hands to promote a peaceful change in mainland China.
He added that both the mainland and Taiwan should try to pursue a win-win resolution to the differences between the two sides, on a principle of rationality, mutual benefit and parity.

The KMT chairman arrived in Los Angeles from San Francisco earlier on Sunday, accompanied by KMT Vice Chairman Lin Cheng-chih, Cultural Affairs Department Director Jason Hu, Overseas Affairs Department Wang Neng-chang and former Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairman Chiao Jen-ho.
During his stay in Los Angeles, Lien was expected to continue to listen to suggestions on KMT reform and related matters from local party members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM TRADE UNION TO STAGE PROTEST ON AUG. 16

TEXT.P: The trade union of state-owned Chunghwa Telecom is planning to stage a street protest on Aug. 16 against the over-pricing of more-than 289 million shares that the government is planning to sell in late August.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) approved on Aug. 4 a plan to auction off 3 percent of the government's stake in Chunghwa Telecom within two weeks.
The offered price for each of the shares up for grabs was set at NT$104 (US$3.35) on Aug. 4 by a share price appraisal committee comprised of government officials.
The price provoked anger among Chunghwa Telecom employees, who said the price is much higher than the NT$60 passed by the legislature earlier in the year and makes it difficult for them to afford.

The Chunghwa Telecom trade union reached a consensus on Monday that it will take to the streets to seek a satisfactory response from the MOTC, or demand the resignation of Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan.

Tseng Chih-ming, a high-ranking union official, said the union had filed two appeals demanding that the MOTC diversify company employees' subscriptions and continue to protect the rights of those employees who are concurrently civil servants and laborers, after the privatization has been completed.
The auction in late August is part of the first phase of a privatization plan in which a total of 33 percent of the government's shares in Chunghwa Telecom will be sold off.
It is expected that the auction will augment government coffers by at least NT$30 billion.

During the first phase of privatization, the government will also release 13 percent of shares for public subscription in Taiwan, 5 percent for company employees' subscription, and 12 percent for listing on the New York Stock Exchange. The first phase of privatization is expected to be completed by the end of this year.
The government plans to release another 33 percent of its shares in February next year, with a goal of complete privatization by the end of June.
The two phases of privatization are expected to raise at least NT$660 billion for the government.
At present, Chunghwa Telecom is totally owned by the MOTC and has total capital of NT$96.48 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR DEFENSE DRILL HELD IN EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The eastern Taiwan county of Taitung held its annual joint civil and military air defense exercises on Monday to simulate evacuation procedures during enemy air raids or missile attacks.

Wanan No. 23 is a series of drills being held throughout Taiwan. It began in central Taiwan on Aug. 1 and was held in southern Taiwan on Aug. 4. It is scheduled to be held in the outlying island of Kinmen on Aug. 16 as well as in northern Taiwan and the islands of Penghu and Matsu.

Wanan No. 23 follows the rescue model imposed after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake and focuses on the operations of each county and city's coordination centers for civil defense mobilization in order to improve the public's ability to react. Local garrison forces are also called in to support and coordinate with civil defenses.

Monday's drills in Taitung covered only evacuation procedures but sources said that related units in Taitung County sent representatives to the southern city of Kaohsiung to observe and learn from the Aug. 4 drills there in preparation for a return to a full spectrum of disaster relief exercises next year.
Kinmen's scheduled drills will mark the first time that the Wanan series has been held on the island, which is only kilometers away from the southeastern coast of mainland China.

According to the Kinmen Police Headquarters, the civil defense portion of the 20-minute drill will only consist of emergency klaxon broadcasts, personnel evacuation, and traffic control because of the sensitivity involved in being in such close proximity to mainland China.

Police went on to say that Kinmen has already established a good foundation from past drills, which have included not only personnel evacuation, but also firefighting, rescue of the wounded, disaster shelters, emergency utility repairs, and civil defense mobilization.
Kinmen police added that a rehearsal will be held on Thursday and Friday before the real exercise is held.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 MAINLAND CHINESE FILMS TO AIR IN TAIPEI GOLDEN HORSE FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Under the recommendation of the Motion Picture Bureau of mainland China, three mainland-produced films will take part in the 2000 Taipei Golden Horse Film Exhibition, helping to promote films and cultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
A spokesman for the exhibition organizing committee said that the three films will be "The Last Bear Hunter," "My 1919" and "Endless."

"The Last Bear Hunter" is a Chinese version of the movie "Dancing with Wolves." Directed by Shih Hsuehhai, the film depicts a painting scholar who falls into a trap set by a tribe while studying the tribe. He is rescued by a daughter of the tribe's chief and they fall in love.

"Endless," starring Ge Yu and Wu Zhenlien depicts a taxi driver furious about the boss of a travel agency who fails to pay his taxi bills. He retaliates by kidnapping the boss's girlfriend. The film is directed by Feng Shiaokang.
"My 1919" is directed by Huang Zhienzhung and depicts Chinese diplomat W.C. Ku, who took part in the 1919 Paris Peace Talks on behalf of the Chinese government.
Three films shot by the Rolling Stone (Taiwan) Co. in mainland China will also be shown in the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS HOLD TALKS WITH JAPANESE COUNTERPARTS IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Tsai Tung-jung, a leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, on Monday urged the Japanese Diet to enact a Japanese version of the United States' Taiwan Relations Act.
He made the appeal while attending a symposium organized by the supra-party "Japan-ROC Parliamentarians Council" for a visiting 12-member parliamentarian delegation of which he was head.
Tsai also expressed the hope that Japanese political parties will follow the American model in supporting a proposal that Taiwan's future be decided by the Taiwan people.
The symposium was presided over by former Japan Defense Agency Director-General Sadanori Yamanaka, with more than 50 parliamentarians and aides participating.
The Republic of China's Representative to Japan, Lo Fu-chuan, also attended the hour-long symposium.

The Japanese side told the visitors that it would be almost impossible for Japan to enact a Japanese version of the Taiwan Relations Act, because the political situation in Japan is different from that of the United States.
However, they added that they expect both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to resolve their difference through peaceful means.
The DPP delegation arrived in Tokyo on Sunday. It will leave for Seoul on Aug. 9 to continue its "parliamentarian diplomacy" mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DISHES OUT MEASURES AIMED AT BOOSTING REAL ESTATE MARKET

TEXT.P: A package of measures aimed to boost the sagging real estate market was approved by the Cabinet on Monday.
Under the measures, the government will funnel at least NT$320 billion (US$10.32 billion) in prime loans to help house buyers, said Chung Chin, Government Information Office director-general.

Of the NT$320 billion, NT$20 billion will be used to help first-time house buyers aged between 20 and 40. Each of them can apply for a loan of NT$2.2 million (US$64,516) carrying an interest rate of 3 percent over a period of seven years.

The other NT$300 billion will carry an interest rate one percentage point over that given by the Postal Remittances & Saving Banks on two-year deposits, which stands currently at 5.35 percent but is subject to change.

Chung said that in order to sell unsold newly built houses, the government will try to decrease the over-supply of new houses by stopping the encouragement of construction and putting on hold the development of land owned by state-owned Taiwan Sugar Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXCHANGES VIEWS WITH LEADING LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian exchanged views with leading legislators over a banquet on Monday night in an attempt to seek support for his minority government in the legislature.

The formal banquet, hosted by Chen at the Taipei Guest Hall, which is usually reserved for state banquets for foreign dignities, brought together the leaders of Taiwan's four main political parties and one faction at the Legislative Yuan, as well as Premier Tang Fei and other government leaders.

Although the banquet was said to be a social gathering rather than a political event, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Chen exchanged views with the legislators on national issues, and especially ways to soothe the often jarring relations between the legislature and Chen's office.

Lai Shih-pao, a legislator of the New Party said afterward that Chen emphasized that he will abide by the Constitution and take charge of policy toward Beijing, diplomacy and defense, which will allow the premier to cope with domestic policy with full authority.
Tseng Yung-chuan, the KMT caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan, hailed the banquet as a goodwill gesture by Chen toward the opposition legislators.
He quoted Chen as ordering Tang at the banquet to consult with the opposition fully about the government budget, in order to ensure its passage.

Deputy Premier Chang Chun-hsiung was quoted by an attendant as suggesting raising the ceiling on government debts from 15 percent to 30 percent of the government's budget, but the attendant added that Chen did not respond.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Cabinet unveils a NT$342 billion package of low-interest loans for home purchases as part of its efforts to buoy the sluggish real estate market.
The China Times:
The Cabinet finalizes a four-point package designed to stimulate the island's real estate market and offer low-interest loans to first-time home buyers.

Low-interest loans, fewer housing starts are among new measures to boost the battered real estate market.

The China Post:
Loan package unlikely to solve housing market slump.

The government moves to boost real estate market.
The Taipei Times:
The Cabinet set to boost real estate sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 8, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
117: Hadrian becomes emperor of Rome after the death of Trajan.
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is finally defeated by the British.
1786: Dr. Michel Gabriel Paccard of Chamonix, Switzerland, and his porter, Jacques Balmat, complete the first ascent of the 4,807 meter Mont Blanc, the tallest peak in Europe outside the Caucasus range.
1834: Britain introduces workhouses for the poor.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler hangs four of his top men with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain, and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first US president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140, and that of Taipei 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: The SEF and ARATS sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the Republic of China attending.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 81.79 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 81.79 points to close at 7,797.78.
Market turnover amounted to NT$63.41 billion (US$2.05 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 81.79 points to close at 7,797.78.
Encouraged by a surge in the US stock market, the bourse opened at 7,751.28 and fluctuated between 7,818.67 and 7,670.28 during trading.

A total of 1.37 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.41 billion (US$2.05 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.19 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$48.15 billion.

Half of the eight major categories posted losses, with construction shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.9 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent. Textile issues, meanwhile, remained unchanged.
The other categories gained ground, with electrical stocks and bank and insurance shares moving up the most, both at 1.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 256 to 227, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Tuesday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved up 52 points to close at 7,857, with 4,391 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September increased 58 points to finish at 7,888, with 259 contract transactions, while December futures gained 41 points to close at 7,899, with three contract transactions.
However, next March futures moved down 17 points to finish at 8,000, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were: 7,805 for August; 7,830 for September; 7,858 for December; 8,017 for next March; and 8,126 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
August TE futures moved up 5.3 points to close at 412.3, with 1,395 contract transactions, while September TE futures increased 5 points to finish at 413, with 42 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures gained 9 points to close at 890, with 547 contract transactions, while September TF futures moved up 5 points to finish at 892.4, with nine contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CIST CHIEF CALLS FOR DOMESTIC MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: A former head of the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) said on Tuesday the Ministry of National Defense (MND) should "localize" military procurement and enact a law to protect competent officers.

Former CIST Director Shen Fang-cheng made the appeals during a public hearing on the implementation of the military supply policy under the two new "national defense laws" -- the National Defense Law and the MND Organization Law.
Shen pointed out that military build-up plans are usually designed for meeting the combat needs five to 10 years from now, while combat preparedness is aimed at meeting today's combat requirements.

In the past, Shen said, the General Staff Headquarters took full control of both military build-up and combat preparedness work. Against this background, he said, headquarters of the three military branches were only able to dish out their demand for tactical weapons and lacked the capability to draw up forward-looking military build-up plans.

In the future, Shen said he hopes that the new military supply bureau, scheduled to be inaugurated next July in accordance with the two new "national defense laws" will be authorized to handle all military build-up plans and work out the country's need for strategic weapons.

Shen said the military should "localize" its demand for weapons, equipment and other relevant supplies to help boost domestic economic development, facilitate defense operations and promote self-sufficiency in defense industry.

"If we use NT$100 billion (US$3.23 billion) in defense budget to purchase locally made military equipment, it will bring about value-added effects to relevant domestic industries," Shen said, adding that he simply couldn't understand why the military would purchase military trucks from South Korea since local automakers were able to produce similar vehicles.

Noting that cost should not be a decisive factor in making strategic investment, Shen said mainland China doesn't care how many Mirage jet fighters and Lafayette-class frigates Taiwan has made. "What mainland China really cares is which new weapons and new defense technology the CIST can develop," he noted.
"The CIST is a strategic unit where we have invested a very large amount of hard currency. And the institute has become one of our bargaining chips in negotiating with the mainland," Shen explained.

Touching on the upgrading of Taiwan's defense industry, Shen said the MND should first change its mentality and thinking. In the past, Shen said he once pushed for domestic development of submarines. "The MND then came up with a demand requiring the CIST to produce a Kilo-class submarine. Even the United States cannot manufacture this kind of Russian-developed underwater warship," he recalled.

Shen said the MND should be more realistic in working out weaponry procurement plans. "We should take into account our country's own subjective and objective conditions while drafting a procurement list," he urged.

Turning to the many scandals or kickback allegations involving major military procurement projects, Shen said the MND should legislate a comprehensive law or a set of regulations to protect capable, competent and law-abiding procurement officers. "Otherwise, competent, hard-working officers would all hesitate to take up procurement work," he added.
