DOC.HEADLINE: US SCIENTISTS FIND BETTER WAY TO STORE NUCLEAR WASTE

TEXT.P: American scientists working at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico said they have found a better way to store nuclear waste.

High-level radioactive waste is currently stored inside containers designed to last 100 years. After this time, they will begin to deteriorate, eventually exposing their dangerous contents to the environment. The problem is that the waste will continue to emit deadly radiation for tens of thousands of years.

The team of researchers said they have discovered that ceramic materials with chemical structures similar to fluorite crystals can withstand exposure to nuclear waste for a long time because the material's atoms shift to accommodate defects caused by radiation.
The research team, led by Kurt Sickafus of the US Department of Energy's laboratory, is developing the material by experimenting with different combinations of pyrochlore and fluorite compounds.
They found that the material becomes more resistant to the effects of radiation when large metallic ions, like zirconium, are added to the compounds' atomic structures.
The team is still trying to develop the right combination of compounds to make the strongest ceramic crystal for long-term storage of nuclear waste.
Each nuclear power plant produces about 20 tons of radioactive waste every year.
The scientists' study appears in the current issue of Science magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE IN RURAL CHINA SAID WORSE THAN IN SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Health care in rural China is considered worse than in sub-Saharan Africa as the impoverished rural population of more than 500 million only receives the most basic preventative health care, according to a report in The Australian Financial Review on Tuesday.

The daily reported that disruptions to mainland China's education system during the Cultural Revolution has left the country with less than 30,000 medically trained professionals, most of whom are based in the more developed cities on the eastern seaboard.

The daily quoted official Chinese figures as showing that China's infant mortality rate rose from 34.7 deaths per 1,000 in 1981 to 37 per 1,000 in 1992. The United Nations Children's Fund reckons the present figure is closer to 52 deaths per 1000 births.
The international aid agency Medecines Sans Frontieres claims that health in rural China is worse than in sub-Saharan Africa, the daily reported.

Previously, China's health care system relied on Mao Zedong's brigade of "barefoot doctors", who only received the most rudimentary medical training. Nevertheless, they were successful in lifting the health standards of China's rural poor, the daily reported.
From the early 1950s, China's infant mortality rate steadily declined while tuberculosis and other infectious diseases were also largely kept under control.

But the collapse of the rural communes from the early 1980s, brought about by the economic reforms of Deng Xiaoping, turned many of the achievements of the previous 30 years to dust, the daily reported.

Beijing is only now paying serious attention to the reform of the country's crumbling health care system, but most of the efforts are focused almost exclusively on city dwellers and do little for the 90 percent of peasants who have lost access to free medical treatment, the daily reported.

Under the government's new plan, Chinese workers will be required to pay the equivalent of 2 percent of their annual income into an individual medical fund. Employers have to contribute the equivalent of 6 percent of the employees' annual wage, with half being deposited in the individual fund and the other half going into a national health insurance program, the daily reported.

But the big problem with such a scheme is collecting such contributions from unprofitable state enterprises, analysts told the daily. The other problem is the ever-increasing cost of pharmaceuticals in mainland China, which could deprive most poor people of the ability to buy medicine or see doctors, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US INTELLIGENCE CONCERNED ABOUT ABILITY TO SATELLITE MONITOR PRC

TEXT.P: Reconnaissance satellite monitoring and analysis of Communist China is a growing concern for US intelligence operations, according to a report in the latest issue of Aviation Week & Space Technology Monday.

The weekly magazine reported that national security managers directly involved with US recon satellite tasking and image analysis said that the Chinese are already demonstrating the ability to use countermeasures capable of thwarting overhead surveillance.
"Mainland China is an example of a real challenge for the US intelligence community," intelligence managers were quoted as saying.

"In some ways it is difficult today, but it is also a looming intelligence challenge for tomorrow. The question is, have we devoted sufficient resources to one of the world's largest pieces of geography?" asked one manager.
"The Chinese are very good at denying us information. This is what in the community we call a `hard target,'" he added.
One major current problem is staffing. The analyst workforce is one-third smaller than in 1990, but the work they have to do has roughly doubled, according to the intelligence managers.

They said this has come from shrinking intelligence community resources while the size and diversity of the customer base for imagery (the military services, State Department, White House, etc.) has been growing every day.

The daily pointed out that these are problems that could have contributed to the US overlooking preparations for Indian nuclear tests in 1998 and the accidental bombing of the Communist Chinese embassy in 1999.
As a result, according to one official, the intelligence community has made a major investment in research on how to boost its understanding of nuclear test activity.

The database problems that led to the PRC embassy bombing are also being addressed. "There are a lot of issues being worked on now to address the quality of our databases. We have 21st century weapon systems and expectations, but our infrastructure is still far from Joint Vision 2010 (the Defense Department vision for information superiority)," he said.

Under normal circumstances, the largest share of US satellite tasking and analyst time is focused on the monitoring of key regions. As part of this, about 35-40 percent of the overhead assets and analysts are focused on regional military monitoring -- looking at the disposition of forces and equipment in areas such as Yugoslavia, Russia, Communist China, North Korea and Iraq.

About 15 percent of current US satellite recon capability is devoted to tracking nuclear, chemical, and biological proliferation targets. Another 10 percent of the work is devoted to "advance warning" issues, including checking the status of weapons that could directly threaten US interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN HAS TO DEAL OPENLY AND HONESTLY ON SPRATLYS AND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) papered over the real issues during last week's meetings in Bangkok, according to an editorial in the Bangkok Post on Tuesday.

From Burma's destabilizing drug trade, North Korea's missiles, and Indonesia's internal religious conflicts, through to China's belligerence over the Spratlys and Taiwan, no major controversial issue was raised by delegates to the meetings.
As a result, "The United Nations seems to consider ASEAN so incompetent that New York diplomats are offering international forces for Indonesia, without consulting ASEAN."
The editorial stressed that the 10-member ASEAN and 23-member ARF "must deal with such issues openly and honestly as the groups are designed to do."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCRUB TYPHUS CAN SUPPRESS VIRUS IN AIDS PATIENTS

TEXT.P: In a joint study involving researchers from the United States, the United Kingdom, and Thailand, it has been confirmed that scrub typhus, an insect-transmitted tropical disease which only occurs in Asia, can suppress HIV to undetectable levels, reported the Bangkok Post on Tuesday.
"The level of virus in the blood of four out of 10 AIDS patients in Chiang Rai and Mae Hong Son provinces fell dramatically," the daily reported.

"This drop is the exact opposite of what occurs with other infections in AIDS patients. No other infectious disease has shown the effects of reducing the HIV viral load," said Dr. George Watt, the leader of the research team.

The study involved 15 patients, 10 of whom were infected with scrub typhus, four with malaria, and one with leptospirosis. No improvement was found in the health of five other patients in the study infected with malaria and leptospirosis.

However, Somsong Rakphao, director general of the Communicable Diseases Control Department of the Ministry of Public Health, cautioned that the information could mislead the public into believing there is a cure for AIDS.
Dr. Patcharee Kantipong of Chiang Rai Prachanukoah Hospital said that the patients in the study received treatment for scrub typhus, but did not receive any anti-AIDS drugs.
She warned scrub typhus could lead to critical health conditions or even death among AIDS patients in a similar manner as other patients, if they do not receive proper treatment on time.
According to official statistics in Thailand, 2,597 patients were treated for scrub typhus last year, of whom three died of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC LIKELY TO INCREASE PRESSURE ON AUSTRALIA FOR BACKING US NMD

TEXT.P: Mainland China is expected to intensify its pressure on Australia to drop its support for the controversial US National Missile Defense (NMD) system through its vice foreign minister's visit to Canberra.
The Sydney Morning Herald reported that Yang Jiechi was scheduled to hold talks with Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and other senior officials on Tuesday.
The daily reported Yang, accompanied by the Chinese ambassador to Australia, is expected to lodge a very strong protest with Downer for Australia's support of the US NMD system.

The daily quoted foreign policy experts as predicting that the Beijing leadership will likely threaten that Australia's bid to export A$20 (US$12.5) billion worth of liquefied natural gas for power generation to the mainland could be at risk.

They also predicted that Australia's support for research into ballistic missile systems means that Canberra's carefully nurtured diplomatic and trade ties with mainland China could be under threat at a time of increasing regional instability, the daily reported.

Prime Minister John Howard and Downer are sympathetic to the US proposal to deploy a missile shield and are likely to support Washington if President Bill Clinton or his successor decides to deploy it, the daily reported.

The daily quoted senior Chinese diplomats as saying that Yang would be making Beijing's strongest protest yet after the official Chinese media last month condemned Australia's stand and the Chinese ambassador to Australia urged the Howard government to consider Australian interests rather than US security fears.

The Australian opposition Labor Party has publicly criticized the Howard government for supporting the US NMD system, warning that it could only lead to a greater missile build-up in mainland China and in India or Pakistan.
"If China boosts its arsenal, the prospects for future nuclear arms reductions will be dealt a severe blow," said opposition foreign affairs spokesman Laurie Brereton.
"NMD has the potential to trigger a new nuclear arms race and gravely undermine global disarmament and non-proliferation agreements," he added.
The daily reported Australia is one of the few US allies being targeted by mainland China because Canberra has publicly supported the US NMD proposals.
Beijing is aware that Australia has actively cooperated with the US on research into a Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, the daily reported.
But other Australian experts earlier said the main reason behind Beijing's strong objection to the US NMD system is that it would likely expand that system to a TMD system.

TMD could limit or hamper mainland China's ability to attack Taiwan, they said, adding that both an NMD system and a TMD system would be for defensive purposes only and could pose no threat to mainland China, Russia, or any other country.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN VICE PRESIDENT ADVOCATES CONFEDERATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Yao Eng-chi, vice president of the Legislative Yuan, on Tuesday advocated a confederation system as the best way to ensure stable relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Yao made the remarks when he attended a seminar on "current cross-strait relations and the future direction of China." Domestic and mainland scholars also attended the seminar sponsored by the World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD).

Yao, who is also president of the WLFD, pointed out that a confederation system could handle many issues that are difficult to solve at present. A confederation is a structure formed by two or more political entities which retain their political sovereignty while cooperating on solutions to mutual problems.
He noted that Beijing's insistence on the "one China" principle would be satisfied by such a confederation between the two sides, and peaceful unification would be the natural result.

He said that moreover, Taiwan could ensure its own sovereignty in such a system, because political entities in a confederation retain their own sovereignty and the right to organize their own governments. He added that Taiwan people would not have to fear that their nation would be devoured by the mainland.

Yao noted that President Chen Shui-bian has extended conciliatory gestures to the mainland since his election victory, and although Chen's soft approach has eased cross-strait tensions, Jao said that the nature of cross-strait relations remains unchanged.
Yao said that Chen's "soft approach to overcome the mighty one" strategy has not actually solved the real problem between the two sides of the Taiwan strait.
Yao summed up President Chen's strategy toward the mainland as "no action," which he said is only passive, and not aggressive or constructive.

He said that faced with mainland China's aggressive promotion of its "one country, two systems" formula, Taiwan should present a position that is in its own interests. He added that any other course of action would be detrimental to Taiwan.

Yao said that Taiwan people could not accept the mainland China's cherished "one China, two systems" formula right away, as the model practiced in Hong Kong and Macau could not work for the welfare of Taiwan people. Instead, he said that the formula would feed the public's misgivings that Taiwan would soon be simply absorbed by the mainland.

He also said that it is inappropriate to promote the "two states" theory, not only because world opinion does not support the idea, for fear that it would result in a war across the Taiwan Strait, destabilizing all of East Asia.
The mainland has repeatedly warned that it would use force against the island if Taiwan introduced a "two states" theory into the ROC Constitution, he noted.

Yao concluded by saying that as both "two states" and "one county, two systems" are not suitable as the basis for cross-strait relations, a confederation system would be the best way for both sides to maintain stable relations and ensure peace for the benefit of all Chinese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU RECEIVES JAPANESE SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Monday warmly received visiting Japanese scholar Masahiro Wakabayashi, the president of the Japan-Taiwan Studies Society, at the Office of the President.

At the meeting, Wakabayashi, professor at the University of Tokyo, thanked the new ROC government for inviting him to the recent presidential inauguration. He also exchanged views with Lu on the future course of Taiwan.
Lu told Wakabayashi that she has devoted her life to the promotion of women's rights and the cause of democracy, adding that she is quite pleased with the results of her efforts.

She said that although the women of Taiwan have attained some success in the political field, they need to continue to work harder as there is still a long way to go to reach their goal of sexual equality in Taiwan's politics.
Lu further noted that she will dedicate herself to promoting human rights, women's rights, and care for the elderly and disabled.

Lu also presented Wakabayashi with her autobiography, which she personally autographed. She expressed the hope that both Japan and Taiwan can facilitate more cultural exchanges in order that the two sides may understand each other better.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.004 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$31.088.
The local currency opened at NT$31.089 and was traded between NT$31.087 and NT$31.097.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$237 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP DELEGATION PLANNING TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) decided on Tuesday to dispatch a legislative mission to visit mainland China later this month.

According to PFP Legislative Whip Chiu Chuang-liang, the PFP legislative mission, to be headed by former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan, will depart for mainland China on the third day after the annual Beidaihe conference of Beijing's leaders has concluded.
But Chiu pointed out that the party would cancel the trip should mainland Chinese leaders work out any policy harmful to Taiwan's interests during their upcoming Beidaihe meeting, he added.

Chiu said the PFP will maintain a low-key and cautious profile about the planned mainland trip to avoid public misunderstandings, since President Chen Shui-bian has recently blasted some Taiwan lawmakers for their "mainland fever."

In addition to sponsoring seminars for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen to provide them with services, the PFP lawmaker said the delegation will also seek to discuss practical issues with mainland Chinese representatives regarding mainland Chinese brides and workers in Taiwan as well as the mainland Chinese agricultural imports to Taiwan.

Chiu also confirmed outside speculation that former Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao will join the delegation to visit the mainland. The PFP has arranged academic meetings in mainland China for Liao, he noted.

But he stressed that a reported trip to the mainland by former Judicial Yuan President Lin Yang-kang is not linked to the PFP delegation's trip, which has been postponed several times as a result of uncertainties between Taiwan and mainland China since Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party was elected as the Taiwan's new president on March 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD'S 17TH-LARGEST INVESTOR IN 1998: UN REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment across the globe totaled US$3.79 billion in 1998, ranking the island as the world's 17th-largest investing nation, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported on Tuesday.

From 1980 to 1998, Taiwan was the world's 16th-largest investor, pouring a combined capital of US$38 billion into markets in other countries, the MOEA pointed out, citing the latest UN report on worldwide investment operations.

Compared to other Asian countries, Taiwan's 16th-place worldwide ranking trailed behind Japan's fourth spot, Hong Kong's 10th place and Singapore's 15th spot, but was ahead of South Korea's 21st place, according to the same report. Other worldwide investment leaders during the eight-year period included the United States, Britain, Germany, Holland, France, Switzerland, Italy and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: REORGANIZATION RESULTS IN NEW INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIAL ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: The Euro-Asia Trade Organization (EATO) announced on Wednesday that it has reorganized its structure and changed its name to the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA).

In the future, affairs now handled by the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC), will be handed over to this newly-formed organization. Besides the member-firms of the EATO, companies joining the new organization include Evergreen Group, I-Mei Group, Nien Hsing Textile Co., and Giant Manufacturing Co.

The reorganization was implemented by some 30 industry individuals, including Jeffrey L.S. Koo, chairman and chief executive officer of Chinatrust Commercial Bank. President Chen Shui-bian is expected to attend the CIECA's inaugural ceremony, which will be held at Chinatrust's headquarters.

Koo said that domestic economic groups such as the EATO and CNAIC have played important roles in lots of international meetings. However, the lack of integration among such groups has resulted in a lack of efficiency, which the new organization is designed to alleviate. Koo added that the organization will ask for government subsidies of about NT$40 million (US$1.29 million) per year.

A proposal to establish the CIECA was issued in April, and the Ministry of the Interior approved the organization in May. Its goals for the second half of this year are to reinforce and develop Taiwan's industrial relations with mainland China, as well as nations in the Middle East and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE AND FOREIGN INVESTMENTS HIT HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) has reported a record-breaking total of US$3.6 billion in foreign and overseas Chinese investment from Jan. 1 to the end of July.
During the first half of the year, 672 overseas Chinese and foreign investors were given permission to invest in Taiwan, up 130.65 percent from the same period last year, IDIC officials said.

Officials added that the government is actively promoting about 20 important investment cases, totaling some NT$90 billion (US$2.9 billion). Major investment sectors are semiconductor equipment, integrated circuits, TFT-LCD screens, optical electronic equipment, photoelectric chips and DRAM technology, the IDIC said.

Major investments were made by entities in the United States, Japan, German, France, Switzerland, Australia, and Italy, the officials said, adding that the increased foreign capital is an indication that foreign investors still have confidence in Taiwan.
The IDIC is also working to establish an international alliance of industries, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has already signed agreements with 67 international industry groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC NATIONAL DEFENSE REPORT PUBLISHED (I)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) published a new version of the "National Defense Report" on Tuesday in line with the government's transparent defense policy.

The ministry said in the "2000 National Defense Report" that with the commissioning of a new generation of arsenal, the Republic of China military's overall combat capabilities have been upgraded and now can embark on some sort of counterattack.

The report, commonly known as the ROC's national defense white paper, mentioned for the first time the military's plan to push for the establishment of a mutual trust mechanism with mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA), but it didn't touch on President Chen Shui-bian's "offshore defense" concept.

The report divulged that relations across the Taiwan Strait became rather strained last summer after then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a special state-to-state relationship.
In retaliation for Lee's remarks, the report said, the PLA conducted Taiwan-targeting combined services landing drills in its Guangzhou and Nanjing military regions.
The white paper said mainland China's reaction indicated that it has felt a sense of urgency to resolve the so-called Taiwan issue after it smoothly reclaimed sovereignty over Hong Kong and Macau.

Noting that mainland China's threat to Taiwan's national security has become ever more serious, the report said the PLA is now actively developing unlimited war, electronic warfare and asymmetrical combat strategies and relevant arsenal. Such developments will enable mainland China to diversify its methods to invade Taiwan, the report said.

According to the report, mainland China's air force could win air supremacy over the Taiwan Strait after 2005. It further said the PLA may set up special military units to invade Taiwan. If mainland China finally decides to take Taiwan by force, the report said, it will first launch a maritime blockade and conduct air bombardment and missile attack.

The report said mainland China's current missile deployment along its southeastern coast is completely targeted at Taiwan, and the number of its missiles deployed in the region will exceed 600 by 2005.

The report further said the PLA currently deploys 70,000 troops in the Fujian area, which is directly opposite Taiwan. Moreover, the report said, the PLA can move an additional 250,000 troops to Fujian from its other military regions in a very short period of time.

According to the report, the PLA can mobilize up to 400,000 troops for a landing battle with Taiwan and its air force can airlift two parachute regiments to Taiwan. The PLA can also launch multi-dimensional and multiple rounds of missile attacks on Taiwan, the report said.

In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, the report said, the ROC has also upgraded its overall defense capability with the completion of various arsenal replacement and modernization plans.

The report said the ROC military now has "active" strategic combat capability and can launch counterattacks. Against this backdrop, the report said, the military has adjusted its basic combat strategy from "defense and deterrence" to "deterrence and defense." The change in the strategic concept indicated the military's determination to establish an elite force to deter mainland China from trying to invade Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said in a preface to the white paper that the ROC has no intention of engaging in an arms race with mainland China.
Instead, Wu said, the ROC looks forward to conducting military exchanges with the mainland and forge a mutual trust mechanism to ensure lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait.

The report also said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should increase civilian and governmental exchanges and jointly foster a climate favorable for dealing with the issue of a "future one China" based on goodwill and mutual trust.

The MND began to issue a national defense report every other year in 1990. The 2000 report is the fifth of its kind. It was originally scheduled to be off the press in March. But the marketing was postponed until Tuesday due to the transition of power from the long-ruling Kuomintang to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

After the inauguration of the DPP-led government on May 20, the MND made some changes to the content of the report to more clearly reflect President Chen Shui-bian's national defense policy. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DEFENSE REPORT (II)

TEXT.P: The report comprises seven chapters: international security environment and military situation; national security and defense policy; defense resources; armed forces; defense management; important national defense programming; and the armed forces and the people.
The information and data compiled in the report spanned from Jan. 1, 1998 through June 30, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS 'VERY OPEN' INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT: EUROPEAN REPORT

TEXT.P: A July report by the European Round Table of Industrialists (ERT) categorized Taiwan's investment environment as "very open," particularly in the area of foreign investment.

The Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) of the Republic of China Ministry of Economic Affairs on Tuesday cited the ERT report as an indication that Taiwan's efforts to promote liberalization, internationalization, and an obstacle-free investing environment in recent years have paid off.
The IDIC added that the recognition that Taiwan receives from the ERT report will have a positive effect when foreign investors assess their Taiwan investment strategies in the future.

The report, titled "Improved Investment Conditions: third survey on improvements in conditions for investment in the developing world," covers the period from 1997-1999, and is based on the results of a survey of some 33 developing countries.

The survey was conducted in cooperation with the United Nations and the International Chamber of Commerce. It investigated each country's conditions for foreign investment, overall investment environment, government legal system, local enterprises, labor force, social culture, and living conditions.

The ERT then rated each country's investment environment on its degree of openness and speed of liberalization. Taiwan was rated as "moderately open" in 1992, "quite open" in 1996, and "very open" in 1999.

The report also demonstrated that over the last three years, despite the financial crisis in Asia, the developing countries surveyed have continued to open their economies rapidly to private investment, and to deregulate and modernize related rules and institutions to bring them in line with global requirements.
Particularly substantial progress was found in five main areas:
- Fewer restrictions on ownership, and improved access to new sectors for local- and foreign-invested private firms;
- Increased effectiveness and efficiency of tax allocation and collection;
- Continued deregulation of import/export regimes and reduction of tariffs; and
- Modernization and better integration of local financial markets, aligning relevant rules to global requirements.
The ERT report, the third in a series, was prepared by an ERT working group led by Helmut Maucher, honorary chairman of Nestle S.A. and former ERT chairman.
The ERT comprises a group of 48 European industrial leaders, including the heads of large multinational companies such as British Telecom, Nokia, Bayer, Nestle, Ericsson, and Philips.
Free copies of the report are available through the ERT website (www.ert.be) or e-mail (contact@ert.be).

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS, EXPERTS CRITICIZE GOVERNMENT'S LOAN PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Public confidence will be eroded even further should the low-interest home loan package put forth by the government fail to stimulate the sluggish real estate market, opposition lawmakers warned on Tuesday.

Lee Ching-an, caucus spokeswoman for the People First Party in the Legislative Yuan, said public confidence will melt down again if the measures turn out to be ineffective because the major reason for the sluggishness is a lack of public faith provoked by the government's unclear policies on Taiwan's future and its economic situation.

PFP legislative whip Chen Chao-jung also voiced his suspicion of the package, saying that he feels the four-point measures designed by the government are only aimed at bailing out vested interest groups.

The remarks came in response to an announcement on Monday by government spokeswoman Chung Chin that the Executive Yuan will earmark NT$320 billion in low-interest loans for low-income and first-time home buyers as part of the government's efforts to revitalize the property market.

Meanwhile, some local experts also contended that the measures are only a short-term approach to lure potential buyers into the real estate market. They added that the package represents no root solutions to the long-term problem of housing oversupply and capital movement.

C.O. Chang, a professor at National Chengchi University, said the Taiwan property market is facing a structural crisis that should be corrected by market mechanisms -- allowing house prices to fall and setting up a sound system to provide loans.

Judging from the situation of Taiwan's macroeconomy, Chang suggested the government mull whether it is necessary to pour so much money into the real estate sector because it is no longer the "locomotive" of Taiwan's industrial sector.
Calling on the public to refrain from cashing in on the low-interest loans, he said potential home buyers should carefully assess their needs.

Chinese Culture University Professor C.H. Wu said that the government's announcement of the preferential loan measures at this time has "no true meaning." The government's efforts to attract more home buyers will only further underpin house prices, which are beginning to slide because of a housing glut and a decline in land prices, he noted.
According to Wu, there are probably as many as one million unoccupied properties in Taiwan, although the island's house ownership rate has already reached around 85 percent.

However, many large banking institutions, such as Bank of Taiwan, welcomed the government's loan package, claiming that it will create a "win-win-win" situation for the public, the banking sector and the real estate market.
The bank expressed the hope that the measures will help increase the loan business for banking institutions, reduce the loan burden on home buyers and stimulate the real estate industry.
According to statistics compiled by the Central Bank of China, loans released by local banks to the construction sector hit a 23 month-low of NT$491.6 billion as of the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CITES 98 MODEL FATHER-SON, FATHER-DAUGHTER PAIRS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian cited 98 model father-son, father-daughter pairs from the military, police and firefighting communities on Tuesday, in recognition of their contributions to the country and society.
The citation at the Presidential Office coincided with the celebration of Father's Day which falls on Aug. 8.
Chen first wished all fathers around the island a happy Father's Day and said he was very happy to celebrate the special day with selected personnel from the military, police and firefighting forces.

Chen said the citation was arranged to express the government's recognition and gratitude for all military, police and firefighting personnel's contributions to the defense of national security, the maintaining of law and order, and the conducting of emergency rescue and disaster relief operations.

"Despite differences in the nature of their work, the three sectors' contributions to national security, social welfare and providing a secure, comfortable living environment is the same," Chen noted.

He went on to say that the large number of father-son and father-daughter pairs in the three sectors is admirable because it signifies success in family education. "Only a good father can inspire his children to choose the same profession," Chen said.

The accumulated seniority of all of those cited reached 3,000 years. "This is a marvelous record. You are no ordinary people. You are all great. You have made extraordinary choices and have created extraordinary lives," the president lauded.

He also encouraged all of the model military, police and firefighting workers to regard all fellow countrymen as their offspring and develop rapport with them in order to ensure social harmony and domestic stability.

Chen also revealed that his daughter and son jointly presented him with a shaver as a Father's Day gift. "I will highly treasure it because the shaver will remind me that I must `shave my beard before shaving others' beards,' by which I mean I must reflect upon my own actions before blaming others," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MA YING-JEOU TO VISIT US, CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to leave on Thursday for a two-week tour of cities in the United States and Central America that maintain sisterly ties with Taipei, a City Government spokesman said on Tuesday.

Ma will arrive in Atlanta on Thursday for a two-and-a-half day visit in which he will meet with that city's mayor, as well as the speaker of the Atlanta City Council. He is expected to observe Atlanta's garbage handling center and mass rapid transport (MRT) system.

Ma will also visit the headquarters of the Cable News Network (CNN) and other mass media in Atlanta. On Saturday, he will deliver a keynote speech at the opening ceremony of the annual meeting of the Chinese Scholars Association in the Southeastern United States, before leaving for New York on Sunday. The Big Apple is the only city on Ma's itinerary that does not maintain sisterly ties with Taipei.

In New York, Ma will attend the so-called "second track" U.S.-China-Taiwan Tripartite meeting on Aug. 14 and 15. Scholars and experts on cross-strait affairs from China, Taiwan and the United States will hold a two-day closed-door discussion on the tripartite relationship among the three nations. Ma will deliver a keynote speech at the meeting.

Ma will then proceed to Panama, continuing on his tour of Taipei's sister-cities in the Americas. Lung Ying-tai, director of the Cultural Bureau of Taipei City Government, will join Ma in Panama. The trip will also bring him to Tegucigalpa, Honduras, and Guatemala City, Guatemala.
During his sojourn in Central America, Ma will visit the Panama Canal, Mayan ruins and other cultural sites of interest in these cities before returning to Taipei on Aug. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HISTORY BOOK ISSUED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan History Research Foundation on Tuesday issued the multi-volume Taiwan History that records modern Taiwan's history in words and pictures.

Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who attended the launch, said sending out the correct history of Taiwan is very important. He claimed that all the Han Chinese who came to Taiwan came seeking a better life, and further claimed that everyone in Taiwan shares the same history and strives for an ideal future.
Soong said Taiwan's history is not all sorrowful, but also has satisfaction and achievement, and he noted that the main purpose of the book is to give a correct understanding of the island's past.

Foundation President Hsu Tsung-mao, who hosted the launch party, expressed the hope that the people of Taiwan can form a correct view of Taiwan's history through the book, and he thanked the Central News Agency and the China Times for providing the pictures used in the book.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TANG IRREPLACEABLE PILLAR OF POLITICAL STABILITY: CHANG

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei is a key force contributing to current domestic political stability, Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said on Tuesday.

Chang made the remarks after ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said on Monday that Premier Tang has failed people's expectations in the last two months due to a lack of resolve and diplomacy.
Chang said Tang, a Kuomintang stalwart and a four-star-general-turned politician, is an "irreplaceable pillar" of domestic political stability.
Chang said all members of the DPP-led government, including President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Tang, are willing to accept criticism and make self-reflection in a modest manner.

Chang, himself a DPP heavyweight, reminded critics of the performance of Tang's Cabinet that the Cabinet is composed of members from different political parties who need time to forge a consensus on major public issues.
"Moreover, while some Cabinet members are experienced politicians, several others are scholars with lofty ideals and little political experience," Chang noted.
Against this background, Chang said, the public should give the Cabinet a bit more time before measuring its performance.

Since the inauguration of President Chen's administration on May 20, Chang said, some 200 people have joined the new government team. "But the middle-ranking civil servants have not yet fully adapted themselves to the new situation and failed to completely shed their old bureaucratic thinking. This trend has also affected the operation of the new government," he added.

With the recess of the Legislative Yuan, Chang said, Tang's Cabinet now can devote its full energy to administrative work. "So the Cabinet will from now on enter a new stage. I hope local public will remain confident in the new government's capability. I believe the Cabinet will be able to project a new image and score remarkable achievements in the near future."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OLDEST FATHER NAMED
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records on Tuesday named Taiwan's oldest father -- 109-year-old Hu Chin-yao, on Tuesday, Taiwan's "Father's Day."

Center President Dai Sheng-yi announced Hu's record at a press conference, while Hualien County Chief Wang Ching-fen and Hualien County Bureau of Social Affairs Director Chung Wen-tsin celebrated Hu's record at the old man's residence.
Wang said he believes Hu will break the world record of 120 years because of Hualien County's unpolluted environment, and added that he will "help Hu travel the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCH UNIT EXTENDS COOPERATION WITH JAPANESE UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, Central Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province on Tuesday signed a contract to extend its cooperation with Japan's Chukyo University on the study of historical archives of the Taiwan Government-General.

The two sides have cooperated for eight years to compile the categories of the valuable historical data of the Taiwan Government-General, which is now being kept by the historical research commission.
So far, six volumes of archives have been published, with Volumes 7-9 to be published soon.
The new contract will extend the cooperation for a further three years.

Yang Cheng-kuan, director of the historical research commission, said that after the compilation of the categories, his commission plans to turn its efforts to the study of Taiwan history during the Japanese occupation of the island (1895-1945).
Masako Sakeyasu, director of the Institute of Social Sciences under Chukyo University, said that the financial burden creates pressure for the cooperation project.
Despite some subsidies from the Japanese Education Ministry, she expressed the hope that sufficient financial support will be forthcoming to allow the significant cooperation project to continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVENUES FROM STOCK TRANSACTION TAX DROP TO 16-MONTH LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's revenues from stock transaction taxes dropped to NT$6.6 billion (US$213 million) in July, its lowest level since March 1999, sources from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Tuesday.

Stock transaction taxes in July fell off NT$3.8 billion (US$123 million), 36.5 percent lower than those collected in July 1999, MOF officials said, adding that July saw the largest single-month drop in such revenues since April of last year.

The MOF said that the nation's tax revenues collected in July reached NT$166.1 billion (US$5.36 billion), up an annual NT$7.8 billion (US$252 million), an increase of 4.9 percent over the year-earlier levels.

Of the nation's total revenue collections, NT$73.9 billion (US$2.38 billion) was collected from income taxes, an annual increase of 24.2 percent; while NT$14.2 billion (US$458 million) was generated by commodity taxes, up 25.2 percent compared to the previous year, the figures show.
Taxes raised from business transactions totaled NT$46.1 billion (US$1.49 billion), a decline of 9.7 percent over that of last July, the MOF said.

Meanwhile, revenues from incremental taxes on real estate value declined 12.3 percent -- some NT$1 billion -- to reach NT$7.2 billion (US$232 million) in July; and Customs tax revenues edged up 3.4 percent, or NT$300 million, to hit NT$8.9 billion (US$287 million), MOF tallies showed.

The nation's overall year-to-date tax collections as of the end of July stood at NT$951.3 billion (US$30.69 billion), up 4.8 percent, or NT$44 billion, over the same period during the preceding year, the MOF said.

During the seven-month period, tax revenues collected by the central government totaled NT$682.9 billion (US$22 billion), up 18 percent, or NT$104.4 billion, from the same period last year; while tax revenues collected by all local governments amounted to NT$268.4 billion (US$8.66 billion), dropping 18.4 percent, or NT$60.4 billion, the MOF tallies indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIRATES ROB KAOHSIUNG FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung-based deep-sea fishing vessel Shun-man No. 12 was robbed by pirates on Tuesday in the Malaccan Strait, according to a report by a radio station operated by the Kaohsiung Fishermen's Association.

The vessel, a squid boat, was on its way home on Tuesday when it was pursued and fired upon by the pirates in the narrow channel which separates the Indonesian Island of Sumatra from the Malayan peninsula and is notorious for pirate attacks.
One of its crew members was reportedly killed.
The Shun-man No. 12 was reported as being escorted by other fishing boats following the robbery and is expected to reach Kaohsiung Harbor in five or six days.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA DEPLOYING OVER 400 MISSILES OPPOSITE TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing has deployed more than 400 guided missiles along the coastal provinces of Jiangsi and Fujian opposite Taiwan, according to the 2000 National Defense Report released by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Tuesday.
The range of the missiles covers the whole of Taiwan, according to the report.
The report further said that the number of missiles will increase by over 600 by the year 2005.
It pointed out that Beijing's armed forces deployment maintains a "positive defense" strategy combining army, navy, air force and missile units in the seven military regions of mainland China.

Beijing has been redoubling its efforts to modernize its armed forces, the report said, adding that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) has launched across-the-board reforms in training, war strategy and administration.

Affected by the Persian Gulf War, Beijing reformed its Central Military Commission (CMC), the country's highest military guiding body, in 1998. A General Logistics Department was established under the direct control of the CMC to carry out the procurement, research and administration of weapons and related equipment, the report said.

With regard to missile development, the report went on, Beijing has been concentrating its efforts on improving the mobility, precision and capability of its guided missiles. Beijing has successfully developed its Dongfeng 31 ballistic missile and is also developing new missiles with solid fuel to replace its old missiles that use liquid fuel.

With respect to the air force, under the technical assistance of Israel and cooperation with Russia, the PLA Air Force has successfully manufactured J-10 and J-11 jet fighters that will enter military service by 2005. The combat capabilities of these jet fighters are similar to those of US-made F-15s and F-16s.

Beijing has also purchased AA-12 air-to-air missiles to build up the combat capability of its warplanes, and has self-developed a low-level, all-weather bomber -- the J-7 -- as well as buying Russian-made Su-30MKK fighter-bombers.
The mainland has also successfully developed a series of anti-aircraft missiles, including the Red Flag-9, the SA-10, the Red Flag-7 and the SA-15, according to the report.

With regard to naval developments, Beijing is developing the model-093 and model-094 nuclear-powered assault and guided missile submarines. The O94 can be equipped with 12 to 16 intercontinental long-range missiles that would reach all of the United States.
Beijing has also bought modern-class destroyers and K-class diesel powered submarines from Russia, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES PANAMANIAN PARLIAMENTARY HEAD

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday received Enrique Garrido Arrosemena, president of the Legislative Assembly of Panama, and exchanged views with him on bilateral relations.

Chen extended a warm welcome to Garrido and his entourage and promised that his government will continue and honor all the commitments and cooperation projects that the ROC has entered into with the Central American country.

He said that in the past two months, high-ranking officials of the two countries have exchanged visits, and noted that Panamanian Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan came to Taiwan to attend the presidential inauguration on May 20, while President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriquez visited the ROC in early July, becoming the first foreign head of state to visit the ROC since the new government was inaugurated.
The visit of Garrido's delegation of legislators further indicates that bilateral relations are stable and cordial, Chen went on.
Chen described Panama as a true democratic country because its people elected a woman president last year, while the parliament also elected a president descended from aborigines.

After finding out that Garrido was to curtail his visit in order to rush back to Panama to take care of his 89-year-old tribal chief, Chen expressed hope that Garrido will convey his personal regards to the tribal elder.

Chen said that the ROC, with its population of 23 million, is ranked as the world's 13th-largest trading nation with the third-highest foreign exchange reserves and is a leader in the field of high-technology, but is still discriminated against and excluded from world organizations. He expressed gratitude for Panama's support for the ROC's bid for membership in international organizations.

He further said that the ROC experienced its first transition of power in five decades, indicating that the ROC respects democracy, freedom and human rights, which are common believes shared by both countries. "We should treasure these common believes and step up our cooperation," Chen noted.

Garrido for his part said that both the ROC and Panama share a similar historical background. He said Panama believes that the ROC has every right to seats in international organizations and will continue to offer its assistance to help the ROC achieve this goal.

Chen also noted that he visited Panama in 1984 and 1996 in his capacity as city council member and mayor, respectively and added that he hopes to someday visit Panama in his capacity as ROC president.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU WARNS OF POSSIBLE STRONG QUAKE IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) on Tuesday warned that the eastern city of Hualien might be hit by an earthquake measuring 6 or more on the Richter scale in the near future and urged residents there to be extra careful.
CWB Seismology Center Director Kuo Kai-wen said the quake-prone city has regularly suffered a major temblor of a magnitude of at least 6 every three to five years over the past 20 years.
From July this year, the likelihood of another major temblor has increased as a large accumulation of tectonic momentum has already built up underground, which could manifest as a powerful quake.

Noting that Taiwan is located on a juncture between the Philippine Sea and the Euroasian tectonic plates, where underground activity is common and tectonic momentum regularly builds up, Kuo said Hualien's chances of a major earthquake in the near future is scientifically reasonable, particularly in view of the fact that the city has not had a powerful temblor since 1995.

Kuo stressed, however, that he was not making an earthquake prediction, because earthquakes are so far not predictable. He said he was just making a scientific analysis based on geostratical viewpoints.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO CALL ON KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will call on opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in early September, after he returns from a state visit abroad, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Eugene Chien said on Tuesday.
It will mark the first time a Republic of China president will have paid a formal courtesy call on an opposition party chairman.

Chien called on KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng earlier in the day to work out details regarding a roundtable meeting to be held between Chen and the heads of Taiwan's three major political parties.

He also conveyed the president's wish to pay a visit to Lien, who was vice president under the previous KMT administration, to "seek Lien's counsel" on affairs of state and to discuss Chen's roundtable idea in person.
Lien is currently in the United States on a 14-day North American visit, while Chen will embark on a state visit to the ROC's six allies in the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa on Sunday.
Chien said that many sectors of society are in favor of holding the roundtable meeting, which he said would be beneficial to national development and social stability.
He went on to say that the Presidential Office is especially looking forward to establishing a communications mechanism with the three parties.

He added that Chen has no preset stance or bottom line regarding the issues to be discussed at the meeting, and that anything beneficial to the national welfare and the people's livelihoods, such as the constitutional system, interparty coordination, cross-strait relations, financial issues, and earthquake reconstruction, can be discussed.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the KMT, and the opposition People First Party (PFP) will each appoint a representative to attend a preparatory meeting to set up the formal roundtable.
The DPP will be represented by Deputy Secretary-General Hsu Yang-ming, the KMT's representative is as yet unannounced, while the PFP has appointed its deputy secretary-general, Chin Chin-sheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TURNS OVER ARMS SALES DOCUMENTS TO INVESTIGATORS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Tuesday handed over more than 200 cases of documents to investigators charged with probing the death of a navy captain and alleged irregularities in navy arms purchases.

The documents were turned over to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and the Investigation Bureau (IB), which were ordered by a special panel to look into the death of Capt. Yin Ching-feng in 1993, and the allegations of corruption in the navy.
Vice Chief of the General Staff Gen. Wang Han-ning told a press conference afterward that the documents -- including 796 files, 433 of which are classified -- run to 277,862 pages.

Calling Yin's death and the allegations of corruption fueled by his death "the shame of the military," Wang said the handover of the documents vindicated the MND's determination to get to the bottom of the case and quell speculation that the MND intended to block the panel's probe of the case.
He also cautioned the panel to abide by gag rules imposed by law during the criminal investigation and to refrain from leaking any classified information about naval arms purchases.

Chen Pi-lien, a Supreme Court prosecutor and a spokeswoman for the investigation panel, expressed "sincere thanks" to the military, saying that the panel believed the military had turned over all related documents in their possession.

The MND delivered the documents four days after a prosecutor with the panel accused the military on Aug. 3 of blocking the work of the panel and ordered them to produce the related files within a week or risk being searched by investigators.

Facing the tremendous volume of documents, State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa, who was named by President Chen Shui-bian as head of the panel, said Yin's death will be investigated by the CIB, while the irregularities in naval arms purchases will be probed by the IB.

In order to address the military's concerns that some classified testimony made by witnesses in the case during the military investigation were leaked to and published by the press earlier this month, Chen Pi-lien said the panel will look into the alleged leakage of information and prosecute those responsible to the full extent of the law.

In 1993, Yin was the executive secretary of the weaponry procurement program under Navy General Headquarters when his body was found floating in Suao Harbor in eastern Taiwan on Dec. 9 after he was allegedly collecting evidence about corruption in the navy's arms purchases.
An investigation carried out by the MND turned up nothing and no one was ever arrested in connection with his death.
In a related development on Tuesday, reduced jail terms were meted out to two brokers who had already been convicted of bribing two navy officers.
One of the brokers, Cheng Cheng-kuang, had his sentence overturned, while the other, Liu Shu, was given a lighter sentence of seven months in a third retrial by the Taiwan High Court.
Both men had been sentenced to one year and two months in the previous trials for bribing their way to winning a contract to provide Italian-made survey ships to the navy in 1993.
The High Court ruled that the sentences should be reduced in light of the fact that Cheng confessed before the case even came to light, while Liu later copped a guilty plea.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HEARS REPORTS ON FISCAL 2001 BUDGET PLAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday heard reports from Premier Tang Fei and other officials on the compilation of the central government's budget for fiscal 2001.
He asked the administrative branches to step up communications with various party caucuses in the legislature to gain their support for the budget plan during deliberations in the Legislative Yuan.
The budget plan lists fiscal 2001 revenues at NT$1,455.8 billion and expenditures at NT$1,605.5 billion, revealing a shortage of NT$149.7 billion.

As the government is also obliged to raise NT$155.7 billion for repayment of government debts, the total budget shortage will rise to NT$305.4 billion, which will be covered by issuance of government bonds worth NT$260 billion and the previous fiscal year's surplus of NT$45.4 billion.
Because of the tight financial situation, Chen said that the compilation of the new budget for government units had encountered more difficulties than usual.

For instance, he said, the expenditure for 2001 increased by only NT$92.3 billion over the present fiscal year, and of that figure, NT$62.4 billion and NT$21 billion are to be used to cover losses in the health insurance program and for pay raises for public servants, respectively.
As a result, only NT$2.8 billion is allocated for the new government's "3-3-3" welfare policy, which was promised by Chen during his presidential campaign.

Nevertheless, he stressed that appropriate budget arrangements have been made to address the needs of national security, eradication of black gold, strengthening of cultural, educational, scientific and technological development, speeding up post-earthquake reconstruction, promotion of economic development and "improvement of the welfare of all the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE KIDNAPPED IN MACAU RESCUED
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Ren Chung-hong and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan tourist who was kidnapped by Macau loan sharks, was rescued on Tuesday, according to Macau police.

Acting on a tip off, the police stormed into an 18-floor building in the northern part of the former Portuguese enclave. In addition to the Taiwan tourist, they also found four people suspected of being members of the loan shark ring.

The tourist, who was said to come from northern Taoyuan County, had lost more than HK$10 million (US$1.28 million), mostly borrowed from the loan sharks, in a local casino. As he was unable to repay the amount, the Taiwanese was abducted and forced to call his family to provide the money.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO HEAD TECHNOLOGY ADVISORY PANEL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Vice President Annette Lu to serve as the convener of a presidential technology advisory panel, the Presidential Office said on Tuesday.

Chen Che-nan, acting secretary-general to the president, said that the president pointed out in his May 20 inauguration speech that Taiwan will become a "green silicon island" by striking a balance between ecological protection and economic development.

Chen added that the president has also said on many occasions that Taiwan should develop itself into a so-called green silicon island by building upon the accumulated foundation of the entire people while also giving consideration to the "never-ending management" of Taiwan so that future generations will not have to be afraid of environmental pollution.

Chen pointed out that the Presidential Office has begun to draw up plans for the establishment of the technology consultation panel and related staffing affairs to quickly carry out the president's administrative goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH OPPOSITION PFP HEAD

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh paid a call on opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on Tuesday, in the DPP's third bout of inter party exchanges.

Hsieh was accompanied by party Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen, Deputy Secretary-General Hsu Yang-ming, party whip at the legislature Peng Shao-chin, special aide Chen Chien-chung, and DPP Propaganda Chief Cheng Yun-peng.

They were warmly welcomed by Soong, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi, Deputy Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng, and party whip Chen Chen-sheng upon arrival at PFP headquarters.

Although Soong described the atmosphere of the talks as "harmonious," there still appeared to be some contention on cross-Taiwan Strait issues, with Hsieh proposing that all political parties seek common ground on the issue, while Soong stressed that a sound formula for the rotation of power among the parties has been established in Taiwan and that all the political parties should deal with issues on their individual merits.
Soong also said opposition parties do not play insignificant roles in a nation's political arena, and he added that they should not oppose ruling party policies just for the sake of opposing.
Hsieh paid a courtesy call on opposition New Party Chairman Hau Lung-pin on Aug. 1 and visited the nation's biggest opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAS 100 PERCENT SUPPORT FOR PREMIER: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A ranking presidential official said on Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian has 100 percent confidence in and support for Premier Tang Fei.

The official, who asked not to be named, was joining Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsing in defending Tang, who came under fire from Wu Nai-jen, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), for what he claimed was Tang's inability to meet the expectations of the general public.
Wu on Tuesday again publicly made it clear that he is very much concerned about the administrative performance of the new Cabinet under Tang's leadership.

He told the media that the Executive Yuan has failed to deliver what the new government promised and has failed over the past two months to meet the expectations that Taiwan voters had when they went to the polls on March 18.
Other DPP top brass a day earlier had also criticized Tang, saying he "does not have the guts" to be a leading administrator.
Wu urged Tang to "flex the muscle" of a military leader (Tang was defense minister before being appointed premier) and go ahead with administrative reforms "in a big way."
Wu's strongly worded criticism of Tang and the new Cabinet marked a staggering and unprecedented political situation in the Republic of China whereby the ruling party lambasted the administration.
The presidential official said that Wu's criticism was inappropriate, as the Cabinet's performance is improving and will come up with "a beautiful score list" in the next three months.
He added that Wu's remarks were just his personal views, of which the Presidential Office had no prior knowledge.

However, Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, a DPP heavyweight and Chen's secretary-general before becoming Tang's deputy on Aug. 1, rejected Wu's castigation of the premier and said Tang is an irreplaceable pillar that supports Taiwan's political arena.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislative Yuan caucus whip Hsu Tien-tsai said he believes that Chen is completely positive about Tang's ability and style of working, and claimed that Tang enjoys 100 percent support from DPP legislators.

Protesting against Wu's criticism of Tang, opposition Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng ridiculed Wu's remarks as "absurd," saying that the ruling DPP pressed hard to persuade the former defense minister to take the helm of the government just a couple of months ago, but has now already begun to dump him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 9, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: Thomas Telford, Scottish bridge engineer, is born. He is best known for his construction of the suspension bridge over the Menai Strait in Wales and of the Calendonian Canal built 1823-33 in Scotland.
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the US government and the Creek Indian tribe, the Indians are to lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the US and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested as an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six-week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto is crowned as Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1918: Robert Aldrich, American film director, is born. His films include "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?" "The Choirboys," and "The Dirty Dozen."
1919: India reaches a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sank during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The ROC Navy sinks 12 Chinese communist ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon, becoming the first American president ever to take office without being chosen by the American people in a nationwide election.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district. A sign stated "Clothes Need Not Be Worn Beyond This Notice."
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The US government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he raised the "special state-to-state" theory on cross-Taiwan Strait ties last month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 250.36 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its upward streak on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 250.36 points to close at 8,048.14.
Market turnover amounted to NT$95.85 billion (US$3.09 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOSPITALIZED FOR HEALTH CHECKUP

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei, whose office hours have not lacked twists and turns ever since he took the helm of the government more than two months ago, was hospitalized again on Wednesday for a health checkup.

Tang checked into Veterans General Hospital (VGH) after having suffered dizzy spells over recent days, particularly after the long, stomach-churning interpellation sessions at the Legislative Yuan, according to sources from the Government Information Office (GIO).
On the suggestion of family members, Tang went to the hospital on Tuesday, four days earlier than originally scheduled, for a health checkup.

This resulted in Tang's absence from a "black gold" sweeping action meeting, which represented the first serious national anti-crime and anti-corruption meeting with President Chen Shui-bian delivering a keynote speech.
At noon, VGH President Chang Mao-sung told the media that after preliminary checkups, the premier's breathing, blood pressure, and heart beat were all found to be normal.

He added, however, that more thorough examinations will have to be carried out in order to discover the reasons behind Tang's recent dizzy spells, speculating that they may be due to lack of sufficient rest, particularly during the period of his rehabilitation after undergoing chest surgery in April.

Tang, who was defense minister in the previous KMT government before being appointed premier by President Chen, has been hospitalized on and off since a benign thymoma was removed from his chest on April 16.

He was admitted into VGH again on May 2 after catching a cold. After agreeing to Tang's release from the medical center, VGH doctors suggested that the premier work no more than six hours a day as he had still not fully recovered from the operation.

Although Tang's admittance to hospital this time came on the heels of a series of attacks on him by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen for his "inability to meet the expectations of the general public," Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung denied that the pressure of politics was the reason for the premier's state, saying that Tang was admitted to hospital simply because he "has been too tired recently."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 250.36 points to close at 8,048.14.
Encouraged by favorable government measures to boost stock prices, the bourse opened at 7,866.11 and fluctuated between 8,048.14 and 7,866.11 during trading.

A total of 2.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.85 billion (US$3.09 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.37 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$63.41 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only construction shares and textile issues remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.1 percent, cement stocks at 2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.8 percent, and electrical stocks at 1.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 460 to 82, with 45 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Tuesday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved up 233 points to close at 8,090, with 5,303 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September increased 242 points to finish at 8,130, with 315 contract transactions, while December futures gained 206 points to close at 8,150, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 7,857 for August; 7,888 for September; 7,944 for December; 8,000 for next March; and 8,178 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
August TE futures moved up 15.7 points to close at 428, with 1,640 contract transactions, while September TE futures increased 15 points to finish at 428, with 93 contract transactions.
December TE futures rose 9.65 points to close at 424.25, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures gained 24.4 points to close at 914.4, with 669 contract transactions, while September TF futures moved up 21 points to finish at 913.4, with 43 contract transactions.
December TF futures moved up 21.8 points to close at 922.8, with two contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-WASHINGTON-BEIJING ROUNDTABLE TO OPEN ON AUG. 14
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A "Track II" roundtable meeting on relations across the Taiwan Strait and the US China policy is scheduled to open in New York on Aug. 14, with the participation of delegates from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States.

The roundtable, to be sponsored by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP), a noted US think tank, will bring together about 20 scholars and former foreign policy officials from the three areas to discuss the latest cross-strait situation and the US policy toward cross-strait issues.

Among the Taiwan delegates to the upcoming closed-door meeting will be Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, an opposition Kuomintang heavyweight, and Wu Jui-kuo, a close aide to opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.

The NCAFP, which enjoys enormous clout in the formation of US foreign policy, began to hold a biannual unofficial meeting on the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations after cross-strait hit a snag over the "one China" principle, as it thought that private, closed-door discussions, also known as "Track II" consultations, would be most effective in mending differences and fostering goodwill.

The first NCAFP-organized three-way roundtable was held in June 1997. The upcoming meeting will be the first of its kind since the Republic of China completed its first democratic transition of power from the long-ruling KMT to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in May.

NCAFP sources said no incumbent central government officials from the three areas will take part in the Aug. 14-15 roundtable whose agenda will focus on an analysis of the impact on cross-strait relations of the DPP's grip on power, the DPP-led ROC government's policy toward mainland China and Beijing's views and stances on Taiwan.

The participants will also discuss how the United States should cope with the new cross-Taiwan Strait situation, NCAFP sources said, adding that minutes of the meeting will be presented to the three governments for reference.

Several senior NCAFP members, including Winston Lord, a former US Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific affairs, have twice traveled to both sides of the Taiwan Strait to collect first-hand information about cross-strait relations since the DPP won Taiwan's March 18 presidential election.
