DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE POLICE PROBING CASE OF ROBBING & BEATING OF TAIWANESE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Australian police in New South Wales are investigating the alleged robbery and beating involving three junior Taiwanese students in Sydney after the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) stepped in to demand that justice be done.

In an interview with the CNA on Wednesday, Maggie Tien, director general of the Sydney-based TECO, said one of the students said he was hit twice on his left cheek and the other one said he was robbed of his mobile phone during a stroll near the University of New South Wales on Aug. 3.

In addition, several young Australians also allegedly used abusive language, shouting "go home" to the three students from Taichung. Tien declined to identify the students, who are studying English in Sydney on a short-term basis.

After the incident, the cousin of the three students, who has been studying in Sydney for some time, reported the case to police in South Maroubra. He said that police officers at the station did not take the matter seriously.
Two days after the incident, the cousin and the students again came across the young Australians who they say robbed and beat them when they were walking a dog in a park near their home-stay house.

The cousin again reported the case to the same police station, but it was ignored again. Instead, the cousin and the students received a threat from the Australians who allegedly robbed and beat them.

Tien and her colleagues became aware of the case on Tuesday and immediately stepped in to report the case to a senior police officer, who instructed the South Maroubra police to investigate the matter.

Tien told the police inspector assigned to the investigation that the incident could damage the tourism and education industries in Australia. In addition, it could also damage the country's international image if authorities did not handle the case carefully and bring the offenders to justice.
She said the three students have moved to another place in order to avoid any further harassment. They are returning to Taiwan soon, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN RESEARCHERS TAKE E. COLI VACCINE TO ANIMAL TESTING STAGE

TEXT.P: Canada's National Research Council is cooperating with Foragen Technology Ventures Inc. in testing a vaccine against the E. coli 0157 bacterium that causes "hamburger disease."

This particular strain of E. coli causes serious illness in humans, especially in young children and the elderly. Infections with E. coli 0157:H7 have recently been associated with the water contamination in Walkerton, Ontario which killed six people, as well as with recalls of hamburger meat by certain supermarket chains in North America.
Cattle are the primary source of E. coli infection for humans. Eliminating E. coli 0157 from cattle could go a long way towards the prevention of disease outbreaks in humans.

The NRC vaccine is expected to trigger an immune response in cattle against E. coli 0157 through the production of protective antibodies that prevent the growth of the bacterium in the animal's gut. If proven effective, this simple, inexpensive vaccine could provide an effective solution to the elimination of the bacterium at the source.

NRC's partnership with Foragen will provide funding for the next stage of the evaluation, namely the testing of the vaccine in cattle this month at the Veterinary Infectious Disease Organization in Saskatoon. If the cattle evaluation is successful, action will be taken to commercialize the vaccine.
The vaccine has been developed by the Bacterial Pathogenesis group led by Dr. Malcolm Perry. The team began research into E. coli 0157 during the early 1980s following disease outbreaks in Canada.
"The understanding of how bacteria cause disease is a fundamental step in combating the disease," said Perry.

His group first isolated and chemically identified a unique component of the E. coli 0157 -- an antigenic marker. The antigen is used as the basis of a diagnostic tool for the detection of the E. coli 0157. This antigen could form the basis of a specific vaccine.

In subsequent work, the group discovered that there were other, non-pathogenic bacteria that carried markers identical or chemically similar to the E. coli 0157 antigenic marker. Oral immunization of mice with some of these non-pathogenic bacteria produced antibodies that successfully prevented colonization by E. coli 0157 in the animals.

Foragen Technology Ventures Inc. is a venture capital company for early seed-stage project financing to create companies in advanced agricultural technologies. Royal Bank Ventures Inc. has partnered with Foragen to create the fund to help bridge the early stage development gap in company creation.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTY CHIEFS RECALLED TO BEIJING FOR FURTHER TRAINING

TEXT.P: Almost half of the Chinese Communist Party's county secretaries have been called back to Beijing for further indoctrination and training, illustrating that Beijing sees its authority slipping and is attempting to bolster it, according to an analysis published Tuesday.

Stratfor, Inc., a Texas-based private global intelligence services company, wrote in its global intelligence update titled "Beijing's Anxiety" that for the first time in more than 50 years, over 2,000 Chinese Communist Party chiefs at the county level have been summoned to Beijing to "advance their ideology at the professional and managerial level" at the Central Party School.

These chiefs are Beijing's front line troops in its great contradictory effort to open the economy while maintaining tight political control, and the mainland Chinese government is signaling that they may not be up to the job, said the analysis.
The training program highlights Beijing's concern with the interaction between politics and economics at the local level, according to the analysis.

Hong Kong Mail was quoted as reporting Monday that Communist Chinese authorities are hiring additional lecturers and building additional classrooms and dormitories at the Central Party School campus. It will apparently take at least three years for the 2,000 county party heads to complete the six-month training courses, longer than the four months allotted for ministerial officials.
The entire process is unorthodox, the analysis noted, considering that local Communist officials have their own schools, usually at the provincial or municipal level.

"This high-level attention underscores the importance Beijing attaches to this training," which appears to be an attempt to buttress the party at what is simultaneously its weakest and most significant interface between the party and the masses, it noted.

The analysis continued that these local officials have to resolve the tension between economic reform and social stability and operationalize central policy on a daily basis. This is especially true if Communist China becomes a member of the World Trade Organization. If accepted, Beijing will likely have to liberalize its agricultural sector, which will involve thousands of low-level decisions involving millions of farmers.

"But distance makes it difficult to double-check their judgment and erodes the central government's authority. Central officials often lack sufficient power and are prone to corruption," stated the analysis.

"Beijing clearly sees its authority slipping at the most significant level and appears to be taking emergency steps to bolster its authority. This training program is an attempt to prepare the local authorities to make the decisions that will set the course for the economy," concluded the analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SENDS MORE MOFA STAFF TO BE TRAINED IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) of the Republic of China has sent more of its staff to receive training in Australia following the successful training of an initial batch over the past year.

The first batch of three MOFA staff members -- Chen Tsun-ling, Chen Huei-chin, and Hsu Hai-lei -- successfully finished their training, including English language study at the Australian National University and different programs specially designed by the ANU in Canberra.

They received 10 weeks of language training at Anutech, a special language training center of the AN. Afterwards, they were assigned to different programs, including the Australian Aid Commission, for a period of 10 months.

Also included were the Australian Youth Ambassadors for Development Program, the Australian Agency for International Development, volunteer work, government and community service, documentation and filing, liaison work, education and business networking, and various seminars and forums on wide-ranging topics.

MOFA staff training in Australia is the brainchild of Dr. Liu Polun, retiring representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra. Liu will leave Canberra on Thursday for a one night stopover in Sydney before heading to Taipei on Friday where he will retire after ending a diplomatic career of nearly 40 years.
Liu proposed to the MOFA that its staff be sent to Australia to receive training in order to receive different experiences and perspectives for their future career.

He said the MOFA used to send its younger staff for various training programs, including language training in English, Spanish, and other languages, to the United States, the United Kingdom, Malaysia, South Africa and European countries.

"I believe Australia will provide a different type of training and perspective to our foreign office staff and help them develop different ideas when they serve in different overseas postings in the future," Liu said in an interview with the CNA.
The first group of trainees told the CNA that they were lucky to have received their training programs in Australia because they obtained "very valuable and practical experiences."
"Just like going to a mountain filled with treasures, I did not go home empty handed from my one-year training in Australia," said Chen Chun-ling.

"It was the first time that I took part in practical meetings, including one that was chaired by UN Secretary General Kofi Annan in 1999, on discussion about Australia's temporary acceptance of about 4,000 Kosovar refugees.
"Such an important discussion meeting on emergency issues opened my eyes and vision on how representatives from developed countries dealt with important problems," he added.

Hsu Hai-lei said aside from taking part in major conferences between Australia and other countries on different topics, she also listened personally to a series of discussions on Australia's foreign aid program and humanitarian assistance.
"I will cherish all of what I received from the various training programs in Australia. There were very practical and useful for my future career," she said.
Due to this initial success, the MOFA in July sent another batch of five staff members for another year of training in Australia.
At a welcome party last week, Liu Polun encouraged them to take every opportunity to learn and benefit from all the programs and studies they are receiving.

"The dispatch of the first group of MOFA staff members is a good start and the dispatch of the second group speaks well for the fact that the Australian training programs cater to the practical needs of our foreign office personnel," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS BUSINESS DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: Superseding the venerable Euro-Asia Trade Organization (EATO), the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) was established on Wednesday to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.

Addressing the inaugural ceremony, President Chen Shui-bian spoke of high expectations regarding CIECA's collaboration with government agencies to jointly promote business and trade diplomacy for the Republic of China.

Chen said he has high hopes that CIECA will cooperate closely with government agencies, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Board of Foreign Trade, to help the country achieve its diplomatic goals.

He urged leaders and executives from Taiwan's private business and industrial sectors to join CIECA as permanent members in order to help bolster exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and countries in the rest of the world.

Chen also asked government agencies and academic circles to provide essential training to executives and personnel from the private business and industrial sectors to allow them to become a strong part of Taiwan's diplomatic front.
EATO Chairman Jeffrey Koo, who is also chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce (CNAIC), became the first chairman of CIECA.

Addressing the inauguration of the new international trade group, Koo vowed that CIECA will cope with government policies and collaborate with all possible sources to promote Taiwan's economic exchanges and cooperation with the world.

Initially, Koo said, CIECA will continue to carry out the tasks of EATO, a 25-year-old organization devoted to cementing contacts and working relationships between Taiwan and European trade promotion groups, and at the same time bolstering exchanges with trade organizations in the Middle East and Africa.

According to Koo, CIECA currently has 120 companies, groups and individuals as its members, which include all existing members of EATO and a number of newcomers, including big names like the Evergreen Group, Acer Inc., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronics Corp., I-Mei Foods Co., and Quanta Electronics.

Koo gave high marks to EATO's contributions to the country over the past two decades, saying that it has established regular conference relationships with 11 European countries and has worked hard to develop bilateral cooperative ties with Russia and East European nations.
He also noted that CIECA will assume all CNAIC business involving international cooperation and exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATCHDOG MEMBERS TO QUESTION ARMS SCANDAL VICTIM'S SECRETARY

TEXT.P: Members of the Control Yuan, Taiwan's top watchdog agency, were scheduled to question the former secretary of a murdered navy captain on Wednesday in an investigation of a high-profile scandal that has tarnished the image of the navy.

Control Yuan members Kang Ning-hsiang and Ma Yi-kung said they had summoned Wang Wan-ying to the Control Yuan and would ask Wang to recall events in 1993 before and after the death of Capt. Yin Ching-feng, then-executive director of the navy's weaponry procurement program.

Kang said that since Wang was the captain's secretary, knew Yin's office activities and most importantly, was told to "clean up" Yin's room at naval headquarters, Wang should know some matters regarding her boss' death.
Most puzzling, Kang said, was why Wang was asked by Yin's colleague Kuo Li-heng to clean up Yin's room even before Yin's whereabouts was known.
Ma said the Control Yuan wanted to fathom what Wang had observed while she was cleaning Yin's room and what was the motive behind the decision to clean his office.

Yin's body was found in Suao Harbor in eastern Taiwan on Dec. 9, 1993 after he had been collecting evidence about alleged irregularities concerning the Navy's procurement of four German-made minesweepers and six French-made frigates.

The investigation into his death had bogged down over the past six years as several arms brokers competing for contracts to provide the navy with the warships fled the island shortly after Yin's death.

Recent reports from Paris saying that huge kickbacks were paid to Taiwan officials for the deal of six frigates fueled speculation that Yin's death was just the tip of an iceberg, and that where was a ploy to cover up massive corruption involving senior military officers and government leaders.

The investigation of Yin's death got a shot in the arm after President Chen Shui-bian on July 30 ordered the establishment of an ad hoc panel, with State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa as its head, to look into the case.
After prosecution, police, investigation and military circles pitched in to renew the probe, the Control Yuan on Wednesday joined in the hunt for Yin's murderer or murderers.
Meanwhile, Yin's widow Lee Mei-kuei visited the Control Yuan that morning, where she produced two photos of Yin's body taken after it been retrieved from the sea.

Lee, who said she has not had a chance to talk with Wang over the past six years, said she wants to show the secretary the photos to let her see how cruel the murder was and how sad it was for Yin to die in such a way.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar remained unchanged against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$31.088.
The local currency opened at NT$31.085 and was traded between NT$31.079 and NT$31.095.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$327.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ASKED TO DEFER CONSTRUCTION OF NEW HOSPITALS

TEXT.P: New Party legislative caucus convener Lai Shih-pao on Tuesday suggested that the Department of Health(DOH) put off plans to construct six new hospitals to a later time due to excessive personnel costs, lack of competitiveness, and poor advance planning.

Lai said during a Legislative Yuan public hearing that on average administrative personnel and office errand runners make up 38.7 percent of all staffs in the 35 hospitals under the DOH, according to data from the DOH.

He added that the total annual deficit of DOH-run hospitals has surpassed NT$4 billion and that because of the poor personnel structure and excessive personnel costs, the government must subsidize these hospitals to the tune of NT$6 billion each year.
As a result, Lai stated that the building of new hospitals should be postponed and that public demand for an improvement of their operations should also be carefully considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS NO COMPROMISE ON `BLACK GOLD' CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday reaffirmed the government's "no compromise" determination to wipe out "black gold" and establish clean politics in Taiwan.

Chen made the pledge in a speech delivered at the opening of an inter-ministerial meeting on the new government's anti-black gold crackdown, which refers to eradicating any connection between organized crime and the government.
Chen said his administration has consistently given top priority to clamping down on organized crime, official corruption, and gangster involvement in politics.

"We will never compromise on this mission, no matter how difficult it is to accomplish the goal," Chen pledged, adding that all relevant government agencies should drop their parochial mentality and work hand-in-hand in anti-black gold operations.

Noting that the public have high expectations of the new government's reform programs, Chen said all law enforcement officers should adopt an active, aggressive working attitude to live up to public expectations of putting an end to black gold politics and establishing "rule by the clean and upright."
Chen outlined three guiding principles for the government's anti-black gold crusade:

-- Taking concrete action to signify the government's determination to engage in an all-out war on black gold, regardless of the stature or rank of officials allegedly involved in bribery scandals or kickback schemes;
-- Dealing with all anti-black gold cases in a just, impartial manner, abiding by all legal procedures and avoiding infringing upon the basic human rights of suspects in probing those cases.

Chen encouraged all government officials to adopt a "do more and talk less" attitude and to use concrete measures to win the hearts and minds of the public. "All members of the new government team should redouble their efforts and achieve solid results to prove the government's anti-black gold determination. Otherwise, the public will lose patience and confidence in the government," he cautioned.

To show its no-nonsense, no-compromise attitude toward "black-gold" politics, Chen said, the new government set up a national anti-black gold action center under the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court on July 1 and formed a special task force on Aug. 1 to probe the high-profile 1993 murder of navy captain Yin Ching-feng.

Chen especially cited the Yin case to stress the importance of cooperation among various government units and even military agencies in investigating the highly complicated and controversial criminal case allegedly involving the country's warship procurement projects in the 1990s. "We will probe the case to the maximum degree, no matter how many incumbent or former military servicemen and government officials are suspected of being involved," he added.
The inter-ministerial anti-black gold meeting was organized by the Ministry of Justice to discuss major problems and possible difficulties in carrying out relevant missions.

Speaking on the occasion, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said the meeting was designed to strengthen communication and coordination of relevant government agencies in anti-black gold operations in order to enhance operational efficiency.

The meeting brought together more than 200 officials from the newly established anti-black gold action center, and prosecution, police, investigation, military police agencies, as well as the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Public Construction Commission and other related government departments.

The justice minister said the anti-black gold action center has so far received 163 applications for investigating corruption, kickback and other criminal charges. Seventy-two of those cases have been assigned to suitable law-enforcement offices for investigation and the remaining 91 cases are being handled by the action center.

He said there will "no ceiling, no bottom line and no deadline" for probing anti-black gold cases. Noting that the action center will focus its operations on cracking down on organized crime, official corruption and vote-buying, Chen said the action center has singled out 17 major categories of public projects for close monitoring, including infrastructure construction bidding, huge procurement programs and business license applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT COMMITTEE TO BE FORMED TO CRACK DOWN ON MILITARY CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: The government decided on Wednesday to form a joint committee of military and judicial prosecutors to effectively crack down on corruption in military procurement operations.

The decision was made at a national rally convened by President Chen Shui-bian to demonstrate the government's determination to stamp out "black gold" in politics -- special links between government agencies, vested interest groups and organized crime syndicates.

In line with a proposal made by Taipei District Prosecutor Chen Rue-jen at the rally, it was decided to recruit investigative units of the Coast Guard Administration, military police and prosecutors to join forces with the "black gold crackdown center" under the Taiwan High Court.

Chen currently also serves as head of a special ad hoc group composed of Taipei district prosecutors and investigative officers of the Criminal Investigation Bureau that is probing the death of naval captain Yin Ching-feng, former chief of the navy's military procurement office who is widely believed to have been assassinated in 1993 to stop him from blowing the whistle on corruption in the navy's purchase of six French-made Lafayette battle ships.

The joint committee will hold meetings periodically to exchange opinions and pool government sources to fight against black gold, and especially corruption in the military's weapons procurement, Chen said.

According to Chen, military corruption is a fierce "black hole" which sucks up the country's economic strength, as military budget totals more than NT$400 billion per year. If military procurement personnel are illegally linked to gang organizations, it will slash the country's combat capabilities terribly, he noted.

As military prosecutors, in compliance with Republic of China law, are granted greater access to information in secret military establishments than ordinary judicial prosecutors, Chen said they will be a great help in investigating cases related to corruption in military procurement.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARINE BOOK SHOW KICKS OFF AT KAOHSIUNG HARBOR
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The world's oldest "gospel ship" has docked at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan, where it will host a book show from Aug. 9 to Sept. 3, according to the local organizer of the show.
It is the fifth time the 86-year-old Doulos has visited Taiwan to exhibit books from all over the world.

He Bi-chin, the local organizer of the exhibition, said on Wednesday at a press conference that the more-than 300 volunteer crew members of the Doulos, from 35 countries, hope to bring peace and the gospel to the world with their port calls.

More than 60,000 people went aboard the Doulos to visit the book show in 1999, when it last docked at Kaohsiung Harbor. This year's exhibition showcases more than 6,000 books, on topics including education, business administration, cookery, children, families and religion.

The Doulos, just two years younger than the ill-fated Titanic, is 131 meters in length, 17 meters in width and weighs 6,800 tons. It is operated by the German charity Gute Bucher Fur Alle (Good Books for All).
More than 15 million people have tramped the decks of the Doulos during its visits to 87 countries over the past 23 years, according to He.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BOEING JETLINER STOPS BY TAIWAN ON WORLD TOUR
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The US-based Boeing aircraft company showcased the newest member of its 767 family here on Wednesday on one of the last stops of a round-the-world tour.

Representatives from local airlines, the media, and the Civil Aeronautics Administration attended the flight demonstration of the Boeing 767-400ER (extended range) jetliner, which began its tour in Vienna on July 12 and is scheduled to return to Seattle on Saturday.

The month-long tour included a week's stay at the Farnborough Air Show in England and one-day stops at cities stretching across three continents, including Hannover, Prague, Warsaw, Frankfurt, Nairobi, Shanghai, Beijing, Tokyo, Bangkok and Seoul.

According to Boeing, the one-of-a-kind display jet has a special World Tour design that features graphics and fabrics that reflect the human fascination with flight. Illustrations from the Greek myths of Pegasus and Mercury are woven into the carpets, and the cabin decor features renditions of Leonardo da Vinci's drawings.

The 767-400ER is 6.43 meters longer than the 767-300ER and draws its interior design from the Boeing 777. With increased takeoff weight, a new main landing gear, and an upgraded flight deck, the jetliner can seat up to 355 passengers in a single-class configuration and fly 10,460 km non-stop.
In a three-class configuration, the plane can accommodate 245 passengers, while a two-class configuration seats 304.
The first Boeing 767-400ER is scheduled to enter service later this month.
Internet users can take a virtual tour of the plane at the 767-400ER's world tour website (www.boeing.com/767tour).

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA SETS NEW TREND IN PERSONNEL RECRUITMENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) launched a trend-setting program on Wednesday to scout for qualified hopefuls to join its staff roster.

The council said all those who are qualified for 10th- to 12th- rank civil service positions and interested in cultural promotion work are welcome to apply before Aug. 31 to head the CCA's first and third departments and the National Taiwan Museum, which is under the CCA's jurisdiction.

According to the council's plan, the talent scouting will be carried out in two phases. In the first qualifying screening stage, candidates will be required to present their civil service accreditation certificates, detailed resumes, career plans and papers detailing their vision of the nation's cultural development.

In the second stage, the CCA will organize a special panel of judges to interview those who make the first cut to examine their professional expertise, career goals and work ethics. The jurors will include the CCA head, deputy heads, secretary-general and specialists in relevant fields.
This will be the first time that a government agency has tried to recruit high-ranking civil servants in such an open and fully transparent manner.
CCA Chairwoman Chen Yu-chiou, a noted pianist, said she hopes the move will help inspire the new Republic of China government to develop a new personnel administration culture or system.

"We hope this trend-setting move will enable us to find highly competent and dedicated cultural professionals to work for our country and people and help boost our cultural renaissance and development," Chen said.
"Competence and aspiration for work and service are our main concerns, while personal connections and partisan backgrounds won't matter at all," stressed Chen, who herself has no party affiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC WILL NOT ILLEGALLY SET UP OPERATIONS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Chinatrust Commercial Bank (CBC) President Jeffrey Koo, who is also chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, said on Wednesday that he will not establish CBC branches or representative offices in mainland China without government approval.

Speaking at the inaugural meeting of the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association that was held at CBC headquarters, he noted that the increasing trade and economic contact across the Taiwan Strait is making many local banks interested in setting up offices in the mainland, and added that CBC is no exception.

He also said that once Taiwan and the mainland enter the World Trade Organization, it will simply be a matter of time before the Republic of China government relaxes its policy on local bank operations in the mainland, and claimed that the move is an inevitable trend.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WINS BRONCO LEAGUE WORLD BASEBALL SERIES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei captured the Bronco League World Series baseball championship for the third consecutive year on Tuesday, beating Puerto Rico 16-7 at Monterey, California, with two home runs in the sixth inning.

The Chinese Taipei team showed its batting skill in the bottom of the first inning to lead the competition 4-0. Bayamon Puerto Rico got one point at the top of the second inning, while Chinese Taipei added two points at the bottom of the second inning, taking the score to 6-1.
The Puerto Rican nine brought the score up to 5-6 by the end of the fifth inning, when the Chinese Taipei team sent on a relief pitcher.

Although the Chinese Taipei got one point in the bottom of fifth inning, the Puerto Rico team added two points in the top of sixth inning. The neck-to-neck situation remained unchanged until the Chinese Taipei team scored two consecutive home runs at the bottom of sixth inning, thus sealing the final win.

The 2000 Bronco League World Series for 11-and 12-year-olds, opened on Aug. 3 with teams representing the six zones of Pony Baseball -- North, South, West, East, Caribbean, and Asia-Pacific -- participating along with host team Monterey and a host area team from northern California.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL EXTENDS APOLOGY TO PREMIER

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen on Wednesday extended an apology to Premier Tang Fei for his recent public criticism of Tang.

For two consecutive days earlier in the week, Wu told the media that he was disappointed by Tang's performance and that the poor performance of his Cabinet might affect the DPP's campaign for next year's legislative election.
Wu's remarks astonished the DPP government and the public. President Chen Shui-bian immediately voiced his support for Tang and reiterated his affirmation of Tang's performance.
DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh also told reporters that Wu's remarks did not represent the ruling party's stand.

Apologizing for causing misunderstanding between the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan, Wu said that through the establishment of a consultation mechanism between the DPP, the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan, he has discovered that the Cabinet is actually striving hard to carry out its various policies.
The consultation meeting will be held at the DPP Central Headquarters on Wednesdays.
Wu's criticism of Tang also came under attack from other quarters, with the Kuomintang caucus in the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday describing his remarks as "inhumane" and "unfair."
Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT heavyweight in the Legislative Yuan, said that despite illness, Tang has been doing his best for the new government.
Some other lawmakers from the KMT and the People First Party also came to Tang's defense to affirm his performance since assuming office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 10, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
843: The Treaty of Verdun divides the Frankish empire.
1810: Count (Camillo Benso) Cavour, Italian statesman, is born. He played a major role in the unification of Italy and became prime minister of the new kingdom.
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1885: The first commercially operated electrical streetcar begins operation in Baltimore in the United States.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania, and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of US President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: US State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the US Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the EEC.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in flooding in mainland China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 23.45 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 23.45 points to close at 8,024.69.
Market turnover amounted to NT$82.76 billion (US$2.67 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 23.45 points to close at 8,024.69.
The bourse opened at 8,087.1, and due to profit-taking selling pressure, share prices began to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 8,105.63 and 7,988.39 during trading.

A total of 1.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.76 billion (US$2.67 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.01 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$95.85 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only electrical shares gained ground, edging up by 0.4 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.2 percent, followed by cement stocks and plastics and chemical shares, both at 2 percent, textile issues at 1.6 percent, food stuff stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 1 percent, and construction stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 379 to 137, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN PROTESTS BAN ON MEETING WITH PRESIDENT CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A US congressman has demanded the Department of State ease its restrictions on ROC President Chen Shui-bian's activities during his upcoming transit stay in Los Angeles, Capitol sources said on Wednesday.
President Chen is scheduled to arrive in Los Angeles on Aug. 13 for a brief stopover on his way to Central America for his first state visit since taking the helm of the Republic of China on May 20.

An aide to Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) told CNA that several pro-Taiwan US congressional members have expressed interest in meeting with Chen in private during his Los Angeles stopover. However, the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. has politely turned down all requests for arranging meetings with Chen.

As Rep. Rohrabacher was fully aware that the true reason behind the ROC representative office's refusal was pressure from the Clinton administration, his aide said, the congressman already wrote to Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth urging the State Department to lift its improper ban on informal meetings between President Chen and US lawmakers.

According to his aide, Rohrabacher said in his letter dated on Tuesday that he was disappointed by the Clinton administration's continued sacrifice of its ties with Taipei simply for coddling Beijing.
Rohrabacher was quoted as saying in his letter that the Clinton administration's stringent restrictions on Chen's transit activities provide yet another evidence to its kowtowing to Beijing.

The US lawmaker further said if the United States wants to maintain its leadership in the democratic world, it should let President Chen and his entourage enjoy their basic rights to freedoms of speech and assembly during their transit stay in Los Angeles.
The State Department announced on Monday that it will grant a transit visa to Chen with the understanding that no public activities will be on his agenda during his stopover in the United States.

The arrangement is designed "for the safety and convenience of the traveler," State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said, adding that there are no meetings expected with any Clinton administration officials during Chen's stopover.
Despite Beijing's consistent objection, the United States has usually allowed transit visas for senior ROC leaders on the condition that they refrain from any public activities while on US soil.

Due to his hectic schedule, President Chen will stay in Los Angeles for only about 15 hours. His first overseas trip as the ROC's head of state will take him to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, and Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, as well as the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad in West Africa.
