DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA INCREASES MISSILE-RELATED ASSISTANCE TO PAKISTAN: CIA

TEXT.P: The Central Intelligence Agency said in its latest National Intelligence Estimate (NIE) that Communist China appears to have honored its pledge not to expand aid beyond Iran's two nuclear projects, but it accused Beijing of increasing missile-related technical assistance to Pakistan in the second half of last year.

First disclosed by congressional aides in late July and then reported in The Washington Times on Wednesday, the non classified version of the NIE report, which reviewed nonproliferation developments during the last half of 1999, was made public by the CIA.

The CIA pointed out that mainland Chinese companies also provided missile-related items, raw materials, and/or assistance to several countries of concern to the United States, including Iran, North Korea, and Libya.

"The Chinese have taken a very narrow interpretation of their nonproliferation commitment," noted the CIA report. Beijing has promised not to export whole missile systems and denied selling them to Pakistan, but it has refused to sign the Missile Technology Control Regime or abide by its ban on sales of missile components.

The CIA added that the United States has failed to stop the increasing flow of Russian aid to Iran's missile and non conventional weapons program, saying Washington's appeal to Moscow for an end to the transfer of missile technology to Tehran has fallen on deaf ears. The result is that Iran has significantly advanced its program to develop such intermediate-range and long-range missiles as the Shihab-3 and Shihab-4.
"The Russian government's commitment, willingness, and ability to curb proliferation-related transfers remains uncertain," stressed the CIA report.

The CIA said Iran's non conventional weapons program is also being assisted by Communist China, North Korea, and Western Europe. This includes the construction of chemical weapons plants and missile production facilities. In addition, Syria has obtained missile-related equipment from Russia and North Korea and is building a solid-fuel missile motor plant in its drive to develop intermediate-range missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: NZ OFFICIAL PROPOSES JOINT CITIZENSHIP SCHEME WITH AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: New Zealand Finance Minister Michael Cullen proposed a joint citizenship scheme with Australia during a speech at a Council for Economic Development of Australia luncheon in Melbourne on Wednesday.
He said the time has come to acknowledge that the increasingly free flow of labor between the two countries is in Australia's economic interests.
But a spokesman for Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock told The Australian that Cullen's comments smacked of financial self-interest on New Zealand's part.
New Zealand's Prime Minister Helen Clark last year urged her compatriots to return home and stem the brain drain.
Nearly 34,500 New Zealanders settled in Australia during 1999, and only 12,000 Australians went to live in New Zealand during the same period.
More than 330,000 New Zealanders now live in Australia, enjoying the social welfare benefits of their country of residence.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DEPORTS 22 M'LAND CHINESE BOAT PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Australia has deported 22 boat people to mainland China less than one month after they landed illegally in Cairns, Queensland, said Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock in a written statement.
The statement, faxed to the CNA on Thursday morning, said the 22 male Chinese nationals were flown from Port Hedland in Western Australia where they had been held in detention since July 15.

Ruddock said that "the removal of the illegal arrivals showed the value of cooperation between countries that are determined to end people smuggling rackets and also the futility of trying to enter Australia illegally."
"The return of the 22 illegals is a further example of the ongoing cooperation that exists between the Australian and Chinese governments," he added.

Between July 1999 and the first half of 2000, more than 4,000 illegal immigrants landed in Australia, with most of them coming from Afghanistan, the Middle East, Turkey, and other Asian countries, including mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.019 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$31.069.
The local currency opened at NT$31.078 and was traded between NT$31.068 and NT$31.085.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$432 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO HOST BANQUET FOR FIVE YUAN LEADERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will host a banquet for the heads of the Executive, Legislative, Judicial, Control, and Examination Yuans on Thursday evening at the Taipei Guest House.
An official at the Presidential Office said that President Chen seldom meets with the five yuan leaders because he is usually fully occupied with state affairs.
The spokesman added that Chen wants to thank the five yuan heads for assisting him and also to listen to their opinions about the current political situation.
Vice President Annette Lu, deputy heads of the five yuans and other senior officials will also attend the banquet.
In addition, Chen will also brief them on his upcoming 13-day state visit to Latin America and Africa.
The spokesman added that Chen is expected to ask them to take good care of domestic affairs while he travels abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLICE CHIEF CALLS FOR SERVICE-ORIENTED CONCEPTS

TEXT.P: The country's new police chief pledged on Thursday that he will push for the establishment of a service-oriented management system to reduce crime rate and more effectively maintain law and order.
Wang Chin-wang, new director-general of the National Police Administration (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), made the remarks after assuming office.
Wang, who, at 53, is the Republic of China's youngest-ever national police chief, said the public have high expectations of enjoying a safe, crime-free living environment.

"All police staff should treat all members of the general public as their clients and help them resolve problems," Wang said, adding that police should not reject handling of burglaries on the excuse that they are minor criminal cases.

Wang said the NPA will crank out forward-looking work plans to step up criminal investigations, protect women and children's safety, prevent juvenile crime, improve traffic conditions and lower traffic accidents.
In this democratic era, Wang said police must reach out to ordinary people and develop close ties with grassroots communities to understand their demand.

Wang also promised to promote structural and systematic reforms to enable all police officers to continuously acquire new knowledge and expertise so as to enhance individual and group competitiveness and operational efficiency.
Wang succeeded Ting Yuan-chin who resigned over the Pachang Creek tragedy which claimed four lives due to a government rescue fiasco.
Wang took his oath of office in a joint swearing-in ceremony presided over by Interior Minister Chang Po-ya.
Also sworn in by Chang at the same ceremony were new National Fire Administration (NFA) Director-General Chao Kang and new National Police University President Chu Cheng-min.
Chao took over the top NFA post from Chen Hung-yi who, like Ting, quit over the Pachang Creek incident which also resulted in the resignation of Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun last month.
Both Ting and Chen have retired from public services after their departure from their posts to assume the political responsibility for the Pachang Creek tragedy.

On July 22, people in Taiwan watched in horror and anxiety as live TV beamed the image of four hapless workers huddled together in the raging Pachang Creek in the southern county of Chiayi waiting for rescue helicopters until they finally lost their footing and were swallowed by the surging current.

For more than two hours, the three men and a woman waited for a helicopter rescue which was only a five-minute flight away, as the Air Force's Seagull Rescue Team is stationed nearby. However, the various authorities -- firefighters, police and military -- were unable to agree as to who was responsible for rescue, and the petty bureaucratic wrangling of low-level pen-pushers led directly to the death of all four people.
Their deaths triggered a public uproar and shaved about 20 percentage points off Chen's popularity ratings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN TO ATTEND OVERSEAS CHINESE MEETING IN BERLIN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-huan & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong arrived in Berlin on Thursday to attend an annual meeting of overseas Chinese organizations in Europe.

It was Soong's first trip to Europe since the March 18 president election, in which he garnered 36 percent of votes, second only to the 39 percent of votes for President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party.
Arriving at Berlin's airport, Soong was greeted by Republic of China Representative to Germany Charles King, as well as some delegates to the overseas Chinese meeting.
During his stay in Berlin, Soong will deliver a speech at the gathering of overseas Chinese and visit local Chinese organizations.
He will also exchange views with PFP supporters on the development of the new party, which was formed after the presidential election.
Soong is accompanied on the European trip by his wife, daughter, PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi and Legislator Huang Yi-chiao (PFP-Taichung City).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER HAS NO INTENTION OF RESIGNING, SAYS GIO CHIEF

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Tang Fei has no intention of resigning from the premiership despite of his illness, said Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Chung Chin on Thursday.
Tang underwent a medical examination at Veterans General Hospital on Wednesday after complaining of dizzy spells. He continued to take sick leave on Thursday, when he rested at home.
Chung told the media that Tang has no intention of stepping down, and added that he still wants to head the Cabinet and implement various administrative plans.

Some observers have speculated that Tang's latest illness might have been prompted by recent critical remarks questioning Tang's ability to head the Executive Yuan by Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen.
However, Chung waved off such speculation, saying that Tang will continue to serve the new government. Wu expressed his apology to the premier on Wednesday.
The GIO chief said that Tang's blood pressure was normal on Thursday, with his general physical condition returning to a normal level.
Chung noted that Tang will go back to office on Friday to handle important matters, with part of his schedule to be shifted to Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

A crowd of reporters waited on Thursday outside Tang's residence for news about the premier's activities. His wife asked the media to convey her family's appreciation to the public for their concern about Tang's health.

When asked whether or not she supports Tang continuing in his post as premier, she replied, "There is no use for me to speak on this issue, because he has never listened to me. Had he ever listened to me, he would not have been on the post today."
Mrs. Tang said that she sincerely hopes that Tang will take good care of his health and will not work too hard.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF: LOCAL BANKS STILL HAVE DIFFICULTY SETTING UP OFFICES IN M'LAND

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Ministry of Finance said here on Thursday that it still has technical problems concerning local banking institutions that wish to set up offices in mainland China.

Taiwan's banking regulations say that if local banks want to set up offices in a "third country" -- meaning mainland China -- the application should be made by an overseas branch. Many banks in Taiwan do not fulfill Beijing's requirements as to total assets, Vice Minister of Finance Sean C. Chen.

According to Beijing's rules, a Taiwanese bank is regarded as a foreign institution, so its total assets should surpass US$20 billion and it should be able to show a profitable record for several years if it wishes to set up an office in mainland China. At present, a total of 14 local banks meet those qualifications, Chen said.

He went on to say that in addition to these technical problems, authorities in Beijing may ask the bank's home country to present a certification before allowing its mainland branches the freedom to trade in renminbi. It remains unclear whether Beijing would accept a certification bearing the official name of the Republic of China, he added.
Chen made these remarks at a breakfast meeting with members of the opposition People First Party's caucus in the Legislative Yuan.

Financial officials who were present at the meeting included Governor of the Central Bank of China Perng Hai-nan, and Chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTPUT OF ROC COMPUTER PRODUCTS SURGES IN FIRST HALF OF 2000

TEXT.P: The output of Taiwan's computer products surged in the first half of this year, according to a report issued on Thursday by the Institute for Information Industry (III).

Production of personal computers (PC's) was up a whopping 60.45 percent annually during the first six months of 2000, that of notebook computers rose by 50.46 percent during the same period, and that of motherboards grew by 30.44 percent, the III said. However, the III noted that output of most computer peripherals failed to keep pace, with an exception being digital camera production, which rose by 50.1 percent during the same period.

Despite the huge increase in production of PCs, revenues from their sales grew by just 10.79 percent compared to the year-earlier period, to reach US$3.6 billion, according to the report. Meanwhile, revenues from sales of notebook computers and motherboards were up 40.92 percent and 20.66 percent, respectively. In comparison, sales of digital cameras grew by some 227 percent to reach about US$400 million.

In other peripheral products, production of monitors grew by a slim 8.57 percent annually, while that of scanners grew some 10.9 percent compared to the same period in 1999, due to consumers' increasing use of digital images, the III said. Taiwan's' total output of CD-ROMs increased 50.1 percent compared to the first half of the previous year, according to the report.
The III added that revenues from sales of monitors, scanners, and CD-ROMs grew by 10.27 percent, 20.48 percent, and 48 percent, respectively.

The III forecasted that output of PC's in the second half of 2000 will increase by an annual 20.17 percent, while that of notebook computers will grow some 30.14 percent due to expected high fourth-quarter demand.

Meanwhile, the report forecasted that output of motherboards, monitors, digital cameras, and CD-ROMs will increase annually by 30.33 percent, 20.55 percent, 80.43 percent and 30.73 percent, respectively, in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR ARMED FORCES POLICE HELP IN ANTI-BLACK GOLD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday urged the armed forces police to assist law enforcement officers in sweeping away "black gold" and establishing clean politics in Taiwan.

Chen made the call during an inspection tour of the Armed Forces Police Command (AFPC) in Taipei, also the last stop of his first nationwide "journey of national defense" as the Republic of China military's supreme leader.
Chen was accompanied by Vice President Annette Lu, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming and other senior military officers on his AFPC inspection visit.
The president received a grand welcome from the AFPC's newly formed honor guards band. AFPC Commander-in-Chief Yang Yu-tsun then briefed Chen on AFPC's operations and future work plans.
In his speech to AFPC staff, Chen said as the AFPC is responsible for safeguarding capital, it plays a pivotal role in defending the security of the country's political and military centers.

Noting that mainalnd China has stepped up development of high-technology-oriented partial war strategy and "acupuncture warfare" strategy, Chen said Taiwan's political and military centers will certainly become the prime targets of mainland Chinese attack.
Therefore, Chen said, establishing a modern, professional elite military police force is one of the priorities of Taiwan's military build-up plans.
Chen further said that under the military's ongoing 10-year troops reduction plan, the AFPC's functions have been adjusted and streamlined.

In addition to defending the government and military command centers and major public facilities, Chen said, the AFPC should also share the responsibilities of safeguarding military barracks security and maintaining law and order in local society.

Chen further said the APPC should focus on helping crackdown on smuggling of humans, contraband goods, narcotics and firearms, as well as on eradicating organized crime and gangster involvement in politics, also known as "black old" which is seen as a malignant tumor to Taiwan's political and economic development.
To accomplish these anti-"black gold" missions, Chen said, all AFPC staff members should beef up their professional criminal investigation capability and expertise.

In response, AFPC Commander-in-Chief Yang Yu-tsun said the AFPC has set up four special task forces, stationed in northern, central, southern and eastern parts of the island respectively, to assist law enforcement officers in anti-black gold operations.

President Chen began his nationwide "journey of national defense" on June 16 when he reviewed a military cadets exercise at the Chinese Military Academy in Fengshan, southern Taiwan as part of the celebrations of the school's 76th founding anniversary.
Over the past two months, Chen has visited all major military units around the country and presided over new warplanes and warships commissioning ceremonies.

Chen is scheduled to start his 13-day, six-leg diplomatic tour on Aug. 13, which will take him to the ROC's allies in the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa. This will be his first overseas visit since taking office on May 20. After ending the trip on Aug. 26, Chen will preside over the opening of an annual combined services military drill, code-named Han Kuang No. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT BUDGET MEETS ONLY 80% OF DEFENSE NEEDS: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The defense budget for fiscal year 2000 meets only 80 percent of the needs of the island's defense forces, and should not be cut anymore, said a defense official on Thursday.

Huang Yi-li, an planning official under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), told a hearing called by Legislator Chin Hui-chu that although the NT$271.9 billion (US$8.77 billion) in defense expenditures in the government's draft budget for 2000 is NT$1.6 billion more than that of 1999, it falls far short of the NT$324.2 billion (US$10.45 billion) required by the MND.

As a result, the MND will be forced to prioritize programs aimed at improving operational readiness, such as preparations for cyberspace warfare, operational support and the replacement of aging weaponry equipment.
On the other hand, non-operational expenditures, such as administrative expenses and expenditures for vehicles' fuel, will be cut because of the shortfall in the budget, said Huang.

Stopping short of asserting that this year's tight defense budget will jeopardize Taiwan's national security, the officer cautioned that any further Legislative Yuan cuts in the already-stretched budget would spell trouble for the MND.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NOTEBOOK COMPUTER MAKERS TO GRAB 60 PERCENT OF WORLD'S MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's notebook computer suppliers will enjoy a 60 percent share of the worldwide market this year, according to a report released on Thursday by the Institute for Information Industry (III).

III senior analyst Chen Wen-tang said that major Japanese firms such as Sony, Toshiba, and NEC have all increased their orders of Taiwan-made notebook computers, which will allow Taiwan's notebook suppliers to dominate the worldwide market.

Chen added Taiwan's notebook computers have been No. 1 in the world in terms of total shipments for two years running, beating out their competitors worldwide, including Korean firms such as LG and Samsung.

Chen forecasted that unless the government stands in the way, production of notebook computers will gradually shift to mainland China starting from the third and fourth quarters of this year, as manufacturers look forward to taking advantage of lower production costs on the mainland. Most of Taiwan's personal computer firms have moved their production facilities to the mainland China already.
The report also noted that Taiwan's OEM and ODM computer manufacturing during the first six months of the year increased by an annual 50.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS NOT MAINLAND'S BIGGEST ISSUE: MAC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The main issue being debated at an annual meeting of Beijing leaders is not mainland China's relations with Taiwan but rather its domestic economic and political dilemmas, said Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin here on Wednesday.

Speaking on mainland China's domestic issues and cross-strait relations at an annual meeting of overseas Chinese in Europe, Lin said that the mainland's top brass and party leaders are currently more worried about economic development and domestic unrest than they are about Taiwan.

Lin said that the Beidaihe meeting is about whether authorities in mainland China should break through a political bottleneck in order for economic development to continue or let conservatives retain their power and interests, which risks worsening social instability.

As evidence of increasing instability on the mainland, he cited a little-known riot that took place in northeastern China in February that involved over 100,000 people, including servicemen from a nuclear submarine base in the vicinity. He said that it received virtually no publicity because of a ban on media coverage in the area.
He added that riots by farmers are commonplace, but that they are scattered across mainland China.

Lin said that most people in Taiwan observing cross-strait relations only look at the exchanges and fail to realize that the mainland's domestic situation has a big effect on how Beijing deals with Taiwan.

He added that Taiwan's mainland policy should emphasize patience, and that the best way to handle Beijing's continued push for its "one China" principle before restarting bilateral negotiations is to return to the "spirit of 1992," which circumvents problems that cannot be solved at the moment to focus only on those that can be worked out.
Lin also warned that mainland China is not about to back down on its military buildup, regardless of whether the United States decides to establish a National Missile Defense system.

Wednesday's meeting is traditionally held each year before the annual meeting of Chinese Associations in Europe, slated to begin on Friday. It is the biggest annual event for overseas Chinese in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR APPROVAL OF HIS DEPUTY'S MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday urged the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to approve Deputy Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsiung planned visit to mainland China in line with the government's pledge to promote exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Ma said since Pei is not an elected local government chief, the Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, should not reject Pei's mainland travel plan.
Moreover, Ma said, the main purpose of Pei's mainland visit is to attend an academic seminar on the population aging problems.

Noting that Pei is a well-known expert on the problems of elderly people, Ma said Pei has been invited to attend the seminar in his capacity as an expert on population graying problems, not as a deputy mayor of Taipei.
The MAC last month forced Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to cancel his plan to visit the southeastern mainland port city of Xiamen. Ma said Pei's case is different from Hsieh's.

"For one thing, Hsieh is an elected local government chief, while Pei is not," Ma said, adding he hopes the MAC will approve Pei's application to show the new Republic of China government's sincerity to promote cross-strait exchanges and rapprochement.

Meanwhile, Ma said he has been invited to attend a "Track II" roundtable meeting on cross-Taiwan Strait issues and US China policy to be held in New York from Aug. 14-15. Ma, himself a former MAC vice chairman, will deliver a paper at the seminar.

The non-governmental roundtable is sponsored by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a noted US think tank which enjoys enormous influence on the formation of US foreign policy. The meeting will bring together about 20 scholars and experts from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States.
Ma said he believes that the three-way roundtable will help promote cross-strait mutual understanding.
Except for Ma, Taiwan delegates will include Soochow University professor Kuo Cheng-liang and Lin Cheng-yi, head of the Institute of European and American Studies of Academia Sinica.
Following his New York visit, Ma will visit several of Taipei's sister cities in Central America to help cement the Republic of China's diplomatic relations with its Central American allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER SIGNS COOPERATION MEMORANDUM WITH OKINAWA INDUSTRY CENTER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) on Thursday signed a memorandum of academiC cooperation with the Nansei Shoto IndustriaL Advancement Center in Okinawa, Japan.

TIER President Wu Rong-I said that Okinawa is in an important position for Taiwan's security. TIER hopes not only to facilitate regional economic development through academic exchanges with Japan, but also to promote substantial relations between the two countries, he added.

Wu noted that the Japanese government is now actively seeking to develop Okinawa and the government there hopes that Taiwan's information industry sector will make investment in Okinawa. If offers to Taiwan investors are attractive enough, further discussions will be made on investments in Okinawa, he added.
The signing ceremony was also attended by Chio I-jen, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council under the Presidential Office, and other concerned officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COASTAL PATROL SEIZES MAINLAND CHINESE FISHING VESSELS

TEXT.P: The Kinmen Coastal Patrol and the Kinmen Defense Command's "Sea Dragon" patrols together seized 10 mainland Chinese fishing boats on Thursday for poaching in Republic of China territorial waters.

A total of 11 men and nine women were discovered aboard the vessels, but after a search of the cabins revealed that no smuggling or illegal petty trading was involved, the officers cited the fishermen as being in violation of the statute governing relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China and deported them.

Wu Hsing-pang, acting captain of the Kinmen Coastal Patrol, said that his team is the first line of defense against smuggling in the area, and that the coastal patrol will continue to team up with other related authorities to monitor, disperse, and deport illegal mainland Chinese fishermen from Kinmen waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EUROPEAN GOODS AND TRAVEL EXHIBITION TO KICK OFF

TEXT.P: EUROGATE 2000, a new European goods and travel exhibition, will run at the Taipei World Trade Center from Aug. 24-27.
The show, jointly organized by the economics and foreign ministries will feature exhibits from European countries including Poland, the Czech Republic, Macedonia, Hungry, Lithuania, and Latvia.

Goods on display will include hand-painted glass and ceramics from the Czech Republic, jewelry and cosmetics from Poland, agriculture and textile products from Macedonia, and amber products from Latvia.

In addition to showcasing their goods, Polish, Czech, Macedonian and Latvian representatives will hold investment seminars to explain the investment environment and rules in their countries, while Poland and Macedonia will also put on folk art performances.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST-EARTHQUAKE RECONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO COST US$ 7.7 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, Central Taiwan, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The cost of post-earthquake reconstruction projects over the next three years is estimated at over NT$240 billion (US$7.74 billion), according to the post-quake reconstruction committee under the Cabinet.
The committee said on Thursday that of the figure, NT$81.14 billion will be spent in fiscal 2001, NT$75.12 billion in fiscal 2002, and NT$89.37 billion in fiscal 2003.

Housing and community reconstruction projects will account for NT$149.44 billion, public reconstruction projects for NT$53.17 billion, ground reconstruction projects for NT$21.01 billion, social reconstruction projects for NT$17.46 billion and industrial reconstruction plans for NT$4.46 billion.
The committee has decided to compile a special budget for the reconstruction fund, to be appropriated from the Ministry of Finance.
Nantou and Taichung counties in central Taiwan were the hardest-hit areas in last September's temblor, the strongest quake to hit Taiwan in nearly 100 years, in which about 2,400 people were killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PATENTS APPROVED DOUBLES IN FIRST HALF OF YEAR

TEXT.P: The number of patent devices approved by the government totaled 20,365 in the first half of this year, an increase of 46 percent from a year ago, a government agency reported on Thursday.

According to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) report, the increase is a reflection of the Taiwan people's upgraded capabilities of invention, a development which it said will boost the competitiveness of Taiwan's industries.

In the first six months of this year, a total of 32,437 patent items, up 26.1 percent on a year-by-year basis, were submitted for government registration, the DGBAS tallies indicate. Some 19,527 items, or 60.2 percent of the total, were submitted by Republic of China nationals.

In addition, the statistics show that a total of 41,549 applications for trademark registration with the government were filed in the first half of the year, up 18.3 percent from the corresponding period of last year. About 26,398 were approved by the government, up 15.1 percent from a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD-CLASS GOLFERS TO TAKE PART IN LOCAL SKIN TOURNAMENT

TEXT.P: World famous golfers Gary Player, Lee Trevino, Lu Liang-huan and Isao Aoki will compete in a skin tournament scheduled to be held at the Ta Shee Golf and Country Club course on Sept. 10, it was announced here on Thursday.

Player, who has won more than 160 championship titles in tournaments around the world since he began his professional career in 1956, has been dubbed "international ambassador of golf," while Lu Liang-huan of Taiwan, Lee Trevino of the United States and Isao Aoki of Japan are also renowned in golfing circles.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ACCUSES BEIJING OF HYPOCRISY ON `ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday accused Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterated Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.

Stopping short of naming names, Chen told visiting US Senator Jack Reed that while some Beijing leaders have told Taiwan visitors that "one China" does not necessarily refer to Beijing, they stick to the claim on the international stage that "there is only one China of which Beijing is the sole legitimate regime and Taiwan is a part."

Beijing's differing versions of "one China" only betray its plot to annex Taiwan and made the island a province of mainland China through what it calls "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," said Chen.

As a head of state elected by the people, Chen said he would be over-stepping his authority if he were to accept Beijing's "one China" without the people's mandate, as the majority of the people of Taiwan do not consider the island to be "another Hong Kong or Macau."

Just as the US administration is subject to the control of Congress, the government of the Republic of China has to consult public opinion when setting forth its policy toward the mainland, and should give the people the final say on the issue of "one China."

However, the president reiterated an offer he made on July 31 that Taipei is ready to resume contacts with Beijing "in the spirit of 1992" if Beijing backs down on its insistence that Taiwan reconfirm its commitment to the "one China" policy.
Taipei and Beijing held intensive dialogue in 1992, which was capped with the first meeting between the top cross-strait representatives in Singapore the following year.
Chen echoed US President Bill Clinton's call for the solution of the Taipei-Beijing dispute through peaceful dialogue and respect for the free choice of the Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOSTS BANQUET FOR FIVE YUAN LEADERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday hosted a banquet for the heads of the five branches of the Republic of China government -- the Executive, Legislative, Judicial, Control, and Examination Yuans -- at the Taipei Guest House.
Chen Che-nan, acting secretary-general to the president, said that Premier Tang Fei -- head of the Executive Yuan -- appeared to be in good spirits during the course of the banquet.

Tang was hospitalized the day before for a health checkup and took the day off on Thursday to rest amidst nationwide concern over his health, which prompted speculation on whether he intends to step down. Government spokeswoman Chung Chin had quashed the speculation on Tang's behalf earlier in the day.
Chen said that the president briefed the five yuan heads on his upcoming 13-day state visit to Latin America and Africa, and asked them to take good care of domestic affairs while he travels abroad.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said that the president spoke of feeling "at ease" about going abroad because he will be able to maintain control over the domestic situation 24 hours a day.
Wang added that the president told them of his "initial understanding" of the content of an annual meeting of the Beijing leadership, which he added should not manifest too many major problems.

The president was also quoted as saying that the Beidaihe meeting of Beijing's top brass and party leaders touched on three major issues: the after effects of joining the World Trade Organization; the personnel issues regarding the 16th People's Congress; and the Taiwan issue.
Wang went on to say that the president asked the Executive Yuan to report next year's government budget to each party's legislative caucus before officially submitting it to the Legislative Yuan.
Vice President Annette Lu, the deputy heads of the five yuans and other senior officials also attended the banquet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Mainland China's Beidaihe policy meeting ends after extensive discussion on three major issues.
The China Times:
Mainland China plans a 10-fold increase in nuclear weapons deployment to counter the US national missile defense system.
The United Daily News:
The Cabinet calls for hike of the government debt ceiling from current 15 percent to 25 percent.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen promises inter-party consultations on selection of qualified persons to fill vacancies in the Examination and Control Yuans.
The China Post:
Preferential home loans may begin Monday: CBC.
The Taiwan News:
Beijing reshuffles cross-strait officials.
The Taipei Times:
Researchers develop molecular-sized motors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 11, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1786: The Rajah of Kedah in Malaya cedes Penang to Britain.
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupied southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The UN Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1974: The Third National Reconstruction Seminar closes after two weeks of briefings, tours and discussions.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipbreaking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a north American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 50.04 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 50.04 points to close at 7,974.65.
Market turnover amounted to NT$62.28 billion (US$2.01 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PETROCHEMICAL REPS ASK FOR EASING OF M'LAND INVESTMENT RESTRICTIONS

TEXT.P: Leaders from Taiwan's petrochemical industry appealed to the government on Friday for a relaxation of restrictions on mainland China-bound investment in order to allow the up-stream petrochemical industry to invest on the mainland.

Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Petrochemical Industry Association of Taiwan and Lee Chih-tsun, president of Formosa Plastics, Taiwan's plastics giant, along with eight other leaders of the petrochemical industry, called on Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi to make clear their appeal.

The industrial leaders asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to give a green light to the up-stream petrochemical industry to make investments on the mainland, accelerate the development of the seventh and eighth naphtha cracking plants, review the feasibility of rehabilitating the second naphtha cracking plant, and expedite the privatization of state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC).

Chen said the idea of liberalizing Taiwan's up-stream petrochemical industry to allow for Taiwan companies to relocate to mainland China to take advantage of cheap labor and land costs is a consideration based on a globalization strategy.

Taiwan is doomed to loose out to South Korean companies in the international field if ROC government authorities continue to adhere to the "No haste, be patient" policy of keeping a tight rein on Taiwanese investment in mainland China, warned Chen.

Despite the fact that Taiwan companies are still banned from investing in major infrastructure construction projects in mainland China, it was learned that the petrochemical industry has already acted faster than the government in moving to tap mainland possibilities.

Unconfirmed sources said the Formosa Plastics Group has chosen mainland China's southern port city of Ningbo as the location for its second naphtha cracking plant in an attempt to revive a long-moribund plan to develop a petrochemical complex in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 50.04 points to close at 7,974.65.

The bourse opened at 8,012.6, but due to profit-taking selling pressure and a lack of confidence on the part of investors, share prices began to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 8,082.07 and 7,962.05 during trading.

A total of 1.29 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.28 billion (US$2.01 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.63 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$82.76 billion.
Only one of the eight major categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up by 1 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.9 percent, electrical shares at 0.7 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.6 percent, cement shares at 0.4 percent, and construction stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 319 to 160, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Friday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved down 67 points to close at 8,000, with 3,256 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September decreased 75 points to finish at 8,020, with 654 contract transactions, while December futures fell 26 points to close at 8,089, with five contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 8,067 for August; 8,095 for September; 8,115 for December; 8,227 for next March; and 8,388 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
August TE futures moved down 2.8 points to close at 425.2, with 947 contract transactions, while September futures lost 3.6 points to close at 425.2 with 102 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
August TF futures decreased 5 points to close at 903, with 344 contract transactions, while September futures fell 3 points to finish at 905, with 50 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA KEEN ON EXPORTING MORE LNG, OIL TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Australia is keen on exporting its liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Taiwan and wants to boost its sales of coal, iron ore, and crude oil, while also welcoming investment from the island in its energy resources industry.
The Australian message was voiced on Thursday at the 7th Australia-Taiwan Joint Annual Energy and Mineral Trade, Investment and Cooperation Consultations now under way in Perth, Western Australia.

Twenty two representatives of the Australian government and of the LNG, coal, and iron ore industries are holding an annual meeting with ROC delegates from the Energy Commission (EC) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Chinese Petroleum Corporation, the Taiwan Power Company, and executives from the private sector.

Australian LNG producers and exporters expressed their strong desire to crack the LNG market in Taiwan, which has signed 20-year contracts each with Indonesia and Malaysia to import more than 4 million tons of LNG from the two countries per year.

Australian coal, iron ore, crude oil, and other resource industry officials also want to boost their exports to Taiwan, citing their reliability, adequate supplies, and competitive prices at extensive briefings given to potential Taiwanese buyers on the first day of the Perth meeting on Thursday.

In an interview with the CNA, EC Executive Secretary Chen Chao-yih said the ROC delegates also briefed Australian exporters on Taiwan's energy requirements and resources in order to give them a clearer picture of the island's economic development.
Chen said he told the Australian delegates that Taiwan's energy needs are forecast to nearly double by 2020.
He said Taiwan's LNG imports are expected to increase substantially over the next 20 years because of the island's gradual shift towards the use of clean fuel to generate electricity.
He said Taiwan is now one of the few countries in Asia capable of using LNG to generate its electricity, and Australian producers and exporters have begun to realize the market potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MAY ABANDON ANZUS TREATY IF AUSTRALIA DOESN'T BACK NMD

TEXT.P: The United States would abandon the ANZUS Treaty and close its facilities at Pine Gap in Northern Territory if Australia refused to host early warning facilities for a US National Missile Defense system, said Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Wednesday.

His warning was the clearest signal yet that Australia would have no choice but to allow the Pine Gap facilities to be used in any NMD system the US deployed, despite vociferous opposition by mainland China, which is worried that the system could further be developed into a Theater Missile Defense System that would include Japan, South Korea, and possibly Taiwan.

The mainland Chinese government is going to send its vice foreign minister to Australia early next week to personally voice Beijing's protest to any Australian support for the US NMD system, according to a report in The Australian Financial Review on Friday.
Downer's remarks, made in the context of an attack on the Australian Labor Party's policy, suggests an increasing Australian assertiveness towards mainland China based on its alliance with the US.
ANZUS is the defense backbone between the United States and its allies -- Australia and New Zealand.
China's Vice Foreign Minister Yang Jiechie is expected to raise the issue and lodge a protest when he leads a delegation for human right dialogue in Canberra next Tuesday, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLED LIVE HORSES NABBED IN KINMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Kinmen coastal patrol forces on Friday nabbed two live adult horses smuggled from mainland China and also the illegal owner of the animals.

Acting on a tip, members of the Kinmen Coastal Patrol (KCP) squad moved into a small tract of coastal forest in Anchi, northern Kinmen, during the small hours of Friday morning. There they discovered two live horses grazing. Before long, a man, later identified as Hsu Yuan-tsai, 51, appeared and tried to lead the horses away. The coastal guards arrested Hsu and his illicit belongings.
At the KCP headquarters, Hsu admitted to smuggling the animals from across the Taiwan Strait to make ends meets as his business has been suffering over the past year.

While Hsu will be handed over to the Kinmen District Prosecutors' Office for further questioning, the two horses will be sent to the Kinmen County Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine where they are likely to be put down for quarantine reasons, KCP sources said.

The smuggled horses will likely be dealt with squarely and quickly as Kinmen, located just 2.4 km off the mainland Chinese coast, is believed to be the entry point into Taiwan of the deadly O-strain virus that led to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) among Taiwan's cloven-hoofed animals last year, marking the most destructive livestock epidemic in Taiwan in 70 years.

Meanwhile, according to KCP Head Shih Ta-cheng, mainland Chinese citizens have become increasing daring and active in recent months, sailing to Kinmen to conduct "small scale" trade with the Kinmen locals.

This "small scale" trade activity is so easy and widespread that some Kinmen-based travel agencies have even incorporated it into their tourist itineraries for visitors from Taiwan. If a tourist is interested in taking a look at the illegal trade, the travel agency simply makes a phone call, and within half an hour, mainland fishing boats arrive at a predetermined spot where the tourists are not only entertained by watching the transactions, but can also make purchases of their own.

Over the past months, Kinmen coastal patrol forces have confiscated countless amounts of mainland-originating fish catch and agricultural products, including meat, wheat, rice, peanuts, and vegetables.
Shih said the squad's crack down on smuggling will not relent because the illicit activities have become increasingly prevalent.

He urged Kinmen civilians to refrain from continuing the illegal activities which only bring them a small amount of income at the expense of national security and the overall economic interests of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND POLICY UNDER OVERALL REVIEW: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is conducting an overall review of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, with regulations governing bilateral exchanges as the main screening focus, a senior official said on Friday.
MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the statement while meeting with a group of watchdog Control Yuan members who made an inspection tour of the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.
Tsai said mainland policy formulation is one of the greatest challenges faced by the new Republic of China government since its inauguration on May 20.
The international trade law expert-turned-policy planner said the MAC is trying to maintain policy continuity, but also hopes to make necessary policy adjustments to live up to public expectations.

Tsai said Premier Tang Fei called a meeting of senior financial and economic officials earlier this month to discuss current regulations governing trade and economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that both sides of the Taiwan Strait may be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) at the end of this year, Tsai said the ROC must review and adjust its existing trade regime, particularly measures related to cross-strait trade links to meet WTO requirements.

Tsai said no definite conclusions were reached at the meeting. Nevertheless, Tsai said, the MAC will continue consultations with other relevant government agencies and crank out suitable amendment proposals in the near future.
Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman Teng Chen-chung said the MAC is mulling whether to allow local banks to set up representative or liaison offices in mainland China.

"We are considering the issue in an open, favorable manner," Teng said, adding that representative offices can collect information and forge contacts, but are banned from operating money transfer or capital movement deals.
Teng said the ROC hopes mainland China can resume cross-strait dialogue to discuss issues related to further liberalization of bilateral trade, economic and financial exchanges for mutual benefits.
"We also look forward to seeing mainland China make a goodwill response if the ROC allows its banks to set up representative offices on the mainland in the near future," Teng said.

On new Central Bank of China Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng's proposal that the government levy a "national security tax" on Taiwanese investors in mainland China, Teng said the MAC currently has no such a plan. "The MAC doesn't see a need to collect the so-called 'national security tax' at the moment," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO FOCUS ON CROSS-STRAIT PEACE AT PROPOSED ROUNDTABLE MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), said on Thursday that the PFP will focus on the issues of cross-strait peace and political reforms at the proposed roundtable meeting of the heads of the three major political parties in Taiwan.

Soong, who arrived here on Thursday to attend the annual meeting of overseas Chinese residing in Europe, made the remarks while attending a luncheon given in his honor by overseas Chinese who support the PFP.

Soong, who stated the PFP puts the interests of the people above the party, said he is willing to help the minority ruling Democratic Progressive Party, adding that the PFP will take part in the roundtable meeting on national affairs to seek stability and prosperity for the people.
Soong garnered 36.8 percent of the vote in Taiwan's March 18 presidential election, second behind Chen Shui-bian's 39.3 percent of the DPP and ahead of KMT candidate Lien Chan's 23.1 percent.
Soong said that if he joins hands with KMT Chairman Lien Chan at the roundtable, this would mean that over 60 percent of Taiwan's voters were in favor of pursuing cross-strait peace.

He said that the cross-strait policy of the new government should not be rash because this could lead to social instability and possible military confrontation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
He said that the PFP will seek to join hands with the KMT on this issue in order to reflect the mainstream of society's thinking.
In addition, he said that the PFP will unite with the DPP, which will mean that 80 percent of Taiwan's voters aspire for political reforms.

Soong pointed to the kickback scandal in the government's purchase of French-made Lafayette vessels, adding that even the French government is investigating the matter and the new government should again ask the French government to provide it with information to probe the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH COMPANY TO INTRODUCE LATEST INCINERATOR TECHNOLOGY TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for an affiliate of France-based Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux announced on Thursday that her company will introduce the latest incinerator technology in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

The company recently won the tender to take charge of a large incinerator in Jenwu, Kaohsiung County, which will be capable of handling 440,000 tons of garbage per day. The company also plans to generate up to 27 megawatts of electricity per day using the heat produced by the incineration process.
The spokeswoman said the Jenwu incinerator will start operations in November and will adopt high environmental standards in its garbage-handling.
The company has sophisticated equipment and will use its rich experience and new management technology to turn the incinerator into the epitome of multi-purpose incinerators in Asia, she added.
Taiwan is preparing to build 26 multi-purpose incinerators to handle its increasing volume of garbage.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINES REJOICE OVER LAWSUIT VICTORY AGAINST CEMENT MAKER

TEXT.P: Rejoicing over a victory in a five-year lawsuit against a local cement manufacturer, members of two aboriginal activist groups on Friday called for aboriginal people around Taiwan to defend their ancestral lands.

At a public hearing convened by aboriginal legislator Pa Yen-Ta Lu, members of the Taroko Anti-Asia Cement Self-Saving Group and the Taiwan Aboriginal Ethnic Policy Association claimed triumphantly that "victory belongs to the determined."

According to Tien Chun-chou, president of the Taroko Anti-Asia Cement Self-Saving Group, Amis tribespeople in the eastern city of Hualien filed a lawsuit against Asia Cement more than five years ago, seeking redress for the cement makers' long-term usurpation of tribal land and illegal exploitation of soil zoned by the government specifically for aboriginal use.

The aboriginal activist group also brought a lawsuit against the Aboriginal Affairs Commission of Taiwan Province (AACTP), accusing the provincial authorities of possibly receiving kickbacks from the cement maker which resulted in the commission pressuring the aborigines to give up their homes and farmland in Hualien's Hsiulin Township.

Over the past five years, according to Tien, Asia Cement and the AACTP appealed against the aboriginal group on the grounds that Asia Cement was legally allowed to explore the eastern lands to make cement in accordance with government regulations.
On Thursday, more than five years after the lawsuits were filed, the Hualien District Court overturned an appeal by the AACTP, thereby handing victory to the Taroko group.

Analyzing the results, Yisak-Afu, chair of the Taiwan Aboriginal Ethnic Policy Association, said the case will serve as an example and a precedent, providing inspiration to other local aboriginal tribes on how to fight to secure their own interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR TRIBUTE TO POLITICAL VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said on Friday that she will suggest to President Chen Shui-bian that he invite the country's political victims to a tribute gathering on Dec. 10 -- international human rights day.

Lu, who is herself a political victim and who is currently the convenor of a national human rights consultation team, said that without the sacrifices of Taiwan's political victims, there would be no freedom in Taiwan today.
She made the remarks in a speech delivered at a literary camp in Kuantu, suburban Taipei, in which she also spoke of her aspirations to be a writer and her plans for the latter part of her life.
Lu said that after her retirement, she plans to write a novel, adding that she wrote a book when she was behind bars, using Taiwan society of thirty years ago as a background.
She said that she plans to use this book as the basis for a larger work when she retires or when she has some leisure time during her stint as vice president.
Lu also noted that the world will ring in the 21st century in just five months, and that before its arrival, "we should altogether end the guilt and mistakes of the 20th century."

She also said that before the last international human rights day of the 20th century, she wishes to form a national women's union, so that the next century will see gender equality with equal rights for men and women.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.016 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at NT$31.085.
The local currency opened at NT$31.065 and was traded between NT$31.064 and NT$31.089.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$251 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PUSHES DESALINIZATION PLANTS AS MEINUNG ALTERNATIVE

TEXT.P: The government has decided to use desalination plants to provide a water supply for southern Taiwan, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said on Friday.

The desalination plan was adopted as an alternative to the controversial Meinung reservoir plan that was shelved last week by President Chen Shui-bian following months of bitter protests by Meinung residents and environmental activists who were outraged at the plan to inundate one of the island's most pristine valleys.

The initial stage of the plan will see four desalination plants established on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, while feasibility studies will be conducted on the possibility of setting up further plants to provide water to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan and other industrial zones.
Lin said that the Meinung reservoir project will not be re-evaluated until after 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY MAYOR'S MAINLAND VISIT MUST BE IN LINE WITH REGULATIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Teng Chen-chung said on Friday that an application by Taipei Deputy Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsiung to visit mainland China will be considered favorably if it complies with government rules.

At a routine press conference at the MAC, Teng said that according to existing regulations governing bilateral exchanges with mainland China, Pai, as a political official, must submit an application to the Ministry of the Interior, where officials from the National Security Bureau, the Ministry of Justice and the MAC will jointly screen the application and decide on whether to grant him permission to visit the mainland.

Teng stressed that Pai's proposed visit will be handled in a manner equal to that accorded to Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who planned to visit southern mainland Chinese city of Xiamen in early July to bolster city-to-city exchanges. Hsieh's proposal was rejected because he made his application too close to his stated date of travel.

Teng added that it is hoped that besides being in line with government regulations, Pai's visit would also fully take into account the nation's dignity and the principle of equality in such an engagement.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has already approved Pai's proposal to visit Beijing and Shanghai between Sept. 4-13 to boost inter-city exchanges, particularly in the fields of metropolitan development, social welfare and cultural conservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO RAISE HUMAN RIGHTS ABUSES WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia plans to raise mainland Chinese human rights abuses, including its persecution of Tibetan prisoners, Falun Gong sect members, Christians and dissidents, when it holds a dialogue with mainland leaders early next week.

The Australian Financial Review on Thursday quoted a senior Australian official as revealing that Australia is gravely concerned about the mainland's continuing relentless crackdown on a range of dissidents.

His remarks suggested a growing Australian aggressiveness after four years of private human rights dialogue, which has racked up few direct and obvious achievements, although some individuals have been released after Australian representations and some mainland administrative procedures have been modified.

Next Wednesday's dialogue will take place in Canberra, with the mainland delegation to be headed by Vice Foreign Minister Yang Jiechie and the Australian mission to be led by Deputy Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Miles Kupa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD RETURN DIPLOMATIC GIFTS TO THE PUBLIC: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: An opposition legislator said on Friday that the president and former president should "return" to the public diplomatic gifts received while in office.

Shen Chih-hwei of the opposition People First Party made the remark at a press conference timed to coincide with President Chen Shui-bian's departure on Sunday for a tour of Central America and Africa.

She said that when Taiwan's president or government officials make visits to diplomatic allies abroad, they bring large amounts of money to assist those foreign countries, as well as give lavish gifts to foreign officials.

Shen pointed out that while these valuable presents are paid for with taxpayers' money, gifts given in return are divvied up between the president and his staff, which she described as yet another form of government corruption.
She further pointed out that because related laws only pertain to stocks and immovable property, the Control Yuan has no power to oversee who gets these gifts.
She said Chen should establish a museum for these diplomatic gifts, and added that she will make efforts to draw up legislation in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY AWARDS ROC TOP 10 OUTSTANDING YOUNG WOMEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China First Lady Wu Shu-chen on Friday awarded Taiwan's top 10 outstanding young women of the year, the 18th time the awards have been given.

Wu admired the 10 individuals as role models for today's modern women, pointing out that although the award recipients are not public figures like stars and politicians, their efforts have a big impact in all kinds of fields.

Their contributions were made, respectively, in the fields of medicine, biochemistry, language, physical education, broadcasting, electrical engineering, geophysics, social work, the judiciary, and public health.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEW AID PROGRAMS TO BE SEALED DURING PRESIDENT'S UPCOMING TRIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will not sign any new aid programs with any of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies during his upcoming overseas trip, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Friday.

Tien, who will accompany Chen on his Aug. 13-25 "journey of friendship," said the main purpose of the trip is to cement relations with the ROC's allies and display to the world Taiwan's democratic achievements and smooth transition of power between different political parties.
"President Chen is not expected to discuss any new economic aid programs with our allies during his first overseas trip as our head of state," Tien stressed.

The hectic 13-day journey will take Chen to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, and Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, as well as three West African countries -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

Tien said the president will take advantage of his visits to assure the six countries of his administration's determination to continue carrying out existing cooperative programs based on the existing foundations.

"If our allies present any new ideas or make any new aid requests, we'll take them back to Taipei for further evaluation and consultations with relevant government agencies," Tien said, adding: "At any rate, we will not make any aid promises, nor seal any aid projects during the journey."

Asked about his views of a press report claiming that the Nicaraguan foreign minister has publicly said he will ask the ROC to offer his country US$100 million in aid during Chen's visit, Tien said he was not sure whether he believed the report. "If the report were true, I would say that such remarks were inappropriate," he noted.
Tien said he would take advantage of the upcoming visit to explore the truth and hold further discussion with relevant Nicaraguan officials to clarify the ROC's stance on the issue.

Responding to opposition legislators' criticism of the timing of Chen's globe-trotting journey, Tien said the six-leg visit is of great significance as it will allow the president to demonstrate to the ROC allies his administration's sincerity in further strengthening bilateral friendship and cooperation.

Many opposition lawmakers have cast doubts on Chen's wisdom in undertaking a long overseas journey at a time when the public is losing confidence in his administration's ability to cope with the host of problems facing the country due to the recent Pachang Creek rescue bungle in which four people lost their lives.
Tien said the president's state visits had been arranged before the July 22 tragedy.
"If we cancel the trip in the wake of the Pachang incident, our international credibility will go bankrupt and our national image will also be at stake," Tien warned.
The minister further said Chen is highly concerned about domestic problems exposed by the Pachang incident, but he added that the Executive Yuan alone can address all those problems well.

Touching on mainland China's move to invite the ROC's African diplomatic allies to attend a Sino-African forum to be held in Beijing in October, Tien said the diplomatic tussle between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has a long history.

"We have full information about Beijing's plan since it unveiled the meeting schedule early this year. We have reached an understanding with all of our African allies concerning the issue. If any of our allies finally decide to attend the Beijing forum on the grounds of promoting regional development, they will certainly inform us in advance. And I believe that our allies will only dispatch low-echelon civil servants to attend the meeting," Tien said.
He further said the ROC will not pay an unreasonably exorbitant price to court an "unfaithful" friend or ally.
Due to Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, the ROC manages to maintain diplomatic ties with only 29 countries, most of which are located in Latin America and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAISING DEBT CEILING CAN RESOLVE FINANCIAL ISSUE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei broke his silence for the first time on Friday to stress that a moderate raising of the ceiling on public debt is a practical way to resolve the financial problems facing the government.

Tang made the remarks when responding to requests by Hualien County Magistrate Wang Ching-feng and Taichung City Mayor Chang Wen-ying for financial aid from the central government for local governments.

Tang pointed out that while the financial difficulties of local governments in Taiwan seem to stem from the central government's allocation of tax revenues, they are actually a problem of "the nation's financial allocation."

The financial allocation issue stems from the imbalance of expenditures and revenue. The government has not only spent a great deal on social welfare payments, but has also paid a lot for implementing educational and communications establishments. As a result, tax revenues cannot balance outgoing revenue, according to Tang.

He went on to say that public debt and the privatization of state-owned enterprises are the government's main financial resources. However, Taiwan is facing an economic transition in which traditional industries must upgrade their structure and productivity, while high-tech industries have to break through a bottleneck.
He added that tax increases will not be considered for the time being, and that therefore, a moderate rise in the ceiling of the public debt would be a better way to resolve the difficulty.
He also expressed hope that the ruling and opposition parties will reach a consensus on the modification of the debt ceiling after holding careful and detailed discussions.

Earlier in the day, Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said that if the current public debt ceiling can be raised from the existing 15 percent of the annual budget to 25 percent, it would help the government resolve the financial issue.
However, the opposition Kuomintang said it would adopt a conservative attitude toward Chang's proposal until next week, when the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan meets.
Vice Finance Minister Wang Teh-shan said that government revenues are expected to increase by NT$160 billion per year if the debt ceiling is readjusted to 25 percent.
Peng Shao-chin, chief of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP supports such a readjustment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO CRACK DOWN ON CREDIT CARD CRIME

TEXT.P: A group of bankers on Friday urged the Republic of China government to take effective measures to crack down on credit card crime to prevent the island from becoming an "Asia-Pacific financial crime center."
The bankers made the call at a public hearing on credit card crime, sponsored by opposition People First Party Legislator Chou Hsi-wei.

Senior executives from various local banks complained at the hearing that credit card crime is rampant in Taiwan, partly because punishments meted out in local courts according to ROC law are "too lenient."

They said even though their banks have taken many precautionary and preventive measures, credit card crime is still increasing rapidly in Taiwan. They pointed out that credit card-related criminal activities will cost them, and a result the banking public, more than NT$2 billion (US$64.52 million) this year.
"This amount will greatly exceed the figure recorded in Japan, thus giving Taiwan the dubious distinction of being the most notorious credit card crime country in Asia," a bank executive claimed.

He said the most worrisome development is that organized crime is moving into credit card crime in Taiwan. "The involvement of gang syndicates has made it even more difficult to curb credit card crime," he warned.

Another bank executive said the most serious credit card crime is when a criminal steals encoded credit card information and uses the data to make a copy card. "There is no easy way to discern problems with those copycards," he noted.
In some cases, he said, gangsters pretend themselves to be bank employees to swindle out victims' personal data for credit card forgery purposes.

Legislator Chou displayed an advertisement in a local newspaper saying that forged credit cards are available at NT$30,000 apiece. "The advertisement indicates how devilish local credit card forgery rings are," he lamented.
Chou said the maximum prison term for credit card forgery is five years in Taiwan, horter than Hong Kong's seven years, Malaysia's 20 years, and America's 10 years.

Noting that lenient punishments can't effectively deter credit card crime in this high-tech world, Chou said he is drafting an amendment bill to the current law to impose harsher penalities on credit card convicts. "I hope the bill can be passed in the next parliamentary sesion," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN YOUNGSTERS URGED TO SUPPORT KILLER WHALE'S RELEASE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By K.Pan and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: In an attempt to foster children's love of nature, a local educational foundation on Friday urged Taiwan's youngsters to support the release of the famous killer whale Keiko.
The King Car Education Foundation suggested that local young people surf related websites to get more information about Keiko's release, and to become Keiko's friends.

The killer whale Keiko, captured in waters off Iceland at 2 years old, was trained to perform at sea parks in Canada and Mexico. In 1992, the film "Free Willy," produced by Warner Bros. Studios, made the animal internationally famous. Now Keiko has completed his third film.
The Ocean Futures Society and some other environmental protection organizations plan to release Keiko when a documentary film about the whale has been completed.
Morgan Sun, director general of the King Car Education Foundation, said the time for Keiko's release to the open sea depends on when he can be received by his fellow whales.

Sun revealed that Keiko has recently been swimming in the ocean while guided by trainers aboard ships, and has had "talks" with other whales. The researchers have made detailed recordings of their noises.
The Chinese Press for Children will publish eight special articles about Keiko's recent news and people interested in the whale are welcome to visit the website -- www.mdnkids.com.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL JOURNALISTS RECEIVE NEWS AWARDS

TEXT.P: The 26th annual Tseng Hsu-pai Journalism Awards were handed out on Friday to Taiwan writers, reporters, and photojournalists in recognition of their professional excellence and their contributions to public service.

Termed "Taiwan's Pulitzer" by respected local journalism pioneer Ouyang Chun, this year's coveted Tseng Hsu-pai Journalism Academic Award went to Fang Peng-cheng, an official of the Straits Exchange Foundation, a quasi-official organization that handles communications with mainland China. Fang's award-winning entry was his new book called "Kueiku Tzu: The Art of Persuasion and Negotiation."

Fang, a former correspondent for the Central News Agency, systematically applied an ancient Chinese philosopher's teachings and writings to persuasion and negotiation under the broader perspective of mass communication theory. The panel of judges credited the work with advancing the "sinolization" of local mass communication studies.

The Tseng Hsu-pai Journalism Awards were established in 1975 to promote professionalism and public service in the domestic journalism community. This year's awards ceremony was held in the conference room of the CNA headquarters in Taipei.

Hsu Chia-shih, a noted journalism scholar and a member of the judging panel, told the recipients of the awards to be proud of their accomplishments not only for the excellence of the works themselves, but also for the impact their works have made in society -- an important criteria in the judging process, he added.

As if to drive home his point, three news teams received their respective awards for providing comprehensive and nonstop coverage of last year's devastating Sept. 21 temblor. It was the strongest earthquake to hit Taiwan in almost 100 years, and about 2,400 people were killed.

A team of United Daily News (UDN) columnists won the Public Service Newspaper Commentary Award for their in-depth analysis of the various issues that surfaced in the wake of the earthquake, such as flaws in some public construction that led to the collapse of buildings, and the government's responses.
Another UDN team of photographers took the Public Service Newspaper Photography Award for capturing the disaster relief efforts on camera and sharing them with the anxious Taiwan public.
The third team, of the Min Sheng Daily, received the Public Service Newspaper Reports Award for focusing on useful rescue and medical information during the same disaster.
An investigative study into the problems of radioactive building materials landed a Chinese Television System reporting team the Public Service Television News Report Award.
The Broadcasting Corporation of China's Ilan County Station reporting team won the Public Service Radio Broadcasting News Report Award for a series of reports on the plight of an ancient forest.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND SETS ASIDE BUDGET FOR IDF UPGRADING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has earmarked NT$1 billion (US$32.26 million) in its budget plan for fiscal 2001 for the upgrading of the locally built Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters (IDFs), a senior official said on Friday.

Deputy Defense Minister Sun Tao-yu made the statement at a hearing on the future of the IDFs, sponsored by a group of legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang.
Sun said there is still ample room for the upgrading of the IDF performance by improving avionics firing system and weaponry systems installed in the warplane.
