Despite its limited budget, Sun said, the MND still has set aside NT$1 billion in its fiscal 2001 budget plan for commissioning state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) to further upgrade the IDF performance.
AIDC, the ROC's only aircraft manufacturer, is expected to finalize an IDF upgrading plan by the end of this year, Sun said.

AIDC was originally the aircraft manufacturing arm of the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), but it was restructured into a corporation under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Economic Affairs a few years ago as part of the government's plan to boost the island's aviation industry development.

The ROC Air Force originally planned to purchase 250 IDFs from AIDC, but cut its order to 130 after it managed to buy 150 US-made F-16 jet fighters and 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters. These three types of jet fighters now form the backbone of the ROC's second-generation air fleet.

In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, President Chen Shui-bian said last month that the Air Force should begin preparation for acquiring a new generation of warplanes to beef up its air defense capability.

Sun reported at the hearing that the MND has formed a special task force to make a preliminary study of the possibility of developing a third generation of warplanes at home or shopping for suitable one abroad.

Most lawmakers present at the hearing said they hope the MND can commission CIST, AIDC and its satellite plants to develop a new generation of aircraft for the Air Force in line with the government's self-sufficiency defense policy.
In response, Sun said the MND task force will make an overall evaluation of technological requirements and cost efficiency and other related factors before making a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL ORDER, CLEAN POLITICS TOP CONCERNS FOR TAIWAN PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Improving social order and rooting out corruption are the top concerns for people living in Taiwan, according to the results of a recent survey released on Friday.

The poll taken by the Interior Ministry found that as many as 91.5 percent of Taiwan's public said that the top public security issue facing the government is improving the island's social order, while 64.3 percent of the public voiced a desire for greater government security inspection of public facilities.

In the field of government efficiency, 73.7 percent of respondents said the government should accelerate its pace in stamping out corruption, while 58.4 percent said the government should further improve its administrative efficiency to provide better services to the public.

At the same time, 44.6 percent of Taiwan residents think that the government should take effective measures to improve Taiwan's election system and get rid of irregularities in all levels of elections, according to the survey.

In other aspects of daily life, about 90 percent of Taiwan people are satisfied with their marriage and relations with their children, the poll found. Some 34 percent expressed the hope that they would have a secure life in their old age through social welfare programs and pension subsidies, according to the results.

Regarding issues related to the government's performance in the relief operations following the Sept. 21 earthquake last year, 67 percent of the public contended that private religious and charity groups have done the most in relief operations, ahead of 41 percent who said they are satisfied with the government's performance in providing assistance to earthquake victims, the poll found.
The survey was conducted by the Interior Ministry in May, and covered a total of 4,070 Taiwan residents over 20 years of age.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S U-LAND AIRLINES FLIGHT ROUTES REVOKED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Friday revoked the flight routes of U-Land Airlines and ordered the domestic company to resolve its safety and financial problems within six months or lose its company license as well.

CAA Director-General Chang You-heng said that U-Land has failed to improve its safety and financial problems since the CAA suspended its operations two months ago. He added that U-Land still does not meet the necessary related aviation regulations and can no longer meet the most basic requirements of a civilian air transport firm.

U-Land Chief Executive Officer Chou Chi-ruey said at a press conference that his company will suspend its operations for one month starting Monday, but that it will appeal the CAA decision. "Not one point fails to meet aviation safety requirements," Chou said of his firm.
Chou added that his company's financial problems have already been "put back in order," and that he is not sure why the CAA still believes U-Land is still in the midst of financial troubles.

The CAA first noticed U-Land's financial problems at the end of 1998, Chang said, adding that the suspension of the company's flights will not have too much of an effect on the public because U-Land only offered a limited number of flights on three routes -- Taipei-Kaohsiung, Taipei-Kinmen, and Kaohsiung-Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI COMPLETES 100TH OVERSEAS BONE MARROW TRANSPLANT SURGERY
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: Tzu Chi Medical Center on Friday announced the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied the bone marrow for transplant operations.

The 99th overseas bone marrow recipient is a 30-year-old female patient at Shanghai's Ruijin Hospital, while the 100th recipient is an 18-year-old male patient at Zhejiang Medical University Hospital.
The donated marrow was delivered to Shanghai and Zhejiang on Friday by Tzu Chi volunteers.

The Tzu Chi Foundation's bone marrow databank was established by Master Chen-yen in October, 1993. The databank has supplied the marrow for a total of 198 such operations, including the 100 overseas transplants.

The Tzu Chi bone marrow donation center was the third such organization in the world, following the establishment of similar institutions in Europe and the United States. It forecasted that the total number of potential bone marrow donors in its databank will hit 200,000 this October.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN UNVEILS 5 QUAKE-ZONE RECONSTRUCTION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Friday announced five new programs for speeding up reconstruction of the central Taiwan areas hit by the 921 earthquake.

Chen, who will leave Taiwan on Sunday for his first overseas trip since taking office on May 20, made the announcement during an inspection tour of the central county of Nantou which took the brunt of the 7.6-magnitude earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21 last year.
Chen first inspected a bridge reconstruction project in Nantou County. The bridge, which linked the mountain township of Mingchien to the outside world, was seriously damaged in the 921 earthquake.

Chen said one of his major concerns before his departure for his Aug. 13-25 overseas trip was the earthquake zone reconstruction work. "Therefore, I took time out of my hectic schedule to visit the area to see for myself the progress in the reconstruction project."

Chen urged the Nantou County Government, the Cabinet-level Post-Earthquake Reconstruction Commission and other relevant government agencies to coordinate and cooperate closely to facilitate reconstruction work.

"We need team spirit and concerted efforts to carry out the daunting reconstruction task. If relevant government agencies cannot shed parochial mindset and bureaucratic thinking, reconstruction work cannot proceed smoothly and completion of all relevant projects will be nowhere in sight," Chen noted.

The president then announced five new measures designed to speed up quake-zone reconstruction. First of all, the government will offer additional low-interest loans to help earthquake victims rebuild their houses; those whose homes were partially destroyed in the quake will be given another one-year grace period for interest payments for their original housing loans; and the government will also raise a NT$2 billion fund for quake-zone business loans guarantee.
Second, the government will offer loans and subsidies for developing new residential communities and new townships, promoting rural development and urban renewal.
Third, the government will raise a NT$10 billion fund in the next three years for mudslide prevention projects in the earthquake zone.
Four, the government will push for the completion of repair work for five major roads linking tourist attractions in Nantou County to the outside world before April 2001.
Five, the government will build a roving medical service network within the next six months for all Nantou County villages that still do not have any hospital or clinic.

Chen told a group of legislators from both ruling and opposition parties accompanying him on the inspection tour that the government is drafting a special three-year budget plan for quake zone reconstruction projects. "I hope all lawmakers of different political colors could support the budget plan to facilitate completion of major reconstruction programs in the next three years," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CADETS ENROLL IN US MILITARY ACADEMIES

TEXT.P: Three cadets of the Republic of China Army, Naval, and Air Force Academies have completed their basic training at the US Military Academy at West Point, the US Naval Academy, and the US Air Force Academy, respectively.

An ROC Defense Ministry official confirmed on Friday that army cadet Lee Wu-ling, navy cadet Tan Tzu-wei, and air force cadet Chang Chi-rong are the first ROC exchange students ever to be accepted into the prestigious US military academies.
The official added that President Chen Shui-bian had received the three cadets in June prior to their departure and urged them to stand tall as all men should, even in the face of adversity.

Lee, Tan, and Chang are the only exchange students at the respective US military academies from a country that does not maintain official diplomatic relations with the United States, and their enrollment is seen as a breakthrough in ROC-US military ties. Enrollment records from the three academies reveal that no cadets from mainland China are currently studying there.

Lee is one of only eight foreign students out of over 1,000 cadets at West Point, while Tan sailed over some 200 applicants to become one of only 10 foreign exchange students at the US Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland.

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH TV MAKER SETS UP PLANT IN YUNLIN
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, central Taiwan, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan-based maker of plasma televisions has set up a production plant in Yunlin County, central Taiwan.
Lee Tsung-chang, chairman of Ruey Long Technology Co., said on Friday that his company, in conjunction with US firm Vitek Displays, will jointly produce the advanced television in the Yunlin plant.
According to Lee, his company was set up in April this year, and has poured some NT$300 million into the first stage of the establishment of the Yunlin plant.
Lee made the remarks while paying a visit to Yunlin County chief Chang Jung-wei in the company of Vitek Displays President Craig Schreiber to supply details on the investment project to Chang.

He further said that a total of NT$10 billion will be channeled into the plant to manufacture hi-tech home appliances, including plasma televisions, liquid crystal displays and digital projectors. Chang, a Yunlin native, said that he was setting an example for other Yunlin-born people to give something back to their hometown.

Plasma televisions are expected to become mainstream consumer electronics products over the coming five years, and Lee predicted that business volume is expected to reach NT$3.5 billion for the first year of full production after construction of the plant is completed at the end of next year. He added that sales are expected to exceed NT$10 billion during the second year of production.

Chang expressed his appreciation of Lee's decision to set up the plant in Yunlin, and promised to provide all necessary assistance as a token of the central Taiwan county's strong desire for investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX DPP HEAD CRITICIZES CHEN ADMINISTRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By James Kuo & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party Former Chairman Shih Ming-teh on Friday fiercely criticized President Chen Shui-bian's administration and described the Chen administration as a "clean and dirty" one which merely co-governs.
Shih suggested that President Chen return to the basis of the national constitution as soon as possible so as to resolve difficulties resulting from the current constitutional controversy.
President Chen, who has advocated the concept of "government for all people" to substitute for party politics, has caused a lot of difficulties which the new government has to resolve, Shih went on.

He pointed out that DPP does not hold a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan, and needs the cooperation of opposition parties when introducing any new policy or bill into the Legislative Yuan. Without such cooperation, he said, any bill will be killed or modified before the Legislative Yuan begins deliberating on it.
Consequently, President Chen's concept of "clean" ruling would demote his administration and transform it into one that is jointly controlled by "the clean and the dirty," Shih said.
Shih made these remarks in Berlin when addressing the 26th meeting of Overseas Chinese Associations in Europe.
High-ranking government officials and civic leaders, including Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi and Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, attended the meeting.

Later on the same day, Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said that the OCAC will provide services to all overseas Chinese who hold Republic of China passports, no matter their age or when they emigrated.
President Chen also sent a televised congratulatory message to the meeting, which was attended by more than 900 overseas Chinese community leaders in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE CHINESE JOURNALISTS SACKED FOR MAKING MISTAKE

TEXT.P: Three journalists of a Chinese TV station have been sacked because a scene of confrontation in the 1989 Tiananmen incident appeared for about two seconds in a background display of news on July 9.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Friday that Lin Shufu, director of the news department of Zhuhai TV Station in southeastern Guangdong province, has been dismissed for making the mistake. Two editors of the department have also been removed from their jobs.
At least hundreds of demonstrators were killed by Chinese troops in the pro-democracy incident on June 4, 1989. The Chinese government doesn't want anybody to mention it any more.
Propaganda authorities of the Guangdong provincial government took the mistake very seriously, and wanted to punish all those responsible for it, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Japan puts an end to 'zero interest' era as part of its economic reform plan.
The China Times:
Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Chen Yao offers to resign.
The United Daily News:
President Chen invites Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Kuang Yew to visit Taiwan in September.
The Liberty Times:
The new ROC government will pool private resources in carrying out foreign aid programs.
The China Post:
KMT comes out against lifting ceiling on debt.
The Taiwan News:
President Chen won't discuss new aid, says Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao.
The Taipei Times:
Scholar unveils Taiwanese dictionary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 12, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, American film director, is born. He is legendary for large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four-cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of an illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non-aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing and injuring a total of 31 people.
1971: Syria severs diplomatic relations with Jordan after a conflict between the government and Palestinian guerrillas.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tienanmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES PLANE CRASH REPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Saturday that no signs of a plane crash have been found off Taiwan's northeastern coast.
The ministry was responding to a report that a military aircraft crashed into the sea off Tungao in the northeastern Taiwan county of Ilan Saturday morning.

The MND said it had contacted the Air Force combat command center, the combat control radar station and the newly formed national emergency rescue command center for information about the crash report.

"Our inquiries have proved that the report was speculation and couldn't be substantiated by any concrete signs," an MND spokesman said, adding that all the three agencies had not found any signs showing an offshore plane crash.
The Ilan County Government's fire department said it received a report from a local citizen at 9:50 a.m. saying that he had seen a military plane crash into waters off Tungao.

The Ilan fire department immediately contacted the Navy's Chungcheng base nearby. However, the naval base authority told the fire department that there was not any military or commercial airliner flying past the Ilan area during the period around the reported time.

Acting on the Ilan fire department notice, the airborne police squadron and the naval patrol unit also sent a helicopter and patrol ships, respectively, to search for signs of the reported mishap. Neither unit found any signs and they also confirmed that no aircraft flew over the Ilan skies during the period.

Even before the MND contacted the national emergency rescue command center, the center had received a notice from the Ilan fire department. The center then approached the military information service unit and civil aviation authority to check the flight situation in the Ilan area. Both units said all military and civilian planes were flying normally and that no plane crash had been detected off the Ilan coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX DPP HEAD RECOVERS FROM OVEREXERTION
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A former chairman of the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party was released from the hospital on Friday after recovering from a dizzy spell that doctors said was caused by high blood pressure stemming from travel fatigue.
Shih Ming-teh, now a legislator, was in Berlin to give a speech to the 900-some guests in attendance at the 26th annual conference of the Overseas Chinese Associations in Europe.
Shih, who fiercely criticized ROC President Chen Shui-bian's administration during his speech, had to end it abruptly when he apparently became overly agitated and could not continue.

He was later diagnosed at a nearby hospital as having blood pressure as high as 190/118. However, Shih said that he called his doctor in Taiwan who said he didn't think it was a stroke but merely the symptoms of fatigue due to long travels.
In his speech, Shih said that Chen's "government of all people" -- as a substitute for party politics -- has caused numerous difficulties for the new administration.

He pointed out that the ruling party does not hold a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan where Shih is a lawmaker, and needs the cooperation of opposition parties when introducing any new policies or bills. Without such cooperation, he said, any bill would be killed or modified before the Legislative Yuan began deliberating on it.
Consequently, Chen's concept of "clean" rule would reduce his administration into one that is jointly controlled by "the clean and the dirty," Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO POPULARLY ELECT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh on Saturday urged mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between Taiwan and the mainland's political systems and public opinions.

Hsieh, who concurrently serves as Kaohsiung mayor, made his remarks in response to press reports that the annual meeting of mainland China's leaders at Beidaihe yielded a consensus that the future development of cross-strait relations will depend on the Taiwan public.

Hsieh, whose party sent Chen Shui-bian to the Presidential Office in the March 18 election, said that any political party or figure in a democratic system must first persuade the people before making any major changes.
He went on to say that if Beijing wants to change how the Taiwan public feels about mainland China, then improvements in the political system and bilateral exchanges will be necessary.

As an example of possible changes to the political system, Hsieh said that if mainland China can produce a popularly elected president, then it will go a long way toward improving bilateral interactions.

As to whether the DPP's attitude is shifting from a pro-independence to a "one China" stance, Hsieh noted that no political party's platform can successfully go against public opinion, so a party is continuously developing according to the wishes of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, AUSTRALIA TO COOPERATE IN ENERGY EXPLORATION

TEXT.P: Delegates to the 7th Australia-Taiwan Joint Annual Energy, Mineral Trade, Investment and Cooperation Consultations pledged on Friday at the end of a two-day meeting in Perth to cooperate more closely on coal mining and oil exploration to broaden trade and investment between the two nations.

In an interview with the CNA on Saturday, Taiwan's chief delegate Chen Chao-yih said this year's conference, with its zealous discussions on the mining of coal and offshore oil exploration in Western Australia and Northern Territory, marked the beginning of a new era of trade between the two nations.

"The Australian delegates expressed their strong desire to welcome their Taiwanese counterparts to invest in coal mining and oil exploration so that both sides can benefit from such cooperation," Chen said.

He said there are lots of opportunities for both sides in trade and investment that are waiting to be exploited, and delegates from the two countries have expressed a strong desire to cooperate with each other.

Chen said the Taiwan delegates on Friday visited the Australian Center of Renewable Energy at the Murdoch University in Perth where they saw demonstrations on the use of solar power and wind power to generate electricity.
The Taiwan delegates will visit liquefied natural gas mines in Western Australia on Saturday before winding up their trip and returning to Taipei on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WELCOMES LEE KUAN YEW'S VISIT PLAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian welcomes Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's plan to visit the Republic of China, a Presidential Office source said on Saturday.
The source was responding to a newspaper report that the prominent former Singapore prime minister is scheduled to visit Taiwan in late September at the invitation of President Chen.

Commenting on the report, one of Chen's aides said as Lee has expressed an interest in visiting Taiwan, President Chen is indeed planning to invite the respected architect of independent Singapore to Taiwan.
Nevertheless, the aide said details of the tour, including the schedule, have yet to be cranked out.

Chen has made no secret of his admiration for Lee's achievements in making Singapore one of the world's most competitive economic powerhouses. During his 1994-1998 stint as Taipei mayor, Chen made four visits to the Southeast Asian city state. On each of his Singapore visits during that period, he met with Lee for wide-ranging talks.

Lee has maintained close relations with the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. He was reportedly to be instrumental in pushing for a historic meeting between top envoys from Taipei and Beijing in Singapore in April 1993.

But Lee has gradually suspended his mediatory role in recent years due to his different views with former ROC President Lee Teng-hui on cross-strait relations and basic political concepts. He last visited Taipei in 1994.

During his visit to Beijing in June this year, Lee reportedly exchanged views with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji on the development of cross-strait relations after the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in Taiwan.
After his Beijing visit, Lee has on several occasions urged Taiwan and mainland China to resume talks this year, saying it would be dangerous to drag out the current stalemate.
Taipei's United Daily News said in a front-page report on Saturday that Lee is likely to visit Taipei late next month to assist with future cross-strait talks.

President Chen's aide said it's too early to talk about whether Lee would resume his intermediary role in cross-strait engagement. Moreover, the aide said, Lee's Taiwan visit is still on the drawing board as no details have so far been worked out.

Relations across the Taiwan Strait soured after former President Lee described cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station in July last year.

Lee's remarks were deemed by Beijing to be a departure from the "one China" principle, and Beijing launched military exercises along the southeastern mainland coast to intimidate the island. The PRC considers Taiwan to be part of its territory and has vowed to use force against the island if Taipei was to declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM CHAIRMAN CHEN YAO DETERMINED TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Chen Yao, the chairman of state-owned Chunghwa Telecom, on Saturday voiced his determination to resign from his post for personal and medical reasons, leaving the company to complete its privatization plans under his yet-unnamed successor.

At a press conference held a day after the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) confirmed Chen's resignation request, Chen urged the employees of Chunghwa Telecom to throw their support behind the company's privatization project, which is soon to move into the actual stock release phase.

Chen said that his resignation should not affect the company's ongoing plans and that he will continue to supervise the privatization project until the Minister of Transportation and Communication approves his resignation.
He also urged the employees to cancel their trade union's plans to stage a street protest on Wednesday against what they say is the overpricing of more than 289 million shares.

Chen, 66, said that he has been taking medicine to keep his high blood pressure at bay over the past year and that his three children are all abroad. After Chunghwa Telecom Vice President Lin Feng-cheng fell to his death from Lin's office at the company's headquarters in an apparent suicide, Chen said he has come to believe that indeed nothing is constant in life.

Chen, whose first job was at Chunghwa Telecom, added that the company is right on the edge of privatization, so he asked for support from all quarters to ensure the future development of the enterprise.

He went on to say that privatization is an international trend but that much remains to be done and that the rights of the employees must be given consideration. Talent abounds in the industry, so he said that after he leaves, "tomorrow will be even better than today."

The MOTC on Aug. 4 approved a plan to auction off 3 percent of the government's stake in Chunghwa Telecom within two weeks. The offered price for each of the shares up for grabs was set at NT$104 (US$3.35) on Aug. 4 by a share price appraisal committee comprised of government officials.
The price provoked anger among Chunghwa Telecom employees, who said the price is much higher than the NT$60 passed by the legislature earlier in the year and makes it difficult for them to afford.

The auction in late August is part of the first phase of a privatization plan in which a total of 33 percent of the government's shares in Chunghwa Telecom will be sold off. It is expected that the auction will augment government coffers by at least NT$30 billion.

During the first phase of privatization, the government will also release 13 percent of the shares for public subscription in Taiwan, 5 percent for company employees' subscription, and 12 percent for listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

The first phase of privatization is expected to be completed by the end of this year. The government plans to release another 33 percent of its shares in February next year, with a goal of complete privatization by the end of June.

The two phases of privatization are expected to raise at least NT$660 billion for the government. At present, Chunghwa Telecom is owned entirely by the MOTC and has capital assets totaling NT$96.48 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HELPS YOUTHS FROM POOR, WAR-STRICKEN COUNTRIES TO JOIN CELEBRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Fang Pei-ching and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has subsidized youths from poor and war-stricken countries to take part in the 15th World Youth Day, part of the Catholic Church's 2000th jubilee celebration.
The 15th World Youth Day celebration will be held at Tor Vergata University in Rome. The number of youths who will attend the celebration has been forecast at around 1.5 million.

Pope John Paul II called on each participating member of countries being represented at the celebration to donate US$10 to aid youths from poor countries to attend. The Embassy of the Republic of China in the Vatican City responded by donating US$3,000.

Meanwhile, the number of participants from Taiwan will top 400. ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Ramond R.M. Tai will head to the celebration to meet Taiwan's youth representatives as they arrive in the Vatican.
According to sources, 158 countries and regions, including South and North Korea, were invited to send representatives to this celebration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REMAINS UNDECIDED ABOUT NUC POST

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Saturday denied a newspaper report that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to serve as chairman of the National Unification Council (NUC).

Deputy Secretary-General to the President Eugene Chien made the denial in response to a China Times report that President Chen agreed to head the NUC after consultations with former President Lee Teng-hui.

The Chinese-language Taipei daily said Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), originally planned to invite a Kuomintang heavyweight to head the NUC, an advisory board founded by the previous KMT-led government to provide the president with counseling services concerning the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait and the promotion of eventual cross-strait unification under freedom and democracy.

According to the paper, the KMT heavyweight had discussed Chen's offer with former President Lee, also a former KMT chairman, and incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan. Both Lee and Lien reportedly gave a thumbs-down to Chen's proposal because they thought that the Chen-proposed arrangement would downgrade the NUC's status.

During the KMT era, Lee himself served as the NUC chairman. The China Times said Lee was afraid that if Chen refuses to serve as NUC chairman and instead names a KMT politician to head the council, the already shaky cross-strait ties may become even worse.

According to the paper, Chen has been reluctant to take over the top NUC post as he frets that such a move may draw a backlash from pro-independence DPP members. But the paper said Chen is likely to assume the NUC chairmanship after a recent meeting with Lee on the issue.
Commenting on the report, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Eugene Chien said the report was speculation, adding that no decision has been made since the NUC has not discussed the issue.

Chien said it remains uncertain how the NUC will operate in the future. He further said the NUC will not convene until after the newly formed cross-party task force on cross-strait relations begins operations later this month.

President Chen has appointed Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel Prize-winning chemist, to head the cross-party task force designed to forge a national consensus on future cross-strait ties.
The task force, composed of 25 members from across the political and social spectrum, is expected to provide advice and research findings to President Chen on cross-strait ties-related affairs.

Lee, who unveiled a list of 25 panel members last weekend, said he is convinced that the panel will be able to achieve concrete work results in one year or two to help improve cross-strait relations and maintain lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA ENCOURAGING FORMATION OF PRIVATE DESALINATION PLANTS

TEXT.P: Officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced on Saturday they are encouraging private industries to build desalination plants to supply water to the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

The desalination plan was adopted as an alternative to the controversial Meinung reservoir plan that was shelved last week by President Chen Shui-bian. The new plan, which will be established along the southwestern Taiwan coast, will cost NT$3 billion (US$96.77 million) and will supply 30,000 tons of water per day when completed.

Officials forecast that by 2006, the Tainan region's total water demand will hit 224,200 tons per day, including 73,800 tons required by the Tainan park, 57,700 tons by the Tainan Industrial Zone, 4,000 tons by the Dongshi industrial zone, and the water needs of southern Taiwan residents.
Officials added that the success of the Penghu area's desalination plants provide an example of the effectiveness of such a plan.

The MOEA calculated that if the government's desalination plan is put into practice along the western coast of Taiwan, it will provide 138,000 tons of water per day to Tainan Park, Changpin Industrial District, the Yunlin area, and the biotechnology park in Chunan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR VISITS ATLANTA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Shen Shu-hung, director of the Taipei City Hall's Bureau of Environmental Protection, arrived in Atlanta on Saturday to visit Cobb County's garbage disposal plant.

Low Kennebeck, the director assistant, introduced the garbage disposal plant to the two officials from the Republic of China. In Atlanta, garbage is disposed of by using natural decomposition and a sun-dried process.

Forty to 50 percent of the county's garbage can be delivered to burying plants to be converted to surface soil or compost. Kennebeck added that Cobb County only recieves family garbage, more than 300 tons per day. There are no service charges because Cobb County subsidizes the service.

Ma said the United States has no incinerators. Most grabage can be buried because of the country's huge territory. He added that although Alanta's garbage disposal system doesn't fit Taipei City's requirements, its compost disposal technique is worth imitating.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC HEAD SAYS LEFT-WING OVERSEAS CHINESE TRYING TO SOW DISCORD
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chang Fu-mei said here on Friday that left-wing overseas Chinese groups are using the controversy created by her earlier remarks as an opportunity to sow discord among overseas Chinese communities in the United States.

Chang, who flew into San Francisco on Friday night from Berlin where she attended the 26th meeting of Overseas Chinese community leaders in Europe, also said that nothing will come of the remarks calling for overseas Chinese to be classified into three separate groups.

Chang made remarks several months ago prior to assuming the chair of the OCAC to the effect that service provided by the OCAC to overseas Chinese should be in accordance with a priority system based on the three different classifications of overseas Chinese. The comments invited strong criticism from traditional overseas Chinese communities throughout the United States.

The Chinese Confederation in San Francisco, which is regarded as the headquarters of the overseas Chinese communities in San Francisco, boycotted her until the eve of her arrival on Friday. However, Tseng Jung-yao, board chairman of the confederation, was not present at the airport to greet Chang upon her arrival, giving as a reason that he was going out of town at the time.

Chang told the CNA that she will attend the opening of the 16th Overseas Chinese in North America Athletics competition on Saturday in San Francisco. She will also call on the Chinese Confederation and other overseas Chinese organizations in the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO LEAVE FOR FIRST OVERSEAS VISIT ON SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, accompanied by a large entourage and members of the media, is scheduled to leave here on Sunday for Los Angeles to conduct his first state visits to the ROC's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean, Central America, and Africa since assuming office on May 20.

Officials accompanying President Chen on the trip will include Secretary-General of the National Security Council Adm. (Retired) Chuang Ming-yao, Foreign Minister Tien Hong-mao, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih, and Chairman of the Council of Agriculture Chen Hsi-huan.

Thirteen ROC heavy-weight entrepreneurs, including Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce; Lin Kun-chung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries; Wang You-tseng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China; and others will also accompany Chen.
Four legislators and a 53-member media contingent will also travel along with President Chen.

A spokesman for the Presidential Office said that a score of senior officials and foreign envoys stationed in the ROC will see President Chen off at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on Sunday evening.
Touching on the purpose of Chen's upcoming overseas trip, the spokesman said it is to demonstrate the nation's sovereignty and to further enhance relations between the ROC and its diplomatic allies.

Despite the fact that Chen's overnight stop in Los Angeles is meant to be of a low profile nature, The Los Angeles Time quoted a source close to members of the US House of Representative as revealing that a score of House members will meet with the ROC president in Los Angeles on Sunday.

President Chen and his entourage will leave Los Angeles on Monday for Santo Domingo, where President Chen will attend the inaugural ceremony of President-elect Hipolito Mejia of the Dominican Republic on Wednesday.
According to the ROC envoy in Santo Domingo Adolfo Sun, President Chen will sit in the first seat of the first row during the ceremony to be attended by more than 20 heads of state.

Presidents from Costa Rica, Honduras, Nicaragua, Haiti, Belize, Guatemala, Panama, Saint Christopher and Nevis, the Commonwealth of Dominica, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines will also attend the inauguration ceremony.

Chen's trip, being dubbed "the supra continental diplomatic and democratic trip," will also take the ROC president to Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Gambia , Burkina Faso, and Chad before he returns to Taipei on Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY MEETS TOP US NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's new representative to the United States, Chen Chien-jen, has met with White House National Security Adviser Sandy Berger, reliable sources said on Friday.

Sources said Berger held a secret meeting with Chen in a hotel shortly after Chen, a career diplomat and former ROC foreign minister, assumed office as the ROC's de facto ambassador to the United States on July 7.

Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, meetings between senior US officials and the ROC representative stationed in Washington, D.C. have consistently been kept secret. The United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, but still maintains close substantive ties with the ROC.

The content and other details of the recent Chen-Berger meeting remained unknown, the sources said. Neither the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. nor the Clinton administration would confirm whether Chen and Berger did meet recently.

Douglas Paal, president of the Washington-based think tank Asia-Pacific Policy Center who once served in the White House National Security Council during the Bush administration, said he had heard of the meeting between Chen and Berger.

Paal said he thought that the meeting was mainly a "get to know each other" social function. To his knowledge, Paal said, the ROC's previous representatives would meet the top White House national security adviser at least one time during their tenures.

With the retirement of former ROC National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih and the departure of James Steinberg from the post of the White House deputy national security adviser, Paal said he thought that the recent Chen-Berger meeting means that Chen will from now on take full charge of communications between the new ROC government and the Clinton administration.

Ding, a career diplomat, had traveled to the United States at least once a year during his NSC stint to meet with Steinberg for exchanges of views on relations across the Taiwan Strait and Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations since the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis. The Ding-Steinberg meeting marked the highest-level ROC-US dialogue mechanism aimed at averting escalation of cross-strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT LOCAL DPP CHAPTERS

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh on Sunday will make his first visit to some local chapters of the ruling party since assuming the chairmanship on July 22.
The trip will bring Hsieh, who is concurrently the mayor of Kaohsiung, to Tainan City, Tainan County, Yunlin County, and Chiayi City.
He will meet with officials of the local DPP chapters to exchange views on the development of the DPP, which became the ruling party after winning the March 18 presidential election.
Among the topics to be discussed are next year's elections for the Legislative Yuan, where the DPP controls only 30 percent of the seats.
Hsieh will also take advantage of the tour to solicit public support for the DPP.
In this connection, he will deliver a speech at a rally organized for the care of the younger generation to be held at Chung Cheng Park in Chiayi City on Sunday afternoon.

The DPP chief will be accompanied on the trip by DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Wang-tai, Organizational Department Director Liu Yi-teh, Public Opinion Survey Center Director Chen Chun-lin, and Social Development Department Director Lee Wen-ying.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is currently on a visit to Atlanta, Georgia, said on Friday that he thinks relations across the Taiwan Strait will gradually improve.
Ma made the optimistic forecast in interviews with the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and Cable News Network (CNN).

The charismatic politician from the Republic of China told the Atlanta journal that he personally supports the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under specific conditions, but opposes the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification formula.
Ma stressed that the most important cross-strait issue at the moment is "maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and further improving bilateral ties."
If both sides can regard their ties from the viewpoints of market economy and partnership, Ma said, cross-strait relations will move in a positive, constructive direction.
And if the two sides can deepen their interaction, Ma said he believes that cross-strait military confrontation can be avoided.

Asked about his views on mainland China's military intimidation and bellicose rhetoric against Taiwan, Ma said he thinks mainland China was shocked by pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian's victory in the ROC's March 18 presidential election.
Ma further said he thinks that mainland China should have been equally surprised by Chen's repeated goodwill remarks and olive branches toward Beijing since his election.

Ma, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said he doesn't think the long-stalled cross-strait ties could make headway until after the US presidential election in November. He further said it takes wisdom of Taipei and Beijing leaders to resolve the basic cross-strait dispute over sovereignty issue.
In his interview with CNN, Ma said as the ROC has been an independent sovereign state since its establishment in 1911, it does not need to declare independence once again.

Asked about the Kuomingtang's reform plan after its defeat in the March 18 presidential election, Ma, a KMT stalwart, said he believes whether the KMT can return to power will hinge on the degree and speed of its intraparty restructuring.

Ma also said he has no plan to run for the ROC presidency in 2004. "My immediate career plan is seeking re-election because it takes eight years, not just four years, to delivery on all of my mayoral campaign promises," he added.
Following his Atlanta visit, Ma will travel to New York to attend a roundtable meeting on Taipei-Beijing ties and US policy toward both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Ma will also visit several ROC diplomatic allies in Central America, including Panama and Honduras, before returning to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE SMUGGLED LIVE HORSES SEIZED IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: Two more live horses smuggled from mainland China were seized in the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen on Saturday, police authorities said.
The seizure of the two ponies followed the confiscation of two adult horses by Kinmen coastal patrol force on Friday.
Initial investigations show that the two ponies were smuggled to Kinmen, located some 2.4 kilometers off the mainland Chinese coast, in late July.
As mainland China is a foot-and-mouse disease (FMD)-stricken area, the two ponies were put down by Kinmen quarantine officials shortly after they were seized by police.

Kinmen police took action to seize the two ponies and one adult horse at a chicken ranch in Hsipao late Friday evening after the Kinmen Coastal Patrol nabbed two adult horses in a coastal forest in northern Kinmen early Friday.

The chicken farm owner, Chou Chih-hsiang, has been detained for questioning. Chou told prosecutors that he bought the two ponies from a mainland fisherman in the Kinmen coastal area late last month at a price of NT$6,000 apiece. Chou said he planned to re-sell the ponies for high profits.

As Chou said the adult horse was bought from a local resident, Kinmen quarantine officials are still studying whether to kill it for anti-FMD purposes. "If the adult horse was also smuggled from the mainland, it would certainly be put down, too," said a quarantine official.

Kinmen police said at least 10 other horses were believed to have been smuggled into the ROC's offshore defense outpost from the mainland. "We have intensified investigations in order to seize them as early as possible to prevent a possible FMD outbreak," said a police officer.

Live animal smuggling in the Kinmen area was suspended after a batch of smuggled cattle and goats from mainland China triggered an outbreak of FMD in Kinmen and certain Taiwan areas among in June last year. During that period, some 200 cattle raised in Kinmen were all slaughtered to prevent a further spread of the deadly disease which mainly infected cloven-hoofed animals, including pigs, cattle, horses and goats.

However, live animal smuggling resumed recently as the ROC is planning to open its three main outlying islands --Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu -- for direct trade, postal and shipping links with mainland China southeastern port cities, such as Xiamen and Fuzhou, commonly known as the "mini three links," to help boost the three offshore islands' economic development.

Kinmen police and coastal patrol authorities said they will launch a crackdown on cross-strait smuggling of contraband goods, including live animals, to protect the country's agricultural and livestock industries. The ROC government has said it will not open the so-called "mini three links" until after comprehensive preparatory work, including quarantine and many other safety measures, has been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PRAISES LOCAL RELIGIOUS PRAYER CEREMONY
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday urged the participants of a large prayer ceremony to pray for the victims of recent major disasters and ask for eternal peace in the world.

Lu said at the Ling Chiou Mountain Buddhist grand benediction ceremony that the power of religion is limitless, just like the power of love. The ceremony has been held seven years in a row for seven days and seven nights each year. An estimated 10,000 people and thousands of volunteers attend the ceremonies.

Lu asked the entire nation to pray together for the 2,400-some people who perished in last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, the four people who died in a flash flood last month, and the 113 people who died onboard the Air France Concorde that crashed in Paris last month.
With the World Religions Museum to be established in Taiwan next February, Lu urged everyone to respect each religion, accept every ethnic group, and love all life.

Fielding questions after the ceremony, Lu expressed her support for ROC President Chen Shui-bian's 13-day state visit to the ROC's Latin American and West African allies which begins Sunday. She added that with Taiwan's current plight in its foreign diplomatic relations, every effort should be made to introduce Taiwan to the whole world.

Lu may visit South Africa in October in a private capacity to attend the World Women's Summit, but her office said that it has not received a reply from the South African government so far. South Africa was an ROC diplomatic ally until it switched its recognition to mainland China in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG CHAO-HSIUNG LEAVES FOR DEMOCRATIC PARTY CONVENTION

TEXT.P: A delegation of the opposition People First Party (PFP), led by its vice chairman, Chang Chao-hsiung, left Taipei Saturday evening for Los Angeles to attend the year 2000 Democratic Party's national convention and to attend the three-party roundtable meeting scheduled to be held in New York Aug. 14-16.
Other members in the delegation include Wu Jui-kuo, a policy-planner for PFP chairman James Soong, and Legislator Chou Hsi-wei (PFP-Taipei County).
This is the second time Chang is conducting a political party diplomatic trip to the United States. Chen also attended the 2000 Republican Party's national convention in Philadelphia last month.
These trips indicate that the PFP is aiming to introduce Chang to US political and academic circles and to overseas Chinese societies in the United States, according to a local political commentator.

Wu Jui-kuo will attend the so-called "second track" roundtable meeting that will be participated in by scholars and experts from Washington, Beijing, and Taipei. Discussions will focus on US-China policy and cross-strait relations with the aim of helping related government agencies resolve the controversial issues.

Prof. Kenneth Lieberthal of Michigan University, Senior Researcher at the Nixon Center David Lampton, and the former US assistant secretary of state in charge of Asian and Pacific Affairs, Winston Lord, will represent the US side during the three-day closed door discussions.

In addition to Wu Jui-kuo, Hsiao Mei-chin, adviser to the Presidential Office; Prof. Kuo Cheng-liang of Soochow University in Taipei; Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou; Lin Cheng-yi, chairman of the Institute of European and American Studies; and Prof. Kao Ying-mao of Brown University will attend the meeting on behalf of Taiwan.

Mainland China's representatives to the meeting will include Hsu Hsih-zhuan, director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences; and Yang zhieh-mian of the Shanghai Institute for International Relations.
The PFP delegation is expected to return to Taipei around Aug. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC VICE MINISTER NAMED CHUNGHWA TELECOM CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, minister of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), on Saturday accepted the resignation of Chunghwa Telecom Co. Chairman Steven Chen.
She named MOTC Vice Minister Mao Chi-kuo to fill the chairmanship of the state-owned firm.
Chen, 66, presented his resignation on Aug. 10, and called a press conference to express his determination to retire on Saturday morning, citing personal and health reasons.
Yeh met with Chen on Saturday evening, and accepted his request for retirement, and named Mao as his successor.
At first, Mao was reluctant to accept the new offer, but he had no time to reject, as Chunghwa Telecom is undergoing a privatization plan.
Chen was apparently annoyed by the recent sudden death of Chunghwa Telecom Vice President Lee Ching-chiang, and the dispute between the MOTC and the labor union of Chunghwa Telecom.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Beijing is willing to resume cross-strait talks based on 1992 consensus.
The China Times:
Chunghwa Telecom Company changed heads ahead of proposed walkout by employees.
The United Daily News:
Direct trade with mainland China to be phrased in by three steps in frontline islands.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen departs today for two-continent itinerary.
The China Post:
Telecom chief resigns, citing mental fatigue.
The Taiwan News:
Chen leaving this evening on 13-day diplomatic mission.
The Taipei Times: Presdient Chen departs on state visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 13, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish-American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho," and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Fidel Castro, the Cuban revolutionary who became the country's socialist president in 1959, is born.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Tse-tung names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1973: The second executive board meeting of the Asian Cultural Center opens in Taipei.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seeker freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Chinese communist Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria to Seoul, Korea on May 5, 1983.
1989: two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of them plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapsed in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development of the Executive Yuan estimates the ROC's economic rate will reach 5.5 percent this year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUA FM DENIES REPORTS ON AID REQUEST

TEXT.P: Nicaragua Foreign Minister Eduardo Montealegre has denied news reports concerning his demand for Taiwan to honor its aid commitments made earlier to Nicaragua, Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan said on Sunday.

Foreign wires reported last week that on the eve of Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's visit to Nicaragua, Montealegre asked Chen to fulfill a US$100 million aid package to Nicaragua made by Chen's predecessor, former President Lee Teng-hui.
Chen is scheduled to arrive in Managua on Aug. 17, on the second leg of his 13-day two-continent tour which will also bring him to the Dominican Republic, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

Wu said that Montealegre denied the reports in a letter to ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao on Aug. 11, saying that they were totally untrue and ran counter to the spirit of the cooperative ties between Taiwan and his country.
Montealegre said that Nicaragua has given full support to Taiwan in the international arena, based on mutual respect and cooperation.

He added that Taiwan has always come to Nicaragua's relief whenever needed, and that both the Nicaraguan government and people have been appreciative of what Taiwan has done for their country. He also said that his country will enthusiastically welcome Chen upon his arrival in Managua.
Meanwhile Nicaragua President Arnoldo Aleman has also told the ROC envoy in Managua that Taiwan should ignore the groundless reports.
He assured the ROC official that President Chen's upcoming visit will further cement bilateral ties between the two countries.
Taiwan's Foreign Affairs Ministry has repeatedly stressed that Chen, during his six-nation tour, will not make any new aid commitments to Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN LAUNCHES DIPLOMATIC DEFENSE

TEXT.P: Alarmed by Beijing's increasing efforts to win over Taipei's allies in Africa, President Chen Shui-bian will consolidate Taiwan's diplomatic foothold in Africa during his visits to three of the island's eight allies on that continent, said his office.

At a pre-departure briefing on Chen's itinerary, Deputy Secretary-General of Presidential Office Eugene Chien called the president's trip an exercise in "diplomatic defense" aimed at demonstrating Taiwan's democratic achievements, winning international recognition for the island, and cementing ties with its allies.

Considering that Beijing leader Jiang Zemin has visited nine African states during the last five years on three separate trips, Chien said Taipei sees trouble with its African allies this year, because of Beijing's all-out efforts to woo Taiwan's allies away.

With mainland authorities gearing up for a forum with African states in Beijing this October in the hope of enhancing their presence on the African continent, Chien said Taipei has determined that it is essential to preempt by Chen's visit any plots by Beijing to lure away its allies.

Chung Chin, director general of the Government Information Office, branded President Chen's trip a bid to enhance Taiwan's international profile by reaching out on the international stage, and called for her fellow countrymen to rally behind President Chen's trip.
Chen is slated to depart on a 13-day, six-state tour on Sunday evening. It will take him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
It is Chen's first overseas trip since his swearing-in on May 20, and he will be the first ROC president ever to set foot in Africa, where the island has eight allies.

Chen will make a stop in Los Angeles on Sunday night, on his way to the Dominican Republic. Although several pro-Taiwan US congressmen have tried to set up meetings with Chen during his stopover there, Vice Minister Wu Tzu-dan said at Sunday's press briefing that no meeting with any US public officials were on Chen's agenda, because his stopover will be too brief.

He denied that Washington has made it a ground rule that President Chen should not meet any US officials or lawmakers during his stopover on US territory, saying that Chen could not fit in any appointments during his 15-hour stay and will do nothing inconsistent with a normal transit stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH SUPERMARKET CHAIN TO EXPLORE TAIWAN MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Mark Chun-lin Ou & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: British supermarket chain store Tesco, following in the footsteps of British grocery chain Boots, will open its first outlet in Taiwan by the end of year, the company has announced.

A Tesco spokesman said on Saturday that his firm has taken over a shop with more than 100,000 square feet of floor space in the Taipei suburb of Nankang. The store was acquired from Makro, a Dutch group which has recently shifted its business focus from retail to wholesale.
Calling Asia an important part of its worldwide business expansion program, Tesco said the company's entire plan will be spelled out in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPASSION IS TAIWAN'S MOST VALUABLE ASSET: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: As much as it is tiny in size, Taiwan is rich in compassion, mainly because of the benevolence promoted by the Tzu Chi Foundation, a Buddhist charity organization, said Vice President Annette Lu in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County on Saturday.

Speaking at the dedication ceremony of the new Tzu Chi Hospital in Talin, Chiayi County, Lu said that Tzu Chi has inspired Taiwan people to care about others, thereby glorifying the country and making compassion the island's most valuable asset.
She urged her fellow countrymen to learn from the non-profit charity and make compassion a cornerstone of the country in the 21st century.

Covering an area of 18 hectares, the hospital was financed by Tzu Chi and has some 1,200 beds. Sunday's inauguration capped ten-year's worth of planning and a three-year construction period. The ceremony was jointly presided over by Lu and Tzu Chi founder Shi Chen Yen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI VILLAGE IN SOUTH AFRICA INAUGURATED
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, was formally inaugurated on Friday.
Located near Alexandra, a big town in suburban Johannesburg, the village of 64 fabricated houses currently accommodates over 200 black people whose houses were washed away by floods in February.

In a written congratulatory speech read by a Tzu Chi member stationed in South Africa, Tzu Chi founder, Master Cheng Yen said her organization built the "Tzu Chi Village" in the spirit of fraternity, and she hopes that the residents of the new village will help one another to live and show love for their fellow residents.

Speaking at the inaugural ceremony, Tzu Chi member Shih Hung-chi said the foundation has provided over 50,000 South African families with assistance, including digging wells, building schools, and setting up a vocational training center.

The foundation has established a vocational training center in Durban, eastern South Africa, with 3,000 South Africans currently granted vocational training. The Tzu Chi organization also has donated 300,000 yards of cloth to be woven in the vocational training center, in order to provide manufactured garments to the poor in South Africa.

Du Ling, representative of the Taipei Liaison Office in the Republic of South Africa, praised Tzu Chi members for their fraternal kindness toward Africa and extended a message of gratitude to Tzu Chi members on behalf of the people of Taiwan.

J. Hlomuka-Ngidi, mayor of metropolitan Johannesburg's East District, thanked Tzu Chi on behalf of all the recipients of the Tzu Chi houses, and expressed the hope that the new residents will jointly maintain their village's environment.

Tzu Chi members in South Africa, Johannesburg City Hall officials, officials of Taipei Liaison Office in the Republic of South Africa, as well as over 200 recipients of houses participated in the inaugural ceremony of the "Tzu Chi Village."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO LAUNCH MEMBER RE-REGISTRATION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) will launch a member re-registration campaign in September as part of efforts to reform the party following its setback in the March 18 presidential election, party sources have said.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, former ROC vice president and the KMT candidate in the election, will send a letter to the party's two million members, inviting them to complete the re-registration process, the sources said.
Lien will be the first KMT member to re-register, beginning the three-month campaign on Sept. 1, in an effort to encourage members to follow suit, the KMT said.

The KMT will send its heavyweights to invite senior party members, such as former KMT chairman and former ROC President Lee Teng-hui and former Premier Sun Yun-hsun, to re-register their memberships in the party, the party said.

The sources added that party members who fail to re-register with party branches in counties and cities within the three-month period will have their memberships revoked and lose their right to take part in party activities, including voting.
The campaign is to be undertaken to pave the way for the direct election of the party chairman by members, the sources explained.
The KMT, which had ruled Taiwan for over five decades until its presidential election defeat this year, has always determined its past chairmen through indirect elections by the party elite.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORT ON FIGHTERS FLYING OVER 'MIDDLE LINE'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Sunday denied a local news report that its fighters flew over the "middle line" of the Taiwan Strait and were intercepted by mainland Chinese fighters.
"(The news report) is absurd and the scenario is absolutely not likely to take place," military spokesman Kung Fan-ding said when interviewed by CNA.

A local evening newspaper quoted mainland China's Liberation Army Newspaper as reporting on Sunday that several Taiwan Air Force Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs) and F-16 fighters in mid-July took off form their bases in northern Taiwan and flew across the "middle line" of the Taiwan Strait, which separates Taiwan from the mainland.
The Taiwan fighters were detected by mainland military radar and expelled by mainland aircraft, the report said.

Kung said that his ministry has consistently asked Air Force and Navy to refrain from taking any provocative actions against the mainland ever since July last year, when cross-strait tensions heightened after former President Lee Teng-hui redefined Taiwan-mainland ties as having a "state-to-state" nature.
He said that Taiwan's armed forces have strictly observed the MND directive, and would not dare take the initiative to provoke the mainland.

However, Kung would not comment as to whether or not the Taiwan fighters ever encroach upon or fly over the "middle line" in order to monitor war games conducted by the mainland's People's Liberation Army there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DEPARTS ON SIX-STATE TRIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage left Taipei on Sunday evening, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.

He and his entourage were seen off at the airport by First Lady Wu Shu-chen, Vice President Annette Lu, the chiefs of five government branches, Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming, and foreign envoys stationed in Taiwan.
President Chen said before his departure that his tour signals that Taiwan is standing up and reaching out. "We want to see the whole world and let the world see us," he added.

Saying that the island would like to share its "Taiwan miracle" experience with the rest of the world, Chen stressed, "We will carry our 'Taiwan experience' out of the country and bring back friendship from our allies so as to enlarge Taiwan's presence on the international stage."
Chen's trip will take him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
He is scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 26, via Dubai.

According to the schedule issued by his office, Chen will arrive in Los Angeles Sunday night for an overnight stopover. Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan said at a press briefing earlier in the day that no meetings with any US politicians were on Chen's agenda, because of the briefness of his stopover there.
Washington granted visas to Chen and his entourage for their convenience, and President Chen would do nothing inconsistent with a normal transit stopover during his stay in Los Angeles, said Wu.
Chen will attend the inauguration of President-elect Hipolito Mejia while in the Dominican Republic, and meet with his counterparts of Taiwan's diplomatic allies who attend the ceremony.
Accompanying Chen on the trip include Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, ranking financial and economics officials, and local business leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO PROTECT ZHONG GONG FOUNDER IN GUAM

TEXT.P: The Zhong Gong organization in China Sunday urged US authorities in Guam to take necessary measures to protect Zhong Gong founder Zhang Hongbao against possible assassination.

In a statement issued Sunday through the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, the organization said that Zhang has been in a detention center in Guam since he applied for political asylum early this year, and that he is vulnerable even in the detention center, because communist Chinese assassins may disguise themselves as illegal immigrants and get into that center to kill or hurt him.
Zhang established Zhong Gong in 1987, and publicized his "Chi Lin theory" in 1990. Chi Lin is a propitious animal in ancient Chinese mythology.
The information center said the theory, which is inconsistent with Marxism, prompted Chinese authorities to crack down on Zhong Gong, which has an estimated membership of 38 million in China.

Another reason for the crackdown, the information center said, is that a task force formed in 1993 by Chinese authorities found that Zhong Gong was more dangerous than Falun Gong, because the former was expanding not only like a spiritual and religious sect, but also like a modern enterprise.

In 1996, the Chinese government began to crack down on Zhong Gong and search for Zhang in order to arrest him. Many training centers and affiliated enterprises of Zhong Gong have been closed down by the government since then.
