DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 125.78 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 125.78 points to close at 7,848.87.
Market turnover amounted to NT$39.65 billion (US$1.28 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 14, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy, march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The ROC Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow" press, dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three communist MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States maintains an embargo on trade with communist China, North Korea, and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1973: The 6th Asian Youth Recreation Tour is concluded. Some 100 youth representatives from 24 countries and areas took part in the two-week program.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1976: Eleven US Congressional assistants arrive in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with General Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at the Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities involved in the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal: 15 financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits, or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in Burundi in east- central Africa, killing more than 24,000.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association (IBA) Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 125.78 points to close at 7,848.87.

The bourse opened at 7,977.42, and due to a wait-and-see attitude on the part of most investors, share prices continued to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 7,982.13 and 7,838.5 during trading for the day, which saw a record low turnover for this year.

A total of 0.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$39.65 billion (US$1.28 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.29 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$62.28 billion.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.1 percent, textile issues and plastics and chemical shares, both at 0.9 percent, and construction stocks and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 396 to 95, with 89 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Monday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for August moved down 119 points to close at 7,881, with 2,542 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September decreased 115 points to finish at 7,905, with 1,187 contract transactions, while December futures fell 91 points to close at 7,998, with five contract transactions.
Next March futures moved down 59 points to close at 8,101, while next June futures plunged 209 points to finish at 8,112, with one contract transaction.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 8,000 for August; 8,020 for September; 8,089 for December; 8,160 for next March; and 8,321 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
August TE futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 418.4, with 643 contract transactions, while September TE futures lost 6.1 points to finish at 419.1, with 204 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures decreased 12.4 points to close at 890.6, with 255 contract transactions, while September TF futures fell 8.2 points to finish at 896.8, with 103 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S 6-STATE JOURNEY NOT TO AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's current six-country "journey of friendship" is not expected to have any adverse impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait, a senior opposition Kuomintang official said on Monday.
Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, said President Chen's ongoing overseas visit will inevitably provoke mainland China's ire and criticism.
Nevertheless, Chang said he thinks mainland leaders should also understand that Chen's state visits to the Republic of China's allies will not have substantive adverse impact on cross-strait ties.

Asked whether Beijing will take any provocative action during President Chen's first post-inauguration overseas trip, Chang said Beijing has again endorsed its double-edged strategy against Taiwan during its recent Beidaihe policy review meeting.

Under its double-edged strategy, Chang said, Beijing will on the one hand continue publicizing its "peaceful unification" overture to win international support for its cherished "one China" principle, while on the other Beijing will not cease its combat preparedness in order to intimidate Taiwan.
"It's worthy of our attention when and how mainland China will launch military intimidation against us after the Beidaihe meeting," Chang explained.
Because of Beijing's perennial diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Chang said, the number of the ROC's diplomatic allies has been limited (29 at the present).

"And against this background, the ROC's head of state is obligated to expand the country's diplomatic frontiers while simultaneously endeavoring to improve cross-strait relations," Chang said, adding that he believes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will continue their diplomatic tug-of-war, particularly in the Latin America and Africa where most of the ROC's diplomatic allies are located.
In fact, Chang said, the most difficult part in the current cross-strait relation lies in accommodating Beijing's "one China" principle and the ROC's quest for a decent international status.

Mainland China's "one China" principle claims sovereignty over Taiwan and deems the ROC as a local government under the People's Republic of China. Such a stance is unacceptable to the people of Taiwan.

President Chen left Taipei on Sunday for a hectic 13-day, six-country visit aimed at highlighting the ROC's first-ever democratic transition of power in May and cementing relations with diplomatic allies.
The visit will take Chen to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, and Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, as well as the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad in West Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MAKES OVERNIGHT STOPOVER IN LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and his entourage arrived in Los Angeles Sunday for an overnight stopover en route to the Dominican Republic, where Chen will begin a 12-day six-state visit to the Caribbean, Central America, and Africa.

The new ROC president received an overwhelming welcome from some 500 Taiwanese-Chinese residents in California when he arrived at the five-star Long Beach Westin, despite a 25-minute delay due to engine failure of the limousine which was arranged by the US State Department to take him to the hotel.
Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto US ambassador to Taipei, met Chen at the airport and accompanied him to the hotel in a different limousine.

Chen's trip, representing his first overseas visit since taking office on May 20, will take him and his 200-member entourage to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso, and Chad.

During his stay in Los Angeles, Chen is not expected to do anything that is inconsistent with a normal transit stopover, such as meeting with US officials or lawmakers, according to Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan.

Meanwhile, the president has been kept fully abreast of national affairs since beginning his overseas trip. Premier Tang reported to Chen on the latest operations of the Executive Yuan through a fax, while Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming sped a message to him concerning a report that ROC Air Force jet fighters flew over the "middle line" of the Taiwan Strait and were intercepted by mainland Chinese fighters sometime in July. Tang told the president the report proved to be false.
During his 12-hour flight from Taipei to Los Angeles, Chen took time to meet with three leading Taiwanese entrepreneurs to exchange views on the country's economic and business developments.

Chen held separate talks with Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce; Wang You-tseng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC; and Lin Kun-chung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries.

Talks focused mainly on the private business and industrial sectors' wish for government intervention to help protect the country's traditional industries and to help prop up prices on the stock market, according to Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Poh-chih, who accompanied the president during the talks.
The CEPD head said the government will at the end of August for the first time make public plans on how to revive the traditional industries.
Also present at the talks were Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, and Chuang Ming-yao, secretary-general of the National Security Council.
In the capital of the Dominican Republic, Chen will attend the inauguration of President-elect Hipolito Mejia and meet with other attending heads of state who are diplomatic allies of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID RELUCTANT TO PUNISH TOP-LEVEL OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese government authorities uncovered 319,000 "economic crimes" -- the Chinese euphemism for corruption -- over the first six months of 2000, according to official Chinese figures, reported the Australian Financial Review on Monday.

The daily reported that although more than 17 provincial and vice ministerial-level officials were investigated and punished for corruption in 1999, Beijing appears extremely reluctant to pursue corruption all the way to the top.

The central government in Beijing has slapped a ban on news coverage of this week's trial of officials involved in a US$10 billion smuggling scandal that indirectly implicates the wife of Jia Qinglin, a member of China's ruling Politburo and head of the party in Beijing, reported the daily.
The smuggling ring is the biggest uncovered in mainland China and has already resulted in the arrest of more than 200 officials in Xiamen city in southeastern Fujian province, the daily reported.

While the government has been doing its best to keep the politically sensitive Xiamen scandal under wraps, it has been more than keen to publicize the show trials of other senior officials, including the sentencing to death of the former governor of Guangxi province, Cheng Jejie, the highest level official to receive such a sentence for corruption since the communists took power in 1949.

Despite this crackdown, the daily reported that many Chinese remain skeptical about the authorities' seriousness in eliminating corruption as Beijing seems to be reluctant to punish top party and government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE SCIENTISTS CREATE HORMONE TO SLOW GRASS GROWTH

TEXT.P: Australian scientists at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) have created a hormone capable of slowing the growth of grass, reported The Australian on Monday.
The CSIRO has developed a "slow mow" grass by using a hormone, not a genetic modification, to restrict grass growth, according to the report.

The daily quoted Rod King, a senior research scientist at the CSIRO, as saying that canisters of the plant retardant hormone could be attached behind mowers and sprayed over one's lawn, making regular mowing unnecessary.
"It's the home gardener who thinks it will be great. They can sit outside and watch their lawn not growing," King added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM TANG INSTRUCTS UPDATING OF LAWS TO CRACK DOWN ON NEW CRIMES

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei on Monday instructed the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on new types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
During a Cabinet meeting on social order, Tang expressed his concerns about the new crimes -- including Internet crimes, credit card fraud, and the use of students to sell pirated porno CD ROMs.

Tang instructed the Executive Yuan to come up with new and amended regulations soon in order to help eradicate the crimes that were formerly hard to imagine and now have become difficult to deal with.

Meanwhile, the premier also instructed the MOJ to establish a special ad hoc committee to look into the alleged illicit intervention of "improper" forces into the elections of executives and board members of local farmers associations around Taiwan.

The positions of farmers association leaders, like those of some temples in Taiwan, have for the past several decades been hot spots of contention because they are considered tantamount to power and money.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCNSAA APPEALS FOR KEUISHAN ISLAND'S ECOLOGICAL CONSERVATION
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan County, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Yolanda K.C. Chen)

TEXT.P: The Northeast Coast National Scenic Area Administration (NCNSAA) on Monday urged visitors to Kueishan Island not to take away any articles from the island as souvenirs so that the island's natural beauty may remain intact.

Since Kueishan Island was partially opened to tourism on Aug. 1, many tourists, upon completing there visit, have attempted to depart with various objects that belong to the island, such as pebbles, plants, and even animals, for keepsakes. Litter left behind by tourists has also seriously ruined the island's natural ecology, noted the NCNSAA.

The NCNSAA has currently restricted the number of daily arrivals to the island to 250. They are allowed to stay up to only two hours. Prospective visitors must make an application 15 days in advance of their desired travel date.
The NCNSAA further reminded visitors not to enter restricted areas in order to minimize the impact of tourism on the island's natural environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE TO FORM MIRAGE WING IN APRIL 2001

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force is scheduled to form a wing of Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters in April 2001 and two F-16 jet fighter wings by February 2002, Air Force Commander-in-Chief Chen Chao-min announced on Monday.
Chen made the announcement at a rally marking Air Force Day which falls on Aug. 14.

Chen said the commissioning of the new Mirage and F-16 wings will mark the completion of the installation of the ROC's second-generation warplanes and a substantial upgrading of the ROC's air defense capability.

At the ceremony, Chen cited outstanding Air Force officers who have contributed to the recent commissioning of the third and last wing of locally built Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters (IDFs) and to the replacement of the ROC's aging air fleet with second-generation arsenal. The ROC Air Force has acquired 130 IDFs, 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5s and 150 US-built F-16s. All these three types of warplanes form the backbone of the ROC's new generation of air defense arsenal.

Noting that military build-up and combat preparedness require continuity, Chen said all Air Force staff should devote full energy to accomplishing new aircraft replacement as scheduled and simultaneously intensify various training programs to upgrade overall combat capability and deter mainland China's invading attempts.
Chen also outlined three Air Force modernization goals -- establishing a professional air combat force, averting any flight mishaps and beefing up overall combat capability.

Meanwhile, Chen categorically denied a mainland Chinese press report that the ROC's IDF and F-16 jet fighters flew over the center line of the Taiwan Strait last month to collect information about a recent mainland military exercise off the southeastern mainland coast.
"The report was false outright," Chen stressed, adding that the ROC's warplanes are unlikely to fly over the middle line of the Taiwan Strait.

Mainland China's Liberation Army Daily reported over the weekend that the ROC's IDF and F-16 fighters took off from its Sungshan and Chiayi air bases, respectively, and flew over the center line of the Taiwan Strait in July for monitoring the People's Liberation Army's amphibious training exercise.
"The report was sheer speculation and absurd," Chen said, adding that Sungshan Airport in downtown Taipei has not been a military base for any jet fighters.

"By allowing its official mouthpiece to disseminate such a fabricated report, Beijing apparently wants to mislead mainland people and the international community into believing that Taiwan was provocative," Chen noted.
He pointed out that the Air Force leadership has consistently reminded all Air Force officers and men to avoid triggering cross-strait tension while performing their official duties.

Chen assured the press confidently that Air Force pilots were not likely to fly over the Taiwan Strait center line by mistake because Air Force flight control personnel have routinely kept close watch on their operations.

Chen further said if the ROC's warplanes undergo long-range training missions, including BVR missile test-firing, they tend to undertake such training exercises off Taiwan's eastern coast, namely in the skies over the Pacific Ocean.

Asked how the Air Force will react if a mainland Chinese warplane flies over the Taiwan Strait middle line, Chen reiterated that the ROC Air Force will under no circumstances take any provocative action.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR CLOSES UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar remained unchanged against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 31.085.
The local currency opened Monday at 31.081 and was traded between 31.081 and 31.088.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$189 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY TEAM TO BE ESTABLISHED TO SAVE STRANDED WHALES

TEXT.P: Tainan County Government on Monday announced its decision to establish a rescue team for stranded whales, as more and more of the aquatic mammals have been found beached on or near the shores of Tainan County.
The team will be separated into emergency, rescue, academic affairs, and medical groups in order to allow it to save stranded whales more efficiently and swiftly, government sources said.

According to a report by Professor Chuo Lien-hsiang of the Department of Animal Science at National Taiwan University, many whales become trapped ashore or in shallow waters near Taiwan's coast every year, especially in winter and spring.

There were 86 reported cases of stranded whales in Taiwan from January 1990 to January 1997, according to Chuo, who also noted that the number of whales running aground near Taiwan's coastal areas has been on the rise during the past three years. In most cases, stranded whales have been near death when found, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PER CAPITA GNP TO HIT US$ 14,500 THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross national product (GNP) will break the US$300 billion mark to reach US$320.8 billion this year, according to a forecast released on Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The nation's per capita GNP will hit more than US$14,500 this year, the DGBAS added.
The DGBAS also adjusted downward its economic growth forecast for 2000 by 0.16 percentage points, saying that the economy will only grow by 6.57 percent.

The downward adjustment was made due to sluggish stock trading volume in the local equities market since the second quarter of this year, as well as declining private sector expenditures, DGBAS sources said.

However, due to increasing domestic industrial demand and the overall good health of the world economy, Taiwan was still able to register 6.65 percent economic growth in the first half of this year, the DGBAS said. It added that the growth rate for the whole of this year will reach 6.57 percent if exports continue expanding in the second half.

However, the DGBAS' newest forecast is very close to similar estimates made by private economic research institutes. Among them, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research forecasts a 6.6 percent GDP growth for this year, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research foresees economic growth of 6.5 percent in 2000, and Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics predicts that growth will hit only 6.44 percent this year.
Looking forward to next year, the DGBAS said that the nation's GNP in 2001 will grow to over NT$10 trillion (US$324 billion), which will translate into a per capita GNP of US$15,427.
The DGBAS also forecast that next year's economic growth rate will hit 6.48 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE FIFTH CROSS-STRAIT ANGELS ACTIVITY KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The fifth cross-strait angels activity sponsored by National Planner's Association (NPA) began on Monday.

NAP members said the main purpose of this activity is to promote cross-strait peace, adding that this 70-individual troupe is biggest one to visit the Republic of China since the new government formed.

Besides the cross-strait peace, this activity also focus on concering earthquake-stricken areas caused on Sept. 21, 1999. It will have a performance "Angels Promising for Peace, Entering the New Ear. Yuin Nan Traditional Dance for Peace Cross-Strait" in National Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall on Aug. 21.

Meanwhile, this troupe will be scheduled to visit elementary schools in Puli, Nantou and aborigines in Sao's conservation area. Also, cross-strait angels will respectively present their own-made pottery to ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Mainland China President Jiang Zheming.
NPA members added they held a blessing party in The Grand Hotel while this troupe arrived in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT-ELECT REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic President-elect Hipolito Mejia said on Sunday he likes the Republic of China very much and will make his country the ROC's staunchest ally in Latin America after assuming office.

Mejia, who has made 22 visits to Taiwan over the past years, made the remarks during a meeting with a group of Taiwan reporters who are here to cover ROC President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming visit to the Dominican Republic to attend Mejia's inauguration. Chen and his entourage are scheduled to arrive in Santo Domingo via Los Angeles on Monday.

Mejia said he has enjoyed cordial friendship with many Taiwan friends, including the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, former President Lee Teng-hui and former Premier Sun Yun-suan. The president-elect said he has been impressed by Taiwan's economic prosperity and urban development.

Mejia said he will need the ROC's assistance in carrying out many projects to boost his country's development. "I will take advantage of President Chen's visit to discuss possible bilateral cooperative projects," he added.

Mejia further said his government will continue construction of the Dominican Republic's first high-tech industrial park, which was patterned after the ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, also Taiwan's high-tech industry stronghold.

Mejia promised to improve visa services to ROC passport holders after assuming office. Noting that the Dominican Republic welcomes ROC investors, Mejia said his government will take concrete measures to encourage Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in his Caribbean nation to help spur its economic development and create more job openings.
Mejia said he plans to visit Taiwan next year.
Meanwhile, outgoing Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez presided over the opening of his country's first high-tech industrial park on Sunday.
Fernandez pushed for construction of the new industrial park after he visited Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and was impressed by its role in Taiwan's high-tech development.

Construction on the Dominican high-tech park began last October and the first-phase construction has roughly been completed. During the inaugural ceremony, Fernandez encouraged companies in the park to learn from their counterparts in Taiwan's Hsinchu park to help upgrade the Dominican industry.

ROC Ambassador to the Dominican Republic Sun Ta-cheng was among the 100-plus guests present at the grand opening ceremony. Sun said he has met with senior administrators of the Dominican park on many occasions and has offered them the Hsinchu park's developmental experience.

Sun said he has also exchanged views with Taiwan business people here on the prospects for investing in the Dominican industrial park. "Many of them told me that they believe investment in the new park will be profitable as the Dominican Republic has decided to offer incentives to attract its 1 million expatriates in New York to return for investment and work," he said, adding that Taiwan firms are also welcome to invest in the high-tech park.
According to Sun, a consortium of Taiwan banks have offered a syndicated US$10 million loan for the Fernandez administration to build the high-tech park.
Taiwan companies have launched some 100 investment projects in the Dominican Republic, with a combined capital investment of US$100 million over past years.
The Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in the Dominican Republic was established in 1989. It now has 100 members. Taiwanese-owned firms provide more than 10,000 jobs for Dominican people.

Many Taiwan businessmen have arrived in Santo Domingo from the United Sates and other Central and South American countries in preparation for welcoming President Chen's arrival on Monday for his first state visit since taking office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE ANGELS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FOR PERFORMANCE TOUR

TEXT.P: The Cross-strait Peace Angels, a performance troupe consisting of mainland children and youths, began their Taiwan tour on Monday.

The tour organizer -- Taiwan's National Planner's Association (NPA) -- said that the main purpose of the activity is to promote cross-strait peace, adding that the Peace Angels, a troupe of 50 mainland children, is the biggest group of its kind to visit the Republic of China since the new government's inauguration.

Besides cross-strait peace, the Angels will also focus on helping victims of last year's disastrous Sept. 21 earthquake. The group will give a dance performance at Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall in Taipei on Aug. 21.
Meanwhile, the troupe is scheduled to visit elementary schools in Puli, Nantou County -- which was struck hardest by last year's earthquake -- as well as aborigines in the Shao Conservation Area.
Also, the group will visit Shuili, Nantou County, where they will make a special "Peace Pottery" to be presented to ROC President Chen Shui-bian and mainland China President Jiang Zemin.
The NPA will be scheduled to hold a "praying for peace" event at Taipei's Grand Hotel upon the troupe's arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN POLICE FORM SPECIAL TASK FORCE TO PROBE HORSE SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: The Kinmen County Police Bureau formed a special task force on Monday to investigate the smuggling of live horses from mainland China to the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen.
The formation of the special investigative panel was prompted by Kinmen law enforcement authorities' seizure of a total of six smuggled mainland horses since last Friday.

The Kinmen Coastal Patrol first seized two mainland horses in a northern coastal forest early on Friday, and Kinmen police caught two ponies and two horses in three different townships on Saturday and Sunday, respectively.

As mainland China is an area in which two horse-related contagious diseases are endemic -- equine anthrax and glanders -- all the animals were destroyed at the Kinmen animal quarantine center to prevent a possible spread of the diseases.

The owners of the smuggled mainland horses were detained for questioning and were quoted as saying they had purchased the horses from mainland fishermen for re-sale at a high profit. Smuggling a mainland pony to Kinmen costs NT$5,000 and the cost for smuggling a horse is NT$10,000. The smuggled animals can fetch NT$28,000 to NT$50,000 apiece in Kinmen.
Police said some Kinmen residents like to keep horses as pets, while others use them to lead funeral processions.

Police said they suspect that underworld criminal rings might be involved in the recent smuggling cases. "We will intensify investigations to bring to justice to all those involved and to seize all smuggled live animals to prevent an outbreak of any epidemic," said one police officer.
Police sources said at least 10 other horses were believed to have been smuggled into Kinmen since late last month.

Live animal smuggling in the Kinmen area was suspended after a batch of smuggled cattle and goats from mainland China triggered an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in Kinmen and certain areas of Taiwan proper in June last year. During that period, some 200 cattle raised in Kinmen were slaughtered to prevent a further spread of the disease which infects cloven-hoofed animals such as pigs, cattle and goats.

However, live animal smuggling resumed recently as the ROC is planning to open its three main outlying islands -- Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu -- for direct trade, postal and shipping links with mainland China's southeastern port cities such as Xiamen and Fuzhou, in a move commonly known as the "mini three links," to help boost the three offshore islands' economic development.

Kinmen police and coastal patrol authorities said they will launch a crackdown on cross-strait smuggling of contraband goods, including live animals, to protect the country's agricultural and livestock industries.
The ROC government has said it will not open the so-called "mini three links" until after comprehensive preparatory work, including quarantine and many other safety measures, has been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER PROBES CAUSE OF PENGHU BLACKOUT

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) said on Monday that a power blackout a day earlier in the offshore island county of Penghu was caused by neither an electrical storm nor by mainland Chinese sabotage.

Taipower, a state-owned enterprise, said it sent engineers and technicians to Penghu to assist in probing the possible cause of the major blackout that suspended electricity supplies to more than 35,000 households and businesses in the county, located off the southwestern Taiwan coast near Kaohsiung.
The blackout hit the county at 6:43 p.m. on Sunday and it was not until 8:25 p.m. that power was partially restored. In some areas, the electricity supply did not return to normal until 11:45 p.m.
Taipower offered a public apology on Monday to all the 35,000-plus affected Penghu households and businesses.
Speculation about the cause of the rarely experienced major blackout had been rife in the county where fishing and tourism form the backbone of the economy.
Taipower said initial investigations show that the blackout had nothing to do with an afternoon thunderstorm, nor was it caused by any sabotage by mainland China.
A senior executive said the blackout might have been caused by problems with a 12-kilometer-long underground electricity distribution cable between the county's Makung and Chien power plants.

Nevertheless, he said, further investigations will be needed before the true cause can be determined. "We believe a final investigative report will be ready soon, as our engineers and technicians already traveled to Penghu to make extensive checks," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SCHOLAR OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A noted US expert on relations across the Taiwan Strait said on Sunday he is cautiously optimistic about the prospects for resuming cross-strait dialogue in the near future.

Professor Donald S. Zagoria, the chief organizer of a "Track II" roundtable meeting on cross-strait relations to be sponsored by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) from Aug. 14-15, also made a bold forecast that cross-strait dialogue could resume next year at the earliest.
Zagoria, also an NCAFP trustee, made the remarks during a dinner in honor of some 20 delegates from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States to the two-day roundtable.

This is the eighth time that the NCAFP, a prominent US think tank which has enormous influence on US foreign policy, has sponsored a "Track II" unofficial meeting on cross-strait ties since the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis.

Based on the findings of his April and June visits to Taiwan and mainland China, Zagoria said he thinks both sides of the Taiwan Strait have shown certain flexibility in dealing with their bilateral relations.
Zagoria said he supports new ROC President Chen Shui-bian's remarks that if North and South Korea could sit down to talk, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should also be able to make it.

Zagoria further said the US government will not pressure either side of the Taiwan Strait to go to the "negotiating table." He predicted that the top negotiators from both sides, Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu and mainland China's Wang Daohan, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, are likely to meet next year.

Republic of China delegates to the roundtable include Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, also a stalwart of the opposition Kuomintang; Hsiao Bih-kim, an aide to President Chen; Wu Jui-kuo, an adviser to the opposition People First Party; Kuo Cheng-liang, a professor with Soochow University and a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party; and Lin Cheng-yi, head of the Institute of American and European Studies of Academia Sinica.

Hsiao said this is the first time she has been invited to attend the NCAFP-sponsored roundtable on cross-strait ties. Hsiao said the new DPP-led ROC government is very interested in Beijing's and Washington's views and thinking about cross-strait relations.

"I hope the roundtable will help me gain a better understanding in this regard," Hsiao said. But she stressed that she is attending the meeting in her private capacity, not as a government representative.

Mainland China's delegates include Xu Shiquan, director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, and Yang Jiehmien, head of the Institute of American Studies of the Shanghai International Relations Research Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT COMMENTS ON ROC-US-CHINA RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen, Chu Lu-shen, and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Monday that relations between the ROC and the United States are so close that there is "no distance" between them.

Chen, who is in Los Angeles on a 16-hour stopover at the start of his 13-day, six-state visit to the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa, likened the closeness of Taipei-Washington ties to the proximity of his charter plane to the US president's "Air Force One," parked less than 100 meters away.
Chen made the remarks while meeting Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents American interests in Taiwan in the absence of official relations.
Chen urged the United States to play a more active role as a "stabilizer" and a "balancer" in ROC-mainland China relations, even if it is not willing to serve as a mediator.
He added that the unobstructed communications channel between the governments of the ROC and the United States plays "an important role" in the peace and stability of the Asia Pacific region.
Bush welcomed Chen in a dinner address and said that Chen's election opened "a window of opportunity" for resumed dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China.

Bush told Chen afterward that US support for Taiwan remains unchanged, that US adherence to the Taiwan Relations Act remains unchanged, and that no matter who becomes the next US President, US policies toward Taiwan will retain their continuity and stability.

Chen told Bush that the Taiwan public cannot accept mainland China's "one country, two systems" policy. He added that he is willing to promote beneficial exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under the foundation of the "1992 spirit" -- through dialogue, exchanges, and setting aside controversial issues.

Chen went on to say that Taiwan has already expressed its greatest sincerity by holding out several olive branches to mainland China. He added that Taiwan will continue to be even more patient, and that as long as both sides can sit down and temporarily set aside their differences, they can surely come to a consensus.

Bush told Chen that the United States is very pleased with Chen's patience, admires his policies toward mainland China, and that it will encourage Beijing to seize the opportunity to resume cross-strait dialogue.

Bush then asked Chen about Taiwan's domestic situation, to which Chen replied that after the new government stabilizes Taiwan's foreign diplomatic environment, it will focus on domestic reform. He added that he is confident about Taiwan's domestic, cross-strait, and economic issues.

Chen also met US Representative Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), who paid a visit to Chen in defiance of a publicly announced US State Department objection to any congressional meeting with Chen during his transit stop.
Rohrabacher said that he was determined not to be concerned about the US State Department's policy and insisted on welcoming Chen as the representative from California.
He recently accused the Clinton administration of sacrificing Taiwan in order to appease mainland China.
He also claimed that many congressmen from both the Republican and Democratic parties had wanted to meet Chen, but that they had all been dissuaded by the State Department.
Chen's trip, his first overseas visit since taking office on May 20, will take him and his 200-member entourage to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
Chen will attend the inauguration of Dominican Republic President-elect Hipolito Mejia and meet with other attending heads of state who are diplomatic allies of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: DONATIONS FOR EARTHQUAKE RELIEF HIT NT$ 31 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing Village, central Taiwan, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: Donations for relief and reconstruction after the 921 earthquake have hit NT$31.8 billion (US$1.03 billion), according to a report released on Monday by the Cabinet-level Post-Earthquake Reconstruction Commission.

Although the earthquake which devastated parts of central Taiwan last Sept.21 occurred almost a year ago, the stricken areas still need large amounts of money to continue with reconstruction and the commission wants to launch a second round of fund-raising.

However, the report points out that the public do not know exactly how their donations have been used, although there has been speculation that quantities have gone into the pockets of corrupt local officials.
Worried that the rumors will affect the second round of fund-raising, the Ministry of the Interior has added up the donations from the all city and county governments and private groups.

According to the report, 108 government organizations and 222 private groups have been raising money, with the Central Government providing NT$13.4 billion, local governments NT$7.6 billion, private groups NT$9.4 billion, and the remaining NT$1.2 billion from unreported sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO INVITE INTERNATIONAL OIL CORPORATIONS TO INVEST

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is planning to invite major international oil corporations to invest in CPC as part of its privatization process, officials with the Commission of National Corporations (CNC) said on Monday.

The CPC, along with two other state-run firms -- Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) and Chunghwa Telecom -- is facing privatization, and Chunghwa Telecom will begin its first stage of privatization in late August by auctioning off 3 percent of the government's stake in the company.

By the end of the year, the figure will have been increased to 33 percent, with a further 33 percent of shares divested in February next year, and the goal of complete privatization by the end of next year or early the following year.

The CNC, meanwhile, has mapped out three phases of privatization for the CPC and Taipower. In the first phase, the government will auction off some of its shares in the two companies and release part of its stakes for company employees' subscriptions. The second phase will see the government listing its shares abroad, while in the third phase, the government will offer more shares for public subscription.
The CPC will invite the international oil corporations or oil-producing countries to be strategic investors in the second phase of its privatization process, the CNC said.

The government originally planned to release 15 percent of its stake in the CPC in 1998 and 18 percent in 1999. However, the legislature passed a resolution that only after the passage of the Petroleum Control Law would the CPC be permitted to release shares, forcing the privatization plan to be postponed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STATE-RUN BANKS' OVERDUE LOANS HIT RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Overdue loans for Taiwan's seven state-run banks hit a record high of NT$339.552 billion (US$10.92 billion) in July, an increase of NT$5.414 billion from the end of June.

The average rate of overdue loans for the seven banks -- Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan, Taiwan Cooperative Bank, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, the Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, and the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan -- was 5.275 percent for the month.
Bank of Taiwan's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$32.1 billion, an overdue loan rate of 2.38 percent.
Land Bank of Taiwan's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$56.6 billion, an overdue loan rate of 5.11 percent.
Taiwan Cooperative Bank's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$66.7 billion, an overdue loan rate of 5.85 percent.
First Commercial Bank's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$49.2 billion, an overdue loan rate of 5.76 percent.
Hua Nan Commercial Bank's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$45.78 billion, an overdue loan rate of 5.81 percent.
The Chang Hwa Commercial Bank's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$52.19 billion, an overdue loan rate of 6.46 percent.
The Medium Business Bank of Taiwan's overdue loans by the end of July totaled NT$36.982 billion, an overdue loan rate of 5.56 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR REMAINED UNCHANGED IN 1999: REPORT

TEXT.P: The gap between rich and poor in Taiwan remained unchanged in 1999, according to the results of a survey released on Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS).

The DGBAS results, Taiwan's average monthly family income in 1999 was NT$91,000 (US$2,936), an annual increase of 1.75 percent, with the highest income families bringing in 5.5 times the amount brought in by the poorest families, little changed from the 5.51 times recorded in 1998.
The annual disposable income of the highest-income bracket families reached NT$1.74 million compared to NT$317,000 for the lowest families, DGBAS added.

It said that 39 percent of Taiwan's families had computers, with half of them having Internet connections, 54.3 percent had automobiles, 79 percent had air conditioners, 43 percent had microwave ovens and 23 percent had dehumidifiers, which the report said shows the modernization of Taiwan society.
In related news, the DGBAS also predicted that Taiwan's exports will grow by 24.2 percent and imports by 30.8 percent this year, resulting in a shrinking trade surplus of US$6.3 billion.
It forecast that due to promising prospects for the semiconductor and optical-electronic sectors, Taiwan will see a 17.6 percent increase in its private investment this year.
The DGBAS said that the trend will continue until next year when the two sectors are expected to make NT$250 billion and NT$100 billion more, respectively, in new investment.
The agency also foresees a recovery of the construction industry, benefiting from the building of Taiwan's high-speed railway, large shopping shopping malls and entertainment centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WORLD NO. 2 FOR NEARSIGHTED CHILDREN
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: The percentage of nearsighted children has reached 19 percent, the second-highest level in the world after Singapore's 34 percent, according to the latest statistics of the Singapore National Eye Center (SNEC) released on Monday.

The SNEC is undertaking a five-year research project on more than 1,000 school age children and preliminary results reveal that genetics is the main cause of nearsightedness, although other factors such as reading, watching TV at an improper distance, and playing video games also has an effect.
The SNEC is setting up a series of tests in order to slow down the rate of increase of nearsighted people and the entire research project is scheduled to be completed by next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT LEAVES UNITED STATES FOR DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Monday left for the Dominican Republic, continuing on his 13-day, six-state visit to ROC allies in the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa.

Chen was seen off at the airport by Chen Chien-jen, ROC representative in the United States and Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two nations.

Chen and his 200-member entourage arrived here on Sunday evening for a 15-hour transit stop. He left Taipei on Sunday for a "journey of friendship" aimed at highlighting the ROC's first-ever democratic transition of power in May and cementing relations with diplomatic allies.
Chen is scheduled to attend the inauguration of Dominican Republic President-elect Hipolito Mejia and meet with other attending heads of state who are diplomatic allies of the ROC.
He will stay in the Caribbean republic until Aug. 17, when he will travel on to Nicaragua (Aug. 17-18), Costa Rica (Aug. 18-19), Gambia (Aug. 20-21), Burkina Faso (Aug. 21-23), and Chad (Aug. 23-25).

A US State Department spokesman told CNA as Chen was preparing to depart for the Dominican Republic that the United States appreciates Taiwan for acting in accordance with a "shared understanding of the private nature of this transit."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 15, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1856: James Keir Hardie, Scottish politician and founder of the British Labour Party, is born.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The ROC Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with General Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules ground-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1974: The Seventh Asian Youth Camp holds its opening ceremony in Taipei.
1976: Premier Chinag Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energies to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacations military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong, and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen-kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-some years has won it international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel prize winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 3.18 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 3.18 points to close at 7,845.69.
Market turnover amounted to NT$48.53 billion (US$1.57 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 3.18 points to close at 7,845.69.

Encouraged by a surge in US stock prices, the bourse opened at 7,883.84, but due to a continued wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors, share prices went down and fluctuated between 7,913.77 and 7,821.74 during trading.

A total of 1.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.53 billion (US$1.57 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 0.89 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$39.65 billion.
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 0.9 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.7 percent, construction shares at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 275 to 168, with 123 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET CLOSED MIXED

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Tuesday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved up 19 points to close at 7,900, with 1,869 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September increased 17 points to finish at 7,922, with 3,154 contract transactions, while December futures gained 32 points to close at 8,030, with five contract transactions.
However, next March futures fell 55 points to close at 8,020, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were: 7,881 for August; 7,905 for September; 7,998 for December; 8,075 for next March; and 8,160 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
August TE futures moved up 2.4 points to close at 420.8, with 449 contract transactions, while September TE futures increased 2.15 points to finish at 421.25, with 776 contract transactions.
December TE futures gained 12.3 points to close at 426.95, with seven contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures fell 7.4 points to close at 883.2, with 218 contract transactions, while September TF futures moved down 9 points to finish at 887.8, with 196 contract transactions.
December TF futures decreased 6.8 points to close at 892.2, with two contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE HAS NOT MET WITH US NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Washington said Monday that ROC Representative C. J. Chen has not met with Sandy Berger, the White House National Security Adviser, since he arrived in early July to assume the Washington, DC post.

When asked about a recent news report that the two had met secretly due to the lack of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the United States, a spokesman for the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in the United States made the above statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PLEASED WITH PRESIDENT CHEN'S LOW-KEY TRANSIT

TEXT.P: The US administration is "very pleased" that President Chen Shui-bian kept a low profile during his one-night transit stopover in Los Angeles, said the US State Department spokesman on Monday.

"We noted to Taiwan our expectation that President Chen's activities while in the United States would be in line with a transit, would be consistent with that, would be private in nature," said Philip Reeker.
"We are very pleased that this is exactly what occurred," he told a regular briefing at the State Department.
Despite the administration's efforts to persuade members of Congress against meeting with President Chen, Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-CA) showed up at a dinner on Sunday held in President Chen's honor.
Reeker played down the significance of this episode, however, saying the congressman went uninvited to the hotel where the president stayed overnight en route to the Caribbean.
"Mr. Chen clearly stated that his limited time in Los Angeles precluded the possibility of meeting with members of Congress," Reeker said.
"I believe he greeted Mr. Rohrabacher briefly and returned to the private dinner that he was having," he added.
The US administration agreed to Taipei's request for a transit by President Chen, considering the safety, comfort, and convenience of the traveler.
Emphasizing that a transit is different from a visit, the administration noted the expectation that President Chen's activities during the 15-hour stop-over would be private.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON ADMINISTRATION CRITICIZED FOR KOWTOWING TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: While the Clinton administration said it was "very pleased" that ROC President Chen Shui-bian acted in a manner consistent with the nature of his transit stopover in the US, a renowned American foreign policy expert on Monday criticized the administration for humiliating itself by unnecessarily appeasing Communist China.

Instead of brusquely dismissing Beijing's protest, "the Clinton administration went out of its way to be accommodating," assuring the regime in Beijing that President Chen would make only a brief transit stop and would not hold meetings nor conduct public activities while on US soil, Ted Galen Carpenter, vice president for defense and foreign policy studies at the Cato Institute, wrote in a commentary.

He pointed out that the Clinton administration's conduct has been "disgraceful but not surprising." It is reminiscent of the policy adopted more than five years ago when then-President Lee Teng-hui requested a visa to attend a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.

He said the proper response to Beijing's attempts to block the visits of Lee and Chen would have been a firm rebuff, because the Beijing regime habitually responds to US protests about its egregious human rights record by denouncing "interference in China's internal affairs."
Yet Communist Chinese leaders don't hesitate to try to dictate America's visa policy or decide whether a traveler in transit can set foot on American soil, said Carpenter.

"The administration's excessively deferential behavior toward China not only betrays important American values, it is potentially dangerous. Chinese leaders are impressed with quiet displays of strength and pride, and they have justifiable contempt for fawning behavior. Unfortunately, the Clinton administration has all too often engaged in the latter," he wrote.

In addition to its campaign of diplomatic appeasement regarding the Lee and Chen visits, Carpenter noted, the administration acquitted itself poorly in responding to attacks on the US embassy in Beijing following NATO's inadvertent bombing of the PRC embassy in Belgrade.

"It was certainly appropriate for Washington to apologize -- once -- for the bombing and to offer generous compensation to the victims and their families. It was troubling, though, to see US officials apologizing to China again, again and again," he said.

Even worse, he said, the Clinton administration responded to the violent, week-long attacks on the US embassy and the US ambassador's residence -- clearly conducted with the connivance of the Beijing regime -- with nothing more than anemic diplomatic protests.

"The proper response would have been to recall the ambassador and, more important, announce that appointment of his successor would be delayed until Beijing apologized and made explicit assurances that it would provide appropriate protection for embassy property in the future. Other contacts between the two governments should have been curtailed as well, to show Washington's displeasure," said Carpenter.

He emphasized that "such actions would have made it clear to Beijing that the United States was not about to be bullied and intimidated. Unfortunately, the administration's actions conveyed precisely the opposite message."

Few people would dispute that it is important for the United States to maintain a cordial relationship with the PRC. "But there is a big difference between that goal and having US officials abase themselves when China's Communist rulers make outrageous demands or engage in outrageous conduct. The Clinton administration seems incapable of grasping that distinction," concluded the foreign policy expert.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BANS IMPORT OF ARGENTINE, PARAGUAYAN BEEF OVER FMD EPIDEMIC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Tuesday that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in the two South American countries.
COA officials said the import ban is not expected to affect the Republic of China's beef market because Taiwan mainly relies on the United States and Australia as its major sources for beef imports.
The ROC representative office in Buenos Aires informed the COA on Monday that an FMD epidemic has broken out among cattle population in northern Argentina bordering Paraguay and Brazil.
Acting on the notice, the COA immediately decided to ban entry of refrigerated and frozen beef that was delivered from Argentina and Paraguay after Aug. 11.
The COA also decided to tighten inspection of Argentine and Paraguayan beef that were already imported into Taiwan.

The ROC opened its market to Argentine beef for the first time last year in preparation for its accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO). In 1999, Taiwan imported about 395 tons of Argentine beef which accounted for only a small slice of the island's overall beef import market.
But beef imports from Argentina have increased rapidly this year. In the first seven months, the amount already reached 1,551 tons.
COA officials said Argentina, which recognizes Beijing but maintains substantive ties with the ROC, mainly supplies medium- and lower-price beef for the Taiwan market.

Taiwan also began to allow beef imports from Paraguay in 1999, but actual import quantity remains limited. The Paraguayan first lady just visited Taipei last month to help promote sales of Paraguayan beef to local consumers. Paraguay is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in South America.
Taiwan imports premium-grade beef mainly from the United States and Canada, medium-grade beef from Australia and New Zealand, and lower-price beef from Argentina and other Latin American countries.
COA officials said as Taiwan has many beef import sources, the import ban on Argentine and Paraguayan beef will have little impact on the local market.

In view of frequent reports of FMD outbreaks in other countries, COA officials said the council will intensify quarantine and inspection measures at airports and sea ports and call for support and cooperation of importers to prevent the spread of the animal killer disease into Taiwan.

The FMD mainly affects cloven-hoofed animals, including pigs, cattle and goats. An FMD outbreak hit Taiwan's hog ranches in 1997 and some of its cattle and goats farms were also struck by the epidemic last year, resulting in large financial losses to local livestock farmers.
