DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG MEMBERS IN AUSTRALIA HARASSED BY CHINESE DIPLOMATS

TEXT.P: The Australian Security Intelligence Organization and the Australian Federal Police revealed that they are aware of mainland Chinese harassment of Falun Gong sect members in Canberra and Sydney and are monitoring the situation, reported The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday.
The daily reported officers from both the ASIO and AFP had warned Falun Gong devotees in Canberra and Sydney of the alleged mainland Chinese campaign.

The daily reported that Chinese diplomats have also been involved in attempts to curtail the activities of the sect in Sydney and Canberra by pressuring local Australian governments to not allow Falun Gong members to take part in community activities and use community facilities.
The daily reported that Chinese diplomats have warned the Blacktown and Hurstville councils near Sydney that the sect, banned in mainland China, is destructive and should be discouraged.
But the Blacktown council has continued to allow the group to take part in its community activities and use its facilities, the daily reported.
The daily quoted some Falun Gong members in Sydney and Canberra as complaining about the Chinese diplomats' harassment, which includes allegedly tapping their home phones.
In addition, the members told the daily that they have been blacklisted by the Chinese authorities and cannot get visas to visit mainland China.
China's Vice Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi is leading a delegation to Canberra for an annual dialogue on human rights between Australia and mainland China starting on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIA PREPARING TO WELCOME ROC PRESIDENT WITH OPEN ARMS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Gambia, one of the three African diplomatic allies that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will visit during his 13-day, six-state trip, has been one of the staunchest supporters in recent years of the ROC's bid to join such international organizations as the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

Gambia, located in west Africa with a land area of 4,000 square miles and a population of 1.3 million, had a per capita income of only US$300 in 1998. The agricultural, fishery, and tourism industries are the backbone of the nation's economic development.

ROC Ambassador to Gambia Lee Chen-hsiung said that since the two nations resumed diplomatic ties in 1995, relations between the two nations have been close, with frequent visits of officials between the two nations.

Mustapha Wadda, the speaker of Gambia's National Assembly, visited the ROC at the invitation of his ROC counterpart Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, in June 1999. Foreign Minister Momodou Sedat Jobe also visited Taiwan to attend the inauguration of ROC President Chen Shui-bian this May.

Although some said that Gambia resumed diplomatic relations with Taiwan with the aim of receiving economic assistance to help improve the living standard of its people, Lee said he takes pride in sharing the ROC's economic development experience with its allies.

Lee noted that it will be significant if Taiwan can help Gambia develop quickly economically through technological cooperation and substantial assistance in agricultural technology, medical care, and road construction.

In recent years, the volume of trade between the two nations, although not large, has recorded steady growth. P.K. Chiang, former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, led a delegation to visit Gambia last year and worked out a proposal on bilateral cooperation after the visit in which he suggested that Gambian youth come to Taiwan for training.
Lee said the ROC is now pushing for the plan, with an enthusiastic response from Gambia, which he said will be beneficial to the promotion of bilateral trade cooperation.
The ROC has also sent an agricultural mission to Gambia to help it improve its rice growing technology and establish vegetable gardens.
ROC President Chen Shui-bian will also travel to Nicaragua (Aug. 17-18), Costa Rica (Aug. 18-19), Gambia (Aug. 20-21), Burkina Faso (Aug. 21-23), and Chad (Aug. 23-25).

It is expected that Gambia's President Yahya Jammeh will accord full military honors to President Chen and will bestow a medal of highest honor on Chen during his visit in recognition of the friendship and contribution extended by the ROC to Gambian economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.011 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 31.096.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 31.082 and was traded between 31.082 and 31.100.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$265 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO TAKE PART IN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY EXHIBITION IN ISTANBUL
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: Firms from the Republic of China will take part in an information technology exhibition in Istanbul, Turkey, starting from Sept. 6.
"Bilisim 2000 -- a CeBIT Event" is an exhibition being organized by HIFAS, a firm jointly established by German and Turkish companies.

Scheduled exhibitors include 50 companies from 13 countries. Besides the ROC, firms from Germany, France, the United States, Holland, Israel, Italy, Singapore, Hungary, Greece, Slovakia, the United Arab Emirates, and Turkey will join the event to showcase their wares, HIFAS General Manager Erdem Ozel said on Wednesday.

Ozel added the international exhibition will include a technology fair and several seminars, and will focus on office information, communications technology, information technology, and software. The show will wind up on Sept. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN PRESIDENT-ELECT REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Oscar Chuang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Dominican President-elect Hipolito Mejia said on Monday that he will continue to support the Republic of China in its efforts to join international organizations during his upcoming four-year stint, and revealed his plan to visit Taiwan in March next year.
Mejia made the remarks at a news conference in which he detailed policies on several key issues which his administration will adopt after he assumes the presidency on Wednesday.

Describing himself as a "most loyal friend" to the ROC, the incoming Dominican president noted that he has visited Taiwan 22 times, adding that he understands that the two countries are good partners in economic cooperation because of their similar climates and geographic features.

Although Mejia said he maintains very good relations with the former ruling Kuomintang, he voiced his desire to continue to be a loyal friend to the ROC. He also praised the performance of current Taiwan President Chen Shui-bian, a member of the Democratic Progressive Party, during his term as Taipei mayor several years ago.
On the conflict between Taipei and Beijing, Mejia said he will not touch on this problem, but vowed to continue backing Taipei in its bids to enter international organizations.

Mejia also brushed aside reports by international media that the relations existing between the ROC and the Dominican Republic are based on "money diplomacy." Rather than money, diplomatic relations between the two countries are maintained by mutual respect, he stressed, adding that ROC agricultural and fishery missions stationed here have contributed a great deal to the promotion of bilateral links.

The Dominican president-elect also claimed that he will set up an organization similar to the ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission to handle affairs related to the millions of Dominican people residing abroad.
Mejia said he is keen to pay a visit to Taiwan in March 2001, and promised to meet with Taiwanese reporters at that time.
President Chen, traveling at the head of a delegation composed of more than 200 ROC officials and business leaders, arrived here on Monday afternoon to attend Mejia's inauguration on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANKS' RATIO OF DEPOSITS TO LOANS AT 84.04 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Local banks' ratio of loans to deposits was a mere 84.04 percent at the end of June of this year, according to a Ministry of Finance (MOF) report on Taiwan's banking industry released on Tuesday.
An MOF official said that loans by local banks were much too conservative and should have been higher, and may be an indication of pessimism over the nation's economy.

The official said that the ratio of loans to deposits normally stands in the range of 100 percent to 111 percent. When the economy slackens, however, the ratio may sink below 100 percent, as bankers shy away from lending money for fears of amassing irredeemable debt.
On the contrary, when the market is in high spirits, the ratio often exceeds 100 percent, as banks do not wish to leave their capital idle, the official explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HAS FEWEST LARCENIES, FIRES AMONG MAJOR TAIWAN CITIES

TEXT.P: Taipei has the highest population density among the seven largest cities in Taiwan, with an average of 9,718 people per square kilometer, according to statistics from the Taipei city government.

Despite its high population density, Taipei city had the fewest numbers of larcenies and fires in 1999 among Taiwan's seven largest cities, with an average of 1,848 criminal cases and 1,191 thefts for every 100,000 people, and an average of 1.07 fires for every 1,000 families.

In terms of educational resources, class sizes in elementary schools and junior high schools in Taipei have gradually been getting smaller each year, with the ratio now at 17.22 students per teacher. Meanwhile, Taipei's average class size stands at 30.76 students, the lowest among Taiwan's seven largest cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO SOLVING NAVAL CAPTAIN MURDER CASE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Monday reaffirmed his administration's commitment to solving a high-profile naval captain murder case that occurred in 1993.

President Chen reiterated his commitment during a dinner party given in his honor by all overseas Chinese associations in the Dominican Republic as he started his first state visit to the Caribbean nation.

Chen told some 1,000 overseas Chinese representatives, including members of the federation of Taiwanese chambers of commerce in North America, present at the dinner that even though he is currently on an overseas trip, he is still concerned about progress in investigations of the naval captain Yin Ching-feng murder case and other related weaponry procurement scandals back in Taiwan.

Chen said "no ceiling, no limit and no deadline" are his administration's cardinal principle for probing the Yin murder case. "I don't believe that pursuing the case to the maximum would rock our country's foundation as some people fret. And even if that be the case, the probe would still not be stopped until after the truth comes out to prove our determination to wipe out corruption and 'black gold' politics."
Chen's firm declaration drew enthusiastic response from all overseas Chinese representatives.

President Chen arrived in Santo Domingo on Monday evening after an overnight stopover in Los Angeles. Chen was accorded a red-carpet welcome and full military honors upon his arrival at the airport. He was greeted by Dominican Foreign Minister Eduardo Latorre Rodriguez, ROC Ambassador to the Dominican Republic Sun Ta-cheng and hundreds of ROC expatriates in the Caribbean nation.

Chen will attend the inauguration of President-elect Hipolito Mejia on Wednesday. The Dominican Republic is the first leg of his hectic 13-day, six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at cementing the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies in the face of mainland China's intensified offensive to isolate Taiwan in the international community.

During his stay, Chen will hold bilateral talks with both outgoing Dominican President Leonel Fernandez and incoming President Mejia on various existing cooperative projects and other matters of mutual concern.

Chen was given a grand welcome, complete with dragon and lion dances, upon his arrival at the hotel. Chinese community leaders said President Chen's visit to the Dominican Republic is of great significance. They pledged full support for the ROC's new government.

Ambassador Sun then briefed President Chen on the current ROC-Dominican ties. Sun said the two countries have traditionally enjoyed close friendship. But Sun said the incoming Dominican ruling party is basically a left-wing party and has many pro-Beijing members.

In addition, Sun said, mainland China has set up a trade office in Santo Domingo and plans to build a power plant in the Dominican Republic. Beijing also offers preferential tariff rates for Dominican products. "All these moves are aimed at tempting the Caribbean republic to switch its diplomatic allegiance," Sun said, adding that the ROC Embassy here has stepped efforts to strengthen ties with the Dominican parliament to win its support for the ROC's national cause.

After listening to Sun's briefing, Chen said he remains confident in future ROC-Dominican relations. Noting that incoming Dominican President Mejia has made 22 visits to Taiwan over past years, Chen said Mejia is friendly toward the ROC.

Chen is the first ROC president to visit the Dominican Republic since the two countries forged diplomatic ties 60 years ago. Chen encouraged all ROC embassy staff to hold confidence in ROC-Dominican relations.

Speaking at a dinner with overseas Chinese representatives, Chen said this is his second trip to the Dominican Republic. "I first visited this beautiful country in 1984 when I was a Taipei City Council councilor. I met with the then-Dominican president and has fond memory about that visit. This is why I have chosen the Dominican Republic as the first destination of my first overseas visit as the ROC's head of state," he explained.

Chen also encouraged Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest more in the Dominican Republic to help boost its economic development and consolidate ROC-Dominican diplomatic ties. Chen's first post-inauguration journey will also take him to Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America as well as the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad in West Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRACK II ROUNDTABLE MEETING OPENS IN US
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A roundtable meeting of scholars from both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the United States opened in New York on Monday.

The focus of the meeting was the track II cross-strait communications channel, an alternative to the current semi-official contacts between Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). The gathering was sponsored by the US-based National Committee on American Foreign Policy.

As this was the first roundtable meeting since the March presidential election in Taiwan, many issues were hotly debated. The election was a watershed event in Taiwan politics, with the Kuomintang losing its five-decade grip on political power in Taiwan, and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which had a record of supporting Taiwan independence, taking the helm of the central government.
Issues discussed at the New York meeting included the cross-strait policy of Taiwan's new administration, the current situation of party politics in Taiwan, and mainland China's policy toward Taiwan.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who represented the KMT at the meeting, suggested that both sides of the Taiwan Strait go back to the cosensus reached in 1992 -- the "one China, separate interpretations" basis for relations -- so as to help establish a systematic dialogue channel to solve pressing issues between the two sides.

Ma, who has served as vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, noted that the 1992 agreement helped pave the way for the first meeting between the heads of the SEF and ARATS in Singapore in 1993.
Ma said that he was not optimistic about the resumption of a cross-strait dialogue in the short term, saying that if both sides want to have a breakthrough, they must first show sincerity.

Ma said that President's Chen had showed a great deal of good will in his inaugural speech, in which he pledged that if Beijing does not use force against Taiwan, Taiwan will not declare independence and will not change the official name of the Republic of China.

The mainland also needs to know that if it does not give up its strategy of intimidating the island and squeezing Taiwan diplomatically, it is unlikely that the ROC will go back to the negotiations table, Ma said.

Two mainland China and four Taiwan scholars delivered papers on the cross-strait situation during the meeting. Hsiao Bi-khim, adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, represented Taiwan's ruling DPP, while Wu Juei-kuo represented the island's People First Party, another opposition party.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA, MAINLAND CHINA TO HOLD HUMAN RIGHTS DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer will open the formal session of the fourth human rights dialogue between Australia and mainland China on Tuesday evening.
In a statement faxed to CNA, Downer said both Australia and mainland China will decide on activities to be conducted under the Human Rights Technical Assistance Program.
He said the delegates from mainland China attending the dialogue will increase from five ministries to nine ministries and agencies, reflecting the importance of the meeting.
The Chinese delegation is led by Vice Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi, and the Australian group is headed by Deputy Secretary Miles Kupa of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
"The meeting is expected to cover a large number of human rights issues and concerns," Downer said.

Aside from attending the dialogue, the Chinese delegates will visit various organizations in Sydney and Canberra, including the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, a juvenile detention center and a center for indigenous education.
They will also meet the Joint Standing Committee for Foreign Affairs, Defense and Trade, and attend a question-and-answer session in the House of Representatives in Canberra, Downer said.
It is understood that the Australian delegates would raise China's human rights abuses, including persecution of Tibetan prisoners and dissidents in the mainland's democracy movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF THE GENERAL STAFF ARRIVES IN NANTOU COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: A top-level military official arrived in Nantou County on Tuesday to make an inspection of ongoing earthquake relief efforts there.

Accompanied by several senior officers of the nation's armed forces, General Tang Yao-ming, the chief of the General Staff, listened to a report on disaster relief efforts in areas hardest hit by last year's Sept. 21 earthquake.

Chief of Nantou County Pang Pai-hsien made several requests regarding the reconstruction work, and expressed his appreciation for the armed forces' assistance in the wake of the disaster. He added that reconstruction work continues to depend on the help of Taiwan's armed forces, expressing the hope that military experts will blow up the many huge rocks which have been deposited by mudslides and rock slides.
Tang replied by noting that President Chen Shui-bian, after his Aug. 11 inspection of Nantou, commanded the military to assist in the demolition of boulders blocking the Chitou-Alishan Highway.
Tang added that the commanding general of the Tenth Field Army maintains district command centers all around Taiwan, and the county should directly contact these centers for assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNION OF CHUNGHWA TELECOM WORKERS STAGES PROTEST IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Members of the labor union of Chunghwa Telecom Co. will stage a mass demonstration in Taipei on Wednesday in protest of alleged inefficiencies in the government's efforts to protect their rights following the company's privatization next year.
Over 10,000 workers, mostly Chunghwa labor union members but also members of labor unions of other state-run companies, will join the demonstration, organizers said.
The union decided to push ahead with the planned demonstration after negotiations with officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications broke down Monday evening.

During the talks, ministry officials rejected demands from the union that workers' salaries should not be cut and that their mandatory retirement age should remain unchanged at 65 after Chunghwa's privatization.

With so many workers protesting, Chunghwa's telecommunication services will be adversely affected. However, union leaders reassured the public that automated equipment, fixed-line phone service and cell phone service would all still be available.
The demonstration will begin at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall at 9:00 a.m. on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVES SENTENCED TO LIFE IMPRISONMENT FOR DUMPING TOXIC WASTE

TEXT.P: Executives and drivers of two factories were sentenced to harsh jail terms on Tuesday by the Kaohsiung Prosecutors' Office on charges of dumping toxic waste solvents in Kaoping Creek in southern Taiwan last month.

According to Public Prosecutor General M. L. Shih, Yang Wen-hsiung, president of the Eternal Chemical Company, the producer of the toxic waste, as well as Hung Shang-ching and Hung Yu-sheng, manager and deputy manager of the Shengli Chemical Company, which handled the toxic waste, and truck driver Lo Shou-kuan, were given life-long prison terms for their respective roles in the dumping.
The two companies -- Eternal and Shengli -- were also hit with fines of NT$260 million and NT$160 million, respectively.

Additionally, Chang Cheng-chun, Shengli's contractor in the case, was also sentenced to life imprisonment, while another 19 people involved in the crime were handed jail terms ranging from three years to 12 years, Shih said.

Shih said all the defendants were given harsh sentences because they had engaged in "greedy and selfish" activities which posed a serious threat to public security, water conservation and environmental protection.
Since no one has been reported to have been harmed or killed, they were convicted on charges of attempted murder, Shih noted.

The incident took place on July 12, when trucks carrying toxic waste containing the carcinogenic chemical dimethyl benzene were caught red-handed dumping the substance into Kaoping Creek, a major source of tap water for Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city and home to 3 million people.
The event, the latest in a series of similar activities, shocked the nation, and tap water services in Kaohsiung were cut off for the following three days.

Although Eternal and Shengli were already ordered to shut down operations and have had their licenses revoked, Shih said that prosecutors will continue investigating the case to determine where other toxic wastes have been dumped, and whether government officials are guilty for negligence of duty.
It is estimated that more than 400 tons of toxic substances were produced by Eternal from June to the time of the firm's shut-down.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR DEFENSE DRILL HELD IN NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An annual joint civil and military air defense exercise was held in northern Taiwan on Tuesday to simulate emergency rescues, riot mob dispersal, and evacuation procedures in the event of enemy air raids or missile attacks.

A total of 10,094 police officers, military police, voluntary policemen, and civilian defense personnel were involved in clearing the streets of all traffic and directing pedestrians into bomb shelters during the 20-minute exercise in the cities of Taipei, Keelung, and Hsinchu, and the counties of Ilan, Taipei, Taoyuan, and Hsinchu.

Wanan No. 23 is a series of drills being held throughout Taiwan. It began in the central regions on Aug. 1, was held in southern Taiwan on Aug. 4., and was again held in eastern Taiwan in Aug. 7. It is scheduled to be held in the outlying islands of Kinmen, Penghu, and Matsu on Wednesday.

The exercise follows the rescue model imposed after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake, and focuses on the operations of each county and city's coordination centers for civil defense mobilization in order to improve the public's ability to react. Local garrison forces are also called in to support and coordinate with civil defense forces.
The exercise included a simulation of several emergency situations at an abandoned chemical fertilizer plant in Hsinchu City.

First, under the premise of a hypothetical drop in pro-unification sentiment followed by mainland China attempting to take Taiwan by force with missile and fighter attacks, a "mob" of 500 men gathered in front of a mock-up of Hsinchu City Hall to simulate an insurrection to force the government to enter into peace talks with mainland China.

As the simulated drill at the abandoned industrial site went on, riot police and water cannons moved in to disperse the increasingly aggressive crowd after the deputy mayor failed to talk them out of leaving -- as planned.

The exercises also allowed related forces to practice rescue efforts in the event of a bombing run on a Hsinchu chemical plant, including fires, ruptured gas lines, and collapsed buildings with people trapped inside. Coordinated teams from law enforcement, medical, fire fighting, and health sectors joined in the simulated rescue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORT ON PLA FIGHTERS IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Tuesday denied a report that mainland Chinese military aircraft flew close to the center line of the Taiwan Strait on the eve of President Chen Shui-bian's overseas trip.

Unidentified military sources said four mainland Chinese jet fighters conducted offshore patrol missions on Aug. 12, two of which flew close to the middle line of the Taiwan Strait at around 9:53 a.m. on Saturday.

The Republic of China Air Force then went on heightened alert and kept a close watch on the mainland fighters' flight paths and movements, the sources said, adding that the alert was not lifted until between 10:40 a.m. and 10:50 a.m.

The mainland aircraft were reportedly J-8 fighters, the mainland version of Russian-made MiG 21s, which the sources said might have taken off from a mainland air base in northern Fujian Province, located opposite Taiwan.

The report caused concern as Chen left Taipei on Sunday for his first post-inauguration overseas visit which will take him to six of the ROC's diplomatic allies -- the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

However, both the Air Force Operations Command and the Air Force General Headquarters denied the report, saying that because of rainy weather on Aug. 12, no PLA fighters took off for offshore patrol missions.

A senior officer with the Air Force Operations Command said he was on duty at the command that day. "I fully remember the situation on the day. Because of bad weather, no mainland Chinese warplanes flew close to the center line of the Taiwan Strait which separates Taiwan from the mainland," he said firmly.

According to the officer, it is all too common for mainland warplanes to conduct patrol missions off the Fujian coast, commonly known as "offshore patrols" in the mainland military jargon. "But there were absolutely no mainland fighters flying along the middle line of the Taiwan Strait last Saturday," he stressed.
The officer further said it is understandable that local people are concerned about Taiwan Strait security during the president's absence.
In fact, the officer said, the air force has gone on heightened alert and maintains constant close monitoring of mainland China's military movement.

MND spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding also said mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) has not conducted any abnormal movement in the past few days and has only embarked on routine training exercises.
Kung said the ROC military has consistently kept a close watch on PLA activities. "We have not detected any changes in the PLA's deployment so far," he added.
Meanwhile, MND officials said Chen's overseas visit will not affect the schedule of various military training programs.

For instance, the officials went on, the Wan-An No. 23 civil air defense drill, part of the annual combined services military training exercise code-named Han Kuang No. 16, was held on Tuesday afternoon as scheduled.
The officials said all Han Kuang No. 16-related preparations and training drills will proceed as scheduled despite Chen's absence.
The Han Kuang No. 16 exercise will last for six months in order to upgrade the three military branches' capability to engage in three-dimensional or amphibious warfare.

After his return from the Aug. 13-25 overseas journey, Chen will preside over a computerized simulation confrontation between two military units, one of which will act as an enemy force. The president will also review all troops taking part in the annual Han Kuang exercise.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY POPULATION INCREASES TO 8.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's elderly population had increased to 8.5 percent of the island's total population as of the end of 1999, according to a report released on Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS).

DGBAS officials said their statistics show that every 100 middle-aged individuals in Taiwan have to support an average of 31 children and 12 elderly people. Compared to 1971, the dependent population has decreased from 72 to 43. However, the number of elderly has increased from five to 12 as a result of the changing population structure in recent years.

The officials added that the median age of the population has soared to 31.6 years, an indication that Taiwan's population is graying, while the population growth has decreased to 0.75 percent, the lowest in Taiwan's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO TACKLE NUC ISSUE AFTER RETURN FROM OVERSEAS VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has not ruled out the possibility of serving as chairman of the National Unification Council (NUC), a senior Presidential Office official said on Tuesday.
Chen Tze-nan, acting secretary-general to the President, said President Chen does not want to see the NUC become a rubber stamp if he assumes the NUC chairmanship.

Chen said the president truly has considered inviting a political heavyweight or other social celebrity to head the NUC. "But no final decision has been made. The president will tackle the issue after his return from his current overseas visit," he noted.

The NUC was established in 1991 to serve as a presidential advisory board offering advice concerning promotion of relations across the Taiwan Strait and unification of the two sides in accordance with the National Unification Guidelines which calls for phased development of cross-strait ties.

During the Kuomintang era, the NUC was headed by the president himself. President Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has reportedly been reluctant to assume the NUC chairmanship for fears of drawing backlash from DPP members.
The late DPP Chairman Huang Hsin-chieh rejected former President Lee Teng-hui's invitation to serve as the NUC vice chairman because of the DPP's pro-independence stand.

However, Chen Tze-nan said President Chen will not rule out the possibility of serving as NUC chairman because he attaches great importance to the development of cross-strait relations. In his May 20 inaugural speech, President Chen also promised not to abolish the NUC and the unification guidelines.
Chen Tze-nan said President Chen will certainly honor his promise.
Nevertheless, he said, the Nub's role, function and membership should be adjusted in line with changes in the Taiwan Strait situation and local political and social climate.

"And the adjustment direction and related details are not issues that President Chen alone can decide," Chen said, adding that the Presidential Office hopes to arrange for a summit meeting between President Chen and KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the first week of September to enable them to exchange views on the issue.
Despite losing its grip on power, the KMT still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan's parliament.

Following the proposed Chen-Lien meeting, the Presidential Office will push for the convention of a roundtable meeting between President Chen and the top leaders of three major parties -- the ruling DPP, the KMT and the People First Party.
"The roundtable meeting can also provide a forum for the discussion of the NUC issue" said Chen Tze-nan.

Chen Tze-nan visited the legislature on Tuesday to send appointment certificates to legislators of different parties who have been appointed to sit on a special cross-strait task force headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.

The 25-member task force, composed of legislators, social celebrities, scholars and experts, will also serve as an advisory panel offering counseling services to President Chen to help forge a national consensus on cross-strait ties.

Chen said he believes that both the NUC and the cross-party cross-strait panel can co-exist and work smoothly to help forge cross-strait rapprochement and achieve a breakthrough to the long-stalled cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE POET BEI LING ARRESTED IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese poet Bei Ling, who is chief editor of the quarterly literary magazine Tendency and has permanent US resident status, has been formally arrested in Beijing, a human rights group said here Tuesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said police picked him up in Beijing and confiscated 2,000 copies of the latest issue of the magazine on Aug. 11. The police has informed his family of his arrest, but did not give the reason for the arrest. The information center said he might be indicted on charges of attempting "to overthrow state power."

The quarterly magazine, which was started in 1993, carries poems and "underground articles," which are often seen by Chinese communist authorities as unfit for publication. The Chinese authorities have however adopted a tolerant attitude toward the magazine until now. Bei's arrest is an indication that the Chinese government is tightening its control over literary works, the information center said.
Bei, 40, went to the United States in 1988 and has become a permanent resident of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA RELEASES POLITICAL PRISONER FOR PNTR STATUS: REPORT

TEXT.P: A human rights group alleged Tuesday that China has released a political prisoner early in order to help secure the status of permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) with the United States.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Liu Wensheng, founder of the outlawed "Social Democratic Party of China," was released from prison on Aug. 9, about 20 months before the end of his 10-year prison term.

The information center said that the US Congress will soon vote on a bill that would grant China PNTR status if enacted, and that the Congressional vote and his early release are related. His name was on a list of Chinese political prisoners given recently to the Congress by American labor groups, who have been lobbying against the legislation, it pointed out.

Liu, 32, was a student leader during the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement. He was arrested in April, 1992 and was sentenced to 10-years in prison on charges of committing "anti-revolutionary crimes," because he established the Social Democratic Party. It was one of the three major political parties established by dissidents after the 1989 Tiananmen massacre in Beijing.
The Chinese government has promptly outlawed the political parties and sentenced more than 100 of their leaders to long prison terms, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRTH CONTROL VACCINE EXPECTED TO HELP CUT STRAY DOG POPULATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan researchers working on a therapy for ovarian cancer have come up with a vaccine which they believe can also be used to help cut the number of stray dogs and cats on the island in a cheap and humane way.

Production know-how for the vaccine, described as a vaccination against gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) using toxin receptor-binding domain-conjugated GnRH repeats, was transferred to a local business group on Tuesday for commercial production, according to sources from Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute.

Addressing a ceremony marking the signing of an agreement between Academia Sinica's Institute of Molecular Biology (ASIMB) and the Chyang Sheng Group, ASIMB Director Shen Che-kun said the cooperation marks another example of intellectual property transfer from academic circles to the private industrial sector so that research and development of cutting-edge technologies can be commercially carried out on products that will benefit people and animals.

The researchers reported in the July 15 edition of Cancer Research, the organ of the American Association for Cancer Research, that the ovaries of female rabbits injected with the vaccine degenerated with just a single dose, rendering the animals permanently infertile.
Researcher Jaulang Hwang also noted that the vaccination can also be used to treat diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, as well as other forms of cancer.

According to Chen Jen-fa, chairman of the Chyang Sheng Group, the vaccination method is expected to help achieve effective control of Taiwan's population of stray dogs, as well as offering a pain- and stress-free method of neutering domestic pets.

Chen added that in Taiwan, the current cost of castrating a male cat is about NT$700 (US$22.6), while it costs NT$2,000 to spay a female cat. The vaccine, to be manufactured by a newly founded Chyang Sheng offshoot, will cost only about half that, and does not require surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACM SIGGRAPH ESTABLISHES TAIPEI OFFICE

TEXT.P: The US-based Association for Computing Machinery (ACM SIGGRAPH) on Tuesday established a Taipei office to provide a gathering place for local animation professionals and promote technical exchanges between local and international animators.

ACM SIGGRAPH, whose members were responsible for creating the computer graphics for such box office hits as Titanic and Toy Story, will hold an international computer animation symposium on Sept. 8 and 9 at the Taipei International Conference Center.
Daniel Loeb of Digital Domain, which was the special effects company responsible for Titanic, and Jin Liiou of Antz fame, are scheduled to speak at the conference.

According to ACM SIGGRAPH, the Taipei office will not only serve as a bridge linking Taiwan's animation technique exchanges with the world, but will also organize conferences and seminars on different computer animation programs such as Maya and Softimage to nurture local animation talent.
ACM SIGGRAPH, which was founded over 30 years ago, has local chapters in more that 40 cities worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN TOTALS US$ 13 B. IN FIRST 7 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan in the first seven months of this year reached US$13.26 billion, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The statistics show that Taiwan exported US$9.4 billion-worth of goods to Japan in the first seven months of this year, while importing US$22.68 billion-worth of goods from Japan, creating a deficit that was US$3.51 billion up from the same period of last year.
The DGBAS attributed the increase to the boom in the local information technology and machinery industries that caused increased demand for imports of components and spare parts.

In terms of value, Taiwan's imports from Japan increased by 39.1 percent in value in the first seven months of the year as compared with the same period of a year ago, representing 27.9 percent of Taiwan's total import value and an increase of one percentage point.

Machinery and parts topped the list of imports, with a total value of US$7.04 billion, an increase of 49.4 percent over the previous year. This was followed by electronics equipment, with a value of US$5.67 billion, or an increase of 42.6 percent.
During the same period, Taiwan's exports to Japan, an increase of 43.8 percent over the previous year and representing 5.3 percent of Taiwan's total exports.

Machinery and spare parts also topped the list of exports, with a value of US$3.34 billion, an increase of 66.4 percent over the previous year, followed by electronics equipment valued at US42.31 billion, an increase of 52.1 percent over the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIEN CHAN RETURNS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan returned to Taipei on Tuesday after winding up a visit to the United States and Canada.
Lien told the local press that he was deeply impressed by the loyalty and patriotism demonstrated by overseas Chinese in the regions he had visited.
He said that he also had been encouraged by KMT members now residing abroad, and said that the KMT will redouble its efforts to carry out party reform so as to revive the former ruling party.
Lien, accompanied by his wife and Jason Hu, director of the KMT Cultural Affairs Department, left Taipei on Aug. 3 for a two-week visit to San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Vancouver.
In addition to stepping up its internal reorganization, the KMT should also work to strengthen its relations with international organizations, Lien said.
On hand at the airport to greet Lien upon arrival were the KMT's five Vice Chairmen -- Wang Jin-pyng, Vincent Siew, Chiang Chung-ling, Wu Poh-hsiung and Lin Cheng-chih.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO STREAMLINE PARTY STRUCTURE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang has decided to streamline its party structure, beginning at the end of August, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said on Tuesday.
Lin said that the KMT plans to finalize its framework and personnel establishment at the end of August and to abolish the party's Taiwan Provincial Committee in October.

According to KMT's reform plan, the 18 units under the direct jurisdiction of its Central Committee will be merged into four major departments, with the number of professional party members who deal with party affairs being simultaneously cut.

After finalizing the framework and personnel establishment, the Central Committee will proceed with the incorporation of organization and assignment of duties in September, and then formally abolish the KMT's Taiwan Provincial Committee in October.
Lin said that the current party members who deal with party affairs in the Taiwan Provincial Committee will, in principle, all be dispatched to the local party committees around the island.

However, reports have surfaced that while some of the Taiwan Provincial Committee administrative party members have indeed been posted to local committees, many of them have expressed their willingness to transfer to the Central Committee.
Meanwhile, the KMT has put forth a preferential retirement plan for such members in a bid to encourage them to retire, although fewer than 10 members have taken up the offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINATRUST BANK TO OFFER INTERNET LOAN SERVICES
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Jason Lo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinatrust Commercial Bank signed an agreement with US Internet firm Trade Card on Tuesday to jointly offer services to export and import companies, according to business sources in Hong Kong.
The agreement will allow such companies to conduct cross-border trade and acquire loans via the Internet, the sources said.
By signing the agreement, Chinatrust becomes the first Taiwanese bank to operate Internet loan services, the sources went on.

The agreement, jointly inked by Chinatrust Vice President Hsu Chien-chi and Trade Card Chairman and CEO Kurt Cavano, will allow Trade Card members in Taiwan, Hong Kong and the United States to conduct cross-border trade through Trade Card's Internet systems and to apply for loans provided by Chinatrust via the Internet.

Hsu said the cooperation will enable Chinatrust to offer faster and more efficient services to Taiwanese companies. The operation will also help Taiwanese companies to secure trade links with their business partners in Hong Kong and the United States, he added.

Cavano noted that to meet the ever-increasing needs of export and import companies in Taiwan, Hong Kong and the United States, Trade Card chose to cooperate with Chinatrust, which maintains operations in all three places.
Trade Card offers high-efficiency Internet services to traders, while Chinatrust provides loan services, enabling the trading houses to secure cross-border trade on a fast track.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT'S SON TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: John Chang, an illegitimate son of former Republic of China President Chiang Ching-kuo and a former high-ranking ROC official, will visit his father's ancestral home on Aug. 23 to acknowledge his relationship with the Chiang family.

Chang, who was Secretary-General of the Presidential Office under ex-President Lee Teng-hui, said that he will first make an offering to the ancestors of the Chiang Clan at the clan shrine in Hsikou Township, Fenghwa County, Zejiang Province. He added that he will also burn incense at the tombs of his great-grandmother and grand mother, his great-great-grandfather and great-great-great uncle.

The late President Chiang Ching-kuo never acknowledged Chang and his late brother Hsiao-tzu as his sons. Chang said that he began to make preparations for a trip to mainland China after he stepped down from office in March, and added that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has approved his travel plan on humanitarian grounds.
In addition to his wife and children, Chang said that his late brother's widow and children will join him on the trip.

He said he will go to Ningpo on Aug. 24, and will lunch with mainland-based Taiwan businessmen on Aug. 25. The next day, he will proceed to Shanghai, where he will lunch with Taiwanese businessmen there.

The office in charge of Taiwan affairs in Shanghai will honor him at a dinner party later that day, and he will visit the Shanghai home of the Kuomintang's founding father, Dr. Sun Yet-sen, the following day.
Chang and his family will then proceed to Quilin, Kwangxi Province, where he will offer incense at the tomb of his mother Chang Ya-juo on Aug. 29.
He is expected to return to Taiwan on Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIDNAP SUSPECTS ARRESTED, VICTIM RESCUED

TEXT.P: Taipei police on Tuesday announced that they had rescued a kidnapped major stockholder of the Askey Computer Co. and arrested all his abductors.
Police said that Wu Yian-lung, 36, and Chai Yung-sen, 35, were allegedly the masterminds behind the July 24 kidnapping of Chou Pu-pin.

They allegedly hired Kuo Kuo-feng, 27, and Kuan Chien-ming, 23 -- two mainland Chinese who were in Taiwan illegally -- to guard Chou, while Hu Yi-kuang, a taxi driver, committed the actual kidnapping.
Chai and Hu were arrested days earlier, while Kuo and Kuan were arrested in an empty house in Taipei County on Tuesday.

Wu was caught by waiting police as he was returning to the house to pick up his car, also on Tuesday. He denied taking part in the kidnapping, saying that it was entirely a financial dispute between Chou and Chai and adding that all he did was find the two mainlanders to guard Chou.

Police revealed that until March 16, Chai had worked for the Investigation Bureau, where he was in charge of the security of Hsinchu's Science-based Industrial Park, home to some of Taiwan's largest electronics and computer companies -- including Askey.

Chai's alleged involvement sparked concern in the park that if an investigator in charge of park safety and security can break the law, it will be difficult for companies to trust law enforcers in the future

Police added that the kidnapping was apparently a well-planned crime because Chai and Wu never showed up on the day of the kidnapping and Chai fled to mainland China afterward, while Wu continued to give orders to Hu, Kuo, and Kuan via mobile phone.

Police said that they had locked onto Hu from very early in the investigation and listened in on his mobile phone calls. Through the telephone conversations between Hu and Wu, police were able to locate the hostage and move in to make the rescue and arrests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK INDEX REGAINS GROUND

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange reversed its downward trend on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index rising 157.84 points to close at 8,003.53.
Daily market turnover totaled NT$72.99 billion in moderate trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS TO LEAVE FOR MAINLAND VISIT NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators have finally decided to leave for a long-planned visit to mainland China next week, party sources said on Wednesday.
According to the sources, the PFP parliamentary delegation will be headed by veteran Legislator Liu Sung-fan, also a former Legislative Yuan speaker.

The sources said the delegation will focus on meeting with Taiwanese business people in Shenzhen, Xiamen and Shanghai. "As the main purpose of the visit is to serve our people doing business on the mainland, the group has no plan to visit Beijing, mainland China's political center," said Legislator Chiu Chuang-liang.

Chiu said the group is tentatively scheduled to leave for the mainland visit on Aug. 24 after mainland leaders end their annual policy review meeting at Beidaihe, a summer resort on the outskirts of Beijing.
Nevertheless, Chiu said, if mainland leaders cranked out any unfavorable decisions toward Taiwan, the PFP delegation will call off its mainland travel plan.
Chiu said former Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao may join the delegation on its visit to Shanghai, the last leg of the group's mainland trip.
Chiu further said the delegation looks forward to helping Taiwan business people resolve their problems during its upcoming mainland visit.
"Therefore, the mission members do not expect to meet with high-ranking mainland officials," Chiu said, adding that the group will not request for meeting with senior mainland leaders.

Except for Taiwanese business executives, Chiu said, the group may only contact local-level mainland administrators and officials of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a Beijing-based quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Chiu said the delegation hopes to exchange views with mainland administrators and ARATS officials on practical issues regarding cross-strait exchanges, including illegal mainland immigrants to Taiwan, cross-strait intermarriage and farm trade.

The PFP, which was formed after the Republic of China's March 18 presidential election, first planned to organize a legislative group to visit the mainland in June, but later postponed the travel plan as PFP Chairman James Soong was reluctant to endorse it.

Soong, a charismatic former Taiwan governor who lost his presidential bid with a very narrow margin, and PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung have said they are unlikely to visit the mainland in the near future.

The PFP has become even more cautious in arranging a mainland trip after President Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, recently criticized opposition lawmakers for a rush to visit the mainland following Taiwan's transition of power from the Kuomintang to the DPP in May.
Chiu said the PFP legislative group will keep a low profile concerning its mainland visit to avoid causing misunderstanding or criticism of its mainland travel purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM WORKERS TAKE IT TO THE STREETS

TEXT.P: Some 9,000 labor union members of Chunghwa Telecom Co. and their supporters on Wednesday took to the streets to appeal for their rights in the face of the imminent privatization of the largest telecommunications corporation in Taiwan.
The union decided to push ahead with the planned demonstration after negotiations with officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) broke down Monday evening.

The union members demanded that workers' salaries not be cut and that their mandatory retirement age should remain unchanged at 65 after Chunghwa's privatization, but their requests were rejected by MOTC officials during the negotiations.

The group of demonstrators, which also included family members of the Chunghwa employees and labor union members of 13 other industrial associations and state-run enterprises including Taiwan Railway Administration, assembled at around 9:40 a.m. at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall where they proceeded to the Executive Yuan to make clear their appeal.

Shouting slogans and waving banners, the demonstrators also condemned Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan for her recent comments that some Chunghwa labor union members were being "insatiably greedy."

They demanded that Yeh step down from her ministerial position and asked that Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chih-kuo not take up his latest appointment as Chunghwa Telecom chairman, replacing Chen Yao, who resigned last week to protest against the government's tampering with Chunghwa Telecom's stock price before the company was listed on the stock market.

The selling off of Chunghwa Telecom's shares in late August was part of the first phase of a privatization plan in which a total of 33 percent of the government's holding shares in Chunghwa Telecom will be sold off.

A few days before Chen's resignation, Chunghwa Telecom Vice President Lee Ching-chiang, 61, was found dead in the company building's lobby. Lee's relatives and colleagues were quoted as saying he suffered from depression and insomnia.

Lee's death came after Chunghwa Telecom announced a NT$104 (US$3.35) base price for the upcoming share sell-off, taking a further step towards eventual privatization. Chunghwa Telecom authorities said Lee's death was unrelated to the stock sale.

Trying to soothe the protesters, Mao, slated to be the next Chunghwa Telecom chairman, managed to deliver a speech to them at noon when the demonstration lines approached the Control Yuan headquarters.
As a vice minister who is set to head the soon-to-be privatized Chunghwa Telecom, Mao said his first encounter with Chunghwa Telecom colleagues "on such an occasion was awkwardly strange."
Mao was castigated by the protesters when he said issues pertaining to the welfare of Chunghwa Telecom workers are "internal affairs" of the company.

Mao was unsuccessful in soothing the demonstrators, who said his rank was too low and demanded talks with "higher-level officials." Mao later accompanied his new colleagues to the Executive Yuan, where they met with legislators to hold talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAIL TO OFFER 15,000 JOB OPENINGS TO ABORIGINALS

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) promised on Wednesday to offer some 15,000 job openings to the island's aboriginal people during construction of the high speed railway and after its completion.

THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing and Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu jointly signed an agreement on Wednesday highlighting the THSRC's intention of providing job opportunities to aboriginal citizens so as to help improve their livelihood.
Under the agreement, CLA will first offer them career training to provide them with the skills required by the THSRC.

During the signing ceremony, Ing said the aboriginal people are not only welcome to work for THSRC on the civil construction projects during the five-year development period, but they will also be asked to stay on as maintenance staff once the railway begins operation.

Initially, the 11 civil construction works along the proposed 345-km high speed rail system will create 1,600 job openings for aboriginal workers, Ing said, adding that eventually a total of 15,000 jobs are expected to be created for this sector of Taiwan's society.

The multibillion-dollar high speed railway that will connect Taiwan's two largest cities -- Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south -- will pass through 13 cities and counties and 77 urban and rural townships.
The trains using the high speed railway will have an average speed of 300 km per hour and will be able to shuttle passengers between Taipei and Kaohsiung in about 87 minutes.
The high speed railway, the first of its kind in Taiwan, is expected to become operational by October 2005.

It is also Taiwan's first infrastructure project to be built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model, under which private firms will build and operate the system for a set period of time before turning over the management to the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STEPS UP ANTI-INDEPENDENCE 'UNITED FRONT' TRICK AGAINST DPP

TEXT.P: Mainland China has stepped up its anti-Taiwan independence "united front" tactics against the Republic of China's new ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Presidential Office sources said on Wednesday.

Quoting mainland China's internal documents, the sources said Beijing will strengthen its relations with Taiwan's pro-unification New Party and People First Party (PFP) and actively court the island's largest opposition party the Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 20 and now still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan or parliament.

As part of its "united front" trick, the sources said, mainland authorities sponsored a series of anti-independence, pro-unification seminars in southeastern mainland cities located opposite Taiwan, including Shenzhen, Shantou and Xiamen, before Taiwan's March 18 presidential election with an apparent attempt to sway Taiwan voters away from DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian.

At that time, mainland authorities invited Taiwan politicians supporting Beijing's cherished "one China" principle to attend those seminars whose theme focused on blasting the DPP's pro-independence party charter and Chen's policy proposals concerning relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Despite Beijing's intimidation, Chen still managed to win the presidential election. Against this backdrop, Beijing has intensified its anti-independence "united front" trick. As part of the drive, Beijing will join forces with the European Chinese Peaceful Unification Promotion Association (ECPUPA) to sponsor a seminar in Berlin from Aug. 26-27 to boost its cause.

Presidential Office sources said ECPUPA President Zhang Manxin traveled to Beijing earlier this week to discuss with mainland officials in charge of Taiwan affairs the lists of mainland Chinese and Taiwan attendees to the seminar.

The sources said 56 mainland delegates, including Zhang Jincheng, vice president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- and Wan Guoquan, vice chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, will attend the meeting.

Meanwhile, 108 delegates from major pro-unification organizations in Taiwan will also take part in the two-day seminar. Among the Taiwan delegates will be Liang Su-jung, a former Legislative Yuan speaker and head of the Cross-Taiwan Strait Peaceful Unification Promotion Association.
Presidential Office sources said Shi Hwei-you, vice chairman and secretary-general of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), has also been invited to attend the meeting.
Both SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Sources said the National Security Council under the Presidential Office called a meeting earlier this month to explore the feasibility of Shi's attendance to the Berlin meeting. But no final decision has been made so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FOREIGN MINISTER URGES M'LAND CHINA TO REDUCE NUCLEAR ARSENAL

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has urged mainland China to follow the steps taken by the United States and Russia and reduce its nuclear weapons arsenal.

In an interview with The Australian on the eve of a human rights dialogue with mainland China, Downer said both the US presidential candidates -- Al Gore and George W. Bush -- have committed themselves to reducing the US nuclear arsenal and Russia has similar strong views.

"We would like to see a similar commitment made by China. I make no apology for that. We would like to see China, instead of building its nuclear weapons capability, reducing its nuclear weapons capability," Downer said.
"We would like to see all the nuclear weapons states and the nuclear threshold states undertaking that task," he added.

Without naming mainland China, Downer said that he is also concerned about the transfer of missile technology around the world -- a long-standing Western complaint against Beijing, the daily reported.

He repeated earlier comments that the proposed US nuclear missile defense system is defensive in nature and that there is no reason for any country to build up its nuclear arsenal to counter the system.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC ENVOY SAYS AUSTRALIA HOSTAGE TO ITS ONE-CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: A former Republic of China envoy to Canberra said that Australia has become a hostage to its one-China policy to the detriment of its commercial interests with Taiwan.

In an interview with The Australian on Friday, Dr. Liu Polun, former representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra, said Australia had lost a golden opportunity to supply Taiwan with 8 million tons of liquefied natural gas (LNG) because it was suspicious that Taipei might use its commercial leverage to influence Australia's foreign policy.
He said Taiwan wanted to sign an agreement with Australia because it wanted to diversify its import sources. Liu told the daily that the LNG proposal to Australia was purely a commercial proposition.
"Australia has the advantage of having proven LNG reserves, especially in the North West Shelf where there is a possibility of expanding production to 7.5 million tons a year," said Liu.
"The figure could be doubled if the Gordon fields are included. We think that Australia's production capacity can be lifted to around 16 million tons a year," he added.

Liu said he was disappointed that the Australian government mixed business with politics, adding that if only Canberra had been more forthcoming to his overtures, it could have struck an even more lucrative deal. Instead, he said Canberra avoided contact with him and Taipei and repeatedly denied trying to stall the deal.
He contrasted Canberra's caution to the enthusiasm of its competitors. Washington, Paris, and Moscow have courted Taipei for a possible billion-dollar LNG deal, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDY FINDS HEALTH, WEALTH NOT ENOUGH FOR HAPPY RETIREMENT

TEXT.P: Being healthy and wealthy may not be enough for a retiree to lead a happy life, according to the authors of a new study published in the Canadian Journal of Behavioral Science.
"Missing workplace friends and being bored can also affect life after work," said researcher David Evans of the University of Western Ontario.

Evans, a professor of clinical psychology, and Terry Lynn Gall, a humanities faculty member at Saint Paul University in Ottawa, studied 109 men six or seven years after they retired and found changed social situations were more typically on their minds than money or health.

They found that interaction with co-workers, feeling wanted, and a sense of belonging have more of an impact on quality of life because these factors represent more sudden interruptions to daily routines compared with health and financial concerns which tend to set in over time, Evans said.
Material well-being, personal growth, and relationships with a partner and family and friends are all considered when measuring quality of life.

While other researchers have assessed disruptions in lifestyle immediately after retirement, the study by Evans and Gall differed in that it involved assessing how people fare years after leaving work.
The latest research also provides a more realistic image of post- retirement life, said Evans, referring to the first six to 12 months after retirement as the "honeymoon phase."
"Once that phase is over, you sort of face the reality of retirement," he noted.

The authors hope their findings will encourage companies and unions to work with employees nearing the end of their careers to help prepare them for the psychological distresses that may lie ahead. As well, they recommend post-retirement programs to monitor changes in lifestyle and to help retirees evaluate their values and goals.
The latest study was a follow-up to earlier research involving 224 London, Ont. men who were assessed two to four months, then a year, after retiring.
Of those 224 retirees, 109, ranging in age from 61 to 75, some of whom had been managers and others laborers, were interviewed and/or completed questionnaires.

The authors found that while most workers viewed retirement as a positive step, only about a third looked forward to it and adjusted well. The retirees complained of financial difficulties, missing friends from work, being bored, and having trouble adjusting to change.
In fact, 16 percent of those interviewed saw nothing good about retirement.
The study suggests that while health plays a role in a good quality of life, just as important -- if not more -- are the mental pressures of coping after leaving the work force.

"Symptoms of psychological distress (such as being unhappy, depressed, or lonely) may be experienced as more bothersome on a daily basis for the older adult than physical symptoms," wrote the authors.

Evans will retire next year to focus on writing. He hopes, however, that a follow-up study by Gall or others might involve recruiting retirees who take on community or paid work and comparing their quality of life to those who don't take on new work.
"I think a lot of people do well if they are employed in some way, be it through gainful employment or being a volunteer," said Evans.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the share index moving up 157.84 points to close at 8,003.53.
The total market turnover amounted to NT$72.9 billion (US$2.35 billion) with 85.47 million shares changing hands.
The weighted index opened at 7,870.58 and fluctuated between 8,023.17 and 7,870.58, excluding the bank stock index, which closed at 6,886, up 152.25 points.
Boosted by an upward surge of semiconductor stocks in US stock markets, Taiwan stocks prices also went up, with semiconductor stocks leading other gainers.
Of the eight major stock categories, only construction stocks lost ground, descending 1.4 percent.

The other major categories all posted gains, with electrical shares rising the most at 2.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.7 percent, textile issues at 0.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 337 to 167, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT-ELECT REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Chen Yin-Yin and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic President-elect Hipolito Mejia on Tuesday said that the friendly relations between his country and the Republic of China will remain unchanged after he assumes the presidency.
Mejia, who will be sworn as the head of state of the Caribbean country on Wednesday, made the assurance to ROC President Chen Shui-bian.
President Chen, who arrived in Santo Domingo on Monday, paid a call to Mejia at his residence and exchanged views with him on ways to enhance bilateral relations between the two countries.

Chen during the 30-minute talks thanked Mejia for his country's continued support for the ROC's bid to take part in the international community. He said that he loves the Dominican Republic very much and it has become his "second hometown."
Chen last visited the Dominican Republic 16 years ago when he as a Taiwan City councilman.
Mejia expressed the hope that Taiwan will encourage its businesses to make more investment in his country so as to help create job opportunities and give a boost to its economic development.

Before meeting Mejia, Chen also called on outgoing Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez. Chen extended his appreciation to Fernandez for his contribution to promoting bilateral ties during his tenure.

While addressing the opening of the directors' meeting of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in North America earlier in the day, Chen spoke highly of the contributions that overseas Chinese have made to the founding and democratization of the ROC.
The conference was held in Santo Domingo specifically to coincide with the President's Chen visit to the Dominican Republic.

Chen urged overseas Chinese to put aside their ideological differences and party affiliations, close ranks and stand behind the ROC government. He was referring to disunity in the overseas Chinese community, especially between "old" and "new" Chinese immigrants.
President Chen, traveling at the head of a delegation composed of more than 200 ROC officials, business leaders and journalists, was in Santo Domingo for Mejia's inauguration on Wednesday.
He will stay in the Caribbean republic until Aug. 17, when he will travel on to Nicaragua (Aug. 17-18), Costa Rica (Aug. 18-19), Gambia (Aug. 20-21), Burkina Faso (Aug. 21-23), and Chad (Aug. 23-25).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 16, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1886: Ramakrishna, the Indian Hindu saint and religious educator, dies. He taught the essential unity and truth of all religions.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine at Anshan in Liaoning province in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant at Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli statesman and prime minister of Israel from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt against Japanese rule of Taiwan in Tahu, Hsinchu County, in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli statesman and prime minister of Israel from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council meeting decides that the National government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the major league home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21) and again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly consisting of eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies from heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing at his mansion in Memphis, Tennessee.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. As prime minister of a Progressive Conservative government, he lost the 1963 election because of opposition to proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns US President George Bush that thousands of the troops he sent to the Gulf would return home in coffins.
1993: The 14th National Congress of the Kuomintang opens.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; critically to inquire into it; carefully to ponder over it; clearly to sift it; and earnestly to carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.001 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$31.095.
The local currency opened at NT$31.089 and was traded between NT$31.089 and NT$31.100.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$234 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER APOLOGIZES FOR INVESTIGATOR'S INVOLVEMENT IN KIDNAP

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Wednesday offered his apologies to the country for the alleged involvement of a former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) agent in the kidnapping of a local businessman.

Calling it "the shame of the Ministry of Justice," Chen expressed deep regret at Chai Yung-sen's alleged involvement in the kidnapping of Chou Pu-ping, a shareholder of Askey Computer Corp., Taiwan's biggest modem maker.

Chai, 35, a graduate from Central Police University, had served as an MJIB agent until March this year, when he quit his post at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan and claimed that he was going to the United States to study for a doctorate.
He was fingered by his five accomplices as one of the masterminds of Chou's kidnapping in late July.

On July 27, the kidnappers wrote to Chou's wife demanding a ransom of US$4 million dollars to be remitted into an account in a Hong Kong bank. Chou's family reported the kidnapping to the police the next day.

Chai was arrested on Aug. 4 by police and cooperated with the police to crack down on the five others, who included fugitive fraudster Wu Yen-lung, a taxi driver, two illegal immigrants from mainland China and Wu's girlfriend.
All six captors had been rounded up as of Tuesday when Chou was discovered hidden in a rented apartment in the Taipei suburb of Hsichih.
According to the testimonies gathered by investigators, Chou received a call from Chai, whom he had known well for years, in late July, saying that they were going to meet "babes" in a pub.
Chou was then abducted to the Hsichih apartment, where he was locked up for 23 days and guarded by the two mainland illegals.
At the apartment, police found a coffin-like wooden box, which the abductors said might have been used to transport Chou to the mainland if necessary.
Chai, whose testimony led to the five other arrests, might be spared the death sentence in accordance with the code that encourages criminals to cooperate with law enforcement agencies.
