DOC.HEADLINE: VP HAS NO PLANS TO VISIT EL SALVADOR IN AUTUMN: VP OFFICE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will take part in a world women's summit slated for October in South Africa, but has no plans at present to visit El Salvador at that time, the Vice Presidential Office said on Wednesday.

The comments by the Vice Presidential Office came after local media reported that President Chen Shui-bian had told Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt during a meeting in the Dominican Republic capital of Santo Domingo that Lu is likely to pay a visit to his country in September or October.

The reporters had claimed that Quintanilla had originally invited Chen to take part in a "Central American summit" scheduled for later this year in El Salvador, to which Chen answered that Lu may visit the country in September.

Chen, traveling at the head of a Republic of China delegation of more than 200 people, arrived in the capital of the Dominican Republic on Monday to attend the inauguration of Dominican President-elect Hipolito Mejia on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, Foreign Affairs Vice Minister David Tawei Lee also said he was unaware of any planned trip by Lu to El Salvador in the coming months. Lee, who had just concluded a two-week tour of several countries with no formal diplomatic ties with the ROC, added that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) had not received any related information either.

Echoing Lee's remarks, Y.L. Kuo, vice chief of MOFA's Central and South American Affairs Department, said the Foreign Ministry had not been informed by the Vice Presidential Office of such a trip or its supposed purpose.
If the vice president plans to visit El Salvador in September, her office should notify MOFA as soon as possible to allow MOFA to make full arrangements for the trip, Kuo added.

Despite the vehement denials, however, it is understood that Lu, on behalf of Chen, might visit certain ROC diplomatic allies next month, as Sept. 15 is the national day of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador.
In addition to the Dominican Republic, Chen is scheduled to visit Costa Rica and Nicaragua on his current Central American tour, but not El Salvador, due to time constraints.

DOC.HEADLINE: TE, TF FUTURES MAKE GAINS

TEXT.P: Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures both gained ground on Taiwan's futures market on Wednesday, with August TE futures moving up 11.7 points to finish at 432.5, and August TF futures rising by 5.8 points to 889.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading were: 7,900 for August; 7,922 for September; 7,995 for December; 8,092 for next March; and 8,179 for next June.
August TE futures recorded 721 contract transactions, while September TE futures moved up 10.75 points to close at 432, with 1,381 contract transactions.
December TE futures surged 9.05 points to finish at 436, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures increased by 5.8 points to 889, with 470 contract transactions, while September futures rose 4.8 points to end at 892.6, with 478 contract transactions.
December TF futures went up 5.6 points to 897.8, with three contract transactions. No other transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EXCUSE FOR DIPLOMATIC FLOP: ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said here on Tuesday that there is still ample room and opportunity for ROC diplomats to work for the country's diplomatic cause, despite Beijing's diplomatic embargo on Taiwan.
Chen, who arrived in the Dominican Republic on Monday for a state visit, made the remarks during a lunch meeting with the staff of the ROC Embassy in Santo Domingo.

Chen first recognized the devotion and contributions of all embassy staff in promoting relations with the Caribbean nation over the years. The ROC's first opposition leader-turned-president further said he fully understands the hurdles in carrying out diplomatic work in the face of mainland China's constant diplomatic offensive against Taiwan.

Nevertheless, he said he believes Beijing's perennial attempts to block Taiwan's presence on the world stage and sabotage its relations with other countries should not be used as an excuse for the country's diplomatic plight.
Noting that diplomacy is the most important symbol of an independent sovereign state, Chen said the ROC must step up its diplomatic work to signify its sovereign status.

He acknowledged that it is no easy task to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation. "But I believe where there is a will, there is a way. So long as we have the resolve, we will be able to find a way to overcome the obstacle. Nothing is impossible. We still have ample room to achieve a breakthrough in our diplomatic plight. So long as we want success, we can find a way to realize our goal," the outspoken president noted.

Stressing that mainland China is not expected to cease its diplomatic suppression of Taiwan in the foreseeable future, Chen said the ROC's diplomatic corps should not use this as an excuse for lackluster performance in the diplomatic domain.
"We should have vision and the ambition to boost our national interests, safeguard our national status and dignity, and upgrade our international profile," Chen said.

The Dominican Republic is the first leg of Chen's first post-inauguration overseas visit. The president said he wants to take advantage of his current six-state "journey of friendship" to further cement the ROC's existing diplomatic ties and display to the world the ROC's economic and democratic achievements.

Chen said he is proud to be the first ROC president to visit the Dominican Republic since the two countries forged diplomatic ties 60 years ago. Noting that new Dominican President Hipolito Mejia had made 22 visits to Taiwan, Chen said he is convinced that bilateral ties will become even stronger in the future.

During his stints as Taipei mayor, a legislator and a Taipei City councilor, Chen said he has made many overseas trips. "Whenever I see our national flag during my overseas trips, I have been excited, as have been our expatriates and business people abroad," he said, adding that the ROC national flag is the common language of all ROC citizens, regardless of their party affiliation, ethnic origin or ideology.

Responding to Chen's call for ROC diplomats not to use Beijing's diplomatic embargo as an excuse for the country's diplomatic plight, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, a member of Chen's entourage, said the president's remarks were mainly aimed at boosting morale among the ROC diplomatic staff.

Tien echoed Chen's view that there is still ample room for the ROC to improve its relations with other countries, saying that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is now working hard to boost ties with the 15-member European Union, the United States and Japan.
Chen's ongoing 13-day globe-trotting visit will also take him to the Central American states of Nicaragua and Costa Rica as well as the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad in West Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS HAITIAN, PANAMANIAN LEADERS

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian met with Haitian President Rene Preval and vice presidents of Panama, El Salvador and Guatemala on Tuesday for wide-ranging talks.
Chen arrived in the Dominican Republic on Monday to attend the inauguration of President-elect Hipolito Mejia on Wednesday. This is Chen's his first state visit since taking office on May 20.

Chen took advantage of his current visit to the Caribbean nation to meet with his counterparts or senior officials from the Republic of China's diplomatic allies, who are also here to attend Mejia's inauguration.
During his meeting with Preval, Chen invited the Haitian president to visit Taiwan in October to attend the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebration.
Chen also reaffirmed the ROC's commitment to economic aid to Haiti, saying his administration will faithfully carry out all existing cooperative programs between the two countries.

For his part, Preval said he is interested in visiting Taiwan in October. He further said although Beijing has used its clout in the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) to pressure Haiti, his government will not switch its diplomatic allegiance and will continue maintaining full diplomatic ties with the ROC. Mainland China, a UNSC permanent member, has threatened to boycott the dispatch of UN peacekeeping forces to Haiti to force the Caribbean nation to cut diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Later in the day, Chen held talks with Panamanian Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan on matters of mutual concern. Bazan first conveyed to Chen a personal letter from Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso expressing her gratitude for the hospitality shown by the ROC government and people during her July visit to Taiwan.

Bazan invited Chen to visit his country on the behalf of the Panamanian government. In reply, Chen said Moscoso was the first foreign head of state to visit the ROC after his inauguration. "I appreciate her visit and will make a reciprocal visit at an appropriate time," Chen said, adding that he will invite Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa to accompany him on his Panama visit.
The Taipei-based Evergreen Group operates the world's largest container shipping fleet and has many interests in Panama.
Bazan said as Panama just reclaimed control of the Panama Canal from the United States, it needs support and assistance from the ROC and other countries in managing and developing the canal.
Chen assured Bazan that the ROC government will fully honor its promise to assist Panama in the management and development of the canal and its nearby zone.

On Tuesday, Chen also met with Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt for exchanges of views on bilateral ties. Chen told Quintanilla that ROC Vice President Annette Lu may visit El Salvador in September or October.
For his part, Quintanilla invited Chen to attend a summit meeting between the ROC and its Central American allies to be held in El Salvador next year. Chen said he will consider the invitation.

The Dominican Republic is the first leg of Chen's current six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at cementing the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies after the ROC completed its first democratic transition of power between different political parties in May.
The Aug. 13-25 hectic visit will also take Chen to Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America and three West African countries -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET REACHES AGREEMENT WITH CHUNGHWA TELECOM WORKERS

TEXT.P: The government reached an agreement on Wednesday with union members of Chunghwa Telecom Co., ending a Taipei street protest of some 9,000 union members.

The Chunghwa union members and their supporters took to the streets earlier in the day to appeal for their rights in the face of the imminent privatization of the country's largest telecommunications corporation.
The union demanded that workers' salaries not be cut and that their mandatory retirement age should remain unchanged at 65 after Chunghwa's privatization.
Wea Chi-lin, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, received union representatives and reached an agreement with them promising to resolve the problem.

According to the agreement, while the government is very concerned about Chunghwa workers' rights, the privatization of public enterprises is the set policy of the government. The agreement adds that problems related to workers' rights in the process of privatization can be negotiated by incoming Chunghwa Chairman Mao Chih-kuo and union representatives.

The agreement also indicates that if the process of the privatization touches on other ministries besides the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Executive Yuan must form a task force to coordinate related ministries to resolve the problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN CONDUCTS AIR RAID DRILL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's offshore Kinmen Island on Wednesday took part in an ongoing nationwide joint civil and military air defense exercise to simulate emergency responses in the event of enemy air raids or missile attacks.
Kinmen, which is only a stone's throw away from mainland China's southeastern province of Fujian, cleared its streets of all moving vehicles and personnel during the 20-minute drill.

The island's garrison forces conducted field air defense exercises at their bases, while civilian and military police cleared the roads. The airport and seaports were closed temporarily, and defense intelligence information was quickly disseminated.

Wanan No. 23 is a series of drills being held throughout Taiwan. It began in central regions on Aug. 1, was held in southern Taiwan on Aug. 4., and in eastern Taiwan on Aug. 7. Tuesday saw northern regions taking part in the drill.

The exercise follows the rescue model imposed after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake and focuses on the operations of each county's and city's coordination centers for civil defense mobilization. Local garrison forces are also called in to support and coordinate with civil defenses.

This was the first time Kinmen had been included in the drill, and a National Police Administration official lauded the island as a model for the rest of the country due to the high degree of cooperation and alertness displayed by its residents.

Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai pointed out that Wednesday's exercise was especially aimed at those aged under 40, who have never experienced the actual air raids or bombardments endured by the previous generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND COMMERCIAL BANK TO ISSUE `GODDESS OF MERCY' CREDIT CARD

TEXT.P: The Grand Commercial Bank is to cooperate with the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Foundation in issuing a new "Goddess of Mercy" credit card, bank officials reported on Wednesday.
Designed to symbolize "security and blessing," the new credit card will offer the same services as all other credit cards, but will also include a free "golden Goddess of Mercy card."

The bank will also pay 0.3 percent of each transaction amount to the Ling Jiou Mountain Foundation, which will be used for charity work and to fund the world religion museum scheduled to open in Taipei in 2001, according to the bank officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIWANIS AWARDS TOP 10 OUTSTANDING AGRICULTURAL SPECIALISTS

TEXT.P: Kiwanis International ROC District Chairman Hsiao Chia-sheng and Republic of China Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Hsu Chung-jen on Wednesday jointly presided over the 24th awards for Taiwan's top 10 agricultural specialists.
The award ceremony took place in the Yunlin County stadium in southern Taiwan, the country's rural heartland.

Kiwanis International, which has its headquarters in Indiana, the United States, has more than 8,700 branches with 320,000 members in 81 countries and areas who undertake various charity activities and social services aimed at helping to improve peoples' lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC YOUTHS WHOLEHEARTEDLY TAKE PART IN WORLD YOUTH DAY

TEXT.P: The 15th World Youth Day festival kicked off here on Tuesday.
About 1.5 million young people from the four corners of the world, including the Republic of China, joined the festival.
A highlight of Tuesday's celebration came when John Paul II put in an appearance at Tor Vergata University.
Seven Catholic groups from the ROC gathered at various churches in Rome.
Officials of the ROC Embassy in Vatican City, Holy See on Tuesday morning visited the groups and presented them with gifts, including introductory maps of Rome.

Because the 15th World Youth Day coincides with the year 2000, which the pope has designated as a holy year, Vatican radio stations provided live broadcasts of the opening ceremony in 40 languages. The station also conducted a live interview with the ROC groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PARTY REPRESENTATIVE OBSERVING DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan's major political parties are in Los Angeles on Wednesday to observer the 2000 Democratic Party National Convention being held in Los Angeles.

The Taiwan political party representatives included Chang Chao-hsiung, vice chairman of the People First Party (PFP); Shaw Yu-min, deputy secretary-general of the Kuomintang; Ding Shou-chung of the KMT Central Standing Committee; Prof. Chou Yu-jen of Taipei University; Liu Shih-feng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Central Standing Committee; DPP Representative in the United States Lai Yi-chung; Legislator Hau Lung-pin (New Party-Taipei City); and Legislator Chou Su-wei (PFP-Taipei County).

Shaw said that he would observe carefully the procedures of the convention, including how the party delegations are mobilized and how the party candidate is introduced, to provide references for the KMT.
He added that in order to correct the nomination procedure, the KMT plans to implement the primary system coupled with public opinion surveys, to select future candidates.

The KMT is desperately trying to salvage some remnants of respect and popularity after its dismal showing and total humiliation in Taiwan's March presidential election that swept the DPP's Chen Shui-bian into the presidency .

DOC.HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FORUM 2000 HELD IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By C.H. Su & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Wisers Info Tech Forum 2000, sponsored by Hong Kong's Wisers Information Limited, opened on Wednesday, with more than 100 representatives from mainland China, Taiwan, Macau and Hong Kong participating.

The objective of the two-day forum, the first of its kind, is to encourage the sharing of experience and the exchange of ideas and opinions inside the media industry, and Wisers intends to make it an annual event.

Speakers at the opening ceremony included Patrick Cheung, vice chairman of the Newspaper Society of Hong Kong and Carrie Yau, secretary for Information Technology and Broadcasting under the Hong Kong government.
In his speech, Cheung identified capital flow and rapid changes in technology as the most crucial problems faced by conventional media taking on website development.

He cited World Press Alliance research as showing that 65 percent of conventional media with spin-off portals suffer losses and reminded the audience to see capital investment in Internet media as a long-term commitment, with a thorough knowledge of IT a prerequisite to success.
Yau addressed the various measures the Hong Kong government has taken to reassure the public of a secure and trustworthy environment for electronic commerce.
Three seminars were also conducted to discuss different aspects and concerns in running Internet media business.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER VISITS EXPORT PROCESSING ZONE IN SANTO DOMINGO

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi on Tuesday visited an export processing zone in Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic.
Lin is currently in the Dominican capital as a member of the visiting ROC delegation led by President Chen Shui-bian.

Accompanied by Wang You-theng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, and Jeffrey L. S. Koo, Chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Lin inspected the management and processing methods of a plastics firm there.

After the visit, Lin held a seminar with Taiwan business officials operating in North America. He said that Taiwan's labor-intensive traditional industries need new ideas to advance their competitiveness, but noted that traditional industries should not be thought of as "sunset industries."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEVELOP KNOWLEDGE-BASED ECONOMY: ROC PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Tang Fei on Wednesday unveiled a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with the world's most advanced nations within ten years.

Tang said at a regular meeting of local industrial and commercial leaders that a decade-long observation of the development, experiences, and accomplishments of the United States shows that Taiwan must look upon a knowledge-based economy as an international trend and adjust its development accordingly.

He added that Taiwan already has a basic foundation for developing such an economy because of the government's long-term nurturing of Taiwan's talent, its focus on technical development, and its promotion of information technology and industrial automation.

Tang went on to say that the Cabinet's plan for a new draft law on the development of a knowledge-based economy will take three months to complete, and that the final version will take another month to reorganize. He therefore estimated that the government and the private sector will be able to begin implementing the proposal in January.

The law will help supply basic network facilities, nurture domestic talent and bring foreign know-how to Taiwan, establish a mechanism for innovation and new ventures, and promote the use of information technology and the World Wide Web, Tang said.

Tang said that he would not deny the challenge involved in the government's promotion of a knowledge-based economy, adding that the most important aspect will be for civil servants to change their mindset. For example, many government research and development units lack sufficient interaction with the manufacturing industry, creating gaps in government research endeavors and actual private sector needs, he said.

Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., said at the same meeting that the development of a knowledge-based economy will depend on three main factors -- technical know-how, a corporate spirit for adventure and risk, and innovation.

Chang said that Taiwan's hardware technology is fairly good, but that the domestic software industry still needs improvement. He noted that the development of forward-looking technology is particularly important.

Answering questions regarding a shortage of talented manufacturing industry professionals, Tang said that in the face of insufficient manpower, Taiwan must look beyond its shores for workers, possibly including mainland Chinese. He added that the government has already noticed the issue and will resolve it step by step.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REMAINS UNDECIDED ON WHETHER CHEN SHOULD HEAD NUC

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsien said on Wednesday that the ruling party has not decided whether or not President Chen Shui-bian should head the National Unification Council (NUC).

Speaking to the media after a DPP meeting, he said that the party has not yet made the final decision on this matter but that it is still under discussion, and added that Chen himself has not yet made up his mind.
Since the establishment of the NUC in 1990, former President Lee Teng-hui had served as its chairman until his term ended on May 20 this year.

But the spirit of the NUC calls for Taiwan's unification with China, running counter to the pro-Taiwan independence platform of the DPP. Chen is a DPP member, which makes the issue of whether or not he will assume its chairmanship an object of public concern.

Hung Yu-chin, a heavyweight of the Kuomintang (KMT), said on Wednesday that Chen has no reason to evade his responsibility of assuming the NUC chairmanship, because it is a customary practice for the president to take over that post.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP HOPES PRES. CHEN CAN BE INVITED TO WHITE HOUSE AS GUEST

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said on Wednesday that she hopes that one day President Chen Shui-bian will be invited to the White House as a guest to further enhance substantial relations between the Republic of China and United States.
Lu made the remark in a meeting with visiting US Congressman Rob Riley (R-AL).

Lu noted that the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, and Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, have been invited to the White House as guests. Considering the long and close relations between Taipei and Washington, the leader of the Republic of China should have been treated better during his recent stopover in Los Angeles, she said.

Lu also said that 20 years ago, when she was imprisoned for her involvement in Taiwan's democracy movement, she could not imagine that Taiwan would reach its current state of democratization. Even in March's presidential election, she still was not sure whether the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would be able to win the election, Lu added.

However, Taiwan voters chose the DPP, and the island took another step toward pure democracy without any bloodshed, she said, adding that this was accomplished by the effort of all of Taiwan's people.

Riley told Lu that the shining example of Taiwan's successful democratic movement is the reason why most US congressmen support Taiwan, and these US lawmakers will continue backing the ROC to ensure peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Lu noted that local people have high expectations for President Chen's current overseas trip to Taiwan's diplomatic allies, which they hope will allow him to carry Taiwan's voice to the world. However, Lu lamented that Chen had received unsatisfactory treatment during his stopover in the United States.
On the same day, Riley also had a meeting with Lin Chong-ping, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Lin told Riley that he thinks relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will move in a positive direction, considering the two sides' mutual economic independence and the increasing demand for democracy within mainland China.
Riley said that no country in history ever benefited from conflict, adding that the cross-strait economic interdependence can enable a "win-win" situation for the two.

Referring to the question of balanced military power, the US congressman added that it is necessary that the United States supply Taiwan with sufficient defensive arms to maintain peace and security in the region.
Riley said he hopes that Taiwan will use its democratic and economic power to push for the positive development of cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TAKES PART IN DOMINICAN PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURAL

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation on Wednesday took part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.

Chen and members of his delegation were later entertained at a national luncheon banquet hosted by President Mejia at the Presidential Building in honor of the foreign dignitaries who were here for the inauguration.

Meanwhile, Speaker Ramon Alburquez of the Dominican Republic's Senate said that President Shen has promised to offer US$4.8 million as fund for his country to help boost the Caribbean nation's credit that will enable it to more easily seek loans form the International Monetary Fund.

Earlier in the day, Chen met with Haitian President Rene Preval and vice presidents of Panama, El Salvador and Guatemala, who were among the foreign heads, or deputy heads of state attending the inauguration, on Tuesday for wide-ranging talks.
Chen arrived in the Dominican Republic on Monday. This is Chen's his first state visit since taking office on May 20.

Chen has taken the advantage of his current visit to the Caribbean nation to meet with his counterparts or senior officials from the Republic of China's diplomatic allies, who are also here to attend Mejia's inauguration.

On Tuesday, Chen also met with Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt for exchanges of views on bilateral ties. Chen told Quintanilla that ROC Vice President Annette Lu may visit El Salvador in September or October.

The Dominican Republic is the first leg of Chen's current six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at cementing the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies after the ROC completed its first democratic transition of power between different political parties in May.
The Aug. 13-25 hectic visit will also take Chen to Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America and three West African countries -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST BATCH OF CHUNGHWA TELECOM SHARES TO BE SOLD OFF ON AUG. 25

TEXT.P: Three percent of state-owned Chunghwa Telecom is scheduled to be sold off on Aug. 25, when the results of bidding for the shares in an open tender will be announced.
Sixteen underwriters in Taiwan were entrusted on Wednesday to handle inviting the public to bid in an open tender from Wednesday through Saturday.
Qualified institutional and individual investors at home and abroad will be able to bid for the shares, which number more than 289 million.

Investors will be required to purchase a minimum of 5,000 shares, and will be limited to bidding for a maximum of 15 million shares. The initial offered price for the shares was set at NT$104 (US$3.35) each.

The government's release of three percent of Chunghwa Telecom is part of the first phase of the company's privatization plan. A total of 33 percent of the government's stake in the company will be sold off by the end of this year. It is currently fully-owned by the government.
The government plans to sell another 33 percent of Chunghwa Telecom beginning in February next year, with the goal of complete privatization of the firm by the end of next year or early in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR'S OFFICE, RESIDENCE SEARCHED BY PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: Prosecutors and other law enforcement authorities on Wednesday searched the office and the house of Legislator Liao Fu-pen (Kuomintang-Yunlin County). They took away some 10,000 shares from Liao's house.

Lin Chieh-teh of the Public Prosecutor's Office of Taiwan's High Court told the media that the search was conducted because Chi Mei Corporation complained to the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office that some people were suspected to have fabricated Chi Mei shares.

Two prosecutors from Tainan first entered Liao's office in the Legislative Yuan's Chunghsing Building on Wednesday afternoon. Police guarding the Legislative Yuan argued with them over their right to search Liao's office.
Liao's aide said that the prosecutors stayed at the office for about one hour, but took nothing away.
On Thursday night, the prosecutors and law enforcement authorities searched Liao's residence at the Legislative Yuan's Ta-an Building. Lin said that about 10,000 shares were taken away.

Upon learning of the search, Liao rushed back to Taipei from his constituency in Yunlin County on Wednesday night. He told the media that the shares the prosecutors had taken away from his house are those of Chungtai Canned Manufacturing Co., of which he is board chairman. He stressed that he owns no Chi Mei shares.
Liao said he had already lodged a protest to the public prosecutor's general, and added that the prosecutor's general had already apologized to him.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng had called up the public prosecutor general to protest the search.
Meanwhile, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said that he knew nothing about the search beforehand, but noted that he had stated that such kind of search must be made in accordance with law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS TIES WITH DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A videotaped greeting from Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to the president, officials, and people of the Dominican Republic has been broadcast on about a dozen local television channels since Monday.
Chen, who arrived in Santo Domingo on that day, is on the first stop of his 13-day, six-state trip to the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa.
In the video, Chen reaffirmed the ROC's ties with the Caribbean country and congratulated Dominican Republic President-elect Hipolito Mejia, who was later sworn in on Wednesday.

Chen noted that although the ROC and the Dominican Republic are far apart geographically, common ideals between the two governments and the two peoples regarding democracy, freedom, human rights, and the establishment of pluralistic societies have allowed the two countries to maintain a close alliance and cooperative relations since bilateral ties were established.

Chen said that the ROC will continue to actively promote all manner of cooperative projects between the two nations, adding that he is certain that his visit will further improve the cooperative relationship between the two nations -- particularly in the areas of politics, economics and trade, technology, and international affairs.
He added that he hopes his visit will also cement the mutual understanding and friendship between the two peoples.

Chen, who last visited the Dominican Republic 16 years ago when he was a Taipei City councilman, went on to say that his visit is significant in that it is the first time that he is attending an ally's presidential inauguration ceremony in the capacity as the head of state of the ROC.

He added that the March 18 ROC presidential election rewrote history by implementing the first-ever democratic transfer of political power in Taiwan from one party to another, making the ROC a truly democratic country.

With domestic policies, foreign relations, and cross-strait policies steadily moving forward, Chen said that the ROC will continue to speed up the pace of Beijing-Taipei exchanges under the principle of mutual respect and for the benefit and prosperity of both sides.

In international affairs, Chen said that the ROC will continue to actively participate in international organizations and activities as well as develop cooperative relations with all democratic, freedom-loving nations in the world.

Chen, traveling at the head of a delegation of more than 200 ROC officials, business leaders and journalists, will stay in the Caribbean republic until Aug. 17, after which he will travel to Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso, and Chad. He is scheduled to wind up his tour on August 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC ATHLETES FACING HAY FEVER PLAGUE IN SYDNEY GAMES

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 athletes from over 100 countries competing in the 2000 Olympic Games will be facing a hay fever plague, as spring is beginning to dawn in Sydney.
Already, US competitors have been warned to prepare for the onslaught of runny noses and itchy throats, while African athletes have asked for briefings on expected pollen levels.

Many of the 200 African athletes training in Adelaide are concerned about which hay fever medications are approved by the International Olympic Committee, according to the training camp's coordinator, Meredith Clark, an official of South Australia's Sport Department.

"A lot of the African teams have been concerned about pollen levels and what they can and can't take. They want to make sure they're not taking the wrong medicines," Clark was quoted as saying in a Wednesday report in The Australian, a local daily.
The IOC has approved some steroid-based nasal sprays and antihistamines which do not cause drowsiness, but individual athletes must apply directly to the IOC for permission to take them.
The US Olympic Committee has alerted American sports federations that Sydney's pollen levels have been known to spark hay fever attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN LEADERS REAFFIRM STABLE TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Dominican President Leonel Fernandez and President-elect Hipolito Mejia on Tuesday reaffirmed the stable ties between Taipei and Santo Domingo to visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian.

In an earlier meeting, Chen expressed gratitude to Fernandez for his contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties during his four-year term, while Fernandez thanked the ROC government for its help in his country's development of hi-tech industries and the setting up of science-based parks.
Chen also presented Fernandez with the gift of a computer produced by the Acer group, Taiwan's largest computer firm.
Chen later met with Mejia, who will be sworn in to succeed Fernandez on Wednesday as the Dominican Republic's new head of state for the next four years.

Mejia, an agricultural engineer, told Chen that he was deeply impressed by Taiwan's expertise in agriculture and water engineering, and voiced his desire for greater Taiwan investment in the country's electricity and sugar sectors.

Stressing that he has great admiration for the ROC, the incoming Dominican president recalled that he first visited Taiwan in 1976, and has visited the nation 22 times in his capacities as minister, mayor and businessman.
Mejia also recalled that he had visited late President Chiang Ching-kuo and former Premier Sun Yun-shuan, and had traveled to the cities of Taichung and Kaohsiung, in addition to Taipei.

Mejia told Chen he has "a crush" on Taiwan and that he is determined to continue bolstering two-way relations based on the existing ties. He gave his assurance that bilateral links will remain stable.

In the face of Beijing's strong offensive designed to lure away Taipei's diplomatic partners around the world, Chen also expressed his appreciation for Mejia's firm support for the ROC and its bids to join international organizations.

Claiming that he felt as comfortable in the Dominican Republic as if he were at home, the ROC president said that the Caribbean country felt like his "second home country." He invited Mejia to visit Taiwan for a 23rd time, whereupon the incoming Dominican president promised to make the trip within six months.
Chen also presented Mejia with an Acer computer as a token of bilateral technical cooperation between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX CONTINUES RISING

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange continued its upward trend on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index gaining 139.72 points to close at 8,143.25.
Daily market turnover amounted to NT$101.57 billion (US$3.28 billion) in moderate trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CONTINUES UPWARD SWING

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices closed 1.7 percent higher on Thursday on brisk buying of technology issues due to a positive outlook for the sector.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rose 139.72 points to close at 8,143.25.
The market opened higher at 8,059.02 following Wednesday's rebound. The index dropped slightly in the first hour of trading, but rallied after mid-session and closed at the day's high.
Market analysts said capital seems to have flowed back to the market, with semiconductor and small-sized electronics stocks as the main targets of purchase.

A total of 1.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.57 billion (US$3.28 billion), a sharp increase from the previous trading session which saw 85.47 million shares changing hands on a turnover of US$2.35 billion.

The price indexes for the eight major categories closed mixed, with electrical and electronics issues registering the largest gain of 2.6 percent, followed by banking and financial stocks, up 1.6 percent; cement stocks, up 0.9 percent; and textile stocks, up 0.7 percent.
In contrast, the price indexes for foodstuff shares declined 1.6 percent; plastics and chemicals, down 0.7 percent; paper and pulp stocks, down 1.1 percent; and construction stocks, down 1.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers, 252 to 244, with 93 stocks remaining unchanged. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO BE WELCOMED TO GAMBIA WITH PRODUCE FROM ROC-ASSISTED FARMS
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Gambia, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By M. J. Tsou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian is expected to be accorded with not only a formal military salute, but also a welcome kiss offered by the most beautiful lady in Gambia when he arrives in the capital of Banjul on Sunday.

The lady is a representative from a Gambian women's group which in recent years has been up-and-coming, gaining its reputation through the planting of vegetables that have contributed to improving Gambian families' economic situation.

When Chen and his 200-member entourage fly into Banjul from Costa Rica on Sunday, the first ROC head of state to ever visit the African country will be welcomed with a long line of tables covered with fresh vegetables and fruits cultivated at farms in the suburbs of Banjul under the technical guidance of members of an ROC agricultural mission.
The ROC agro-tech mission has helped develop four model vegetable farms near Banjul, with members of 300 local households taking part as planters.

The four model farms, on a combined tract of 40 hectares, have marketed produce which immediately earned a reputation for the planters in the second harvest. Orders have even come from England and Ireland for the vegetables, said Chen Yi-sung, chief of the ROC agro-tech mission.
The harvests have not only improved the households' incomes, but have also turned the farms into a sort of tourist attraction in recent months, Chen added.

Apart from the planting technique, the ROC mission also applied Taiwan's precious experience in organizing farmers' cooperatives to the Gambian planters, allowing them to organize their own cooperatives to serve farmers in various fields, Chen noted.
From the cooperative, Chen said, the planters acquire high-quality seeds imported from Taiwan, fertilizers, and other needed equipment and materials.

With one-fourth of the profits derived from every sale of the vegetables being channeled into the cooperative bank, the farmers will have enough funds to acquire new farm machinery, to maintain the land, and to secure a good public irrigation system.
In addition, Chen said, the cooperative offers low-interest soft loans to the planters and also scholarships to help promote education for the children of farmers.

Commenting on the achievements of the ROC agro-tech mission, ROC Ambassador to Gambia Lee Chen-hsiung, who was largely instrumental in arranging the ROC mission to lead the Gambian model vegetable farm development, said the vegetable plantation project has proven to be a quick success in efforts to promote friendship and to help improve the locals' livelihoods.

Lee said he is proud that the ROC agro-tech mission has harvested so much with relatively little effort. He attributed the achievements to an inspiration he got from the fact that some four decades ago, the United States granted Taiwan US$15 billion in aid to help the island develop its own agriculture, proving to be an important force behind Taiwan's economic take-off in later years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUTURES MARKET REGISTERS GAIN

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Thursday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for September went up 129 points to close at 8,215, with 4,998 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for October also surged 158 points to close at 8,235, with 32 contract transactions, while December futures rose 72 points to finish at 8,247, with four contract deals struck.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 8,086 for September; 8,077 for October; 8,175 for December; 8,185 for next March; and 8,299 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also closed higher.

September TE futures moved up 10 points to finish at 442, with 1,710 contract transactions, while October TE futures picked up 8.15 points to close at 444.1, with nine contract transactions. And December TE futures surged 11 points to close at 447, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures advanced 27.4 points to close at 920, with 685 contract transactions; October TF futures gained 4.4 points to finish at 899, with one contract transactions; December TF futures climbed 21.2 points to close at 919, with six contracts traded; and next March TF futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 895, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
