DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DANCERS PERFORM AT 15TH WORLD YOUTH DAY FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: Aboriginal dancers representing the Republic of China won the loud applause of onlookers when they performed at the 15th World Youth Day festival held in Vatican City on Thursday.
Meanwhile, representatives from Hong Kong and Macau put on special "Chinese Kungfu" performances at the festival.

Before the performances began, there reportedly was a minor unpleasant incident between Taiwan performers and youths from Hong Kong and Macau regarding national identity. When the Taiwan dancers displayed the national flag of the Republic of China, the youths from Hong Kong and Macau shouted at them and took out the Communist Chinese flag. Fortunately, no major conflicts broke out among the participants.
Over 300 representatives from the ROC took part in the festival put on by the Roman Catholic Church.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO CONSIDER VISITING LATIN AMERICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will actively consider paying formal visits to El Salvador and other Republic of China diplomatic allies in Central America next month, sources from the Vice Presidential Office said on Thursday.

Visiting diplomatic allies and promoting diplomacy are responsibilities that the vice president has to share with the president, officials from Lu's office said, adding that the vice president will "actively and carefully" consider making the visits in September.

Lu's office on Wednesday had said that the vice president had no plans to visit El Salvador in September in response to a local media report which said that President Chen Shui-bian told Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt during a meeting in the Dominican Republic capital of Santo Domingo on Wednesday that Lu is likely to pay a visit to his country in September or October.

The sources said Thursday that Lu is likely to represent President Chen and visit Central America next month as Sept. 15 is the national day of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and El Salvador. They added that no concrete itineraries for the visits have been worked out yet.

Lu, who is currently in charge of Taiwan's top office while President Chen is overseas on a six-state, 13-day visit, flew to the eastern city of Hualien to inspect disaster and emergency management morale there.

Lu told Hualien officials that the Pachang Creek tragedy, in which four river-bed cleaning workers were washed away by turbulent floods after rescuers failed to show up, is a shameful episode that she will not allow to happen again.
She said as public functionaries, rescue forces should never be late in carrying out emergency actions, let alone procrastinate doing their duty.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRONZE WINNERS SAID HAPPIER THAN GOLD OR SILVER MEDALISTS

TEXT.P: Gold and silver medalists are not as happy about their accomplishment as bronze medal winners because they sometimes experience the greatest letdown, according to the Australian Olympic team's head psychologist Graham Winters, reported The Australian on Thursday.

"You climb to the top of the mountain and win gold then think: `Where do I go from here? What do I do now? Has my life really changed?'" said Winters, who will lead a team of 15 colleagues to offer advice to Australian athletes competing in the Sydney Olympic Games.

He said a series of studies of Olympic athletes show that bronze medalists are happier than silver medal winners. Bronze medal winners are generally delighted to have at least won a medal, but silver winners are often devastated that they missed winning gold by such a narrow margin.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.006 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$31.089.
The local currency opened at NT$31.087 and was traded between NT$31.084 and NT$31.095.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$240.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC MINISTER BEGINS TOUR OF CENTRAL TAIWAN'S QUAKE-HIT AREAS

TEXT.P: The Minister of Transportation and Communication Yeh Chu-lan, leading about 1,000 officials, on Thursday began a "trip of concern" to areas in central Taiwan devastated by last year's 921 earthquake.
Since taking office in the Ministry of Transportation and Communication, Yeh has made efforts to resuscitate the tourist industry in Taiwan's earthquake stricken areas.
In July, she instructed the Tourism Bureau to assist the tourist industry in central Taiwan, and she also told the MOTC to organize five stops in these areas for the "trip of concern."
Yeh said that central Taiwan's tourist resources really were not affected by the 921 earthquake and she hopes that this "trip of concern" will demonstrate this fact to the public.

The "trip of concern" will take Yeh and her entourage of officials to Taichung County, Nantou County, Yulin County, and Chiayi County . All of Taiwan's famous scenic spots, including Alishan, Puli, and Kukuan, are on the itinerary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 17, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1743: Jack Broughton, champion bare-knuckle English fighter, publishes a set of rules to control boxing. He also introduces 10-oz (300-g) gloves, called mufflers, to protect the hands and face from bruising during training.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a US representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England by a car traveling at just 6.4 kph.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon is premiered in Paris.
1943: American forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After Japanese occupation during World War II, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch full-scale war against the nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator, a device that speeds up the movement of tiny bits of matter, is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the US and mainland China. The ministry also asks the US to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, one hour and 20 minutes faster than the old record.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy in the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing KMT membership, which he had held for 42 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learn a thing you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE EXHIBITORS WALK OUT OF CHICAGO SHOW OVER ROC FLAGS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By David Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese exhibitors at the Chicago Hardware Show walked out of the fair on Tuesday in protest of the flying at the show's venue of several national flags of the Republic of China (ROC) on Taiwan.

The Chinese exhibitors had occupied 303 booths, making them the largest participating group at the show. They said they were told by their government to close the booths on Monday -- two days before the show was scheduled to end -- to protest against the show organizers' refusal to remove the ROC flags.

A spokesman for the exhibition's organizers said that trade shows are pure business and should not be linked to politics. Exhibiting firms from many countries are all guests of the fair, and all of them should be accorded respect, he stressed.
The mainland Chinese exhibitors were apparently dismayed by the order to shut down their displays, in a protest which was believed to be officially orchestrated.
In a printed statement, the mainland Chinese delegation blasted the fair authorities for allowing ROC flags to be displayed in the exhibition hall.
"This erroneous decision by the show organizers runs counter to the United States government's 'one China' policy and offers Taiwan authorities a stage to create two Chinas," it said.

Officials from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Chicago said they are appreciative of the show organizers' firm stance of being fair and providing justice to all the exhibitors, regardless of nationality.
TECO officials stressed that the hardware show is purely a private sector business activity, and mainland China's protest makes no sense at all.
The Taiwan exhibitors, who represent 61 companies from the island, viewed the flag issue as ridiculous.
The Chicago Hardware Show is the largest fair in the Western Hemisphere for professional and DIY hardware, home improvement products, and lawn, garden and building supplies.
The fair kicked off on Sunday at Chicago's McCormick Place Convention Center, and is scheduled to wrap up on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE IN ECONOMIC OUTLOOK DECLINES: POLL

TEXT.P: Consumer confidence in Taiwan's economic outlook has declined because of a combination of factors, according to the results of a quarterly government survey released on Thursday.

The third quarter survey of the local public's confidence in the general domestic economic situation was conducted by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Survey results show that consumer confidence in the domestic capital market, economic outlook and job opportunities for the next six months has all declined from the second-quarter levels.
As much as 47 percent of those surveyed said they don't think that the coming six months are a good time for stock investment.

The quarterly consumer confidence survey covered six categories -- the domestic inflation rate, household economic status, domestic economic prospect, job opportunities, stock investment and durable goods purchases for the next half year.

The DGBAS used a zero-to-200-point scale to measure consumer confidence in the above-mentioned six major economic indicators. Survey results show that the score for each indicator fell below 100 points, which meant that consumers have become more conservative, more reserved about future economic prospect.

According to the survey, consumers were least confident of the stock market prospect for the next six months, with a score of a mere 69.1 points. Compared with the second quarter survey, consumer confidence in stock investment registered the largest decline.
And consumer confidence in domestic price stability was the only category that showed a slight improvement in the third quarter survey.

DGBAS officials attributed the falling consumer confidence to a host of factors, including recent flooding in central and southern Taiwan, the Pachang Creek tragedy and bearish stock trading in recent weeks. "Because of these factors, consumer confidence in the domestic capital market, economic outlook and employment opportunities has all dropped," said a DGBAS official.

As the Legislative Yuan's recent passage of a bill cutting the legal bi-weekly working time to 84 hours from next year is expected to have a significant impact on the domestic economic development, the DGBAS especially surveyed public opinion about the issue in its third quarter consumer confidence poll.

Poll results show that the majority of the respondents said they think that the new legal workweek scheme needs a further review or supplementary measures should be adopted to complement the new scheme.

According to the survey, 52.12 percent of employers interviewed said the 84-hour-biweekly-workweek system should be subject to further review or supplementary measures should be adopted if the system will be put into force as scheduled; 23.4 percent said implementation of the new system should be postponed for one year; and only 9.57 percent said the new system should be enforced next year as scheduled.

In contrast, 28.25 percent of salaried people said they think the new workweek scheme should be implemented next year; and 34.63 percent said they think a further study is needed before the new scheme is put into practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS WITH HONDURAN PRESIDENT FLORES
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met with Honduran President Carlos Flores here on Wednesday, local time.
Chen and his Honduran counterpart are in Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic, to attend Wednesday's inaugural ceremony of President-elect Hipolito Mejia.

Chen told Flores that relations between the ROC and Honduras will continue to be very cordial and stable. Taiwan's recent transition of power will not affect established ties between the two countries, the ROC chief of state added.

Chen took the opportunity to express gratitude to Flores on behalf of Taiwan's government and people for Honduras' staunch support of the ROC in its bids for membership in international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO).

Flores said that he was eager to meet with Chen in Santo Domingo because he was unable to attend the ROC president's inauguration on May 20 in Taipei, as he had to deliver a keynote speech at the university commencement ceremony of his eldest son.

Flores went on to say that the friendship between Honduras and the ROC is everlasting and inseparable, and urged Chen to visit his country. Honduras holds the same democratic concepts and shares common goals with the ROC, and will continue supporting the ROC's bids for membership in international organizations, Flores added.

Chen replied that he understood Flores' reason for missing his inauguration, saying that the affection of a parent toward a child is paramount. He noted that he had attended the commencement ceremony of his daughter in June.

Chen reaffirmed that relations between the two countries will not be affected by the recent ROC transition of power, adding that all economic and technical cooperation projects will continue as before.
President Chen also extended his invitation to President Flores to visit Taipei.

Secretary-General of the National Security Council Adm. (Retired) Chuang Ming-yao, Foreign Minister Tien Hong-mao, and Deputy Secretary General to the President Eugene Chien were also present at the meeting of the two presidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT WELCOMES VISITING TAIPEI MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso on Wednesday expressed her warm welcome for Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who currently in Panama on a two-day visit.

Moscoso welcomed Ma before presiding over a ceremony marking the opening of a long-distance bus terminal at the former Albrook US Air Force Base in the Panama Canal Zone. The Taipei mayor attended the same ceremony.

Later on the same day, Panama City Mayor Juan Carlos Navarro presented Ma with the Panamanian capital's Key to the City. Navarro conferred Ma with the honor at a dinner party in honor of Taipei's mayor. City mayors from San Jose, Costa Rica; San Salvador, El Salvador; Tegucigalpa, Honduras; and Havana, Cuba were also present at the dinner.

Following his acceptance of the Key to the City, Ma expressed his gratitude in a short Spanish-language speech, for which he had spent four hours in preparation before departing Taipei. Ma's linguistic efforts drew applause and polite laughter from the assembled guests.
Navarro also expressed his hope that Panama City and Taipei City will strengthen their cultural and economic relations in the future.

Ma arrived in Panama City on Tuesday night, accompanied by King Fu-tsung, Taipei City Government spokesman; Kung Wen-chi, chairman of the Aboriginal Affairs Commission of Taipei City Government; and City Councilors Chen Su-hua, Wei Yi-lung and Chen Hui-mi.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC POSITIVE ON SETTING UP BANK LIAISON OFFICES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Senior mainland affairs and finance officials said on Thursday that they are working on a proposal of allowing local banks to set up representative offices in mainland China.

Both John C.C. Teng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), and Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen said relevant government agencies are working on regulations to govern bank applications for gaining footholds on the mainland.

They made the remarks at a public hearing on the pros and cons of allowing local banks to open liaison offices or representative offices on the other side of the Taiwan Strait. The hearing was sponsored by Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta of the New Party, a tiny pro-unification opposition party.

Teng said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, is promoting the proposal in a positive direction. "We are crafting a comprehensive package of regulations in cooperation with the Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank of China to pave the way for an orderly opening of local banks to operate liaison offices on the mainland," he added.

Teng pointed out that the local public remain divided over the feasibility of permitting local banks to open liaison offices on the mainland. While the proponents said the liberalization measure would help facilitate mainland-based Taiwan companies' financial management and market expansion drive, opponents said the move would accelerate outbound capital movement and hinder local businesses' acquisition of bank loans.

Noting that the establishment of a bank liaison office must first pass stringent screening of the mainland government, Teng said local banks must consider whether they will face political pressure from mainland authorities, such as asking them to spell out their political stance.

Teng said the government basically favors an open-door policy and will carry out the policy in a gradual manner. Nevertheless, he said, local banks should have "risk management" concepts and develop a sound in-house supervisory system to prevent irregularities and unnecessary financial losses.

Teng also urged local bankers and members of the general public not to have unrealistic expectations of the liberalization proposal. Local banks should evaluate their own financial status and the mainland financial and political environment before making inroads into that market.
Vice Finance Minister Chen echoed Teng's views, saying local banks should carefully survey mainland China's financial climate and banking regulations before deciding whether to tap that market.

Chen particularly reminded local bankers that they should take into account the possible changes in the mainland market situation following its entry to the World Trade Organization. "It is important to understand whether mainland China offers an advanced environment for banking operations," he noted.

Chen said mainland China only allows 32 foreign-owned banks to operate the mainland currency (renminbi)-denominated banking services. Against this backdrop, he said, local banks should consider whether they can survive if they open footholds on the mainland.
Chen further said opening representative offices is different from opening bank branches because a representative office can only collect information and is banned from operating banking services.

So long as relations across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said the government will not oppose local banks' plan to seek a foothold on the mainland. "In fact, the finance ministry is working with other relevant government agencies in drafting rules for local banks to apply for opening liaison offices on the mainland," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL UNREST GROWING IN CHINA: MAC REPORT

TEXT.P: Social unrest is growing in mainland China, the Mainland Affairs Council said in a report released Wednesday at a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.

The report pointed out that the number of public protests and demonstrations in China reached 110,000 in 1999, a jump of 70 per cent over the 60,000 registered in 1998. The situation is getting worse this year, especially in the past one and a half months.

Economic reforms in the past 20 years in China have made some people rich, but have also created some factors that are destabilizing the country, such as the problems of unemployment, corruption, and the great disparity of wealth between rich and poor areas of the country.

The report also said that there is unrest in different strata of society. For example, practitioners of Falun Gong are still defying authorities despite widespread government crackdown on the spiritual sect. The police arrest an average of 40 to 50 practitioners everyday in recent months, and have detained 35,000 since April, 1999.
The report warned that social unrest in China is not in the interest of Taiwan, because the unrest may affect the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMBINATION OF TRADITIONAL MEDIA AND INTERNET IS FUTURE TREND

TEXT.P: At a time when the development of websites is facing a "bubble," Internet media should be based on traditional media if it is to have a bright future, a Taiwan media expert said on Thursday.

Lee Wan-lai, editor-in-chief of the Taipei-based Central News Agency (CNA), made the remark at the Wisers Info Tech Forum 2000 in Hong Kong. The conference is aimed at sharing experience and opinions among the media industry in Chinese societies.

Lee said that the rapid development of the Internet and the mushrooming of diverse websites in the mid-1990s in Taiwan were based on breakthroughs in high technology, the stimulation of the economy and a free and open society.
He indicated that conventional media with spin-off portals is the future trend, but added that he did not think that Internet media will replace conventional methods of news dissemination.
He also expressed the opinion that media groups should have the backup of other relevant business groups in order to ensure long-term development.

Lee mentioned that while many local network operators are finding ways to obtain benefits, they have found it difficult because of limited advertising resources, high personnel costs and high technology costs.

He said that providing only content on the web is not lucrative and he suggested that some media portal sites transfer to e-business industry and network operators to use high technology to promote economy and trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH BELIZE PRIME MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met with Belize Prime Minister Said Musa of Belize here on Wednesday, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the ROC and that Central American country.
President Chen expressed his gratitude to Musa for dispatching a congratulatory mission to his presidential inauguration on May 20.

Chen noted that the ROC and Belize established diplomatic ties 11 years ago when Musa was foreign minister of Belize. Chen also expressed his gratitude to Musa for his contributions to the promotion of cultural and economic cooperation between the two countries.

Chen pointed out that relations between the two countries will not be affected by the recent transition of power in the ROC. The new ROC government will further cement relations with Belize on the established basis, President Chen said.

Chen also expressed his thanks to Belize for its long-term staunch support of the ROC in its bids for membership in international organizations. Chen hoped that Belize will continue to support the ROC petitions for membership in international organizations, such as the UN and the World Health Organization (WHO).
Chen also praised the economic and political progress Belize has made under the able leadership of Musa. He described Belize as a great country comprised of many races living harmoniously.
Chen extended an invitation to Musa to visit the ROC at his convenience in the future. In return, Musa also invited President Chen to visit Belize.
Chen expressed his hope that he will be able to visit Belize as soon as possible.

Musa replied that he always upholds the principle of self-governance, and added that he will continue to promote ROC-Belize relations on this basis. Musa also expressed gratitude on behalf of the people and government of Belize for the ROC's assistance in Belize's development.
Both Chen and Musa are in Santo Domingo to attend the Dominican Republic's presidential inauguration on Wednesday, Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER SHENG-YEN ESTABLISHES 'TAIWAN'S NOBEL PRIZE'

TEXT.P: The International Cultural and Education Foundation of Dharma Drum Mountain on Thursday announced the establishment of the Dharma Drum Mountain Foundation for the Humanities and Social Sciences Prize.

The foundation was established to promote public appreciation for the humanities, said foundation founder Master Sheng-yen. He added that the foundation was formed in commemoration of his teacher, the late Elder Master Tung-chu. He said that he wants the new prize to be thought of as "Taiwan's Nobel Prize," and added that he hopes the prestige of the award will rise to an international level.
Meanwhile, Master Sheng-yen emphasized that the prize will not only be awarded to Buddhists, but also to all Taiwanese and even to people beyond Taiwan's shores.

Thursday's press conference, held at the National Central Library, coincided with a donation ceremony. Shih Ping-huang, founder and chairman of Sunplus Technology Co., and his wife, Wu Yi-yeh, donated NT$200 million (US$6.45 million) to the new foundation. They said that science and technology professionals like themselves earn a lot of money from their knowledge, and should give something back to society.

Shih added that they made the donation to thank their parents for raising them well. He likened their donation to "throwing out a minnow to catch a whale," as their gift was small in comparison to its potential benefit to society.
The foundation is actively seeking additional contributors to assist it in funding the humanities and related research. It has set a fund-raising goal of NT$5 billion (US$160 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NAMES NEW TAIWAN AFFAIRS OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Beijing has recently reshuffled the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under its State Council by naming new office heads, an office spokesman said on Thursday.

In an interview with CNA, Zhang Mingqing, director of the office's Information Bureau, said that Tang Shubei and Wang Yonghai, two of the three deputy heads of the office, will retire, and that Li Bingcai, Wang Fuqing, Zhou Mingwei and Wang Caixi will be appointed as deputy directors.
It was the first time that Beijing had officially confirmed the personnel change, although it had been widely reported by the media on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Li, the only vice head to keep his job, will be promoted to first deputy director in charge of trade and economic affairs concerning Taiwan, and he will also concurrently take over Tang's concurrent job as vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a semi-official organization authorized by Beijing to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal contacts.

Chang, however, would not confirm reports that Vice Premier Qian Qichen will be named ARATS president, succeeding Wang Daohan, or that mainland Chinese Ambassador in the United States Li Zhaoxing will become the new director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE AND FOREIGN INVESTMENT HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Foreign and overseas Chinese investment in Taiwan hit a new high during the first seven months of this year, reaching US$4.5 billion, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The MOEA Investment Commission said on Thursday that foreign and overseas Chinese investment made from January to July had already surpassed the US$4.3 billion recorded for the whole of 1998.
The statistics show that in July alone, a total of 129 foreign and overseas Chinese investment projects worth US$926 million were approved by the MOEA.

From Jan. 1 to July 31, the MOEA approved a total of 801 investment projects from foreign and overseas Chinese investors, with an increase in value of 120.23 percent compared to the year-earlier level.

In the same period, the MOEA approved 642 overseas investment projects submitted by local investors, with a total value of US$2.18 billion, representing growth of 4.62 percent from the same period of last year.

The investments abroad were made mainly in Central America, the United States, Singapore and Panama, and covered the finance, insurance, electronic and electrical appliance, service, retailing, and vehicle manufacturing industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING SHOULD RESUME DIALOGUE SOON: US OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior US Department of State official has urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue as soon as possible to prevent unexpected twists from further hampering cross-strait rapprochement.

Darryl Johnson, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, made the call at a just-concluded "Track II" roundtable meeting on cross-strait relations and the US policy toward Taiwan and mainland China.

Meanwhile, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush, also the top US liaison officer with the Republic of China in the absence of official ties, made a similar appeal on the same occasion.

Both Johnson and Bush said they are afraid that if cross-strait dialogue cannot resume promptly, changes in domestic political conditions on both sides of the Taiwan Strait could add up to twists and obstacles to resumption of bilateral talks.

Johnson, who had headed the AIT Taipei office before assuming his current post, and Bush said they believe that the timing for resuming cross-strait dialogue is crucial. They pointed out that Taiwan is scheduled to hold parliamentary and local government chiefs elections late next year and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will step down the post in 2002. Noting that all these factors could change the political climates on both sides, they said cross-strait dialogue should resume as early as possible.

In an interview with CNA on Wednesday, Prof. Donald Zagoria, also the chief organizer of the Aug. 14-15 roundtable, said although Taiwan and mainland China are not expected to come to terms on their dispute over the "one China" principle, they are likely to resume their long-stalled dialogue next year.

Zagoria, who has made many visits to Taiwan and mainland China for talks with their senior leaders in the past few years, said both Taipei and Beijing basically hope to resume dialogue, but they are hindered by their different definition of "one China."
Zagoria said he believes the two sides will be able to narrow their gap concerning the "one China" cognition. But he didn't elaborate on the reasons of his confidence.
The US China hand pointed out that cross-strait relations are the most dangerous factor that could trigger military confrontation between the United States and mainland China.
Against this backdrop, Zagoria said, both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the United States should face the issue with prudence, patience, pragmatism and dialogue.
Zagoria further said the current annual policy review meeting of Beijing leaders at the summer resort of Beidaihe should be a key point for observing Beijing's new policy guidelines toward Taiwan.

Zagoria said he thinks that mainland China will continue its military intimidation to curb growth of pro-independence force in Taiwan while simultaneously inviting influential pro-unification Taiwan politicians to visit the mainland for talks.

Zagoria said he personally believes that the World Trade Organization (WTO) would provide a forum for cross-strait dialogue after both sides are admitted to the organization late this year or early next year.
This was the eighth cross-strait roundtable sponsored by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a noted US think tank which has enormous influence on US foreign policy.

More than 20 scholars and experts from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States took part in the two-day meeting. The participants spent much time discussing ways to resolve the "one China" dispute. Most of them said there is no easy way to settle the issue in the near future. But they agreed that the continued cross-strait trade and cultural exchanges are good omens for improvement of bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPATIBLE WITH SILICON VALLEY: SINGAPORE STATESMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Israel are the only two countries in the world compatible with California's Silicon Valley in the era of the "new economy," Singapore elder statesman Lee Kuan Yew commented on Wednesday in Kuala Lumpur.

Lee voiced his opinion that today, "only Taiwan and Israel have adequate scales to maintain links with the US' Silicon Valley," because both Taiwan and Israel have a great deal of young professional talent. He added that "close relationships between each other can help produce many creative ideas."
Lee made the remarks while answering questions at a seminar sponsored by Malaysia's Institute of Strategic and International Studies.

Recalling a symposium held by Cisco Systems Co. in which he participated two years ago at Stanford University, Lee said "the country which has the scale to maintain links with Silicon Valley" was the answer to a major question hanging over the attendees -- which country could create a Silicon Valley of its own?

According to the Singapore senior statesman, the city state does not lack the funds for career development, but the people of Singapore are content with what they have. Therefore, "we must change the people's concepts and culture, and change their old-fashioned mindsets," he noted.

Noting that the use of the Internet will be ubiquitous in the coming 20 or 30 years, he stressed that to succeed in the era of the "new economy," people should make all-out efforts to face challenges and be brave enough to take risks, including the possibility of losing their affluent lifestyles and wealth.
Lee returned to Singapore on Thursday after concluding a four-day visit to Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER APOLOGIZES FOR PROSECUTOR'S STATEMENT

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Thursday apologized to legislator Liao Hwu-peng for a public prosecutor's statement the day before which claimed that a raid on Liao's office and dormitory had turned up fabricated stock certificates.
The controversial incident marked the first time that the nation's judicial personnel have entered the legislature to conduct a search.
Chen said at a press conference and later in a news release that he is sorry for any damage caused by the prosecutor's statement, which the prosecutor later retracted.

He went on to say that a prosecutor should notify the Legislative Yuan before conducting a search within its perimeters, but Wednesday's search -- which took place before Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng was notified -- "apparently showed a difference in understanding" between the person they notified and the Legislative Yuan.

However, he added that the prosecutors did not search Liao's research room in the legislature in the end, so that there should not be any problems with regard to prosecutors searching the legislative compound.
Chen added that he did not take any "political considerations" into account and was concerned only with whether or not the procedure was legal.
However, regarding the search of Liao's Taipei residence, Wang said on Thursday that the legislator's dormitory should have been considered part of the Legislative Yuan.

Wang added that Chen's apology is not the issue, because the fundamental issue is really about respect. He went on to say that the country is an integrated whole, whose different branches must respect each other so that the autonomy of the legislature can be ensured.

Legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties held an emergency joint meeting on Thursday, and the general conclusion was that most legislators recognize the resolve displayed by the prosecutors to fight corruption and crime, but that the new government should show more respect toward the legislature.

The controversy came about when Tainan prosecutors reported that their search of Liao's apartment in the Ta-an complex, a "dormitory" building occupied exclusively by legislators, turned up 10,000 fake stock certificates in Chi Mei Electronics, an unlisted Tainan-based company.

Lin Chieh-teh of the Public Prosecutor's Office of Taiwan's High Court told the media on Wednesday that the search was conducted because Chi Mei Corp. had told the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office that "some people" were suspected of having fabricated Chi Mei share certificates.

Upon learning of the search, Liao rushed back to Taipei from his constituency in Yunlin County on Wednesday night. He told the media that the shares the prosecutors had taken away from his house are those of Chungtai Canned Manufacturing Co., of which he is board chairman. He stressed that he owns no Chi Mei shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA FORECAST TO BECOME WORLD ECONOMIC CENTER IN 40 YEARS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The world's center of economic growth will shift from the Atlantic to the Pacific by 2040, Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew forecast on Wednesday.
But Lee claimed that latent suspicions exiting between the Chinese, Japanese, and Koreans will degenerate into conflict if there is no assurance of big-power balance in the region.

He said he thinks that the major threat will come from conflict between mainland China and the United States over Taiwan. "The largest imponderable is the danger of conflict between China and the US over Taiwan's drift or move toward independence."
Lee made the remarks while giving a keynote speech at a seminar sponsored by the Kuala Lumpur-based Institute of Strategic and International Studies.

Pointing out that mainland China will be the locomotive of the region's economic growth after it enters the World Trade Organization, Lee said that Northeast Asia will reap more benefits than Southeast Asia from the situation by enjoying a three-fold or five-fold increase in current business and investment volumes.

According to the Singapore elder statesman, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, and Korea will also benefit from increasing investments in Southeast Asia, as the economies of the northern regions are complementary to those of the south.

The challenge at present is how to maintain a security balance, dissolve the possibilities of war and risk within the region, he noted, adding that an all-out focus on economic developments and market competition by regional countries will upgrade their living standards.

The 1997 financial crisis, he said, has slashed Southeast Asia's growth rate in the region the from the previous level of 9.7 percent to the current 7.6 percent. During the same period, the average gross domestic product of the Northeast Asian economies jumped from 25.1 percent 27.5 percent.

Citing additional figures as evidence, he detailed that the combined value of Southeast Asian stock markets has declined by 23 percent, down from the pre-crisis level of US$753 billion in 1996 to US$578 billion in 1999. At the same time, the combined value of bourses in the north has grown by 64 percent, increasing from US$981 billion to US$1.6 trillion.

Southeast Asian countries can ride out the crisis setback by making the necessary changes and completing their structural reforms to make them less vulnerable in the event of another market crisis, he emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO OFFER US$ 4.6 MILLION IN LOAN TO DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will offer US$4.6 million in loan to the Dominican Republic to help the Caribbean nation modernize its congress and budget office, a senior official in charge of foreign aid affairs said on Thursday.

Loh Ping-cheung, secretary-general of the ROC's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF), made the statement after Dominican Senate Speaker Ramon Alburquez said on Wednesday that visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian has promised to offer US$4.8 million as guarantee for his country to borrow money from the International Monetary Fund.
Loh said the Dominican parliamentary leader's remarks were not fully correct.

Loh said Eugene Chien, secretary-general to the President, already held a press conference in Santo Domingo to clarify Alburquez's statement. Chien accompanied President Chen on his current six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at cementing the ROC's diplomatic ties with its allies.

Loh said the fact is that the ROC will join forces with the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) in offering a loan of US$28 million to the Dominican Republic to finance its congressional and budget office modernization plan.
Of the amount, Loh said, the ROC will offer a loan of US$4.6 million and the remainder will be provided by the IDB.
Loh said the US$4.6 million loan program has been proposed last year and that the ROC government plans to earmark money for the project in its budget plans for the next three to four years.
According to Loh, the loan program will be implemented after the two countries formally sign an agreement on the project.
Loh said the government has kept open and transparent the whole process of negotiating with the IDB and the Dominican Republic government concerning the loan program.

Loh stressed that the lending offer is an old project, not a new aid program cranked out during President Chen's current overseas trip. Chen said prior to his departure for his first post-inauguration overseas visit that he will not make any new aid commitment during his trip.
Loh said the loan project is mainly designed to help the Dominican Republic strengthen its democratic mechanism through modernizing and beefing up its congress and budget office.

President Chen arrived in the Dominican Republic on Monday to attend the Caribbean ally's presidential election on Wednesday. He ended his state visit on Thursday and left for Nicaragua to continue his first overseas trip since taking office on May 20. Following his Nicaragua visit, he will travel to Costa Rica and three West African countries -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: US NEWSPAPER BLASTS CLINTON ADMINISTRATION FOR TAIWAN SNUB
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A US newspaper on Thursday blasted the Clinton administration for keeping Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's US stopover under wraps in deference to Beijing, calling it "Chinese interference in American internal affairs."

Chen, who is currently on his 13-day, six-state "journey of friendship" to the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa, had arrived in Los Angeles on Sunday for a 15-hour transit stop before traveling on to the Dominican Republic.

The Washington Post criticized the US government for doing "everything it could" to keep the American public from knowing that the head of state from "one of Asia's most vibrant democracies" was in the country, for fear of upsetting mainland China.

The paper went on to say that the administration even went as far as pressuring Chen to back out of a "private, unofficial reception" to be held in Los Angeles by a former congressional aide, to which five members of the US Congress were invited.
The reception was canceled, and only one of the invited guests -- US Representative Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) -- defied the administration to meet Chen in person at his hotel.

The paper pointed out that "a quick meet-and-greet" between Chen and a few congressmen should not have been taken as something that would renege on the United States' long-standing "one China" policy.

It questioned Beijing's right -- or that of any foreign government, for that matter -- to tell foreign visitors where they may go or US congressmen whom they may see, calling it a blatant example of "Chinese interference in American internal affairs."

Chen, traveling at the head of a delegation of more than 200 ROC officials, business leaders and journalists, is scheduled to leave for Nicaragua on Thursday, after which he will travel to Costa Rica (Aug. 18-19), Gambia (Aug. 20-21), Burkina Faso (Aug. 21-23), and Chad (Aug. 23-25).

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO BUY 25 PERCENT STAKE IN MAINLAND CHINESE AIRLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) plans to buy a 25 percent stake of mainland China's China Air Cargo Transport Co. (CACT), the Hong Kong-based China News Agency said in a dispatch from Shanghai on Thursday.

The news agency quoted Lo Chu-ping, board secretary-general of mainland China's China Eastern Air Ltd., as reporting that CAL has settled on mainland China's air cargo market in view of the fact that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are expected to soon join the World Trade Organization.
China Eastern Air Ltd. holds a 70 percent stake in CACT, the only all-air cargo transport company in mainland China.
It is CAL's cargo transport strength, capital and management experience that makes China Eastern Air Ltd. willing to seek cooperation with CAL, said Lo.

The news agency report quoted sources with mainland Chinese transportation authorities as saying that because both CAL and China Eastern Air Ltd. are mostly state-owned, the bilateral cooperation will have a certain political meaning and will be regarded by the mainland as a touchstone for the "three direct links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE WILL COST TAIWAN US$ 560 MILLION ANNUALLY: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A local financial expert calculated on Thursday that Alzheimer's disease will eventually cost Taiwan as much as NT$17.6 billion (US$567 million) annually.

Chou Li-fang, associate professor in finance at National Chengchi University, said in a seminar in the southern city of Kaohsiung that the number of Taiwan people over the age of 65 already accounted for 7.1 percent of the population in 1993, which is considered an elderly society according to the criteria set by the United Nations.
Taiwan's gray population this year has been recorded at 8.6 percent, and it is expected that the aged will account for 23.9 percent of the population in 2051.

Chou indicated that the problem of the aging population should receive more concern from the government, citing as an example the fact that at present, around 340,000 old people in Taiwan need long-term care because of senility, mostly as a result of Alzheimer's.
He added that each Alzheimer's patient costs the country between NT$310,000 and NT$710,000 each year.

Chou pointed out that caring for Alzheimer's patients is a heavy burden for the families of the victims and society in general, and suggested that the government establish a long-term care system to solve the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: US$ 4.6 MILLION FOR DOMINICAN REPUBLIC `NOT AID': ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A sum of US$46 million promised by Taipei to Santo Domingo is a part of a syndicated loan designed to help with the "parliamentary modernization" of the Dominican Republic, Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday.

Chen stressed that the money is not new economic assistance, but rather part of a syndicated loan of more than US$20 million jointly promoted by the ROC in cooperation with the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) to help modernize the country's parliament.

According to the president, officials with the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs had reported to him on several cooperation projects between the ROC and some of its diplomatic allies in Central America and Africa before his departure on his overseas trip.

Some of the cooperative ventures were previously clinched by Taiwan's former Kuomintang government, including the package to help the Dominican Republic with its plan of "parliamentary modernization," Chen said during a breakfast meeting with reporters from Taipei.

The president's remarks came after a statement made by Dominican Senate Speaker Ramon Alburquez on Wednesday during the inauguration of President Hipolito Mejia that Chen had promised to provide US$46 million to the Dominican Republic to help the country pay back deposits to the International Monetary Fund.

The declaration stirred up a strong reaction in Taiwan, with many suspecting that Chen's administration is engaged in the very "money politics," which the president had earlier vowed he would never stoop to.
Meanwhile, Chen had already left the country for Nicaragua after concluding a four-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT YET TO DECIDE ON WHETHER TO SERVE AS NUC HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday that he has not decided on whether or not to concurrently serve as chairman of the National Unification Council (NUC).

Chen, who was in the capital city of the Dominican Republic for Wednesday's inauguration of President Hipolito Mejia, made the remarks at a breakfast press conference for Taiwan reporters covering his 13-day, six-state trip which will also take him to Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
"It's too early to say now whether I will be the NUC chairman, and it is not impossible that the position could be filled by somebody else who is fully qualified," he said.

Concern has recently mounted on both sides of the Taiwan Strait over whether or not Chen will take over the NUC chairmanship, as it would be considered a gauge of whether Chen, a member of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is likely to deviate from the DPP's pro-independence stance and support Taiwan's unification with mainland China.
Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui founded the NUC and also served as its chairman.

Chen did say that the NUC will have to be reshuffled, as the tenure of all its members expires soon, but he stressed that the personnel change will not be tantamount to the abolishment of the organization. He also said that any revisions to the Guidelines for National Unification would have to be made in line with the changing times.

Chen said that any solution to the cross-strait dispute must be first approved by the Taiwan public and that he will listen to the voice of the Taiwan people before making any decision as to whether unification is the only and best solution to the cross-strait problem.
The president emphasized, however, that normalizing cross-strait relations is his government's obligation and "moral mission."

Answering questions as to whether or not he will invite Vice President Annette Lu to serve again as his running mate in Taiwan's next presidential election if he is to seek reelection, Chen said that since he has only been in office for three months, his focus has always been on how to do a good job as president and he has never even thought of the question of reelection, far less a running mate.
In an interview in Taipei earlier in the day, Lu was reported to have said that she would never run with Chen again, even if invited.
Chen said that in future he will assign Lu to visit foreign countries on his behalf, as she is interested in, and capable of handling, foreign affairs.
Lu, Taiwan's first female vice president, will reportedly visit El Salvador, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, in October. Her office has denied that any such plans exist.
The president said his is satisfied with his visit to the Dominican Republic and described it as "meaningful and useful."

He thanked President Mejia for his "considerate arrangements" which enabled Chen to meet with many heads of state and ranking officials of foreign countries, thus improving mutual understanding between the ROC and those countries.
Chen said that he has accepted invitations from the presidents of several diplomatic allies, including Honduras, to visit their countries.

He also defended what was described by the media as his "low-key" transit stop in Los Angeles, saying it was out of respect for the host country and the "tacit understanding" between Taiwan and the United States.
Chen and his entourage of 200 was scheduled to arrive in Nicaragua, the second leg of his two-continent trip, later in the day for a two-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PARTY REPRESENTATIVES COMMENT ON US PARTY PLATFORMS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Delegates of the Republic of China's major political parties observing the US Democratic Convention on Thursday agreed that both Republican and Democratic platforms regarding US support of Taiwan are similar.

Shaw Yu-min, deputy secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang, said that although the Democratic platform does not give the impression of being as clear and resolute as the Republican platform, that is not really the key factor.
He went on to say that what is important is that the ROC is now a democratic nation whose values are in line with the United States' so-called "mainstream" values.

Furthermore, he continued, the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), a US law that outlines US conduct toward Taiwan -- including the continued provision of defensive weapons to Taiwan -- has been in effect for several decades, and both the Republican and the Democratic parties should adhere to the law.
People First Party legislator Chou Hsi-wei agreed with Shaw that the Democratic Party's new platform is basically the same as that of the Republican Party, only worded differently.

A comparison of the two party platforms reveal that both parties support the "one China" policy, but the Republican Party supports the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, while the Democratic Party espouses following through on the responsibilities set forth in the TRA.
The Republicans describe mainland China "strategic competitors" while the Democrats call them "strategic partners."
The Republican platform states that the party will keep its promise to the Taiwan people because they are long-term friends of the United States, and because Taiwan's democracy is a "real" democracy.

The Republican platform also states that any issue regarding Taiwan's future must be resolved in a peaceful manner with the agreement of the Taiwan public. If mainland China goes against these principles and attacks Taiwan, the platform states that the United States will respond according to the TRA and assist in defending Taiwan.

The Democratic platform also urged Taiwan and mainland China to resolve their differences through peaceful methods and refrain from resolving issues by force. It went on to say that the Democratic Party supports resolving cross-strait issues according to the wishes of the Taiwan public.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM URGED TO STOP BEIJING EMBASSY'S FALUN GONG HARASSMENT

TEXT.P: A major Australian daily has urged Prime Minister John Howard to stop harassment by Chinese diplomats of followers of the Falun Gong religious sect in Canberra, Sydney, and other Australian cities.

The Sydney Morning Herald made the comments in a editorial on Thursday. "When China oppresses its people, there is not much Australia or any other outsiders can do, except speak up for the oppressed. If China's fear of difference extends to its diplomats' behavior in Australia, it is a more serious matter," the daily said.

"As long as the beliefs and practices of Falun Gong harm no one, they should not only be tolerated, they should also be protected from anyone who might seek to curb or interfere with them," the paper said.
"The Prime Minister, Mr. Howard, who has been willing to speak out in relation to human rights abuses in Malaysia, should be consistent in this case, too," it added.

The Herald published the editorial after the Chinese Embassy in Canberra on Wednesday denied that its diplomats had tried to extend the ongoing mainland crackdown on Falun Gong sect members to Australia, claiming that an earlier Herald story to that effect was a complete fabrication.

The original story had quoted the Australian Security and Intelligence Organization and the Australian Federal Police as saying that they were monitoring harassment by Chinese diplomats of Falun Gong members. The harassment included tapping the phones of Falun Gong members, slashing their car tires, and damaging their property, the daily reported.

In addition, Chinese diplomats have also reportedly demanded that the municipal governments of Blacktown and Hurstville, both near Sydney, deny the sect members the right to use local facilities and engage in community activities.
"There is no mistaking the Chinese government's hostility to the Falun Gong sect, in China and abroad," the paper said in the editorial, headlined "In Fear of Falun Gong."
Australia and China on Wednesday held a one-day closed-door dialogue in Canberra on the issue of human rights in China.

"It is not clear what discussion of the suspected harassment of Falun Gong members in this country took place. But if the least harassment has occurred, it is a matter of great seriousness. Falun Gong members in Australia . . . should have the freedom to express their beliefs within the law like anyone else," the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATOR PROTESTS EXCLUSION OF DALAI LAMA FROM PEACE SUMMIT

TEXT.P: In a letter to US Ambassador to the United Nations Richard Halbrooke Thursday, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms expressed his dismay that the UN has refused to invite the Dalai Lama, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, to the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders.

"Mr. Ambassador, can it be that the United Nations has chosen to appease the communist dictators in Beijing (who drove the Dalai Lama into exile in the first place, and who continue to oppress the Tibetan people), rather than to include one of the world's best known and respected spiritual leaders?" wrote the North Carolina Republican senator.

"Surely you share my dismay that the organizers of a world peace summit would choose to exclude a Nobel Peace Prize winner. Isn't it ironic that one of the world's most brutal atheistic dictatorships can dictate to the UN who can and cannot participate in a so-called `World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders'?" asked Helms.

"Mr. Ambassador, the United States must not condone such weak-kneed behavior by the UN. If this is to be truly a summit of religious and spiritual leaders, then political considerations must be set aside," concluded the senator.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TOLD TO STOP HARASSING FALUN GONG MEMBERS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told mainland China to stop harassing Falun Gong sect members in Australia, ignoring advice from his senior officials about a possible backlash from Beijing.

In an statement faxed to the CNA on Friday morning, Downer said the Australian delegates to the bilateral human rights dialogue with mainland China in Canberra on Wednesday had raised their concerns about alleged harassment of Falun Gong sect members in Canberra and Sydney by the mainland Chinese embassy.

"We obviously would not want to see harassment of any Australian citizens in Australia or, for that matter, anywhere by any embassies or diplomatic officials. We have raised these concerns that have been expressed by some of the Falun Gong practitioners here in Australia," said Downer.
He said the Chinese delegation, led by Vice Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi, denied harassing the sect members in Australia.

It is understood that senior Australia officials had earlier advised Downer to refrain from publicly making any statement on mainland China's human rights abuses or harassment of Falun Gong members in China or Australia for fear of angering Beijing.

But Downer ignored the advice and told Chinese delegates that Australia was concerned about the harassment, reflecting Canberra's assertiveness over certain issues, including human rights abuses and persecution of dissents by Beijing authorities, political analysts said.

The Sydney Morning Herald this week quoted officers from the Australian Security and Intelligence Organization and the Australian Federal Police as revealing that they have been monitoring the situation after Falun Gong members complained about the harassment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IMPORTS OF AUSSIE BEEF EXPECTED TO CONTINUE GROWING

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will continue to be a major growing market for Australian beef in the coming years, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Research Economics (ABARE).

In an interview with the CNA on Friday morning, ABARE analyst Tris Gleeson said that "Taiwan is our fifth biggest beef market and we believe our exports will continue rising in the next few years as a result of growing consumption of meat in that country."

Australia is the world's largest beef exporter, exporting 22 percent of the world's total. In 1999, Australia's total beef exports jumped to 868,000 kg from 856,000 kg in 1998. Japan is Australia's biggest market, followed by the United States, South Korea, and Canada, she said.
In 1999, Australia exported 34,700 kg of beef and veal to Taiwan, up from 33,700 kg in 1998, she said.

Gleeson said the prospects of exporting more beef to Taiwan in the near future are bright. "Our beef industry is competitive because we produce grains, and our exporters benefit from geographical proximity to Taiwan," she said.

Gleeson predicted Australian beef exports would rise after Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization, either at the end of this year or in early 2001, because Taipei will have to open its domestic market wider to foreign exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER TO ATTEND APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong will lead a delegation to attend a regional economic meeting in Brunei next month.

Global and regional macroeconomics, finance management, and the strengthening of the global financial system will be among the topics on the agenda at the 7th Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's finance ministers meeting, to be held in Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei, on September 9-10.

Prior to the finance ministers meeting, Deputy Finance Minister Sean Chen and Deputy Central Bank of China Chen Shih-meng will attend the APEC finance and central bank deputies meeting on September 7-8.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Y. Y. Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo assured visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday that Nicaragua will continue supporting the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations and other world bodies.
Aleman reaffirmed his country's commitment during a meeting with President Chen at the Nicaraguan Presidential Office which was completed recently with funds donated by the ROC.
Aleman expressed his gratitude for the ROC's financial, agricultural and technological assistance to Nicaragua since 1972 when the Central American country was rocked by a devastating earthquake.

"Nicaragua is a small, poor country. We appreciate and will never forget the ROC's longtime support and assistance," Aleman said, adding that his government will continue strengthening cooperation with the ROC and back its bid to take part in major international organizations.

For his part, President Chen said he doesn't think that Nicaragua is a small, poor country. "Instead, I think it is a great country as it still boldly moves toward democratization after enduring long-term martial law, civil war and numerous quake and hurricane natural disasters," Chen said.
The Aleman-Chen meeting was held in a conference hall dedicated to the ROC in appreciation of the ROC's financial support for the construction of the new Nicaraguan Presidential Office.

Chen thanked Aleman for his speeches in support of the ROC's UN bid at the annual UN General Assembly plenary session over past years. He lauded Aleman and former Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro as statesmen with a sense of justice.

Chen, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician said he admires Aleman's frequent call for his fellow Nicaraguan countrymen to stand up and contribute to national development. Like Aleman, Chen said, he consistently thinks that Taiwan should stand up and walk out into the world to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic embargo.
Chen arrived in Managua from the Dominican Republic on Thursday for a hectic two-day state visit after attending the inauguration of Dominican President Hipolito Mejia on Wednesday.

Upon his arrival at the Managua airport, Chen was accorded a red-carpet welcome and full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute. Aleman personally presided over the welcoming ceremony at the airport. Both Chen and Aleman reaffirmed their commitment to further reinforcing bilateral ties and cooperation in various fields based on existing foundations.
Chen then paid a visit to the Nicaraguan National Assembly where he was warmly received by a full house of Nicaraguan parliamentarians, senior government officials and diplomatic corps members.
Nicaraguan National Assembly Speaker Ivan Escobar Fornos conferred the Order of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro on President Chen in recognition of his efforts to promote relations between the two countries.
Chen then delivered a speech to Nicaraguan parliamentarians, stressing the ROC's desire to play a more active role in the international community.

Chen, the ROC's first opposition leader-turned-president, said the ROC is more than willing to share its developmental experience with its allies and work together with all countries around the world for global prosperity and peace.
Chen also told Nicaraguan lawmakers that he feels at home to visit the Nicaraguan lawmaking body because he himself once served as an ROC legislator for five years.
Later in the day, Chen visited the ROC Embassy in Nicaragua where he was briefed by ROC Ambassador Tsai Teh-san on Nicaragua's general situation and relations between the two countries.
Chen told the embassy staff that his administration will faithfully implement cooperative programs and lending and economic aid offers signed by the previous Kuomintang government with Nicaragua.

Chen will sign a joint communique with Aleman prior to his departure on Friday for Costa Rica to continue his current six-state "journey of friendship aimed at cementing the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies.
This is Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20. The Aug. 13-25 journey will also take him to the ROC's three West African allies -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX CLOSES 33.57 POINTS HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 0.4 percent higher on Friday in active trading following Wall Street's overnight gains and on a positive outlook for the technology sector.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, picked up 33.57 points to close at 8,176.82, on turnover of NT$124.45 billion (US$4.02 billion).

The market opened higher following the overnight rises on the Wall Street, but selling pressure began to emerge after the index breached 8,200 points. And the index lost most of its early gains due to profit-taking by short-term players.
A total of 2.34 billion shares changed hands during the three-hour trading session.
The bourse opened at 8,192.30 and fluctuated between 8,276.24 and 8175.35 during the day's trading, with electronics stocks posting some gains and semiconductor issues acting relatively weakly.

Six of the eight major categories registered gains, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by pulp and paper shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.8 percent, construction stocks at 0.7 percent , electronics issues at 0.4 percent, and cement issues at 0.1 percent.
The two other major categories, foodstuff shares and bank and insurance stocks, remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 333 to 159, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROGATE PRODUCT AND TRAVEL FAIR TO OPEN NEXT THURSDAY

TEXT.P: A product and travel fair to promote trade, cultural and tourism relations between the Republic of China, central and eastern Europe, and the Baltic nations, will open at the Taipei World Trade Center from August 24-27.
The fair, dubbed Eurogate 2000, will be co-sponsored by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and is the second event of its kind to be held in Taipei.

Liu Hsiang-pu, director-general of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, noted that Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Lithuania took part in the first fair last June, while an additional three countries will be represented this time around.

Liu said that Latvia and the Republic of Macedonia have formally registered to participate, while Adriatic nation Slovenia failed to register in time, but will provide trade and economic information in a display booth.
He also said that all participating countries will send delegations to Taiwan to promote bilateral trade relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 18, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, conqueror of a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Admiral Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, now in Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War I, is born.
1900: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Indian politician and diplomat, is born. She served as ambassador to Moscow, Washington and Mexico and was president of the UN General Assembly in 1953.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung.
1974: ROC baseball teams win for the first time all three world titles of Little League, Senior League and Big League.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its racist politics.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action to launch a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the ROC leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Honduras, and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy at San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: Earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."
