DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICA BECOMES NEW BASE OF TAIWAN'S TEXTILE INDUSTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By C.P. Wang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Over the past decade, Taiwan's textile manufacturers have one by one moved their production lines overseas, taking advantages of lower labor costs and investment incentives.
Central America and the Caribbean countries have benefited from this exodus.

Comparatively high production costs, difficulties in acquiring land for factories, and mounting environmental consciousness have forced Taiwan's textile manufacturers to find solutions outside of Taiwan.

Mainland China and Southeast Asia were once the most favored regions for Taiwan textile makers seeking to branch out, but many of them became frustrated by disturbing non-economic factors, and profits soon began to dwindle, making Central America more attractive.

In early June, the US Congress approved the Caribbean Basin Initiative (CBI) Enhancement Act aimed at luring more investors into the region to help stimulate the economies. With the implementation of the CBI Act, effective from Oct. 1, 2000 through Sept. 30, 2008, textile products from the 24 countries in Central America and the Caribbean will be subject to beneficial treatment in the US market.

With its tremendous demand, North America has long been the target market of textile industries all over the world. In 1994, the US Congress approved the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) to provide beneficial measures to Mexico. This allowed textile products from Mexico to have easier access to the quota-regulated US market.
NAFTA helped Mexico to attract many foreign textile manufacturers, among them Nien Hsing Textile Co. from Taiwan.

While foreign investors have concentrated their interest in Mexico, NAFTA is indirectly to the disadvantage of the Central American countries. The implementation of the CBI Act, according to the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF), will make the 24 countries of the region more attractive.

The TTF has suggested that Nicaragua, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Honduras and Guatemala are most favorable to Taiwan's textile manufacturers, in view of their abundant natural resources, low labor costs, stable political situations and free economic systems. It takes between three and seven days for deliveries from the Central American countries to reach the US market, and a secure delivery schedule is another advantage.
Several Taiwan textile manufacturers have already set up bases in Central America. Managers of these processing plants have pointed out that Central America has various advantages.

Nicaragua, for instance, was chosen by Taiwan textile manufacturers because of low labor costs (US$115 per month), as well as good supplies of apparel. Honduras has Puerto Cortes, the largest seaport in the Caribbean Sea, while El Salvador has a sound infrastructure.

The Central American countries are also the most cordial allies of the Republic of China. While reinforcing diplomatic relations, the ROC government is also encouraging the industries to further their cooperation with the Central American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA URGED TO TAKE BACK ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Mainland China should cooperate with the Republic of China in repatriating illegal mainland Chinese immigrants into Taiwan, senior officials said on Friday.

Cheng Tsai-kuei, a section chief with the Bureau of Immigration under the Ministry of the Interior, and Liu Teh-hsun, a department chief with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the appeal at a public hearing sponsored by Kuomintang Legislator Tsao Erh-chung.

Tsao, a lawmaker from the ROC-held frontline island of Matsu, said as the Mid-Autumn Festival is approaching, the government should accelerate repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants so that they can spend the festival with their families in their hometowns.

The Mid-Autumn Festival, also known as the Moon Festival, falls on the 15th day of the eighth moon on the lunar calendar or Sept. 12 this year. It is one of the three most important festivals in Chinese society.
Tsao said all the three detention centers set up by the ROC government to accommodate seized mainland immigrants have reached capacity.
Take the Matsu detention center as an example. Tsao said anyone who has ever visited there would find that it is not a suitable place to shelter illegal mainland immigrants.
"I hope our relevant government agencies can develop an illegal mainland immigrants early warning system and craft out a systematic repatriation formula," Tsao urged.

Responding to Tsao's call, Cheng of the Immigration Bureau said 1,900-plus illegal mainland immigrants are still waiting for repatriation, about 1,800 of whom are staying at the three special detention centers. Except for the Matsu center, the other two are located in Taiwan, one in the northern county of Hsinchu and the other in the northeastern county of Ilan.
There are still more than 100 illegal mainland immigrants detained at other places due to the overcrowding in the three special detention centers, Cheng said.

Cheng pointed out that the only obstacle to repatriating the illegal mainland immigrants lies in Beijing's uncooperative attitude. According to him, repatriation tends to come to a halt so long as relations across the Taiwan Strait become strained.

For instance, Cheng recalled that repatriation was halted for several months after former President Lee Teng-hui declared cross-strait ties as a special state-to-state relationship. Lee's remarks enraged Beijing and sent cross-strait ties to a new low.
And after several months of difficult talks, Cheng said Beijing finally agreed to take back a batch of illegal mainland immigrants on March 19 this year.
However, Cheng said, Beijing again broke its promise after Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, won the ROC's March 18 presidential election.

"The mainland Red Cross Society informed us that they couldn't dispatch a ferry boat to take back the mainland immigrants as originally scheduled because higher-level mainland officials had not given a green light," Cheng recalled.

At present, the Red Cross Society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are authorized to handle illegal mainland immigrants repatriation. "Without mainland China's cooperation, we cannot unilaterally repatriate any mainland immigrant before the Moon Festival," Cheng said.
Speaking on the same occasion, Liu Teh-hsun of the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said immigrants' security is the biggest concern of the ROC government in repatriation.

"Therefore, we cannot unilaterally send back illegal mainland immigrants," Liu said, adding: "The mainland Red Cross Society must first inform its Taiwan counterpart of the timing and place for repatriation, then we can start necessary preparations."

Noting that the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has been actively contacting its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), concerning the repatriation issue.

"We hope the SEF-ARATS contact can achieve positive results as soon as possible, so that we can repatriate mainland immigrants before the Moon Festival," he said, adding that taking care of the large number of illegal mainland immigrants has become a heavy financial burden for the ROC government.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA WELCOMES ROC PRESIDENTIAL VISIT `AT ANY TIME'

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso told visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday that Panama would welcome Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian "at any time," according to Taipei City government officials.
The officials said on Friday that Moscoso denied US media reports that Panama would not welcome Chen.
Moscoso, inaugurated last September, visited the ROC in 1993 as the leader of the country's opposition. She revisited Taipei this July, when she met with Chen.

Ma lauded Moscoso as a model for female politicians, saying that women in Taiwan today are more active in politics than ever before. He noted that the current ROC vice president is a woman, that female members account for a quarter of the new Cabinet, and that women account for one-third of the members of the Taipei City Council.

Moscoso pointed out that her government is planning to enlarge the Panama Canal and expressed the hope that the expansion plan will help introduce more investment in her country, to which Ma promised that he will encourage Taiwan businessmen to visit Panama to tap investment opportunities.
During his stay in Panama, Ma also called on Foreign Relations Minister Jose Aleman.

Ma, who departed from Taipei on Aug. 10 for a two-week tour of the United States, Panama, Honduras and Guatemala, noted that his visit to Central America coincided with that of Chen, who is currently on a two-week, six-state visit to the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa, saying that while they are "rivals" at home, they are "partners" in promoting national interests when out of the country.
He expressed the hope that Panama City and Taipei can increase bilateral exchanges, including exchanges of students and artists.
Ma later toured schools for the children of overseas Chinese, and received a warm welcome from the students and faculty.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL CRITICIZES PRESIDENT'S LOAN RHETORIC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should take the blame for the strong suspicion provoked in Taiwan by the news that he has promised to extend US$4.6 million in a syndicated loan to the Dominican Republic, a ranking Kuomintang official said on Friday.

Jason Hu, head of the KMT's Cultural Affairs Department and former minister of foreign affairs, said Chen himself is to blame for the situation, because the president had vowed prior to his departure on his current overseas trip that he would promise no economic aid or loans to any of the countries on his itinerary.
The president held a news conference in Santo Domingo on Thursday with reporters from Taiwan to dismiss reports about US$4.6 million he had promised to offer to the Dominican Republic a day earlier.

He claimed that the money is only part of a syndicated loan of US$28 million jointly promoted by the Republic of China's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) in cooperation with the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) to help modernize the country's parliament, and stressed that the money does not constitute new economic assistance or a gift.

Hu, who served as foreign minister in the former KMT administration, said he could not recall any such cooperative venture between the ICDF and IDB. If venture really exits, he went on, it should be a normal and routine Foreign Ministry activity.

In addition, the former foreign affairs minister also criticized Chen's recent remarks that ROC diplomatic officials stationed overseas should not use mainland China's diplomatic blockade against Taiwan as a pretext for their setbacks in the international community.

According to Hu, the officials have the responsibility to report the real situations in international society, and such remarks by Chen are just not fair to the many ROC diplomatic personnel working overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, NICARAGUA PRESIDENTS VOW TO ENHANCE TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Y. Y. Chen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Presidents Chen Shui-bian of the Republic of China and Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo of Nicaragua on Friday pledged to enhance bilateral relations between their two countries.
The heads of state of the two countries made the pledge in a joint communique they signed at the end of Chen's two-day visit to the Central American nation.
Chen promised that Taiwan will continue to encourage its private sector to invest in Nicaragua and to help with Nicaragua's educational and economic development.

For his part, Aleman reaffirmed his nation's support for the ROC's bids for membership in the United Nations and other international organizations, saying that Taiwan and its 23 million people deserve greater respect and support from the international community.

The two leaders noted in the communique that they have exchanged views on matters of mutual concern during the past two days, and that they both agree that existing international disputes should be solved peacefully through negotiations, in accordance with international laws.
While expressing satisfaction about existing ROC-Nicaragua ties, Chen and Aleman stressed that more efforts should be made to further cement the friendship and cooperation between the two countries.

Aleman extended appreciation to Chen for Taiwan's agricultural assistance to his country, and agreed with Chen that bilateral agricultural cooperation should be further expanded so as to help improve the living standards of Nicaraguan farmers.
Chen also praised Aleman for his dedication to promoting Nicaragua's political, economic and social developments.
Chen arrived in Managua from the Dominican Republic on Thursday for a hectic two-day state visit, after attending the inauguration of Dominican President Hipolito Mejia on Wednesday.

Chen then paid a visit to the Nicaraguan National Assembly, where he was warmly received by a full house of Nicaraguan parliamentarians, senior government officials and members of the nation's diplomatic corps.
Nicaraguan National Assembly Speaker Ivan Escobar Fornos conferred the Order of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro on Chen in recognition of his efforts to promote relations between the two countries.
Chen then delivered a speech to the Nicaraguan parliamentarians, in which he stressed the ROC's desire to play a more active role in the international community.
Later in the day, Chen visited the ROC Embassy in Nicaragua, where he was briefed by ROC Ambassador Tsai Teh-san on Nicaragua's general situation and relations between the two countries.
Chen and his entourage of 200 are scheduled to depart Nicaragua and fly to Costa Rica on Saturday morning. His two day visit there will be the third official stop on his two-continent trip.
This is Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20. The Aug. 13-25 journey will also take him to the ROC's three West African allies -- Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.007 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at 31.079.
The local currency opened at 31.081 and was traded between 31.076 and 31.082.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$102 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX EDGES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices continued its upward swing for the fourth consecutive day on Saturday thanks to follow-through buying in the technology stocks.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, picked up 32.25 points to close at 8,209.07 on a turnover of NT$84.33 billion (US$2.72 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX CLOSES SLIGHTLY HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market continued its upward swing for the fourth consecutive day on Saturday, thanks to follow-through buying in the technology sector.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, edged up 32.25 points to close at 8,209.07.

The market opened higher at 8,195.25 points following gains over the past three days. The index reached a high of 8,234.73 at one point, but lost some grounds in late session due to profit-taking by short-term players.
Market analysts said although the daily turnover was not large, trading in medium- and small-sized electronics stocks remained very brisk.
A total of 1.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$84.33 billion (US$2.72 billion) for the two-hour weekend trading session.

The price indexes for the eight major categories closed mixed, with electrical and electronics issues registering a 1 percent gain, while all other categories posting losses. The index for cement issues recorded the largest decline of 1 percent; followed by plastics and textiles, both down 0.9 percent; construction, down 0.6 percent; financial and banking stocks, down 0.4 percent; foodstuff, down 0.3 percent; and pulp and paper, down 0.1 percent. stocks, down 1.1 percent; and construction stocks, down 1.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers, 279 to 212, with 87 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TTV CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT ENDORSE NEWS AUTONOMY AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV) Chairman Lai Kuo-chou endorsed a news autonomy agreement at his inauguration ceremony on Saturday following his controversial appointment, which some critics have called "a politically charged decision."

The News Autonomy and Fair Reporting Joint Manifesto began as a signature drive that originated from TTV's news department. It covers such issues as political endorsements and public interest, editorial autonomy and fair reporting, working and managerial rights, commercial discourse and news values, and the principle of non-avoidance.

TTV's board of directors appointed Hu Yuan-hui, president of the Independence Evening News, to be the station's new president. Lai likened Hu -- who is highly regarded by his peers -- as an indispensable driver for the car that is TTV, while modestly claiming that Lai himself is but the car attendant who punches tickets and brings the tea and towels.
Lai and Hu's endorsement of the agreement won immediate praise and recognition from the acting presidential secretary-general, Chen Che-nan, who witnessed the inauguration.

Chen urged the new TTV leadership to give consideration not only to on-the-job professionalism, but also to professional ethics like the violinists in the movie Titanic who continued to belt out their soothing melodies even in the face of a life-and-death situation.

A statement issued by the Association of Taiwan Journalists on Friday criticized President Chen Shui-bian's administration for nominating Lai to the partially government-owned broadcast station as a political favor, adding that the decision will seriously harm the new government's image and set a poor example for the future.

However, Lai countered that his media expertise and education won him the position. Lai holds a doctorate in journalism from National Chengchi University and is a senior opposition Kuomintang official as well as the son-in-law of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

The statement recalled that Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had expressed its wholehearted support for the removal of political and military interests from the mass media while it was still an opposition party.

This move abrogates the DPP's past ideals and violates Chen's promises, the statement said, adding that the "backroom dealing" was undoubtedly aimed at maintaining warm relations with the former president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUTURES MARKET REGISTERS GAIN

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Saturday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for September went up 98 points to close at 8,281, with 3,951 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for October also surged 98 points to close at 8,309, with 45 contract transactions, while December futures rose 92 points to finish at 8,348, with three contract deals struck.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 8,183 for September; 8,211 for October; 8,256 for December; 8,282 for next March; and 8,396 for next June.
TAIEX Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also closed higher.

September TE futures moved up 8.2 points to finish at 449.2, with 1,291 contract transactions, while October TE futures picked up 5.5 points to close at 448.5, with 15 contract transactions. And December TE futures surged 1 points to close at 449, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures advanced 3.2 points to close at 910.2, with 540 contract transactions; October TF futures gained 2.8 points to finish at 913, with five contract transactions; December TF futures climbed 5.8 points to close at 933.8, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months. (By Sofia Wu) ENDITM ZCZC CEP009 08-19-00 US EXPECTED TO ANNOUNCE RADAR SYSTEM TRANSFER TO TAIWAN SOON

Washington, Aug. 18 (CNA) The Clinton administration is expected shortly to follow through on a promise made last year to transfer an advanced long-range radar system to Taiwan, according to a report in The Washington Times on Friday.
The daily reported that the Pentagon is close to announcing final approval of the sale, a move which is likely to upset Beijing.
In the spring of 1999, the Clinton administration agreed in principle to sell the radar system to Taiwan.

Since then, administration officials have been working on the specifications of the system, called PAVE PAWS, to be exported. PAVE is the name for a US Air Force radar program and PAWS stands for phased array warning system.
The Washington Times quoted knowledgeable government officials as saying that the Pentagon recently worked out arrangements with Taiwan for the transfer.
"Taiwan had to meet a couple of conditions and they were things they planned to do anyway," one official told the daily.
The conditions include upgrading and networking existing radar stations in order to help Taiwan better monitor aircraft or missile activities on the Chinese mainland, according to the report.
The daily did not mention the cost of the transfer or other details, and the Clinton administration and Taiwan's representative office in Washington would not comment on matters related to the sale.
Taiwan hopes the advanced radar system will extend warning time, some say by a few minutes, in case of an air or missile attack from the mainland.
Some experts, however, say they believe short-range missiles deployed just across the Taiwan Strait can be used to attack Taiwan with little or no warning at all.
According to a recent Ministry of National Defense estimate, mainland China has deployed as many as 400 M-9 and M-11 short-range missiles in areas opposite Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MUST MAKE PLANS TO DEFEND INTERESTS IN ASIA: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The United States must acknowledge the possibility of conflict with Communist China and make appropriate plans to protect and preserve US national security interests and those of its friends and allies in Asia, stressed an American expert on East Asian affairs.

Peter Brookes, the principal adviser for East Asian affairs with the Republican staff of the House Committee on International Relations, said in a July 26 lecture released Friday by The Heritage Foundation that "Beijing must comprehend that the development and ultimate deployment of these ballistic missile defensive systems are in part due to China's increased offensive capability and proliferation practices."

In fact, he pointed out, Communist Chinese strategic modernization has been underway for over 15 years and predates the current missile defense debate in Asia. It is further asserted that Beijing's strategic force upgrades and expansion will proceed regardless of a US decision to deploy ballistic missile defenses.

"The PRC's international arms control and diplomatic crusade against missile defenses is most likely an effort to deflect attention from the real issues: the direction, scope, and pace of China's strategic nuclear weapons and ballistic missile program and its desire to retain and broaden this asymmetric capability," said Brookes.

Contrary to the assertions of Beijing, he noted, "a regional arms race will be based upon the deployment of Chinese offensive missiles and the PRC's perceived regional global ambitions -- not the fielding of American ballistic missile defenses. Chinese claims to the contrary are a `red herring.'"

Brookes concluded that changes in Chinese capability, doctrine, and proliferation practices require an appropriate response from the US to deter and, if necessary, defend against it. There will certainly be consequences to the deployment of US missile defenses, "but the cost of inaction to US national security in the face of the evolving Chinese missile threat and proliferation to countries of concern greatly outweighs the cost of action."

The development and deployment of US missile defense systems will provide greater freedom of action and a broader range of policy options and potential responses to the US military. American strategic forces, including missile defenses, must retain the capability of deterring wars, precluding crises from evolving into major conflicts, and of winning wars rapidly and decisively should it become necessary, said the expert.

As international security talks with Beijing resume after the hiatus that followed the accidental bombing of the PRC embassy in Belgrade last year by NATO forces, Brookes emphasized, it is time for Washington to bring the arms race precipitated by Beijing to the front and center of political-military discussions with the PRC in an effort to stem misconceptions, preclude a dangerous arms race, and ultimately avoid the deadly risk of a miscalculation and military conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO STOP PERSECUTING FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS

TEXT.P: A dozen participants at the International Conference on Peace in Ottawa, Canada signed a petition on Friday calling on the government of the People's Republic of China to stop persecuting Falun Gong practitioners.

The signatories, including research fellow Barry Myers and physician Neil Arya, mainly from the United States and Canada, said Falun Gong is a peaceful and non-violent form of personal belief and practice with tens of millions of practitioners in China and elsewhere.

However, the petition pointed out, starting on July 22, 1999, the Beijing regime has banned the movement and, according to credible reports prepared by Amnesty International and other organizations, resorted to arbitrary detention, torture, and inhumane treatment of Falun Gong practitioners.
As of Aug. 9 this year, at least 27 practitioners have died while in police custody in China, the document noted.

"We, participants of the International Conference on Peace, call on the Government of the People's Republic of China to stop mass arbitrary detentions, unfair trials, and other human rights violations resulting from the crackdown on the Falun Gong," it said.

They also called on all governments and international organizations which treasure peace and justice to use every appropriate public and private forum to urge the regime in Beijing to release detained practitioners, to allow them to pursue their beliefs, and to abide by the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

As members of the Falun Dafa Association of Canada prepare to stage a nationwide Falun Dafa Week next week, many Canadian government and civilian leaders, including Governor General Adrienne Clarkson and several members of parliament, have expressed their support for all Falun Gong practitioners.

Extending her greetings to all those celebrating Falun Dafa Week, Clarkson praised Falun Dafa followers for striving to perfect their bodies and minds and learn compassion for others and for helping to create a more open and tolerant society.

Vivienne Poy, the first ethnic Chinese woman to become a senator in Canada, also extended her support to Falun Dafa Week celebrants, stressing that "it is important that organizations, such as yours, have the freedom to practice their beliefs in Canadian society."

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY RUSSIAN SAILORS JUMP SHIP IN CANADA

TEXT.P: As many as 40 Russian sailors jumped ship in Halifax, and Canadian immigration officials were interviewing them on Friday as some of them were asking to stay in Canada.

Thirty-two Russian sailors on Thursday night walked away from the trawler "Bizon" docked in Halifax, joining eight others who jumped ship earlier. On Wednesday, about half a dozen men leapt off the ship, landing in the harbor. Three were picked up by the coast guard, while the rest were fished out by fellow crew members.
With 40 having left the ship, only 20 of the crew, including the captain, remained on board.

A Canadian inspector with the International Transport Federation said the Russian crew members who left complained that they had not been paid for six months. The crew also said that conditions on board the 33-year-old ship were awful.

Some Russians told immigration officials they fear reprisals from the Russian mafia and that they'll be jailed or beaten if they go home. A few men have told reporters that the captain has threatened them, accusing them of not working.

"I spoke to the captain and he tells me he will prosecute the 12 ringleaders to the full extent of Russian law," inspector John Parsons said, adding that "I think those 12 will be wanting to stay in Canada."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW DOSES OF BETA-BLOCKERS MAY BE BETTER FOR HEART PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Low doses of beta-blockers may be more effective in preventing further heart failure in patients who have already suffered a heart attack than high doses of the drugs, according to a Canadian study published in the prominent British medical journal The Lancet.

Doctors treating elderly heart patients should "start low and go slow" in prescribing beta-blockers, said lead author Dr. Paula Rochon, a researcher at Baycrest Centre for Geriatric Care and the Institute for Clinical Evaluative Sciences. Both facilities are part of the University of Toronto.
"One of the reasons our study is important is it would suggest that if you are on a lower dose and you can't tolerate a higher dose, then it's probably just fine to continue," Rochon said on Friday.

The research team looked at the health records of more than 13,000 people in Ontario aged 66 and over who had suffered a heart attack between 1993 and 1995. Of that group, 4,681 were prescribed beta-blockers after their heart attack.

Beta-blockers are a class of drug that slows the heart rate. They are commonly prescribed in the treatment of angina, heart arrhythmias, high blood pressure, and other heart conditions. The drugs are highly effective, but not everyone tolerates them well at standard doses.
The team found that people on low doses of beta-blockers -- defined as lower than the standard tablet -- appeared to have been better protected by the drug than those on high doses.
Low-dose patients were 52 percent less likely to suffer heart failure in the year after their heart attack than patients who weren't given beta-blockers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SAID RECOGNIZED BY MANY NATIONS FOR ITS ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is not isolated, but instead widely recognized by many countries around the world for its economic and political achievements, according to the outgoing ROC envoy to Canberra.

In an interview on the eve of his departure from Sydney, Liu Po-lun said that "Taiwan is not isolated in the international community because many countries have profound sympathy, friendship, and support for us. This can be justified through our substantive relations with many countries in the world."

He said the prospects of substantive relations between Taiwan and Australia will be brighter in the coming years because Canberra has come to realize that there is much room for trade and economic cooperation with Taiwan.
He noted that both Taiwan and Australia are complementary not only in the economic field, but also in the scientific, medical care, biological, and environmental fields.
"I believe there are lots of opportunities waiting to be explored by businessmen from the two countries," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ADVISERS BACK CROSS-STRAIT NEWS EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A group of advisers to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) have thrown weight behind a proposal to open news exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said on Saturday.
Chao Chieh-fu, director of the cultural and educational affairs department of the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the report after an MAC advisory board meeting.

According to Chao, most of the MAC advisers voiced support for a proposed opening of cross-strait news exchanges. Many of the advisers also suggested that the Republic of China government formulate a comprehensive package of regulations to pave the way for mainland Chinese media to post journalists in Taiwan, he added.
Chao quoted the MAC advisers as saying that allowing mainland newsmen to live and work in Taiwan will enable them to experience Taiwan's democratic and liberal lifestyle.

"Although some advisers worry that resident mainland journalists may get involved in intelligence gathering, most of them still adopt a positive attitude toward the proposed opening as they hope that the measure would help boost interaction between media professionals on both sides and enable mainland reporters to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's culture and lifestyle," Chao explained.

Most of the advisers recommended that in the initial stage, the government only allow mainland news organizations to send reporters to Taiwan for news coverage without opening a permanent office. After a certain period of time, the advisers said, the government can decide whether to allow mainland media organizations to open offices and post journalists in Taiwan.
During Saturday's meeting, Chao said, some advisers also cast doubts over whether mainland news media would faithfully publish articles written by their reporters stationed in Taiwan.

At present, Chao said, cross-strait news exchanges are seriously unbalanced, with mainland media carrying few Taiwan-related news reports. Worse yet, Chao said, mainland media often carry false or misleading reports about Taiwan.

Chao further said mainland reporters currently travel to Taiwan mainly for attending seminars or for fact-finding tours. "Mainland journalists have made 5,045 visits to Taiwan over the past years, but only 280 of visiting mainland newsmen had engaged in news coverage," he noted.
According to Chao, mainland journalists presently can apply for news coverage in Taiwan in accordance with the existing regulations governing visits by mainland professionals.

In fact, Chao said, the government has largely eased requirements for mainland newsmen to apply for news coverage in Taiwan. "Mainland journalists are no longer required to name a guarantor and they need only to present applications one month in advance," Chao explained.

Commenting on reports that mainland China's official mouthpiece, Xinhua News Agency, plans to send reporters to cover news in Taiwan, Chao said the MAC will screen relevant applications based on the working plans presented by mainland newsmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE WITH US HITS NEW MONTHLY RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's import and export trade with the United States hit a new monthly record high in June, according to US Department of Commerce (DOC) figures made public on Saturday.

Taiwan's import trade with the US in June amounted to US$2.36 billion, the highest monthly total ever. The figure represented a US$390 million increase over May's total and a jump of US$790 million over the previous June's figure.
Taiwan's export trade with the US in June totaled US$3.52 billion, up by US$86 million over May's figure and up US$435 million from June 1999.
Taiwan's annual export growth rate reached 14.1 percent and its annual import growth rate rocketed up to 50.5 percent in the month of June.

For the first half of the year, the total value of Taiwan's export trade with the US was US$19.19 billion, representing an annual growth rate of 15 percent, while the total value of its import trade with the US in the same period reached US$11.63 billion, showing an annual growth rate of 32.1 percent.

Taiwan is the United States' seventh largest trade partner, its seventh largest export and import trade market, and also the sixth largest source of its trade deficit. Two-way trade for the first half of the year reached US$30.81 billion, 20.9 percent more than that of the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID TO DRIVE WEDGE AMONG DPP MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Mainland China will take steps to drive a wedge among Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) members, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official predicted on Saturday.

Jan Jyh-horng, director of the MAC's research and planning department, made the forecast after a meeting of the advisory board to the Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

Jan said Beijing leadership's annual policy review meeting at the summer resort of Beidaihe is scheduled to end this week. "After the Beidaihe meeting, we think that Beijing will begin arrangements for meeting with DPP moderates in order to sow seeds of discord among DPP members," he noted.

Beijing has until recently ruled out the possibility of engagement with the pro-independence DPP. However, Jan said, Beijing has decided to change its strategy after DPP's Chen Shui-bian won the Republic of China's March 18 presidential election.

In the past few month, Jan said, Beijing has invited some moderate DPP members to attend seminars on the mainland. In the meantime, Jan said, Beijing has continued harsh criticism of DPP radicals' pro-independence stance. Jan said Beijing is expected to continue this double-edged tactic after the Beidaihe meeting.
In addition, Jan said, Beijing may adopt a similar strategy in dealing with ROC lawmakers based on their moderate or radical attitudes toward the DPP-led government's cross-strait policy.

In another news development, Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong said on Saturday that the Ministry of Finance (MOF) has drafted a package of regulations governing applications by local banks to set up liaison or representative offices on the mainland.

Shea said the ministry will invite the Central Bank of China and the MAC to discuss key points of the regulations in the coming week. If the two agencies do not oppose the draft bill, Shea said, the Finance Ministry will refer it to the Cabinet which will then pass the bill to the MAC for further deliberation.

Shea said the government basically supports the opening measure. "We have taken into account issues related to capital outflow and financial inspection in formulating regulations governing the establishment of bank representative offices on the mainland," the minister explained.
The ROC government unveiled a set of regulations governing business exchanges between insurance companies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait early this year.
In line with the regulations, the MOF has approved applications by several Taiwan life and property insurance companies to open liaison offices on the mainland.
However, none of them have so far received a green light from mainland authorities to open a representative office on the other side of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DECORATED BY COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica (CNA) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian was awarded an honorary medal by Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriquez on Friday.

Stressing that he felt highly honored to be able to receive the highest national medal at the Costa Rican Presidential Office, Chen said that the decoration not only represents the highest degree of honor to him, but also underscores the cordial relations between the two countries.
Chen also said that the medal is a treasurable recognition of the economic and political achievements obtained by the ROC government and its 23 million people.
Pointing out that the ROC and Costa Rica use the same colors in their national flags, Chen claimed that it is an indication that the two countries share the same aspiration for freedom and democracy.
Traveling at the head of a delegation composed of more than 200 government officials and business leaders, Chen flew into Costa Rica, the third leg of a two-week overseas tour, earlier the same day.

He has already visited the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua, and will proceed to Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad. All these six countries on his itinerary are among the ROC's 29 diplomatic allies, which recognize Taipei instead of Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCHING PARLIAMENT BUILDING A CONSTITUTIONAL ISSUE: JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Saturday said that the issue of whether searching the legislative building requires the speaker's prior approval cannot be settled by a legislative consensus alone but requires constitutional debate.

Following the search of opposition Kuomintang lawmaker Liao Hwu-peng's research room by prosecutors on Wednesday, ruling and opposition legislative caucuses on Thursday concluded that the legislative building should remain an autonomous area deserving respect.
The controversial incident marked the first time that the nation's judicial personnel entered the legislative building to conduct a search.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng also added that any such search should be subject to his approval.

Chen, who garnered a public approval rating of 71 percent in a recent poll for his tough stance in cracking down on corruption, pointed out that the lawmakers' conclusions cannot stand in for existing laws and regulations, but can only be used as a consensus reference for future amendments.

Chen said that the legislators already possess special privileges under Articles 73 and 74 of the Republic of China Constitution and that if they want to add another privilege to protect themselves from searches, then it is not simply a matter of amending the criminal laws but is in fact a constitutional issue.

Article 73 of the ROC Constitution currently exempts legislators from being liable for any opinions expressed or votes cast in the Legislative Yuan, while Article 74 protects lawmakers from being arrested or detained without the permission of the Legislative Yuan, except in the case of "flagrante delicto," a legal term meaning being caught red-handed.

Shen Fu-hsiung, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator, said on Saturday that the Legislative Yuan should reform itself first before talking about parliamentary dignity and that if his colleagues truly want to improve their collective image, then he would suggest abandoning the umbrella protection given to them by Article 74 until the next term of lawmakers are elected.

However, DPP legislator Lee Ching-hsiung, a former judge, said that although he believes Liao would probably be the first to take up Shen's suggestion, renouncing the privilege does not mean the constitutional law will no longer be in effect.
Lee also gave his "utmost condemnation" to the legislators who joined in the Thursday conclusion that searching the legislative building requires the speaker's approval.

Lee was supporting DPP legislator Tsai Ming-hsien's statement at a Saturday press conference that the Wednesday search did not go against the Constitution or existing laws because Articles 73 and 74 are not in effect when the legislature is not in session, as is the case now, and neither protects lawmakers from being searched.

The controversy first came about when Tainan prosecutors searched Liao's research room in the Legislative Yuan and later his apartment in the Ta-an complex, a "dormitory" building occupied exclusively by legislators.

The prosecutors initially reported that the search turned up 10,000 fake stock certificates in Chi Mei Electronics, an unlisted Tainan-based company, but later retracted their statement, saying that no Chi Mei stocks were discovered.

Lin Chieh-teh of the Public Prosecutor's Office of Taiwan's High Court told the media on Wednesday that the search was conducted because Chi Mei Corp. had told the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office that "some people" were suspected of having fabricated Chi Mei share certificates.

Upon learning of the search, Liao rushed back to Taipei from his constituency in Yunlin County on Wednesday night. He told the media that the shares taken away by the prosecutors from his apartment were those of Chungtai Canned Manufacturing Co., of which he is board chairman. He stressed that he owns no Chi Mei shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP AGAIN PUSHES FOR ASIAN ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday renewed her appeal for Asian leaders to jointly push for the formation of an Asian alliance patterned after the 15-member European Union (EU).
Lu made repeatedly her call during a meeting with James Gerard Collins, deputy speaker of the European Parliament, the EU's legislative arm.
Lu said she looks forward to seeing Asian leaders deal with the continent's common future development with vision and broad-mindedness.
"All Asian leaders should learn from their European counterparts in promoting Europe's gradual integration after World War II through setting up the EU," Lu said.
For his part, Collins said European countries have encountered many difficulties and obstacles on their way toward integration.

"Thanks to generous support from major EU members in the process, the EU has so far managed to develop a viable mechanism for cooperation among all its members for the common well-being," Collins said, adding that it takes time to accomplish such a task.

Noting that mutual respect and forward-looking strategy are pivotal to the EU's success, Collins said formation of an EU-style Asian alliance may need a much longer period of time because of wider differences among Asian countries than European states.
Touching on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Collins said all EU members hope to see Taiwan and mainland China co-exist peacefully for mutual benefits.

In response, Lu said the ROC has no intention to provoke mainland China. "We are more than willing to promote constructive interaction with the mainland, and on the international front, we only want a more reasonable treatment to safeguard our national dignity," she added.
Collins, also an Irish senator, further said he hopes the ROC government can encourage Taiwan companies to invest in Ireland and use his country as a springboard to tap the vast EU market.
Earlier in the day, Lu hosted a tea party at the Presidential Office in honor of women representatives from the central Taiwan county of Changhua.
Lu, a political dissident-turned-politician and human rights activist, said she hopes to see an end to gender discrimination and human rights oppression before the end of the 20th century.
In the face of the dawn of the 21st century, Lu said all fellow countrymen should work together to make Taiwan a society characterized by peace, justice and fairness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM ONLY `ASSESSING' WAFER PLANT INVESTMENT IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Winston Wang, chairman of Hung Jen Group, on Saturday denied media reports that he is investing in eight-inch wafer plants in mainland China, adding that Hung Jen Group is only "assessing" the viability of such a venture.

Wang -- the son of local tycoon Wang Yung-ching, chairman of Formosa Plastics Group -- added that the companies under his flag will not go against the government's "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy, which forbids high-tech investments in mainland China.

Local media reports on Saturday said that Wang and Jiang Mianheng -- the son of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin -- are planning to form a NT$20 billion (US$ 643.5 million) joint venture to build eight-inch wafer plants in Shanghai.
Accompanied by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, Wang held a press conference to clarify his company's position.

Wang said that Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi had clearly announced recently that it is still not appropriate to allow infrastructure and high-tech industries such as eight-inch and 12-inch wafer producers to invest in mainland China for national security reasons.
He added that Hung Jen Group has been assessing the issue for over a year and that it is still assessing the investment possibilities.

Wang went on to say that if the government relaxes its regulations in the future, he will then fund the project with joint investment from American and Japanese firms, and the capital will come from overseas, not from Taiwan.
According to local news reports in May, technology for Wang and Jiang's joint venture to build three eight-inch and three 12-inch wafer plants will be provided by Japan's Oki Electric Industry Co.
Wang also has extensive investments in petrochemical production in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TANG INSPECTS PENGHU'S BASIC INFRASTRUCTURE

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei on Saturday inspected outlying Penghu island's basic infrastructure and said that the county's future development should be based on tourism.
Tang added that he will instruct related government agencies to provide assistance to Penghu's various proposed programs following deliberations on feasible plans.

In his first inspection tour of the islands since taking up his premiership on May 20, Tang noted that the government's finances may face a crunch as the Cabinet begins to implement its plans to boost Taiwan's traditional and high-tech industries, but added that he will not abandon Penghu.
Tang went on to say that he believes county work should focus on "self-help" in order to make the most out of limited financial resources.

He said that the new government has been at the helm for only three months, so many things are still not yet on track, but added that he took it as a priority to inspect Penghu and found that the county government's briefing contained comprehensive long-range plans and showed results worthy of praise and encouragement.

Minister of Transportation and Communication Yeh Chu-lan, who was among the ministers who accompanied Tang on his visit, said that the new government sees boosting the tourism industry as one of its most important policy objectives.

She added that her ministry has already provided subsidies for the construction of a road leading to a Penghu vacation resort and that so long as budgets are not a problem, she is happy to see the construction of a yacht dock on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA VOWS TO BACK ROC'S UN, WTO, WHO BIDS
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Y. Y. Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez on Friday threw support behind the Republic of China's bids to join the United Nations and its affiliates as well as the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Rodriguez offered the commitment during talks with visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian, who arrived in Costa Rica earlier in the day after a hectic visit to neighboring Nicaragua.

The Costa Rican leader was quoted by ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao as having told Chen that he thinks the acceptance of Taiwan into the WTO is a necessity because of the island's role in the new economy and international commerce.

Costa Rica has not actively spoken for the ROC's UN bid at relevant UN meetings in recent years, nor has it joined with other ROC allies in signing a proposal asking the UN to consider the ROC's representation in the world body.

Tien said President Chen took advantage of his meeting with Rodriguez to call for more active Costa Rican support for the ROC's bid to join major international organizations, including the UN, the WTO and the UN-affiliated World Health Organization (WHO).
Tien, who was also present at the two top leaders' meeting, said Rodriguez assured President Chen of his country's full support for the ROC in political and diplomatic domains.

Rodriguez was quoted as having assured Chen that Costa Rica will not waver its diplomatic ties with the ROC even though it may not be able to fully satisfy the ROC's desire in trade and economic affairs. Costa Rica has increased commercial exchanges with mainland China in recent years.

According to Tien, Rodriguez has also told Chen that as the two countries share same ideals of upholding democratic values and human rights, ROC-Costa Rican relations will become even stronger and closer in the future.

Rodriguez also briefed Chen on current bilateral cooperative projects and progress in those programs. For his part, Chen assured Rodriguez that his administration will faithfully fulfill its obligations under all existing cooperative agreements.
Tien said he believes that Costa Rica will take more active steps in support of the ROC's UN bid this year following the summit meeting between the top leaders of the two countries.
Shortly after his arrival in San Jose, Rodriguez presided over a grand welcoming ceremony for Chen at the Costa Rican Presidential Office.

All senior Costa Rican officials, some 70 young students, 100-plus overseas Chinese representatives and 70 Chinese and foreign journalists were present at the ceremony to greet the visiting ROC head of state.
Speaking on the occasion, Rodriguez said Chen's visit has ushered in a new era in ROC-Costa Rican relations and will boost their quest for democracy, freedom, peace, prosperity and human rights.

Rodriguez lauded Chen as one of Asia's "Third Wave" democratic leaders. He then decorated Chen with the Order of Juan Morales Fernandez in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties. The Grand Cross-class golden medal is the highest honor offered by the Costa Rican government to a foreign leader.

For his part, Chen expressed his gratitude for the hospitality extended to him by the Costa Rican government and people. He also thanked Costa Rica for its support for the ROC's cause in the international community over past years.
Later in the day, the two presidents signed a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to forging a mechanism for strategic cooperation in the future.
The two leaders pledged to further reinforce bilateral cooperation in trade, investment and economic development following the ROC's entry to the WTO in the near future.

In the communique, Rodriguez also recognized Chen's efforts to push for resumption of dialogue with mainland China since he took office on May 20. Rodriquez also expressed gratitude for the ROC assistance and aid over past years.

Costa Rica is the third leg of Chen's current six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at cementing the ROC's diplomatic ties with its allies. During his stay, he will also attend a meeting of ROC mission chiefs in Latin America to be held on Saturday. The meeting will be chaired by Foreign Minister Tien.

Chen already visited the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua. He will also visit the ROC's three West African allies -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad -- before concluding his first post-inauguration overseas trip on Aug. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO DIPLOMATIC TRUCE': ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Saturday that joining the United Nations and more international organizations is Taiwan's rights and obligation and that there should be no so-called "diplomatic truce."
Chen made the remarks at a press conference that he jointly presided over with Costa Rica President Miguel Angel Rodriguez at the end of Chen's brief visit to the Central American country.
"Unless the ROC disappears from the earth, we should continue our drive to reach out so as to increase our international presence," Chen said.
"We should not be afraid of blockade by mainland China as far as our foreign relations are concerned, and that the most serious problem for us would be the disunity among our people," Chen said.

"It's a shame to those who oppose our 'reach out' drive if they come to understand Costa Rica's firm support of our bids for membership in the United States and other international organizations," the President said.
President Rodriguez during the press conference, called for the "immediate" admission of the ROC into the UN and other international organizations.

He reiterated that there will be no change in Costa Rica's policy toward the ROC and that his country is willing to join with Taiwan's other allies in issuing a joint statement in support of Taiwan's UN bid."

Costa Rica has not actively spoken for the ROC's UN bid at relevant UN meetings in recent years, nor has it joined with other ROC allies in signing proposals asking the UN to consider the ROC's representation in the world body.
The Costa Rica head of state spoke highly of his ROC counterpart, saying Chen is "a new-generation leader of Asia."

He said that he believes Chen's two-day visit will help promote diplomatic, trade and tourist exchanges between the two countries and he called for more investments in Costa Rica from Taiwan's business sector.
Chen during the press conference praised Costa Rica's achievements in various fields, describing it as "the Switzerland of America and "reach beach."
The ROC President especially cited the establishment of a human rights library and the Pan-American Court in Costa Rica as proof of Costa Rica's full respect for human rights.

He also said that Costa Rica has special respect for women's rights, as has been evidenced by the facts that the two vice presidents of the Central American country, its parliament speaker and one fourth of its parliament members are women. Chen also took the opportunity to stress the importance of national stability.

He said that the exports of Costa Rica and Nicaragua reached about US$800 million, respectively, 20 years ago. But while Costa Rica has increased its export volume to an annual US$7 billion, Nicaragua is running on the other way with a negative export growth, due to its 10-year long civil war. Chen said his government will honor all the promises made by the former Kuomintang administration of financial and technical assistance to foreign countries as a nation's policy must be constant and stable, and cannot be overturned because of power transition.

He said that it's time now for Taiwan, which in the past had received assitance from other countries, to shoulder its responsibility by offering assistance to the less developed countries in the world.

Chen added that the ROC's annual foreign aids totaled US$300 million in value, accounting for just about 0.13 percent of its gross national product (GNP), which is far less than the developed countries' 0.24 percent, or the criteria of 0.7 percent GNP as required by the UN.
Chen, accompanied by Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao arrived in Costa Rica at the head of his 200-member delegation for a two-day state visit.

He met Rodriguez for a wide range of talks shortly after his arrival during which the Costa Rican President threw his support behind the ROC bids to join the UN and its affiliates such as the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Later in the day, the two presidents signed a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to forging a mechanism for strategic cooperation in the future.
The two leaders pledged to further reinforce bilateral cooperation in trade, investment and economic development following the ROC's entry into the WTO in the near future.

In the communique, Rodriguez also recognized Chen's efforts to push for resumption of dialogue with mainland China since he took office on May 20. Rodriquez also expressed gratitude for the ROC assistance and aid over past years.

Before his departure for Gambia, President Chen accompanied by Rodriguez visited a export procession zone and a occupational schools which Taiwan has helped establish and a orchid garden run by Taiwan's Taiwan Sugar Corp.
He later attended a meeting of ROC mission chiefs in Latin America during which he urged the ROC envoys to redouble efforts to help increase Taiwan's international presence.

Chen and his entourage have completed their visits to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, the first three stops of their 13-day six-nation trip which will also take them to Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
They left Costa Rica early Sunday morning and are scheduled to arrive in Gambia later in the day for a two-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:

The China Times:

The United Daily News:
