The Liberty Times:
Premier Tang Fei outlines tourism development in the offshore island of Penghu.
The China Post:
Lawmakers debate scrapping immunity from criminal probes.
The Taiwan News:
Officials try to defuse corruption story.
The Taipei Times:
Chen wants more support from allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 19, or the 20th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
14 A.D.: Augustus, originally Octavian, the first Roman emperor and the grand-nephew of Julius Caesar, dies at the age of 77. He defeated Mark Anthony and Cleopatra in 31 A.D. and subsequently gained control over the empire.
1560: James Crichton, the Scottish scholar who propounded many scientific theories, is born.
1587: Pope Sixtus V proclaims Catholic Crusade for invasion of England.
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under US tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1905: A revolution forces Czar Nicholas II to establish a Russian parliament.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980, and from 1982 until he was elected president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years' detention.
1966: Earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1977: Julius Marx, the American comedian better known as "Groucho," dies of pneumonia in Hollywood at the age of 87.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a US withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- glasnost and perestroika -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the old Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The ROC Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the UN Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stressed that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but when you once try to figure out a thing you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GETS HIGHEST APPROVAL RATING: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's approval rating is the third highest of high-level officials in the new administration, next to the approval ratings of Premier Tang Fei and Justice Minister Chen Ting-nan, according to the results of a poll conducted by the opposition Kuomintang announced on Sunday.

The KMT's Policy Coordination Committee conducted the poll on the performance of the new government in the first quarter by calling 1,096 Taiwan citizens over 20 years of age between Aug. 15 and 16. The survey had a margin of error of 3 percent.
The president's approval rating was 55.11 percent, down from about 80 percent in his first month and 60 percent in the second month of Chen's administration, the poll showed.

Among high-level officials of the administration, Premier Tang Fei received the highest approval rating, at 63.87 percent. He was followed by Justice Minister Chen Ting-nan at 60.40 percent, and the president at 55.11 percent.

The KMT attributed the public's higher approval of Tang than that of Chen to its sympathy for the plight of the premier, who is a KMT member but serves in the ruling government of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Women serving in the Cabinet also received positive ratings, with three female Cabinet-level officials receiving the fourth, fifth and sixth highest approval ratings. Mainland Affairs Council Chair Tsai Ing-wen, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan and Chair of Council of Labor Affairs Chen Chu took those spots.

Among the three lowest-ranked members of the new Cabinet was Chen Hsi-huang, chair of the Council of Agriculture (COA), who received an approval rating of just 18.34 percent. He was followed by Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong at 21.62 percent, and Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi at 21.99 percent.
Turning to the new administration's policies, the public is most satisfied with the new government's policy on cross-strait relations, which received an approval rating of 49.91 percent.
But the public is most dissatisfied with policies regarding social order and ecological and environmental protection, with disapproval ratings of 52.28 percent and 51.1 percent, respectively.
Chen was inaugurated in May, ending five decades of the KMT's grip on political power in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM MOVING TOWARDS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A new tropical storm was formed in the Pacific Ocean on Saturday afternoon, and was moving swiftly on a path towards the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced on Sunday.

The 10th tropical storm in the Pacific this season, the system is located about 1,500 kilometers southeast of Taiwan and is moving steadily to the northwest at 24 kilometers per hour, and could strengthen to the level of a typhoon with maximum sustained winds of more than 30 meters per second , said the CWB.
Based on its current path and velocity, the storm is likely to hit Taiwan in two days, and an ocean storm warning is likely to be issued Monday afternoon, said the forecasters.
The CWB forecast hot and sunny weather for both Sunday and Monday, with rains from the storm reaching the island on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATIONS REACH RECORD HIGH: SURVEY

TEXT.P: In a sign that Taiwan people are always willing to help others, statistics recently released by the government show that the public donated a total of NT$43 billion (US$1.38 billion) between May 1998 and April 1999.
The Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), in releasing the statistics, also said that half of the donations went to religious groups.
DGBAS officials said that 5.93 million people donated money between May 1998 and April 1999, giving an average of NT$8,000 per donator.
The survey also found that those who have higher academic backgrounds tend to donate more money, because they also earn higher salaries.
The survey showed that those who have received college educations or higher donated NT$11,736 (US$379) a year, or twice that of people who received less than a college education.

The survey also found that except for a few cases where donation went to individual people or households, most of the donations went to non-profit organizations, with religious groups getting the lion's share at 49.2 percent.
Social service and charity groups were next, at 37.3 percent. Academic, cultural, medical and political groups only received a combined 13.6 percent of the donations.

DGBAS officials said that after the disastrous earthquake that wreaked havoc in central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, the number of people who donated money nearly doubled, with donations reaching a record high of NT$69.3 billion (US$2.23 billion).
The officials said that the large sum of donations shows that local people have kept the traditional virtues of generosity and helping others.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP SUGGESTS REVISION OF CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested on Sunday that the government revise the Constitution to adapt it to Taiwan's current political reality.

In a speech to the Bar Association of the Republic of China, Lu called the Constitution an out-of-date document concocted more than five decades ago with an eye on applying it to all of mainland China instead of just Taiwan. She went on to blame it for the current political chaos in Taiwan.

The anachronism of governing a modern state with an obsolete constitution has become obvious after President Chen Shui-bian was swept to power on the ticket of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), leaving the legislature still controlled by the opposition Kuomintang, said the dissident-turned vice president.

Because Chen's DPP controls no more than one third of the seats in the legislature, Lu said, the president was forced to tap Kuomintang member Tang Fei as his premier to lead a Cabinet made up largely of Chen's followers.

But Chen's attempt to organize an non-partisan administration has only complicated the problem by obliterating the party's political liability for policy, rather than winning support from parties across the political spectrum.
In order to sort out the current difficulties, Lu strongly suggested an overhaul of the Constitution to review the division of powers among five branches, the cornerstone of the current Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI CROWNS WORLD PONY BASEBALL SERIES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei captured the Pony League World Series title on Saturday by defeating a team from West Covina, California 8-3. It was Chinese Taipei's fourth championship in seven years.

Chinese Taipei's Kuo Sheng-an smashed a solo home run during the first inning to take a 1-0 lead, and later returned to drill another four-bagger, driving in two other players for a total of three points in the fourth inning and leaving Chinese Taipei up 4-2 on the Americans.
Lee Cheng-han consolidated that lead by hitting a two-run homer in the fifth. West Covina managed to score one more point in the bottom of the same inning, but it wasn't enough.
Chinese Taipei added two more points in the seventh, and then held off the American team in the late innings to win 8-3.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. CHEN EXHORTS NEW GOV'T TO HAND OVER PEOPLE GOOD RESULTS SOON

TEXT.P: In response to a 25,000-word critique of Taiwan's government by the Cheng Society, President Chen Shui-bian has instructed all government officials to redouble their efforts so as to give good results to the people as soon as possible, according to a spokesman of the Presidential Office.

The spokesman said that President Chen attaches a great deal of importance to the critique made by the Cheng Society, which is made up academics. The official added that Chen has instructed him to fax him the full text of the critique, as he is currently on an overseas trip to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
President Chen said that members of the new government should use their adapting period as newcomers to hone their skills.

Chen urged all his government officials to listen more to the voice of the land and people, despite the fact that they may have different opinions. The mission of reform cannot be accomplished only by the government, but must be undertaken by both the people and the government, the official quoted Chen as saying.
Meanwhile, Premier Tang Fei said that the Cabinet will step up communications with the people and consult with academics before formulating any policy.
Tang described the Cheng Society's critique as "very significant."
The Cheng Society criticized the current Cabinet's inability to solve Taiwan's problem, suggesting that it be replaced by a clear Democratic Progressive Party administration.
The academic group also called on the president to work harder at harmonizing relations between the Legislative Yuan and the Executive Yuan.
The Cheng Society sent copies of its critique to President Chen, Premier Tang Fei, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan and other ministers.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CHOSEN AS ASIAN REGION'S BEST CITY IN 2000
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Shu Chen-hui and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has been selected as the Asian region's best city in 2000 by US magazine Travel and Leisure, while The Peninsula in Hong Kong is ranked by the magazine as the hotel that provides the best service in the world.
The latest issue of the magazine contains the results of a survey conducted early this year of several thousand of its subscribers on their opinions of the world's hotels.

Hong Kong was chosen as the Asian region's best city by the respondents, who were asked to make a combined evaluation based on hotel rooms, service, equipment, local culture, scenic spots, food and impressions toward local people.
San Francisco was picked by the magazine's readers as the world's best city.
Hong Kong's ranking in 2000 was higher than its second-best ranking last year. Bangkok was selected as the Asian region's best city in 1999.

Hou Shu-chi, chairman of the Hong Kong Travel Association, said Hong Kong's selection as the Asian region's best city will help to promote Hong Kong's tourist industry. However, he suggested that the government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region develop more new tourist attractions in order to keep Hong Kong's tourism industry on track.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMANITARIAN DIPLOMACY IS PRIORITY OF NEW GOV'T FOREIGN POLICY

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee said here on Sunday that "humanitarian diplomacy" will be the utmost priority of the new administration's foreign policy.

Lee made the remark while speaking about the new government's foreign policy at a seminar sponsored by the Po-chung Cultural and Educational Foundation held at Dr. Sun Yet-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei on Sunday.

Lee said that President Chen Shui-bian's statement that Beijing's pressure was not an excuse for failing to engage in foreign affairs was not meant to criticize Taiwan's diplomats, but rather to encourage them. Chen made the statement while on an official visit in the Dominican Republic.
Under the current cross strait situation, diplomats should not be pessimistic, Lee said.

He said that the new government will emphasize humanitarian diplomacy because of foreign assistance in the wake of the killer earthquake that jolted central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, claiming more than 2,400 lives and causing massive property damage. Lee noted that a Japanese rescue team reached Taiwan within 24 hours after the temblor, and teams from the United States, Mexico and others countries arrived later.

The priority in foreign affairs will be to emphasize human rights and democracy, he said, adding that Taiwan has developed into a truly democratic country after the transition of power on May 20, Lee said.

Another priority will be to use economic power to support diplomacy, he said, adding that the government will continue to play a safeguarding role to help local people expand their investments abroad.

The new government will also implement a policy of providing humanitarian assistance to non-government organizations, Lee said, citing the warm welcome that the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation received when a medical assistance team it organized arrived in Macedonia, which recently established ties with the ROC.

Asked about the of future cross-strait relations, Lee said that at this moment, nobody can answer the question. As things stand now, it is impossible to come up with a diplomatic truce between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said. He also added that Taiwan should step up its non-official relations with the United States, Japan and the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY HALL TO OPEN WEBSITE ON TRAFFIC, TRAVELING

TEXT.P: Taipei City Hall will open a website late this year to provide citizens with information on traffic and traveling, City Hall sources said on Sunday.

The sources said that from December this year Taipei citizens will be able to obtain real-time information on traffic, travel maps, and even parking lots, adding that the increasing use of WAP (wireless application protocol) cellular phones will make the site useful for people on the go.
The sources said that their goal for the site is for an average of 3,000 people to use it every day, after the site comes online in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VISITING GAMBIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrived in Gambia on Sunday at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.

Upon their arrival at the airport, Chen and his 200-member delegation were welcomed by Gambian President Yahya Jammeh in a militray ceremony. This is Chen's first African trip which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad since his inauguration on May 20 .
Shortly after his arrival, Chen inspected the ROC embassy in Gambia and was briefed by Ambassador Lee Chen-hsiung on the existing ROC-Gambia relations.
Chen will hold a summit meeting with President Jammeh during which the heads of state of the two nations agreed that bilateral ties should be further cemented.

Meanwhile, Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and several Taiwan business leaders who are accompanying Chen on the visit, will meet their Gambian counterparts in a symposium during which they discussed ways to promote trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and Gambia.
Legislators Chu Feng-chih and Chen Chin-ting, who are also members of Chen's delegation, will visit Gambian parliament members.
The West African trip was the second half OF Chen's two-continent visit. Chen has visited the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica before coming to Gambia.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP OF TAIWAN ELECTRONICS MANUFACTURERS LEAVES FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan electronics manufacturers left for mainland China for a nine-day fact-finding tour on Sunday.

The 80-odd members of the delegation of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) will tour Beijing, Shanghai and Ningbo in Zhejian Province, Central China, to research the investment environment in the mainland, said Richard Wu, TEEMA president and leader of the delegation.

They will also call on Chen Yunlin, director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under the State Council, as well as other Beijing officials to explore the possibility of setting up a special tribunal to settle trade disputes involving Taiwan businessmen.

Owing to differences in legal systems and regulations between Taiwan and mainland China, Taiwan businessmen are often treated unfairly by ordinary courts in disputes with their mainland Chinese partners, said Wu, who added that this issue needed to be addressed by a special tribunal.
In addition to TEEMA members, the delegation comprises officials from the Mainland Affairs Council, Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Ministry of Economic Affairs.
TEEMA also released on Sunday a survey of the four biggest complaints of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.
The biggest problem facing most Taiwan businessmen is marketing and production, including overlaps in investment, cutthroat competition and overcapacity, according to the survey.
The second most common problem is the difficulty in obtaining credit in mainland China and the widespread overdue payments by their mainland Chinese trade partners, TEEMA said.
Based on the survey, TEEMA warned Taiwan businessmen interested in doing business with mainland Chinese firms to prepare themselves for overdue payments.

The third problem is the ambiguity in regulations, which leaves regulators too leery of applying laws, said the survey takers, adding that would-be Taiwan investors should be careful to establish themselves in areas where the implementation of rules is more thorough.
Social security and order are the last but not the least of Taiwan businessmen's concerns. Potential investors should shy away from areas with high unemployment and crime rates, TEEMA advised.

The survey also found that the Yangtze River Delta is the most favored area by Taiwan investors because of its relatively good infrastructure and lack of risk, with Soochow and other six cities across the delta especially favored.
Meanwhile, Beijing, Shanghai, and Tianjing, the mainland's three most densely-populated special municipalities, were rated as the second best areas for investment.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT HOPES TO VISIT JAPAN IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui hopes to visit Japan this October, but whether the trip will take place will depend on the attitude of the Japanese government, said Liu Tai-ying, president of the private think tank Taiwan Research Institute, on Monday.

Liu said that Lee hopes to visit Japan by the end of October to attend the last meeting of Asian Outlook, which he co-founded in 1989, adding that whether the Japanese government will grant a visa for the visit is still unclear.

Mainland China opposes a visit to Japan by the former ROC president in any form or name despite the fact that Lee has already stepped down as Taiwan's head of state and that many groups in Japan have actively promoted such a visit.
Liu made the remarks on the sidelines of an international symposium on East Asia held Monday.

Liu said that the former president wants to gain first-hand information about Japan by visiting the country, adding that Lee hopes to attend the Asian Outlook meeting and to pay a visit to his alma mater Kyoto Imperial University. Liu also noted that many Japanese universities have invited Lee to visit and deliver a speech.
Lee also has plans to visit the Czech Republic before the end of year, said Liu, adding that the former head of state is interested in visiting Europe, America, and Japan.
Asian Outlook held its first meeting in 1989, and meetings have since been held in Taiwan and Japan on alternate years. This year's meeting will be the 12th and last meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS CONTINUE TO RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices continued their upward swing for the fifth consecutive day on Monday as electronics and technology stocks continued to experiencing brisk buying.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's benchmark barometer, gained 48.81 points to close at 8,257.88 on a turnover of NT$111.39 billion (US$3.59 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANKS TO BE ALLOWED TO SET UP OFFICES ON M'LAND IN STAGES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government at a meeting on Monday decided to allow local banks to set up offices in mainland China in stages.

Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong convened the meeting with Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan and Mainland Affairs Council Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen to discuss related matters concerning local banks setting up offices on the mainland.
The meeting came on the heels of an earlier meeting of the Executive Yuan during which the policy of liberalizing rules to allow local banks to set up offices in mainland China was established.

During the Monday meeting between Shea and related government agency heads, participants decided that the Ministry of Finance will set up a task force and meet with related government agencies to make an overall review on risk management, financial monitoring and regulations, and related legal issues.

Earlier this year, the Executive Yuan liberalized regulations pertaining to insurance companies, allowing local companies to set up offices on the mainland. Several insurance companies have since attained approval from the Ministry of Finance to set up offices on the mainalnd, but none have yet received approval from mainland authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIA VOWS STRONG SUPPORT FOR ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Gambia, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh stressed on Sunday that Gambia's support for the Republic of China will not waver despite Beijing's intimidation and that his nation will continue to speak in support of the ROC at the United Nations General Assembly.
Jammeh said the ROC was the first republic to be established in Asia, but unfortunately it has been excluded from the UN since 1971 simply because of pressure from mainland China.

In his summit meeting with Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, who arrived in the Gambian capital Sunday afternoon on the first leg of his three-nation African tour, Jammeh said that if East Timor can hold a plebiscite on the issue of independence from Indonesia, so can Taiwan.

Chen, the first ROC president and the first Asian head of state to visit the West African nation, said President Jammeh is the youngest head of state in Africa and the first president of any nation in the world to speak at the UN General Assembly in support of Taiwan. He said he hopes that Gambia will continue to voice its full support for Taiwan at the UN.

Although Chen did not respond directly to Jammeh's statement regarding Taiwan's right to hold a referendum to decide its fate, he stressed that Gambia, despite its small size, always has a loud voice in the international community as it stands firmly on the side of freedom, democracy, human rights, and justice.

Chen said that in order to help achieve the goals of President Jammeh's ambitious 2020 Prospects Project to economically escalate Gambia into the ranks of the middle power nations, the Republic of China is willing to continue to provide its African ally with infrastructure development assistance, including the areas of electricity, public health, highways, and agricultural technology.

For his part, Jammeh told Chen that he has for long aimed at building his nation into a window on Taiwan in West Africa, adding that toward that goal, he has actively pushed for effective development in the areas of education, public health, and manufacturing.

The Chen-Jammeh summit meeting was followed by a state banquet that was hosted by Jammeh himself. During the banquet, Chen said he has been overwhelmingly moved by the warm welcome he has received since stepping down onto Gambian soil. More than 10,000 Gambian citizens turned out to welcome Chen and his 200-member entourage, with the welcoming line extending for miles from the airport.
Jammeh told Chen that he plans to visit Taiwan in November of this year, representing his third official trip to the island.

Chen is expected on Monday to visit the model vegetable farms near Banjul that were the brainchild of the ROC agricultural mission stationed in Gambia. The farms have not only gained a reputation as the model of agricultural development in Gambia, they have also greatly helped improve the Gambian people's livelihood.

Chen is scheduled to sign a joint communique with Jammeh on Monday to further cement bilateral ties before proceeding to Burkina Faso and Chad, the two other stops on the president's landmark tour of Africa.
Before arriving in The Gambia, Chen and his delegation had visited Taiwan's Latin American allies of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CLOUD GATE SHINES AT OLYMPIC ARTS FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The reputation of Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theater Company seems to have been confirmed by the fact that it was invited to perform at the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney.

In an interview with the CNA, Jon-Claire Lee, representative of the Cloud Gate in Australia, said that organizers considered the possible political repercussions of choosing a dance troupe from Taiwan before making their final decision.

The organizers sent a letter to the Chinese embassy in Canberra, telling them that the Cloud Gate would be invited to perform and, to their delight, the answer from mainland China was positive, Lee said.

"I was thrilled with the successful result, though it took me about two and a half years to arrange and negotiate for the Cloud Gate Theater to be part of the Olympic Arts Festival, which I regard as a very significant occasion due to its magnitude and the massive publicity given to participants," Lee said.
Craig Hassell, general manager of the arts festival, told the CNA that the organizers informed the Chinese embassy as a gesture of "courtesy."

In a speech at the opening night of the Cloud Gate performance on Saturday, Hassell praised the superb performance put on by the Cloud Gate on opening night on Saturday, saying the company is one of the best contemporary dance troupes in the world.
He and other organizers said they were very satisfied with their choice of having the Cloud Gate Theater take part in the Olympic Arts Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM BECOMES STRONG TYPHOON AFTER GAINING STRENGTH

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Bilis, the 10th such storm to hit Taiwan this year, has gained strength and was upgraded to the level of a strong typhoon at 2:00 p.m. on Monday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced.

The CWB also issued a land storm warning for all of Taiwan, singling out the eastern region of the island as especially vulnerable. The agency called for Taiwan residents to take precautions against possible destruction that the typhoon may incur on the island.

Bilis, which was only a mid-level typhoon on Monday morning, was located about 740 kilometers southeast of Taiwan and was moving steadily in a north north-westerly direction at a speed of 22 kilometers per hour at around 3:00 p.m.
Packing winds of 51 meters per second at its center, and with a radius of 300 kilometers, Bilis is showing no signs of subsiding.

While the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien and the southern county of Pingtung are expected to bear the brunt of the typhoon's strong winds, the entire island can expect torrential rains in the coming two days, the weather agency said.
Residents in mountainous areas should be extra careful of possible landslides, they warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 21, or the 22nd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal-gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1765: William IV, the English monarch known as "the sailor king," for his service in the British Navy, is born. He joined the Royal Navy at 13 and was a close friend of British admiral Nelson. The king was renowned for his affairs and had 10 illegitimate children by actress Dorothea Jordan.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States, meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1976: Mary Langdon, 25, joins the East Sussex fire brigade to become Britain's first female firefighter.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: ROC Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: Massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1988: Earthquake rocks India's border with Nepal, killing at least 300 people and injuring over 1,500 others.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes at Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir, and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of an attempt by hardliners to depose him.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX EDGES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 48.81 points higher on Monday after a day of active trading.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, edged up to close at 8257.88 on turnover of NT$111.39 billion.
The bourse opened at 8,232.91 and fluctuated between 8,305.67 and 8216.42 during the day's trading, with electronics stocks particularly strong.

Six of the eight major sectors registered gains, with electronics stocks moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by cement issues at 0.7 percent, bank and insurance equities at 0.4 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent, textiles issues at 0.3 percent, and pulp and paper stocks at 0.1 percent.
Only two of the eight major sectors lost ground, with construction stocks declining the most at 1.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 251 to 245, with 93 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL UNIFICATION GUIDELINES NEED TO BE OVERHAULED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Guidelines for National Unification (GNU) should be overhauled to meet actual needs, as the environments in both Taiwan and mainland China have changed, a ranking official from the Presidential Office said on Monday.

Chen Che-nan, acting secretary-general to the President, said there is room for debate on whether the contents of the GNU are still appropriate, as the guidelines were drafted more than eight years ago, and things have changed drastically since that time.
In what manner the GNU should be amended or overhauled should be decided by all members of the National Unification Council, which will meet for a new round of talks in the near future, Chen noted.

The guidelines outline the principles and positive steps that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can take to expedite China's unification. According to this gradual, sequential plan, unification is imperative not only for the sake of territorial unity, but also for the political freedom and equitable distribution of wealth for all Chinese.

The guidelines state that China's unification should be achieved in three phases: a short-term period of exchanges and reciprocity, a mid-term phase of mutual trust and cooperation, and a long-term period of consultations followed by unification.
This phased approach was planned with the full realization that the unification of China will be a long and arduous process, the GNU framers wrote.

China's unification will not be achieved overnight, because the two sides have divergent social, political and economic systems, not to mention vast differences in lifestyles. However, there is no fixed time frame for each stage in the guidelines, which only say that the speed of progress depends on the pace with which the mainland authorities respond.

In response to Chen's remarks that the guidelines need to be overhauled after weathering eight or nine years of change in the cross-strait situation, officials from the opposition New Party said the unification timetable and how the unification should be conducted can be talked about, but the ultimate goal of unification should never be altered.

Lai Shih-pao, whip of the New Party Legislative Yuan caucus, said the national unification guidelines can be amended, but only in regards to the timetable and methodology for unification, as some flexibility is necessary to meet the needs of the country. However, he stressed, the ultimate goal of the guidelines -- unification -- is the central guiding idea which should not be changed under any circumstances.

Hao Lung-ping, convenor of the New Party's National Election and Development Committee, said the banner of unification is an umbrella of protection for President Chen Shui-bian as far as cross-strait relations are concerned.

As a national leader who has singled out avoiding war as his major duty and obligation, Chen understands that waving the unification banner is the one and only way for him to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Hao said.
He added that the contents of the GNU may not be appropriate now, and need to be revised if that is true, but he stressed that the goal of unification should never be changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WANTS TO LIVE IN PEACE WITH MAINLAND CHINA: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said on Monday that the Republic of China hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to live in peace and prosperity, and that it has no intention of provoking the mainland.
Lu made the remarks when she received Elie Goldschmidt, chairman of the Finance Committee of the Israeli Knesset, or parliament.

Lu noted that Israel is similar to Taiwan in that it is in a difficult situation in the international community. But Israel has been more fortunate in that the world has paid a great deal of attention to the relations between Israel and its neighboring states, she noted.

Lu said that since the Chinese Communist Party established its political regime in the mainland in 1949, it has never exercised jurisdiction over Taiwan, but most of the countries in the world have recognized that there is only one China, and that Taiwan is a part of China, which she said is far from the truth.
She stressed that the government has no intention of provoking Beijing, adding that Taiwan hopes to live in peace with mainland China.

When both sides of the Taiwan Strait resume their long-stalled dialogue, the talks must be conducted on a basis of equality, mutual respect and mutual benefit, rather than one side exerting overwhelming pressure on the other, she added.

For his part, Goldschmidt said that it was unimaginable in the 1980s that Israel would sit down at the negotiations table with the Palestinians because of the two sides' mutual mistrust and long-standing animosity.

But he said that Israel is now moving in this direction, adding that though the process of negotiation is tough and the results still unpredictable, he said the experience gained during the process is valuable.
The Israeli parliamentarian was accompanied on his visit by Francis Chang, director general of the Department of West Asian Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKES SHAKING KAOHSIUNG AREA ARE NATURAL: CWB

TEXT.P: The Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said on Monday that the intense earthquakes that have been occurring in the township of Taoyuan, Kaohsiung County, over the last two days are a normal phenomenon, judging from past seismological records.

Three earthquakes respectively registering 4.4, 4.6, and 4.8 on the Richter scale, jolted Taoyuan on Sunday, with another three quakes of magnitude 4.5, 4.6, and 4.0 hitting the same township between 3:02 a.m. and 3:31 a.m. on Monday.

A magnitude 5.0 earthquake may sound scary, but the strongest of those that hit Taoyuan over the weekend, registering this level, was different from the "921 quake" of last year. The tremors of that quake lasted for a long time, while this jolt only lasted for one-tenth of a second.

Deputy-Director Lu Pei-ling explained that the tremors occurring in Taoyuan these days are simply the normal phenomena of energy being released as the township is located in the area of the Central Mountain range where intense quakes strike every few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX INDEX FUTURES DOWN SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: September futures for the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index on Monday dropped six points to close at 8,275, with 3,623 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for October were also off slightly, dropping nine points to finish at 8,300, with 38 contracts traded, while December futures closed at 8,350, up two points, with nine contract deals struck.
Futures for next March fell by 79 points to reach 8,301, with just one contract traded.
No contract transactions were recorded for other months.

The Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange's reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading on Monday were 8,281 for September, 8,309 for October, 8,348 for December, 8,380 for next March, and 8,494 for next June.
TAIEX electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures contracts based on TAIEX-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, closed slightly higher on the day.

September TE futures increased 1.70 points to finish at 450.90, with 1,372 contract transactions, while October TE futures moved up 2.40 points to end at 450.90, with 15 contracts traded. December TE futures climbed higher to close at 454.80, up 5.80 points, with six contract deals struck.
No TE futures contract transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures rose 5.6 points to finish at 915.8, with 508 contract transactions, while October TF futures were up seven points to close at 920.0, with one contract transaction. December TF futures climbed 5.6 points to end at 939.4, with just one contract traded.
No TF futures contract transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND YOUTHS PERFORM IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Cross-strait Peace Angels, a performance troupe consisting of mainland children and youths, put on a dance show on Monday.

Taiwan's National Planner's Association (NPA) has organized this annual activity since 1991, allowing young people from mainland China and Taiwan to visit each other's countries, with the venue of the performance alternating every year. The fifth performance of the Cross-Strait Angels was held at Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall on Monday, and included a lively children's folk dance.

Taipei Deputy Mayor Ou Chin-der expressed his appreciation for the troupe's efforts, noting that they were bringing peace and love from mainland China to Taiwan. He added that the young people would also have the chance to get to know Taiwan and bring that understanding back to the mainland.
Ou added although cross-strait political issues still need to be solved, cultural interaction is more important than those issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT TO CALL ON OPPOSITION PARTY LEADER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian may call on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan in the first week of September, acting Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan said on Monday.
It would mark the first time that an ROC president paid a formal courtesy call on an opposition party chairman.

The presidential spokesman said at a routine press conference that he has already picked out three to four different time slots to fit with Lien's schedule, and that if these times are still inconvenient for Lien, the meeting could take place at a different time.

The president had said during his July 31 press conference that he would be willing to visit the KMT's headquarters personally to invite Lien to a cross-party roundtable with the heads of the ROC's three major political parties.

According to Chen Che-nan, the president's sincerity so touched Lien that he wanted to come to the Presidential Office himself. As both sides want to show respect by visiting each other, Chen Che-nan said that the meeting between Lien and the president should take place at a midpoint between the Presidential Office and the KMT's headquarters, adding that the Taipei Guest House is a possible venue.

KMT spokesman Jason Hu responded to Chen Che-nan's statements by saying that he is unable to confirm the news of the possible meeting, but that if there is indeed to be a meeting, the venue would be up to its host, President Chen.

The president had earlier said that he wanted the roundtable meeting to take place in August, but plans were shelved as the party leaders called for preliminary meetings to set up details for the roundtable meeting, as well as because of scheduling difficulties brought about by the president, KMT chairman, and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong all leaving Taiwan on their respective overseas trips.

Lien left for the United States and Canada on a two-week visit that ended Aug. 15. Soong left for Germany on Aug. 10 to attend a meeting of overseas Chinese in Europe, returning on Monday. The president himself is currently on a 13-day, six-nation official state visit to the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS URGE PRESIDENT TO BOLSTER TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Gambia, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Y. Y. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Three business leaders traveling with President Chen Shui-bian on his 13-day, six-state official foreign trip suggested to the President that he work to bolster traditional industries in Taiwan.

Lin Kun-chung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries; Wang You-tseng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China; and Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, had suggested earlier this month to Premier Tang Fei that the government spend NT$300 billion (US$9.67 billion) to buy stocks in Taiwan' traditional, labor-intensive industries.
The trio of business leaders again made the proposal to the President on Sunday, and Koo stressed later that President Chen is firm in his desire to bolster traditional industries.

Eugene Chien, deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office, said that President Chen listened carefully to the business leaders' report on the difficult situation facing traditional manufacturers. They expressed their hope that the president would support labor-intensive industries by stepping in to bolster share prices in related firms and also to help them obtain financing.
The three business leaders went on to suggest that the government grant a six-month suspension on loans made to traditional manufacturers, which currently fall due at the end of next January.
President Chen did not give a substantial response to the trio's suggestion, only saying that he intends to promote actively Taiwan's economic development after his return this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO SET UP TRIBUNAL FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Beijing has agreed to set up an ad hoc tribunal to settle trade disputes involving Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China, a Taiwan business leader visiting the mainland said on Monday.

Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) President Richard Wu told a group of Taiwan-based journalists that the Beijing authorities have agreed to establish a "business court for Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau," to adjudicate disputes between businessmen from the three areas and their mainland Chinese trade partners.
Although the proposed court will also hear disputes involving businessmen from Hong Kong and Macau, Taiwan businessmen will be its major users in light of their larger number, said Wu.

Taiwan businessmen often complain that they cannot get fair treatment at ordinary courts in mainland China because of the rampant regionalism and protectionism. In order to address the problem, the TEEMA has lobbied Beijing for years to set up a special tribunal to hear such cases, said Wu.
Wu, who added that he personally has had unpleasant experiences with Beijing's courts, expressed hope that such incidents will become a thing of the past after the new tribunal begins operations.
Wu and his delegation arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a ten-day visit. They will call on Beijing leaders and tour central and southern China to research the investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARFT REPRESENTATIVES VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A delegation from mainland China's State Administration of Radio, Film and Television (SARFT) arrived in Taiwan on Monday for a 10-day visit.

The delegation, which made the trip at the invitation of Da-chung International, a local multimedia company, is headed by An Li, deputy director of the SARFT Department of Foreign Affairs, and more than 20 other personnel involved in radio and TV work.

President Jiang Feng-chyi of China Television Co. (CTC), Da-chung's parent company, greeted the representatives and said An's visit indicated that the two sides have the potential to cooperate with one another.

The delegation is scheduled to visit CTC and Da Ai TV, a station operated by the Tzu Chi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Foundation, as well as touring various local spots of cultural and geographic significance.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI, TRANSASIA AIRWAYS CANCEL FLIGHTS TO EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: UNI Airways Corp. and TransAsia Airways on Monday canceled their flights to eastern Taiwan scheduled for the following day as strong typhoon Bilis approached the island.
Rail transport was set to continue as scheduled, at least on Tuesday morning.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced that it had formed a crisis center to handle any disasters precipitated by the typhoon.

Vice Chief of the General Staff Wang Han-ning was named as head of the center, and a MND spokesman said all related units have been instructed to give full support to any rescues that may become necessary.

Bilis, which was only a mid-level typhoon on Monday morning, was located about 740 kilometers southeast of Taiwan and was moving steadily in a north north-westerly direction at a speed of 22 kilometers per hour at around 3 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau announced.
Packing winds of 51 meters per second at its center, and with a radius of 300 kilometers, Bilis is showing no signs of subsiding.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH SCHOOL HACKERS ARRESTED FOR PLANTING COMPUTER VIRUSES

TEXT.P: Three local high school students were arrested on Monday for allegedly running Trojan programs to steal dial-up account passwords from compromised computer systems.

According to the Ninth Investigation Corps of the Criminal Investigation Bureaus (CIB), which handles computer crime, the three teenagers were still beaming with pride during questioning when they described their attacks.

The students allegedly scanned specific regions of the Internet for computers that had already been infected with the SunSeven and NetSpy Trojan programs, which act as local servers that allow any hacker with appropriate client programs to remotely access the local system and acquire otherwise secure information such as passwords. The stolen information can then allow hackers to run up huge charges with a victim's Internet service provider.
CIB officials said that there has been a recent increase in reports of compromised systems, stolen account numbers, and skyrocketing dial-up fees that are linked to the two programs.
Police said that Trojans normally infect large corporate computer systems, but added that any individual's computer can be vulnerable.

Most commercial anti-virus programs can only detect popular Trojans, while the rest slip past unnoticed. With over 600 Trojans out in cyberspace and a noted lack of anti-Trojan programs that can recognize them all and weed them out, computer users should be wary of opening any executable email attachments, even from known sources.
Strange or unexplained dialogue boxes with conversation or keystrokes entered with a user's interaction may also be indications of a Trojan infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO TO OFFER WARM WELCOME TO ROC PRESIDENT (I)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to arrive in Burkina Faso on Monday for a three-day visit to the West African nation.

Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore will lead all his government officials and "mobilize citizens in the capital" to give Chen a grand reception upon his arrival at Ouagadougou airport, according to unnamed reports.

Compaore, 49, is very friendly towards the ROC. He had visited the ROC three times since the two countries restored diplomatic relations in 1994 and is said to have been much impressed by the ROC's progress in the fields of politics, economy and society.

Compaore has also cited "the Taiwan formula" as a paragon for the development of his own country and always attends the ROC's national day reception held by the ROC Embassy in Burkina Faso each Oct. 10.
The former Upper Volta changed its national name to Burkina Faso in 1984. Burkina, in local language, means "honest people," and Faso means "land of the ancestor."
A landlocked country, Burkina Faso lies on the southern edge of the Sahara desert. It occupies an area of 274,200 square kilometers and has a population of 11 million.

Burkina Faso's climate is dry with a rainy season that lasts for just two months per year. Infertile soil forces three million of Burkina Faso's people to work in neighboring countries and they are the biggest contributors to the country's foreign reserves.
The impoverished West African nation's per capita income in 1998 was just US$255.

Compaore grabbed power in a 1987 coup and his rule has been marked by a struggle between him and opposition leaders. Abandoning his former leftist leanings, he has sought to "establish a democratic system" and has improved the nation's economy.
In a "multi-party" presidential election in December 1991, Compaore won by a huge margin. The opposition refused to participate, however, claiming that the election had been fixed.
He was re-elected in 1998. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG MEMBERS STAGE SHOW IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Falun Gong sect members in Sydney, encouraged by Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer's support, are holding a one-week show in the city's Chinatown to confront mainland China's harassment and threats.

The show, which opened on Aug. 19, includes a video shot in New York in which American practitioners explain the benefits of practicing Falun Gong, a form of deep breathing used to promote spiritual, mental and physical health. Photos of practitioners are also on display.

In an interview with CNA on Sunday, Kao Yuan, an Australian Chinese member, said: "We are putting on the show to confront any Chinese harassment and threat of crackdown outside of China. We are not afraid of any Chinese diplomats' threats because they have absolutely no rights to harass us in Australia."
Kao was referring to reports that mainland Chinese diplomats in Australia were harassing Falun Gong members, accusations that have been vehemently denied by the mainland.

Kao said the mainland Chinese authorities are trying to eliminate Falun Gong and its members because they are "desperate" they will be usurped by the sect, despite the fact that the sect is peaceful in nature.
He said the sect members in Sydney and Canberra were feeling encouraged after Downer told a visiting mainland Chinese delegation last week to stop harassing Falun Gong members in Australia.
The delegation, led by Vice Foreign Minister Yang Jeichi, was in Canberra to attend a one-day human rights dialogue with its Australian counterpart.
The delegates denied that the Falun Gong members were being harassed and accused the sect members of damaging Beijing's relations with Canberra with their protests and demonstrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT DENIED OF JAPANESE VISA FOR FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative to Japan on Monday denied news reports that Japan will issue a visa for former ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
Representative Lo Fu-chen said: "We have tried our best and employed every opportunity over the years to make it possible for President Lee to visit Japan.

"However, at this moment, we have yet to receive an exact answer from the Japanese authorities about the date and manner in which the former ROC head of state would be allowed to enter Japan," he added.
Japan is sensitive to pressure from Beijing regarding visits by Taiwan officials.
Lee has expressed the hope that he can attend the 12th Asian Outlook Forum scheduled to be held in October in Japan. He would also like to visit his alma mater -- Kyoto University.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT PROPOSES ESTABLISHMENT OF ASIAN MONETARY FUND

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Monday proposed the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
He raised the proposal while speaking at the opening in Taipei of the Fifth East Asian International Symposium -- IT Revolution and Northeastern Asian Economic Cooperation.

In order to pursue further economic development in Asia, Lee said that all the countries in the region must continue to engage in reform of their economic structures and suggested that some new financial assistance mechanism, in the form of an Asian monetary fund, should be established between Southeast Asian countries and other countries of the region.
He also pointed out the need for studies to be conducted on the establishment of a free trade zone in Northeast Asia to strengthen private investment and economic exchanges in the area.
He said that at the start of the new century, the three major countries in Northeast Asia -- Taiwan, Japan and South Korea -- are entering a new phase in both the political and economic fields.

Lee noted that Taiwan has completed a peaceful transfer of government, while the leaders of the two Koreas have held a historic summit meeting and Japan has resumed talks with North Korea on normalization of diplomatic relations.

In the economic area, he said that amid the coming of the IT technological revolution, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea are facing a situation that requires huge changes in their respective industrial structures.
As a result, he said that finding ways to enhance economic cooperation has become a new and important task for these countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN INVITES MEMBERS TO RE-REGISTER WITH PARTY

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan wrote an open letter on Monday to invite his fellow party members to re-register with the party to reconfirm their memberships.
The letter will delivered through the party's apparatus to its members across the island, asking them to stand up and be counted and acknowledge their loyalty to the party.

Recalling the hardships the KMT has gone through in the last hundred years, the KMT leader urges his comrades in the letter to follow the footsteps of the party's prominent members, many of whom have given their lives for the party's cause in the past.
Lien acknowledges the deep sorrow he felt after being defeated in the May 18 presidential election -- the first time the party had been stripped of the power to rule in more than five decades.

"Instead of fraying our nerves and beating us completely, the temporary loss in the presidential election will only prompt all of us to fight tooth and nail for the party's ultimate victory," says Lien's letter.

Noting that KMT members have always come forward in force to buttress their party whenever the organization created by ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen was in crisis, Lien urges his fellow members to reconfirm their commitment to KMT, and vows to fight shoulder to shoulder with them "for the party's brighter future."

The KMT, which boasts a membership of 2.4 million, was divided in the presidential election between Lien Chan and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong who ran as an independent, effectively handing victory to the Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian, who won by a narrow margin.
The rift between Lien and Soong led to a massive breakaway of Soong' KMT followers who formed their own People's First Party with Soong as their head.

In order to "clean its own house" after the division, the KMT launched the re-registration of its membership with the purpose of regrouping their followers and paving the way for party primaries as a method of choosing party candidates for public office.
Lien and several elder KMT statesmen will re-register their memberships on Sept. 1 as a publicity stunt to encourage other members to follow suit, said KMT party officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SIGNS JOINT COMMUNIQUE WITH GAMBIAN COUNTERPART
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Chen Ying-ying & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh on Monday signed a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.

In the joint communique, Chen and Jammeh agreed that all countries of the world should work on the principle of sovereign independence and parity to resolve international problems through dialogue, negotiation and other peaceful means.

They indicated their satisfaction over the friendship and close cooperative relations between the two countries, and stated that they would continue their efforts to promote the common interest of the two countries and their people.
Jammeh reiterated the Gambian government's firm support for the ROC's participation in the activities of the United Nations and other international organizations.

He praised the ROC for its outstanding achievements in political democratization and economic development, and expressed appreciation for Taiwan's assistance to Gambia in the fields of agricultural development, medical care, highway construction, power generation and other national construction projects.
Chen for his part invited Jammeh to visit Taipei and Jammeh accepted with pleasure. The visit plans will be arranged through diplomatic channels.

The ROC president arrived in the Gambian capital of Banjul on Sunday for a two-day official visit and held talks with Jammeh to exchange views on the international situation and issues relating to bilateral cooperation.
He was scheduled to depart for Burkina Faso on Monday night to continue his first African trip since assuming the presidency on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2Q BALANCE OF INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS HITS SEVEN-QUARTER LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments hit US$1.011 billion, the lowest single-quarter amount in seven quarters, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Monday.
This quarter's balance of payments surplus was US$7.013 billion less than the first quarter's US$8.024 billion, which was a 12-year single-quarter high.
Total current account surplus for the first and second quarters reached US$2.547 billion compared to the US$4.829 billion recorded in the same period of last year.
Total capital account deficit for the first and second quarters hit US$200 million compared to the year-earlier total deficit of US$71 million.
Net monetary account inflow for the first and second quarters reached US$6.17 billion, compared to the year-earlier net inflow of US$3.85 billion.
CBC reserves for the first and second quarters increased US$9.035 billion, compared to the increase of US$10.347 billion recorded for the same period of last year.
Second quarter current account surplus reached US$1.428 billion, compared to last year's second quarter surplus of US$2.118 billion.
Second quarter capital account deficit hit US$82 million, compared to last year's second quarter deficit of US$39 million.
Second quarter net monetary account outflow hit US$1.318 billion, compared to last year's second quarter inflow of US$2.415 billion.
CBC reserves increased US$1.011 billion during the second quarter, compared to the increase of US$5.465 billion recorded in the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO TO OFFER WARM WELCOME TO ROC PRESIDENT (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Burkina Faso resumed diplomatic relations with the ROC in 1994 in the hope of learning from Taiwan's development experience to create "a Burkina Faso miracle."

In the six years since the resumption of bilateral ties, the ROC has offered a variety of technological assistance. Those contained in the cooperative agreement include agricultural assistance, medical cooperation, programs aiming at improving livelihoods, as well as forestation that prevents the southward encroachment of the Sahara.
All the assistance programs have achieved "significant effects."
At a speech at the legislature, Compaore claimed that the ROC assistance has brought hope for Burkina Faso's national development.

On Aug. 2, when Compaore announced that Chen would visit Burkina Faso on Aug. 21-23, he said that the two heads of state would hold a summit meeting to review the results of bilateral cooperation and usher in a vision for cooperative relations in the future.

According to Saidou M. Ouedraogo, the Burkina Faso Presidential Office official in charge of press affairs, Compaore is to receive Chen at Ouagadougou airport and accompany him on a series of activities, including a ribbon-cutting ceremony for the inauguration of a farming area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRAVELERS SPENT US$ 2.03 BILLION OVERSEAS IN SECOND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan travelers spent US$2.03 billion overseas in the second quarter of this year, an indication that the people of the island have gradually emerged from the shadow of the disaster caused by the Sept. 21 earthquake last year.

Although US$126 million less than the US$2.16 billion spent in the previous quarter, it is far more than the US$1.75 billion registered in the last quarter of 1999, when the island was still reeling from the 7.3-magnitude quake which claimed the lives of 2,400 in central Taiwan.

The second quarter's spending brought the island's total tourist spending in the first half of this year to US$4.19 billion, and more spending is expecting during the seasonal travel peak of the third quarter, according to an analyst with the Central Bank of China.
Meanwhile, the island's domestic tourism earned US$955 million, which is US$US$20 million less than the previous quarter. This revenue was also expected to surge in the third quarter.
In related news, the public sector's outstanding foreign debt declined to US$31 million as of the end of March, which is a historic low against the 1982 peak of US$7.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERHAULING GNU MIGHT DAMAGE CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The director of the opposition Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Research said on Monday that overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification (GNU) would damage cross-Taiwan Strait stability.

Chang Jung-kung was reacting to remarks by Acting Secretary-General to the President, Chen Che-nan, who said the GNU should be overhauled to meet actual needs, as the environments in both Taiwan and mainland China have changed.

However, Chang said that according to President Chen Shui-bian's remarks that cross-strait reunification was not the only choice, overhauling the GNU would affect the main direction of the cross-strait relationship development and might also start a domestic war of words on independence versus unification.

Chang said Presidential Office officials have expressed the intention to overhaul the GNU many times. However, they have never explained the direction such an overhaul would take. Chang said that is the reason he has maintained his conservative attitude toward a GNU overhaul.

He emphasized that the present GNU does not force Taiwan to handle the cross-strait unification issue, which is to the advantage of the people. In addition, under the democratic system, any important development in the cross-strait relationship should be agreed upon through public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO EXTEND FIVE-YEAR FARMING COOPERATION PLAN TO GAMBIA
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Chen Ying-ying & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Monday announced that his government will extend an agricultural cooperation plan for Gambia for an additional five years when the current five-year plan expires.

Accompanied by the Gambian agriculture minister, Chen visited a vegetable garden in Banjul, where vegetables and other crops are grown with the assistance of a Taiwan agricultural technical assistance mission.
He expressed satisfaction with the results of the vegetable garden, where such popular Taiwan vegetables as four-season long beans and peanuts are cultivated.

The Gambian agriculture minister also announced that the name of the vegetable garden would be changed to the "A-Bian Vegetable Garden" to mark Chen's visit and to illustrate the Gambian government's appreciation for Taiwan's assistance.
Chen later visited several local memorial sites and exchanged greetings with local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REITERATES ROC'S DETERMINATION TO RETURN TO UN
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Chen Ying-ying & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Monday that Taiwan's determination to return to the United Nations will not be affected by oppression from Beijing.
He made the statement while meeting with the media after signing a joint communique with Gambian President Yahya Jammeh in Banjul.

Like the determination of Gambia to defend its sovereignty against the threat from Senegal, Chen said that Taiwan's efforts to go back to the UN will not be affected by oppression from mainland China.
"The chance will come, so long as we insist," Chen noted, and added that "hope will be visible, so long as we can breathe."
The president said that the efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations will not affect Taiwan's role in and its contributions to the international community.
Before realizing the goal of returning to the UN, Chen said that Taiwan will do its best to contribute to the international community through humanitarian efforts and economic cooperation.
He expressed his appreciation for the Gambian government's support for Taiwan in international organizations.
Chen arrived in Banjul for a two-day visit on Sunday and was to proceed to Burkina Faso on Monday night for a three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON GOV'T URGED TO LIFT RESTRICTION ON TAIWAN LEADERS US VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A heavyweight US congressman on Sunday criticized the Clinton Administration's restrictions on meetings between US congressmen and Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian when the latter made a one-night stopover in Los Angeles recently.

Samuel Gejdenson (D-Conn.), a minority member of the House of Representative's International Relations Subcommission, said that Chen and Taiwan deserve to receive fair treatment. He added that the Clinton Administration should permit ROC leaders to make contact with US parliamentarians and related US government officials.

In an article published in the Washington Times on Sunday, he described a meeting scheduled between members of the House of Representative's International Relations Subcommission and Chen as "proper and important."

About 15 parliamentarians from the Democratic Party and the Republican Party had originally planned to meet with Chen on Aug. 13. Yielding to political pressure from Washington and Beijing, however, Chen was forced to say he would not attend, so the meeting was canceled, he said.
He said members of Congress have long had the freedom to meet with world leaders and to travel to places the administration cannot, including Cuba, North Korea, Iraq and Yugoslavia.
"These meetings present vital opportunities to discuss issues of mutual concern that directly affect the US national interest," he said.

Gejdenson said he regretted that the meeting with Chen was canceled due to the US executive branch's adherence to an executive order issued more than 20 years ago that limits Taiwan leaders' visits to the United States or meeting with US officials.

He stressed that in the changing times, Congress must keep focused on US policy towards Taiwan. "We must find ways to reduce the threat of war between Taiwan and China and in particular, to counteract China's buildup of missiles pointed at Taiwan.

He went on to say that the House of Representatives has already overwhelmingly approved the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, which will strengthen the US-Taiwan defense relationship, but this important bill remains bottled-up in the Senate. The Congress must encourage the administration to find meaningful ways to involve Taiwan in international organizations, to the benefit of both Taiwan and the international community, he said.

He said that members of Congress traveling in Asia routinely visit Taipei to meet with senior officials, and that it is time high-ranking Taiwan officials be permitted to come to the United States to meet with member of Congress and relevant US officials.

The United States must try to find some way to afford Taiwan's leader the respect he has earned, he said, adding that meetings of this kind would send a strong message to mainland China that the United States is committed to defending Taiwan and its democracy in deeds rather than words.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CONCERNED ABOUT TYPHOON THREAT
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Y. Y. Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian telephoned Premier Tang Fei shortly after his arrival in the West African country of Burkina Faso on Monday to express his concern about a typhoon forecast to strike Taiwan on Tuesday.
President Chen telephoned Tang after attending a state banquet given by Burkina Faso President Blaise Comparore in his honor.

Deputy Secretary-General to the President Eugene Chien quoted Chen as having told Tang that he hopes the government can take full precautions against heavy rains, strong winds and landslides probably to be brought to Taiwan by typhoon Bilis.
In response, Tang was quoted as saying that the nation's anti-typhoon center has been on a full alert and that the government will make every possible effort to minimize possible typhoon damage.

Chien told Taiwan reporters covering President Chen's current overseas trip that the president also gave a phone call to Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who concurrently heads a national emergency rescue center, and urged Chang to oversee all anti-typhoon precautionary measures.

Chen arrived in Burkina Faso capital on Monday to continued his six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at cementing the Republic of China's diplomatic relations with its allies in Central America and West Africa.

He already visited the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, and the West African nation of the Gambia. Before ending his first post-inauguration overseas trop, Chen will also visit Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT COMPAORE OF BURKINA FASO VOWS TO SUPPORT ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie)

TEXT.P: President Blaise Compaore of the West African state of Burkina Faso declared on Monday that he will spare no effort in seeing the Republic of China re-enter the United Nations and other international organizations.

"We strongly support the efforts employed by the Republic of China in view to breaking through its diplomatic isolation because we think that the international community cannot continue to ignore a nation of 23 million inhabitants," he told CNA in an interview.

Shortly before welcoming his counterpart, Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, on a visit to Burkina Faso, President Compaore reiterated that it was a great honor for the whole nation to welcome President Chen. He stressed that he attaches great importance to the visit.

The ROC president arrived in Ouagadougou late Monday afternoon with a 80-strong entourage for a three-day official visit. The ROC resumed diplomatic relations with Burkina Faso in 1995 after 22 years of suspension.
Refuting criticism of the ROC's alleged so-called "money diplomacy," President Compaore noted that relations between Burkina Faso and the Republic of China are based on friendship and solidarity.

"Our two nations are motivated to working toward a world of justice and peace," he said, adding that the importance of the bilateral relationship has been perceived through the positive results recorded in various fields of cooperation during the past years.

Under the bilateral Technical Cooperation Agreement signed in 1996, the ROC sent a 12-member team of experts to help develop Burkina Faso's rice cultivation and also five doctors to improve medical services in the West African nation. The ROC government has also provided some financial aid to build irrigation systems, to help with reforestation efforts in the northern regions of Sahel, and to establish a handicraft industry.

President Compaore also expressed the hope that the two countries can cooperate in the private sector so as to further strengthen their overall relationship. He said agriculture and related industries, as well as textiles, are potential areas of investment for Taiwan investors.

In his view, such cooperation is very promising because Burkina Faso is located at the hub of the 70-million consumer common market of the West African Economic and Monetary Union, which was established on Jan. 1 this year among eight French speaking nations in the region.
