DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY READY FOR ANTI-TYPHOON DISASTER MISSION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China armed forces are ready for rescue and relief missions for any disasters probably to be caused by typhoon Bilis, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday.

MND spokesman Kung Fan-ding said President Chen Shui-bian, who is currently on a state visit in the West African state of Burkina Faso, already ordered military units through Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming to join post-typhoon relief work so long as the mission will not affect combat preparedness and national security affairs.
Kung said the MND formed an anti-typhoon damage command center at 2:40 p.m. Monday, with Vice Chief of the General Staff Wang Han-ning as commander.
"Wang will be on duty around the clock to organize various military units to take part in emergency relief and rescue work," Kung said.

Typhoon Bilis, packing winds of 234 kilometers an hour, is set to smash into Taiwan later Tuesday, the Central Weather Bureau said. Schools and offices were closed in the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung which were already being battered by Bilis' fringe winds and heavy rain.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET WEAKENS ON TYPHOON THREAT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices declined on Monday, reversing an upward trend that had continued for five trading sessions.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, lost 139.83 points to close at 8,118.05 on a turnover of NT$77.97 billion (US$2.52 billion) in slow trading as investors kept on the sidelines due to a looming typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACES FOR TYPHOON BILIS

TEXT.P: Bracing for the strongest typhoon to hit Taiwan this year, airlines have rescheduled their flights while the Taipei City government announced the closing of schools and government offices for Tuesday afternoon and all day Wednesday.
Airlines have advised passengers to check with them in advance to get information on possible flight rescheduling.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange also announced that the stock market will be closed on Wednesday in line with natural disaster contingency measures.

The Central Weather Bureau said that as of noon Tuesday, Typhoon Bilis was located 280 kilometers southeast of Taitung, in southeastern Taiwan, and was moving west northwest at a speed of 22 kilometers per hour.

Meteorologists said that offshore Orchid Island is now under the influence of the strong typhoon, adding that Typhoon Bilis is forecast to reach Taitung in the evening when the whole island is expected to come under its influence.
They said that the entire island experienced rain Tuesday morning, adding that the rains and winds will gradually increase in strength.

Pounding rains and fierce winds will come after the whole island comes under the typhoon's influence, and the worse is forecast to occur between Tuesday night and Wednesday morning, according to meteorologists.

Premier Tang Fei urged the public to be on guard against the dangers posed by the strongest typhoon to hit Taiwan this year. The Ministry of Defense also notified the military to be on alert for potential rescue operations.
As strong winds are expected to pound Taiwan for a long duration, meteorologists forecast that damage, such as trees being uprooted and electric poles being toppled, is likely.

They noted that the greatest danger to northern Taiwan residents will likely be the strong winds, adding that people living in central Taiwan should be on guard against mudslides and those living on the coast in southern Taiwan may be faced with high waves.

The weather forecasters said that possible dangers from heavy rains should not be ignored, especially in the eastern and southern mountainous areas where rainfall is expected to reach 450 millimeters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, BURKINA FASO PRESIDENTS REAFFIRM STRONG TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Y. Y. Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: In a show of warm welcome, a Burkina Faso young lady presented fresh water, a live goat and a bronze statue to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian upon his arrival in the West African state on Monday for a visit.

President Chen, heading a large delegation of government officials, business executives and journalists, arrived in the Burkina Faso capital of Ouagadougou from neighboring Gambia around 17:30 p.m. for a three-day state visit.

Chen was accorded a red-carpet welcome, complete with a 21-gun salute upon his arrival at the airport. Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore personally presided over the grand welcoming ceremony to greet the first Asian leader to his country.

A large crowd of Burkina Faso nationals decked out in traditional costumes and performed folk songs and dances to welcome President Chen. The welcoming procession wound along a highway linking the Ouagadougou airport to the Presidential Office plaza.

Compaore and Chen jointly drank a ladle of water to symbolize solid friendship between the two countries, while a young lady presented three special gifts -- fresh water, a white live goat and a bronze statue -- to signify Burkina Faso people's hearty welcome the visitor from afar.
Noting that Burkina Faso means a "country of people of integrity" in local dialect, Chen said he indeed feels that this is a great country upon his arrival.

Compaore, who has made three visits to Taiwan, said he has been impressed by the ROC's prosperity and progress in various fields. The Burkina Faso head of state added that he hopes to develop his country into an economic powerhouse like Taiwan.

After the welcoming ceremony, Compaore and Chen held talks inside the Presidential Office. During the meeting, Compaore said Chen's visit marks a new chapter in ROC-Burkina Faso relations. He also expressed gratitude for the aid and assistance the ROC has extended to his country over past years.
For his part, Chen thanked Burkina Faso for its support for the ROC's bids to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.

Chen assured Compaore that his administration will faithfully implemented the 21 existing cooperative programs between the countries. He also invited Compaore to visit Taipei again in October to attend the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebrations.
Later in the day, Compaore hosted a dinner in honor of President Chen and his entourage.

On Tuesday, Chen will visit a model farm founded with the assistance from a resident ROC agricultural mission. He will also attend a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a new bilateral cooperative venture to promote new strains of rice in Burkina Faso. Compaore will confer a decoration and host a state banquet in honor of Chen on Tuesday evening.

On Wednesday, Chen will tour a bilateral cooperative program aimed at upgrading women's status in Burkina Faso and deliver a speech to the Burkina Faso parliament. Chen will also sign a joint communique and give a joint press conference with Compaore before his departure for Chad to continue his six-state "journey of friendship" to cement the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies.

Chen had visited the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America and the Gambia before coming to Burkina Faso. This is also Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: JULY EXPORT ORDERS HIT NEW MONTHLY RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced on Tuesday that the total value of July's export orders hit the third highest monthly level ever.
The value of July's export orders reached US$12.99 billion, representing a 20 percent increase over the previous July's total, said the MOEA.

The MOEA stated that the total value of July's exports of electronics, which remain the hottest export order products, reached US$3.16 billion, a jump of US$1.35 billion over the previous July's total, or a 74.68 percent increase.

The largest source of export orders was the United States, with orders totaling US$4.11 billion, representing an increase of 10.19 percent over the previous July's figure. The US was followed by Hong Kong, Japan, and Europe, as the top sources of export orders for Taiwan products.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA READY TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE FOR LEE'S VISIT TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Tuesday that it will provide the necessary assistance for former President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Japan.
Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee was responding to a report on Monday which said that the former president hopes to visit Japan in October.

But the MOFA has yet to receive any requests for assistance pertaining to the ex-president's planned visit, nor has it received related reports from the ROC's Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan, said Lee, adding that if there is such a need, the ministry will provide assistance.

Liu Tai-ying, president of the Taiwan Research Institute, said on Monday that the former president, who is now serving as the honorary chairman of the private think tank, is keen on visiting Japan, hoping to attend a meeting of the Asian Outlook, which he co-founded in 1989, and also to call on his alma mater Kyoto Imperial University, as well as to meet several groups that are friendly to Taiwan.

The Vice Foreign Minister said that the exchanges between Japan and Taiwan are close and that there have been many invitations to the ex-president from Japanese private groups, but added that the ministry currently is not making any preparations for such a visit.

Meanwhile, Lin Chin-ching, representative of the Association of East Asia Relations, also said on Tuesday that many private groups from Japan have invited Lee Teng-hui to visit Japan because of their admiration for the former president.
Lin noted that many people in Japan had extended invitations in various ways hoping that Lee would be able to visit Japan after stepping down as the ROC head of state in May.
But as Lee's status is still a sensitive issue because of his past position, Lin said that it is better that the visit takes place in a most natural way.

Lin noted that as People's Republic of China Premier Zhu Rongji is scheduled to visit Japan in October, this makes Lee's planned visit uncertain, adding that the chances of the former ROC head of state visiting Japan before the end of the year are not to high.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX DECLINES OVER JITTERS ABOUT ECONOMIC OUTLOOK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices reversed its upward trend seen in the past five consecutive trading sessions and closed 1.7 percent lower on Tuesday.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometers, fell 139.83 points to close at 8,118.05, on turnover of NT$77.97 billion (US$2.52 billion).

Market analysts attributed the fall to a combination of factors, including profit-taking by short-term players and jitters about the island's economic outlook caused by lower-than-expected results of July's export orders, which slid 0.7 percent from the previous month to US$12.99 billion.

As for the sharp decrease in daily turnover, analysts said the reason was that many players kept on the sidelines due to a looming typhoon and imminent announcement by listed firms of their business records for the first half of this year.
A total of 156.92 million shares changed hands during the three-hour trading session.
Losers outnumbered gainers, 425 to 88, with 68 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUTURES MARKET DROPS

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Tuesday, when the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for September went down 95 points to close at 8,180, with 3,670 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for October also fell 102 points to close at 8,198, with 61 contract transactions, while December futures droped 109 points to finish at 8,202, with two contract deals struck. And next March futures declined 73 points to close at 8,301, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 8,275 for September; 8,300 for October; 8,311 for December; 8,374 for next March; and 8,488 for next June.
TAIEX Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also closed lower.

September TE futures fell 6.7 points to finish at 444.2, with 1,243 contract transactions, while October TE futures also lost 6.7 points to close at 444.2, with 10 contract transactions. And December TE futures slid 10 points to close at 444.8, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures declined 12 points to close at 903.8, with 491 contract transactions; October TF futures shed 5 points to finish at 915, with one contract transactions; December TF futures lost 25.4 points to close at 914, with one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON BILIS KNOCKS OUT ELECTRICITY OF 900 HOUSEHOLDS IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: Strong winds had knocked out the electricity supply for some 900 households in Taitung, southeastern Taiwan, as of noon on Tuesday, as Taiwan braced for Typhoon Bilis, the strongest typhoon to hit the island so far this year.

Typhoon Bilis, which has been upgraded to the level of a super-typhoon due to its high-speed winds, was centered 210 kilometers southeast of Taitung at 3 p.m. on Tuesday and was moving steadily in a west-northwesterly direction at a speed of 22 kilometers per hour.
Strong winds and heavy rains began to pound Taitung, nearby coastal areas, and offshore Orchid and Green Islands early on Tuesday morning.

The winds had been growing in strength since 9 a.m. Tuesday, but other than the power blackout, there were no reports of major calamities. Air, sea and railway traffic have all been suspended in Taitung County.
Meanwhile, Premier Tang Fei on Tuesday urged the public to be prepared for Typhoon Bilis, saying that people should pay attention to their safety, remain indoors and avoid unnecessary outings.
Tang urged the residents in the eastern regions of Taiwan to be well prepared for the typhoon so as to minimize its damage, while people in Keelung, Taipei, Taoyuan and Ilan should also be on alert.

Tang noted that the government's weather bureau had predicted that the typhoon will land on Taiwan between 6 p.m. and 7 p.m. Tuesday, and that it will leave Taiwan at around 7 a.m. Wednesday. As the storm's duration is expected to be very long, Tang warned the public to be careful of fallen advertisement boards and trees on the streets.
He also instructed local governments to persuade residents living in mudslide-prone areas to evacuate to safety shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 22, or the 23rd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1868: Ten thousand Chinese plunder the China Inland Mission as the Taiping Rebellion gathered momentum.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement to obey the National government, to join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprising China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Tanks belonging to a five-nation Warsaw Pact force enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush with military might the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named US secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1978: Jomo Kenyatta, the first president of Kenya, dies at the age of 87.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang-kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the nomination but to run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, you will use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds by ten efforts, you will use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCERS WOW AUSTRALIAN CRITIC

TEXT.P: The Cloud Gate Dance Theater, one of very few international dance troupes invited to perform at the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney, won a rave review in a mass circulation newspaper here on Monday, as the company continued its show for the third consecutive day on Monday.

Art critic Deborah Jones, who penned the article, praised Cloud Gate choreographer Lin Hwai-min and his production of "Nine Songs," describing him as "a master of choreography who seamlessly joins the ancient Asian with the utterly contemporary."

"He makes visible the great flow of time and history, linking the traditional and the here and now to fashion a piece that has political and social relevance, yet makes one understand that everything moves on," she said.

She praised Lin's long view of time and history. "In Nine Songs -- based on 2500-year-old Chinese poems -- seasons pass, epochs come and go, the realm of the gods elides with that of humankind, and there is struggle and acquiescence."

"There is also glorious dancing. The intense, powerful Cloud Gate performers have a kind of internal muscularity that lets them explode or stretch a moment out until every bit of essence has been extracted, but there is never any sense of such skill being used for mere pyrotechnical display," she said.
"At the end of 'Nine Songs' there is silence and a river of light. To Lin Hwai-min, one suspects, we are, somehow, always waving," she added.

Organizers of the arts festival said that the review would likely tempt more and more people to attend Cloud Gate performances of "Nine Songs" on Monday and Tuesday, and also increase ticket sales of the troupe's production of "Moonwater," slated for August 25 to 27 at Her Majesty's Theater in Sydney.
On Saturday and Sunday, the first two nights of the performance, about 80 percent of the theater's 1500 seats were taken, the organizers added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED INTRUDERS ATTEMPT BREAK-IN AT ROC DIPLOMAT'S RESIDENCE IN MALAWI
DOC.DATELINE: Lilongwe, Malawi, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Four armed men attempted to break into the local residence of a Republic of China diplomat, but were deterred by a warning shot and fled the scene.

A secretary at the ROC embassy surnamed Tsao told the Central News Agency that he was asleep when his night-shift security guard blew a whistle at around 12:10 a.m. on Sunday, alerting him to the presence of intruders on his property.

The guard said that four men, each armed with a knife, broke into the yard. After he blew the whistle, two of the intruders confronted and threatened him in an attempt to keep him quiet, while the other two men cut the main power line to Tsao's residence and ordered Tsao to open the door.

Tsao said that the houses in his neighborhood are often broken into, and that frequent warning shots can be heard at night to deter unwelcome guests. However, this was the first time that intruders ever tried to force their way into his house, he added.
After the four men tried to force open his door and windows with blunt instruments, Tsao fired a shot through the front door with his handgun, registered with the police for self-defense.

Tsao said that he couldn't hear any sounds from outside the door after he fired the shot, but he suspected that the intruders might have still been lurking outside the door, so he called for backup on his mobile phone.

Because Malawi policemen are often late to arrive at crime scenes due to transportation difficulties, ROC Ambassador to Malawi Chen Hsi-tsan called up three other embassy personnel to rush to Tsao's residence.
A search revealed that the suspects had escaped, and no signs of injuries were found.

According to the ROC embassy in this Southeast African nation, Malawi is considered to be a friendly country, but that an economic decline in recent years has pushed more and more people into crime. Residences of other embassy personnel have been burglarized in the past, but such blatant attempts at robbery as this case usually occur in more rural residential areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND BANKS MAY BE ALLOWED TO SET UP LIAISON OFFICE IN ROC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will consider the feasibility of allowing mainland Chinese banks to set up representative or liaison offices in Taiwan, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said on Tuesday.

Yen said since the government has agreed to a phased opening for local banks to establish footholds in mainland China, it will simultaneously mull the possibility of opening the door to mainland banks intending to tap the Taiwan market in line with the principles of fairness and parity.
Beijing authorities reportedly have made a goodwill response to the ROC's decision to allow a phased opening for Taiwan banks to set up footholds on the mainland.

Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council, was quoted as having said that Beijing will lower its requirements for Taiwan banks to open branches on the mainland and will also all Taiwan bank branches to operate mainland currency (renminbi)-denominated banking services. Chen's remarks have caught attention in the local banking community.

Yen, however, would not make any comments on grounds that Chen's remarks have not been officially confirmed. Instead, he said if the report about Chen's statements is correct, the ROC would welcome such mainland moves.

Noting that the government basically adopts a positive attitude toward the proposal of allowing local banks to set up liaison offices on the mainland, Yen said some issues need to be evaluated further.

For instance, Yen said that the ROC government hopes to known whether mainland China would allow Taiwan's banking inspectors to inspect branch operations after a liaison office is upgraded to a branch.
"We must also evaluate the possible impact if mainland China imposes restrictions on Taiwan inspectors in auditing operations of Taiwan banks' mainland branches," Yen noted.

Sean C. Chen, also a finance minister, said last week that the Ministry of Finance is working with the Central Bank of China and the Mainland Affairs Council on drafting a comprehensive package of regulations governing applications by local banks to open a representative office on the mainland. The package will be referred to the Cabinet for approval soon, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCERS PUT TAIWAN IN WORLD SPOTLIGHT (I)

TEXT.P: With superb technique and worldwide fame, the Cloud Gate Dance Theater Company has successfully avoided political opposition from mainland China to perform at the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney, putting Taiwan in the spotlight in Australia and many other countries as well.

In an interview with CNA, Cloud Gate representative Jon-Claire Lee said that the organizers decided last year to invite the Taiwan-based dance troupe to perform at the arts festival, an important preliminary event of the 2000 Olympic Games. He stressed that the company was the only Asian dance troupe to perform there.

But before the official announcement last October, the organizers had feared the possible repercussions from mainland China, which might have objected to the international publicity that the performance would generate for Taiwan, and because of Australia's strict one-China policy.

Seeking to ease the situation, the organizers had sent a letter to the Chinese Embassy in Canberra, telling mainland officials that Cloud Gate would be invited to perform. Lee said that to their delight, the answer from mainland China was positive -- they did not oppose the invitation.

"With the tacit understanding of Beijing, the organizers went ahead with their official launch of the dancing performance and made an official announcement that Cloud Gate will perform at the arts festival," Lee said.

"I was thrilled with the successful results, though it took me about two years and a half to arrange and negotiate for the Cloud Gate Theater to be part of the Olympic Arts Festival, which I regard as a very significant occasion due to its magnitude and massive publicity to be given not only to the company, but also to the Republic of China, as well," Lee said.
Craig Hassell, general manager of the arts festival, told CNA that the organizers had informed the Chinese embassy as a gesture of "courtesy."

In a speech on Saturday, opening night of the Cloud Gate performance, Hassell expressed his thanks to the ROC government for making the Cloud Gate performances possible by providing US$400,000 in funding so that the troupe could stage their show in Sydney during the arts festival.
He praised the superb performance of Cloud Gate on opening night, citing the company as one of the best contemporary dance troupes in the world.
"Organizing the arts festival is not an easy task because we have to match the scale of the 2000 Olympic Games, which is the world's biggest sports event," he said.
He and other organizers said they were very satisfied with their choice of the Cloud Gate Theater as part of the Olympic Arts Festival.

Founded in 1973 by Lin Hwai-min, then a student of world-renowned Martha Graham, the Cloud Gate troupe has given at least 2,000 performances in five continents over about 27 years. More than one third of the performances have been given in Taiwan.

Lin said he was proud that the troupe has toured extensively in Europe, North America, Asia and Australia, dancing from one stage to another and performing on such occasions as the 25th anniversary of Pina Bausch's Tanztheater Wuppertal and the Adelaide Festival, and at venues including Sadler's Wells Theater and the Kennedy Center. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCERS PUT TAIWAN IN WORLD SPOTLIGHT (II)

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate is acclaimed as "Asia's leading contemporary dance theater and one of the finest dance companies in the world."
"It's the first time for us to perform at the Olympic Arts Festival and we are excited to have such an opportunity to present our best performance in such an auspicious occasion," Lin said.

"We have won lots of friendship, respect and admiration in many countries, thanks to our unswerving efforts to present our best to them. Above all, our extensive tours to many countries have put Taiwan on the global map," he said.

To the Republic of China, it is well beyond reach from diplomatic front because Taiwan is always being strangled and isolated, thanks to constant threat and pressure from mainland China, political analysts said.

Professor Hsu Chia-shih, chairman of the Cloud Gate, said Lin and his troupe have provided foreigners in many countries another perspective on the image of Taiwan, which has been notoriously known as an island of disaster and fist-fighting.

"Our parliament is known for fist-fighting and name-calling because our MPs like to quarrel. That often leads to fist-fighting in the parliamentary floor to force their case. Last September, Taiwan was for the first time in one century as a place of disaster just because of the onslaught of 7.8 degree earthquake," Hsu said.
The quake killed about 2,400 people and made tens of thousands of people homeless in central Taiwan, making the island instantly famous worldwide from such a natural calamity, he noted.
"But the superb Cloud Gate performances give Taiwan a very good image internationally," Hsu said.
Two key dangers agreed with Hsu's remarks. They are Wu I-fang, who portrays a god, and Lee Ching-chun, who portrays a witch in "Nine Songs."

"I feel thrilled and hilarious every time I and my colleagues perform no matter in Taiwan or abroad. The feedback is spontaneous from our audience. Especially, the support given to us from overseas Chinese in many countries, they just want to see our performances no matter how far they are away from the venues we performed," Wu said.

"I try our very best to perform so that people enjoy our performances. But at the same time, we have one burden to carry wherever we go -- that 's to make Taiwan known to many people in the world," Lee Ching-chun said.
Both Wu and Lee said they were especially delighted to perform at the Olympic Arts Festival, because it's part of the major cultural event going along with the 2000 Olympic Games.

"Being able to perform at the festival is our best opportunity to present not only our dancing technique, but also win more friends from Australia and many other countries to be represented at the same occasion," Wu said.
More than 10,000 athletes from over 100 countries will compete in the Olympic Games from mid-September.
Jon-Claire Lee and Hsu Chia-shih said the Cloud Gate performances will generate more admiration and respect for the ROC on Taiwan.
"This is a precious thing we value much more than others," Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEGISLATORS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A legislative delegation of opposition People First Party (PFP) members will visit mainland China in late August, the PFP said on Tuesday at a caucus meeting in the Legislative Yuan.
PFP legislative whip Chen Chen-sheng, PFP legislators Liu Sung-fan, Chiu Chuang-liang and Chin Hui-chu announced the delegation's itinerary at the meeting.
According to the itinerary, the delegation, which will be led by Liu, will leave on Aug. 28 for Beijing and will travel on to Shanghai on Aug. 31.
They will wind up their visit in Shanghai on Sept. 1 and Liu will return to Taipei while the rest of the delegation will proceed to Canton, returning to Taipei on Sept. 3.
Chin said the party will hold a press conference on Aug. 26 to explain the purpose of the visit.

He added that PFP Chairman James Soong will meet with the delegation before its departure to exchange views on cross-Taiwan Strait issues and map out the PFP's policy toward mainland China in order to ensure that the delegation toes the party line when dealing with its hosts.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE-LANGUAGE WEEKLY PUBLISHED FOR FOREIGN WORKERS IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: A Taichung publishing company has recently begun printing a five-language weekly for foreign workers in the Taichung area.

The number of foreign workers in Taiwan is estimated at 300,000, and the weekly is believed to be the first Taiwan publication with stories in five languages -- Chinese, English, Vietnamese, Thai and Indonesian.
The weekly carries news about Taiwan and the workers' home countries, as well as providing information on regulations and activities relating to foreign workers.
The first issue of the weekly was published in mid-July, with some 200 free copies distributed to firms that employ foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR 'TAIWAN EXTRAORDINARY GOV'T' FORMED

TEXT.P: A preparatory committee for establishment of "an Extraordinary Government of Taiwan" was formally established on Tuesday, a spokesman for the organizing committee said.

Shen Chien-teh, the general convener for the organizing committee, said that the committee will also set a deadline of Aug. 28 for the government to show the original copy of the joint declaration of the Cairo Conference, the legal basis that the government of the Republic of China has used for being stationed in Taiwan.

Shen said that the committee again sent a certified letter to President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Tang Fei to appeal for the government to show the original copy of the joint declaration of the Cairo Conference issued on Dec. 3, 1943.

The letter pointed out that the committee had already sent a registered letter to President Chen and Premier Tang on Aug. 14, asking the government to show the original copy of the joint declaration of the Cairo Conference.

The original request's deadline of Aug. 21 passed without any information received from government authorities, he said, adding that the preparatory committee for a Taiwan Extraordinary Government was therefore formally established.
The Extraordinary Government of Taiwan will be formally set up if the authorities fail to show the original copy of the joint declaration of the Cairo Conference by Aug. 28, Shen said.
The preparatory committee's meeting place is located at an office of the Taiwan Independence Party in Kaohsiung City.
The committee is comprised of members of the Taiwan Independence Party, the Confederation for Taiwan Independence, the Taiwan Independence Association and the Presbyterian Church.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO TALK ABOUT OVERHAULING UNIFICATION GUIDELINES: PFP

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong said on Tuesday that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification (GNU), as the government has yet to show consistency over cross-Taiwan Strait policies.

Reacting to remarks by Acting Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan, who said on Monday that the GNU should be overhauled to meet actual needs as the environments in both Taiwan and mainland China have changed, Soong said Chen's idea is tantamount to an action trying to alter pivotal national policies.

Soong said Chen's uttering of the remarks on behalf of the government, before a President Chen Shui-bian-proposed roundtable meeting of major political party leaders has been held to canvass opinions from the opposition politicians on important national issues, is tantamount to making a declaration before a decision has been made.

Soong, who organized his own political party after losing the March 18 presidential election to Chen Shui-bian by a narrow margin, applauded the creation of the roundtable meeting, saying it will have a positive influence on solving differences among parties on major national issues.
He suggested to Chen that the new government try to work out concerted cross-strait policies which are consistent and have continuity in order to regain the people's confidence in the government.
He also criticized Chen's current overseas visit as "badly and hastily timed."

Soong asked scathingly that if the 13-day, six-state trip was as well prepared as the new government has claimed, how come Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao was not accompanying the president throughout the entire trip? He said Tien, who left Chen to participate in a meeting somewhere else, should return to Chen's side immediately before the trip wraps up on Saturday.

Meanwhile, Soong, who was the first and last popularly elected Taiwan provincial governor, welcomed the government's recent actions to renew the investigation into the highly publicized murder of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng some six years ago.
Soong said the government should give the investigators a free hand to get to the bottom of the case even at the cost of the reputations of some "high level" people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GIO CHIEF CLARIFIES `MONEY DIPLOMACY' CRITICISM ON BBC
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China government spokeswoman Chung Chin has denied in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) that the ROC has resorted to "money diplomacy" to promote its external relations.

Chung, also director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), is currently accompanying ROC President Chen Shui-bian on a six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at bolstering Taiwan's diplomatic ties with its allies in the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa. She gave the interview with the BBC on Sunday.
In the interview, Chung said developing mutually beneficial cooperative ties is the primary direction for the new ROC government's diplomatic work.
Chung said the international community used to have "misunderstandings" about the ROC government's economic aid to its diplomatic allies.

In fact, Chung said, the previous Kuomintang government accomplished many outstanding diplomatic achievements and that financial aid was only a part of its diplomatic work. Moreover, she went on, the ROC's economic aid to its allies has also formed an integral part of "the global foreign aid project."
Chung pointed out that the ROC's current Democratic Progressive Party-led government gives priority to promoting substantive cooperation with its allies.
"The ROC looks forward to strengthening cooperation with its allies in economic, trade, cultural, political, democratic system development and other related fields," Chung noted.

During his current visit, Chung said, Chen has assured leaders of the ROC's allies that his administration will faithfully fulfill its obligations under existing bilateral agreements signed by the previous administration on lending, financing or direct economic aid, based on the principle of government continuity.

Chung said the ROC's diplomatic allies have benefited greatly from those cooperative projects over the years. For instance, ROC medical, agricultural and fishery missions have helped cultivate a generation of young professionals in the host countries and have helped promote their overall economic growth.

Asked how Chen's administration will cope with mainland China's perennial diplomatic embargo against the ROC, Chung said Beijing's opposition to the scenario that a country simultaneously maintains diplomatic ties with both sides of the Taiwan Strait has indeed seriously restricted the ROC's quest for greater "international space" or higher international profile.
Nevertheless, she said, the ROC will continue forging cooperative ties with as many countries as possible on an equal, reciprocal basis.

Chung further said she sees no contradiction in the ROC's quest for better cross-Taiwan Strait relations and greater diplomatic frontiers. "We will continue pushing for normalization of cross-strait trade, economic and political relations and expanding bilateral and multilateral international ties," she stressed, adding that diplomacy is pivotal work for any sovereign state.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS ON GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By S.F. Huang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou called on Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo on Monday to exchange views on cultural and artistic exchanges between the two countries.
Ma also called on various Guatemalan government officials, including Vice President Francisco Reyes Lopez and Minister of Culture Otilia Lux de Coti.
Ma arrived in Guatemala City on Monday for a two-day visit to that Central American country, accompanied by a nine-member entourage.
Ma lauded Portillo for his efforts to preserve his country's aboriginal culture.
Later in the day, he called on his Guatemala City counterpart Fritz Garcia and signed an aboriginal culture interchange memorandum with Garcia.

Under the terms of the memorandum, the two sides vow to exchange visits of artists, to offer scholarships for aboriginal students and to step up cultural and art interchanges between Taipei City and Guatemala City.
Garcia also presented the keys to the city to Ma and a "certificate of outstanding citizenship."
The visit was part of Ma's visit to Panama City, Tegucigalpa and Guatemala City, which maintain sisterhood ties with Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE ROC PRESIDENT'S SON TO ACKNOWLEDGE ANCESTORS

TEXT.P: John Chang, an illegitimate son of late Republic of China President Chiang Ching-kuo and a former high-ranking ROC official, will visit his father's ancestral home on Wednesday to acknowledge his relationship with the Chiang family.

Chang, who was secretary-general to the president under Chiang's successor -- former President Lee Teng-hui -- said that acknowledging his blood ties was Chiang's dying wish as well as the will of the three Chiang clan elders who wrote to him three years ago, urging him to return.
Chang is scheduled on Thursday to make an offering to the ancestors of the Chiang clan at the clan shrine in Xikou Township, Fenghua County, Zejiang Province, in mainland China.

The late president never acknowledged Chang and Chang's late brother Chang Hsiao-tzu as his sons and refrained from seeing them except at open banquets. Even then, they had to keep their distance, Chang said. It was not until a few years before Chiang's death that Chang began to bring his father little gifts like ties and shavers, always delivered through someone else, Chang added.

He said that he began to make preparations for a trip to mainland China after stepping down from office in March, and added that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council has approved his travel plan on humanitarian grounds.
In addition to his wife and children, Chang's late brother's widow and children will join him on the trip.

Fang Chih-yi, the widow of Chiang Hsiao-yung, one of Chiang Ching-kuo's three legitimate sons, recently said that if Chang is to return to the Chiang family, he should first consult Madame Chiang Kai-shek -- his grandmother -- who lives in New York, and Chiang Ching-kuo's wife, who still lives in Taiwan.

However, Chang said that he had requested to see Madame Chiang four times, but nothing ever came of his requests. In the end, he decided against trying to see them again, and asked for Fang's understanding.
After paying his respects at the Chiang ancestral shrines, Chang said, he will be officially "back in the Chiang family."
He will then travel to Ningpo and lunch with mainland-based Taiwan businessmen on Friday. The next day, he is scheduled to proceed to Shanghai, where he will lunch with Taiwan businessmen there.

The mainland office in charge of Taiwan affairs in Shanghai will honor him at a dinner party on Saturday, and he will visit the Shanghai home of the Kuomintang's founding father, Dr. Sun Yet-sen, on Sunday.
Chang and his family will then proceed to Quilin, Kuangxi, where he will offer incense at the tomb of his mother, Chang Ya-juo, on Aug. 29.
He is expected to return to Taiwan on Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PROMISES TO RETURN ANY ILLEGALLY ACQUIRED ASSETS

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang, Taiwan's ruling party until May 20, said on Tuesday that it will return any illegally acquired assets to the Republic of China's national coffers.

Chang Tse-chen, director of the KMT's financial department, said the party has completed an initial check of its assets. According to Chang, the KMT's total assets are estimated at slightly more than NT$79.9 billion (US$2.58 billion).
Chang said the party assets include 14 houses and 100 land parcels which were given to the KMT with the approval of township councils during the party's 55-year rule.
He said that although the presentation procedures fully complied with existing laws and regulations, doubts have been cast as to the justification for the gifts.

"We will conduct a further study of the procedures regarding the acquisition of each land lot and will then make a public explanation after finalizing the study," Chang said, adding that if any of the party assets in question are found to have been illegally acquired, the KMT will not hesitate to return them to the government coffers.
Chang said that all of the 114 properties in question were given to the KMT between 1967 and 1981 when the government had not yet enacted a local-level self-government law.
According to an initial check carried out by the party, the KMT owned 688 buildings and 927 pieces of land around the island, worth a total of NT$8.83 billion.
Although the KMT lost the March 18 presidential election, it still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan and is reputed to be the world's wealthiest political party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BUSINESS EXECUTIVES MEET MAINLAND VICE PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen said on Tuesday that from now on mainland law enforcement agencies will be required to inform the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council immediately after they arrest a Taiwan businessman.
Qian made the statement while meeting with a delegation from the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA), headed by Richard Wu, also the association's president.

Qian was quoted as having assured the TEEMA group that mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office will offer necessary assistance to any detained Taiwan businessman and tries to understand the truth concerning the incident.
Qian, however, reportedly didn't respond to the TEEMA's proposal that Beijing set up an ad hoc tribunal to settle trade disputes involving Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.

Wu told a group of Taiwan journalists on Monday that Beijing authorities have agreed to establish a "business court for Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau," to adjudicate disputes between businessmen from the three areas and their mainland Chinese trade partners.
Although the proposed court will also hear disputes involving businessmen from Hong Kong and Macau, Taiwan businessmen will be its major users in light of their larger number, said Wu.

Taiwan businessmen often complain that they cannot get fair treatment at ordinary courts in mainland China because of the rampant regionalism and protectionism. In order to address the problem, the TEEMA has lobbied Beijing for years to set up a special tribunal to hear such cases, said Wu.
As Qian kept mum on the "tribunal" proposal, it became unclear whether Beijing would set up a special business court for Taiwan business people.

During Tuesday's meeting, the TEEMA group also exchanged views with Qian on the opening of direct "three links" -- trade, mail and transportation -- across the Taiwan Strait, physical safety of Taiwan business people on the mainland and the opening of the mainland door for Taiwan banks to set up footholds on the mainland.

According to Wu, Qian stressed that mainland China hopes the opening of direct cross-strait three links should be simplified. Qian was also quoted as having blamed Taiwan for hindering an early opening of direct "three links."

As for Taiwan's plan to allow its banks to set up representative offices on the mainland, Qian said mainland China welcomes such an opening plan. Qian reportedly said mainland China would lower its requirements for Taiwan banks to open branches on the mainland and that it hopes Taiwan banks can be allowed to make a "landing" on he mainland before Beijing is admitted to the World Trade Organization.
Taiwan is planning to allow its banks to make inroads into the mainland market in a gradual, phased manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 80,000 MAINLAND CHINESE PEOPLE REGULARLY STAY IN TAIWAN: NSB

TEXT.P: About 80,000 mainland Chinese people are in Taiwan at any given moment, a situation that challenges the Republic of China's security fabric, sources from the National Security Bureau (NSB) said on Tuesday.
After attending an inter-section meeting at the NSB headquarters on national security, Premier Tang Fei stressed that there is a critical need for a new, more efficient national security system.

According to Ting Yu-chou, director of the NSB, which is the top government agency in charge of information and intelligence gathering and assessment, cross-Taiwan Strait relations have remained static for the last three months.
Nevertheless, he added, Beijing has "hastened the speed of drawing in the net that it has cast toward Taiwan," using every possible means and scheme to suppress Taiwan in the international community.

Ting seconded Tang's statement that the creation of a comprehensive national security mechanism is urgently needed in light of increasing cross-strait exchanges and the increasing number of mainland people who visit Taiwan.
He added that about 30,000 mainland people are currently living in Taiwan as residents, while 50,000 others make short term visits as invited visitors or relatives of Taiwan citizens.

Meanwhile, he said, the number of mainland stowaways or illegal immigrants from mainland China has been significantly reduced recently since the establishment of the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS PROBE POST-QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION SCANDAL IN NANTOU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Nantou prosecutors on Tuesday were continuing an investigation into a post-earthquake reconstruction scandal involving Chungliao Township Chief Wu Chao-feng.
Prosecutors and other law-enforcement authorities had searched Wu's villa on Monday and discovered two truckloads of relief materials donated for victims of last September's devastating earthquake.

Wu, 57, was suspected of embezzling the relief materials, including 17 television sets, five water heaters, 12 gas stoves and 40 blankets, which were donated by the Red Cross Society, World Vision, the Taipei City Government and former Taiwan Governor James Soong.

When the prosecutors tried to summon Wu for questioning, he started a four-day period of sick leave from Tuesday until Friday. The prosecutors have already asked the immigration authorities to prohibit Wu from leaving the country.

Before Monday's large-scale raid on Wu's villa, the prosecutors had been tipped off that Wu was suspected of having received illegal commissions from contractors carrying out post-quake reconstruction projects in his township.
However, the discovery of the relief materials took the investigators by surprise.

Several officials with the Chungliao Township Office have been investigated in connection with the scandal and the acting chief of the construction section, Pai Hua-po, has been detained for further investigation.
The prosecutors said that they might detain Wu if he fails to turn up for questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1 DEAD, 1 MISSING AS TYPHOON BILIS NEARS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: One person was killed and another listed as missing as strong typhoon Bilis approached Taiwan on Tuesday, according to an official at the central typhoon coordination center.

The dead man was identified as Lin Tsai-mao, 27, who was killed when a retaining wall collapsed at a construction site in Pali, Taipei County, said Interior Vice Minister Chien Tai-lang, who is deputy chief of the coordination center.

Chien also said that Chen Yi-chieh, a doctor at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, had lost contact with his climbing companions while scaling a mountain in Hualien, eastern Taiwan. A search for Chen was still under way, he added.

Strong winds knocked out electricity supplies for some 30,000 households in eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung counties and the Taiwan Power Company sent workers to make emergency repairs in the area.

Bilis, which was moving steadily in a west-northwesterly direction at a speed of 22 kilometers per hour, was reported to be centered east of Taitung as of 9 p.m. on Tuesday, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN TO ATTEND MEETING IN US

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung left Taipei for Los Angeles on Tuesday to attend an annual meeting for Taipei officials stationed in the United States.

The meeting will be chaired by Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao who is also in Los Angeles and participants will include Republic of China Representative to Washington Chen Chien-jen, a former foreign minister, as well as the chiefs of ROC representative offices in other major American cities.
The MAC official is expected to report on the new government's policy on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
In the past, meetings of this kind were presided over by a vice foreign minister, but this year, the US government agreed to let the American-educated foreign minister chair the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLIND ROC CLIMBERS ATTEMPTING SUMMIT OF JAPAN'S MOUNT FUJI
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of blind climbers from the Republic of China and Japan climbing Mount Fuji are expected to reach the summit of the mountain by sunrise on Wednesday.

The 61-member Taiwan team, eight of whom are blind, arrived in Tokyo Monday to take part in the climb that was sponsored by the Japan Blind Federation, accompanied by a 48-strong group of Japanese climbers, 20 of whom are blind.

The two teams met at the foot of the 3,776-meter Mount Fuji at 1 p.m. and by 7 p.m., the Taiwan team had reached the 3,200-meter point where they planned to spend the night before summiting the following morning at around 6 a.m. The Japanese team was expected to make the top a little later.
Led by Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung (KMT-Taichung County), the Taiwan team will spend another two days sightseeing before returning to Taipei on Aug. 26.
Blind climbers from Taiwan, South Korea and Japan successfully climbed Taiwan's Jade Mountain last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VISITS ROC MODEL FARM IN BURKINA FASO
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday visited a model farm founded with assistance from an ROC agricultural mission and attended a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a cooperative agricultural project.

Chen arrived in the Burkina Faso capital of Ouagadougou from neighboring Gambia on Monday at the head of an entourage of government officials, businessmen, and journalists for a three-day visit to the West African ROC ally.

Villagers dancing to traditional music welcomed Chen to the model farm and presented him with two goats, two chickens and a broad-brimmed rain hat, which Chen -- the son of a farmer -- promptly donned. He then grabbed the two chickens and posed with the farmers for photographs.

Accompanied by Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore, who has visited Taiwan three times, Chen planted a tree at the village to signify the never-ending cooperation between Burkina Faso and the ROC. They then moved on to an agricultural development zone to inspect the results of the ROC's past rice-cultivation missions.

Chen said at a ribbon-cutting ceremony there that he will continue to promote the second term of a five-year agricultural technology cooperative project and assist in Burkina Faso's agricultural development.

The project will begin in 2001 and will bring a further 6,000 hectares of land under rice cultivation, to bring Burkina Faso's annual rice production up to 24,000 metric tons within five years, he added.

Under the project, Taiwan will also assist in the development of Burkina Faso's water conservancy facilities, agricultural technology, production, marketing, and farmer's organizations so that the newly developed farms can continue to run by themselves.
Taiwan's agricultural missions began assisting Burkina Faso in 1994 and has already completed the development of 1,000 hectares of rice paddies.

On Wednesday, Chen is scheduled to inspect a bilateral cooperative program aimed at upgrading the status of women in Burkina Faso and deliver a speech to the Burkina Faso parliament. He will also sign a joint communique and give a joint press conference with Compaore before his departure for Chad to continue his six-state "journey of friendship" to cement the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies.

Chen had visited the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, and the Gambia before coming to Burkina Faso. This is Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER MEETS POLICE CHIEF OVER JAIL BREAKOUT

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan met with National Police Administration (NPA) Director-General Wang Chin-wang on Wednesday to seek police help for nabbing four prisoners who escaped from a jail in the eastern county of Taitung at midnight.
During their brief meeting, Chen asked Wang to mobilize police forces in Taitung County to work together with the prosecution and investigation authorities to bring to justice the four escapees.

The four prisoners, identified as Chen Yung-chung, Chiu Chin-lien, Mao Tsai-pao and Chen Chun-nan, cashed in on the chaos caused by typhoon Bilis to break out of their cells in the Taiyuan Prison in the county's Tungho village.
The Taiyuan Prison provides vocational skill training for its inmates. Prisoners at other jails can apply to serve prison terms at Taiyuan if they have good behavior records.
Chen said the Ministry of Justice has not yet received a detailed report about the breakout incident. The minister said he plans to travel to Taitung to inspect the jail in the near future.
Chen said the Taitung district prosecutor's office is investigating whether any Taiyuan jail administrators should be held responsible for the incident.

Taiyuan administrators said the four escapees, all convicted of serious crimes, escaped from their cells by destroying a wall. But many details, including the mastermind of the escape, remain unknown.

Typhoon Bilis, the strongest to hit Asia this year, left a trail of destruction in its wake, killing at least two people. Taitung bore the brunt of the typhoon's torrential rains and ferocious winds when it battered the island at around 10:30 p.m. on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONTACTS MILITARY CHIEF OVER TYPHOON DAMAGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian telephoned Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming on Wednesday expressing his concern about military assistance in relief work after a strong typhoon hit Taiwan overnight.
Military spokesman Kung Fan-ding said the president's phone call from the West African country of Burkina Faso reached Tang's office at 8:50 a.m.
President Chen was quoted as having ordered all military units to do their utmost to assist local-level governments in post-typhoon relief and rehabilitation work.
According to Kung, Tang had briefed Chen on the military's participation in emergency rescue and relief operations since Tuesday.
Before typhoon Bilis battered the island, the military already formed a special task force aimed at helping minimizing possible typhoon damage.

"Tang has told President Chen that all military servicemen have suspended vacation leave and are awaiting distress calls in the barracks," Kung said, adding that so long as any local government agencies apply for assistance, military units stationed in the area tend to actively join in rescue and rehabilitation missions.
As of 11 a.m. Wednesday, Kung said, the military had dispatched 63 servicemen, one ship and seven vehicles to assist in relief work.
Thanks to well-organized precautionary measures, initial tallies show that typhoon casualties were not very serious.

President Chen is currently on a six-state "journey" of friendship aimed at bolstering the Republic of China's relations with its allies. He is scheduled to wrap up his visit to Burkina Faso, the fifth leg of his trip, and travel to Chad on Wednesday.

Chen had visited the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, and the Gambia before coming to Burkina Faso. This is Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CLOUD GATE DANCE TROUPE SCORES SUCCESS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The first set of four performances by Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theater at the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney from Aug. 19 to 22 was a success, said organizers Wednesday.

They told the CNA that "Nine Songs" -- a production by choreographer and Cloud Gate founder Lin Hwai-min -- filled about 80 percent of the 1,500-seat Her Majestic Theater for each of the performances.
The organizers described the performances by the dance troupe as "impressive and successful."
Cloud Gate will stage its second production, "Moonwater" -- also by Lin -- from Aug. 25 to 27 at the same venue, according to the organizers.
Jon-Claire Lee, Cloud Gate's representative in Australia, said he expects that "Moonwater" will attract even larger audiences, thanks to the successful staging of "Nine Songs."

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY'S WATER SUPPLY STILL FACING PROBLEMS AS OLYMPICS APPROACH

TEXT.P: As the Olympics draw near, Sydney is still facing problems concerning the quality of its drinking water two years after facing a water crisis.
According to a recent independent audit by Australia's License Regulator, Sydney Water has failed to fully meet almost a fifth of the conditions in its operating license.
Sydney experienced a water crisis more than two years ago, but the auditors found that several problems related to the crisis still remained unresolved, according to the report.

The auditors said they believe the problems related to the water crisis will not be fully solved in time for the Olympic Games when more than a hundred thousand athletes, journalists, officials, and spectators flood into Sydney for the sporting event.
They have recommended that visitors to Sydney and residents alike boil all tap water before drinking it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CLOSES LOWER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index edging down 19.21 points to close at 8,098.84.
Market turnover totaled NT$80.93 billion (US$2.61 billion) in moderate trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PRUDENTLY CONSIDER MAINLAND'S BRANCH OFFICE OFFER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will prudently consider mainland China's reported offer of allowing Taiwan banks to directly open branches on the mainland without going through the regular three-year waiting period, said Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen on Thursday.

Describing mainland China's reported offer to allow Taiwan banks to bypass the process of first having to establish a liaison or representative office for three years as a goodwill gesture, Chen said Taiwan will exercise care and thought in considering it.

Sources from the mainland quoted Li Ruoku, assistant to the president of the People's Bank of China, as having said recently that before mainland China is formally admitted into the World Trade Organization, the mainland financial authorities will consider skipping the three-year requirement as long as Taiwan banks file applications.
The ROC's Chairman of the Bureau of Monetary Affairs, Wang Yao-hsing, said he does not think Li's remarks, even if officially confirmed, are true. "It's impossible, at least not for now," he said.

Earlier this week, Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials held a meeting to discuss matters pertaining to liberalizing regulations to allow for the gradual opening of branches of Taiwan banks on the mainland.

After assessing the issues of risk management, financial monitoring and regulations, as well as related legal issues, the MOF may allow local banks to branch out to the mainland in the near future, beginning with the establishment of representative offices, said the MOF.

Yen Ching-chang, another vice finance minister, said Tuesday that the ROC will consider the feasibility of allowing mainland Chinese banks to set up representative or liaison offices in Taiwan and also the gradual establishment of local bank branches on the mainland in line with the principles of fairness and parity.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK ELITES BIGGEST THREAT TO TERRITORY'S DEMOCRACY: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's political elites are the principal threat to autonomy and democracy in the PRC special administrative region under their jurisdiction, said an American expert on Asian affairs.

Eric Bjornlund, senior associate at the Washington-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, wrote in this summer's issue of Hong Kong Update that until popular and international pressure force those elites to respect the pledges already made to Hong Kong as a whole, "the promise of full democracy in Hong Kong will remain unfulfilled."

Since its reversion to Communist Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997, "Hong Kong's commitment to democracy and fundamental rights has remained suspect," he wrote in the quarterly published by the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

While the Beijing regime has largely refrained from interfering with Hong Kong's autonomy and way of life, Hong Kong authorities and elites have themselves manipulated democratic institutions and undermined the autonomy of the judiciary, pointed out Bjornlund, who is also the Asia director of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs.

For example, he said, the Hong Kong government has changed the system of electing representatives to the Legislative Council, added appointed members to district councils, dissolved elected municipal councils, and invited Beijing's reversal of Hong Kong court decisions.

Most troubling, Bjornlund noted, while the Hong Kong Basic Law established a 10-year transition toward democracy, Hong Kong officials have specifically refused to commit to full democracy at the end of that period.

Chief Executive C.H. Tung and other Hong Kong government officials have argued against amending the Basic Law to accelerate the transition to full democracy. But more ominously, notwithstanding the Basic Law's goal of universal suffrage, Tung has refused to accept that fully democratic elections should be held at the end of the 10-year transition period.

Hong Kong's autonomy is also a fundamental part of its democracy. noted Bjornlund, adding that the negotiated compromises that led to Hong Kong's reversion promised the territory autonomy as a kind of protection for the freedoms that its citizens enjoyed.

This autonomy was to include a judiciary independent not only of executive or legislative interference, but also of interference from Beijing. "But the constitutional arrangements cannot provide democracy if the Hong Kong government itself invites such interference," he emphasized.
"In short, the main impediment to autonomy and democratization in Hong Kong has been the authorities and elites in the territory itself," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD NOT CURTAIL FREEDOM IN HONG KONG: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Beijing should realize that curtailing Hong Kong's rights and freedoms in order to punish advocates of Taiwan independence is unlikely to make the concept of `one country, two systems' attractive to Taiwan, commented Frank Ching, senior editor of the Far Eastern Economic Review, in this summer's issue of Hong Kong Update.

Ching wrote in the quarterly published by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies that up to April this year, reports by the British Foreign Office, the US Department of State, and the European Union have all been generous in their praise of Communist China for demonstrating restraint in its handling of Hong Kong, adding that things have been going so well that the world is no longer focusing much attention on Hong Kong.

"But there are disturbing signs that, just as the world is letting down its guard, the situation in Hong Kong may be deteriorating. Chinese officials are demonstrating a tendency to put the mainland's political interests ahead of those of the Special Administrative Region (SAR), and two recent incidents illustrate this emerging tendency," said the former Wall Street Journal correspondent in Beijing.

The first incident of Communist Chinese interference occurred in April when Wang Fengchao, a deputy director of Beijing's Liaison Office in Hong Kong, told the local media that it could not treat news about Taiwan as just ordinary news, saying it had to be handled with a special sensitivity.

Wang's comments were apparently the Beijing government's response to Hong Kong media actions, and not his personal views, pointed out Ching. The day after Wang's remarks, the Communist press in Hong Kong and the spokesmen for the PRC Foreign Ministry as well as the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council echoed his position.

He said Wang's remarks are very troubling because they go beyond what any Communist Chinese official has previously said concerning freedom of the press in Hong Kong. But Wang had also made it clear in his comments that Beijing expects the situation to be resolved when the Hong Kong SAR introduces legislation to implement Article 23 of the Basic Law, making it a crime for anyone to advocate Taiwan independence.

"If such legislation does pass, however, the SAR government will certainly lose much credibility in the public's eyes, and Hong Kong's relations with the central government will be badly strained," wrote Ching.

The second incident Ching pointed to occurred in May when He Zhiming, another official of the Liaison Office, issued a not-so-veiled warning to Hong Kong businessmen not to trade with Taiwan businessmen who advocate independence.

It appears his remarks were not a reflection of pressure from Beijing due to the fact that Mr. He was not supported by the Communist press or by spokesmen for the Beijing regime, "but it is evident that his words represent the unspoken views of central government officials who wish to see advocates of Taiwan independence punished," wrote Ching.

He stressed it is significant that both incidents of interference relate to the issue of Taiwan. The policy of "one country, two systems" was adopted with Taiwan in mind and applied to Hong Kong with a vision to making the SAR a model for Taiwan.

But Beijing should realize that curtailing Hong Kong's rights and freedoms in order to punish pro-independence advocates is unlikely to make the concept of "one country, two systems" attractive to Taiwan, noted Ching.

These recent incidents show that while Beijing exercised self-restraint in the early years of the Hong Kong SAR, "now is not the time to be satisfied, or believe that all is well with Hong Kong. The monitoring of Hong Kong affairs by the US and other governments should continue, especially since China has shown a tendency in recent months to flex its muscles in Hong Kong with little regard for its promises of noninterference," concluded Ching.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEBRIS FROM CHINESE ROCKET EXPLOSION DETECTED

TEXT.P: The University of Chicago's space dust instrument (SPADUS) has detected a cloud of tiny debris particles that was scattered into space when the upper stage of a Chinese Long March 4 rocket unexpectedly exploded March 11 after five months in orbit.

The US Space Command detected the explosion immediately, but the Chicago finding marked the first time that scientists have been able to link ultra-small particles to the break-up of a particular satellite, said Nicholas Johnson, chief scientist for orbital debris at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, Wednesday.

The largest of the particles are barely large enough to be seen with the naked eye. The particles, although tiny, race around the earth at a speed 19 times faster than a speeding bullet, fast enough to scratch a space shuttle window on impact or cause potential problems during a space walk.
"For example, if we think there's a chance of the space station going through one of these very small particle clouds, we may decide to postpone a space walk," Johnson added.
The smaller particles also pose a minor but continuous threat to orbiting satellites, said Anthony Tuzzolino, the University of Chicago scientist who heads the SPADUS project.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TANG INSPECTS TYPHOON-HIT EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei made an inspection tour of the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien Thursday to signify his concern about damage caused by a devastating typhoon which ripped through the island Wednesday.

Premier Tang first inspected a pomelo orchard in Hualien's Juisui township. Tang assured the owner of the orchard that the government will offer NT$30,000 (US$967.74) in subsidy for each hectare of land for damage to the fruit grown in the orchard in accordance with current regulations.
Tang also ordered relevant agricultural administration agencies to help promote sales of mature fruits swept down by the storm.

Later on, Tang inspected a run-down breakwater in neighboring township of Yuli. The breakwater, built during the Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan, needs renovation. Tang directed relevant government agencies to take immediate steps to repair and reinforce the breakwater to protect the Yuli coast from the force of ocean waves.
Tang also toured another typhoon-hit Hualien township of Fuli to see for himself the typhoon damage to the area.
After the inspection tour, Tang declared Hualien as a disaster zone which will receive priority central government assistance in rehabilitation work.
Tang also directed that power supply to the three hardest-hit Hualien townships -- Juisui, Yuli and Fuli -- should be fully resumed by Friday noon.

Tang further said the government will subsidize Hualien county farmers who saw their farms flooded in the wake of the storm. The government will offer NT$100,000 in subsidy for each hectare of affected farmland, he said.

Meanwhile, Tang said he will direct the Cabinet to study the feasibility of offering financial subsidy to the people whose houses were partially or fully destroyed by the typhoon. In the past, the government didn't offer subsidies for this kind of typhoon victims.
Tang was accompanied by several central and local government officials, including Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, on the inspection tour.
Tang and his entourage visited neighboring Taitung County in the afternoon. Taitung County bore the brunt of the storm.

Typhoon Bilis, the strongest to hit Asia so far this year, swept over Taiwan from Tuesday evening through Wednesday, leaving at least 11 people dead, five missing and 108 others injured. According to initial tallies, the storm also left 309 houses completely destroyed and 1,499 houses partially collapsed.
The storm has also prompted President Chen Shui-bian to cut short his current six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at bolstering the Republic of China's diplomatic relations with its allies.

Acting Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan said President Chen is scheduled to return to Taiwan at 3:00 p.m. Friday. The president will directly take a flight from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to the central county of Nantou where eight people were buried alive by mudslides caused by typhoon Bilis.
Chen Che-nan said President Chen is also scheduled to make an inspection tour of the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung on Saturday.

President Chen, who is currently in the African state of Chad, was originally scheduled to return from his first post-inauguration overseas visit on Saturday. He decided to return ahead of the schedule after the typhoon, the most powerful to hit the island in 40 years, wreaked havoc in Taiwan.
