DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX CLOSES SLIGHTLY LOWER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock prices closed 0.2 percent lower Thursday due mainly to a weakening of large-cap blue chips in the traditional industry sector.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index, the market's key barometer, lost 19.21 points to close at 8,098.84, on turnover of NT$80.93 billion (US$2.61 billion).

The Taiex opened higher on Wall Street's overnight rally, but selling pressure quickly emerged as the index approached the psychologically important barrier of 8,200 points and wiped off earlier gains.
Market analysts said the index is not expected to breach the 8,200 level in the near term without fresh leads.
Thanks to good market prospects, semiconductor and electronics stocks remained strong amid active buying during the three-hour trading session.
A total of 1.45 billion shares changed hands, marking a modest increase from Tuesday's trading volume. The market was closed Wednesday as typhoon Bilis swept over the island.

The price indexes for the eight major categories closed mixed, with electrical and electronics issues registering a 0.6 percent gain; cement issues, down 2.2 percent; plastics, down 2.8 percent; textiles, down 2.4 percent; construction, down 2.7 percent; financial and banking stocks, down 0.8 percent; foodstuff, down 2 percent; and pulp and paper, down 1.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers, 382 to 127, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED FOR MEETING WITH PRESIDENT, SAYS KMT CHAIR

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said on Thursday that there is no need for him to meet with President Chen Shui-bian for a talk.
"I don't even know what the necessity for the talk is," Lien, who is also former vice president of the Republic of China, was quoted by local media as saying.
"If it were necessary, I'd be willing to meet with Chen," he reportedly added.

Reacting to Lien's remarks, acting Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan said that President Chen, who is currently on an overseas trip but will return ahead of schedule due to the emergency situation at home in the wake of Typhoon Bilis, will continue to demonstrate his sincerity in trying to meet with Lien in the near future.

The Chen-Lien meeting, proposed by President Chen in his July 31 press conference, is considered a preliminary rendezvous leading to a cross-party roundtable meeting of the heads of Taiwan's three major political parties.

President Chen had earlier said that he wanted the roundtable meeting to take place in August, but plans were shelved as the party leaders called for preliminary meetings to set up details for the roundtable meeting, as well as because of scheduling difficulties brought about by the president, KMT Chairman, and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong all leaving Taiwan on overseas trips.

When acting Presidential Secretary-General Chen Che-nan said on Monday that the proposed Chen-Lien talk is expected to be held in the first week of September, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng showed his explicit displeasure. Reports said that Lin telephoned Chen Che-nan the same day and scathingly asked Chen why he had made a declaration on a matter that was as yet far from decided.
Whether Lien's Thursday remarks signaled the death of plans for the Chen-Lien meeting or the cross-party roundtable meeting remains to be seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX INDEX FUTURES UP

TAIEX Index futures for October also moved up, increasing by six points to finish at 8,204, with 38 contract transactions, while December futures surged 111 points to end at 8,338, with two contract transactions.
No contract transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading were 8,180 for September; 8,198 for October; 8,227 for December; 8,279 for next March; and 8,393 for next June.
TAIEX electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on TAIEX-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, showed mixed results for the day.

September TE futures increased four points to close at 448.2, with 1,489 contract transactions, while October TE futures rose 1.9 points to end at 446.1, with nine contract transactions. December TE futures finished up four points at 448.8, with a single contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 24, or the 25th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
79AD: Mount Vesuvius erupts and destroys Pompeii, Herculaneum, Stabiae, and a number of smaller settlements in Italy.
1690: Job Charnock establishes a trading post on behalf of the English East India Company in Kalikata, West Bengal.
1770: British poet Thomas Chatterton becomes depressed and fatally poisons himself with arsenic in London at age 18. He duped scholars by ascribing his poetry to a 15th-century monk, Thomas Rowley.
1814: The small but very bitter war currently being fought by Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek, leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the UN Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Getulio Vargas, President of Brazil, shoots himself to avoid scandal and demands that he should relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the US West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon last December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Chinese communist pilot Lieutenant Colonel Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter on Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Chinese communist pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year jail term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the US city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT SEES CHINA STRENGTHENING ITS CURRENCY AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Mainland China is likely to strengthen its currency rather than letting it weaken after it joins the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to former Australian ambassador to Beijing.

Ross Garnaut, who headed the Australian Embassy in China from 1985 to 1988 and is now an economics professor at the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies at Australian National University in Canberra, said China's currency was more likely to appreciate than depreciate, due to systematic changes within its financial system to occur over the first few years after it joins WTO.

His forecast that the Chinese yuan will appreciate is in striking contrast with Chris Nailer, a Singapore-based forecaster, who said earlier that China would devalue its currency by about 20 percent in two stages during 2003 and 2004, as its current account balance is seen as turning negative in 2003.
He said China's imports would grow faster than its exports after the impact of the WTO membership began to take effect in 2002.

The Australian on Thursday quoted Garnaut as saying that China had emerged from the Asian financial crisis more confident about its role in the global and regional economies, and with greater standing among its neighbors.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN CUSTOMS FACING HEADACHES FROM FOREIGN ATHLETES' LUGGAGE

TEXT.P: Australian customs officers are facing new headaches every day, as more and more foreign athletes enter Sydney with luggage containing banned items, including weapons and raw meat.

A customs spokesman told reporters that officers had to detain Russian rowers who entered Australia carrying dozens of kilograms of raw meat, as well as a Japanese shooter who failed to declare his pistols as dangerous items. The officers have also had to deal with yachts, kayaks and canoes that arrived as normal luggage instead of cargo.
He said Russian and Japanese athletes were simply not familiar with Australia's border controls.
"There (have) been a few headaches, let's just say that," he added.

The officers are also facing paperwork for a large number of crates containing tons of medicines for each team. In addition, they have to make special checks on each of the 237 horses brought in for the equestrian events.
Another 200 special chemicals and biological weapons-proof suits that were sent from the United States to supply Sydney's anti-terrorism police may face tax and import duties.
Above all, customs officers have to do their best to explain Australia's rules and regulations to athletes before they arrive. But some mishaps have been unavoidable, the spokesman said.
Altogether, more than 10,000 athletes from over 100 countries are due to arrive from August to early September to compete in the Olympic Games, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUSICIAN ENCHANTS AUSSIE AUDIENCE WITH SUPERB TECHNIQUE

TEXT.P: World-renowned violinist Lin Cho-liang on Wednesday enchanted an audience of about 700 Australians in Canberra with his technical mastery and interpretive skills, as he performed pieces by Mendelssohn and Mozart under the baton of a most experienced and dynamic conductor, Sergiu Comissiona.
Accompanied by the 104-member Asian Youth Orchestra, Lin drew an enthusiastic 10-minute ovation from the audience in the Canberra School of Music's Llewellyn Hall.

It was a warm-up performance for Lin, who will play a show on Friday at the Opera House in Sydney. It was also the first performance for the Taiwan-born violinist at the Olympic Arts Festival, part of the celebration leading to the Olympic Games.
Lin said he has made nearly 2,000 performances worldwide in the past 20 years, but this was the first time he was invited to perform at the Olympic Arts Festival.
"I feel very honored and pleased to have the chance of playing at the Olympic Arts Festival," he told CNA in an interview after the concert on Wednesday night.

Founded 12 years ago and based in Hong Kong, the Asian Youth Orchestra comprises 104 young musicians from 12 countries, including 21 from Japan, 20 from Taiwan, 19 from South Korea, 13 from Hong Kong and five from mainland China.
Lin said he plans to return to New York after his performance at the festival to prepare for other concerts in the United States later this year and more concerts in Australia next year.

The 40-year-old Lin is going to become a first-time father in January 2001. He has been married for about five years, and his wife, now working as a medical doctor in a New York hospital, hails from Meinung in Pingtung.
The couple met in 1993 when Lin was staging a solo performance in Atlanta, and his current wife helped him turn the page during his performance.

"It was just a fateful coincidence when I met my present wife because she replaced her sick friend to do the job for me," Lin said. The pair dated each other for a couple of years, and got married five years ago.
"I have been very busy traveling to many countries in the past five years, and feel very excited because I am going to be a father for the first time," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL DAMAGE OF TYPHOON BILIS EXCEEDS NT $3.7 BILLION

TEXT.P: Typhoon Bilis, which killed at least 11 people and injured several dozens of others when it roared across Taiwan on Tuesday and Wednesday, also wreaked damage of more than NT$3.7 billion (US$119 million) to the island's agricultural sector, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Thursday.

According to the latest COA tally, agricultural damages from the latest typhoon had reached NT$3.754 billion as of noon Thursday, with the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien bearing the brunt of the destruction.

Losses due to damaged agricultural produce or crop-bearing plants have hit NT$3.662 billion, losses due to flooded or washed-away farm lands have reached NT$29 million, and livestock and animal husbandry damage have topped some NT$62 million, COA officials said.

Agricultural damage reports from Taitung and Hualien Counties have both reached NT$1 billion. Similar losses in Taichung County exceed NT$700 million, followed by Nantou County's NT$456 million, and Kaohsiung County's NT$212 million.
Farmers and planters of the five hardest-hit counties are now eligible to apply for relief aid and low-interest loans to help them get back on their feet, COA officials said.
Agricultural crops that bore the full brunt of Typhoon Bilis included pears, litchis, pomelos, bananas, papayas, watermelons and sugar cane, they noted.

Bilis, the strongest storm in the West Pacific this year, wreaked havoc on eastern Taiwan. Its heavy rains caused flooding in central and southern Taiwan, as well as landslides and mudslides that claimed the lives of some nine people.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE PRESIDENT SAYS CHEN ASKED HIM TO CHAIR NUC
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China, broke his silence Wednesday to confirm that President Chen Shui-bian has asked him several times to chair the National Unification Council.
Wang said that in addition to turning down Chen's offer, he suggested that Chen himself serve as NUC chairman.
He also told the president that the NUC should operate according to the established political system as this is what the great majority of Taiwan's populace expects.

Wang made these remarks at an airport press conference in San Francisco held upon his arrival here. Wang will attend the 23rd Annual Convention of the Benevolent Associations of Taiwanese in America scheduled to be held in the Bay City on Friday.

According to Wang, Chen said that the non-partisan ad hoc committee on cross-strait relations headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh is an advisory group, while the National Unification Council is an institute that integrates the opinions of local political party leaders so as to help the nation implement the mission of national reunification.

He has also consulted with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and other senior KMT officials on Chen's proposal, Wang said. "We reached a conclusion that the NUC should be chaired by the nation's president, and we (the KMT) will render our assistance," he added.

Wang stressed that he disagreed with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proposals that the NUC be suspended, but said that he agrees that the contents of the NUC could be adapted to changing situations in cross-strait relations if it is necessary.

Chen, a DPP member, is seen as reluctant to serve as NUC chairman due to internal conflicts such a position would cause within his political party. The DPP advocates Taiwan independence, while the purpose of the NUC is the island's unification with mainland China.
At the airport to greet Wang upon his arrival included Tsao Tung-po, deputy director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, Hung Tu, former national assemblyman, and others.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ARRIVES IN CHAD TO GRAND WELCOME
DOC.DATELINE: N'Djamena, Chad, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in the central African country of Chad Wednesday for a whirlwind overnight state visit.

With the understanding of the Chadian government, President Chen has decided to cut short his visit to Chad, the last leg of his six-state "journey of friendship," as a strong typhoon just wreaked havoc in Taiwan.
Chadian President Idriss Deby presided over a grand welcoming ceremony, complete with a 21-gun salute, to greet Chen upon his arrival at the N'Djamena international airport.

The express its gratitude for the ROC's assistance, the Chadian government pooled its resources to welcome Chen, the second non-African leader to visit Chad after the late French President Charles de Gaulle. Chad used to be a French colony.

The Chadian people were given a half-day off to facilitate participation in welcoming activities. A large crowd of N'Djamena residents turned out to greet Chen. They made long lines along the road linking the airport to Deby's official residence where President Chen would stay during his overnight visit.
After listening to ROC Ambassador to Chad Chiu Chung-jen's briefing on the current state of bilateral relations, President Chen paid a visit to his Chadian counterpart at Deby's office.
During their talks, Deby reaffirmed his country's staunch support for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other major international bodies.
Later in the day, Deby decorated Chen with the Order of Grand Cross, Chad's highest national honor, in appreciation of Chen's efforts to promote ROC-Chadian relations.

Speaking at a state banquet in honor of Chen, Deby said Chad sincerely welcomes Chen's visit. He further said the ROC has offered wide-ranging assistance to Chad since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties slightly more than three years ago. As most of the ROC aid programs are highly effective in helping boost Chad's national development, Deby said the Chadian people have longed awaited the top ROC leader's visit.

For his part, Chen said the ROC is more than willing to share its developmental experience with Chad and other allies. As a member of the international community, Chen said, the ROC takes pleasure in helping other countries because it once received assistance from the United States in the process of its development.
Noting that both the ROC and Chad have limited natural resources, Chen said the two countries should cooperate to create "infinite possibilities."

In a briefing on current ROC-Chadian relations shortly after Chen's arrival, Ambassador Chiu told Chen that the ROC's three-year assistance to Chad is very fruitful. Chiu said he is the most popular ambassador in Chad and the first foreign envoy to be decorated by the Chadian government during active service. Nowadays, Chiu said, all Chadian officials and ordinary people are aware of Taiwan. "They all know that the ROC's head of state i coming for visit," he added.

The Chadian government began to broadcast programs introducing the ROC on its television channels a week before Chen's arrival. Chad's state-owned TV company also gave a live broadcast of the state banquet in honor of Chen.

On Thursday, Chen will hold a breakfast meeting with the eight ROC ambassadors stationed in Africa, including Chiu. In addition to Chad, the ROC has seven other diplomatic allies in Africa -- Burkina Faso, the Gambia, Liberia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal and Swaziland.

Chen will also visit the construction site of a Taiwan-financed bridge and attend a highway christening ceremony on Thursday. The new road will be named the "Chen Shui-bian Boulevard" in honor of Chen.
The ROC president is scheduled to wrap up his Chad visit after issuing a joint communique and giving a joint press conference with Deby around Thursday noon.
Chen and his entourage of government officials, businessmen and journalists will return to Taiwan Friday afternoon after a brief transit stop in Dubay.

This is Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20. He had visited the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, the West African states of the Gambia and Burkina Faso before coming to Chad.

After his return, Chen will immediately take a flight from Chaing Kai-shek International Airport to the central Taiwan county of Nantou where eight people were buried alive by landslides caused by Typhoon Bilis.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT HIGHER, BUT JOB PICTURE HEALTHY: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that the Republic of China's unemployment rate hit 3.06 percent in July this year, the employment environment is taking a turn for the better, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Thursday.

DGBAS officials said the average monthly jobless rate from January to July was 2.85 percent, slightly higher than a forecasted 2.8 percent. However, the DGBAS said that the average unemployment rate for the entire year will not exceed 2.8 percent.

Even if more people are losing their jobs, DGBAS officials said that Taiwan's unemployed are finding new jobs more quickly. The average of period for a successful job search shortened in July to 22.3 weeks, down 1.2 weeks from the same figure in June and indicating a brighter employment environment, the officials said.

According to the DGBAS sources, there were 9.81 million workers in Taiwan's labor pool in July, an increase of 43,000 on the same figure for June; while the number of employed workers hit 9.51 million, some 26,000 higher than the previous month. That left some 300,000 people out of work in July, an increase of 17,000 from the same figure in June, said the DGBAS.

According to the DGBAS, workers from 15 to 24 years of age were most likely to be unemployed, as that age group suffered a jobless rate of 8.24 percent. Meanwhile, 25- to 49-year-olds fared better, with an unemployment rate of 2.48 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO INSPECT REGIONS AFFECTED BY BILIS AFTER RETURN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will head directly to regions hardest-hit by Typhoon Bilis after he makes an earlier-than-expected return from his six-state overseas trip on Friday.

Chen, currently in Chad on the sixth and last stop of his "journey of friendship" to ROC allies in the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa, had been originally scheduled to return on Saturday.
However, Chen decided to move up his return because of heavy damage caused to Taiwan by the strongest typhoon to hit the island this year.
Bilis roared across Taiwan Tuesday night, leaving heavy casualties, damaged farmlands and mammoth crop losses in its wake.

After his return, Chen will head directly to Nantou, central Taiwan, which was also hard-hit by last September's devastating earthquake, to inspect the storm's damage on temporary housing units still occupied by victims of the temblor.

Chen was severely criticized during his term as Taipei's mayor for failing to return immediately from a vacation in Hawaii after a typhoon struck Taiwan. On this trip, Chen kept in close contact with Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang, and other high-ranking officials, and finally decided to return ahead of schedule.

Before traveling to Chad, Chen had visited the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, the Central American countries of Nicaragua and Costa Rica, and Gambia and Burkina Faso, both also in West Africa. It is his first official overseas trip since assuming the presidency May 20.
During the visit to Burkina Faso Aug. 23, Chen decided to return home one day ahead of schedule, and also canceled a press conference that had been scheduled for Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY MIGRATES TO MAINLAND CHINA (1)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electronics industry began to shift its labor-intensive production lines to mainland China more than 10 years ago due to rising costs at home. With operational centers in Taiwan and production lines in mainland China, the move has set a profit-proven business model.

Impressed by the business model set by the downstream assemblers and manufacturers of computer peripherals, upstream chip manufacturers, which are still subject to government restraints regarding investment in mainland China, are quietly deploying across the strait.

Monitors and scanner manufacturers were among the first to move their production lines to the mainland when international competition became more and more severe and profit margins were cut further and further. Quite a few manufacturers have boosted the production capacities of their mainland factories while folding up their production lines in Taiwan altogether.

For medium- and low-level scanner manufacturers, mainland China is not only ideal as a production site, it is also a market of tremendous potential. Microtek International, for instance, with a manufacturing center in Jiangsu Province and 150 sales outlets all over the mainland, has already grossed 40 percent of mainland China's market for medium- and low-level scanners.

Plastic circuit board (PCB) manufacturing is a booming electronics sector in mainland China, thanks to investment from Taiwan as well as multi-national corporations. Facing rising production costs and mounting resistance from local environmentalists, PCB manufacturers have found that migration to the mainland is the only option to maintain their competitive edge. Now, the mainland is the world's fourth-largest PCB supplier, next only to the United States, Japan and Taiwan.

The booming PCB sector in mainland China has inspired Taiwan's materials and plastics industries to explore the tremendous market there. Elite Material is boosting the production of its Kunshan plant in Jiangsu, while Nan Ya Plastics, a subsidiary of the Formosa Plastics Group, will invest US$75 million to build new plants in Jiangsu Province that will begin production in 2002.

Like the PCB sector, Taiwanese desk-top computers are largely produced by Taiwan-owned factories in the mainland. Statistics compiled by the Institute of Information Industry (III) show that in the first half of this year, Taiwan manufacturers produced 13.35 million desk-top computers, 5.6 million of which were assembled in the mainland.

Hou Hai Precision Industry, the world's No. 1 desk-top computer supplier, for instance, is making 90 percent of its deliveries from factories in the mainland. The office in Taiwan is in charge of taking orders, purchasing, designing and molding.

Lap-top computer manufacturers are still restricted by the government with regard to investing in the mainland. However, several manufacturers, including Compal Electronic, Inventec Corp. and Twinhead International have set up marketing outlets there to familiarize themselves with the investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR CONFIRMS TRAVEL BAN ON SEVERAL NAVY OFFICERS

TEXT.P: An ad hoc panel charged with the investigation into the death of a navy captain seven years ago has taken action to ban several navy officers from going overseas pending their interrogation, said State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa on Thursday.

Lu, who was named by Premier Tang Fei to lead the probe into the death of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng, confirmed press reports that several navy officers had been put under the travel restriction, but declined to reveal how many officers were named or why they were named.
He also said that all of those barred from traveling abroad are still in the country.

In response to questions from reporters, Lu said his panel has almost completed their review of all the documents concerning the case, and has found that several questions needed to be clarified. Interviews with people possibly involved in the case will begin soon.

Yin, who died mysteriously in 1993, was then chief executive for the navy's weapons acquisition programs, including the purchase of four frigates from France. A six-year investigation into his death by a joint task force of the military and police has turned up nothing.

President Chen Shui-bian ordered that the investigation be reopened on July 31, after press reports in France said that huge kickbacks were paid to Taiwan officials involved in buying the four frigates.

The China Times, a mass-circulated local newspaper, said earlier this week that Yin was murdered by colleagues at the General Headquarters of the Navy after he threatened to go public with information about their irregularities in the deal.

The paper said Lu's panel has prohibited fifteen navy officers from traveling overseas. However, it added that retired captain Chen Lu-tseng, who was the chief of staff of then-Navy chief Chuang Min-yao, and who was named by the paper as the person most wanted to be questioned by investigators in the case, is now in New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM OFFICIATES AT MEETING OF HEADS OF DIPLOMATIC MISSIONS IN US
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao presided over the annual meeting of the heads of the Republic of China's diplomatic missions in the United States on Wednesday.

Chen Chien-jen, ROC Representative in the United States, and the heads of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Offices in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, Kansas City, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Guam, Honolulu, Houston, Miami and New York attended the two-day meeting.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and Chen Jung-chieh, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, were also invited to attend the meeting.

According to custom, the annual meeting has always been held in Washington, D.C. and chaired by a vice minister. This year, the United States agreed for the first time since diplomatic ties between the two nations were severed that a meeting chaired by a foreign minister could be held on US territory. This is seen as an indication that Taipei-Washington relations are steadily improving.
However, the US government has not allowed an ROC foreign minister to visit Washington since officially recognizing the regime in Beijing. Therefore, the meeting was held in Los Angeles instead.

As the meeting was of a closed-door nature, the agenda, contents of the meeting will not be disclosed. It is believed that the discussions will focus on the US general election in November, Taiwan-Washington relations and Beijing-Washington ties.
The meeting will close on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 100 CHRISTIANS ARRESTED IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Chinese police Wednesday arrested 130 Christians of the "Chinese Fangcheng Church" in Xihua county in northern Henan province, a human rights group said here Thursday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said the police took away the Christians from a religious meeting, and sent them into a detention center of Xihua county. Among those arrested were three American missionaries.

The Chinese Fangcheng Church of an evangelical group with 500,000 members was outlawed by the Chinese government as an "evil cult" in 1999. One founder of the group, Zhang Rongliang, was sentenced to two years in a labor camp without trial in December of that year. The government has outlawed at least 14 Christian sects as evil cults in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC OFFICIAL VISITS ANCESTRAL SHRINE IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Zhejiang, mainland China, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: John Chang, an illegitimate son of the late Republic of China President Chiang Ching-kuo, made an offering to the ancestors of the Chiang clan at the family shrine in mainland China on Thursday.
An emotional Chang, who took his mother's family name, said from now on he is "officially a member of the Chiang family."
Chang's wife and their three children as well as the widow and children of Winston Chang, Chang's late twin brother, also paid respects to the Chiang clan ancestors in the same ceremony.
The widow of Winston Chang said she believes that her husband's soul was also present at the traditional ritual of paying tribute to one's ancestors.
The rite, held at the clan shrine in Xikou township, Fenghua County in the southeastern mainland province of Zhejiang, was witnessed by six Chiang clan elders.
Chang, 58, said the long overdue rite has given him "peace of mind" because acknowledging his blood ties was the late President Chiang Ching-kuo's dying wish.
Nevertheless, Chang said he has no intention of changing his family name to Chiang. "I will keep my mother's family name in memory of her," he explained.

After paying tribute to the Chiang clan ancestors, the Changs visited the tombs of the parents of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and the grave of the mother of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo. Chang is a grandson of Chiang Kai-shek who moved to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Chinese communist forces on the mainland.

Chiang Ching-kuo never publicly acknowledged Chang and Chang's twin brother Winston as his sons and refrained from seeing them. It was not until a few years before Chiang's death in 1988 that Chang began to bring his father little gifts like ties and shavers, always delivered through someone else.
According to Chang, three Chiang clan elders on the mainland wrote to him three years ago, urging him to return to visit the family shrine.
Chang said he began to make preparations for the trip after stepping down from the post of secretary-general to former President Lee Teng-hui in March.

Chang, a career diplomat, also once served as secretary-general of the Kuomintang, Taiwan's ruling party until May 20. He has held no public office since the KMT lost the March 18 presidential election.

Chang and his family will then travel to Ningpo and lunch with mainland-based Taiwan businessmen on Friday. The next day, he is scheduled to proceed to Shanghai, where he will lunch with Taiwan businessmen there.

The mainland office in charge of Taiwan affairs in Shanghai will honor him at a dinner party on Saturday, and he will visit the Shanghai home of the ROC and KMT founding father, Dr. Sun Yet-sen, on Sunday. Chang and his family will then proceed to Queilin, Guangxi, where he will offer incense at the tomb of his mother, Chang Ya-juo, on Aug. 29. He is expected to return to Taiwan on Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: 921 EARTHQUAKE MEMORIAL TO BE HIGHLIGHT OF NATIONAL DAY 2000

TEXT.P: The main welcome activities for overseas Chinese visiting Taiwan for National Day this year will focus on the Sept. 21 earthquake, Minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chang Fu-mei announced on Thursday.

Chang said that on the first National Day to be celebrated since the inauguration of the new government, both old- and new-generation overseas Chinese will be welcome to take part in the celebration rally.
He said the four-day celebration will focus on humanitarian concern over the 921 earthquake and on love for Taiwan.

Chang noted that overseas Chinese donated a total of NT$1.9 billion (US$0.06 billion) to help the victims of the earthquake, and said trips would be organized for the visitors to see at first-hand the fruits of their donations and how the reconstruction is progressing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT, PREMIER INSPECT DISASTER REGIONS

TEXT.P: Top Republic of China government officials spent Thursday inspecting the areas that received the heaviest battering as Typhoon Bilis crossed the island the day before, leaving heavy casualties and agricultural damage in its path.

ROC Vice President Annette Lu inspected earthquake- and typhoon-torn Nantou County and encouraged local residents to bounce back from the devastating natural disasters like "unbendable lotus flowers" while Premier Tang Fei inspected the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien, declaring them to be natural disaster regions eligible for state relief.

Urging Nantou citizens to rise above the difficult times, Lu witnessed the "graduation" ceremonies of 13 mothers who undertook sewing training to acquire new job skills after last year's killer Sept. 21 earthquake destroyed homes and depressed the local economy.
Lu also praised returning students who spent the summer serving their home county, and added that she is certain this year will be a particularly significant period in their lives.

Pointing out that the disaster region residents have only two major demands from the government -- a place to live and a job to go to -- Lu said that the government's post-quake reconstruction committee should answer to the people and show substantial results by the earthquake's first anniversary in September.

She also paid her respects to the families of seven Nantou fruit pickers and a six-year-old girl who were buried alive overnight by a mudslide that washed away the hut in which they were sheltering from the strong winds and torrential rains brought on by Bilis.
Meanwhile, Tang inspected damaged granaries, orchards, levees, and roads in Taitung and Hualien counties, which bore the brunt of the typhoon's fury.

He declared that farmers in the two counties are eligible for relief aid and low-interest loans and added that relief aid of NT$30,000 (US$966) per hectare of fruit trees should be handed out within a month for it to be effective. NT$500,000 (US$16,100) emergency loans will have an interest rate of 4.5 percent.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) reported over NT$1 billion-worth (US$32 million) of crop damage for each of the two counties. Tang directed the COA to release onto the market frozen vegetables it had helped farmers put into storage earlier, in order to maintain sufficient supplies and keep market prices from increasing too much.
He also directed his staff to look into helping the affected farmers to limit their damage by processing the tons of windfall fruit.
According to disaster relief regulations, rice from damaged public granaries will be made into rice wine, while any surplus will be dried. Financial aid will also be provided to repair the granaries.

Tang watched soldiers from the military's Hualien-Taitung Defense Command as they transferred wet rice from the damaged Fuli Village granary to be dried and stored in another granary. He also inspected the damaged granary and directed state-run Taiwan Power Company to repair damaged power lines by Friday morning in order to limit further losses for the farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILIS CAUSES LOSSES OF NT$4 BILLION IN AGRICULTURAL SECTOR

TEXT.P: Powerful Typhoon Bilis had caused losses worth more than NT$4 billion (US$120 million) in Taiwan's agricultural sector as of Thursday, according to a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
He said the losses included NT$3.94 billion-worth of crop losses, NT$36 million in damaged farmland and NT$72 million in the livestock industry.

Three counties and cities -- Tainan City, Taipei City and Hsinchu County -- were added to the list of areas affected by Bilis, bringing the number of affected areas to 19. Of these, Taitung County topped the list of hardest-hit counties, with losses totaling NT$926 million. It was followed by Hualien County, with losses worth NT$900.6 million.

The spokesman said that farmers in Taitung, Hualien, Nantou, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Ilan counties are eligible for cash bailouts and low-interest loans, while those in Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties can apply for low-interest loans.
Farmers in Nantou, Ilan, Yunlin, Pingtung, Taitung and Hualien can also apply for subsidies for their storm-damaged land, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SOFTWARE SHOW KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2000 International Software Show kicked off Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with the organizers hoping to attract some 200,000 visitors.

Officials of the Information Service Industry Association (ISIA) of the Republic of China, which is organizing the show, said that in line with the rapid development of Taiwan's software industry, the ISIA has this year organized Taiwan's largest-ever software show.

The show, which has attracted hundreds of software companies to display their wares, is divided into ten zones for categories such as commercial software, multimedia applications, game software, educational software and Internet applications.
Although crowds overall were thin, perhaps because of the just-departed Typhoon Bilis, a throng of youngsters flocked to the game displays.
The ISIA and software companies are offering coupons and have organized various activities in a bid to attract customers and has set up a website at www.cisanet.org.tw., according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE TRADE FAIR OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A European trade and tourism fair opened at the Taipei World Trade Center on Thursday under the joint sponsorship of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
"Eurogate 2000" brings together 100 firms from Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Macedonia, Hungary, Lithuania and Latvia.

Vice Foreign Minister Lin Ki-tseng said at the opening of the show that more than 40 trade officials from the seven states are attending the fair, and will exchange views with local economic officials as well as business leaders in the hope of promoting bilateral trade exchanges.

Notable among the visiting foreign officials are Macedonian Economics Minister Borko Andreev, Hungarian Agriculture Minister Jozsf Torgyan, Slovenian Economics Minister Joze Zagozan and Polish Vice Economics Minister Tadeusz Donocik.
Poland dominates the trade fair floor with more than 70 stalls displaying jewelry, amber, lamps, coffee, agricultural equipment, electronic goods and iron products.
Macedonia, which is taking part in the fair for the first time, has more than 30 booths featuring spirits, diary products and agricultural products.

The Czech firms are showcasing their stained crystal glassware and ceramics, while Hungarian firms are offering their wines, foie gras and honey. Slovenia was late in applying to take part in the show and consequently is manning a booth featuring catalogues of its products.
Eurogate 2000 is open free of charge from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day until Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY FOUND AT SEA CONFIRMED AS THAT OF ESCAPED CONVICT
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Police confirmed on Thursday that a body found floating in the sea off the coast of Taitung, eastern Taiwan, was that of one of four convicts who staged a jailbreak Tuesday at the height of Typhoon Bilis.
The police said the body had been identified through fingerprints as that of Chen Yung-sung, 33.

The sound of their actions muffled by the typhoon, the prisoners shattered the concrete bars of a window using part of an iron bed, lowered themselves to the ground with a rope made of blankets and scaled the outer perimeter fence with the aid of some trashcans.
Police investigators said Chen was probably swept away and drowned while trying to cross a swollen river.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE GOLFER TAKES LEAD IN ROCPGA

TEXT.P: Japanese golfer Daisuke Maruyama shot a seven-under par 65 to take the lead in the first round of the Republic of China Professional Golf Association (ROCPGA) tournament which teed off Thursday at the Tong Hwa Golf and Country Club.

Local golfer Hsieh Chin-sheng completed the first round in 67 to share second place with his countrymen Hong Chia-yuh and Lee Wen-sheng, as well as US player Gary Rusnak and English player Simon Dyson.

Prayad Marksaeng of Thailand, Lin Fu-chin of the ROC, Adrian Percey of Australia and Ho Chia-feng of the ROC scored 68, while Chen Yuan-chi of the ROC, Thongchai Jaidee of Thailand, Tseng Wen-chi of the ROC, Yu Chin-han of the ROC, Tseng Kuo-chang of the ROC, Lin Keng-chi of the ROC, Boonchu Ruangkit of Thailand, Hsieh Min-nan of the ROC, and Masato Endo of Japan all shot 69.

Indian Jyoti Randhawa carded a two-under par 70, along with Kao Yu-huang of the ROC, Taku Yamanaka of Japan, Lee Lien-fu of the ROC, Hsu Huang-lung of the ROC, Greg Hanrahan of the United States, Thammanoon Sriroji of Thailand, Lin Chih-chen of the ROC, Gerald Rosales of the Philippines, Lu Wen-teh of the ROC and Chen Liang-hsi of the ROC.

A total of 144 golfers from 16 countries and regions are competing in the four-day competition for US$300,000 in prize money, while a pro-am section of the event has been postponed until next Monday due to the effects of Typhoon Bilis.
The ROCPGA tournament is one of three majors held in Taiwan along with the annual Mercuries Masters and the ROC Open.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP VISITS SHANGHAI TO DISCUSS EDUCATION
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: An investment study delegation of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) paid a call on Shanghai City Hall on Thursday.

Shanghai Deputy Mayor Chou Mu-yao and other officials received the delegation and talked with the delegates for about one hour on topics including the education of the children of Taiwan businessmen living in mainland China.
The delegation, led by TEEMA Chairman Wu Ssu-chung, arrived in Beijing on Aug. 20 for a 10-day tour of Beijing, Shanghai and Ningbo.
After a four-day stay in Beijing, they flew to Shanghai on Wednesday for a four-day visit that will take them to two Taiwan-funded plants.
The delegation will then travel on to Ningbo before returning to Taipei on Aug. 29.

During their stay in Beijing, delegation members met with several high-ranking mainland officials, including Vice Premier Qian Qichen, to exchange views on Taiwan businessmens' investments in mainland China.

The delegation proposed various suggestions to the officials, including the three direct cross-Taiwan Strait links, allowing Taiwan banks to establish branch offices in mainland China, the strengthening of security measures for Taiwan businessmen, as well as the removing of obstacles to investment by Taiwan businessmen.
Wu said the mainland officials "responded positively" to all the suggestions.

The delegation also visited the emerging Zhongguancun high-tech science-based park in Beijing, home to 6,690 high tech enterprises, 200 of which are Taiwan-funded. The park registers an average annual production value of US$52.7 billion with an export value of US$880 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND BOASTS OF EFFORTS IN TYPHOON RESCUE AND RELIEF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) boasted on Thursday of its great contribution to the rescue and relief of the victims of Typhoon Bilis which cut a swathe across Taiwan on Tuesday.

A statement by the MND said that an emergency center was established under the ministry on Monday to coordinate the military's rescue and relief efforts, and that forces around the country were ordered to freeze all regular training and holidays to be ready for possible rescue operations.
As of 5 p.m. on Thursday, the military spent 45,451 men/times, 214 vehicle/times and ten helicopter/times on rescue or relief missions around the island.

The military has since been engaged in after-typhoon clean-up operations in Taipei and Kaohsiung, helping to reopen highways blocked by mudslides and falling trees, dredging the sewage system, and sheltering refugees evacuated from low-lying areas, said the statement.
The statement added that the military's efforts have won acknowledgment from President Chen Shui-bian, who was in Chad for an official visit on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR ASKED TO DETAIN TOWNSHIP HEAD IN NANTOU COUNTY

TEXT.P: A prosecutor asked a court on Thursday for permission to detain a rural township head wanted for questioning on suspicion of corruption.

Wu Chao-feng, administrator of the Chungliao rural township in Nantou Country is suspected of siphoning off government funds earmarked to fix roads in his township after the Sept. 21 earthquake last year.
He had turned himself in to prosecutors earlier in the day after disappearing for a couple of days, but the prosecutor asked the court's approval for Wu's detention out of fear that he might escape.

DOC.HEADLINE: TDA TO HELP SPONSOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION PROGRAM IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: US Trade and Development Agency (TDA) will donate US$450,000 to help sponsor an environment development scheme in Tainan City, Tainan Mayor George T.H. Chang announced Thursday.
Chang said Tainan City was to be given the fund with the assistance of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and Oregon Trade and Information Center.

TDA and Chang will sign formal agreement in September. Chang emphasized that Tainan will be the first city in Taiwan to undertake the US-funded environmental protection program, which will include the establishment of sewage farms, ecological schools, and cleaning of rivers.
The scheme will not only help promote US-based companies' interests in Taiwan, but will also set a model for other Taiwan cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF TIANANMEN MASSACRE VICTIMS PROTEST US VISIT BY PRC VP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: US-based families of the victims of the June 4, 1989 Tienanmen Square massacre protested Wednesday against a visit to the United States by Li Peng, chairman of mainland China's National People's Congress (NPC).

A total of 116 refugee families wrote a joint letter to Inter-Parliamentary Union President Andres Johnsson to protest over Li's participation in the Conference of Presiding Officers of National Parliaments, which is scheduled to be held in the United Nations General Assembly Hall from Aug. 30 to Sept. 1, according to Human Rights in China (HRIC) Chairman Liu Qing.

The letter noted that Li was the top official responsible for the massacre and that if he were to be permitted to attend the conference, it would be a mockery of the United Nations Charter and the International Human Rights Trust.

The HRIC, which also distributed the letter to the chairmen of all the member parliaments, said it hoped the UN will agree to the request of the families and bar Li from attending. Mainland China is a permanent member of the UN Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT WRAPS UP STATE VISIT, RETURNING HOME

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian wrapped up his visit here ahead of schedule Thursday after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.

Chen and his entourage of government officials, businessmen, and journalists will make a transit stop in Dubai, the largest city in the United Arab Emirates, before arriving at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 3 p.m. Friday.

Chen decided to cut short his visit to Chad -- the last leg of his six-state "journey of friendship" to the ROC's allies in the Caribbean, Central America, and Africa -- to take charge of the situation at home in the wake of Typhoon Bilis.
He was originally scheduled to return to Taiwan on Saturday.
Upon his return, Chen will immediately take a flight from the airport to the central Taiwan county of Nantou where eight people were buried alive by landslides caused by the typhoon.

In his joint communique with Deby, Chen reiterated the ROC government's promise to strengthen existing cooperative relations and expand the areas of cooperation, urging private enterprises in both nations to establish partnerships through the use of all existing channels.
The two heads of state also expressed their pleasure at the sound bilateral relations as seen from the continued high level visits and mutual support of the same international issues.
Deby reiterated the Chadian government and people's firm support for the ROC government's right to participate in all international organizations, especially the United Nations.
Chen and Deby expressed their mutual concern for the worsening conflict situations in Africa and urged for dialogue through the UN and other regional organizations to resolve disagreements.

Earlier in the day, Chen held a breakfast meeting with the eight ROC ambassadors stationed in Africa. In addition to Chad, the ROC has seven other diplomatic allies in Africa -- Burkina Faso, the Gambia, Liberia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal and Swaziland.
He thanked the ambassadors for their work and reminded them that no ally is too small or too big, and that developed and undeveloped nations alike are all important friends to the people of Taiwan.

Chen also visited the construction site of a Taiwan-financed bridge and attended a highway christening ceremony. The new road was originally to be named "Chen Shui-bian Boulevard" in his honor, but Chen suggested that it should renamed "Republic of China Boulevard," at which N'Djamena Mayor Ali Haroun said that because the bridge is to be called "Taiwan Bridge," perhaps the highway leading to it could also be called "Taiwan Boulevard."
Chen also visited a local hospital to inspect the work of an ROC medical team and later visited the ROC-assisted Farcha oil refinery plant.

The "journey of friendship" is Chen's first overseas trip since taking office on May 20. It took him to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica in Central America, and the West African states of the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan demands the government make an overall review of anti-typhoon measures.
The China Times:
Premier Tang Fei promises to offer emergency relief for typhoon-affected farmers.

The China Post:

The Taiwan News:
Water supply in Kaohsiung area curbed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CONTINUES DOWNWARD STREAK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market continued its downward streak Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index losing 72.52 points to close at 8,026.32.
Daily turnover totaled NT$70.3 billion (US$2.27 billion) in the three-hour trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DENIES 'RESHUFFLE' REPORT, FORMS FINANCIAL PANEL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet Friday denied a press report that the three-month-old Cabinet will undergo its first partial reshuffle at the end of this month.
Chang Ping-nan, deputy director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), told a routine news conference that Premier Tang Fei already denied the report Thursday.
A local newspaper claimed that both the Presidential Office and the Cabinet had reached a consensus that at least two or three Cabinet members will be replaced late this month.

During an inspection tour of the typhoon-affected regions in the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung, Premier Tang said he was surprised by the report. "There is no such thing," the premier added.
Acting Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan has also dismissed the report as "sheer speculation."

Meanwhile, Premier Tang announced at a weekly Cabinet meeting on Friday that the Cabinet will form a special economic and financial task force to work out feasible measures to cope with relevant issues faced by the country.
According to a GIO press release, Tang will personally head the panel and Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan will serve as its chief executive secretary.

Members of the group include Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Cabinet Secretary-General Wea Chi-lin as well as Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
From now on, the GIO statement said, the panel will meet regularly to discuss major financial and economic issues and recommend measures for resolving them.

Tang's Cabinet has been criticized for failing to present consistent, coherent and clear-cut economic and financial policies. The results of some public opinion polls also show that the approval ratings for senior financial and economic officials are generally low. Against this backdrop, some news media have speculated that certain Cabinet members in the relevant fields may be replaced.

Observers said the formation of the new Cabinet financial and economic panel is part of Premier Tang's efforts to signify the importance the new government attaches to financial and economic issues as well as to invalidate any Cabinet reshuffle reports.
During Friday's Cabinet meeting, Tang also reiterated the government's concern about the development of traditional industries which face many difficulties due to changing global market situation.

In another news development, the Ministry of Finance will sponsor a seminar on the country's current financial problems over the weekend in the central Taiwan county of Nantou, which bore the brunt of the devastating "921 earthquake."

The Aug. 26-27 seminar will discuss three major themes -- public debt management and major government financial sources; how to improve the financial status of local governments; and a mechanism to cut government expenditures and save resources.
More than 100 legislators, scholars, industry delegates, central and local government representatives have been invited to attend the seminar to present policy proposals or options.

Premier Tang, Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Cabinet Secretary-General Wea Chi-lin, Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, CEPD Chairman Chen Po-chih and GIO Director-General Chung Chin will all attend the seminar.
Two former Finance Minister Paul Chiu and Lin Chen-kuo have also been invited to attend the meeting to provide counseling services.
