DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE CHINA' POLICY GOOD FOR TAIWAN, CHINA: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: It makes a great deal of sense for the United States to maintain its "one China" policy, because it reduces the possibility of war across the Taiwan Strait, compels PRC modernization and democratization, and buys time without endangering Taiwan, claimed an American defense expert Thursday.

Nicholas Berry, senior analyst at the Washington-based Center for Defense Information, wrote in a commentary that "one doesn't have to be a devotee of Beijing to realize the one-China policy serves American interests and, over the long term, serves the interests of Taiwan and even the mainland Chinese."
He pointed out that understanding how the one-China policy affects the policies of Beijing and Taipei confirms its usefulness:

-- Reduces possibility of war. Virtually no analyst believes that the PRC leaders are not serious when they talk about the necessity of territorial integrity. And the fact that national unification is a deeply cherished dream by virtually all mainland Chinese is widely recognized. People's Liberation Army leaders are extremely patriotic, fiercely supportive of unification, and deeply suspicious of foreign meddling what they regard as "China's internal affairs."

President Lee Teng-hui's 1995 pro-independence speech at his alma matter, Cornell University, mobilized PLA officers to press Beijing's political leadership to hold military exercises off Taiwan's coast. "Quite simply, Taiwan independence means war. No government in Beijing could tolerate the permanent division of China. Peace, therefore, depends on maintaining the one-China principle which the US one-China policy supports," wrote Berry.
-- Compels PRC modernization and democratization. As long as the one-China principle is maintained, the PRC is obliged to pave the way towards reunification by becoming more like Taiwan.

"The PRC's systems are the ones undergoing fundamental change. Mainland leaders may not want democracy, but creating a vibrant economy balloons the middle class that does want more freedoms and participation in public policy. The closer the mainland's economy and political system approach Taiwan's, the faster reunification will occur. The one-China principle backed by the US one-China policy puts the burden on Beijing to modernize," argued Berry.

-- Paves the way for cross-strait exchanges. As long as the United States maintains the one-China principle as the basis of its overall China policy, Taipei will not go off on its own and challenge Beijing with a declaration of independence. Alone, Taiwan's prospects in a long-term conflict with the mainland are not good.

Instead, Berry said, "by not challenging the one-China principle (while not surrendering by accepting that Beijing is the only government for all of China), Taiwan opens the way for greater direct trade, communications and transportation with the mainland. This will help China modernize, sustain progressive leadership in Beijing, break down emotional barriers across the Taiwan Strait, and increase the cost if Beijing considers taking military action against Taiwan."

-- Buys time without endangering Taiwan. Taiwan has de facto autonomy now, and its democracy and economy are well established. "Taiwan President Chen Shui-bian has reasonably stated that the Taiwanese people would have to approve reunification. Current trends are favorable for increasing the convergence of the two societies. Why disturb the status quo?" asked Berry.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY IS PREREQUISITE OF CROSS-STRAIT UNIFICATION: ACTIVISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By M. J. Tsou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Democracy in mainland China is a prerequisite of cross-strait unification, a group of Chinese democracy activists residing in France said Thursday.

In a letter to the European Daily News, the four Chinese democracy campaigners stated that if Beijing wishes to see a peaceful and unified China, it must first accept and recognize the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are two separate political entities. They also added that Beijing must first initiate and deliver democracy on the mainland.
The European Daily News is a Chinese-language newspaper in Paris, and an offshoot of Taipei's United Daily News.

The letter was jointly authored by Chinese dissidents Xue Chaoqing, Zheng Qi, Jiang Ping and Hu An. They said that there is no doubt that mainland China is keenly eager for peace and unification with Taiwan, but that authorities in Beijing must first ease controls on democratic activities and allow mainland people the freedom of speech, freedom of publication, and freedom to organize groups.

Only when the Chinese public really have the right to know and the right to express themselves can all Chinese people around the globe work together to accomplish the ultimate goal of unification, the activists said.
They stressed that above all, all parties concerned must respect the truth of history -- that there are two separate political entities in China under two different governments.

One such entity is the Republic of China government in Taipei, the sovereignty of which covers all of Taiwan's territory, including the offshore islands of Kinmen, Matsu, Penghu, and other tiny islets in the South China Sea, they said. They added that the other political power is the PRC government in Beijing.

Any party that does not recognize this historic truth and insists on proclaiming itself "the only legitimate Chinese government" is showing a hegemonic mentality, which simply demonstrates that its unification drive is part of a "united front" against Taiwan, they continued.
The letter urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to take the first step toward reconciliation and use the terms "Taipei government" and "Beijing government" to refer to one another.

A truce must come before any peace, they went on, suggesting that the Taipei government renounce the use of force to "recover" the mainland, and urging the Beijing government to renounce the use of force to "liberate" Taiwan.

The Chinese democracy campaigners also gave Beijing the thumbs down for its attempt to impose the "one country, two systems" scheme on Taiwan. The mainland imposed the controversial system on Hong Kong after the territory's handover from British rule.

It will be a dead-end alley for Beijing if it sticks to its totalitarianism on one hand and attempts to have the 23 million people in Taiwan return to its fold on the other, they said. The public in Taiwan will never be willing to unify with the mainland under Beijing's communist totalitarianism, they said.

In conclusion, the Chinese activists said they wrote the letter to mark the significance of the soon-to-open World Chinese Convention on the Promotion of Peaceful Unification, which they said would serve as a great inspiration for Chinese people from across the Taiwan Strait.
They said they keenly hope that Taiwan and the mainland will reunify along the lines of East Germany and West Germany, and create a government of freedom, democracy and peace to rule the two sides.

The World Chinese Convention on the Promotion of Peaceful Unification is being organized by the Chinese Unification Promotion Federation in Europe. The event is scheduled to be held Aug. 26-27 in Berlin, with scholars, officials and democratic campaigners from Chinese communities around the world participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANE MISHAP FORCES CANCELLATION OF FLIGHTS AT KAOHSIUNG AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A mishap involving a Uni Air plane has thrown the operation of Kaohsiung International Airport into chaos, forcing the cancellation of more than 120 flights between Thursday afternoon and Friday morning.

The Uni Air plane, flying from Taipei to Kaohsiung on Thursday afternoon, overshot the main runway because of slippery conditions caused by heavy rains in the wake of Typhoon Bilis. Fortunately, no passengers were hurt when the plane finally came to a halt on a grassy area 50 meters away from the runway.
For safety reasons, the airport was closed to deal with the aftermath of the incident, forcing the cancellation of both domestic and international flights.

Meanwhile, continuing rains softened the ground under the plane, which became trapped in the mud, making efforts to remove it more difficult. The plane was finally towed away from the scene at 8:25 a.m. Friday morning, and the airport was reopened at 9:07 a.m.
Uni Air has apologized to all other airlines for the inconvenience caused by the mishap.

Airport officials said that more than 120 flights were canceled between Thursday afternoon and Friday morning. Friday morning's flight schedule was also thrown into chaos, and the air traffic at the airport returned to normal only in the afternoon, they added.

Despite the complaints of passengers, the officials said that the cancellation of the flights was caused by unavoidable factors, and it will be difficult for the affected passengers and airlines to obtain compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ADVISED TO DEVELOP 'KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY'

TEXT.P: The Australian currency may plunge to only 30 U.S. cents within a decade if Canberra does not develop a "knowledge economy" by making major investments in education and research and development, according to a warning by a chief scientist.

Dr. Robin Batterham, chief technologist of Rio Tinto, the United Kingdom-based resources giant, warned the Aussie dollar will plummet unless the Australian government adopts the recommendations he made in a recent paper to spend hundreds of millions of dollars more every year on higher education, research and development, and the commercialization of ideas, according to a report by The Australian Financial Review on Friday.
The Australian dollar was trading at 57.15 US cents on Friday morning, down from 57.25 US cents on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX CLOSES LOWER

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices closed lower on Friday, with about 1.35 billion shares changing hands.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index, the market's key barometer, fell 72.52 points to close at 8,026.32 on turnover of NT$70.3 billion (US$2.27 billion). The index opened at 8,120.96 and traded between 8,014.95 and 8,142.47.
Excluding financial issues, the index lost 65.83 points to finish at 6,923.68.

Closing prices for the eight major sectors were mostly down, with only textile shares gaining 0.5 percent. Foodstuff issues fell the most, losing 3 percent; followed by decreases in share prices of cement firms, down 1.9 percent; construction, down 1.8 percent; pulp and paper, down 1.4 percent; electronics down 0.8 percent; bank and financial shares, down 0.7 percent; and plastics and chemicals, down 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 431 to 81, with 67 stocks unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WRAPS UP SIX-STATE 'JOURNEY OF FRIENDSHIP'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian returned to Taiwan Friday after a 12-day, six-state "journey of friendship" aimed at bolstering the Republic of China's relations with its diplomatic allies.
Chen's chartered plane landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, at 2:50 p.m.

Chen, accompanied by Premier Tang Fei and several other senior government officials, then flew to central Taiwan aboard Taiwan's "Air Force One" to inspect damage caused by a strong typhoon that swept over the island Tuesday through early Wednesday.

Chen would toured several Nantou County townships which were affected by typhoon Bilis. Eight orchard workers in the county's Jenai village were buried alive by an avalanche triggered by the storm Tuesday night.
Chen left Taipei on Aug. 13 to start his first overseas visit since taking office on May 20. The journey took him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES HIGH-TECH DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Friday urged the nation to move toward high technology development, saying that it is the only way to ensure Taiwan's continued development and prosperity.

Lu made the remarks after listening to a briefing of the Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan, which was the first stop on her current "high-tech journey."

Lu, who has been appointed as the convenor of a technology consultation task force at the Presidential Office, noted that President Chen Shui-bian had expressed in his inaugural speech that he envisions transforming Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

She said that with so many people living on such a small island, Taiwan has no other choice but to develop its high-tech skills, especially in the face of strong competition from mainland China. She added that technological development is a worldwide trend in which Taiwan must participate.
She stressed that local people should attach equal importance to production, ecology and human lives, which she said is the gist of the concept of the "green silicon island."
Lu earlier toured the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park. She expressed concern about the site's ability to withstand earthquakes as well as environmental problems.
Lu was accompanied on the journey by Control Yuan member Chao Jung-yao, Chairman of the National Science Council Weng Cheng-i and Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX INDEX FUTURES DROP

TEXT.P: September futures for the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index dropped 73 points to close at 8,117, with 3,772 contracts trading hands.

TAIEX index futures for October also fell 64 points to finish at 8,140, with 42 contracts traded, while December futures fell 103 points to end at 8,235, with three contract deals struck. Futures for next June moved down 115 points to close at 8,288, on 14 contract transactions.
No contract transactions were recorded for other months.

The Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange's reference levels for TAIEX index futures trading were 8,190 for September; 8,204 for October; 8,338 for December; 8,289 for next March; and 8,403 for next June.
TAIEX electronics futures (TE) and financial futures (TF), sub-index futures based on TAIEX-listed firms in the two sectors, both lost ground.
September TE futures descended to close at 444.2, down four points, on 1,275 contract transactions; while October TE futures dropped 1.4 points to finish at 444.7, with 11 contracts traded.
No TE contract transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures moved down eight points to end at 891, with 431 contract deals struck; while October TF futures decreased nine points to close at 896, with two contract transactions. TF futures for next June fell eight points to finish at 918.4, on 10 contract transactions.
No TF contract transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD MEETS WITH PARTY LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) on Friday met with the members of a delegation comprised of PFP legislators scheduled to visit mainland China next week.
Friday's meeting was aimed at forging a consensus on the party's cross-strait policy before the group departs for the mainland on Monday, sources said.
The PFP is seen as likely to set a policy of returning to the agreement reached in 1992 between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on "one China, different interpretation."
The visit of the PFP delegation will be significant in that it will be the first parliamentary group to visit the mainland after the recent Beidaihe meeting of Beijing leaders.
The delegation will elaborate on the purpose and the principles of the visit before their departure, the sources said.
Meanwhile, an official of the Kuomintang (KMT), another opposition party, said in Shanghai that the time is not yet ripe for the KMT party chairman to visit mainland China.
Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Department of Mainland Affairs Research, said that KMT Chairman Lien Chan will visit the mainland only if the timing is appropriate.

Chang, visiting several academic groups in Shanghai during a three-day stay there, said that the purpose of his own trip is mainly to learn about the views of mainland scholars on cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.003 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$31.072.
The local currency opened at NT$31.066 and was traded between NT$31.066 and NT$31.074.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$253 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 25, or the 26th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1530: Ivan IV, known as "Ivan the Terrible," the Russian Tsar who executed more than 3,000 people, including the royal heir, is born.
1819: James Watt, English engineer and inventor of the steam engine, dies at the age of 83.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1270: Louis IX, known as "Saint Louis," the king of France who led the Seventh Crusade against Egypt in 1248, dies in a subsequent crusade to Tunisia at the age of 56.
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (AUG. 26)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 26, or the 27th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1346: An English army under Edward III wins an overwhelming and unexpected victory by defeating Philip VI's larger French force in the battle of Crecy.
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL GROUPS OPPOSE CEPD'S NATIONAL PENSION SCHEME

TEXT.P: Several social groups, including the Taiwan Labor Front (TLF) and the Social Legislation Movement Federation, are opposed to the national pension scheme put forward by the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), officials of the social groups said Friday.
The groups have formed an alliance to oppose the national pension schemes issued by both the new and old governments, because both schemes are not well-developed, according to the officials.
The alliance of national pension system promoters criticized the national pension system proposed by the CEPD as the worst plan yet.
TLF Secretary-General Hsu Chu-feng said the Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) has strayed from its professed ideal of supporting politically and economically weak groups.

Hsu added that the CEPD's scheme would force people to save money for themselves, and is also socially unfair. Moreover, the suggested pension payments would be too low to protect the economic security of Taiwan's elderly, he said.

The alliance maintains that any well-developed system should include a monthly pension of NT$6,000, he noted. Meanwhile, the government should develop a sound system of taxation to increase its financial resources, he said, adding that the public should not be subject to other insurance fees.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CAMPING JAMBOREE KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: An annual international camping jamboree began Friday at Lungmen Campgrounds, in the Northeast Coast National Scenic Area, officials of the area's administration said.

Campers from eight countries, including the United States, Japan and South Korea, are participating in the event, the officials said. They added that this year's jamboree has set a record attendance of over 1,500 people.

In addition to traditional camping activities, a Recreational Van Trade Fair and Dance Dance Revolution (DDR) contest will also be held, the officials said. The three-day event will wind up on Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR DONATES NT$ 150 MILLION TO NTHU

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang on Friday donated NT$150 million (US$4.83 million) to National Tsinghua University (NTHU) to establish the first technology management college in Taiwan.

Noting that NTHU is one of TSMC's major sources of personnel, Chang said that the new economy in Taiwan will have three pillars: technology, creativity, and adventurous spirits. He said he was glad that entrepreneurs can cooperate with educational institutions, adding that he looks forward to the day when NTHU's technology management college is ranked as the world's best.

NTHU President Liu Chung-laung noted that current Education Minister J.L. Tzeng, former Education Ministers Lin Ching-Jiang and Yung Chaur-shin, and former NTHU Presidents Shen Chun-shan and Liu Chao-shiuan all worked for a long time to establish the new college, which has been permitted to open in February this year.

In addition, former Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who had served as NTHU president before he worked for the government, will establish a technology research center at the university in September. His research on the impact and influence of technology on society will be available at the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET INAUGURATES DISASTER RESCUE COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Friday inaugurated a Disaster Prevention and Rescue Commission to further demonstrate its determination to protect the lives and property of the people of Taiwan.

Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who presided over the inauguration ceremony, noted that the commission has already begun operations because of Typhoon Bilis, which roared across Taiwan on Tuesday night, and is aimed at not only emergency rescues, but also disaster prevention and advance warning.
The commission will be made up of the vice chiefs of the Executive Yuan's 16 departments and various experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE WITH MAINLAND CHINA INCREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade with mainland China reached US$15.3 billion in the first half of this year, an increase of 28.7 percent over the same period of last year, according to statistics released Friday by Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).
The BOFT under the Ministry of Economic Affairs added that Taiwan's trade with the mainland in the first half of 2000 accounted for 11 percent of its total foreign trade.

With the increasing demand for imports by the mainland, Taiwan exported goods worth US$12.2 billion to the mainland in the first half of this year, representing 17.4 percent of Taiwan's total exports, while importing US$3.04 billion-worth of goods from the mainalnd, an increase of 47 percent. The figures show a trade surplus of US$9.2 billion in Taiwan's favor.

In June alone, Taiwan exported goods to mainland China with a total value of US$2.3 billion, a growth of 33.2 percent over the same period of last year, while its imports from mainland totaled US$555 million, an increase of 46.8 percent.

According to BOFT officials, Taiwan's monthly exports to the mainland have enjoyed a double-digit increase since last October because of the economic recovery in Southeast Asia and stable economic growth in Europe and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S 1ST POST-INAUGURATION OVERSEAS TRIP DRAWS MIXED REVIEWS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's first post-inauguration overseas visit, which ended Friday, has drawn mixed evaluations from local politicians.
While government officials recognized the positive results of Chen's six-state "journey of friendship," some legislators cast doubt on the effectiveness of the president's 12-day overseas visit.

Chen, accompanied by a large entourage of government officials, businessmen and journalists, left Taipei on Aug. 13 for a journey aimed at bolstering the Republic of China's diplomatic relations with its allies.

Speaking at a seminar on the just-concluded trip, Lo Chih-cheng, director of the Research and Planning Board of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the president's hectic globe-trotting visit was fruitful.

Lo said the visit, which took Chen to the Dominican Republic in the Caribbean, the Central American countries of Nicaragua and Costa Rica, and the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad in West Africa, has helped signify the ROC's sovereign status and cement its ties with its diplomatic allies.

Following Chen's visit to the three African countries, Lo said, all of the ROC's eight African allies have promised not to attend a forum to be sponsored by Beijing to boost its ties with African states. Beijing had invited Taiwan's African allies to attend the seminar as observers.
In the face of Beijing's intensified efforts to court Taiwan's allies, Lo said Chen's trip has contributed to consolidating ties with the ROC's allies.

He said that although some people criticized the timing of Chen's trip, the fact that he managed to embark on an overseas visit after being in office for less than three months manifests the ROC's political stability following its first democratic transition of power between different political parties.
Moreover, Lo went on, Chen's good rapport with the grassroots that was illustrated throughout the trip has won recognition from the ROC's allies.
"The six-leg journey has also allowed Chen to forge personal friendships with foreign leaders and to gain a better understanding of the work situation of our diplomatic corps," Lo added.
Legislators of different political stripes generally recognized Chen's efforts to bolster the ROC's relations with its allies and to upgrade Taiwan's international profile.

Legislator Fan Yang-sheng of the opposition Kuomintang said Chen's trip was an overall success. "In addition to winning the friendship of foreign allies, Chen has helped boost the morale of our agricultural and medical service missions in those countries," he added.

However, some lawmakers, including several of those from Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), criticized the new government for failing to use "new thinking" to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic embargo against Taiwan.

DPP Legislator Parris Chang claimed it is not enough that the new government seeks only to defend the achievements made by the previous KMT administration. He also cast doubt on the government's promise to honor all aid offers or plans made by its predecessor.

Chang said the new government should not follow the previous KMT administration's "money diplomacy" tactics and should instead use "new thinking" to work out new strategies to expand the ROC's diplomatic frontiers.

He said the new government must also tighten the tracking and supervision of all existing aid programs to ensure their effectiveness and prevent any irregularities in the conducting of any foreign aid project.

Chang also criticized the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' failure to protest against what he described as unreasonable US restrictions on the president's activities during his overnight transit stay in Los Angeles on his way to the Dominican Republic, the first leg of his overseas visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY MIGRATES TO MAINLAND CHINA (2)

TEXT.P: Despite their unanimous opinion that there is no hurry for Taiwan's semiconductor industry to shift their production lines to the mainland, leading chip manufacturers in Taiwan are watching closely the moves taken by their foreign peers.

So far, the mainland's semiconductor sector still lags far behind, partially because Beijing is on the list of countries subject to a US hi-tech export embargo. Its prospective entry into the World Trade Organization will help the mainland to obtain technology and equipment and this will accelerate the development of its hi-tech industries. Well aware of this change of climate, foreign investors are keen to enter the mainland hi-tech sector.
Several multinational corporations already have plans to introduce to the mainland the 0.25 micro technology applied to eight-inch integrated circuit (IC) chip production.

The 0.25 micro technology is much more advanced than the 0.35 micro technology, the highest level currently existing in the mainland. Most of the chip factories there are producing six-inch IC chips using 0.8 micro-1.0 micro technology.

WTO membership, the lifting of the hi-tech embargo by the United States, and a large number of well-trained electronics engineers have created an advantageous environment for mainland China to elevate its electronics industry. Taiwan's IC sector is well aware of the importance getting a toehold in the mainland market before their Western counterparts.

Since the government has not yet relaxed its restrictions on upstream electronics manufacturers' investments in the mainland, investors need to seek detours and at least two industrialists in Taiwan have made contact for preparations to establish eight-inch IC chip factories in Shanghai.

However, capital investment for an eight-inch IC chip factory in the mainland is estimated at over US$1 billion and local chip manufacturers are still hesitant over making such a big investment on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

One industrial analyst suggested that Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturers interested in migration to the mainland might set up packaging and testing facilities there in the initial stage and expand to IC design at a later date. In fact, among the new IC packaging and testing plants in mainland China, two are operating with Taiwan capital.

Executives of IC manufacturers in the past few months have been frequent visitors to the mainland market, although several major manufacturers have said recently that they have no immediate plans to move their IC production lines there.

The manufacturers are watching developments closely. With the maturing of the downstream assembling, components and peripherals sectors, it is only natural for the upstream semiconductor suppliers to move their production lines and distribution centers closer to the market, but the timing depends on when the government will lift its ban on such investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR FACING TRIAL ON CORRUPTION CHARGES
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Tainan prosecutors announced on Friday that they had amassed sufficient evidence to secure a conviction for Tainan City Mayor Chang Tsan-hung on corruption charges.

Chang, who was formerly a key figure in the promotion in the United States of Taiwan Independence, is suspected of negligence while serving as Tainan mayor for his part in large-scale bribery and bid-rigging over a canal project in the southern city.
Prosecutors recommended that Chang be sentenced to a 12-year prison term and that he be stripped of his civil rights for a further 10 years.
Chang, 64, who holds a doctorate in chemical engineering from Rice University in the United States, was elected mayor of Tainan in 1997.

The prosecutors said they are also seeking a 15-year term, a 10-year disenfranchisement and a NT$20 million fine for Tung Mei-chen, believed to the mastermind behind the scandal surrounding the NT$500 million project.

According to the prosecutors, Tung, director of the Tainan City Urban Development Bureau, conspired with city government advisers Hsu Cheng-hsiung, Yuan Hua-lun and Hsieh Ching-sung to invite Japanese construction company Nikken Industrial to participate in bidding for the canal reconstruction project.

After Nikken agreed to pay NT$5 million to "grease the wheels," Tung, who was officially in charge of the project, arranged for Nikken to be made the priority choice in an open bid for the project, which included the building of several bridges and extensive tree-planting along the banks of the canal.
According to other city government officials who said the whole project had appeared fishy from the very start, the whole process was flawed and biased in every respect.
Hsu was recommended to face a jail sentence of 13 years, while advisers Yuan and Hsieh face jail sentence of 12 years each.

Three local representatives of the Japanese company, identified only as Sato, Isemura and Murakami, will also face jail sentences of between two and three years for their involvement in the scandal, if the prosecutors are successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOUTH OF BIG UNDERSEA HOT SPRING DISCOVERED OFF TAIWAN COAST

TEXT.P: The mouth of a high-temperature undersea hot spring discovered recently in waters near Taiwan confirms the belief of an oceanographic geologist that a big shallow undersea hot spring, probably the largest on earth, is located to the northeast of the island.

Prof. Chen Chen-tung of National Sun Yat-sen University said he and his research team found the chimney-like opening of an undersea hot spring earlier this month only a few dozen meters off Gueishan (Turtle Hill) Island, off the northeastern Taiwan city of Ilan.
The hot spring mouth has a diameter of about four meters, stands six meters tall and is located about 20 meters below sea level.

In April last year, Chen and his researchers found Taiwan's first undersea hot spring, also near Gueishan. The spring, which was unrecorded in any local historical or geological archives, consisted of eruptions of billowing steam mixed with sulfur fumes, with temperatures as high as 102 degrees Celsius, Chen said.

In an attempt to prove that a group of undersea hot springs actually exist to the northeast of Taiwan, Chen and his researchers set up several thermometers in the area to record the temperature variations, but they soon "disappeared."
Undaunted, Chen and his team continued their undersea research and finally discovered the big mouth of the undersea hot spring.

Chen, who was contracted by Taiwan Power Company to probe the undersea area offshore from a nuclear power plant located in northeastern Taiwan and examine the influence of the plant's discharged water on the nearby ocean, said his main mission is to find out whether or not heavy metal pollution in the waters near Gueishan Island is caused by natural elements brought about by the eruptions from the undersea hot springs.
He said his discovery may help detect tectonic plate activity and eventually contribute to earthquake prediction.
The professor said before the Gueishan discovery, only Japan and Italy have reported discoveries of undersea hot springs.
He said he felt that similar undersea hot springs should be found in the Taiwan area, which is located on the Pacific Rim, or "ring of fire," where oceanic tectonic plates are exceptionally active.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SENDS CONDOLENCES TO RUSSIA OVER KURSK DEATHS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has extended condolences to Russia over the death of 118 crewmen of the submarine Kursk which exploded and sank in the Barents Sea on Aug. 12.

Chang Neng-tien, director of the West Asian Affairs Department under the MOFA, said at a Friday press conference that a message of sympathy had been sent via the ROC representative office in Moscow and also via a telephone call to the Russian representative office in Taipei.
Chang said that the MOFA will also convey the same message in a formal letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECONOMIC MINISTER CHEN ARRIVES IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Minister Chen Ruey-ron arrived in Panama Thursday for a two-day visit.

Chen, accompanied by a seven-member entourage, will call on Panamanian Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Enrique Jacome on Friday to exchange views on economic and trade ties between the Republic of China and Panama. Chen will also visit Panama's Colon Free Trade Zone and Fort Davis Export Processing Zone.

Chen will proceed from Panama to Guatemala City where he will attend a meeting with the economic ministers of five Central American countries scheduled to open on Saturday. Chen will exchange views with his Central American counterparts on how to strengthen economic cooperation among the nations.

The five Central American countries attending the meeting, along with Panama and some South American nations, are expected to complete their negotiations on a trade zone treaty soon, and Chen's visit is seen as further cementing economic ties between the ROC and this part of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO STOP PERSECUTING CHRISTIANS IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Chinese Fangcheng Church, whose 130 members were arrested earlier this week, urged Chinese President Jiang Zemin Friday to stop cracking down on underground churches in China and release all arrested members of the church immediately.

The underground church in Xihua county in northern Henan province said in an open letter to Jiang, which was sent through the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, that Fangcheng is a normal Christian church and that its members are moderate worshipers of God.

The information center said the church also expressed the hope that leaders in the free world will help secure the release of the arrested church members, especially during the time when Jiang attends a world religious conference in New York in early September.

Fangcheng is called an underground church, because it is not sanctioned by the communist government. Also arrested on Aug. 23 with the church members were three American missionaries, who were reportedly released on Friday. The church was outlawed in 1999 as an "evil cult" by the Chinese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILIS CAUSES LOSSES OF US$132 MILLION IN AGRICULTURAL SECTOR
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Strong winds and heavy rain spawned by Typhoon Bilis have caused losses worth more than NT$4.1 billion (US$132 million) in Taiwan's agricultural sector, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Friday.
COA officials said the figure includes NT$4.01 billion-worth of crop losses, NT$36 million in damaged farmland and NT$74 million in the livestock industry.
Taitung County topped the list of hardest-hit counties in the latest report, followed by Hualien County, with both suffering losses exceeding NT$900 million.

The officials said that farmers in Taichung, Nantou, Kaohsiung, Hualien and Ilan counties are eligible for cash bailouts and low-interest loans, with the cash bailouts to be paid out within one month, while farmers in Hsinchu, Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties can apply for loans at a special low interest rate of 4.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE OFFERS TO HAND OVER SAFE TO PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force offered Friday to hand over to prosecutors a safe belonging to an arms broker involved in the controversial death of a navy captain in 1994.

Air Force General Headquarters said in a statement that they had asked the Taipei District Court for permission to relieve itself of the safe reportedly owned by Shan Yi-cheng that is believed to hold clues to the death of Capt. Yin Ching-feng.

The air force issued the statement after opposition legislator Lee Ching-hua went public with allegations that the air force had the safe and asked air force authorities to hand it over to prosecutors charged with investigating Yin's death.

The air force admitted that it had the safe, but said it had been asked by the Taipei District Court to keep it. The safe had been left in air force quarters vacated by Shan after investigators raided it following the death of Yin, who was chief of the navy's weaponry acquirement program in 1994.

Shan left Taiwan after 1994 but was brought back in July this year after being detained in Hong Kong for illegal entry. He has been detained by the Taipei District Court in an unrelated case since his return, but prosecutors want to question him over his role in death of Yin, whose body was found on Dec. 9, 1994 after he had threatened to go public with irregularities in the navy's arms purchases.

The probe into Yin's death has picked up new momentum after President Chen Shui-bian, fed up with the military's fruitless seven-year investigation, ordered the establishment of an ad hoc panel on July 31 to get to the bottom of the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO FINALIZE TYPHOON RELIEF WORK SOON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged on Friday to complete typhoon-related rehabilitation work in one month.
Chen made the promise during an inspection tour of a grassroots community in Puli in the central Taiwan county of Nantou, which was seriously hit by typhoon-driven rainstorms earlier this week.

Chen cut short of his first post-inauguration overseas visit and returned to Taiwan Friday afternoon because of his concern about the damage caused by typhoon Bilis which swept over the island from Tuesday evening through Wednesday.

Chen, accompanied by Premier Tang Fei, took a flight aboard Taiwan's "Air Force One" presidential plane to central Taiwan immediately after he got off a chartered commercial airliner that took him on his six-state overseas visit and returned to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan at 2:50 p.m.
Chen expressed his sorry for failing to stay with all fellow countrymen when the powerful typhoon, the strongest to hit Asia so far this year, ripped through Taiwan.

When he was still on visit in Africa, Chen said, he was very concerned whether Nantou County residents could withstand the severe test of typhoon Bilis after they had endured a devastating earthquake last September and a series of follow-up mudslide disasters.

After seeing many temporary houses in the Niuwei community partially destroyed by the typhoon, Chen said the government will offer the most lenient subsidies to typhoon victims. The Niuwei community was built after the 921 earthquake to accommodate quake victims.

Chen recognized the concerted efforts made by Premier Tang and all relevant government agencies to minimize the typhoon damage. "Thanks to appropriate precautionary measures, we have managed to largely minimize the typhoon-related damage," he said.

The president also expressed his gratitude for military servicemen, police and firefighting officers for their contribution to emergency rescue and relief operations. "I also hope all troops, policemen and firemen will continue their efforts to complete rehabilitation work as soon as possible."

Typhoon Bilis wreaked havoc on the island, leaving at least 11 people dead, five missing and more than 100 others injured. It also destroyed or partially damaged some 2,000 houses around the island. Agricultural and fishery losses were estimated at NT$4.1 billion (US$132.26 million).

Chen directed the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture to offer the best possible subsidies to farmers and fishermen affected by the typhoon in line with relevant government regulations within a month.

Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien told President Chen that the county government already gave NT$10,000 (US$322.58) to each victim in the Niuwei community in the wake of typhoon. The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has also promised to help repair all damaged temporary houses in the community within two weeks, Peng said.

Chen said he had given three phone calls to Premier Tang during his visit in Africa to get the latest typhoon-related information. Chen also telephoned Vice President Annette Lu, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming and Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who concurrently served as convener of the national emergency rescue center, to ask for their assistance in disaster prevention and rescue missions.

Chen's 12-day, six-state "journey of friendship" took him to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central American and three African nations -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad. The visit was designed to signify the ROC's first peaceful, democratic transition of power and to cement the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PLANE MAKERS CAPABLE OF UPGRADING 2ND-GENERATION PLANES: AIDC

TEXT.P: Local aeronautical engineers and manufacturers are capable of upgrading the combat capability of Taiwan's second-generation jet fighters, a senior official of the Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC) said on Friday.

Saying that the capability extends to all the fighters in the ROC fleet, including the Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF), the F-16 and the Mirage 2000, AIDC Board Chairman Tsai Tsun-hui also expressed confidence over the future of Taiwan's aerospace industry.
Tsai made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the National Defense Industrial Development Foundation and held in Taipei.

However, he also expressed worry about the future of the aerospace industry in global terms, which he said was in a worldwide decline, but he stressed that local aerospace industrial development will still have a brilliant future if it can sustain itself for another two years.
Addressing the government's appropriation of NT$1 billion for upgrading the combat capability of the country's IDF fighters, Tsai said that the project has not yet been implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT EXPRESSES SYMPATHY OVER TYPHOON BILIS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso cabled President Chen Shui-bian of the Republic of China on Thursday to express sympathy over the damage caused in Taiwan by Typhoon Bilis two days earlier.
Acting Foreign Minister Harmodia Arias Cerjack also sent a message of sympathy to ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hong-mao on behalf of Foreign Minister Jose Aleman, who was in Tokyo on an official visit.
Both Moscoso and Arias also asked ROC Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-min to convey their sympathies to the Taiwan leadership.

The Panamanian head of state also expressed the hope that the people of Taiwan will soon overcome the difficulties caused by the typhoon that left 11 people dead, more than 100 people injured and caused millions of dollars-worth of property damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VISIT BY SINGAPORE ELDER STATESMAN WILL NOT CONVEY MESSAGE: MAC

TEXT.P: A Republic of China official said Friday that Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew is not expected to act as an intermediary between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait when he visits Taipei in September.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman and spokesman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that Lee has been concerned about cross-strait problems for a long time, but he stressed that the differences between Taiwan and mainland China should be resolved by the two sides through dialogue and communication.
Lin also pointed out that the MAC is not organizing Lee's visit to Taipei and is not responsible for arranging his itinerary.
He was responding to press reports that Lee will make a personal visit to coincide with the local release of his memoirs, and to speculation that Lee will meet with President Chen Shui-bian.
Foreign Ministry officials said they had not received any information related to Lee's Taipei visit and had not arranged any activities for him.

Meanwhile, Lin also indicated that the MAC would not comment on whether the Guidelines for National Unification should be amended, or on whether Chen should serve concurrently as chairman of the National Unification Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE GOLFER MAINTAINS LEAD IN SECOND ROUND OF ROCPGA

TEXT.P: Japan's Daisuke Maruyama shot a six under par 66 to maintain his lead with a two-day total of 131 in the second round of the 2000 ROCPGA golf tournament being held at the Tong Hwa Golf & Country Club course in suburban Taipei on Friday.
England's Simon Dyson carded a four-under par 68 for a two-day total of 135, tying for second place with US player Gary Rusnak.
Local player Hsu Mong-nan shot a six-under 66 to rank fourth with a two-day total of 138.

Felix Casas of the Philippines was a stroke behind Hsu with a two-day total of 139, along with India's Jyoti Randhawa (70-69), Japan's Taku Yamanaka (70-69), Boonchu Rusangkit of Thailand (69-70), Thongchai Jaidee, also from Thailand (69-70), and local golfer Lin Fu-chin (68-71).

Those who finished with a two-day total of 140 were Ecuador's Rafael Ponce (72-68), Taiwan's Lin Chih-chen (70-70), Gerald Rosales of the Philippines (70-70), Kuo Chie-hsiung of Taiwan (70-70), Mardan Mamat of Singapore (70-70), Lin Keng-chi of Taiwan (69-71), Japan's Masato Endo (69-71), Taiwan's Tseng Wen-chi (69-71), Thailand's Prayad Marksaeng (68-72) and Hsieh Chin-sheng of Taiwan (67-73).
A total of 70 players will advance to the third and final round of the US$300,000 tourney which opened on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP ISSUES 6-POINT STANCE ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition People First Party (PFP) issued a lengthy report Friday on its basic views and stances on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
PFP Chairman James Soong, a former Taiwan governor and ROC government spokesman, personally unveiled the report at a news conference.

Soong, who lost his presidential bid with a narrow range in the March 18 presidential election, said he hopes the new ROC government will refer to the report in formulating a new cross-strait policy that complies with the common interests of all residents in Taiwan.
The report outlined the PFP's basic stances on cross-strait relations as follows:

-- Residents in Taiwan are both Taiwanese and Chinese; both sides of the Taiwan Strait are parts of the "whole China" in historical, cultural and geographical terms; but Taiwan is by no means part of the "People's Republic of China";

-- The call for "Taiwan secession" would hurt ethnic feelings of the people on both sides, hinder the development of mutually beneficial economic relations across the Taiwan Strait, and make it even more difficult to maintain cross-strait balance and peaceful co-existence;

-- The PFP does not rule out the possibility of multi-integration between the two sides so long as the free will of all Taiwan residents are fully respected; nevertheless, the party would never accept the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification formula.
The report also offered some suggestions for the future development of cross-strait ties:

-- The two sides should forge a "peace framework" based on the 1992 consensus, sign a "peace agreement" under this mechanism, set up a "military buffer zone" and promise not to use force to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait;

-- The two sides should establish direct dialogue channels for talks on economic, banking, agricultural and transportation affairs to boost constructive interaction and protect the rights of Taiwan investors on the mainland;

-- After both sides join the World Trade Organization (WTO), they should push for direct trade, mail and transportation links based on the principles of "dignity, parity, security and reciprocity" and boost economic cooperation by setting up "free trade zone," "customs alliance" and "common market";
--Mainland China should stop blocking Taiwan's bid to join the WTO and other international economic, cultural and sports organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP UNVEILS GUIDELINES ON ITS MAINLAND CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) on Friday unveiled the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
On the eve of the departure of its legislative caucus for a trip to the mainland, the party also called on Beijing to pursue peace with Taiwan on the basis of a consensus reached in 1992.

Refusing to take sides in the long-standing argument between Taiwan's pro-reunification and pro-independence forces, PFP leader James Soong took pains to position his party as "pragmatic" in terms of its approach toward the mainland.

Soong pointed out in a statement issued by the PFP that the resolution of the disputes between Taiwan and mainland China lies in respect for the will of the people of Taiwan, awareness of the mainland's transformation and knowledge of the international political reality.

According to the statement, the PFP believes that both Taiwan and mainland China are parts of a reunited China, that the Republic of China is a sovereign state, and that both Taipei and Beijing are legitimate regimes which govern effectively within their own jurisdictions.

At a press conference called to announce the statement, Soong claimed that most of Taiwan's people emigrated from mainland China, and that the long history of living together has given rise to a sense of unique identity among them, no matter when they arrived on the island.
This unique "Taiwan sense" demands that "Taiwan's interests be given top priority," which is why the pro-reunification advocates cannot win the support of the majority, he continued.

On the other hand, Soong said he felt that the pro-independent forces on the island have ignored the transformation that the mainland is undergoing, in particular Beijing's forthcoming admission to the World Trade Organization and its full integration into the global economy.
Like it or not, he said, Taiwan will be exposed to the ramifications of Beijing's economic and political transformation, and should carefully assess its impact on the island before responding.

Noting that the international political situation will inevitably influence Taiwan's dealings with the mainland, Soong blamed the government for what he called its "wait and see" approach to Beijing. Instead, he went on, the government should stay abreast of the stances of the major powers on the issue of Taiwan and take advantage of any favorable circumstances to deal with Beijing.

The conflict between Taiwan and the mainland is neither ethnic nor nationalist in character, but rather one that stems from different political systems and thereby should be eliminated through economic cooperation, according to Soong.
He urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue on the basis of the consensus reached during 1992, which he described as "one China de jure, and two administrations de facto."
The 1992 consensus led to the first official dialogue between the two sides in Singapore in 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES GOVERNMENT'S FY 2001 GENERAL BUDGET PLAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed the central government's fiscal 2001 general budget plan at its weekly meeting on Friday.
The central government's fiscal 2001 revenues in the general budget are set at NT$1,458.5 billion, an increase of NT$98.1 billion, or an annual growth of 7.2 percent compared with fiscal 2000.
Fiscal 2001 revenues account for 13.6 percent of the island's gross national product (GNP), compared with 13.7 percent in fiscal 2000.

Offsetting the central government's fiscal 2001 revenues with the expenditures in the general budget, there appears a shortfall of NT$149.7 billion, compared with a NT$152.8 billion shortfall in fiscal 2000.

This shortfall, plus NT$255.7 billion in due debt principals, will make a total shortfall of NT$403.6 billion, which the government plans to replenish by issuing government bonds, making use of budget surpluses accumulated in previous fiscal years, as well as making use of the debt fund.

Premier Tang Fei said that because a new law governing the allocation of government revenues and expenditures attributes to local governments several tax resources that originally belonged to the central government, it will be more difficult for the central government to raise funds to pay for major national development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS SEEK TO DETAIN KMT LAWMAKER IN CORRUPTION CASE

TEXT.P: Prosecutors said Friday that they are seeking court permission to detain Kuomintang Legislator Wang Ling-lin in connection with a case of corruption.

Wang, the son of business tycoon and head of Rebar Group Wang You-tseng, was grilled by prosecutors for his role in the sale of a tract of land by his company -- Far East Silo (FES) -- to the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC), a listed corporation, in 1999.

The prosecutors suspect Wang of conspiring with TDC directors to inflate the price of the land, which was bought by FES in 1998 for NT$850 million (US$27.41 million) and sold a year later to TDC for NT$1.82 billion (US$58.7 million), to the detriment of TDC shareholders.
Wang argued that the price is reasonable and offered to cancel the deal and return the money to TDC if TDC shareholders refused to accept the deal.
The case went public earlier this year after TDC shareholders found out about the high price charged by FES for the land.

DOC.TEXT:
