DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S APPROVAL RATING UP IN WAKE OF OVERSEAS VISIT: POLL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's approval rating has risen 4 percent following his first post-inauguration overseas visit, according to the results of a public opinion poll released on Saturday.
The telephone poll of 857 adult residents randomly selected from around the island was conducted by the Chinese-language United Daily News (UDN) Friday evening.

Poll results show that 64 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with President Chen's performance, up 4 percent from the level recorded in a similar UDN survey conducted on the eve of his departure for his six-state "journey of friendship".

According to the same tallies, the percentage of those discontent with Chen's performance declined to 25 percent to 30 percent. And 11 percent said they have no special opinion about Chen's performance.

Chen left Taipei Aug. 13 to start his globe-trotting journey aimed at bolstering the Republic of China's relations with its diplomatic allies. The visit took him to the Caribbean nation of Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America and three African states -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

Chen was originally scheduled to return Saturday, but he decided to cut short his stay in Chad after a strong typhoon wreaked havoc in Taiwan. Chen returned a day early on Friday and immediately traveled to Nantou to inspect several typhoon-damaged residential communities in the central county.

The UDN poll found that 36 percent support Chen's early return, but 49 percent said they think that Chen should have completed his diplomatic tour as originally scheduled. Fourteen percent didn't answer the question.

In the wake of Chen's first diplomatic tour, the ratio of people dissatisfied with the ROC's current diplomatic situation declined 5 percent to 39 percent, while the percentage of those satisfied with the situation increased 6 percent to 38 percent.
However, the UDN poll found that 70 percent of the respondents couldn't fully identify the countries that Chen had visited.

Meanwhile, 71 percent of those interviewed said they are satisfied with the Cabinet's performance in coping with typhoon Bilis which swept over the island Tuesday evening through Wednesday morning and left at least 11 people dead. Only 10 percent gave a negative evaluation of the Cabinet's anti-typhoon measures.
In addition, 67 percent said they think that the premier should personally inspect typhoon-affected regions.
Asked whether the president needs to inspect typhoon-affected areas, 54 percent said "yes," while 35 percent said they see no need for the president to make such kind of inspection tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO IMPOSE POLITICAL BARRIER TO '3 LINKS'

TEXT.P: Mainland China should not impose any political barrier to the proposed opening of direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait, a senior mainland affairs official said Saturday.

Jan Jyh-horng, director of the Research and Planning Department of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, was responding to mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen's remarks on the "three links" issue.

Qian said during a meeting with a delegation from Taiwan's United Daily News (UDN) press group that the opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links "could be easily resolved under the 'one China' principle."
As Beijing's "one China" principle downgrades the Republic of China's sovereign status, Jan said, Qian's remarks were tantamount to setting a political barrier to opening the "three links."
Without the removal of political barriers, Jan said, the two sides cannot sit down to discuss technical issues regarding the opening of direct cross-strait "three links."

Noting that the ROC government has drawn up a timetable for opening direct "three links," Jan said the realization of the opening plan hinges on whether mainland China can face up to the reality and resolve practical problems in a pragmatic manner.

Jan further said the MAC is always ready to open talks with the mainland on practical "three links" issues. "We hope mainland China can deal with economic topics, such as the 'three links' issue, based on the principle of reciprocity," Jan said, adding that mainland China should not reject talks simply for political purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ALLEGEDLY INVOLVED IN FRAUD CASE RELEASED ON BAIL

TEXT.P: Taipei district prosecutors said Saturday that they will appeal against Taipei District Court's early morning decision to release on bail a lawmaker allegedly involved in a real estate deal suspected to be fraudulent.

On Friday, opposition Kuomintang legislator Wang Ling-lin became the first lawmaker under the new Democratic Progressive Party administration against whom a formal petition has filed to be held incommunicado, which usually suggests that a prosecutor wants to be certain the accused will not have the opportunity to destroy evidence or influence potential witnesses.

Wang, the son of business tycoon Wang You-tseng, head of Rebar Group, was released on NT$15 million (US$483,000) bail following a 4:50 a.m. court decision that there is little risk of Wang destroying any evidence as "the prosecutors already know where most of the money went."

Taipei Prosecutor Weng Hung-tsai and Prosecutor-General Huang Shih-ming expressed their disappointment over the district court's ruling and said that they will appeal the decision. However, because the Legislature will again be in session starting Sept. 1, Wang will be protected by the Republic of China Constitution from any court summons, arrest, or prosecution until the next legislative recess, they added.

Wang had been charged with breach of trust and falsifying documents for his alleged role in the sale of a tract of land owned by his company, Far Eastern Silo and Shipping (FESS), to the state-run Taiwan Development and Trust Corp. (TDTC), in 1999.

The prosecutors suspect Wang, who is chairman of FESS, of conspiring with TDTC directors to inflate the price of the land, which FESS had bought in early 1998 for NT$845 million (US$27.2 million). FESS developed the property and sold it to TDTC a year later for NT$1.82 billion (US$58.6 million).

Wang argued that the price was reasonable and offered to cancel the sale and return the money if TDTC shareholders refused to accept the deal. The case went public earlier this year after TDTC shareholders found out about the high price charged by FESS for the land.

Prosecutors also grilled Wang over some NT$189 million in possible kickbacks that went through several personal accounts before being deposited into his Chung Ting Co. on the same day that FESS first signed the contract to buy the tract of land.
Investigations also showed that FESS may have paid some NT$300 million less than the reported original purchase price of NT$845 million, prosecutors said.
Wang denied the allegations of fraud and said that the transferred funds were actually a loan to an old friend.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INSPECTS TYPHOON-AFFECTED EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Saturday made an inspection tour of the eastern Taiwan counties of Taitung and Hualien, both of which were hit hard by a strong typhoon earlier this week.
President Chen first inspected Taitung County's Tungho Village, which is known for its fruit production. Chen looked somber when he saw many fruits on the ground of a large orchard in the village.

"It's a heart-rending sight," said Chen, the son of a farmer from southern Taiwan. "I will ask relevant agricultural administration agencies to hand out disaster relief money to all farmers within one month to compensate their typhoon-induced losses."

Noting that Taiwan has often been hit by earthquakes and typhoons, Chen said all local residents should not be daunted by such natural disasters and should adopt comprehensive precautionary measures to minimize the possible damage.
Among post-typhoon rehabilitation work, Chen said priority should be given to resumption of normal power and water supplies to meet the people's basic living demand.

Typhoon Bilis, the strongest storm to hit Asia so far this year, ripped through Taiwan Tuesday night, leaving at least 11 people dead, several others missing and many private homes and public facilities destroyed or damaged. Initial tallies also show that agricultural losses in Taitung County alone were estimated at NT$1.2 billion (US$38.71 million).
Accompanied by Taitung County Magistrate Chen Chien-nien, President Chen later inspected a breakwater in Chengkung township where the nucleus of typhoon Bilis swept over.

The Paishoulien breakwater, which was built decades ago to protect the coast from ocean waves, was damaged by strong winds. Chen ordered relevant government agencies to complete repair and rehabilitation work as soon as possible to ensure safety of residents in the coastal region.
President Chen then traveled to the neighboring county of Hualien to inspect damaged roads, railway, farms, electricity and water supply facilities and collapsed houses in the region.
Hualien County Magistrate Wang Ching-feng briefed Chen on the typhoon damage and progress in rehabilitation work and funds needed for various relief programs.

After listening to Wang's briefing, Chen directed Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang to offer typhoon-affected regions all necessary assistance and subsidies.
Chen later toured a railway repair project in neighboring Kuangfu village to express his appreciation of the contribution of railway engineers and workers to rehabilitation work.
Chen said he has directed all government agencies to work hard in order to complete typhoon-related rehabilitation work in one month.
Chen also expressed his sorry for failing to stay with all fellow countrymen when the powerful typhoon hit the island. At that time, Chen was on a state visit in the African state of Chad.

Chen recognized the concerted efforts made by Premier Tang Fei and all relevant government agencies to minimize the typhoon damage. "Thanks to appropriate precautionary measures, we have managed to largely minimize the typhoon-related damage," he said.
The president also expressed his gratitude for military servicemen, police and firefighting officers for their contribution to emergency rescue and relief operations.

Chen cut short his first post-inauguration overseas visit because of his concern about the typhoon damage. He wasted no time after his return on Friday. Once his chartered plane landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, he got on another jetliner and flew to the central county of Nantou where a mudslide killed eight people during the storm.

Chen gave three phone calls to Premier Tang during his visit in Africa to get the latest typhoon-related information. Chen also telephoned Vice President Annette Lu, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming and Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who concurrently served as convener of the national emergency rescue center, to ask for their assistance in disaster prevention and rescue missions.

Chen's 12-day, six-state "journey of friendship" took him to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central American and three African nations -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad. The visit was designed to signify the ROC's first peaceful, democratic transition of power and to cement the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIS YEAR'S EUROPEAN TRADE FAIR WILL BE THE LAST: ORGANIZERS

TEXT.P: An ongoing European trade and tourism fair at the Taipei World Trade Center will not be held again next year due to budget constraints facing its local organizers, the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Economics Affairs, sources said Saturday.

Eurogate 2000, a four-day event bringing together 100 firms from Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Macedonia, Hungary, Lithuania, and Latvia, cost US$400,000, according to the Foreign Ministry's Department of European Affairs. Most of the funds went to air freight and shipping fees for the goods, customs fees, and exhibition hall decorations.

The department added that despite the success of Eurogate, which is now being held for only the second time, across-the-board cuts in the administrative budget will force the government to stop sponsoring the event.
Because last year's trade fair helped attending countries open up new markets and forge new trade ties with local buyers, some expressed regret at the news of the event's termination.
Poland dominates the trade fair floor this year, with more than 40 stalls displaying jewelry, amber, lamps, coffee, agricultural equipment, electronic goods and iron products.
Macedonia, which is taking part in the fair for the first time, has more than 30 booths featuring spirits, dairy products and agricultural products.

Czech firms are showcasing their stained crystal glassware and ceramics, while Hungarian companies are offering their wines, foie gras and honey. Slovenia was late in applying to take part in the show, and is consequently featuring only catalogues of its products.
Eurogate 2000 is open to the public free of charge from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day until Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHOIRS IN AUSTRALIA TO WELCOME OLYMPIC FLAME
DOC.DATELINE: Newcastle, Australia, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Anita Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Olympic Flame, currently on its way to Sydney, will arrive at the coastal city of Newcastle Sunday evening amid a performance of over 1,500 singers from around the world, including more than 200 from Taiwan.
The flame will share the stage with the singers before being carried by a torch runner to the next stop in its 188-city journey across Australia.
In celebration of the upcoming Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, hundreds of performance groups are in Australia to participate in Friendship Australia 2000, the festivities leading up to the games.

Professional and amateur choirs from Taiwan, Canada, the United States, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand, Bulgaria, England, India, and the Philippines will join with local singers to perform the Newcastle Anthem, "Ode to Joy," "Gloria" (the Olympic flame's theme song), "Amigos para Siempre," and "Sydney, Show Me the Life."

In preparing to welcome the flame, the symbol of the Olympic spirit, the singers said that they wake up at 6:30 a.m. every day and usually spend the day practicing together, recording, and performing their best songs for other groups as a part of cultural exchanges until late at night.

For some of the older singers from Taiwan, memorizing the English lyrics took up most of their free time, they said, adding that regardless of the exhausting practice, they are looking forward to performing in the Olympic flame's grand chorus.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REP. DAVID WU SENDS LETTER OF CONDOLENCE OVER TYPHOON

TEXT.P: Rep. David Wu (D-Ore.), the only Taiwan-born US congressman, has expressed his sympathy to the people of Taiwan for their sufferings caused by Typhoon Bilis, which swept across the island on Aug. 22 and Aug. 23.

"I hope in these challenging times you will find comfort in your communities, families and loved ones," the congressman wrote in a letter sent to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office here Thursday.

"As the first member of the US House of Representatives born in Taiwan, I feel an especially unique (tie) to the island. I take great pride that my former home has developed into an economically prosperous land and a vibrant democracy. I feel great sympathy for the suffering of the people of Taiwan through the destructive earthquake of September 21st, 1999, and the recent wrath of Super Typhoon Bilis," he wrote.
"Once again, please accept my deepest sympathy and condolences. Please know that I will keep the people of Taiwan in my thoughts and continue to pray for Taiwan's quick recovery," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ASKED TO LIFT THE BAN ON MEETINGS WITH TAIWAN OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives wrote a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright Friday, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
They also requested the State Department to immediately conduct a review of the Clinton administration's policy on visits by high-level Taiwanese officials to the United States.

"We are writing to express our disappointment at the State Department's restrictions on Taiwan's democratically-elected President, Chen Shui-bian, during his transit stop in Los Angeles this past weekend," the congressmen told Albright.

A number of Democratic and Republican members of Congress sought to meet privately with President Chen on Sunday, August 13. "Unfortunately, he was unable to attend the meeting due to pressure from the U.S. State Department," the officials said in the letter.

They pointed out that the United States has fought for democracy around the world and "is without a doubt the world's leading democracy as we enter the new century. Yet, when visiting the U.S., Taiwan's president was denied the basic rights of freedom of speech and freedom of assembly. The 23 million people of Taiwan have built a mature democracy over the past decade. We wanted to speak with President Chen about his country's accomplishments and its plan to support U.S. interests in Asia."
"U.S. policy toward China and Taiwan should be evenhanded," said the Democratic representatives.

"It is the responsibility of both sides of the Taiwan Straits to come to a mutually acceptable, peaceful resolution that has, as President (Bill) Clinton has repeatedly stated, the 'assent' of the people of Taiwan. Since Jiang Zemin comes to the U.S. to give his views, Chen Shui-bian and his ministers should have the same right," they added.

The seven Democratic congressmen who signed the letter are Sherrod Browne (Ohio), Robert Menedez (N.J.), Tim Holden (Pa.), David Wu (Ore.), Robert Wexler (Fla.), Peter Deutsch (Fla.), and Edolphus Towns (N.Y.).

Dr. Chen Wen-yen, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, said Friday, "We.....strongly hope -- since it is not only in the interest of Taiwan but also in the interest of the United States to communicate directly with elected and appointed top officials of Taiwan, including the President -- that next to this letter, legislation will be introduced when Congress returns in September calling for a complete lifting of all restrictions on high-level visits by these officials to the United States."

"The fact that the letter is signed by seven Democrats, significantly adds to the weight of the letter. This illustrates that the anger amongst Members of Congress about the fashion in which President Chen was treated in Long Beach is not merely a display of partisan politics but a sincere display of genuine frustration," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING REMAINS A REPRESSIVE REGIME: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Mainland China is not yet a full member of the international system and remains a repressive autocratic regime, a leading Australian expert recently said.

In an interview with The Australian Financial Review, Professor Stuart Harris, former head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and now most senior China expert at Australian National University in Canberra, described mainland China as "a dissatisfied status quo member."

Mainland China is dissatisfied because it is not yet a full member of the system, he said, noting that Beijing is still outside the World Trade Organization and feels it is not properly recognized as a major power.
He said mainland China is not a bomb-thrower seeking to overturn the system, and it will eventually become fully integrated and recognized in the international system.
But he also said mainland China is not yet an ideal state, because it remains a repressive autocratic regime.

The daily reported that President Jiang Zemin appears to have won the argument against the mainland's hawkish conservatives by getting them to agree that mainland China should be patient with Taiwan in its search for eventual reunification.
The recent meeting of mainland leaders at Beidaihe ended up with the leadership agreeing to refrain from any military action against Taiwan for at least five years, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HAS HARD TIME MAKING ENDS MEET: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Saturday that the government has a hard time making its ends meet because the existing budget law has failed to achieve desired efficacy since its enforcement.

Tang made the remarks at the opening of a two-day seminar on the government's current financial difficulties. The seminar, held at the mountain resort of Hsitou in the central county of Nantou, was organized by the Ministry of Finance with a view to pooling wisdom of officials, scholars, industry executives and parliamentarians to help resolve the government's budget deficit problems.

Tang said the government will inevitably rely on debts to make its ends meet over the next few years. "Improving the government's financial status is an urgent problem. I earnestly hope that the current seminar can help crank out measures to control government expenditure and create new financial sources in order to establish a sound government financing system," he noted.

The premier pointed out that the government's budget deficits are expected to swell in the next few years because of a combination of factors, including budget shortages of local-level governments, the planned implementation of a national pension system, reconstruction of the 921 earthquake-affect areas, infrastructure construction, military build-up and scientific, technological, cultural and educational development.

In addition to cutting government expenditure and expanding taxation base, Tang said, the government hopes to attract private investment in public infrastructure construction to help reduce financial burden of the national coffers.

Tang further said he hopes the ongoing seminar will focus discussion on three key directions -- helping establish a stable, non-barrier investment climate; improving the taxation system, expanding tax base and establishing a fair, reasonable taxation climate; and upgrading the efficacy of budget control, strengthening financial management and streamlining the budget allocation system.

This was the first large financial meeting since the Cabinet formed a special task force to facilitate formulation of sound financial and economic policies. The four-star-general-turned-premier said he will take part in all panel discussions in order to gain a better understanding of proposals presented by all participants.

The agenda for the two-day seminar include three major topics -- government debt management and financial sources for major administrative programs, such as the new national pension system and post-earthquake reconstruction projects; how to improve and rationalize the financial system of county and city governments; and how to upgrade efficacy of government spending and attract private investment in infrastructure construction.

More than 100 government officials, scholars, experts, parliamentarians, industry executives and local government representatives are attending the seminar to present their views and recommendations. The seminar will close on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER INSPECTS EARTHQUAKE RECONSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Saturday inspected the progress of the ad hoc committee tasked with post-quake reconstruction, instructing it to complete its work as soon as possible.

Chang pointed out five major focus areas in reconstruction efforts -- housing, work and education, mudslide prevention work, industry revival, and public construction. He encouraged the committee to face up to the challenge.

In his first visit to the central Taiwan county of Nantou since taking his current post Aug. 1, Chang encouraged the members of the committee -- of which he is deputy convener -- to put their best efforts into the reconstruction of the area.

He went on to say that it will not be easy to resolve some of the issues that come up during the process of reconstruction, because they are decades-old problems handed down from the past. However, this is a test for the new government, which must go all out to resolve the "deep-rooted illnesses," he added.
Last year's Sept. 21 temblor, which measured 7.3 on the Richter scale, claimed the lives of more than 2,400 people across Taiwan and wrought havoc in Nantou, where it was centered.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS COMPETE FOR TAIPEI CITY STREET CLEANER JOBS

TEXT.P: About 6,000 job seekers from around the island came to Taipei Saturday to be tested on their knowledge of the city's new garbage collection system, each hoping to land a job in the city's reserve street-cleaning team, which also collects garbage.

With only 300 open spots, many are destined to go home disappointed. However, Taipei's Employment Service Center (ESC) announced that on Monday and Tuesday, when the applicants will go through their physical tests, the center will concurrently offer 600 more job opportunities in cooperation with local enterprises.

According to ESC, about 3,000 of the applicants are Taipei City residents, 2,000 are Taipei County residents, 20 are from central Taiwan's disaster area -- which was struck by a killer earthquake last year -- while the rest are from as far as eastern and southern Taiwan.
Notably, about 400 applicants are vocational school graduates, while as many as 72 are university graduates.

ESC added that as long as the necessary documents are complete, the applicants from disaster regions and minority groups will be eligible to apply for transportation subsidies, which will be handed out on the spot.

After Saturday's written and oral examinations, the applicants will go through physical tests, including carrying 15-kilogram bags while running 40 meters back and forth. Test results will be announced in a month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN-BORN LINS IN THE SPOTLIGHT AT OLYMPIC ARTS FESTIVAL (I)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese artists, choreographer Lin Hwai-min and violinist Lin Cho-liang, were in the spotlight Friday at the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney, a precursor to the 2000 Olympic Games scheduled to begin in mid-September.

Lin Hwai-min, 53, is currently two productions -- "Nine Songs" and "Moonwater" -- with the Cloud Gate Dance Theater Company he founded in 1973. "Nine Songs" attracted huge audiences at Her Majesty's Theater in Sydney, where it was staged from Aug. 19 to 22.
The opening night of the second production -- "Moonwater" -- was even more successful, as it nearly drew a full house on Friday, according to organizers of the festival.

Meanwhile, violinist Lin Cho-liang, 40, enchanted an audience of about 1500 music lovers at the Sydney Opera House with his superb interpretations of pieces by Felix Mendelssohn and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
Lin Cho-liang played as a soloist accompanied by the 104-member Asian Youth Orchestra under the baton of Sergiu Comissiona, one of the most experienced and dynamic conductors in the world.
Art critics here have said that both Lins are superb artists in their fields.

The two Lins have several things in common. They were both born in Taiwan and are proud of their country. Both are striving to become perfect in their professions, thus winning a worldwide reputation as a result of their unswerving efforts.
The elder Lin has devoted about 27 years of his life to Cloud Gate, choreographing its performances to entertain people not only in Taiwan, but also many countries throughout the world.
The younger Lin has also devoted more than 20 years of his life to perfect his skills so that everywhere he goes, he can enchant his audiences with his interpretations of western classical music.

Both Lins strive to promote their birthplace and put Taiwan on the map through their efforts. Lin Hwai-min and his Cloud Gate Theater carry spread Taiwan's name through dancing, while Lin Cho-liang often speaks of his birthplace with his fans and has even brought home famous musicians, such as cellists Yo-yo Ma and Carter Brey and violinists Gil Shaham and Mark O'Connor, to take part in his brainchild -- the Taipei Chamber Music Festival.
Both Lins are inspirations to the younger generation in their respective fields, commentators said.
Even after reaching a global status, they continue to practice daily to develop their creativity in their own professions to entertain people throughout the world, they added.
"I still have to practice two to three hours a day so that I can maintain and even improve my skills," Lin Cho-liang said in an interview with the CNA.
He said the Taipei festival, which began last year, drew a large crowd, and the second festival in May this year attracted about 30,000 people.
"I plan to have another festival in two years so that I can bring more musicians and give more people in Taiwan a chance to enjoy their music," Cho-liang said.
Lin Cho-liang said no matter where he goes and lives, his heart will always be in Taiwan.

Lin Hwai-min said he was delighted very much to have more people to see the Cloud Gate performances because "our success can boost the international image of Taiwan" so that more and more people can know more about his birthplace. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN-BORN LINS (II)

TEXT.P: Lin Cho-liang said although the two artists' performances are at different venues in Sydney, watching Cloud Gate's dancers had given him the desire to foster future collaboration with Lin Hwai-min, whom he admires and respects very much.
"I hope our performances in Sydney will serve as a small step for future collaboration between Mr. Lin and myself, so that both Lins are highlighted on the same stage," he told CNA.
"I believe we could have some collaboration in the future," Lin said.
Lin Hwai-min said such a collaboration is possible, but both artists would need to discuss it extensively in the future. "I hope there will be such an opportunity some day," he added.
Lin Cho-liang told CNA that he would continue playing until he is 65 years old, meaning that he will perform for another 25 years.
Lin Hwai-min said he would try his best to continue creating new productions to spread Cloud Gate's global recognition as long as he can.
"If I can not continue, I will resign, and hopefully our new blood will carry on," he said. Lin declined to predict how long he would lead Cloud Gate.

After the Olympic Arts Festival, the first invitation to such an event for both Lins, they will continue their busy performing schedules in different countries. The younger Lin will go back to New York where he lives with his wife. He said he will prepare for touring concerts in the United States later this year, and then go back to Australia next year.

The elder Lin and his Cloud Gate Dance Theater will put on five performances in Auckland before returning to Taipei for a short break. He and his troupe will also visit Lyon and Berlin in mid-September to continue their performing journeys.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:

Legislator Wang Ling-lin released on NT$15 million bail and put under traveling restriction.
The China Times:

Court rejects bid to detain legislator.

Prosecutors accuse court of protecting Gary Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 27, or the 28th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Cheng Cheng-kung, a Ming dynasty general better known to Westerners as Koxinga, is born in Japan. He sailed his troops to Taiwan in 1661 with the hope of fighting his way back to mainland China after the fall of the mainland to invading Manchu troops. Although he never realized his dream, he succeeded in opening up Taiwan for Chinese settlement.
1770: George Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, the German philosopher who proposed that truth is reached by a continuing dialectic, is born.
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.ENDITEM ZCZC CEP003 08-27-00 TROPICAL STORM MIGHT THREATEN TAIWAN
Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) A tropical storm, the 12th of this year's typhoon season, is looming in the Pacific and might pose a threat to Taiwan in two days, said the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) Sunday.
Tropical Depression Prapiroon packed winds exceeding the 18-meter-per-second threshold of a tropical storm at 2:00 a.m. early Sunday. It was centered about 1,000 kilometers southeast of Taiwan, and was moving in a north-northwest direction.
Its tropical storm-force winds extend 180 kilometers from its center, and might pick up force and threaten Taiwan in the next two days, depending on air pressure conditions over the Pacific, said the forecasters.
If air pressure turns higher over the next two days -- which is very likely according to the current weather conditions -- Prapiroon will make landfall on northern Taiwan, said the CWB. Otherwise, it will swerve toward the East China Sea with only its outward spiraling air currents touching the island, said the forecasters.
Either way, the island will be affected by the storm's outward circling air currents in two days, so the CWB forecasts heavy rains for that time.
The island's weather was sunny with afternoon showers Sunday, said the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL UNIFICATION NOT ONLY OPTION: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said national unification is not the only option for Taiwan and the concept should be adjusted to conform to mainstream values.
Yen Chien-fa, director of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, made the remarks when he presented the result of a poll Sunday.

The poll showed that up to 90.5 percent of people in Taiwan do not agree with mainland China's statement that Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China and that it is not qualified to join the United Nations.

Some 72.9 percent of the people agreed with former President Lee Teng-hui's remarks that the Republic of China on Taiwan is a state, and not a province of the People's Republic of China; while 68.3 percent of those polled also said that the ROC should formally recognize the PRC as a country.

Yen said that experts and scholars on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should pay attention to the results of the survey, which shows that people in Taiwan have not dramatically changed their opinions on this issue over the long term.

Lan Shih-chung, director of the DPP's Taipei City Chapter, said that the establishment of the National Unification Council was aimed at soothing those who are pro-unification during the rule of the Kuomintang, the former ruling party. He said that the council should not become the burden of the DPP, and that his party has long held that the operation of the NUC should be adjusted.
Both Yen and Lan said the NUC's operation should be changed to conform with the public's views, but they also added that the council should not be scrapped at the present stage.

The poll also showed that 50.7 percent of the people think that the ties between Taiwan and the mainland are "special state-to-state relations," while 27.7 percent of the people believe that they are "normal international relations."
Lin Yi-hsiang, deputy director of the KMT's Committee of Policy Coordination, said that the results of the poll conformed to similar surveys in past years.

The poll found that three months after President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration in May, 20.4 percent of respondents said they hope that the status quo can be maintained for now and the island be unified with mainland China later, 37.6 percent said they hope to keep the status quo and decide later whether to unify with the mainland or declare independence, and 12.6 percent said they hope to maintain the status quo permanently.

Compared with a survey conducted in January, two months before the presidential election, the ratio of supporters of a permanent status quo is slightly lower, while those who want a rapid unification or independence has increased slightly.

The poll also showed that 73.7 percent of the people think that President Chen's recent visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa was helpful to promoting diplomacy, and that 76.5 percent of the people believed the trip has not increased cross-strait tensions.

The survey was conducted by Trendgo Survey Research Center at the commission of the DPP's Taipei City Chapter between Aug. 24-25 on people above 20 years of age. Some 1,033 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of three percent, the DPP said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRIDGE BETWEEN KAOHSIUNG AND PINTUNG COLLAPSES, DOZENS INJURED

TEXT.P: A highway bridge linking Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties collapsed suddenly Sunday afternoon, leaving dozens of people injured as 16 vehicles plunged into the river, said the police.

The incident took place at 3:21 p.m., according to police sources. Without any warning, a span under the bridge suddenly fell, causing a roughly hundred-meter section of the bridge to collapse, according local television footage.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC SERVICE TO REPLACE MILITARY SERVICE NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Young men in Taiwan will be able to opt for diplomatic jobs in 2002 as an alternative to the current two years of compulsory military service, according to a proposal put forward recently by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Conscripts who are trained experts in medicine or agriculture or who have good command of foreign languages will be able to choose to work for the MOFA or aid Taiwan's allies instead of serving in the armed forces, said Lo Chih-cheng, chairman of the Research and Planning Committee under the MOFA.

The diplomatic service is the brainchild of President Chen Shui-bian, who made it part of his campaign platform during the March presidential election. A draft plan worked out by the MOFA on the basis of Chen's idea calls for the selection of conscripts with special expertise to work for the ministry or aid Taiwan's allies as workers in non-governmental aid groups, said Lo.

In light of the fact that a large part of Taiwan's 29 allies are Francophone states in Africa, Lo said, military draftees with good command of French will be tapped by the MOFA to help it deal with African states, or else to be posted overseas to work as interpreters at Taiwan's agricultural or medical missions.

Owing to the fact that living conditions in many of Taiwan's African allies are harsher than those in Taiwan's two frontline islands, Kinmen and Matsu, draftees posted there should be compensated with better payment or shorter length of service than ordinary conscripts, said Lo.

Furthermore, it would be better if draftees assigned to overseas jobs would keep their civilian status rather than be considered as military personnel, given the sensitivity of host countries to the presence of foreign military, said Lo.

Taiwan introduced an alternative service to replace its compulsory military service this year, as previous years had seen too many draftees. About 6,000 conscripted men have been assigned on a voluntary basis to perform community service or help police to keep peace and order this year.
Those who work in the alternative services are still considered to be military personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL PENSION SCHEME NOT TO BE READY NEXT JANUARY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Sunday that the government will not be able to begin implementing the national pension scheme on Jan. 1, 2001, as had been originally planned.
Tang made the remarks at the closing of a two-day seminar on current financial problems in Nantou County, central Taiwan.

Participants in the seminar, while discussing the financing of the national pension scheme on Saturday, agreed on the principle of tax hikes, but said Sunday that additional taxes will not be the only source of funds for the program.
But Tang said Sunday that further discussion is needed on whether or not to raise taxes, adding that the national pension scheme involves many complex factors.

Tang noted that when the Legislature passed the national pension scheme, it agreed in principle that it would be implemented on Jan. 1, 2001. But as it is now already late August, there is not enough time to prepare for the pension's implementation, he said.

Meanwhile, Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien suggested in the seminar that Nantou County be authorized to issue lottery tickets to raise funds for reconstruction work in his home county, which born the brunt of last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

Tang said that the lottery idea also needs further study. He said the market for lotteries in Taiwan is very limited, and that it would not be profitable if too many lotteries were implemented at the same time.
He noted that the Ministry of Finance has already authorized the Bank of Taiwan to issue lottery scratch tickets, and there will be another lottery later, which he said would fill market demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEPS UP EFFORTS TO CRACK DOWN ON CHRISTIANS: REPORT

TEXT.P: China is stepping up efforts to crack down on Christians for fear that religious activities may grow out of control and threaten the stability of the atheistic government, a human rights group reported here Sunday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said that since the beginning of August Chinese police have arrested nearly 200 Christians in various parts of the country, including some 130 in Xihua county in Henan province, and more than 50 in Guangshui city in Hubei province, Yucheng county in Henan province, and Hejin city in Shanxi province. All of them were arrested on charges of attending "illegal meetings" of "evil cults."

Chinese official statistics showed that there are six million Catholics and 12 million Protestants in China. But the information center quoted experts as saying that the number of all Christians in the country is more than 40 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRIDGE BETWEEN KAOHSIUNG AND PINTUNG COLLAPSES, MORE THAN 20 INJURED

TEXT.P: A highway bridge linking Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties in southern Taiwan collapsed suddenly Sunday afternoon, leaving at least 20 people injured as five vehicles plunged into the river and another 16 were stranded on the sloping deck, said the police.
Most of the injured were rushed to hospitals in Pingtung County. Injuries included fractured bones and internal hemorrhaging, but none were fatal, said hospital sources.

Rescuers said they would continue searching the river bed for any possible missing vehicles or injured until evening. They have condoned off the multiple-span beam bridge after cracks began appearing on other sections of it.

The bridge collapsed at 3:21 p.m., according to police sources. Without any warning, a span under the bridge suddenly fell, causing a roughly hundred-meter section of the bridge to collapse, according local television footage.

The reinforced concrete Kaoping Bridge, named after the river it runs across, is part of the major outbound road in island's southernmost county of Pingtung. The bridge was built in 1978 and was a total of 1990 meters long.
Some of the bridges pier foundations were dangerously exposed to water currents after sand and grit nearby them were dug up illegally to use as construction materials, according to local reports.
Premier Tang Fei and Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan rushed to the scene shortly after learning about the incident.
President Chen Shui-bian issued a statement through his office to express his sympathy to the injured and vowed to pursue anyone found to be responsible for the collapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUBLICATION MISSION TO ATTEND BOOK FAIR IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A large-scale delegation from Taiwan will leave for Beijing via Hong Kong on Aug. 29 to attend the Eighth Beijing International Book Fair to be held from Aug. 30 to Sept. 3.

According to the Government Information Office (GIO), 35 Taiwan publishing companies will exhibit some 15,000 different books and publications at 44 booths during the fair, which will be held at the Beijing International Exhibition Center.
Exhibitors include the National Palace Museum, Lien Ching Publication Co., Times Cultural Publication Co. and Youth Cultural Enterprise.
Under the commission of the GIO, the Republic of China Books and Publications Association organized a 174-member delegation for the Beijing event.
Chao Yi-hung, director of the GIO's Publication Department, will join the delegation to get first-hand information on mainland China's publication industry.
He has no intention of making official contact with Beijing officials during the visit, but will attend a symposium on publication and copyright exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland on Aug. 30.
Chao will present a "Taiwan Publication Yearbook" to the mainland side for reference.
The Taiwan delegation will also meet with its mainland counterpart on Aug. 31 to exchange views on publication cooperation between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES VERY TENSE AFTER PRES. ELECTION: SEF OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Saturday that cross-strait relations once became very tense after the March 16 presidential election.

Shi Hwei-you, vice chairman and secretary general of the SEF, said that although the situation has been restored to normal, both Taipei and Beijing should seek a "middle way measure" to resolve the knotty issue of "one China."
Shi made these remarks at the 23rd Annual Meeting of the Taiwan Benevolent Association of America now being held in San Francisco.

He said that cross-strait relations descended into "unimaginable tension" as mainland fighters and warships crossed over or approached the middle line of the Taiwan Strait, which separates Taiwan and mainland China, after the election results were made known.
President Chen Shui-bian's announcement of the five "noes" in his inaugural message on May 20 has eliminated the misgivings of both mainland China and the United States, Shi went on.

Shi said that President Chen has stated that he will respect the spirit of the 1992 consensus reached between Taiwan and mainland China so as to attempt to resolve the deadlocked ties across the Taiwan Strait. The 1992 consensus left both sides agreeing on the respective interpretation of the "one China" principle.
Both Taipei and Beijing should positively seek a "middle way measure" to resolve the "one China" dispute, Shi added

Shi, who has participated in negotiations with Beijing under the Kuomintang Administration, called on Beijing to give up its hardline "three steps" policy toward Taiwan, which holds that there is one China, Taiwan is an inseparable part of it, and the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government of all of China.

Beijing's hardline policy will not only increase cross-strait tensions, but could also affect the admissions of Taipei and Beijing into international organizations such as the World Trade Organization(WTO), Shi added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST SOYBEAN CONSUMED IN TAIWAN IS 'GENE-MODIFIED': ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: Most of the soybeans used to make food in Taiwan are "gene-modified" (GM), but this vital information is invariably missing on the labels of related products, an environmentalist group said on Sunday.

Liu Ming-lung, secretary-general of the Qualitative Environment Fund, said at a press conference that ten of the soy product samples tested by the Fund, namely bean-curd and soybean-milk, were found to be made of GM soybeans.
Additionally, one of four bands of potato chips, US-imported Pink Potato Chips, also turned out to be made of GM crops.
Liu attributed the results to the island's imports of GM soybeans from the United States.

Although the Fund's test was not designed to check whether or not GM foods are safe, which might take generations to understand fully, consumers at least should be informed of what they are eating, said Liu.
He urged the government to oblige food manufacturers to reveal any GM ingredients on product labels, in order to allow consumers to choose for themselves whether or not they want to eat GM foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO DISSOLVE CROSS-STRAIT IMPASSE WITH FRIENDLY GESTURES
DOC.DATELINE: Newcastle, South Africa, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said he will break through the current cross-Taiwan Strait impasse by using friendly gestures.
Chen made the remark in a written congratulatory message to the 12th Congress of the Overseas Chinese Friendship Federation in the African Region held here Saturday.

Chen said that this is a crucial time for the development of cross-strait relations, and he will deal with cross-strait issues carefully in view of the fact that exchanges with Beijing are necessary to the ROC's national security and the stability of East Asia.
He said he will continue to promote exchanges between both sides of the Taiwan Strait in a bid to dissolve the impasse that is preventing smooth progress toward the unification of China.

Chen extended his respect and thanks to overseas Chinese for their long-standing support of the ROC. He added that he hopes overseas Chinese will continue to bring their influential strength to full play and help the ROC government promote bilateral ties in nations with overseas Chinese residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARUYAMA OF JAPAN CAPTURES 2000 ROCPGA TITLE

TEXT.P: Little-known Japanese golfer Daisuke Maruyama captured the 2000 ROCPGA title after completing the four-day round with a 17-under-par 271 at the Tong Hwa Golf and Country Club in Linkou, a suburb of Taipei.
He carded a one under par 71 on the final day of the competition and pocketed US$50,000 prize money for the title.
Thai player Prayad Marksaen came in second after finishing at 11 under par with a four-day total of 277.
Third prize went to Jyoti Randhawa of India, who completed the tournament at 278, 10 below par.
Gary Rusnak of the United States finished the four-day competition at a nine-under-par 279, good enough for fourth place.
Tying for fifth place were Craig Kamps(RSA), Mike Cunning (USA) Thongchai Jaidee(Tahiland) and Chung Tsung-hsing (ROC), who all finished at 283, five shots under par.
The tourney kicked of on Thursday, with 144 golfers from 16 countries and regions participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER ORDERS INVESTIGATION INTO BRIDGE COLLAPSE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Tang Fei on Sunday ordered the law-enforcement authorities under the Justice Ministry to investigate the cause that led to the collapse of Kaoping bridge linking Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties.
About 100 meters of the 2,400-meter bridge collapsed suddenly on Sunday afternoon, sending 16 vehicles and one motorbike crashing against the tilting span.
A total of 22 people were taken to hospitals nearby for treatment. Most suffered from light injuries, and no one was killed.
Tang flew to the scene from Taipei shortly after learning of the accident. He conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's deep concern about the injured and the cause of the accident.
The premier expressed apology to the injured and the public for inconvenience caused by the collapse, and said that the government will consider paying compensation for the injured people.
Tang asked government units concerned to find out the cause of the accident, and to examine all major bridges around the island.
As the four-lane bridge was sealed off after the accident, Tang instructed the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to work out a substitutive road immediately.

The Ministry of National Defense said that three helicopters, 71 vehicles and 730 military personnel from the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas were dispatched to the site for rescue and related efforts. Hundreds of local firefighters were also mobilized.

Preliminary investigation by law-enforcement authorities indicated that the on-going construction work below the bridge and illegal stone quarrying nearby might have connection with the collapse of the bridge.
Prosecutors from Kaohsiung and Pingtung would join hands to probe the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HIS OVERSEAS VISIT DOESN'T WORSEN CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that relations across the Taiwan Strait does not worsen over his first post-inauguration overseas visit.

Speaking at his third press conference since taking office on May 20, Chen said mainland China has so far neither issued any statements nor taken any actions unfavorable to Taiwan following its recent policy review meeting at the summer resort of Beidaihe.

Before his departure for his six-state "journey of friendship," some observers expressed worries that Chen's diplomatic tour might enrage Beijing and defer resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.
"The result proves that such worries are unjustified," Chen said, adding that his 13-day "journey of friendship" is fruitful and has not strained cross-strait ties.

Chen said his just-concluded visit, which took him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad, has helped signify the Republic of China's sovereign status and bolster its diplomatic ties with its allies.
Chen said his "summit diplomacy" has enabled the world to "see the ROC and the democratic and economic achievements created by the 23 million people of Taiwan."
"The visit has made me even more deeply and vividly feel the importance that our country wins diplomatic recognition of other countries," Chen said.
Chen said he has acquired many valuable experiences through his first overseas visit as the ROC's head of state.

"Seeing the real situation of our allies and meeting with our diplomatic corps on the frontline have given me new ideas and new thinking concerning our future diplomatic strategy and work," Chen noted.
Chen rejected description of the ROC's aid to its allies as "dollar diplomacy," saying that the ROC should display humanitarian concern and assistance to needy countries.

Noting that the ROC's agricultural and technical missions have contributed to many ROC allies' agricultural and fishery development, Chen suggested that the ROC consider sending more volunteer corps to other countries to assist in their economic development.

Chen expressed his gratitude for the hospitality extended to him by the ROC's allies in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa. He also expressed his appreciation of proper handling of post-typhoon rehabilitation work done by Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang Fei and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming during his absence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 180.45 POINTS

Market turnover amounted to NT$59.49 billion (US$1.92 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM MOVING TOWARD NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Prapiroon is now moving toward northern Taiwan, and the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) will decide whether to issue a land warning later Monday.

CWB weather forecasters said that as of 11 a.m. Monday, the tropical storm was located 640 kilometers east-southeast of Taipei, and was moving at a speed of 18 kilometers per hour in a west-northwesterly direction.
The CWB issued a sea warning Sunday night, noting that the 12th tropical storm in the Pacific this year is gradually approaching the northern and northeastern sea areas around Taiwan.
They said that residents in northern and northeastern areas might be affected by the storm and should be on guard against torrential rains between Monday night and Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOSE UNSUITED FOR JOBS SHOULD BE REPLACED: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that after three months in office, the Republic of China's government should not consider itself "new" any longer, and instead, the administration should fully demonstrate its ability and efficiency to meet the expectations of Taiwan's public.

Chen said that by now, Cabinet officials should be "capable hands" in their respective fields. He said if anyone cannot cope with the ongoing reform efforts, he or she will be replaced, adding that there was never any promise that each Cabinet member would be retained throughout the four-year term.

The president made the remarks during a press conference after returning home from a "journey of friendship," his first overseas trip since the May 20 inauguration. The press conference was the third of its kind over the past three months.
Chen said he will allow Premier Tang Fei's Cabinet more space and opportunities in order to improve the performances of its ministers.

Stressing his philosophy that a good manager should "fully trust the persons employed, but don't employ persons who are not trusted," Chen said it's time for the government to strive ahead at full speed and if there were people who cannot keep up the pace or cope with the tempo, they should be replaced.
Chen said there is no need for the administration to reshuffle its personnel, but changes of Cabinet officials can be made if necessary. "Time does not allow us to hesitate or condone," he stated.
"There will be hope for change and reform only when we neglect none of our duties," he continued.
Reacting to the president's remarks, Government spokeswoman Chung Chin said the Tang Administration has no plans to reshuffle its personnel, at least not in the immediate future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET
