DOC.HEADLINE: KAOPING BRIDGE REQUIRES EIGHT MONTHS' WORK TO REPAIR

TEXT.P: Kaoping Bridge is expected to be ready for use again in April next year at the earliest, after eight months' of repair work, according to the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau (TANFB) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

A 100-meter section of the bridge, which links southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties, collapsed into the river Sunday, taking 16 vehicles and two scooters with it. Some 22 people were injured in the incident.

TANFB said that it had retained a consulting firm in 1996 to inspect some 10 bridges, including Kaoping Bridge. The firm found that all the bridges required repair work to ensure their safety, bureau sources said.
After the collapse of Kaoping Bridge, the TANFB has equipped the other nine bridges with warning systems, bureau sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LASER EYE SURGERY CAN POSE DRIVING RISK

TEXT.P: Citing laser eye surgery as a risk factor for unsafe driving, the Canadian Medical Association is recommending that doctors test the night vision of patients who may be experiencing visual difficulties following surgery.

"What we're essentially saying is that refractive surgery has some impact on patients in their night-time vision," said Dr. David Irving, chairman of the committee that drafted the latest edition of Determining Medical Fitness to Drive, a guide for physicians.

The guide lists laser eye surgery as one of several medical conditions known to cause problems with night vision or "contrast sensitivity." Contrast sensitivity is the ability to see in low-contrast conditions such as dim light or darkness.

Physicians use the guide to help determine whether particular patients are unable to drive. In all Canadian provinces except Alberta and Quebec, doctors are legally bound to report those patients to transport authorities.

Adding laser surgery to the list of risk factors represents a warning to both patients and doctors, said the experts committee, which was assembled by the Canadian Ophthalmological Society to draft the guidelines for the CMA.

Last year, in Canada alone, about 100,000 people had laser eye surgery, and the worldwide figure for the same period approached one million. The Canadian guidelines are seen as likely to have some impact on future regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE ENDS AUSTRALIAN TOUR, HEADS FOR NZ

TEXT.P: After their successful shows at the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney, choreographer Lin Hwai-min and his Cloud Gate Dance Theater members Monday left on Monday for Auckland, where they will give five performances before heading home to Taiwan.
Lin and Cloud Gate garnered favorable reviews from Australian critics for their outstanding performances.

On the eve of going to Auckland, Lin told CNA that he and his troupe would give five performances of "Nine Songs" starting from September 1. Then they will return home for a short break before taking their show on the road again next month, when they are scheduled to tour France and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REAFFIRMS DESIRE TO MEET KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his desire on Monday to meet opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan for discussing major political issues and relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen said at his first press conference since return from his first post-inauguration overseas visit that he is willing to meet Lien under any format for an exchange of views on political issues, cross-strait ties and domestic reforms.
Prior to his departure for his six-state "journey of friendship," Chen said he looks forward to meeting Lien, also a former vice president, after his return from the trip.

However, Lien said shortly before Chen's return that he sees no necessity for a Chen-Lien meeting. Lien's remarks cast a shadow over the prospect for a meeting between the president and the top leader of the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen said he intends to pay a visit to Lien to listen to the KMT's opinions about major problems facing the country. "I have no predetermined stance on the timing, venue and conditions for the meeting," Chen said, adding that he sincerely hopes to meet Lien at any time and place and under any format convenient for Lien.

The proposed Chen-Lien meeting is expected to serve as a prelude to a long-talked-about roundtable meeting between Chen and heads of ruling and opposition parties to forge a consensus on cross-strait ties, domestic inter-party relations, Cabinet-parliamentary relations and other major reform issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 28, or the 29th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CROSS-STRAIT TALKS ON 'MINI DIRECT LINKS'

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung on Monday urged mainland Chinese authorities to return to the negotiating table to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, beginning with talks on the "mini three direct links."

Chen said the government is taking a positive stance on the implementation of the so-called "mini three direct links" -- direct trade, shipping and communications links between the Republic of China's offshore islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu with mainland China -- and concrete plans are expected to be put on the drawing-board in the near future.

It is hoped that mainland Chinese officials and experts will join their Taiwan counterparts for talks on details pertaining to the "mini direct links," since the matter is of profound importance to the development of cross-strait relations, Chen noted.

Chen urged mainland authorities and experts to "sit and talk" with their Taiwan counterparts on the "mini links" so as to rebuild a mechanism of interaction and pave the way for resuming the cross-strait dialogue, which was unilaterally suspended by Beijing in July 1999 after then-President Lee Teng-hui redefined the Taiwan-mainland China relations as "special state-to-state" relations.

Chen continued by saying that Taiwan's national security will remain the top concern when the "mini links" are considered. As for other issues involving trade, shipping, finance and communications with the mainland, participation by experts and personnel from both sides of the Taiwan Strait is needed, so as to jointly work them out.
He made the remarks during a hearing hosted by Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ching-pao in Kinmen Monday.
Chen, who represents the frontline outpost area of Kinmen, warned that if the "mini links" plans are not well planned, the impact on Kinmen and Taiwan will be irreversible.

The legislator singled out several matters as his major concerns about the proposed "mini links," including the misgivings of Kinmen residents aged above 60 who bitterly remember when mainland Chinese pirates sailed across the "narrow ditch" from the mainland to Kinmen to rob and loot in Kinmen decades ago.
He also noted that cheap and abundant mainland laborers may take employment opportunities away from Kinmen residents once the "mini links" are open.

Three major topics are expected to be discussed at the Kinmen hearing over the next three days -- how to develop Kinmen into a duty-free shopping paradise, how to build Kinmen into a recreation park on the sea, and how to develop Kinmen into a special zone for business and trade.
Relevant officials from the Cabinet-level MAC, the Ministry of Finance and the Council for Economic Planning and Development have flown to Kinmen for the hearing.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES LAND WARNING

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for northern and northeastern Taiwan Monday afternoon in anticipation of Tropical Storm Prapiroon.

The weather forecasters said that as of 3 p.m. Monday, the tropical storm was centered over seas 630 kilometers east-southeast of Taipei. It was moving at a speed of 18 kilometers per hour in a west-northwesterly direction, and has a radius of 250 kilometers.

The CWB officials said that the storm's path is unlikely to change, and that only northern and northeastern Taiwan are likely to be within its radius. Nevertheless, they added that other areas will face rains due to the storm's peripheral air streams.
The CWB's land warning covers Keelung, Ilan, Taipei and Taoyuan, and the forecasters warned residents in those areas to be on guard against torrential rains.
Ships navigating in seas off the coasts of northern, northeastern and southeastern Taiwan should also be on high alert, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar remained unchanged on Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$31.072.
The local currency opened at NT$31.063 and was traded between NT$31.063 and NT$31.080.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$184 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE TO DECIDE THEIR OWN FATE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated on Monday that the future of Taiwan will be determined by the free will of the 23 million people on the island.

In response to questions about cross-strait relations and their future direction in his first press conference since returning from a six-state, 13-day visit to the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa, the president reaffirmed that it will depend on the free will and choice of Taiwan's people. "No political party or any individual can make the decision for them unilaterally," Chen added.

He also spoke of the stance of the United States, noting that US leaders at both the Republican and Democratic National Conventions stressed that cross-strait issues must respect the decisions of the peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Chen added that both of the major US parties' platforms agree on this point.

He said that as the president of the Republic of China, he must handle cross-strait issues in a manner that respects the consensus of the people, and there will be no "preset stances or conclusions, and any options will be possible."

He said that he is willing to listen to the views of the people as he urged all political parties to forego their ideological differences and party interests, putting the interests of the nation and the people on top.
He noted that US President Bill Clinton has said repeatedly that the solution of the cross-strait problem must be acceptable to Taiwan's populace.

The latest poll on cross-strait relations also showed that most people in Taiwan do not want to be a part of mainland China, which he said is a fact that even the United States could not force Taiwan people to change, Chen said.
The poll also showed that around 70 or 80 percent of the people are in favor of maintaining the current cross-strait status quo, he noted.

But he also said that the mainland still wants Taiwan to accept its cherished "one China" principle, which would turn Taiwan into a part of the People's Republic of China and force it to accept the "one country, two systems" formula, which he said goes against the wishes of most people in Taiwan.

The president also urged caution against the remarks of leaders in Beijing, who say one thing to Taiwan, but another thing to the international community as far as cross-strait relations are concerned.

He said that "from the communiques that mainland China signed with more than 160 countries in establishing diplomatic relations, as well as from the information we have gathered," mainland China's "one China" means the People's Republic of China.

The president again urged the mainland to show "sincerity, creativity and wisdom" in dealing with Taiwan, to shelve their differences with Taiwan, and to sit down and improve cross-strait relations by finding a definition of "one China" acceptable to both sides.

But Chen also said that during his recent overseas visit, mainland China showed restraint, which he said was a demonstration that cross-strait relations have not worsened, but rather have become stable.
He said that whether the two can make a breakthrough in cross-strait relations depends on both sides using wisdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES CHAIRMAN OF KIWANIS INTERNATIONAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received Kiwanis International Chairman Bo Shafer on Monday and thanked him for the global service organization's long-term contributions to world society.

Chen noted that Kiwanis International's goal of serving the public is the same as that of his just-concluded "journey of friendship" to the ROC's allies in the Caribbean, Central America, and West Africa.

He said that the global village should not be differentiated into the strong and the weak, and that national boundaries, skin color and racial heritage should not matter because helping someone is the same as helping oneself, and giving another a chance is giving oneself a chance.
For that reason, the ROC must do its best to assist any allies that are in need of help, Chen added.

Shafer said that Kiwanis International originally began by focusing on local public welfare activities but moved on to international activities, without regard for national boundaries. He added that the main cause it is supporting at the moment is coordinating with the United Nations Children's Fund to help eliminate iodine deficiency in children around the world.

Turning to Kiwanis International's 2001 World Conference, Chen said that it is very exciting for Taiwan to be the first Asia-Pacific host nation of the annual meeting in 87 years. The conference is expected to draw more than 10,000 Kiwanis members to Taiwan.

Chen said that he was an active proponent of bringing the Kiwanis World Conference to Taipei while he was still mayor of the city. Therefore, he added that he will be very happy to attend the opening ceremony of next year's meeting as the nation's president.
Last year's annual Kiwanis International Asia-Pacific Conference was also held in Taipei. It was attended by more than 3,000 representatives from the region's 15 member countries.

Kiwanis International, which has its headquarters in the US state of Indiana, has more than 8,700 branches with 320,000 members in 81 countries. Its members undertake various charity activities and social services aimed at helping to improve people's lives.
Kiwanis International's ROC district, based in Taichung, was founded in 1967, and has set up over 270 branches across Taiwan with more than 20,000 local members.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ UNCOVERS COUNTERFEIT LEATHER PRODUCTS RING IN TAICHUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) on Monday uncovered a criminal ring importing phony leather goods in Taichung County.

The suspects have been importing knock-offs of leather products with famous brand names, according to the officials. Investigators said they seized a total of 4000 phony products, worth a total of NT$40 million (US$1.29 million).
Officials of the Investigation Bureau's Taichung District Office said that the items were all knock-offs of famous brands such as CHANEL, GUCCI, Dunhill, LV, and DKNY.
They added that the ring had been importing the counterfeit goods mainly from Guangzhou in mainland China's Guangdong province, and then selling the products to downstream distributors.

More than 100 crimes involving counterfeit products have been uncovered in Taichung since 1997, the officials said. Products seized in these investigations have reached a total value of NT$1 billion (US$32.26 million), they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOUGH COMPETITION FOR GARBAGE COLLECTOR JOBS

TEXT.P: It was no Olympic race, but the competition was just as fierce as some 3000 hopefuls sprinted down the running track with heavy sandbags on their backs, trying their utmost to get across the line faster then their opponents.

With each runner carrying a 15-kilogram sandbag, the nervous racers took turns running on the track at Taipei Physical Education College in a 90-meter dash competition to decide whether they are physically qualified to work as the cleaners and garbage collectors that Taipei City Government needs to hire this year.
Some runners managed to finish the 45-meter round-trip dash without losing steam, but many stumbled and fell down out of sheer nervousness.
They had reasons to be nervous -- the acceptance rate of the test is about only 4 percent, much lower than Taiwan's hotly-contested College Entrance Examination.
According to Taipei City Government's Vocational Service Center, some 6,000 people are vying for 150 openings as garbage collectors.

Even though a good education is not among the prerequisites of the job, many applicants have completed their high school education and some are even college and university graduates, said Vocational Service Center Director Kuo Chi-yi.

The hopefuls had already sat through a written exam and another physical test, which required the candidates to knot plastic garbage bags to see whether they were quick and efficient enough to collect the city's garbage.

The man who came in first in Monday's sandbag running competition won because he was fast and steady, said the judge panel. Asked why he took part in the garbage collector job test, he said, "There is nothing wrong with being a cleaner at a time when finding any job is difficult."
Some 3,000 other people are expected to compete in similar races Tuesday for the same 150 openings.

Taipei City Government has recently been strenuously promoting a "garbage revolution," which requires city residents to pay for garbage bags used to contain non-recyclable trash in an effort to reduce the garbage volume and to increase daily collections of recyclable waste.

In order to meet the increased need for manpower the program entails, the city government's Bureau of Environmental Protection created 300 new openings for cleaners and garbage collectors. Half of the spots are reserved for aborigines, people from low-income families and other less-privileged groups, and 150 positions are to be filled through an open competition.

Vocational Service Center officials said people who fail the competition Monday and Tuesday should not feel too disappointed as the race is extremely competitive. To further help console the disappointed, the center has arranged for nearly 600 job openings for the competitors to choose from, the officials said. These openings include positions as security guards, building custodians and cleaners.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWEA ESTABLISHES COMMISSION TO HELP CROSS-STRAIT BRIDES

TEXT.P: Taiwan Women Entrepreneurs Association (TWEA) established on Monday a commission to work on issues relating to women who cross the Taiwan Strait to marry men from the other side.

TWEA President Ma Ai-jeng said that although TWEA's main goal is to promote cross-strait trade cooperation, the organization saw a need to form the commission to work on issues related to the status of cross-strait wives.

Ma noted that after the two governments allowed their citizens to visit relatives on the other side, 12,000 mainland Chinese brides became Taiwan residents. Additionally, more than 30,000 mainland Chinese brides are still waiting to gain entry into Taiwan, she noted.
Many mainland Chinese brides of Taiwanese men suffer from domestic violence, and because they are unfamiliar with Taiwan, they don't know where to go for help, she noted.

She pointed out that the same situation sometimes occurs in reverse, when Taiwan-born women marry mainland Chinese men and find themselves in abusive marriages across the strait. The new commission will not only provide marital abuse hotline services to such women, but also offer them legal assistance, Ma said.
TWEA officials said they hope that the special line will provide complete services to cross-strait women who need help. The hotline can be reached at 02-2701-8538.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUEISHAN ISLAND TO BE CLOSED FOR ONE WEEK

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said on Monday that Kueishan Island will be closed to visitors for a week due to the approach of Typhoon Prapiroon.
Bureau officials said that no visitors will be allowed to travel to the island off the northeastern city of Ilan between Aug. 29 and Sept. 4.

The bureau also noted that tourists who have already been issued permits to visit the island during the closed period should present their permits to the Dalih Administration Center of the Northeast Coast National Scenic Area Administration for rescheduling. The center can be contacted by telephone at (03) 978-0727, extension 204 or 209.
Since Kueishan Island was opened to limited public access a few weeks ago, interest has been high, and the bureau warned that no further bookings are being accepted for September or October.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUC NOT HIGHEST BODY ON CROSS-STRAIT POLICY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the National Unification Council (NUC) is not the final and paramount policy-making body, but rather a consultation body on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The president made the remarks in his first press conference since his return last Friday from his six-state, 13-day visit to the Caribbean, Central America and West Africa.

Addressing public concerns about whether he will serve as the chairman of the NUC, he said that until regulations concerning the establishment of the body are abrogated, the NUC chair should be occupied by the president.

Chen said that he has no preconceived views or bias about serving as the NUC head, but he stressed that the NUC is not the paramount policy-making body on cross-strait relations, and added that too many people have the idea that its views are inviolate.

Chen said that the NUC is no more than a consultation body, just like the inter-party team headed by Academia Sinica head Lee Yuan-tseh, and a human rights promotion team and a technology consultation team headed by Vice President Annette Lu, and that the president does not necessarily have to serve as its head.
Mainland China has lashed out at Chen for saying that he will not serve as the NUC chairman, saying that the decision shows that Chen is still quietly harboring thoughts of Taiwan independence.
He again endorsed the inter-party team on cross-strait relations and said it will meet within the next few days. He also added that he will take part in the meeting.

He noted that the NUC was established a decade ago for the president to speed up national unification under the principles of freedom and democracy, but questioned if the goal of national unification now enjoys the support of the majority in Taiwan.

He said that domestic differences on the orientation of the nation, cross-strait relations and the future of Taiwan remain wide. As the leader of a democratic county, he said he must listen to views from all sides, and that the forming of the inter-party team hopes to forge a national consensus on these questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS `NO COMPROMISE' ON REFORM (I)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed on Monday his "no nonsense, no compromise" stance on promoting domestic reforms, saying he will never compromise simply to win re-election.

Chen said he is convinced that a popularly elected government chief can perform his or her official duties well only when he or she has the determination to serve for just one term and has no ambition to seek another term.
"Only with this understanding and resolve can we succeed in reform and in wiping out corruption and gangster influence in politics, commonly known as 'black gold' politics," the president elaborated.

Chen made the remarks at a press conference following his return last Friday from his first post-inauguration overseas visit that took him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
Chen said it is now time for his administration to "shift into high gear." After three months in office, he said, Cabinet members can no longer use "inexperience" as an excuse for their failings.
"All Cabinet members should now become capable hands, particularly capable reform hands," Chen said, adding that the public will not be forgiving if the government cannot live up to expectations.
Chen said he does not rule out the possibility of replacing unqualified Cabinet members with more competent ones in order to satisfy public demand.

In his third press conference since taking office May 20, Chen delivered a 40-minute speech on his just-concluded "journey of friendship" and then spent 50 minutes answering 10 questions from local and foreign journalists.

Chen described his six-state trip as very fruitful. In addition to signifying the ROC's sovereign status, Chen said, the visit helped cement the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies. The leaders of all the host countries have reaffirmed their support for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.
Chen said the visit has made him even more deeply and vividly aware of the importance of making sure that the ROC wins diplomatic recognition from other countries.
"Seeing the real situation of our allies and meeting with our diplomatic corps on the frontline have given me new ideas concerning our future diplomatic strategy and work," Chen noted.

He rejected a description of the ROC's aid to its allies as "dollar diplomacy," saying that the ROC should display humanitarian concern and assistance to needy countries and that the ROC will continue to offer such aid.

"It does not cost us too much but it greatly benefits our allies. Why shouldn't we do it?" Chen asked, adding that all countries in the world are equal and deserve respect, whether they are big or small, advanced or underdeveloped, rich or poor.
Chen praised Taiwan's agricultural and engineering missions which have helped Latin American and African countries build bridges and develop farms.

Noting that ROC agricultural and technical missions have made great contributions to the economic development of the country's allies, Chen said the government should consider sending more volunteer corps to needy countries to assist in their economic development.

According to government tallies, the ROC holds a foreign exchange reserve of some US$110 billion, but its foreign aid accounts for just 0.13 percent of its gross national product (GNP), compared to an average of 0.24 percent of many other advanced countries.
"Helping others is a duty we cannot escape and unless we can do better and more, we are not a member of the global village," Chen said. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS `NO COMPROMISE' ON REFORM (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Turning to the domestic front, Chen said that three months after the inauguration of his administration, the country's defense and diplomatic situation, as well as its relations with mainland China, have gradually stabilized. "From now on, we will shift our focus to domestic affairs, particularly the campaign against `black gold' politics and the creation of a better business climate," he noted.

Asked about whether he would follow the precedent set by his predecessor and chair the National Unification Council (NUC), Chen said he feels that "some people" have deified the NUC and deemed it as an "unchallengeable totem or symbol."

But, he went on, the reality is that the NUC is not the ROC's highest decision-making agency concerning cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and added that the body is basically an advisory board to the president.

Like the newly formed cross-party task force on cross-strait ties, the human rights promotion panel and the science and technology advisory group, Chen said the NUC is supposed to offer counseling services to the president and nothing more.

Touching on the possibility of a long-planned meeting with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Chen reiterated his willingness to discuss major domestic political issues, cross-strait relations and various reform programs with Lien.

Chen said if Lien does not wish to meet him in the first half of September, he would be willing to wait. "I have no predetermined opinion concerning the timing, venue, agenda or any conditions. I am willing to meet him under any format convenient for him. I just hope that he understands my sincerity," Chen explained.

The president had said prior to his departure for his 13-day overseas visit that he would pay a visit on Lien after his return, but the leader of the ROC's largest opposition party said last week that he saw no necessity for such a meeting. It remains unclear whether Lien, a former vice president, will agree to meet Chen in the near future. Lien lost to Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, in the March 18 presidential election.

Chen cut short his visit to the African state of Chad -- the last leg of his six-state journey -- and returned to Taiwan on Friday, a day ahead of his original schedule, to assess the damage caused by a strong typhoon that wreaked havoc on the island on Tuesday.

He wasted no time upon his return, traveling immediately to typhoon-affected areas in the central county of Nantou, where eight people were buried alive by mudslides triggered by typhoon-driven rainstorms. He also toured disaster zones in the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien the following day.

Chen expressed appreciation for the proper handling of post-typhoon rescue and rehabilitation operations by Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang Fei, Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming and all relevant Cabinet members during his absence.
He also reaffirmed his determination to get to the bottom of the 1993 murder of naval captain Yin Ching-feng and related military procurement corruption scandals.

"The Yin case will be an `eternal pain' for the military if it cannot be solved. It will leave a scar on the integrity of most of our military servicemen simply because of a handful of officers' unlawful actions," Chen said, adding that he fully supports the deepest possible probe of the case. "The Yin case symbolizes the government's resolve and the start of its anti-black gold crusade," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 29, or the first day of the eighth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1475: The Truce of Picquigny is signed, under which King Edward IV of England agrees to withdraw his invading troops from France in return for gold and a yearly pension.
1782: The Royal George, a first-rate ship of the British fleet, sinks while undergoing repairs at Spithead, killing more than 900 people.
1831: Michael Faraday, British physicist and chemist, successfully demonstrates the first electrical transformer in London. He also proposed the field theory later developed by Maxwell and Einstein.
1842: The Treaty of Nanking is signed by Britain and the Ching Court, ending the Opium War. Among the treaty's stipulations were the opening of five ports to British trade and the ceding of Hong Kong to England.
1835: John Batman and associates buy land from Australian Aborigines and officially establish Melbourne.
1877: Brigham Young, Mormon leader and founder of Salt Lake City, dies at the age of 76.
1885: The first motorcycle is patented in Germany by Gottlieb Daimler, German engineer and pioneer automobile manufacturer who produced the first high-speed internal-combustion engine.
1910: Japan takes complete control of Korea and begins governing it as a colony to benefit its own interests.
1926: Nepal abolishes slavery, freeing some 55,000 slaves.
1929: The giant airship Graf Zeppelin returns to Lakehurst, New Jersey, after completing a 21-day trip around the world.
1932: A Chinese volunteer army in northeast China launches a surprise attack at Shenyang (Mukden), capital of Liaoning province, during the night. They burned the airport and destroyed 27 Japanese military aircraft.
1945: Allied forces land in Japan following Japan's surrender.
1945: The National government appoints Chen Yi as governor of Taiwan following the island's retrocession to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, receives Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung to discuss such issues as national unity and reconstruction.
1948: Thailand expels some 5,000 ethnic Chinese.
1949: The Soviet Union tests its first atomic bomb.
1958: Michael Jackson, American pop mega-star, is born. His hit albums such as "Thriller" and "Bad" are backed by equally successful videos.
1962: A sword belonging to Lee Siu-cheng, one of the leaders who launched the Taiping Rebellion against the Ching court 97 years ago, is returned to mainland authorities by a Briton.
1969: Chiang Cheng-Tao, a mainland Chinese musician who defected to France, arrives in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China and Haiti conclude a trade agreement.
1975: A nova in the Cygnus constellation is discovered by the Taipei Observatory.
1982: Ingrid Bergman, Swedish star of stage and screen who won Oscars for both "Gaslight" and "Anastassia," dies on her 67th birthday at her London home.
1987: The ROC Little League baseball team wins the world title by beating the US West team, 21-1.
1998: A Cubana de Aviacion Tupolev airplane crashes after taking off from Ecuador's international airport in Quito, killing 81 people.
1999: The New Party (NP) formally recruits writer-critic Li Ao as the party's candidate for the 2000 presidential election in a meeting of party officials.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The intelligence which comes from the direct apprehension of truth is intuition. The apprehension of truth which comes from the exercise of intelligence is the result of education."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 28.38 points compared to the previous day to close at 7,817.49.
The bourse opened at 7,769, and fluctuated between 7,828.37 and 7,621.13 during trading.

A total of 1.57 billion shares worth NT$79.85 billion (US$2.58 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 1.11 billion stocks change hands on market turnover of NT$59.49 billion (US$1.92 billion).
Of the eight major categories, only electrical shares gained ground, moving up by 0.9 percent.

The other major categories all posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 5.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 3.6 percent, construction shares at 3.3 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.9 percent, cement shares at 2.8 percent, textile issues at 2 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 387 to 139, with 47 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3% PAY RAISE FOR CIVIL SERVANTS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Salaries for the nation's military personnel, civil servants and teachers will be raised by three percent starting January 1.

Chu Wu-hsien, director general of the Central Personnel Administration, noted on Monday that a committee on salary adjustments for military personnel, civil servants and teachers held a meeting in July to discuss the pay increase for the workers.

Chu said that most participants in the meeting had considered the fact that the consumer price index had increased by 1.98 percent since the beginning of the previous year, and that average pay raises for private sector workers during the same time was 2.39 percent.

He added that the committee of Executive Yuan officials had suggested implementing the three percent pay raise after taking into account the real purchasing power of civil servants, the financial situation of the government and the annual budget.
Chu said that pay raise will cost the government a total of NT$15.12 billion (US$486.17 million).

He said that the establishment of the committee on salary adjustments for military personnel, civil servants and teachers will make the process of pay adjustments more objective, transparent and institutionalized in the future.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market fell Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved down 13 points to close at 7,913, with 5,160 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 12 points to finish at 7,940, with 76 contract traded; while December futures remained unchanged at 8,000, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading on Tuesday were set at 7,926 for September, 7,952 for October, 8,000 for December, 8,200 for next March, and 8,139 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
September TE futures moved up 5.9 points to close at 439.8, on 1,699 contract transactions; while October TE futures gained 8.5 points to finish at 442.8, on volume of four transactions.
December TE futures increased 1.05 points to close at 438, with eight contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.
September TF futures lost 23 points to close at 843.2, with 809 contract transactions; while October TF futures plunged 38 points to finish at 837, with 19 contract transactions.
December TF futures decreased 27.2 points to close at 846, with seven contract transactions; while March 2001 futures lost 34 points to finish at 850, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next June TF futures. (BY Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON REACTS TO REPORTS OF BOOK SEIZURES BY CHINA

TEXT.P: Reacting to reports that mainland Chinese customs officials have seized copies of a book because it had a photograph of President Bill Clinton alongside the Dalai Lama, the United States said Monday that if the reports are true, such actions represent a violation of basic rights of expression.

Answering press inquiries about the reports, State Department Deputy Spokesman Philip Reeker noted that the reports cited a mainland Chinese spokesman as commenting that politically sensitive materials are not allowed to be printed or exported.

"If the report is true, then it is most disturbing. Seizure of books in order to impose political or religious control violates international human rights instruments, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which China has signed," pointed out Reeker.
The spokesman then reiterated that "if these reports are in fact true, we view the seizure as violations of guarantees of freedom of expression."

On the three American missionaries detained by mainland China last week, Reeker said, "We do understand that all three individuals have been released and are in the process of departing China." However, he declined to comment on press reports that the missionaries were beaten and badly mistreated while in detention.

Meanwhile, Reeker confirmed that US Ambassador Joseph Prueher has returned to Beijing after visiting Tibet between Aug. 24 and 27, in the first such trip by a U.S. ambassador since former Ambassador James Sasser visited there in 1997.

While in Tibet, Prueher met with autonomous region and Lhasa city government officials to discuss human rights and other issues, including such specific topics as the Tibet Heritage Fund and the Panchen Lama issue, according to Reeker. The visit also gave Prueher the chance to explain American policy and Washington's concerns directly to Tibetan officials, the spokesman said, adding that he did not have any details of their discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN BANKS TO MEET IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: The Union of Asian Banks, founded in Taiwan in 1981, will hold its regular convention in Istanbul, Turkey, on Sept. 21-22, the state-run Anatolia News Agency reported today.
The union's sole member in Turkey, Kocbank, also the organizer of the convention, told Anatolia that this year's theme will be "Banking in the New Millennium."

The convention will include topics such as the speedy rise of technology in the banking sector, the necessity of technology investments for more effective operations, forming virtual banks in developed markets, and shaping the banking sector in the new century.
High-ranking bankers from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Vietnam, Japan, South Korea, Russia, Australia, Uzbekistan and Turkey will attend the convention, according to the report.
The Union of Asian Banks was founded in Taiwan in 1981 and currently has 100 members banks from 23 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEAS OFF NORTHEAST COAST OF TAIWAN HIT BY STORM

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Prapiroon has already begun whipping up the seas off Taiwan's northeast coast, according to Tuesday's latest announcement from the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

CWB officials said that Prapiroon was located 390 kilometers east-southeast of Taipei as of 10:30 a.m. With a radius of 250 kilometers, the tropical storm is moving in a northwesterly direction at 19 kilometers per hour, they added.
The CWB said that northern and northeastern Taiwan will come under the storm's influence in succession. Rains and winds are expected to gain strength in the afternoon, the agency warned.
While Prapiroon was approaching northern Taiwan, another tropical storm named Maria, the 13th in the Pacific this year, was being formed overnight Monday, said an official with the CWB.
Because Maria's center has not moved, it remains to be seen whether the new tropical storm will have any impact on Taiwan, the official said, adding that the CWB will keep Maria under observation.
The official said that the weather agency will also observe Prapiroon's development to see if there is any connection between the two storms.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER ANNUAL MILITARY EXERCISE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and other top-ranking government officials presided over the annual Hankuang military exercises Tuesday to inspect the results of the past year's tri-service training.

President Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang Fei, and various Cabinet ministers were first briefed on the cross-strait military situation. They then observed a simulated war game between two teams, in which some 2,000 computer viruses collected by the military were used to test Taiwan's ability to attack the enemy and defend itself in cyber-warfare.

Entrenched deep within a hillside at the top-security Hengshan Command Center, Chen relayed his orders through a direct link to the Army's front-line servicemen using the new Improved Mobile Subscribe Equipment (IMSE) -- an upgraded version of the US Army's MSE telecommunications network system.

According to the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the theme of this year's Hankuang No. 16 war games is "national defense with the participation of the entire people," and the focus is on "unifying and mobilizing national strength."
A military spokesman said that this year's war games marked the first time that the premier has led Cabinet members to attend the military's largest annual military exercise.

He went on to say that the MND decided to invite the Cabinet members to participate because Hankuang No. 16 seeks to examine the ability of mobilized reserves to support military operations. To do so, the coordination of all government agencies and their resources must be strengthened, he added.
The spokesman cited wartime issues such as medical care, transportation, and reserve mobilization as possible situations in which cross-ministerial coordination will be necessary.

According to the MND, the exercise formally began Monday, and the simulated computer war games will last until mid-September. Another stage of the drill is slated for the end of September, when a tactical mobilization of the reserve engineering corps and a head-to-head exercise involving actual Navy, Coast Guard, and air police forces defending the Tamsui River -- which flows through the capital city of Taipei -- will take place.

The Navy and Air Force will also conduct small-scale drills following the conclusion of the simulated computer war games. One such drill will be the ROC Marines' urban warfare exercises scheduled to take place in mid-October.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

The local currency opened at NT$31.069 and was traded between NT$31.069 and NT$31.079.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT ALLIED NATIONS: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is planning a visit by Vice President Annette Lu to the Republic of China's allies in Central America, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Tuesday.

President Chen Shui-bian said during his recent visit to the Dominican Republic that the ROC vice president would visit El Salvador between September and October, a comment that sparked interest in the local media.

Tien noted that El Salvador's leaders had asked Chen several times to include a stop in that country on his just-concluded six-nation tour, and that Chen in fact met with El Salvador's vice president on Aug. 15 in the Dominican Republic, when the two discussed an exchange of visits.
Tien said that he would meet with Lu in the next few days to work out details of her trip.
Lu confirmed that she will visit ROC allies in Central America and "other regions" to promote what she called "soft diplomacy," and added that the president is also in favor of her trip.
Lu said that her visit in late September will target Central American allies, especially those that were not included in Chen's trip.
She said that the trip, like Chen's, will be aimed at boosting the confidence of the allies in the ROC's new administration.

Tien said that Chen's recent "journey of friendship" was successful -- not only deepening Chen's personal friendship with leaders in allied countries, but also boosting the ROC's diplomatic relations.

He noted that during Chen's visit to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, and the West African states of Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad, he met with nine presidents of allied countries, one former president, one prime minister, and three vice prime ministers.
Chen invited all these officials to visit Taiwan, invitations that received enthusiastic responses, said Tien.

The foreign minister added that Chen's trip was significant in that it declared the ROC's sovereignty to the international community. He said he was gratified to see the ROC flag waving in other parts of the world.

Despite mainland China's increased diplomatic squeeze on Taiwan, Tien said that as an independent sovereign state, the leader of the ROC has an obligation to travel outside the country in an official capacity whenever the chance presents itself.

Tien also confirmed that Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew will visit Taiwan this autumn. He said that the government has been informed of the trip, and that Lee is expected to meet with President Chen during the visit.

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian gave a press conference Monday after his return last Friday from his first overseas visit as head of state.
He described his trip as successful and vowed to push ahead with domestic reforms without regard as to whether it will cost him the chance of being re-elected.

Chen said it is now time for his administration to "shift into high gear" and that after three months in office, the members of his Cabinet can no longer use inexperience as an excuse for their failings.

He challenged the democratic process through which the Guidelines for National Unification were laid down and the National Unification Council set up, and shrugged off the question of whether he will assume the NUC chairmanship.
He dismissed Beijing's alleged softening of its stance on the "one China" principle as hypocrisy, claiming that Beijing has characterized "one China" differently at home and abroad.
Following is the full text of the press conference provided by the Government Information Office.
Acting Secretary-General Chen's Remarks:
Mr. President, Deputy Secretary-General Chien, Ladies and Gentlemen from the Media:
Good morning!
First of all, I would like to welcome each and every one of you to the Office of the President for today's press conference.

As you know, this press conference was originally scheduled to be held on August 26, when the president returned from his trip to the Caribbean, Central America, and Africa. However, Taiwan was struck by Typhoon Bilis, the strongest typhoon to have hit Taiwan in a decade. The president was very concerned about the damage and, therefore, decided to return one day earlier. President Chen was back in Taiwan at 3:00 in the afternoon on August 25, and immediately visited the disaster areas in Nantou County. On the second day, the president continued his inspection tour in the Hualien and Taitung areas. This is why the press conference was postponed until this date, and we would like to apologize to the media for any inconvenience caused by the postponement.

I am sure that all of you are interested in hearing the results of President Chen's first overseas "trip of democracy, diplomacy, and friendship" since his inauguration, as well as the president's views on major domestic issues. Now, let us welcome the president to make some opening remarks, after which he will answer your questions.
President Chen's Opening Remarks
Acting Secretary-General Chen, Deputy Secretary-General Chien, and Friends from the Media:
Good morning!

The 13-day "trip of democracy, diplomacy, and friendship" has ended successfully. I want to thank our friends in the media for their company and advice, as well as EVA Air for its chartered service. I also want to thank our colleagues in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and our embassies and overseas representative offices for their meticulous preparations. I especially want to thank the United States and our six diplomatic allies for their kind arrangements facilitating this visit. Of course, my special appreciation also goes to the legislators from different parties as well as the business leaders taking this trip with us.

This tour has proved that the worries and anxieties expressed prior to the trip were unnecessary. During our trip overseas, the domestic political situation was stable and the government functioned smoothly. The cross-strait relationship, a source of concern, did not become tense or worse because of an overseas trip by our head of state. Many had expected some unfavorable comments, actions, or conclusions emanating from the PRC's Beidaihe conference, but this view proved to be unfounded. Although we cannot say much about (MORE)

TEXT.P: Before the trip, we never imagined that these friendly countries would give us such a warm welcome and so much attention. We were very deeply moved. Take President Hipolito Mejia of the Dominican Republic for example. While accepting congratulations from the foreign delegations [after his inauguration], he asked me to join him in receiving congratulations. President Mejia also introduced me to other delegations. Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman further surprised us by making an exception to see us off at the airport. It was unprecedented. Even when President Clinton visited Nicaragua there was no such exception. Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez not only invited us to his home for breakfast, but also introduced us to his party's presidential candidate. There were other things that deeply impressed us. When President Idriss Deby of Chad learned that the place we were supposed to stay lacked some necessary facilities, he especially let us stay at his residence. He then moved to stay at the presidential office. We learned later that Mrs. Deby had sent some people to renovate and decorate the residence so that we would feel more at home. Now, I would like to again express my heartfelt respect and gratitude to all of them for their hospitality.

I would especially like to mention how people here had described conditions in those countries. In fact, such things as sanitation, food, or housing were not as worrisome as imagined or reported. I live a very simple life and feel at home wherever I am. I am not finicky about food or the place I live in. However, before we left for the trip, many misleading reports frightened the delegation members. Nevertheless, they also enjoyed their visit to these countries. Once we were there, nothing unusual happened. I believe we did not make an effort to understand these countries. Despite the fact that they have been our friendly allies for many years, we were not familiar with them, and there were misunderstandings and barriers. If we carefully compare our life here in Taiwan with that in these countries, we have to admit that we are very lucky. We should cherish our achievements and quality of life, none of which was easily attained. In spite of the fact that we are often dissatisfied and the government has not yet performed as well as expected, we are truly one of the luckier nations in the world. As a member of the international community, every nation is great in its own way, and every people is indispensable. Every one is equal and important. In today's world, despite such differences as skin color or the level of development, all countries are important and equally worthy of respect. Gambian President Yahya Jammeh said that, although his country is small, it has a loud voice. Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore said that his country has nothing, but work. I believe that every nation and race has its strengths worthy of respect. Last night, my wife told me that when the first lady of Paraguay visited Taiwan, my wife hosted a banquet to honor her. During the banquet, the visiting first lady told my wife that the Paraguay government would definitely speak on behalf of the ROC, for the people of Taiwan joining the United Nations and many other (MORE)

TEXT.P: Many people here do not realize the national flag is important or that the national anthem means much. But, on May 20, when A-mei led in singing the national anthem, she touched the hearts of the audience. I believe many people shed tears and realized that we could sing the anthem of the Republic of China so beautifully. For decades, many people did not appreciate the importance and beauty of our national anthem. When I stood on the rostrum at national airports with leaders of friendly nations and listened to the national anthem of the Republic of China played by their bands, I was deeply moved and even stirred with pride. Only then did I feel the importance of our country, the importance of our country's being recognized, and the importance of our country's international profile. I do not think all of my compatriots could fully understand and appreciate my experience, or feel the same way I did.

During this trip, we not only proclaimed our country's sovereignty and consolidated friendships with our diplomatic allies, but also put Taiwan on the world stage. We want to see the whole world and let the whole world see the Republic of China and the democratic achievements and economic prosperity resulting from several decades of effort by the 23 million people of Taiwan. We want to offer humanitarian assistance and compassion to the world, which is our responsibility and privilege. This is what Mr. Alexander Shafer, president-designate of Kiwanis International, said this morning when I met him and his wife: "Serving people is not a responsibility but a privilege." If we help other people, it is not a responsibility. It is a privilege. However, if we do not even do our duty, can we enjoy the privilege of helping others? I really cannot imagine why some people do not agree to our providing humanitarian assistance and economic cooperation. I often think about my own background. As a child from a poor family, without the assistance of relatives and friends, or money that didn't need to be returned, or money borrowed from friends or relatives with no or low interest, could there be an ROC president today named Chen Shui-bian? It was because many people helped me to stand up that I was given the opportunity to serve the people. This is the spirit of the "Son of Taiwan."

Half a century ago, the United States assisted us in building Hsiluo Bridge. When I was in the second grade, I had the chance to drink my first cup of cow milk. It was delicious, and it came from the United States. To me, having never tasted cow milk, that first cup was assistance from the US and provided by my school. Can we say that this was "money diplomacy" by the US? American international assistance allowed Taiwan to overcome many difficulties and stand up. Now, we are standing tall and have the opportunity to repay the global community. Why are we so stingy? Clearly, the United Nations suggests that foreign aid should account for at least 0.7 percent of a country's GNP. Currently, the average percentage is 0.24. How about the Republic of China? Our percentage is only 0.13, half the average percentage of the UN. Isn't it too low? Perhaps some people think that if we cannot implement our own social welfare programs, how can we help other countries? We want to ask, are the American people satisfied with their social welfare programs? Is every person taken care of one hundred percent? I don't think so. Several decades ago, the US gave so much care and help to weak countries in this world, including Taiwan. Did the American people complain about that? Were (MORE)

TEXT.P: Q.4 Mr. President, when you were in the Dominican Republic, you reiterated your resolution to dig into the Yin Ching-feng case even though this would rock our nation to its very foundation. Is there any progress in the case? And to what level of the military officers will you investigate? Will it shake our national foundation to solve this case?

A: In order to stabilize our national foundation, we must investigate the Yin Ching-feng case and other relevant scandals to the end. If anything, these cases are the ones that will shake our national foundation. If these cases are not solved, they will remain a pain to the military. We can not let the majority of the honest and nation- and people-loving servicemen bear the humiliation for the misconduct of a minority of people in the military.

At the press conference on July 31, I issued an official order to set up a special investigation committee for the Yin case and other relevant scandals. State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa was appointed the convener of this committee. The Ministry of Justice, Ministry of the Interior, and Ministry of National Defense are also responsible for investigating this case. The committee has been working very hard during this past month. Papers and files relevant to the case are so voluminous that the committee couldn't even read them all in one month's time.

I would like to affirm the efforts of every member of the committee, including the prosecutors, members of the Investigation Bureau, police officers, and relevant units of the military. Every one of them worked very hard in cooperation during the past month. This is not easy. Nor is it easy to find new clues for the case and to make new breakthroughs in this almost "invisible" case. I am very pleased that we have found something new and made some new breakthroughs for the case. We did not disappoint our fellow countrymen. I have to respect the special investigation committee as well as the independence of the judicial system. Eliminating organized crime and government corruption is the common aspiration of everyone. And we have shown our respect for the independence of the judicial system, when we were cracking down on the organized crime and government corruption practices in the past. Similarly, we must show the same respect to the judicial units as we did when they cracked down on organized crime and government corruption. Therefore, I told the special investigation committee and Prosecutor-General Lu not to have any concerns when investigating the Yin case. No matter how high and broad the level might be and no matter whether those involved are still in office or retired, we have no boundaries or limitations for investigating this case. I told them not to worry about anything, just track it down to the end, and not to disappoint our fellow countrymen. If we can have any progress and new breakthroughs for such a dying case, then we can handle any case. If we can solve the most difficult case that seems to all to be almost impossible to solve, what case can't we handle?

I believe that this is just the beginning. The investigation on the Yin case and other relevant scandals only demonstrate our will and resolve to eliminate organized crime and government corruption from our society. There are still some very old cases that were already given up by many people. For those cases, we cannot comfort ourselves by saying that it has been so many years, all evidence has disappeared, and there is no way to solve them. I believe that those who were involved and have passed away will bless us from heaven. I am confident that our fellow countrymen will also give their full support to my new government, as well as to the special investigation committee for the Yin case, to crack down on organized crime and government corruption with a comprehensive effort.

TEXT.P: However, the Multiparty Task Force is currently being actively promoted. The first meeting will be held soon, and I will be participating to give my encouragement and support. After all, the first article in the Establishing Guidelines for the National Unification Council clearly states the reason why the president established the National Unification Council: "Under the principles of freedom and democracy, to accelerate national unification, conduct research, and provide consultation on guiding principles." Although its purposes are quite clear, has it really been carried out? Under the principles of freedom and democracy, the purpose for establishing the National Unification Council was to accelerate national unification. Was this policy objective carried out under the principles of freedom and democracy? Did they get the people's consent and majority support? Were the procedures discussed from top to bottom? Many different opinions have arisen on this subject that need to be further discussed. Indeed, there are currently many different domestic views and ideologies with regard to national status, cross-strait relations, and Taiwan's future, and some of them are diametrically opposed to one another. As the president of a democratic state, I must review all of these differing opinions.

Thus, we hope that the Multiparty Task Force can establish a consensus from top to bottom amongst the government, political parties, and the public with respect to cross-strait relations, Taiwan's future, our national status, and various ethnic problems. I think that the smooth and efficient operation of the Multiparty Task Force should be our current priority and fully support President Lee Yuan-tseh's direction for its future operations. I am here to appeal to our countrymen, all parties, and all factions, to support and participate in the Multiparty Task Force. The Multiparty Task Force is not even operational yet. Do we really want to brush it aside so quickly to return to the disputes of the National Unification Council? We need to examine and face many things. For example, did the past government follow the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council? I think that many things have become too holy. In fact, the main issue is not the National Unification Council or the Guidelines for National Unification; rather, the main issue is on practical, day-to-day operations. What can we do?

Today, many people can already travel to the Chinese mainland, to Shanghai or Beijing, and talk with the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party about cross-strait relations. Why is it that we have no way to shake hands at home, to meet with each other to discuss national affairs, to form a consensus between our government and political parties on cross-strait relations? Is it possible that domestic politics are more important than the Chinese Communists and Zhongnanhai? Thus, I sincerely hope all parties and factions can eliminate their prejudices to discuss national affairs, as it is not only our right to do so, but our obligation and responsibility.

TEXT.P: Q.8: You mentioned earlier the difficulty of forming a domestic consensus on cross-strait policy. Recently, Qian Qichen, the vice premier of the Chinese mainland, gave a new interpretation of the "one-China" principle. In the second point of this new interpretation, he says, "both mainland China and Taiwan belong to one China." What is your response to this statement? What information do you think he is trying to convey to Taiwan?

A: It is especially important that we remind everyone to be cautious of the different remarks made by mainland Chinese officials, as it is virtually impossible to know for sure whose statements are true and final and who actually represents their government's policy. The remarks to visiting groups from Taiwan are often omitted from formal documents and press releases on the mainland, so how accountable are such statements? Furthermore, we have noticed that many international media, research institutes, and experts have expressed a difference between what the Beijing authorities say in their statements to domestic audiences and what they say internationally with regard to Taiwan. Indeed, what they say to the people on Taiwan is often contrary to what they tell the international community. If the so-called "one China" principle, definition, or meaning has changed, then let me ask, what about the "one China" repeatedly mentioned in their communiques with over 160 nations that have formal diplomatic relations with the Chinese mainland? The recent information we have regarding Beijing's orders to their foreign embassies still refers to a so-called "one China"-the People's Republic of China. If today, Taiwan and the Chinese mainland are both part of "one China," this "one China" refers to the People's Republic of China, and the People's Republic of China is the sole, legitimate government for all of China-if none of this has changed in their policies and communiques, and if we merely listen to their self-serving statements and believe them, then aren't we placing ourselves in a very dangerous position? The Beijing leaders have different statements for different groups of people. However, we will continue to act with sincerity, creativity, and wisdom, hoping that Beijing will eventually respond in kind. We wish to follow the spirit of dialogue and exchange and set aside controversies, so that the two sides can meet and talk to improve cross-strait relations, while seeking a mutually acceptable definition of "one China." I wholeheartedly believe that such a definition cannot be unilaterally decided and manipulated by any single nation, political party, or people. We must meet and discuss it together. The outcome is true and final only when it is acceptable (MORE)

TEXT.P: We traveled to many countries during this trip. We saw the Gambia's vegetable cultivation area and found that the vegetables planted are exactly the same as those we have here in Taiwan. This is the result of the hard work of our agricultural technical mission stationed there. Growing vegetables might not mean as much to Taiwan, but it means a lot to the people of the Gambia. We also visited the Bagre farm area in Burkina Faso and saw thousands of hectares of lush rice paddies beside the dam. The irrigation ditches there are like the Chianan Irrigation System near my hometown. However, developing the land is easier said than done, as this area was covered by stones that had to be exploded before cultivation was possible. So many members of our agricultural technical mission stayed there for three, five, or even ten years without getting any preventive inoculations or taking any medicine. They work silently and contribute what they know to that place.

In Chad, we saw that Taiwan Bridge will be opened to traffic next year. Chad has long been divided into north and south by a river. Over the past 40 years, there has only been a rickety one-way bridge connecting the two sides. Now the two-way Taiwan Bridge will be opened to the public next year, and people from the north and the south of the country will be able to cross the bridge from both directions. As Chad President Idriss Deby said, Taiwan Bridge not only connects south and north Chad, but also Chad and Taiwan. It is a bridge of friendship between Chad and the ROC. To us, it costs not much, but to Chad, it is something that makes their lives so much easier. So, why not extend a hand of friendship?

Travel in these countries is very inconvenient. Before I left Chad, I had breakfast with our eight ambassadors stationed in African nations. I told them, "The eight of you are like the eight fairies crossing the sea. You eight fairies crossed the South China Sea and then the Indian Ocean to Africa. As frontline members of the diplomatic corps, you are the greatest and have made wonderful contributions to your nation. You should each receive a medal." Some of them told me that they had spent seven or nine days traveling to Chad from their respective offices before they could meet me. They could not fly to Chad directly, as we did by chartered flight. Before we went on our trip overseas, we took medicine and immunization shots. But they said that they had no vaccinations or medicine and would seek help only after they fell ill. It was the same for our agricultural specialists. And aren't the medical teams just as impressive? It seems that we have difficulty supplying the required agricultural people. The older generation has done very well, but the younger generation doesn't seem to be doing as well. Can we consider "foreign service in lieu of military service"? Can we promote a kind of "peace corps"? Let's take students in our agricultural colleges for example. If they are willing to join a "peace corps," we can offer them foreign language and professional training, including courses at the foreign diplomacy college to be established by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. When they graduate, they can join the "peace corps" or agricultural technical missions. They will not have to serve in the military. The "peace corps" can be an alternative to military conscription, and an alternative foreign service. We can offer them a high salary, and perhaps they can serve five years instead of two. After five years, they might wish to remain on the agricultural technical missions and even start a new career overseas. These are areas where we can dedicate our efforts. I believe tha t many of our young people have such aspirations. Helping others is helping yourself. I raise this proposal, so we can encourage each other.

Finally, I must emphasize that although diplomacy is important, domestic affairs are even more so. As the president of the nation, one must see and feel the suffering of the people. Even as I was in Africa, my heart was at home in Taiwan, and I was concerned about the (MORE)

TEXT.P: As a head of state visiting abroad, I was required to follow international protocol. With the understanding of the counterpart, some adjustments in the schedule could be made. Idriss Deby, the president of Chad, told me it was best not to pressure myself. If he were in the same situation, he would make some adjustments to the schedule and return home at an earlier date. I felt especially comforted by the fact that government affairs had not been adversely affected by my trip aboard. The crises were smoothly managed. As Typhoon Bilis was approaching, I called Premier Tang and Vice Premier Chang, waking them up at midnight and repeatedly exhorting them to make good preparations for the typhoon. After the typhoon struck, I made calls and inquired about the damage. Without the most up-to-date information and assurance of the current situation via reports every two hours, my worries could not be reduced. During the typhoon, I was in direct contact with the vice president, the premier, the vice premier and the chief of general staff eight times, and found my mind constantly on the situation in Taiwan. I reached a decision to change my schedule and return at an earlier date. Very soon I arrived home, saw our people in the disaster areas, and shared their pain. But I am grateful to the outstanding performance of our servicemen, police, firefighters, and personnel in the weather, transportation, electricity, and water supply bureaus and other departments. They were the first to respond and reacted immediately. I would like to again express my thanks and praise for their courageous work. I wish to thank Vice President Lu, Premier Tang, Vice Premier Chang, Chief of General Staff Tang, and related agencies for their efforts. They did an excellent job managing emergency situations.

Yesterday, we handled the Kaohsiung-Pingtung Bridge incident very well. Since the Pa-chang Creek accident, we must be on full alert and must not make any excuses or be slow to respond. We must mobilize to save lives. I could sense that these two incidents have mobilized everyone. However, if like yesterday, proper precautions had been made, I believe many unfortunate situations and accidents could be minimized. If we can prevent disasters, why shouldn't we?

Today is the 100th day of the new administration. In the past three months, we have had the excuse of being the "new driver on the road." But from now on, we cannot use it as an excuse anymore. We must "become experienced drivers" to meet our citizens' great expectations. We must work to solve the serious, chronic problems in a short period of time. We must implement reforms and pursue progress. I believe we do not have time to waste or procrastinate.

The neophytes in government must now enter a new stage of experience. Such numerous trials as eliminating "black gold" politics (organized crime and government corruption), improving the social order, investigating the murder of navy procurement officer Captain Yin Ching-feng, stimulating the economy, maintaining public safety, raising the quality of life and environmental standards, conducting reforms, promoting a multiparty task force, strengthening the communication and coordination mechanisms between the Legislative and Executive Yuans, and, finally, achieving rapprochement between political parties and coordination between the ruling and opposition parties all lie ahead to challenge and continually test us. I would like to reiterate that in the short time of four years, I will do my best. I would like to remind all members of the new administration to cherish this time and make the best of it. Running for a next term is not on our mind, but rather fulfilling our duties and doing a good job in governing our country. All government officials and I will show our willingness to do things right during this term, which is far more important than thinking about running for the next term. In the coming four years, all government officials should be on high alert. No laziness, hesitation, or shirking responsibility is allowed in the new administration.
