TEXT.P: I will not let you down and will work hard. In the future, I will devote more time to domestic affairs. Once we have stabilized cross-strait affairs and foreign relations and enhanced the morale of our military forces, I will spend more time and energy on domestic affairs, especially in the areas of economic revitalization, administrative efficiency, and the elimination of "black gold." I will not compromise because of ballots, nor will I be hypocritical or wishy-washy in order to be elected the next term, otherwise, not only the people of Taiwan but also I myself will not be satisfied. Because of the general dissatisfaction, we have room for improvement. And because I am dissatisfied, I will work all the more.

Q.1 During your stay abroad, there was a major domestic issue regarding the chairmanship of the National Unification Council. The chairman is the president, according to the Statute for the Establishment. What is your opinion now? On the other hand, acting Secretary-General Chen thought that, since the Guidelines for National Unification were made in 1989, it is time to revise them. What is your personal opinion? In the future, how can we distinguish between the functions and responsibilities of the National Unification Council and those of the Multiparty Task Force?

A: I sincerely appreciate everyone's concern and comments about the National Unification Council, the Guidelines for National Unification, and related issues. In my inaugural address on May 20, 2000, I already publicly declared that so long as the Communist regime does not use military force against Taiwan, the National Unification Council and the Guidelines for National Unification will not be abolished. This statement has not changed. Although there are no questions regarding abolition, there are other issues that we must face, which cannot be avoided. As there are still many people who are confused about these issues, I would like to take this opportunity to give appropriate explanations and guidance.

For example, some people misperceive the National Unification Council as the highest policy-making and ultimate decision-making agency on cross-strait policy. In reality, however, the National Unification Council is simply another consultative body, much like the Multiparty Task Force, the National Human Rights Consultation Task Force, and the Science and Technology Consultation Task Force. All of these organizations are merely consultative agencies to the president. Thus, the National Unification Council is not the final decision-making body on cross-strait issues, nor is it the highest policy-making agency.

Another popular misconception is the belief that the National Unification Council is a sacred and inviolable entity. In actuality, the Establishing Guidelines for the National Unification Council proclaimed by the president in 1990 have been continuously revised and were changed in 1993, 1995, and 1997. Since the Establishing Guidelines for the National Unification Council have already been revised three times, they are obviously not sacred or inviolable.
Members of the National Unification Council serve for terms of one year, and those one-year terms have now been completed. Naturally, if the council continues to exist, we must either (MORE)

TEXT.P: A: I emphasized earlier that I have a very simple philosophy when it comes to appointing personnel: "Appoint a person without any doubts, do not appoint a person if there are any doubts." Since the government officials have already been appointed, this means that I do not have the slightest doubt about their abilities. I have given them an opportunity to perform over the past three months, and I am ready to give them even more opportunities in the future. For instance, I hope that the financial and economic task force recently established by the Executive Yuan will take a vigorous and aggressive approach and not give society the impression that it is in disarray or is lacking in direction with its economic and financial policies. I consider this to be very important. The government is like an enterprise: we are more concerned with team performance than individual performance. If an individual performs well, but the team does not, then the individual is not any better off. However, if the team performs well, then the individual will naturally be in a good position as well. A good team needs good members. Thus, I believe we should give our new government-the Tang Cabinet-more time and greater opportunities. Regarding the problems that have occurred in the past three months, we could possibly say that we were "new drivers on the road." However, we cannot use this rationalization to shirk our responsibilities in the future. Society has very high demands, and my expectations are no less. I sincerely hope that the new government, the Tang Cabinet, and all of the ministries and commissions will devote their full efforts to their work. I would like to remind our ministers and heads of commissions that three months have passed since the new government took office. If they have failed to push on with their work because of personnel problems or because subordinate department heads have been unable to coordinate their work in a united effort, then I am sorry to say that adjustm ents must be made. They have to be made-without hesitation, hypocrisy, procrastination, or delay. I hope that our ministers and heads of commissions realize that if they want to thoroughly implement the ideals and reforms of the new government, then "everything will depend on human effort." Each staff member must put "heart" into their work; if the heart is not in it, then adjustments must be made to the staff. I hope that our ministers and heads of commissions will review this matter thoroughly and make the necessary personnel adjustments. Otherwise, we will not be able to proceed with certain matters, and by then, it might be too late to lay blame.

Q.3 The US State Department recently issued a report on the human rights of foreign laborers for various nations. It listed the ROC as having the second worst record in the world. Such a record is bound to damage our diplomatic efforts. What is your opinion on this report?

A: It is vital that the ROC performs a serious self-examination and reviews both the criticism and advice being given. However, I have said that establishing a nation based on human rights will be the goal of the new government. Furthermore, I have consistently encouraged everyone to let the ROC on Taiwan become a new landmark for human rights in the 21st century. While striving for this ultimate goal, though, it is important that we sincerely confront all of the criticisms being made to our freedom and human rights record, as such criticism usually signifies that our measures are insufficient. Thus, I will ask the Executive Yuan, the Council of Labor Affairs, and all other relevant government agencies to work together and thoroughly review the human rights situation of foreign laborers working in the ROC, and I will demand that they make changes to improve those conditions. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF ROC PRESIDENT'S AUG. 28 PRESS CONFERENCE (X)

TEXT.P: A: I sincerely appreciate all of the comments and advice that have been offered to both myself and the new government by people from all walks of life, including different political parties and the media. We especially appreciate the comments given by the KMT and have listened to their opinions with an open mind. Indeed, with respect to a few matters, we would particularly like to invite KMT Chairman Lien Chan to meet with us and discuss them in person, as I hope he can provide us with further insight into his opinions. Nevertheless, we only have one nation and one national interest. I do not believe any single political party would place their party's interests before or above it. Similarly, I do not believe any political party would place their own interests above those of the people, and the KMT is no exception. For the sake of our nation's future, the future of cross-strait relations, and the many initiatives and reforms that are taking place in domestic affairs, I again invite Chairman Lien, with utmost sincerity, to meet with me. If he does not have time now, I can wait. If he cannot make it today, I will wait until tomorrow; if he cannot meet me tomorrow, I will wait until the day after; if he cannot meet this week, I will wait until next week; and if he doesn't have time this month, I will wait until the following month. I can afford to wait until he has time for me to visit him. If the KMT headquarters is not an appropriate place for such a meeting, that is fine. We can choose a different location. Nothing-neither the time, place, form, or conditions-is preordained. I sincerely represent both the nation and the government when I ask for the opinions of Lien Chan, chairman of the largest political party, the KMT.

Naturally, this same sincere invitation is extended to the leaders of all of Taiwan's primary political parties. In fact, we have already made similar consultative arrangements in private. I really do appreciate the opinions offered to us so far, and hope that Chairman Lien can feel and accept my unreserved sincerity.

Q.6 The Legislative Yuan is currently discussing whether to postpone the approaching general interpellation session. Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng has said that you favor postponing it. If so, why?

A: I exchanged views on this issue with the heads of all five Yuans prior to my tour, and we agreed that the interval of time between the last general interpellation, which lasted until the end of July, and the next one, which would begin as soon as the legislators meet in September, was probably too short. That is, if we had the general interpellation immediately after the next administrative report in early September, it might be too close to the previous one, which lasted for a month and was just completed at the end of July. Was postponement possible? The reasons for postponement had nothing to do with Premier Tang or his health. The only consideration was the length of the previous general interpellation and the fact that it lasted so late into July. Was it suitable or necessary to have another right away in September? I brought the issue up merely as an exchange of views with President Wang of the Legislative Yuan, and he thought the request reasonable. Whether it will be postponed, however, will depend on inter-party negotiations and communication between the Legislative Yuan and Executive Yuan. We will respect the opinions of all political parties, and we do not have any predetermined opinions. We simply raised the issue and are discussing the facts.

Q.7 It was the position and hope of the previous administration that the Chinese mainland and Taiwan could be unified someday under democracy. However, you have previously mentioned that unification is but one of several options. Does this imply that unification might not be possible?

A: The new administration has already clearly explained this issue. As I said in my inaugural speech on May 20, I hope the leaders on both sides can deal with the future question of "one China" using their wisdom and creativity under the basic principles of democracy and parity. I believe that the future development of both cross-strait relations and Taiwan itself will follow this direction. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF ROC PRESIDENT'S AUG. 28 PRESS CONFERENCE (XII)

TEXT.P: Q.9 You mentioned earlier your expectations of the new Cabinet and your opinions on its performance. How do you feel about Vice President Lu's performance during your 13-day trip overseas? Also, what is your view on her idea of relocating or renovating the Office of the President?

A: I would like to express both my appreciation and approval of Vice President Lu's performance during my absence. Indeed, not only did Vice President Lu perform well, but everyone-Premier Tang, all of the relevant ministries, and everyone working on the front-line during the typhoon period-did their jobs very well. Thus, I would like to express an equal amount of appreciation and approval for their performance.

Regarding the Office of the President, we believe the building is still in fairly good condition. Thus, there is no need for renovation. Besides, I do not think renovating the Office of President should be a priority for the new administration. I would rather improve the living standards of our people, government efficiency, and the investment environment for factories and businesses, than renovate the Office of the President.

Q.10: You just mentioned that the future for both the people on Taiwan and cross-strait relations should respect the will of the people on Taiwan. By what means do you hope to understand the will of the people? You also said that such a problem should be discussed at a roundtable meeting attended by the leaders of all three major political parties and a special Multiparty Task Force. However, some political parties are not giving their support to a Multiparty Task Force. Under such circumstances, do you think that a consensus reached by the two mechanisms just stated can really represent the will of the people? Or do you think that other means should be considered, such as a plebiscite, to truly reflect the will and desires of the people? Indeed, if the two mechanisms reach completely different conclusions, can using a plebiscite be completely ruled out?

A: A public opinion poll conducted yesterday indicated that more than 80 percent of the people on Taiwan believe we should join the United Nations. This is news that the Chinese communists do not like to read. In fact, not only do they dislike it, but they have also consistently boycotted and stymied any attempt made by the ROC to participate in any international organization, including the United Nations. This poll also revealed that between 70 and 80 percent of the people on Taiwan prefer to maintain the status quo, regardless of what direction cross-strait relations take in the future. The Beijing authorities, however, want us to accept their "one-China" principle, which would downgrade Taiwan as a part of the PRC. They also want us to accept their so-called "one country, two systems" formula, which would make Taiwan another Hong Kong or Macau. All of these things obviously violate the will of the majority of the people on Taiwan.

We are encouraged, however, by the remarks made by both the Republican and Democratic parties in the United States-and especially those made by President Clinton-that any final resolution to cross-strait issues must respect the will of the people on Taiwan. Public opinion polls currently indicate that most of the people on Taiwan do not wish to be a part of the Chinese mainland, and this is a fact that neither the US government nor the US people can force us to change. Thus, during my transit through the US, Chairman Richard Bush welcomed us on behalf of the US government and people. At that time, he told me that the US government expressed its utmost support and admiration for our new government's management of cross-strait relations. Consequently, we do not feel that current cross-strait relations are deteriorating, but rather, believe that we are still in control of the situation.
What we must do now is show our wisdom and creativity and make (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF ROC PRESIDENT'S AUG. 28 PRESS CONFERENCE (XIII)
TYPHOON RELIEF CENTER SET UP IN LIENCHIANG COUNTY

TEXT.P: Lienchiang County Magistrate Liu Li-chun has set up a typhoon relief center for the outlying island of Matsu after sea and land warnings were issued by the Central Weather Bureau over approaching tropical storm Prapiroon Monday.

In an emergency meeting Monday, Liu asked the relevant authorities to maintain high alert and prepare measures to deal with emergencies caused by the storm, which was forecast to arrive the following day.
He also warned residents of the Republic of China-controlled island to beware of wind and torrential rain, as well as possible backsurges of the sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CONFIRMS SEPTEMBER VISIT TO CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu confirmed Tuesday that she will visit Republic of China allies in Central America and "other regions" in late September to promote what she called "soft diplomacy."

Lu said she has received approval from President Chen Shui-bian and added that her itinerary will be arranged by the Foreign Ministry, bearing in mind the fact that Chen himself has just returned from a six-nation trip to Central America, the Caribbean and West Africa.
Lu revealed that her visit will focus mainly on Central American countries, especially those which Chen did not visit.
She said the visits are designed to give the ROC's allies faith in the new government and added that the visits will prove the ROC's respect for its diplomatic allies.
Lu made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Taipei county government to show her concern over methods of protecting women's safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR BLASTS CENTRAL GOVERNMENT FOR BUDGET ALLOCATION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday blamed the central government -- which has been bemoaning its own financial difficulties -- for increasing its own annual budget while cutting funding for his city.

Ma said that the city's 2001 fiscal budget, which was approved by the Taipei City Council on Tuesday, is 9 percent less than last year's. He cited a smaller portion of the central government's "budget pie" and insufficient tax income as the reasons for the reduction -- the biggest drop since Taipei came under the central government's direct jurisdiction in 1968.
The central government's 2001 annual fiscal budget, which is pending legislative approval, increased in contrast by over 6 percent over the previous year.

The Cabinet announced in mid-July that the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities -- will receive 43 percent of the total amount destined for the nation's cities, counties, townships, and villages, down from 47 percent in fiscal 2000.

Ma pointed out that the budget cut has affected several programs such as labor insurance subsidies, high school student incidental fees, medical subsidies for children under three years of age, and a mental handicap subsidy that President Chen Shui-bian established while he was still Taipei mayor.

Ma went on to say that all cities should have their own roles, and that Taipei is no different. Taipei represents Taiwan, he claimed, and urged the central government to respect the legal status of Taipei as a special municipality.

He added that the imbalanced development of the nation's cities, townships, and villages can be traced back to the central government's hold on power and money. He urged the Taiwan public to understand the importance of Taipei in adding to Taiwan's competitiveness in the world, and not to try to "isolate" the city by advocating equality regardless of the effects.

Saying that the struggle for central funding has made him realize that Taipei should follow a more self-sufficient path, Ma said that his city will "walk ahead of the central government" within legal limits instead of waiting for approval for everything, including subsidies and sources of income.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 30, or the second day of the eighth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER HSIN TAO PROMOTES CROSS-STRAIT RELIGIOUS EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Master Hsin Tao of Taiwan's Buddhist Lingchiu Mountain Group is scheduled to play host to a breakfast gathering Thursday to entertain religious leaders from Taiwan and mainland China.

Master Hsin Tao, who is leading a 15-member Taiwanese delegation to the Millennium World Peace Summit of religious leaders which opened Monday at the United Nations, said the Taiwan delegates have had exchanges with the eight-member mainland Chinese delegation since the first day of the summit.
Religious people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait have worked strenuously to enhance social stability and international harmony, Hsin Tao said.

Hsin Tao is scheduled to deliver a speech to the World Peace summit on Thursday, the last day of the summit, to advocate praying for world peace through the power of religion. He gave a five-minute speech to the gathering on Tuesday.

Master Sheng Yen, one of the most reverend religious leaders in Taiwan and founder of the Buddhist Foundation of the Dharma Drum Mountain, delivered a speech to the summit Tuesday and said a prayer in front of the summit before it split into discussion sessions.
Sheng Yen stressed the importance of respect and tolerance, saying that every one in the world has the right to exist and develop and this right should be respected and tolerated.

Despite having no official connection to the United Nations, the first two days of the four-day summit are being held at the UN headquarters, while the third- and fourth-day activities will take place at New York's Waldorf Hotel.

The meeting of more than 1,000 leaders drew controversy before it even began when participants learned that conference organizers did not invite the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, to the event, for fear of offending mainland China.

Master Sheng Yen and Master Yi Fa of Fokuangshan, another prominent religious leader in Taiwan, are attending the summit in the name of US Buddhist or religious groups, also apparently for fear of retribution by Beijing.

CNN founder Ted Turner, who is one of the financiers of the summit, was invited to speak to the conference Tuesday. He said all people around the world -- despite their differences in culture, religion and other issues -- should not make distinctions between one another. The media mogul stressed that there is only one kind of people on the globe -- human beings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING 'DIPLOMACY OF ALL PEOPLE' IS PART OF GOV'T POLICY: MOFA

TEXT.P: Promoting the "diplomacy of all the people" is part of the policies of the Republic of China government and will be implemented beginning next year, a ranking official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

Wei Wu-lien, director of a MOFA agency in charge of diplomatic personnel training and nurturing, said concrete measures to facilitate diplomacy of all the people have already begun. He added that the new diplomatic line is aimed at materializing President Chen Shui-bian's ideals of launching diplomacy of all the people, human rights diplomacy and enabling Taiwan to play a greater role in the international community.

Noting that manpower is of the essence in achieving a nation's revival, while education will be the foundation for a 100-year national reconstruction, Wei said that nurturing talent and manpower on a broad basis can help raise Taiwan's international competitiveness.

By promoting diplomacy of all the people, efforts and resources from the government and the private sector can complement each other in action so as to strengthen Taiwan's diplomatic front and make the voices of Taiwan people heard more clearly, he added.

Wei quoted a survey conducted by National Chung Cheng University on the commission of the MOFA in July as indicating that 82 percent of Taiwan citizens support the government's idea of establishing new institutes of diplomacy studies as one method to promote diplomacy of all the people.
To begin with, the MOFA has organized short-term workshops on international affairs and related activities. The first of which is scheduled to kick off on Sept. 4, Wei said.

Aides to lawmakers, political party workers in charge of foreign affairs, local personnel working in international non-governmental organizations, and other related talent will be accepted to attend the international affairs workshops, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN FOR AMENDING UNIFICATION GUIDELINES: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has no plan to amend the Guidelines for National Unification at the moment, acting Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan said on Wednesday.

Chen was responding to press reports that senior mainland Chinese leaders have said if Taiwan revises its unification guidelines, it will constitute a new barrier to communications across the Taiwan Strait. Mainland leaders were also quoted as having claimed that Taiwan's move to amend the guidelines will mark a dangerous alarm to cross-strait relations.
Chen said the president clearly stated in his Aug. 28 press conference that whether the Guidelines should be revised he will fully respect mainstream public opinion concerning the issue.

The Guidelines were formulated in 1991 during the Kuomintang reign to serve as the highest directives governing Taiwan's policy toward mainland China. The long-term goal of the Guidelines is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
According to Chen, the newly formed Multiparty Task Force will meet soon to discuss cross-strait relations and forge a national consensus on all related issues.
Chen said all the 25 members of the Multiparty Task Force will hold a preliminary meeting Friday and will open its first formal meeting at the Taipei Guest House Saturday.

Noting that the Multiparty Task Force is composed of people with different professional and political backgrounds, Chen said the panel is expected to help forge a national consensus on the delicate cross-strait issue and provide relevant counseling services to the president.

"President Chen will deliver a speech at the task force's meeting on Sunday to express his support for the group and his expectations of the panel's role in forging a national consensus on the future development of cross-strait ties," Chen said.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who concurrently serves as convener of the Multiparty Task Force, is also expected to speak at the meeting to call for resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

In an effort to clarify speculation that the Multiparty Task Force may discuss the role and function of the National Unification Council (NUC) at its first meeting, Lee told the press Tuesday that the NUC will continue to exist even after the inauguration of the Multiparty Task Force.
"The Multiparty Task Force will neither come up with a new document as future cross-strait policy guidelines nor will it affect the NUC's operations," said Lee, also a Nobel laureate.

The Multiparty Task Force office said it has not arranged an agenda for the panel's first meeting. "To show respects for all members, the agenda will be decided after the task force holds a preliminary meeting," said an office spokesman.
Meanwhile, Presidential Office officials reiterated on Wednesday that the Multiparty Task Force will not replace the NUC. They further said the time is not right to discuss the NUC-related problems.

One of President Chen's close aides said the president touched on the NUC issue during his Aug. 28 press conference mainly because more than 80 percent of the respondents to a recent public opinion poll on cross-strait ties said they prefer to maintain the status quo. "As the finding runs counter to the NUC's ultimate goal, the president has mentioned the issue in hopes of inspiring further thinking of the issue," said the aide.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES LIKELY TO CAUSE US-MAINLAND CHINA FRICTION: US ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: Since mainland China continues to link its arms exports to other sensitive issues such as US military sales to Taiwan, US concerns about specific sales will likely be a periodic source of tension in relations between Washington and Beijing, according to two American experts in East Asian affairs.

Bates Gill, director of the Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington, DC, and Evan S. Medeiros, a senior research associate with the East Asia Project at the Center for Nonproliferation Studies in Monterey, California, made the prediction in a co-authored report on mainland Chinese arms exports.

The two experts said that despite the declining volume of mainland Chinese arms exports and its shrinking market share in the international arms market, Beijing's arms exports will continue to be an issue of concern for US policymakers and analysts.

To be sure, they said, Beijing has made various pledges to halt exports of missiles and related technologies to South Asia and the Middle East. But two analysts put little faith in such rhetoric. "China's current commitments are mostly bilateral, political promises made in the context of US-China bargaining; they do not appear to be rock-solid and unequivocal."
Thus, a major downturn in PRC-US relations could lead Beijing to overturn commitments and enter upon a new round of arms exports, they added.

The experts said such a scenario is not unlikely, given the range of Beijing-Washington differences -- especially over security issues like Taiwan. "China continues to link its restraint in arms exports to diminishing US arms sales to Taiwan, and China could use its arms exports to particular countries (such as Iran) as leverage in bilateral debates over Taiwan-related issues," they said.

Indeed, the PRC's vehement opposition to current US proposals to provide Theater Missile Defense technology to East Asian partners, especially to Taiwan, "could trigger a new round of arms exports from Beijing," they wrote. They added that PRC officials have already indicated that they consider TMD sales to Taiwan to be a form of missile proliferation, which may lead Beijing to reconsider its existing missile nonproliferation commitments.

The experts noted that further complicating these issues are the ambiguities and lack of transparency surrounding mainland China's official policies and processes related to arms exports. The principles which guide Beijing's official arms exports policy are sufficiently flexible to justify almost any export on the grounds that it contributes to the legitimate defense requirements of the recipient.

In addition, the 1997 PRC regulations covering military product exports are vague on key points such as the numbers and types of military organizations that can export arms. In aggregate, they said, "these ambiguities are particularly worrisome because they can provide opportunities for Chinese entities to illicitly export military goods without the knowledge of central government authorities."

For example, the experts pointed out, reports surfaced in early 1999 that a mainland Chinese company had sold some type of short-range missiles and long-range artillery systems to Armenia. But in response to protests by Azerbaijan's Foreign Ministry, China's Ambassador to Armenia Zhu Zhaoshun and Vice Foreign Minister Wang Yingfan admitted that Beijing did not know of or approve the deal.
