DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD PROVIDE TMD TO ROC UNLESS M'LAND REDUCES MISSILES: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: In the absence of any constructive moves by mainland China to decrease its missile threat, the United States should assist Taiwan to develop the component elements of a Theater Missile Defense that best suits the island's security needs, an American expert on Asia has emphasized.
Andrew Scobell, Asia expert at the Strategic Studies Institute of the U.S. Army War College, made the statement in a recent report titled "Chinese Army Building in the Era of Jiang Zemin."

In the meantime, Scobell wrote, it is vital for the United States to recognize mainland China's sensitivity to TMD. It would be foolhardy -- indeed, dangerous -- not to take the Chinese threats seriously, he warned. "We must take every opportunity to remind China about the destabilizing and threatening effect of the recent missile buildup it has undertaken in the Taiwan Straits," he said.

But he also urged Beijing to be sensitive to Taiwan's security worries. "China should recognize that it is only natural with such a proximate and growing threat that Taiwan would want to improve its missile defense. Moreover, if Beijing wants to prevent Taipei from deploying TMD, it should ask itself what steps China could take to eliminate or minimize Taiwan's desire for such a system," he pointed out.

Scobell said it is likely that Communist China's defense establishment will strengthen over time. However, rather than obsessively focusing on the emergence of a more powerful threat, mainland China's neighbors and the United States should pay more attention to the strategic implications of a weak Communist leadership.

"Indeed, China today is not as powerful or as a significant player as it is often made out to be. And there is the possibility that China might become weaker militarily and economically and perhaps evolve into a looser federal system or in a more extreme case, even to fragment," he stressed.

"While the possibility may be low, it cannot be completely ruled out, and this eventuality must be seriously considered as a future scenario. The dangers of not contemplating the unthinkable are evident when one recalls that few analysts in the 1980s anticipated or even entertained the possibility of a Soviet collapse," he wrote.

Although arguing that Communist China will not succeed in becoming a military world power during the next 10-15 years, the analyst said this does not mean that he believes that mainland China doesn't pose threat to the Asia-Pacific region. "Indeed, the widely-held conviction that the PLA poses a modest or nuisance threat gives rise to a dangerous tendency to downplay or dismiss the very real threat China's military presents," he emphasized.

Despite assurances that Beijing will be too preoccupied with domestic matters to have time to get involved in foreign military adventures, it should be remembered that leaders in Beijing seem particularly prone to perceiving foreign threats if the mainland is beset by domestic upheaval, he noted.

That is especially if Beijing concludes that there is "collaboration" between internal and external forces as in the case of the popular pro-democracy protests of Spring 1989, Scobell said. It is precisely at these moments when Beijing is likely to lash out, in order to demonstrate to its enemies that it remains vigilant and prepared, he added.

However, Scobell said, rather than fear a highly-capable PLA winning stunning victories, the militaries of the Asia-Pacific region should be more concerned about the prospects of spectacular failure for the mainland's armed forces.

"The most plausible scenario is Taiwan. Failure on a grand scale can come about either if China's leaders mistakenly believe the PLA can win in a specific scenario and so proceed to launch an attack, or if Beijing believes it is unlikely to win but has no choice but to go ahead and attack anyway," he said.

Either way, the results of a failed PRC military strike may be worse than victory, particularly in the case of action in the Taiwan Strait, Scobell said. This is because where Taiwan is involved, Beijing is unlikely to admit defeat and desist, he said.

If the PLA is vanquished on the battlefield Communist China is likely to persist in its quest, and Beijing will seek to rebuild its military might in order to ensure success the next time, the US expert predicted. Thus, defeat will probably prolong and heighten tensions in the region, rather than clear the air, he said.
Scobell warned that such a PLA defeat might very well spark a serious regional arms race, as mainland China's neighbors would perceive an increasingly threatening security environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ACADEMIC SEMINAR OPENS AT TUNGHAI UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Yolanda K.C. Chen)

TEXT.P: A six-day joint seminar of college professors and students from Hong Kong, mainland China, and Taiwan opened here Wednesday on the campus of Tunghai University.

The seminar will discuss the theme of interpersonal relationships and communications, according to Tunghai University. The university said that in hosting the seminar, it hopes to facilitate academic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Organizers of the event at Tunghai University also said that more than 60 participants from Tunghai and six other universities of mainland China and Hong Kong will discuss the theme in various aspects, including interpersonal relationships in families, schools and society, with the aim of helping students learn to respect others and care for society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TREND MICRO OFFERS CURE TO WORLD'S 1ST PALM VIRUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based anti-virus software company Trend Micro Devices Inc. on Wednesday offered a cure to the first virus attacking handheld personal digital assistants (PDAs) using the Palm operating system.

Researchers of Trend Micro's "e Doctor Lab" said the latest virus, a type known as a Trojan horse and dubbed "Palm.Liberty.A", has the appearance of an upgrade for a Palm program, but instead deletes most files from the PDA.

Palm.Liberty.A is being distributed under the file name "Crack1.1" through Internet Relay Chat, a network of chat sites. When run, it deletes all the programs on the user's Palm device, though it leaves the address book data, calendar and other databases intact, Trend Micro researchers said.

Trend Micro made a name for itself when it became the world's first software company to devise a program to counter the infamous Melissa virus. Trend Micro released its anti-Melissa program just 20 minutes after the virus was discovered. The company operates a research center in California's Silicon Valley, and is the first Taiwanese high-tech company to be listed on Japan's stock market.

Trend Micro's team also reacted quickly to the first Palm virus, which was discovered only on Tuesday. The firm's anti-virus specialists reminded Internet users to be extremely careful when they download any file from the Net.

Internet users are welcome to visit Trend Micro's website at http://wtc.trendmicro.com/taiwan/ to keep abreast of the latest developments regarding viruses as well as download Trend Micro software to detect and remove destructive programs from their own systems, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.003 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at NT$31.067.
The local currency opened at NT$31.063 and was traded between NT$31.063 and NT$31.074.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$268 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS NAB PORN MOVIE PIRATES IN TAOYUAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Alice Liang)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Aviation Police Bureau (APB) on Wednesday uncovered a criminal ring that has been exporting pirated pornographic video compact discs (VCDs) in Taoyuan County.

In recent months, the suspects have been exporting pirated VCDs by means of express mail services at C.K.S. International Airport, said the officials, who noted that such activities are not only illegal, but also damaging to Taiwan's international image.

The task force investigated the ring for four months before Wednesday's raid on the ring's headquarters, Tai-dieh Technology Co., in Taipei County, the officials said. The investigators arrested the suspects on the spot and seized 24,000 pirate VCDs and 3,500 CDs, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CONTINUES `JOURNEY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Wednesday continued her "journey of science and technology" with a tour of the Institute of Information Industry (III).
In a briefing for Lu, III officials displayed the application of information technology in census-taking, business information management, agricultural information and weather information.

The officials also said that they are promoting the Nankang Software Science Park in suburban Taipei, and that it is hoped it will become a major software research and development center in the Asia-Pacific region.

Lu praised the III for its work over the past two decades in promoting the nation's information industry, adding that with its limited land area, Taiwan must rely on the development of science and technology to ensure its continued prosperity.

She noted that President Chen Shui-bian attaches great importance to the development of science and technology, and that he has assigned her to serve as the convener of a science and technology advisory committee.

She said the committee will invite scholars and experts to take part in the planning of the nation's science and technology development and provide suggestions to the president, adding that it will be a supra-party advisory committee.

Lu was accompanied by several leaders in the computer field, including Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), on her trip around northern Taiwan, which also included visits to the National Central University, Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, and the Nankang Software Science Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK SYNDICATE LOANS NT$ 4.72 BILLION TO COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY

TEXT.P: Twenty banks, including Citibank, on Wednesday syndicated a loan of NT$4.72 billion to Far EasTone Co. to assist the company's development of wireless communication and Internet services.

Far EasTone Chairman Douglas Hsu said the company now has 2.7 million customers, making adjustments necessary to the financial structure and capital of the company. He added that the syndicated loan will not only assist Far EasTone to undertake the transfer of investments, but will also digest some of the banks' excessive capital.
Peter Baumann, country corporate officer of Citibank, said at the loan signing ceremony that the telecommunication industry will be one of the top industries in the future.

The signing ceremony took place in the presence of representatives of banks including Citibank, the Cathay United Bank, the Tainan Business Bank, the Taipei Bank, the United World Chinese Commercial Bank, the Chinatrust Commercial Bank, the Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank, the Grand Commercial Bank, the International Bank of Taipei, the Bank of Taiwan, the Central Trust of China, and the Hua Nan Commercial Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN TESOL SEMINAR BEGINS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar on teaching English to speakers of other languages (TESOL) for East Asian elementary and high school teachers kicked off Wednesday in Taipei.

Lai Ming-teh, vice president of National Taiwan Normal University, noted at the event that English has become the global language, and a successful TESOL program is the pillar of modernization and internationalization.

He added that Taiwan will provide TESOL courses in all of its elementary schools starting in the year 2001. Because of this, the Ministry of Education (MOE) and National Science Council joined together to sponsor the seminar. NTNU invited TESOL scholars, teachers, and editors from 20 East Asian countries to discuss TESOL lesson planning, teacher training, teaching materials, and testing.

C.C. Lee, director of the Bureau of International Cultural and Education Relations, said that Taiwan's domestic TESOL environment has improved. Lots of peripheral resources can be used to teach and learn English, he said, citing TV, radio, English newspapers, and TESOL websites. However, he added that Taiwan's wealth has provided youths with excessive temptations and lowered their motivation to learn.
Lee added that according to reported statistics, Taiwan's average TOEFL score was the second-worst in all Asian countries, only ahead of Japan.
He noted that the keys to promoting Taiwan people's English proficiency are good teachers and proper use of peripheral resources.
The three-day seminar is taking place at NTNU, and will wind up on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MULTIPARTY TASK FORCE IS PRESIDENT CHEN'S POLITICAL PLOY: KMT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang issued a lengthy statement Wednesday to explain its stances on the National Unification Council (NUC) and the newly formed Multiparty Task Force on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and now still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, issued the statement after a weekly meeting of its elite Central Standing Committee.

The KMT statement came just ahead of the inauguration of the Multiparty Task Force, which was formed under the Republic of China's new Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government. The 25-member task force will hold a preliminary meeting Friday and open its first formal meeting this weekend.

The KMT claimed that the Multiparty Task Force is merely President Chen Shui-bian's political ploy to weaken the role of the NUC and even to completely replace the NUC, which was set up in 1990 during the KMT reign to serve as the president's advisory board.
Since the NUC has functioned well over the past decade, the KMT said, it couldn't understand why President Chen would form another body for similar consultative purposes.

Blaming the Multiparty Task Force as a redundant organ, the KMT accused President Chen of intending to use the so-called consensus to be worked out by the panel as an excuse to justify his refusal to chair the NUC or his plan to abolish the NUC.

The KMT also criticized Chen for his failure to consult with it before recruiting several of its individual members to join the task force, saying the practice runs counter to the norm of party politics in democratic countries.

The KMT further warned that the creation of the Multiparty Task Force to discuss Taiwan's future at this moment could ignite a new round of debate on whether Taiwan should seek cross-strait unification or move toward independence. "Our observation is that such debate would add up to uncertainty in cross-strait relations and such development does not comply with the mainstream public desire for stability in the Taiwan Strait," the KMT statement said.
Moreover, the KMT pointed out that nearly all other opposition parties support the KMT-established mechanism for handling cross-strait ties.

Against this backdrop, the KMT said, President Chen's urgent task does not lie in seeking cross-party consensus on cross-strait ties, but rather in forging an intraparty consensus within his own DPP on the issue.

Speaking at the weekly KMT meeting, Su Chi, a former Mainland Affairs Council chairman, said President Chen's overture that unification is just an option for Taiwan's future will not have any constructive impact on the development of cross-strait relations.

"Open-ended debate on Taiwan's future at this moment will only cause uncertainty and anxiety among local people and will not help mitigate cross-strait tension," Su warned, adding that a new round of "unification-independence" debate could even affect domestic economic development and social stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER ORDERS QUICK HANDLING OF KAOPING BRIDGE AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Tang Fei on Wednesday directed the Transportation Ministry and the Public Construction Committee to keep the effects on traffic of the Kaoping Bridge collapse to a minimum.

After hearing reports from the two Cabinet-level bodies, Tang ordered repairs on the highway bridge connecting Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties to be completed by April next year. He also instructed that a new bridge spanning the Kaoping River should be completed within three years.

In the meantime, he said, related agencies should maintain careful surveillance of the increased loads on other bridges over the Kaoping River caused by the closure of the collapsed bridge, and should also heighten nationwide inspections of all bridges.
A 100-meter section of the 2,000-meter Kaoping Bridge collapsed Sunday afternoon, taking 18 vehicles crashing down with it. Some 22 people were injured in the incident, but there were no fatalities.

At a weekly Cabinet meeting, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan reported to Tang that her ministry has already directed related agencies to plan alternate traffic routes. Four national and provincial highways have been mapped out as possible detours, she added.

Yeh went on to say that most detour signs have already been put in place and the rest will be ready by the end of the week at the latest. Her ministry has also ordered a print run of new road maps showing the detours.

She added that her ministry is obligated to take full responsibility for the 22 injured people and said an ad hoc team will be formed to assist the injured with their medical care and compensation-related matters.

Lin Neng-pai, chairman of the Public Construction Commission, said at the same meeting that his commission has already formed a special task force to probe the bridge collapse and that the team is scheduled to announce its preliminary investigative conclusions and recommendations on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENERAL INTERPELLATION SESSION MAY BE POSTPONED

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that he will meet with the ruling and opposition parties to discuss whether to postpone the opening of the next general interpellation session from its scheduled date of Sept. 15.

Wang, who had just returned from a visit to the United States, said that if the general interpellation session can be postponed, there will be more time to prepare for the main focus of the new session -- a review of the general budget of the central government.

President Chen Shui-bian said recently that he hoped the general interpellation session could be put off and the gap between the general interpellations lengthened, although he added that he would respect the final decision of the Legislative Yuan.

Wang noted that the review of the general budget usually takes two to two-and-a-half months and must be completed by the end of November according to the Constitution. If the new interpellation session opens as scheduled on Sept. 15, he went on, legislators will have difficulty completing the review of the general budget by the November deadline.
Wang is scheduled to meet with the ruling and opposition parties on Saturday to make a final decision on the timing of the general interpellation session.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomingtang are said to be in favor of a postponement, while the New Party and People First Party are against the idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14% OF STOCK VALUE WIPED OUT IN THREE MONTHS

TEXT.P: The total market value of shares on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) has been cut by 14 percent, or NT$1.39 trillion (US$44.83 billion), during the last three months, according to statistics released Wednesday by the TSE.

The TSE Capitalization Weighted Stock Index (TAIEX), the key market barometer, lost another 274 points Wednesday to close at a nine-month low of 7,543 , which is 1,572 points down from its June 7 peak of 9,115 during the three-month administration of President Chen Shui-bian.

That means NT$1.39 trillion has been wiped from the capitalization of NT$12.4 trillion of June 7, which would represent a sum of NT$63,000 for each man, woman and child if the loss were to be borne equally among everyone in Taiwan.
Hardest-hit have been non-tech industries and finance, which have seen their combined market value cut from NT$6.67 trillion to NT$5.32 trillion.

Analysts attributed the downward trend to the new administration's poor financial policy and its vigorous probe into several high-profile scandals involving well-known non-tech firms and financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BUDDHIST MASTER CALLS FOR MUTUAL RESPECT AMONG RELIGIONS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and C.M. Huang)

TEXT.P: Master Sheng Yen, founder of Taiwan's Buddhist Foundation of the Dharma Drum Mountain, called on Tuesday for mutual respect and tolerance among religious and other groups to ensure world peace.
He said he believes all religious and spiritual leaders are peace-loving people, but "there still exists the fact that different religions clash or even provoke wars against each other."

Sheng Yen made the call on the second day of the Millennium World Peace Summit for religious and spiritual leaders which opened at United Nations Headquarters a day earlier. Over 1,000 religious and spiritual leaders from all over the world are attending the four-day meeting. The gathering provides a forum to explore ways to resolve world conflicts and achieve world peace.

The senior monk, who was the first speaker, asked the world's religious and spiritual leaders to be tolerant of each other. "If you find that the doctrines of your faith contain something that is intolerant of other groups, or contradicts the promotion of world peace, then you should make new interpretations of those doctrines," he said.
"Every wholesome religion should get along peacefully with other groups so that it can, step by step, influence humankind to stay far away from the causes of war," he added.
He also stressed that religious people should cultivate wisdom to help them resolve problems such as poverty, environmental pollution and conflicts.

People around the world, despite their different faiths, should respect and love each other because "we are neighbors in the global village. Indeed, we are all sons and daughters born of the same Mother Universe," he explained.

It was his second speech since the meeting opened. During the opening ceremony, he introduced his ideas of how to "uplift the character of mankind and build the world into a pure land." The Buddhist leader is attending the meeting in his capacity as founder of the Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Association of the United States, apparently because the organizers feared it would offend Beijing if he came as a representative of the Taiwan headquarters of the organization.

The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, was not invited to the meeting due to pressure from mainland China, but he prepared a message that was read to the meeting by one of his representatives.

In addition to Master Sheng Yen, several other Buddhist leaders from Taiwan are also attending the meeting, including Master Hsin Tao of the Lingchiu Mountain and Master Yi Fa of the Buddhist Fukuangshen Group.
The summit is being held at two locations, with open dialogues held at United Nations Headquarters and closed-door sessions taking place at a New York hotel. The meeting will close on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE FM HOPES CROSS STRAIT ISSUE CAN BE RESOLVED PEACEFULLY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono on Wednesday reiterated Japan's hope that the cross-Taiwan Strait issue will be resolved peacefully through dialogue.
"This is our consistent stance," Kono said while giving a keynote address to 130 faculty members and cadres at China's Central Party School in Beijing, according to reports reaching Tokyo.
Speaking on Taiwan, Kono said Japan will continue to maintain unofficial relations with Taiwan.
He went on to say that in order to safeguard peace and stability in Northeast Asia, a dialogue mechanism must be set up among the nations of the region to further promote understanding.

Touching on the Korean peninsula issue, Kono suggested that North Korea, South Korea, the United States, Japan, mainland China and Russia should set up a "six-member organization" to promote dialogue between Seoul and Pyongyang.

Commenting on Tokyo-Beijing relations, Kono noted that anti-Beijing feeling is escalating in Japan. Beijing's national defense budget increases year by year and Beijing's failure to appreciate Japan's economic assistance to Beijing have also invited criticism and doubt from the Japanese people, he said.

He said future Japanese economic assistance to Beijing must get the understanding and support of the people of both nations. Japan had originally planned to offer a special loan of 17.2 billion yen to Beijing, but it has been shelved due to objections from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) over Beijing "spy ships" operating in Japanese territorial waters.

Kono said that he has suggested that the two sides set up a mechanism to resolve the ship incursion dispute and added that he reached a tentative agreement on the matter on Aug. 28 with his mainland counterpart Tang Jia-xuan. Details of the agreement will be discussed in September, Kono saidn.

Touching on Beijing's opposition to a proposed theater missile defense system (TMD) to be jointly produced by Japan and the United States, Kono said that Japan has not yet decided whether it wants to be part of the system.
He also categorically denied that there has been a revival of militarism in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TANG WARNS AGAINST TYPHOON MARIA

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei on Wednesday instructed related agencies to be cautious of a possible change in direction of Typhoon Maria and to make preparations to avoid possible storm damage.
Tang issued his instructions after listening to a report by Chao Kang, chief of the National Fire Administration, regarding measures to reinforce disaster prevention and rescue operations.

Maria, the 13th tropical storm this year, remained stationary Wednesday afternoon in the South China Sea near the Tungsha Islands and weather forecasters said it would probably move northeastward toward southwestern Taiwan in the near future.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) had just lifted a land warning for Typhoon Prapiroon, but warned that seas around Taiwan's northern and northeastern coast were still under Prapiroon's influence.
Although Prapiroon did not cause much damage to Taiwan, the disaster prevention and rescue centers around this island were still on the alert for Maria.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY ROC AGENCIES BACK CONTINUED FREEZE ON FILIPINO WORKERS

TEXT.P: Many government agencies and private associations Wednesday gave a thumbs-down to a proposal to lift a ban on the import of Philippine workers.

Officials from relevant government agencies and representatives from private industry and manpower agencies associations voiced their opposition at an inter-ministerial meeting called by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The CLA announced in May a three-month import ban on workers from the Philippines, effective from June 1, due to a combination of factors, including Manila representative office's frequent interference in disputes between Filipinos and local employers.
As the ban is set to expire Thursday, the CLA invited officials from various agencies and trade associations to discuss whether the ban should be extended or lifted.

The inter-ministerial meeting, chaired by CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen, was attended by officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the National Police Administration, the Bureau of Immigration, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), the Chinese National Federation of Industries, the ROC General Chamber of Commerce (GCC) and manpower brokerages associations in Taipei, Kaohsiung and other major cities around the island.

During the meeting, CEPD officials and representatives from major trade and manpower agents associations called for an extension of the ban on the grounds that more time is needed to ascertain Manila's sincerity in wishing to resolve some unsolved problems involving Filipino workers.

For one thing, they said, the abscondence rate among the workers remains high. Of the 5,234 unaccountable absconding foreign workers, 2,666 are Philippine nationals. CLA tallies show that Philippine workers' abscondence rate stood at 2.47 percent in July, the highest rate among all foreign workers.

CEPD officials said the Philippine government has not fully fulfilled the five ROC demands for improving Philippine worker-related issues over the past three months, including whether the Philippine government has agreed to pay the medical bills of illegal Filipino workers and repay the funds that the CLA paid in the past.

CEPD officials further said that although the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO), which represents Philippine interests in Taipei in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, promised not to interfere with labor-management disputes involving Philippine workers, it remained unclear whether it would present a written guarantee.

GCC representatives complained that MECO had still failed to take steps to discourage legally imported Philippine workers from absconding, while some manpower agents complained that Philippine officials are not polite when dealing with them over relevant issues.
Nevertheless, some manpower agencies from central Taiwan said they support the lifting of the import ban as it would help local high-tech companies to resolve manpower shortage problems.
After the debate, CLA Vice Chairman Kuo did not make an immediate decision on whether the ban will be retained or lifted after the current ban expires at the end of August.
He said the CLA will make a final decision within two days, based on the opinions expressed by the various quarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS TO RE-REGISTER BETWEEN SEPTEMBER-DECEMBER

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang, which lost its 55-year grip on power in Taiwan in last March's presidential election, has urged its members to re-register between Sept. 1 and Dec. 31.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan and the four party vice chairmen will take the lead by re-registering at the party's Taipei City Committee on Sept. 1, accompanied by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a party member.
Chan Chun-po, director of the KMT Taipei City Committee, told the media that re-registration of party members is an important step in the party's reform efforts.

He noted that the move is also directly connected with next spring's nomination of KMT candidates for the election of legislators and with next summer's direct election of party chairman by party members.
The KMT boasted of having 2.5 million members before the presidential election. But after the election, the party discovered that the figure had been inflated.

The KMT National Congress has adopted a comprehensive reform plan, aiming at a comeback in the next presidential election four years hence, and re-registration of party members is part of the reform plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS TO BEGIN OIL SALES IN SEPTEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin County, southern Taiwan, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics will produce an annual 6.4 million tons of diesel, 4.29 million tons of gasoline, and 3.81 million tons of naphtha starting September, a senior official of the Taiwan plastics giant said Wednesday.
Introduction of the company's petroleum products to the local market in September will break the decades-old state monopoly in the local oil industry.

Wang Yung-fa, vice manager of Formosa Plastic's oil refining department, said that the company's new 407-hectare refinery plant will manufacture 12 petrochemical products, including diesel, gasoline, naphtha, and aviation fuel.

Wang added that the plant's daily oil refinery capacity is 450,000 barrels, making it the largest oil refinery in the world to be built in such a short time. Construction of the plant cost NT$93 billion (US$3 billion), he said.

Chi Chun-chin, vice president of Formosa Life Station, Taiwan's first private oil company and a wholly owned subsidiary of Formosa Plastics Group, said that approximately 300 gas stations nationwide have already joined its franchise.
Chi said that another 550 gas stations are expected to become a part of the company's franchise by the end of next year and possibly help Formosa Plastics garner 50 percent of the market.
With the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) monopoly on the local oil market broken, oil prices will be set by free market factors for the first time.

A senior CPC official said that Formosa Plastics' entry into the local oil market will help lower prices, but added that an expected rise in international crude prices in September will likely maintain upward pressure on local oil prices.
The official said that some gas stations may sacrifice their profit margin temporarily in order to be more competitive.

He went on to say that domestic consumer prices are facing a sensitive moment due to the recent passage of several typhoons. Therefore, he said, the CPC is not willing to adjust its prices for fear of triggering an increase in consumer prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVENUE OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE EXPECTED TO GROW BY 20%

TEXT.P: The telecommunications service will grow by around 20 percent this year, according to figures released Wednesday on the eve of the Taipei international telecommunications show.

According to the China External Trade Development Council, the increase has been due to the liberalization of the telecommunications market and the increasing popularity of the Internet over the past two years.

The council said that the domestic production value of Taiwan's telecommunications industry in 1999 totaled NT$116.63 billion (US$3.75 billion), while its overseas production value reached NT$24.36 billion.
In terms of the structure of the products, 1999 was a year that saw the rising popularity of mobile phones, with production of 1 million in Taiwan and 1.8 million overseas.
It is estimated that the market for buyers of second mobile phones will surpass that of first-time buyers, with ample room for growth.

Some 84 percent of locally produced telecommunications products were for export, with the top three destinations being North America (43 percent), Western Europe (20 percent), and mainland China (11 percent).
One noteworthy phenomenon is that the mainland China market was larger than that of Japan (9 percent).

It is estimated that the telecommunications industry will see a dramatic increase this year, with domestic production value of telecommunications products growing by 38.9 percent to reach NT$162.06 billion (US$5.17 billion), while the growth of overseas production value will reach a whopping 127.4 percent, or NT$55.39 billion (US$1.78 billion).

In the telecommunications service market, the number of mobile phone users grew by 144 percent last year, while the number of Internet users grew by 59 percent. The revenue of telecommunications services was NT$233.5 billion (US$7.5 billion)last year, and this year is expected to grow by 20 percent to NT$279.9 billion (US$9 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS BRISBANE MAYOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received on Wednesday Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomed his visit aimed at strengthening exchanges between the Republic of China and Australia and seeking intercity exchanges.

Chen congratulated Soorley on his fourth election as Brisbane's mayor this year and expressed gratitude to Soorley for his inviting Chen to attend a 1996 Asia-Pacific city conference when he was Taipei city mayor.
Chen said Soorley had scored extraordinary success in making Brisbane one of the cities most suitable for living in the world.
For his part, Soorley congratulated Chen on his election success and added that his election made an enormous contribution to the peaceful transfer of power in the ROC.
Chen lauded Soorley's idea of establishing an Asia-Pacific intercity conference aimed at reinforcing cooperation among the cities of the region, an idea which has enjoyed great success.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WILL MULL 'KINMEN SPECIAL ZONE' PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The government will mull the proposal to develop the frontline island of Kinmen into a "special trade zone" after the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait are opened smoothly, a senior official said Wednesday.

John C.C. Teng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the statement at a public hearing on Kinmen's future economic development.

The hearing was organized by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ching-pao to discuss pros and cons of the planned opening of "mini three links," which refers to the opening of direct trade, postal and shipping links between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu and mainland China's southeastern coastal cities such as Xiamen and Fuzhou.
Legislator Chen said the government should simultaneously consider developing Kinmen into a "special economic zone" for Taiwan-mainland China trade to help boost the frontline's economic development.

In response, Teng said the proposal deserves further discussion. "In fact, the 'special zone' concept is not new in Taiwan. We already have export processing zones, high-tech industrial parks and offshore cross-strait transshipping center. We can apply these successful experiences to boost Kinmen's development," he noted.
Nevertheless, Teng said, all the above-mentioned projects have managed to succeed mainly because they have been implemented only after long-term planning and extensive discussion.
At the moment, Teng said, the MAC focuses its efforts on evaluating the possible impact of the opening of "mini three links" on Kinmen's security, law and order, as well as its overall economy.
"We hope the opening will not cause any adverse impact on the well-being of all Kinmen residents and our country's overall defense operations," Teng said.

He noted that the MAC will unveil a detailed evaluation report in mid-September as originally scheduled. "We will then begin practical planning work to pave the way for actual opening of 'mini three links,'" Teng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SERVICE MAKES LIFE MORE COLORFUL: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that public service enriches life, self-sacrifice makes life more meaningful and helping others makes life more colorful.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with recipients of this year's "Good Men, Good Deeds" Award. A total of 85 individuals and 45 groups were cited this year for their public-spirited deeds and contributions.
The human rights lawyer-turned-president said he is convinced that everybody is a good person and can do good deeds every day and everywhere.
Many of this year's award recipients had contributed greatly to relief and rehabilitation work after Taiwan was rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999.

Chen said the 921 earthquake shattered Taiwan's landscape, destroyed many homes and claimed some 2,400 lives. "Thanks to your humanitarian concern and voluntary assistance, many earthquake victims have managed to get on their feet again. I appreciate and admire your great contributions," he added.

Saying that all Taiwan residents, regardless of their ethnic origin, profession, social status or political affiliation, form one big family, Chen said "all family members should help each other without prejudice or bias."
Chen said he believes that the contribution of each "Good Men, Good Deeds" award recipient marks an epic story and can serve as good materials for school textbooks.
Touching on his just-concluded overseas visit, Chen said he feels proud to see ROC religious, charity, educational, medical and agricultural groups offer assistance and services to the ROC's allies.

"Following my first post-inauguration overseas trip, I have come to understand that service is not an obligation, but a privilege," he said, adding that the ROC should help its allies with economic development because doing so is tantamount to helping itself.

Chen's Aug. 13-25 "journey of friendship" took him to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in Central America, and three African states -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO JOINTLY SPONSOR FORUM ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Wednesday that he will jointly sponsor a cross-Taiwan Strait ties forum with Hsu Hsin-liang, senior adviser to the president, in mid-September.

He was responding to domestic media reports that the Rising People Foundation led by Hsu, and the New Taiwanese Foundation chaired by Ma, are planning to hold a supra-party cross-strait ties round-table forum in mid-September.

It was reported that organizers will invite the chairmen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party -- Frank Hsieh, Lien Chan and James Soong -- as well as several others well-versed in cross-strait affairs, including Lin Yang-kang, Chang King-yuh and Su Chi, to take part in the forum.

Ma urged the public not to associate the forum with "unnecessary speculation" that the purpose of the forum is to compete on equal terms with the supra-party ad hoc group on cross-strait affairs advocated by President Chen Shui-bian.
He also noted that the agenda of the forum has yet to be finalized.

Meanwhile, Ma said that a visit to mainland China on Sept. 4-13 by Taipei Deputy Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsiung will not be a "secret envoy mission" and added that there will be no secret itinerary for his trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS MEET WITH TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Fang Hsu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A People First Party (PFP) delegation from Taiwan attended a symposium in Beijing on Wednesday to discuss the development of cross-Taiwan Strait economic relations and related issues with Taiwan businessmen there.

Hsieh Kun-chung, president of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Beijing, proposed that the Taiwan government realize direct trade, postal and transportation links with mainland China as soon as possible.

He also expressed the hope that Taipei will allow Taiwan financial institutions to gain a foothold on the mainland, simplify procedures for mainland people wishing to visit Taiwan, and resume cross-strait negotiations at an early date.

Liu Sung-fan, former Legislative Yuan president and leader of the PFP mission, said that PFP Chairman James Soong has recently spelled out the party's policy on the development of cross-strait ties and protection of the interests of Taiwan businessmen in the mainland.
He said that he will bring the proposals of the Taiwan businessmen back to Taiwan for further study.
The PFP delegation of nine legislators visited Beijing officials on Tuesday, and held talks with Taiwan businessmen on Wednesday morning.
On Wednesday afternoon, it heard a briefing on the mainland's experience in developing missile and satellite technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN STATESMAN VISITS TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Willy Wimmer, vice president of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a week-long visit.

Wimmer, who previously served as Germany's vice defense minister and is now a parliamentarian, was invited by the Foreign Ministry to gain a better understanding of Republic of China party politics since the transfer of power on May 20.

During his visit, Wimmer will call on President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and Vice Secretary-General of National Security Council Chiou I-jen. He will also meet members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the opposition People First Party and the opposition New Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE OPPOSITION PARTY MEMBERS FAVOR VISIT BY ROC EX-PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A senior official of Japan's opposition Democratic Party said in Beijing on Tuesday that a majority of the Democratic Party members favor a visit to Japan by Republic of China's former President Lee Teng-hui.

Naoto Kan, chairman of the Democratic Party's Policy Coordination Council, told a Beijing press conference of his fellow party members believe Japan should not hinder Lee's visit in a private capacity.
Kan made the remarks after meeting with Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen.
Kan noted that democracy has not developed in mainland China, while Taiwan has successfully accomplished the transition of political power through democratic elections.

Addressing Japanese economic assistance to Beijing, Kan urged his countrymen not to overreact to the activities of Beijing's ships in Japanese territorial waters, but he added that future economic assistance must be severely controlled because of Japan's worsening domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUBLISHER WARNED IN BEIJING AGAINST AIRING VIEWS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan publisher taking part in a book exhibition in Beijing was warned on Wednesday against talking to the mass media after he complained in an interview about what he called Beijing's neglect of freedom of speech and publishing.

Shen Teng-en of the Taiwan-based Yuan-ching Publishing Co. told CNA that a Beijing official warned him to refrain from giving interviews after his criticism of Beijing's lack of press freedom was carried in several Hong Kong and Taiwan press reports and raised eyebrows among Beijing leaders.

Although security guards at the Beijing International Book Exhibition had beefed up patrols around Yung-ching's stall at the fair, Shen said he will not bow to the pressure and will keep speaking out against what he considers Beijing's restrictions on the publishing industry.
Shen said he has received encouragement from some local people who share his views and were glad he voiced their long-repressed feelings.

He also complained that Beijing has stuck a label reading "Don't violate the one China policy" on every Taiwan-printed book displayed at the exhibition, without the consent of their Taiwan publishers.
Shen said the 31 Taiwan publishers taking part in the exhibition might withdraw en masse if harassed further by Beijing on political grounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LEADERSHIP CHANGES TO BE MADE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing leadership changes will be made from late 2002 to early 2003, with the pivotal event being the 16th National Congress of the Communist Party in late 2002, according to Asiaweek magazine.
By that time, most of the older officials will have been eased out of office to make way for a significantly younger generation, the magazine reported in its Sept. 8 issue.

According to the report, Vice President Hu Jintao is to take over from Jiang Zemin as Communist Party general secretary and state president. Jiang will retain his chairmanship of the Central Military Commission, thus remaining the power behind the throne.

In addition, the report went on, Guangdong Communist Party Secretary Li Changchun has replaced Vice Premier Wen Jiabao as the front-runner for Premier Zhu Rong-ji's job. Zhu has long made it clear that he does not wish to serve a second term and Li's Guangdong roots may help defuse resentment about the ever-expanding clout of Jiang's "Shanghai faction," according to the magazine.

Hu and party personnel chief Zeng Qinghong will be in charge of preparations for the 16th Party Congress. Zeng is rising in stature, reported Asiaweek, and is slated to become vice president when Hu takes over from Jiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSING CLIMBER WALKS OUT OF MOUNTAINS UNAIDED
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A doctor who was separated from his mountain-climbing companions and had been missing since Typhoon Bilis swept across the island on Aug. 22 checked into a hotel Wednesday.

According to Liao Yueh-lang, deputy director of eastern Taiwan's Taroko National Park Administration, Chen walked into the hotel at 7:30 p.m., checked in, and telephoned his family to inform them of his safe return.

Liao, who said he had sent someone to visit Chen at the hotel, said that he received the news from Wang Ting-chung, one of Chen's climbing companions and a fellow doctor at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.

Chen was on a climbing trip in Hualien County when Bilis struck. He was reported missing on Aug. 22, whereupon military and police helicopters began trying to search for him. However, poor weather conditions and limited visibility forced the helicopters to stay out of the region until four days after Chen was first reported missing.
Another wave of helicopter searches were scheduled to be conducted Thursday, but Chen appeared in the hotel lobby, looking "quite healthy," according to hotel employees.
The hotel employees also said that Chen told them he found shelter from the torrential rain and simply rested until the typhoon passed.

Bilis, the strongest storm to hit Asia so far this year, landed in Hualien and ripped through Taiwan on the night of Aug. 22, leaving at least 11 people dead, several others missing, and many private homes and public facilities destroyed or damaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10TH MERCURIES CUP MASTER GOLF TOURNEY TO TEE OFF

TEXT.P: The Tenth Taiwan's Mercuries Cup Master Golf Tournament will tee off Thursday at the Taiwan Golf & Country Club in the Taipei suburb of Tamshui.
More than 100 golfers from 16 countries and regions around the world will take part in the NT$10 million (US$300,000) four-day competition.
The tourney, which is one of three majors to be played in Taiwan, will formally join the Davidoff Asian Tour this year.

Several foreign golfers, including Simon Dyson of England, Jyoti Randhawa of India, Gerry Norquest of the United States and Boonchu Ruangkit of Thailand will vie for the title and US$50,000 in prize money.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT FOUR CENTRAL AMERICA STATES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she will visit four Republic of China allies in Central America in late September.

Dubbing her trip as a "soft diplomatic visit" aimed to show what she described in English as the country's "soft power," the first female ROC vice president said she will visit Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador and Belize.
A group of local female leaders, as well as leaders in the fields of culture and science will be invited to accompany her on the visit, said Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The opposition Kuomintang calls for return to the National Unification Council mechanism to stabilize relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Cash crunch halts anti-missile plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 73.02 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 73.02 points to close at 7,616.98.
Market turnover amounted to NT$89.74 billion (US$2.89 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 31, or the third day of the eighth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1979: A China Airlines Boeing 707 cargo plane takes off from Kaohsiung for Nicaragua capital of Managua with 20 metric tons of peanut seeds and three metric tons of hemp seeds for fiber production.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOVE UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 73.02 points to close at 7,616.98.
The bourse opened at 7,458.34, and fluctuated between 7,661.73 and 7,440.81 during trading.

A total of 1.87 billion shares worth NT$89.74 billion (US$2.89 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 1.66 billion stocks traded on market turnover of NT$86.23 billion (US$2,78 billion).
Only one of the eight major categories posted losses, as construction shares moved down by 0.6 percent.

The other major categories all gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.3 percent, electrical stocks at 0.8 percent, cement shares at 0.6 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 253 to 242, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATION NEEDS TO SHARPEN ITS COORDINATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei admitted on Thursday that there are some aspects of the administration's efficiency that need to be honed, particularly in its coordination capabilities.

In his first press conference since taking office on May 20, Tang promised to the country that his administration is willing to listen to any advice and criticism that comes from a spirit of good will to improve the government's performance and efficiency. "Criticism is the driving force behind progress," he said.

Tang, who was defense minister before being appointed premier by President Chen Shui-bian after Chen won the 2000 presidential election and ended the Kuomintang's 55-year grip on executive power in Taiwan, said that the Executive Yuan will lose no time in speeding up the administrative locomotive so as to "more quickly address the public's urgent needs and better safeguard their interests."
The premier stressed that the administration has no plans to reshuffle its personnel, at least not in the immediate future.

He said it is unfair to judge a minister's performance or capability after only three months. "If anyone is to blame for the administration's not-so-commendable performance, then that person is me," Tang proclaimed.

Tang made the remarks three days after President Chen said in his latest press conference that if there were "people" (Cabinet officials) who cannot keep up the pace or cope with the tempo of the ongoing reform efforts, they should be replaced.

Tang spelled out his administrative guidelines and goals at the press conference. He said the Executive Yuan has completed a preliminary blueprint for developing Taiwan into a "green silicon island," and plans to usher Taiwan into the era of the "knowledge economy" so as to allow the island's residents a better living environment while retaining its economic competitiveness.

Reacting to wide criticism of the new government's economic policies and a spate of major mishaps, including the Pachang Creek tragedy and the collapse of Kaoping Bridge, Tang said that these abnormalities are reflections of a breakdown of public integrity and law and order, as well as a symbol of Taiwan's decreasing international competitiveness.
He pointed out that if these trends are not effectively reversed, the country's long-term development will be hindered.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market rose on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 60 points to close at 7,660, with 5,611 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 60 points to finish at 7,700, with 137 contracts traded; while December futures increased 43 points to close at 7,754, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading on Thursday were set at 7,600 for September; 7,640 for October; 7,711 for December; 7,874 for next March; and 7,813 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
September TE futures moved up 4 points to close at 430, on 1,692 contract transactions; while October TE futures lost 6.9 points to finish at 423.1, with nine contracts traded.
December TE futures moved down 4.9 points to close at 425.1, with only one contract transaction. No transactions were reported for other months.
September TF futures increased 17 points to close at 830, with 683 contracts changing hands; while October TF futures moved up 10 points to finish at 830, with five contract transactions.
December TF futures gained 16.4 points to close at 838, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORACLE SELECTS TAIWAN AS ITS GREATER CHINA E-COMMERCE BASE
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Yolanda K.C. Chen)

TEXT.P: Oracle Corp., the second largest computer software company in the world, has selected Taiwan as its Greater China base for developing e-commerce in the Chinese language format, a move that illustrates the island's international significance in the information industry.

Lin Yi-fu, Republic of China vice minister of Economic Affairs, is scheduled to lead a group of high-tech leaders from Taiwan to the Bay Area to sign a strategic alliance agreement with Oracle on Sept. 12. The alliance is expected to assist industries in Taiwan to develop e-commerce strategies.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will provide Oracle with administrative assistance, while the Silicon Valley-based firm will transfer its advanced technology to companies in Taiwan, MOEA sources said. They added that the alliance will have a significant impact on e-commerce throughout Greater China.

During their stay in the San Francisco area, Lin and his entourage are scheduled to hold an explanatory meeting in Silicon Valley on Sept. 15. They will use the opportunity to encourage high-tech corporations there to invest in Taiwan, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-CORRUPTION CRUSADE AIMED AT CREATING BETTER CLIMATE: PM

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Thursday that the government's current campaign against corruption in financial institutions is mainly aimed at creating a better business climate and maintaining long-term economic stability.
The four star-general-turned-premier made the remarks at his first press conference since taking office on May 20.

Tang said although the government's investigations into loan scandals or kickback scams involving some local financial institutions have caused a stock market slump, the efforts to stamp out corruption will have a positive effect on Taiwan's overall business environment in the long run.
Noting that lending irregularities in the financial institutions are "minority cases" after all, Tang said the ongoing anti-corruption campaign will only bring about "short-term" pain.
"If we are daunted by 'short-term' pain and fail to take action against corruption in banking institutions, we may have to endure 'long-term' pain and a gloomier future," the premier warned.

Tang rejected allegations that the current probes into bank lending activities are a government tactic to win back the public's support after many of its policy goals, directions and measures failed to live up to public expectations.

"The government has no political consideration in launching the anti-corruption campaign," Tang stressed, adding that the government's only concern is to wipe out irregularities and streamline financial market order.

Tang further said Taiwan's economic fundamentals are healthy and sound. "My observation is that the recent stock market plunge was mainly caused by psychological factors or confidence problems," he noted.

In fact, Tang said, the public need not be pessimistic about the country's economic prospects. "Most of our listed companies have registered gains in their business turnover so far this year, and our exports and industrial production continue rising," he added.
Turning to the national pension system issue, Tang said the government must exercise prudence in designing and implementing the proposed social welfare program.

"Many countries have suffered setbacks in implementing a national pension system. We cannot afford to endure a failure. We must carefully craft a well-designed system to cater to the domestic demand and ensure its success," Tang said.

As local economists and experts in the relevant field remain far divided over the designing and timing for implementation, Tang said the government will not decide when the pension system will be inaugurated until after further discussion with the legislature.

The government has mulled the national pension system issue for more than 10 years and has been working on details of the system in the past four years. However, the nation still fails to forge a consensus on most of the details concerning the system. Premier Tang said earlier this month that the proposed national pension system cannot be inaugurated in January 2001 as originally promised.
