DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS REBEL IN JIANGXI, CHINA: REPORT

TEXT.P: Canada's national broadcaster reported Wednesday that mainland China is facing one of the largest civil disturbances in recent years.
Thousands of farmers are in revolt near the cradle of the communist revolution in Jiangxi province, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) said.
According to local officials, heavily armed paramilitary police were sent to the region earlier this month, the CBC said.

The police were moved in after rampaging farmers smashed government offices and looted the homes of the rich, the CBC said. In the most recent clash, the report noted, more than 20,000 peasants staged a violent protest against heavy taxes.
Scores of farmers were arrested, and authorities said that it took five days to bring the rioting and looting under control, the CBC said in its daily major news broadcast.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE FARMERS HIT HARD BY CHINA'S ECONOMIC REFORMS

TEXT.P: Hundreds of millions of Chinese farmers have been hit hard as they missed out on the benefits of mainland China's economic reforms, forcing them to resort to demonstrations against the growing abuse of power by local officials.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, The Australian Financial Review on Thursday reported that the villages around Fengcheng in the impoverished central province of Jiangxi -- a key recruiting ground for the Chinese Communist Party during the late 1920s and early 1930s -- are now at the vanguard of a new social movement in mainland China, with up to 20,000 poor farmers rioting last week in protest of onerous local taxes.

The daily quoted the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy in China as revealing that at least 50 farmers had been arrested after attacking the offices and homes of local government officials, and prompting Beijing to send more than 2000 police to villages around Fengcheng. By last Wednesday, the protests spread to other towns of Yuandu, Baitu, Duantang and Xiaotang, the daily reported.
"Farmers do not have enough to eat, while even a junior Yuandu township official will be able to own at least a car and a house," the daily quoted an unnamed farmer at Yuandu as saying.

The daily reported that many of the rural communities that account for 70 percent of China's population of 1.3 billion are increasingly missing out on the benefits of Beijing's program of economic reform, which was started in 1978 by Deng Xiaoping, the late former paramount leader.

The daily quoted a recent study by China's Rural Development Institute as indicating that the average income of urban workers in 1999 was 2.65 times that of rural workers, compared to 2.51 times greater than rural laborers in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN SCIENCE PARK TO BE COMPLETED AHEAD OF SCHEDULE: NSC

TEXT.P: Development of Taiwan's second science-based industrial park will be completely finished in 2005, about five years ahead of schedule, National Science Council (NSC) Chairman Weng Cheng-yi said on Thursday.

Tainan Science-based Industrial Park (TSIP), patterned after Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan, is touted as Taiwan's second "Silicon Valley" and is located in Hsinshih township in the southern Taiwan's Tainan County.

By 2005, when the site has been fully completed, about 200 high-tech companies over a span of ten years are expected to begin operations there, Weng said, adding that these firms will hire some 77,000 employees and generate business worth over NT$900 billion (US$29 billion) every year.

Noting that the development of such high-tech industrial centers is based on a "win-win" principle, Weng said the southern science park will not only be the latest engine of Taiwan's "knowledge economy," but also will become a locomotive power for economic, social and cultural development in nearby areas.

TSIP is committed to being a good neighbor to proximate areas, Weng added. In the future, he said, the southern science park will combine its industrial operations with a protected natural sanctuary. It will include a museum, and also conserve several invaluable archaeological sites and some parts of a sugar cane plantation, he said.

According to Chen Chun-wei, director of the TSIP Preparatory Committee, the park will consist of an area of 638 hectares, of which 262 hectares will be reserved for company and plant locations. So far, 70 percent of roads in the park have already been completed, 70 percent of the public facilities are available, but only about 5 percent of the projected landscape development has been finished, Chen noted.

TSIP, which became partially operational in 1998, currently has 42 companies on its registration list. Of the total, 13 have already become operational and begun commercial production, while six have just begun construction and development.

Water supply, an issue of concern to many industrialists, will be tackled in time, Chen continued. Daily water consumption is forecasted to reach 200,000 metric tons eventually, and the volume is expected to be supplied jointly by Taiwan Water Company and the Chia Nan Farmland and Irrigation Association, he said. To further secure a safe supply, Chen said, TSIP authorities may also consider the establishment of a desalination plant.
The park will have its own incineration plant, landfill and waste water processing system to manage waste from TSIP companies, Chen noted.

In addition to the three special industrial zones that the southern science park will accommodate -- agricultural biotechnology, semiconductors and microelectronic precision machinery -- TSIP is also envisaged as accommodating an animal research center, a microchip design center, a telecommunications research center and a national laboratory, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 300 COMMON DRUGS IDENTIFIED AS CAUSING LUNG DISEASES

TEXT.P: More than 300 common drugs have been identified by a French physician as causing lung diseases, including coughing and asthma, as side-effects.

Professor Philippe Camus of the University Medical Center in Dijon on Wednesday told about 15,000 specialists from 84 countries attending the first World Congress on Lung Health and Respiratory Diseases in Paris that he had found at least 50 lung diseases and syndromes that could be caused or aggravated by common medicines, The Australian reported on Thursday.

He said about 310 drugs had so far been identified as affecting lungs. These drugs have been supplied for disorders such as high blood pressure, allergies, rheumatism, infections and cancer, he said, adding that they all can cause lung diseases, he added.

He said he had found at least 50 lung diseases and syndromes, including coughing, breathlessness, pleurisy, and acute respiratory failure, that could be caused or aggravated by common medicines, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ENDEMIC' FINANCIAL STORM IS UNLIKELY IN TAIWAN: BUSINESS MAGNATE

TEXT.P: An "endemic" financial storm is unlikely to occur in Taiwan as the country's business and industrial structures are healthy and sound, a local business magnate said on Thursday.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, discounted current worries that the government's ongoing anti-corruption campaign, which has driven the local bourse to a new low and sent shock waves through the island's banking institutions, will eventually trigger an "endemic" financial storm.

Koo said the Asian economic crisis, which began to batter Asia in late 1997, was mainly caused by excessive borrowing in Southeast Asian countries -- which is not the case in Taiwan. He added that any dramatic economic crash on the island is unlikely, as Taiwan has almost no foreign debt and holds foreign reserves of greater than US$120 billion.

Koo, who was part of President Chen Shui-bian's entourage visiting Central America and Africa earlier this month, said that unless a war erupts, the government should never step in to intervene in the stock market.

Nevertheless, he pointed out, the Taiwan stock market has developed in a biased and abnormal manner, with the majority of funds pouring into technology stocks while prices of traditional industrial stocks have dropped to levels below their initial offering price.
Koo said this situation, which is seldom seen in other countries, can only be alleviated if the government addresses it with power and determination.
However, Koo did not elaborate on exactly how the government work to revive the local bourse.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.003 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$31.070.
The local currency opened at NT$31.058 and was traded between NT$31.058 and NT$31.073.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$212.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO URGENCY TO DISCUSS NUC PROBLEMS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Thursday he sees no urgency for the Republic of China government to handle issues related to the National Unification Council (NUC) and the Guidelines for National Unification at the moment.
Tang made the statement in response to an inquiry about his views concerning relations across the Taiwan Strait at his first press conference since taking office on May 20.
Both the NUC and the unification guidelines are part of the ROC government's mechanism for handling cross-strait ties. Both of them were set up or formulated a decade ago during the Kuomintang reign.

Following the transition of power from the KMT to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), there have been discussions whether the unification guidelines should be revised, whether President Chen Shui-bian should follow the precedent set by his predecessor to chair the NUC, and other related issues.

Asked about his views on the NUC and the unification guidelines, Premier Tang said he is not in a position to make any comments on the issue because the NUC is basically a consultative body to the president.

But at the request of journalists, Tang still expressed his opinions about the issue. Weighing the current circumstances, Tang said, it is not the right time to discuss whether the unification guidelines should be amended or whether the NUC should be abolished.
The four star-general-turned-premier further said he hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume regular dialogue as soon as possible.

Tang pointed out that the current cross-strait deadlock lies in different views on "one China." Noting that Beijing interprets "one China" as the "People's Republic of China," Tang said the Republic of China government and people cannot accept Beijing's "one China" principle, which downgrades the ROC to a province under the PRC.

Tang stressed what the ROC wants is "dignity" and "parity" in dealing with Beijing. "So the ball is now in Beijing's court. We hope mainland will make positive response to our numerous goodwill gestures and resume cross-strait dialogue on an equal, reciprocal basis," he added.

Asked about the role of the newly formed Multiparty Task Force for cross-strait ties, Tang said the formation of the new body is part of the government's efforts to seek a national consensus on the future development of cross-strait relations.

Tang said as local people remain divided over whether Taiwan should move toward independence, seek cross-strait unification or maintain the status quo, the new 25-member Multiparty Task Force is expected to help forge a national consensus to serve as a basis for future cross-strait negotiations.
The Multiparty Task Force, headed by Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh, will hold a preliminary meeting Friday and is scheduled to call its first formal meeting Saturday.
The task force, composed of representatives from across the political and social spectrum, will serve as an advisory board to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM MARIA MOVING NORTHWARD, AWAY FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Maria, the 13th such storm in the Pacific this year, is now moving on a northward path and is less likely to influence Taiwan, officials of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Thursday.

The 13th tropical storm has changed its direction from northeast to north, and it is moving at 12 kilometers per hour, the officials said. Maria was located 500 kilometers from the southwest coast of Taiwan and was moving at 12 kilometers per hour at 9:30 a.m. Thursday, they added, noting that it is less likely to affect the island.
But the CWB said that if the storm changes its direction again and begins moving to the east, seas near Taiwan will be within its radius.

The officials said that because of Maria's surrounding air flows, southern and southeastern Taiwan had showers Thursday. The weather in other areas of Taiwan was sunny in the morning, with showers in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TELECOMMUNICATIONS SHOW KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The Taipei Telecommunications Show began Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC).

Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said at the opening ceremony that the public will benefit from the lower prices that will be the result of the free competition in the telecommunications market.
In addition, it has been forecast that the total telecom investment capital will hit NT$420 billion (US$13.55 billion) by 2001, which will promote Taiwan's economic development.

The show, which will run through Sunday, includes 167 exhibitors divided into five areas: telecommunication products; telecommunication services; Internet products; Internet services; and multimedia products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIOTECHNOLOGY FIRM AIMING AT GLOBAL MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan biotechnology company is conducting R&D in pharmaceutical ingredients, with a view to penetrating the global pharmaceutical market worth more than US$300 billion, a company executive said Thursday.

Scinopharm Taiwan, based in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park (TSIP) in southern Taiwan, has been one of the top companies in R&D of active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) in the world, and plans to mass-produce APIs in two years' time.

Scinopharm General Director Ma Hai-yi said that in global terms, the American pharmaceutical market accounts for 39 percent, the European market accounts for 29 percent and the Japanese market accounts for 18 percent. She added that there are no barriers in the pharmaceutical market, noting that medicines that pass US Food and Drug Administration testing can begin mass production.

She explained that the first stage of medicine production is material sourcing, followed by intermediates, API, and dosage in that order. However, she went on, APIs have been explored less, which is what motivated her company to investigate this area.

Thanks to government assistance in capital and preferential measures offered by the TSIP, the company was established in only 14 months, four or five times more rapidly than would be possible in the United States, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ON-LINE STOCK TRADING HITS 6 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's on-line stock trading hit 6 percent of total stock market turnover in June, but only 30 percent of local investors have traded stocks on-line, according to the results of a private investigation released Thursday.
The investigation revealed that Internet security fear is the main worry among investors. According to statistics, the payment defaults from January to July reached NT$250 million (US$8.06 million).

Officials of Elite On-Line, which conducted the investigation, said that since July 1997, 82 securities firms have begun providing on-line trading services. The investigation also revealed that domestic on-line orders accounted for 5.6 percent of total stock market turnover in this first half of this year.
Elite On-Line forecast that domestic securities firms and Internet banks will combine software and databases to provide integrated services in order to further promote their competitive edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR ANTI-CORRUPTION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Thursday his Cabinet will step up efforts to upgrade operational efficiency and improve inter-department coordination to live up to the public expectations.
The four star-general-turned-premier made the pledge at his first press conference since taking office on May 20.

Tang said a slew of disasters in recent months, including the toxic chemical solvent pollution of the Kaoping River, the Pachang Creek rescue bungle and the collapse of the Kaoping Bridge, highlighted a decline in the government's competitiveness.
If the government fails to take bold steps to reform, Tang said, Taiwan's overall national development will further affected.
Tang said the new government team will accelerate reform and develop a sound administrative system to upgrade civil service quality and efficiency.

The premier reaffirmed the government's determination to forge ahead with a sweeping crackdown on corruption, economic crime and gangster involvement in politics, commonly known as "black gold politics."

Noting that corruption and various forms of economic crime would threaten Taiwan's economic foundations, Tang said the government would not ease off the anti-"black gold" campaign even though the crackdown had caused a slump in the local stock market in recent weeks.

Tang said Taiwan's current economic fundamentals are sound and healthy. "There is no reason for pessimism over the local stock market since our economic basics are healthy and positive," the premier noted.

He further said the ongoing crackdown on business crime and corruption in the financial institutions was meant to help the financial sector solve problems to prevent the country from plunging into an economic storm caused by accumulated business irregularities.
Tang called for public confidence in Taiwan's economic prospects and asked the public to "bear the short-term pain in order to seek long-term financial stability."
Tang said the four special investigative teams under the anti-"black gold" action center have been working hard to probe corruption and kickback charges to help establish clean politics.
Starting next year, Tang said, the Cabinet will set up a public infrastructure bidding center to handle public tender for large-scale government procurement and construction projects.
"Starting next year, the new bidding center will handle tender for any government procurement or construction project worth NT$100 million or over to avoid irregularities," Tang explained.
In a 20-minute speech delivered before fielding questions from reporters, Tang outlined his Cabinet's blueprint for Taiwan's future economic development.
Tang said his Cabinet will endeavor to lay a sound system within the shortest possible period of time to facilitate the development of "knowledge economy."
"We will update our legal rules and establish a healthy system to ensure that Taiwan matches the levels of advanced countries in the domain of knowledge economy in 10 years," the premier said.

Moreover, Tang said, the Cabinet has drafted a package of measures to develop Taiwan into a "green silicon island" in the new century. "In tandem with the global development tempo, we will give priority to technological innovation, high-quality production and sustainable and environment-friendly growth," he added.

In an effort to help local financial institutions upgrade competitiveness, Tang said the government is amending the existing banking law to give local banks a freer hand in investment in relevant fields and merger with other financial institutions.

Touching on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Tang said the government will gradually ease restrictions on cross-strait merchandise, personnel, capital and technological exchanges in line with the development of bilateral ties.

Tang said the government hopes to make its cross-strait trade policy an integral part of its overall industrial development policy. "Therefore, we are ready to push for normalization of cross-strait commercial exchanges. We hope mainland China will respond to our goodwill appeal and start cross-strait talks on all relevant issues based on the principles of mutual respect and reciprocity."

DOC.HEADLINE: DENIM GIANT FINDS NEW LEASE OF LIFE IN CENTRAL AMERICA, AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By C.P. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Branching out may not be an easy task for many local businesses, but one Taiwan-based denim giant has successfully done so, both in Central America and Africa.

Nien Hsing Textile Co., Ltd., a Taipei-headquartered denim garment producer, has set up five factories in Nicaragua, two in Lesotho, and one in Mexico over the past decade, setting a success model for Taiwan firms -- especially those in the so-called "sunset industries" -- wishing to expand into other countries.
Founded in 1986, Nien Hsing is currently the world's largest jeans maker, with an annual output of 40 million pairs, and is also the sixth-largest denim maker, producing 60 million yards per year.

Nien Hsing Chairman Chen Ron-chu, a savvy business management maestro who played a key role in transforming his company into a world-class specialized manufacturer of denim fabric and garments in just a few years, granted an exclusive interview with CNA recently. Following is the full text of the interview:
Q: As Nien Hsing is a textbook model for expanding into Central America and Africa, can you tell us what pushed you to make the move when you did?

A: Troubled by rising production costs and a serious labor shortage at home, many local textile firms chose to move to mainland China and Southeast Asian countries. But in view of the United States' keen interest in promoting the formation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) area at that time, coupled with a follow-up Caribbean Basin Initiative (CBI) Enhancement Act to help neighboring poor countries, Nien Hsing decided to edge into Central America to take advantage of the duty-free initiatives provided by the United States to countries in that region.

As it has been predicted that the CBI Enhancement Act will officially become effective on Oct. 1 this year, Nien Hsing's relocation to Mexico and Nicaragua, as well as to Lesotho and Swaziland in Africa, will undoubtedly boost its future competitiveness and profitability.
Q: What is Nien Hsing's main business sphere and its major markets?

A: Our company is principally a jeans producer, although we plan to diversify into the casual wear market through a merger with a local firm this year. Currently, Nien Hsing is the only jeans factory in the world with an entire production line -- from roving, dyeing and weaving, through finishing. We have factories in Taiwan, Mexico, Nicaragua and Lesotho.

With the expansion of a Nicaragua plant to be completed this year, Nien Hsing is expected to become the world's No. 1 jeans producer. Famous US chains like Wal-Mart, JC-Penny, K-Mart, Sears and Target are our major clients, all of whom maintain very close relations with our company.
Q: What are Nien Hsing's prospects for future profit and development in Africa?

A: In addition to our present two garment factories in Lesotho, three more production plants and one more textile mill will begin mass production by 2001. Profits chalked up by the jeans garment division and the textile mill in that African country are estimated at NT$1.5 billion and NT$550 million, respectively, per year. To sum up, Nien Hsing's African plants are expected to produce a profit of at least NT$2.05 billion annually.
Q: What do you think of Nien Hsing share prices?

A: I strongly believe that Nien Hsing's earnings per share can reach NT$4 this year, since the company's profit margin has continued to grow in recent years. But to tell the truth, NT$50 per share is really too cheap for the company. Nien Hsing's share price would hit NT$100 if it were a hi-tech firm.

As a result of Nien Hsing's fast expansion in Central America and Africa, we would like to assure the general public that long-term investment in our company will be a solid move, and I predict that the firm's African plants will begin to post investment profits within two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW SOFTWARE INDUSTRIAL PARK TO BEGIN IN NOVEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The construction of a software industrial park will begin in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, in November, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

The development plan is being drawn up by the Export Processing Zone Administrarion (EPZA) under the MOEA, and the park, which is expected to become known as Taiwan's "Silicon Valley," will be designed to attract software designers.
EPZA Director-General Pan Tin-bai said the idea of the park has obtained a warm reception, with more than 130 software companies and financial institutions expressing the desire to invest there.
Pan added that the first stage of development will be completed in one year, at which time the park will begin trial operations.
He said the park, covering 2.2 hectares, will enjoy an excellent geographic advantage because of its proximity to Kaohsiung Harbor, the north-south freeway, and Kaohsiung International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE, DIPLOMACY AMONG CABINET PRIORITIES IN COMING YEAR

TEXT.P: National defense, diplomacy and clean politics are among the government's priority work plans for the coming year, according to an administrative report delivered by the Cabinet to the Legislative Yuan on Thursday.

The administrative report said that following Taiwan's first democratic transition of power between different political parties, the new government will endeavor to break the constraint of limited financial resources and live up to the expectations of the public.
The report outlined the government's policy goals for the coming year -- encouraging private participation, substantitating democratic politics and rebuilding social strength.
The report also detailed the government's priority tasks for the new year:
-- Establishing clean politics, improving public order and upgrading the quality of life;
-- Creating a better macro-economic climate to facilitate high-tech industry development and agricultural renovation;
-- Cultivating a happier educational environment and developing Taiwan into a cultural and information technology power;
-- Speeding up reconstruction in the "921" earthquake-affected regions.

The Legislative Yuan's new session will start Friday. According to current law, the Cabinet is required to refer its budget plan and administrative report for the coming fiscal year on the eve of the opening of the legislature's new session.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FOREIGN POLICY WILL REMAIN UNCHANGED: EX-ROC REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Ex-Republic of China representative in the United States Steven Chen said Thursday that no matter who wins the upcoming US presidential election, US foreign policy will not be drastically changed.

Chen said that "we should not expect the upcoming US president to instigate a drastic change in US foreign policy." However, he added, "we should watch closely the outcome of the US presidential election in November."

He pointed out that the coming two years will be important for cross-Taiwan Strait ties and for the tripartite Taipei-Washington-Beijing relationship because of the historic transition of power in the ROC, the US presidential election, and the fact that Beijing's political structure is expected to be restructured next year.

Delivering a lecture at the Foreign Ministry, Chen backed his analysis by pointing out that former US President Ronald Reagan said during his election campaign that he would restore diplomatic relations with the ROC, a claim that was never realized, and that in fact, the Reagan Administration signed the Aug. 17 joint communique with Beijing which further hurt the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COASTAL CUTTER CAPTURES 4 MAINLAND FISHING BOATS FOR POACHING

TEXT.P: A Kinmen Coastal Patrol cutter nabbed four mainland Chinese fishing boats and 15 crewmembers poaching in Republic of China territorial waters off the island of Kinmen on Thursday, according to a spokesman.

The ships and their crews were escorted to the port of Shinfu for interrogation and deported later in the day after it had been ascertained that the vessels were not conducting spying missions, the spokesman said, adding that one of the crewmen was found to be a former Beijing policeman.
Fishing gear, including 60 nets, were confiscated according to relevant laws.
The spokesman added that the coastal patrol had captured a total of 15 mainland fishing boats in territorial waters near Kinmen in the past two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WILLING TO BRIEF SUPRA-PARTY AD HOC GROUP

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is willing to brief the supra-party ad hoc group on cross-strait ties before the group's first meeting in September.
Tsai made the remark at a MAC party held for council workers whose birthdays fall in August, where she celebrated her own 44th birthday.

Tsai described current cross-strait relations as "basically stable," with only "one or two little stones occasionally falling in the pond," that she does not think will have an adverse effect on the development of cross-strait relations.
The supra-party ad hoc group on cross-strait relations was established by President Chen Shui-bian and is chaired by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.

However, the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party have refused to join the ad hoc group, claiming that the National Unification Council, which was established in 1990 under the Presidential Office, is the true stabilizing power for cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD MAKE EFFORTS ON COPYRIGHT PROTECTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Thursday with officials of a local association promoting international music recording exchanges and said Taiwan has to make more efforts on copyright protection.

Exchanging views on copyright protection, Chen said in reference to record piracy that he can sympathize with record companies because during the presidential election, the company manufacturing official "Ah Bian" paraphernalia suffered losses because of people selling pirated knock-offs.
He added that in a new economic era, outstanding competition can inspire creativity. Taiwan has to become a country which can protect copyright and also produce new intellectual properties.
Chen noted that the government, the public, education, and cultural policies all have to cooperate to reach this goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-CORRUPTION CAMPAIGN URGED TO BE KEPT LOW PROFILE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong on Thursday urged law enforcement authorities to keep a low profile when cracking down on financial crimes in order "to avoid unnecessary social turmoil."
The current campaign against irregularities in financial institutions caused the Taiwan Stock Exchange to drop to 7,543.96 points on Wednesday, the lowest level this year.

In a speech on financial reform organized by the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, Shea said his ministry backs the crackdown on business crimes 100 percent, but he urged the authorities not to publicize their actions in order to avoid financial fluctuations and public panic.

Meanwhile, Shea added that his ministry will push for the establishment of a private asset reconstruction company to handle bad loans and bad assets, and revealed that some local banks and foreign financial institutions have expressed high interest in the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SENEGAL TIES REMAIN STABLE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Senegal remain stable and friendly, ROC Ambassador Tou Choou-seng said here Wednesday.
Tou, who is currently on a vacation trip in Paris, was responding to a report that ROC-Senegal relations are in jeopardy.
"The report was false," Tou said, adding that relations between the two countries are still growing steadily.
Tou said Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade sent a message to ROC President Chen Shui-bian immediately after learning that a strong typhoon wreaked havoc in Taiwan last week.
In his message to President Chen, Tou said, Wade expressed his sympathy and concern about typhoon damage to Taiwan.

Speculation about ROC-Senegal relations arose after President Chen visited three of the ROC's African allies -- the Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad -- from Aug. 20-24. Chen's failure to make a visit to Senegal, which borders the Gambia, gave rise to the concern that relations between the two countries might be in trouble.

Tou, who met Chen in Chad, said the speculation is unfounded. "I already conveyed Wade's regards and invitation to President Chen during our meeting in Chad," the ambassador recalled. Chen held a breakfast meeting with all of the ROC ambassadors stationed in its eight African allies during his brief state visit to Chad.

Tou said Chen had canceled his originally planned visit to Senegal with the consent of Wade's administration. "Senegal was deleted from Chen's itinerary mainly because August is traditionally a summer vacation period in the West African country, and most government agencies would have been open for only half-days," Tou explained.

In addition to strong official ties, Tou said, civilian exchanges between the ROC and Senegal are also close. According to Tou, major ROC religious and charity groups, including the Buddhist Fokuangshan (Buddha Light) Association and the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association, have actively helped boost civilian cooperation between the two countries.
The Fokuangshan Association recently donated a batch of wheelchairs to handicapped Senegal people and the Tzu Chi Association has frequently donated medical equipment to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIPEI SUBWAY SECTIONS OPEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the steady progress of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit System project was "inexplicably exciting," as if he -- a former Taipei mayor -- were witnessing the birth of his own children.

Chen made the remarks as a special guest of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at an inaugural ceremony for the subway's Hsiao Nanmen Line and the Nankang Line's Hsinpu section, which boasts the nation's longest underground cross-river tunnel at 1.9 kilometers.

The Mucha Line -- the first section of the subway network to be constructed -- began operating in March 1996, while Chen was still Taipei mayor. Successive lines -- Tamsui, Chungho and Hsintien -- were completed in the following three years, opening in 1997, 1998, and 1999, respectively. Parts of the Nankang and Panchiao lines also went into service in December 1999.

In his speech, Ma thanked his predecessors for their efforts and said that after seeing the subway systems in many other countries, he feels Taiwan's can rank as one of the best in the world. He added that many European Council of Commerce and Trade representatives in Taipei have told him that it is "first class."

Ma also urged the central government to provide funding for the continued construction of the subway system, saying that a recent government subsidy of NT$10 billion (US$322 million) was well short of the originally promised NT$25 billion (US$805 million).

Chen responded to Ma's request by saying that the central government's budget will continue to worsen if local governments such as Taipei's do not shell out the required amount in national health insurance fees.

Earlier this week, Ma blamed the central government -- which has been bemoaning its own financial difficulties -- for increasing its own annual budget while cutting funding for his city. Taipei's recently approved annual budget for fiscal 2001 is 9 percent less than that of 2000, while the central government's budget -- pending legislative approval -- will go up by 6 percent.

Prior to the inauguration ceremony, a memorial stone was erected at the Panchiao Line's new Chiangtzu Tsui station to show respect for some 40 workers who were stricken with decompression sickness during construction of the system. They suffer from the condition -- which usually hits divers who ascend too quickly -- because of the depth of the subway lines and the improper use of pressure-equalizing air locks during construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MISSILES CANNOT SWAY TAIWAN PEOPLE: CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF

TEXT.P: The chief of the general staff of the Republic of China armed forces said on Thursday that mainland Chinese missiles cannot sway the will of the Taiwan people.
Tang Yao-ming said that so long as the Taiwan people consolidate their combat will, the island will be able to resist an M-missile attack by mainland China.
Tang made the remarks while meeting with reporters over a dinner at the Ministry of National Defense to mark Sept. 1 Journalists Day.

He noted that during the 1958 shelling of Kinmen, the tiny island withstood a mainland Chinese barrage of some 400,000 shells, and that compared with the 1958 shelling, the M-missiles of today have merely an increased range.

Mainland China has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan. A simulated war game mounted for President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday indicated that Taiwan is vulnerable to attack by mainland missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC DONATES NT$ 1.02 MILLION TO HELP REPAIR SCHOOL
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Cultural and Educational Foundation of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. on Thursday donated NT$1.02 million to help repair a local primary school damaged in the Sept. 21 earthquake.
Hsinchu County Magistrate Lin Kuang-hua received the donation from foundation Board Chairman Chen Kuo-tzu on behalf of the Taping primary school and thanked the foundation for its philanthropic deed.
The school was one of Hsinchu County's worst-hit schools in the devastating earthquake, suffering damage estimated at NT$7.22 million.

The Ministry of Education had provided NT$3.35 million and Hsinchu County Hall had appropriated NT$2.85 million, while the remaining NT$1.02 million needed to come from private organizations, whereupon the foundation stepped in with the required amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCERPTS OF PREMIER TANG'S PRESS CONFERENCE Q&A SESSION (I)

TEXT.P: Instead of confirming the need to reshuffle the Cabinet, Premier Tang Fei on Thursday gave his colleagues some indirect encouragement in response to questions at the end of his first press conference since taking office May 20.

He also defended the government's campaign against the so-called "black gold politics" which was blamed by critics as contributory fator to the stock market nose-dive and blasted as a plot to divert the public's attention from the Cabinet. Tang argued that the benefits of the campaign far overweigh the suffering which might be brought by the crackdown.
The fundamentals of the stock market are good and there is no reason for investors to withdraw in panic, he claimed.

He played down the urgency of considering a revamp of the controversial Guidelines for National Unification, the democratic basis of which was challenged by President Chen shui-bian on July 28. Tang said that now is not the appropriate time for a revision.
Following are excerpts of the question-and-answer session of Premier Tang Fei's press conference:

Q. Although you said in last week's Cabinet meeting that there was no plan to shake up the Cabinet, President Chen Shui-bian said later in his Aug. 28 press conference that he would not rule out the possibility of replacing Cabinet members "who are incompetent, do not cooperate with the leaders, or are unable to do their jobs well."

Is Chen's warning a hint that a Cabinet reshuffle is in the pipeline? Is there any Cabinet member who falls into any of the three categories and should be dismissed? Since the three-month test period you set for your Cabinet has expired, do you think it is time to reorganize the Cabinet now or pending the Legislature's forthcoming general interpellation session? If you have no intention of reorganizing the Cabinet now, when will you weigh the possibility?

A: I said I would review my agenda rather than the performance of my Cabinet after three months into my office, because three months is too short to judge a government's work. All of you can examine whether my administration's agenda as I mentioned above are tasks needed to be done urgently right now.

The question of whether the Cabinet should be reshuffled depends on the Cabinet members' capability, performance and their ability to look forward. Three months after the Cabinet was in place, we do not see any need to take action. Certainly we would use President Chen's three-point instruction as a measure to gauge the performance of every Cabinet member, and ask them to do their jobs well.

Q: Although you say that three months is too short to measure Cabinet members' performance, you do admit that there is still room for improvement in the government's policy-making process and inter-agency contacts. Why do you think this ruling team which did not command a high approval rating in polls will improve its performance in the next three or six months?

A: I would like to give my Cabinet fair judgment. We were sworn in on May 20 and showed up at the Legislative Yuan for interpellation by various committees. They then braced for the general interpellation at the Legislative Yuan in July, and turned to policy-setting only after August. It is unfair to pass judgment on their performance simply by their deeds in a single month. If there is any liability for retaining the Cabinet, let it fall on me.

Q: The local stock market started its downward spiral almost from the very beginning of the new Cabinet's operations, which reflects the public's lack of confidence in the government. Now the government is stepping up its crackdown on so-called "black gold politics." Is this just a plot to divert public attention from the government's inefficiency?

A: I would like to ask the general public if the "black gold politics" should be eradicated, or if the crusade should be shelved. First, in the respect of getting rid of irregularities in the financial sector, if we do not stamp out irregularities and get our house in order now, when should we start? Illegal loans and irregular lending are, at best, exceptions rather than rules. Should we endure the short-term suffering by clearing the scandals or be dogged by the ailments for a long time? The campaign against "black gold" is aimed at pursuing the country's long-term stability.

Second, there is a continuity in the government's work. Our new ruling team has to carry on the work started by our predecessors while setting a direction for ourselves. Personally, I think my Cabinet is working overtime. I wish the general public, as well as the mass media, would examine our policy to see if we are on the right path. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCERPTS OF PREMIER TANG'S PRESS CONFERENCE Q&A SESSION (II)

TEXT.P: Q: You indicated a few days ago that the national pension system cannot be implemented next January. Can you tell us why? Is it because the two proposals planned by the administration are imperfect?

A: The national pension program has been planned for ten years and more active planning has been carried out in the past four years. However, since there were many different opinions during discussions, we have decided that further discussions on the two proposals by representatives and various political parties are needed.
We hope the final results will be accepted by the majority of the public.
Q: The performance of the Taiwan Stock Exchange at present seems no better than under the old administration. What can be done to promote the stock market?

A: Our economy is basically healthy and sound, and the problem we face today is the so-called "confidence" issue. Nevertheless, we do have a few traditional industries that are encountering crisis, and the crackdown on crime has also affected some industries. In general, though, they are all in the same psychological phase.
We have no reason to be pessimistic about our stock market.
Q: Can you list some policies in the fiscal year 2001 budget that reflect your personal character?

A: We hope that in the coming year we can increase revenue through tax reforms, open more sources of income and cut down expenses, and boost other governmental income in order to have more budget to promote what we intend to do.

Q: There have now been 12 premiers since the government moved to Taiwan. Among them, who do you prefer? How do you hope your Cabinet will be remembered? Would you consider running for vice president or even president after accomplishing your mission as premier?
A: Each of the 11 premiers who preceded me made outstanding contributions to the nation.

Maybe people misunderstand that I do not have political ambition and wishes for the future, because after all, I am not a political scientist and my age is already not suitable for me to pursue further political positions. However, when I accepted the invitation of the president to be premier, I hoped that my role would help the government first to stabilize and then to seek development.

President Chen also expressed his hope that I can make some administrative reforms during my premiership, just as the reform projects I carried out in the Ministry of National Defense while I was defense minister.

I am fortunate in that I have outstanding Cabinet members and I believe we can promote various reform projects, including financial, economic and political reforms. I also believe that after three months, it is now time for us to enter a better situation, so we should spare no efforts to promote these projects.
I also expect criticism and advice from the public and I will do my best to promote the projects.

Q: You once said that because you do not have to face election, your words will be honest. However, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be facing legislative, county, and mayoral elections next year. How will you achieve a balance between the DPP's campaign pressure and carrying out your own administrative goals? And how will you strike such a balance, seeing that your Cabinet and the Legislative Yuan have had many differences of opinion over the past three months?

A: Our nation has been around for five thousand years. What enables us to hold a nation together for so long is because our political ideology is about "walking the middle path." A lot of young people nowadays are not very willing to ask what the "golden mean" is. Actually, it is about making compromises. Democratic politics is in reality a system of finding happy mediums where we abide by the majority's opinion while respecting that of the minority. Speaking the truth is necessary, but sometimes it brings negative effects. So sometimes truth and lies need to find a happy medium. Therefore, democracy is about negotiations and compromises.

Q: Do you think President Chen Shui-bian should take over the chairmanship of the National Unification Council (NUC)? If he does not take the chairmanship, what effect will it have on cross-strait relations?

A: First of all, the NUC is an advisory body and not a government agency that answers to the Cabinet. Therefore, it is inappropriate for the Cabinet to make any criticism of the NUC. Under the circumstances, it is not an urgent necessity for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council to discuss the issue of the NUC or the National Unification Guidelines. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCERPTS OF PREMIER TANG'S PRESS CONFERENCE Q&A SESSION (III)

TEXT.P: Q: From public opinion polls, we can see that the people are not very satisfied with your administrative work of the past three months. Do you think your work will be able to benefit the DPP's legislative elections next year?

A: If we pursue short-term benefits, it may act as a kind of obstacle to long-term development. I have already mentioned that if corruption in our banking institutions is not wiped out, it will shake the nation to its foundation. The legal action being taken today will help resolve the problems in the financial sector. If we are afraid of this short-term pain and do nothing, then it will really lead us into a financial storm.

Q: Can you interpret for us why your public opinion rating has always been higher than that of the entire Cabinet, and even higher than that of the president. Also, under the president-premier system, who do you think should take more responsibility for the government's current performance?

A: I am very grateful for the public's support, but if I am overjoyed by it, it may have a negative effect on me and my work. What I am concerned about is the public's appraisal of my Cabinet. Three months have passed, but we have really only had one month to do our job. If our Cabinet is judged based on a single month's performance, I must defend it against this unfairness.

Q: The stock market hit bottom yesterday, and we have seen the government trying to save the industries but failing to save investor confidence. Does the government have any policies to help meet the urgent needs? What will it save first?

A: I hope no one will believe the rumor that our economy is facing a crisis. The economy is fundamentally sound. Foreign financial experts have said that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are sound. Listed companies have registered gains, banks have registered gains in net rates of return. In 1999, it was 5.9 percent. In the first half of 2000, it was 8.9 percent. Our export orders for the first half of this year reached US$73 billion, an increase of 20.9 percent from the same period of last year. Exports and imports for January to June reached US$70.7 billion. June was US$12.4 billion, while June of last year was US$9.9 billion.

Q: Do you think touching on the question of whether the National Unification Guidelines need to be amended or whether President Chen should chair the National Unification Council will cause another conflict between Taipei and Beijing?

A: Both sides of the Taiwan Strait should return to dialogue within the existing mechanism as soon as possible. The key in the president's speeches and the government's statements since May 20 is that we ask for equal status. We hope to resume the negotiation mechanism soon, but the ball is in mainland China's court. And I have already mentioned that there is no urgency in discussing the issue of the National Unification Council or the National Unification Guidelines.
Q: How will you garner support from the Legislative Yuan for the central government's budget for next year, knowing that some ruling party legislators are not satisfied with the budget?

A: Because the budget is limited by the amount of income, it cannot reflect the actual amount that the Cabinet needs to carry out its policies, and we are not willing to raise taxes too much or raise the ceiling on government debt. Therefore, under the circumstances, we hope to explain to each party the content of the budget and limit unnecessary misunderstandings after getting their opinions. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCERPTS OF PREMIER TANG'S PRESS CONFERENCE Q&A SESSION (IV)

TEXT.P: Q. The Executive Yuan has established a task force on economic and financial issues, with the premier serving as convener. Can you tell us the purpose of establishing the task force and the best time for convening a meeting of the task force?
A. The task force is a consultative mechanism designed to coordinate the views of various agencies of the Executive Yuan on economic and financial issues and to work out a farsighted plan and review.

Most ministers without portfolio in the new government have never worked in administrative institutions before, and it is not easy for them to play the role of coordinating the various agencies. Therefore, I came out to head the task force in order to improve efficiency.

To cultivate a man to become an expert in both the economic and financial fields is not easy, and who can assure that a policy solely made by one convener is without mistakes? The task force is in fact a mechanism of collective study.
Q. Let me return to the issue of the stock market. Does the new government consider it necessary to take action to protect the stock market, and what is the base-line for government intervention?

A. Sorry, I cannot answer such a question, as it might mislead the stock market. In fact, as I have just mentioned, the four government-operated funds enter the market every day with their own operations.

The four funds will make a comparatively concerted policy intervention only when the stock market is affected by non-economic factors. We have set no base-line for intervention, and we will intervene only when necessary. (MORE) EXCERPTS OF PREMIER TANG'S PRESS CONFERENCE Q&A SESSION (IV)
Q. Are you considering a Cabinet reshuffle at an appropriate time, as the ruling party will face an important election next year?
A. There will be no time factor for a Cabinet reshuffle. It can take place whenever a policy or implementation error is committed by a government agency.
We will not say that a reshuffle will not take place before a fixed date, but there is also no need to talk about the reshuffle issue everyday, as every one is working hard.

Regarding next year's election, it will benefit the ruling party if the government's administrative measures are affirmed and supported by the public. Otherwise, the ruling party will be hurt. As a result, the Cabinet's goal from the beginning is to strive for the best.
However, I think that the basic principle is to place top priority on the country's best interests.
Q. What is your expectation on the development of cross-strait relations?

A. I stated during the Legislative Yuan's general interpellation in July, my hope is to break the stalemate in the cross-strait dialogue. The cause of the stalemate is the difference over the "one China" issue. So long as both sides can return to a parity status, we can resume bilateral negotiation at an early date.

Regarding the three cross-strait direct links -- trade, postal and transport -- we hope to overcome some obstacles in the near future so that the institutionalized dialogue can be resumed to resolve cross-strait problems.
Q. What is your influence on the new government's policies on the issues concerning national unification, Taiwan independence and cross-strait relations?

A. The people of Taiwan have various opinions over whether to pursue unification, independence or maintain the status quo. That is why we want to hold round-table and inter-party conferences to coordinate their opinions. If we 22 million people cannot reach a consensus, the government will have no foundation upon which to negotiate with the mainland.

As diplomatic, national defense and cross-strait affairs are the responsibility of the president, I rarely raise these matters on my own initiative, but during July's 12-day general interpellation, I made many explanations on these issues. You can check the legislative record to understand my basic stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 GOLFERS SHARE 1ST ROUND LEAD OF MERCURIES TAIWAN MASTERS

TEXT.P: Indian golfer Arjun Atwal shot a four under part 68 Thursday to take the first round lead along with Andrew Pitts of the United States and Felix Casas of the Philippines at the 14th Mercuries Taiwan Masters Golf Tournament.
Tying for fourth place were Lin Keng-chi of Taiwan and Robert Hustable of the United States, each of whom carded a three under par 69.
A total of 82 golfers from 16 countries and regions around the world are taking part in the four-day, US$300,000 competition at the Taiwan Golf and Country Club in the Taipei suburb of Tamshui.
The winner will receive US$50,000 in prize money.
The tourney, which will end Sunday, is one of three majors to be held in Taiwan and is part of the Davidoff tour, Asian circuit.

DOC.HEADLINE: IIA HOLDS FIRST TAIWAN CHAPTER MEETING

TEXT.P: Internet and Information Asia (IIA), which seeks to combine Asian information and the Internet, held an exposition seminar Thursday to explain how IIA can provide members with the opportunity to share their experiences and seek resources.

IIA Manager Hanson Cheah said that although IIA's Taiwan chapter was established in February, it already has more than 1,000 members. This is the first time the organization has held a meeting in Taiwan.

He added that Taiwan has become the center of Asia's Internet industry, but said there is still ample room for further development and that IIA wants to promote the exchange of views among related industries.

In the third and fourth quarters of this year, the Taiwan chapter's sponsors will include: Chinatrust Commercial Bank; iAsia Works internet Co.; Digital Island; Merrill Lynch; Pierce, Fenner and Smith Inc.; Squire, Sanders and Dempsey Legal Counsel Worldwide; and HelloAsia.com.
Cheah added that each of the 14 chapters has its own sponsors and that if any chapter loses its sponsors, it will be forced to close.
IIA, which has its headquarters in Hong Kong, was established by Boom.com's founder Jonathan Hakim, IncubASIA's Jonathan Cheng, iAsia Works's Chris Giacomelli, and renren.com's Richard Robinson.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TRY OBTAINING EARLY WARNING SYSTEM: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said Thursday that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attacks.

At an annual press conference to commemorate Journalists Day, Wu said that Tuesday's Hankuang No. 16 exercises simulated a mainland Chinese attack on Taiwan using its Dongfeng 15 guided missiles, with results showing that Taiwan's Patriot Modified Air Defense System (MADS) would have a low interception rate.

Wu explained that no anti-missile system in the world can claim to have a 100 percent missile interception rate. Even the United States -- which has been developing such systems for decades -- have not had favorable test results, he added.

Wu went on to say that Taiwan's three Patriot batteries are equipped with a newer system than the one used by the US Army in the Persian Gulf War against Iraq's Scud missiles. However, he added that while the Patriot MADS is an anti-ballistic missile system, the Scud -- against which the Patriot only had limited success -- is not a ballistic missile.

Explaining further as to why the annual Hankuang exercises showed only limited anti-missile capability, Wu said that the three batteries are deployed around the periphery of Taiwan's major political and economic center -- Taipei. However, he went on, the simulated attacks focused on other regions unprotected by the anti-missile umbrella.

As a result of the heavy casualties and damage a mainland missile attack would cause if heavily populated western Taiwan were to be struck, Wu said that the military is still hopeful it can acquire an early warning radar system to allow for quicker reaction time when making defensive preparations.

Other than using an anti-missile system to counter mainland attacks, Wu said that immediate dispersion and evacuation would also be able to limit damage. He further said that if a missile were to strike Taiwan, panic might ensue, even if the material destructiveness was limited. Therefore, he added, the people's will to resist would also be a key factor against missile attacks.
